data.name: Databases

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
We live in a world full of data. Almost every human activity nowadays produces data or needs access to data. As such, there is a need for effective and efficient solutions that will allow us to store, maintain, search and retrieve large volumes of data. This is what the data management systems do. The goal of this course is to teach the students the fundamental concepts of data  management, to train them in order to be able to design of good databases, give them the ability to build complex queries, and allow them to identify and solve performance problems in real life situations. 
Naturally the course focuses on relational databases since the relational model is the one that drives most of the existing data management systems in the industry nowadays, it has been around for more than 30 years and has been one of the most studied model, and has been the one with the most commercial tools in operation.

data.name: Analisi matematica 1

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description: Taking into account the observation that "in mathematics you don't understand things, you just get used to them", aim of the course is to make familiar to the students the basic topics of mathematical analysis (functions, limits, derivatives, integrals, series, series of functions, differential equations). At the end of the course the students will be essentially able to orient themselves among the mathematical concepts listed above, and to understand how they can be useful for giving a rigorous form to more specific scientific arguments; they will be also able to solve exercises related to the topics of the course.

data.name: Econometrics
data.degreeProgram: Behavioural and Applied Economics - Economia Comportamentale e Applicata (LM)

data.name: Agiografia II
data.description:
The course aims to offer students an adequate preparation in the field of hagiographic literature, with particular attention to the interpretation of texts.

At the end of the course, students should know the topics covered during the course and be able to interpret the proposed texts.

data.name: Signal, Image and Video

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description: The course provides the basic competences in the field of digital signal processing, with special attention to images and video sequences. Starting from the fundamentals of 1D signal analysis and processing, analog and numerical, in time and frequency domains, we then extend the concepts to the multi-dimensional case of signals in space. Then, we introduce the more important approaches for image filtering and extraction of image descriptors. These concepts are further extended to deal with motion pictures. Finally, the problem of image compression is introduced, focusing on most known techniques for image and video coding, as well as their standard implementations. The approach of the course is rather practical, with the explanation of theoretical concept followed by their translation into algorithmic terms.

data.name: Immagini di futuro

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
The program is aimed at a) introducing to future studies approaches and Futures Literacy; b) guiding in analysis of documents and reports from future studies literature and specifically multisciplinary studies; c) developing the use of conceptual maps to systematize and organize concepts and use of future wheels for developing scenarios.

Each class is supported with learning materials (readings, notes) and recap exercises available on moodle e-learning platforrm.

According to the course calendar of the Master in Social Anticipation, the lecturs are held in presence and online (zoom and recorded on the e-platform moodle).

Knowledge of the textual and ecdotical tradition of Phaedrus' fables

data.name: Technology Strategy
data.description: The course will supply the students with the tools needed to understand core competencies and learning processes in different organizations. These tools will enable the students to manage product development processes, services development processes and product-service systems. Moreover, the course will propose a critical view of the innovation processes.

data.name: Advanced computing architectures

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: The objective of this course is to provide the students the required concepts for the understanding, the design and the evaluation of advanced processing architectures, with emphasis on the various forms of parallelism. At the end of the course, the student will be able to comprehend the organization of recent central processing units, and to design customized architectures, analyzing and evaluating the effects of architectural choices, identifying the critical components, and comparing different solutions in terms of performance and cost, to select the optimal ones in various domains of application. The student will in particular acquire the skills to program applications for GPUs using CUDA.

data.name: Visual brain and design

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description:
The objective of the course is to provide the basis for understanding the neural mechanisms underlying visual perception and visual attention so as to optimize visual design strategies from a neural perspective.

Initially, the study of several cognitive neuroscience paradigms will allow students to understand the general neural principles of visual and attentional systems, and to identify the neural processes most relevant to visual design. Next, the students will be directly involved in the perceptual assessment of webpages and mobile apps on the basis of learned neural principles.

At the end of the course, the students will know the general neurophysiological mechanisms underlying visual perception and attention, and will be able to analyze the implementation of visual interfaces on the basis of their efficacy in optimizing visual, attentional and cognitive processes from a neural perspective.

data.name: Partial differential equations
data.description:
Aim of the course is that of presenting the most relevant types of partial differential equations (elliptic, parabolic, hyperbolic: especially in the linear case), together with the physical models that they describe. Specifically, the functional framework is introduced and it is shown to be suitable for clarifying under which conditions the problems associated with these differential equations are well-posed (existence, uniqueness, stability); [Only for 9-credit course: the students are then introduced to elliptic regularity and maximum principles.]

At the end of the course the student will be able to get oriented among the various types of partial differential equations, to know which are the characteristic qualitative properties of the solutions, to have a deeper knowledge of the mathematical approach to these problems as well as some fluency in the use of modern techniques for the study of these themes.

data.name: Utilizzo di nudging nelle scienze del comportamento

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description: The course aims to provide some theoretical and practical knowledge of decision psychology: starting from a general theoretical framework, it will focus on the main nudging techniques used for behavior modification aimed at obtaining individual and collective benefits. By the end of the course, students will have acquired a general knowledge of some important topics in the behavioural sciences (such as prospect theory, heuristics, cognitive biases) and a specific knowledge, both theoretical and practical, of constructing nudging interventions in different contexts.

data.name: Biodiritto
data.description: The course aims at giving a comprehensive understanding of the logics of bioethics and biolaw in a number of Countries. At the end of the course, the student will be apple to: - Identify the (always changing) object of the life sciences (bio-objects); - to navigate within the complex system of sources of the biolaw; - to recognize, construct and critically evaluate normative models in the different fields treated - define the principles and rules governing areas such as beginning of life, end of life, scientific research.

data.name: Elettrotecnica

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description: The course aims at teaching the the fundamentals of Electrical Engineering and the most important electric applications. Electric circuits both in stationary and sinusoidal state and the developments of the three-phase network are studied. Operating principles of electric machines and electric power systems are treated. At the end of the course, the student will be able to understand the main electric machines: transformers, generators, motors, power lines, overcurrent protection and electrical safety.

data.name: Logic networks

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The course aims at providing students with the fundamental notions of digital circuits, with particular reference to the understanding, analysis and design of logic networks. At the end of the course, the student will be able to understand the functioning of digital circuits making use of logic gates and state machines, and to design complex digital processing systems by analyzing and evaluating the effect of design choices.

The student will learn to approach projects through the application specification and manage project complexity thanks to the use of synchronous sequential models, the analysis through diagrams, and the simulation and implementation with the VHDL language. The student will learn to identify the critical components, and partition them in simple block in order to analyze complex systems. Exercises on design problems and laboratory experiences will allow the student to apply theoretical concepts in practice, and to become familiar with real components and development systems.

data.name: Misurazione e rendicontazione sociale
data.description:
1. Teaching objectives and contents.

The purpose of the course is to acquire knowledge and skills related to the management of corporate social responsibility and non-financial measurement systems (mission report, social and environmental report, integrated report, social impact measurement) in private profit and non-profit organizations.

In today's economic contexts where the boundaries between profit and non-profit worlds are becoming less and less marked, and in which corporate social responsibility in the management of the corporate resources is becoming a major competitive element for companies, this course aims to overcome traditional approaches and develop an understanding of the issues related to corporate social responsibility and its social and environmental reporting. The course will enable you to explore the most innovative concepts of corporate social responsibility, shared value, accountability, social and environmental accounting and reporting (SEAR), social impact measurement, and integrated reporting in an international perspective.

 

2. Expected results.

At the end of the course, the student will be able to:

1. recognize different ethical approaches to Corporate Social Responsibility and become more aware of the role of the company in the market;

2. Interpreting stakeholder theory in managerial view and implementing stakeholder engagement systems taking into account elements of stakeholder salience;

3. Define the concept of accountability and distinguish the application of this notion in different business contexts;

4. Analyze and structure of social and environmental accounting and reporting (SEAR) systems;

5. identify, evaluate and develop integrated reporting systems that are capable of combining not only economic-financial but also non-financial dimensions (such as social and environmental);

6. Identify various social impact measurement systems, describe their limits and potentialities and develop metrics and impact indicators consistent with the business context object of analysis;

7. Express an improved ability to work in groups and critically present/discuss issues related to social responsibility.

data.name: Economic Policy in Global Market
data.description: The course aims at analyzing policy issues in a context of open economy. At the end of the course, students are supposed to understand causes, effects and implications of some of the events currently occurring in the global economy.

data.name: The Legal Framework of EU Policies
data.description:
The course aims at providing students with the theoretical knowledge and the analytical skills required in order to use and apply the law related to EU policies. This outcome will be attained by working with different kinds of legal materials, such as textbooks and articles, legislative texts (primary and secondary EU law), case law, official documents, soft law instruments and other relevant materials.

On successful completion of the course, students will be able to search for the relevant legal rules applicable to issues related to EU policies, analyse their content, highlight their main features and critical elements, and devise solutions to legal questions. This implies being able to search for legal information in all relevant sources, analysing and processing it, applying legal and critical arguments, and present results both orally and in writing.

Adopting a student-centred approach, the course will provide opportunities for students’ engagement, with a view to successfully achieving its learning objectives. The course will be structured to ensure meaningful and accessible learning for all students, and the assessment will be consistent with the teaching method. The course will adopt diversified teaching methods to ensure that every student is able to follow the instructor, participate in debates, and test her/his own understanding during the course.

The course will be organized on a schedule with two classes a week. The detailed syllabus, the class diary, the learning materials, and the instructions for the assessment, as well as news and communications, will be made available on Moodle, the open source system for the management of online courses, fully integrated with the university authentication systems.

data.name: Introduction to Computer and Network Security

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: This is an introductory course to the increasingly important area of computer and network security. The main goal is to enable students to (i) understand the theoretical and practical problems of information security, (ii) understand and recognize threats to fundamental security properties: confidentiality, integrity, and availability, and (iii) understand how the main security mechanisms - such as cryptography, authentication and authorization protocols, and access control - can be applied to mitigate vulnerabilities.

data.name: Dispacciamento dell’energia

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
The course consists of 60 hr of frontal lectures and develops mainly the subjects of the operation and regulation of the national grid high voltage.
After outlining the international framework of regulatory boards (CEN, CENELEC, ETSI, IEC, UCTE, etc ...), it introduces the equations of three-phase lines with the propagation constant and the characteristic impedance.
It will explain then technological innovation on electric transmission and distribution, as well as the control system in real time.
It will be explained the mechanisms to control voltage and frequency according to the request of reactive and active power.
It will also expose the criteria for the protection of the transmission lines and moreover the problem of power quality and the characteristics of the free market.

data.name: Diritto pubblico
Ecoidraulica

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
At a time in which humans have significantly affected the natural environment and yet society increasingly values the many services of natural ecosystems, accounting for ecological processes in engineering design is a major contemporary challenge for environmental engineers. This is the fundamental topic in Ecohydraulics, the discipline that focuses on the consequences of fluid and sediment processes on the organisms that inhabit aquatic environments. While still a young science, Ecohydraulics already endows the engineer with an overall understanding and quantitative tools to predict how physical processes shape habitat quality and quantity, and how, in turn, they are affected by ecological dynamics. This enables the integrated analysis of different management options for natural and man-made water bodies in terms of their ecosystem consequences. At the broadest scale, this class will contribute to the students' appreciation of the tight link between the natural and the built or impacted environment, and of the importance of considering both (and “how-to”) for harmonizing environmental quality with human river uses in river management and restoration.

At the end of the course the student will be able to: i) identify the different fluvial forms and their evolutionary trajectories; ii) use the hydro-morphological quality indexes and assess the status of alteration of river ecosystems; iii) understand the relations between hydro-morphology and biotic component, the causes of alteration of river ecosystems and tools to design ecological flow regimes in altered rivers; iv) appreciate the relevance of the integration of complementary disciplines for the sustainable management of water bodies.

data.name: Interdisciplinary laboratory: Advanced metals
data.description:
After the course, the students will be able

  • To apply the scientific method: to critically analyze the scientific/technical problem proposed and to find a suitable solution;
  • To analyze the state of the art;
  • To produce metallic parts prototypes by manufacturing processes (e.g. additive manufacturing…) and to modify their properties by means of heat treatment and surface engineering;
  • To design parts/new materials and to model different properties using specific software (thermodynamic modeling, thermo-mechanical simulation, Life Cycle Analysys, materials and process selection…)
  • To select and use suitable analytical techniques (metallography, optical- and scanning electron microscopy, thermal analysis, dilatometry,…): set up the experiment, collect/present/analyze/discuss experimental results; calculate confidence levels, compare and correlate different data.
  • To discuss the test results and to answer questions made by an external audience.
  • To use proper oral and/or written scientific communication for results dissemination.
  • To improve “team working” capability.

data.name: Clinica dei disturbi cognitivi e comportamentali nelle malattie degenerative cerebrali

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description:
The aim of the "Clinic of cognitive and behavioral disorders in neurodegenerative diseases" course is to provide students with a knowledge of cognitive and behavioral processes in pathological aging.  Through lessons, study, individual research and group work, the course will enable students to:
• Know and understand the salient aspects of the aging process from a psychological point of view (cognition, affectivity etc.).
• Relate the acquired knowledge, in order to recognize the various  pathologies that can determine a modification of the cognitive and emotional-behavioral profile (pathological aging).
• Apply what has been learned to practical areas of management of the various pathologies in the field of diagnostic support (clinical and neuropsychological evaluation) and management of problems of the person with dementia and caregivers / family members (psychoeducation – emotional support).
• Collect and interpret clinical data (cognitive and behavioral) useful to promote aid initiatives in the management of elderly subjects with or without pathologies.
• Acquire knowledge by consulting critically assessed scientific texts and articles.

A part of the course is dedicated to the description of brain pathologies underlying the possible forms of deterioration with the presentation of exemplary clinical cases.

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
The course provides an in-depth analysis of atmospheric processes relevant for various environmental engineering applications. Large space is dedicated to the modelling tools for weather forecasting, air pollution simulations and the assessment of renewable energy availability. 

At the end of the course the student should:

  • know the basics of atmospheric processes relevant for different environmental engineering applications, such as pollutant dispersion and the assessment of renewable energy resource availability
  • know the basics of meteorological and atmospheric dispersion models
  • know methodologies of data analysis and models to evaluate solar and wind energy availability
  • be able to interpret the output of meteorological models and realize simple weather forecasts

In particular, the methodologies currently utilized for the design of solar thermal systems and solar cooling, photovoltaic systems, heat pumps with particular regard to geothermal plants and the technologies used for the thermal exploitation of biomass will be proposed and investigated. data.name: Diritto comparato delle religioni
data.description:
Learning objectives and expected achievements 

The increasing religious and cultural differentiation going on in many European countries has brought about a renewed interest of the social sciences in the religious factor. Every religion makes law, that is, creates rules guiding its members, whose impact often goes beyond the merely ritual sphere, and which have effect also on public and social behavior as regards family, the workplace, education, social-economic life (prayers, feast days, school, food, slaughter, clothing and burials). 
The knowledge of religious rules has a fundamental importance in order to understand the new Italian and European reality, which is more and more multireligious. Whereas each of these realities has been studied by scholars, the comparison among the various religious laws has been developed recently. Comparative law of religions links the study of the different religious laws, in order to identify analogies and differences. 
The study of comparative law of religions is fundamental: a persons or a communitys religion creates problems of intersection and interference with the civil community, and each of these problems has originated heated controversies that have prompted the approval of laws and the enactment of judgments. As noted by Ferrari (2019), today religion has assumed a far more important legal relevance than in the past, and students dealing with law cannot allow themselves to ignore the rules regulating the behavior of the members of a religion, at the risk of a cultural and professional impoverishment. 
The comparative method will allow students in the first place to know better each of the religious laws dealt with in the course, to understand and appreciate the links existing among them and, lastly, to answer the questions addressed by the different religious communities existing and co-existing in a country. Only in this way will students be able to develop the necessary ability to find a balance between the claims of the various religious groups present on the same territory, on the one side, and the smallest common denominator of values shared by citizens at large, on the other one, in a difficult operation of accommodation. 

At the end of the course, students will be able: 

-to understand the normative content of Christian, Islamic, Jewish, Buddhist, and Hindu religions, and to distinguish the rules proper of religion, and those proper of tradition and/or culture,
-to examine, also in comparative perspective, different institutes as regards in particular family law (marriage and successions),
-to know the normative sources of the different religious laws,
-to be able to order the social living together, that is, to elaborate, at least theoretically, instruments and strategies allowing to live within the contemporary religious and cultural diversity, limiting as far as possible tensions and conflicts,
-to use the appropriate terminology.

data.name: Letteratura italiana II
Cognitive neuroscience of infant development
data.description:
This module provides students with an advanced an in depth view of ongoing research in the filed of infant cognition. The module takes the format of a journal club, where students will read and present research papers on cognitive development. The module convenor will facilitate the discussion, creating a learning friendly atmosphere of open debate, where all participants are encouraged to engage in the discussion, expressing their opinion about open problems in cognitive development, making critical comments and asking clarification questions.

We will discuss empirical studies, contemporary theories and research techniques, including neuroscience methods, in the filed of cognitive development of human infants (below 2 years of age). Special attention will be dedicated to social cognitive development.

data.description: This course unit aims at providing students with a general overview of the basic mechanisms and most prominent theories of learning and memory, as well as of their relationships with attentive and executive control processes. At the end of the course, students are expected to have achieved a good knowledge of such mechanisms and of the experimental paradigms used to investigate them. They should also be able to link theory, empirical research and practice and discuss properly results of the scientific studies described during the course lessons.

data.name: Neuroscienze affettive e cliniche

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description:
The course is designed to provide students advanced knowledge of the main topics of affective neuroscience. The aim is to acquire knowledge of the study of the brain basis of emotions, emphasizing the theoretical models and the investigation methods used, and some exercises on data analyses. Additionally, students will learn the brain bases of psychopathological disorders and psychotherapy. Students will learn how to design an Affective Neuroscience experiment and to use machine learning algorithms to predict psychological variables and classify patients based on brain differences.
At the end of the course, students will be able to understand the relevant literature, design experiments to study emotions, and apply principles and methods of Affective Neuroscience in their work. At the end of the course students will be able to develop their opinions and discuss emotion relevant topics. It is responsibility of students to be able to participate actively in the lessons, take notes during the lessons, read the material indicated by the teacher before the lessons, elaborate the films.  Students are required to study the texts in the bibliography, to reflect on the links between the previous disciplinary knowledge and the contents of the course.

data.description:

The classes consist of theoretical/application lessons aimed at the presentation of the state of the art of the subject and the in-depth study of innovative diagnostic techniques as well as their use in different application contexts through the use of ELEDIA software tools. Psicologia dinamica

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description:
The course aims to promote the acquisition of basic knowledge about the conceptual and methodological frameworks of psychodynamic theories, with specific emphasis on clinical and developmental implications, in light of the original Freudian theory and of some of the most influential subsequent theoretical approaches, such as the Attachment Theory.


At the end of this course, students are expected to:


  • understand the principle psychodynamic theories and identify continuity and discontinuity among different authors.
  • apply theoretical knowledge to practical scenarios (e.g. a clinical interview or a projective test in order to identify defense mechanisms ; analyzing an interaction between caregiver and child with the Emotional Availability Scales) using some of the methods that characterize psychodynamics.
  • connect psychodynamic constructs to different contemporary theoretical paradigms of human mind understanding.
  • work more proficiently in a group, autonomously deepen their knowledge on a chosen topic, and communicate in a clear and proficient way with colleagues and teachers (through the active group learning activities described in the method section).

data.name: Quality and innovation engineering
data.description:
This course covers the scientific and engineering basics of (i) quality management, (ii) innovation management. Specifically, the course main topics are: quality management paradigms, ISO 9000 series of standards, quality awards, process management, basics of risk management, statistical inference, relaibility, innovation management. After completing the course, the student will be able to:

- understand, summarize and compare the main quality management paradigms;

- understand and summarize the ISO 9000 series of standards and the quality awards;

- understand, summarize and analyse the fundamentals of risk management;

- understand, summarize and analyse the fundamentals of process management;

- understand and summarize the fundamentals of statistical inference;

- understand and summarize the fundamentals of innovation management;

- understand and summarize the impact of innovation on sustainability.

data.name: Gene Therapy

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description:
The aim of the course is to provide fundamental notions on gene transfer and gene modifications techniques used in gene therapy pre-clinical and clinical trials. Particular attention is devoted to the development of viral vectors and genome editing approaches.
Through lab lectures students will be able to follow experimental passages required for viral vectors production and their delivery into target cells

Course objectives:
To provide an understanding of how gene delivery tools are developed, and which are used depending on the clinical applications.

Learning outcomes
At the end of the course students will have a solid grasp on following subjects:
-gene delivery either based on physical, chemical or viral methods.
-in vivo or ex-vivo gene delivery approaches
-development of viral vectors starting from replicating viruses
-techniques for genome editing
-real world applications of gene therapy in the clinic

data.name: Idrologia

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
This Hydrology class aims to explain the physics (meaning the mathematical equations and their phenomenology) and, in some cases, their statistics (i.e. the distribution) of the basic hydrological processes (precipitation, runoff, infiltration, evaporation and transpiration)

Students will be required to: being able to derive and comment the hydrological equations above mentioned and to do some statistics on hydrological data. Particular attention will be dedicated to the derivation of the statistics of extreme rainfall.

They will learn how to delineate a catchment for digital elevation models through some appropriate tools. Besides students will be requested to get some basics of the tools that will be used to estimate the hydrological fluxes (using a GIS, Python, and other tools, among those in GEOframe:  https://abouthydrology.blogspot.com/2015/03/jgrass-newage-essentials.html).
They will be required to be able, by means of some models provided by the instructors the main hydrological fluxes and represent them at catchment scale.

This is intended to serve as a basis for getting further knowledge and

• prevent, manage, control floods, landslides and snow-avalanches
• manage irrigation
• estimate water availability for hydropower production
• forecast roads freezing
• estimate soil, roads, or snow temperature
• forecast snow water equivalent and snow height

Assuming that the student will tak a master in Environmental Engineering at Trento University, Acquedotti e fognature, Modelli idrologici, Ingegneria fluviale, are classe that request the knowledge communicate in this Hydrology class.

data.name: Thesis seminar

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
The thesis seminar is mandatory for students of the Laurea Magistrale “Sociology and Social Research” and access is limited to them. Its aim is to (1) provide feedback on relevant choices during the second year of the programme as choices should be made coherently with the desired occupational outcome of students; (2) to guide students through the process of thesis writing. To this end, students will be presenting their thesis research, which, on the one hand, will provide feedback to single students during the process of thesis preparation. On the other hand, it will help other present students to learn about writing a thesis and to provide feedback to their peers.
The seminar is integrated by a training course provided by the Job Guidance Team of the University of Trento. Students need to organize themselves with the relevant offices and make sure they get a certificate for the activity.

How you get access to the credits and other hopefully useful information is provided on the moodle comunity (also the one for the entire MA programme).

data.name: Qualitative research methods

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
Knowledge-related objectives. Upon the successful completion of the course, students will gain:

1.    An understanding of the ontological and epistemological strands informing QR

2.    How these relate to methodological stances

3.    A broad and detailed overview of the main research methods and instruments available, including multimedia and participatory ones

4.    Critical understanding of what sampling, generalisation and evaluation mean in QR

5.    Knowledge of the opportunities of mixing qualitative and quantitative research designs

6.    Ethics and politics of qualitative research.

 

Skills and competences. By the end of the course students will be able to:

1.    Select a case study and develop a research question to be pursued through QR methods

2.    Develop an appropriate research design, including sampling and research instruments

3.    Collect, analyse and represent qualitative data

4.    Adopt reflexive stances with respect to their own research practice

5.    Manage the relation with research subjects, as aware of issues regarding rapport and ethics

6.    Evaluate the quality of a piece of qualitative research

7.    Present their research through writing and oral presentation.

data.description:
The course has the general objective of providing students with the fundamental notions about the interaction between humans and computerized systems. In particular, the course is focused on the principles of the User-Centered-Design methodology, as well as on their application during the design and evaluation of interfaces of various types and for various domains.

Upon successful completion of this module, students should be able to:

- Design and critically assess the user interface of an interactive system as well as the interaction modalities afforded by it
- Use tools, techniques and models for the design and evaluation of the interaction
- Understand the needs and the role of the user and relate them to the design of usable interactive systems
- Know the fundamentals of the human cognitive processes and their implications for the design of interactive interfaces
- Develop prototypes of interfaces of websites and mobile apps, considering usability aspects as well as the peculiarities of the interaction
- Understand the concepts of accessibility, inclusiveness and Universal Design related to the design of interactive systems

data.name: Inglese giuridico B2
data.description:
General Learning Outcomes

This is a language course, not a law content course as the Law Faculty modules are. Legal topics and concepts are used in the course as vehicles to explore legal language. 

While a selection of legal terminology in each legal topic area is presented throughout the course, mastering legal English requires more than simply improving your knowledge of specialized vocabulary. 

By the end of the course the students should have acquired a basic knowledge of the main features of legal English, aspects of specialized lexis; the importance of legal collocations and formal register, considering different degrees of formality in text types within the large genre of legal English.

The course is based on the assumption that, in order to profit from the mobility programs/exchanges available in foreign universities, the needs of the students lie predominantly in improving their speaking skills, in addition to listening and reading comprehension strategies; therefore an essential component of the course is learning to produce and deliver an effective oral presentation of a legal topic. 

Due to constraints of time, written production and in particular legal drafting is not prioritized, although there are opportunities during the course to practice formal letter-writing, such as emails of advice, replies to letters before action and letters of application/motivation, which are marked and feedback given.

Specific Learning Outcomes

This course is focused on improving your language skills at the B2 level. This course will:
Strengthen speaking skills and enable students to engage more effectively in a range of speaking situations typical of the study of law and the practice of law, such as client interviews or discussions with colleagues and fellow students;
Improve the ability to read, understand, and applying analyze a range of legal texts, such as legislation and legal correspondence;
Improve comprehension of spoken English when it is used to speak about legal topics in lectures, presentations, interviews, and discussions appropriate to B2 level; and
Improve the ability to write basic but accurate legal correspondence.

Students will also improve their abilities to:
use legal language confidently and accurately, based on the knowledge of collocations and specific lexis acquired over the course;
make appropriate choices in register, based on the knowledge acquired over the course; and
use a range of databases, online dictionaries and legal resources, including an introduction to using linguistic corpora.

data.name: Paleografia II
data.description:
Access to the course Paleografia I requires that the students have attended Paleografia II. The course Paleografia I includes 60 hours of lesson + 30 of exercise = 12 credits

The first part (= 30 hours 6 credits) aims to introduce to the study of : 1) the metodology of the palaeographical expertise, to gain a critical approach to the ancient script; 2) the abbreviation system of the antiquity and medieval age; 3) the ‘carolina’ script (important to understand also our graphic system) and its historical development .

At the end of the first part the student will be able: a) to understand the abbreviation system; b) to read the graphic specimina of the Carolingian age; c) to give a critical interpretation of the handwriting’s changes during the four centuries of its use .

data.name: Gnoseologia
data.description:
In general terms, the THEORY OF KNOWLEDGE course is intended as an introduction to the main themes and main problems concerning the cognitive relationship between man and reality. In this perspective, it intends to:

A) clarify the different terms in which the problem of knowledge has been formulated in ancient, medieval, modern and contemporary thought;

B) analyze some of the issues of knowledge theory, favoring the assimilation of the specific terminology;

C) explore more monographically, year by year, single relevant paradigms in the history of the discipline;

D) provide competences for the independent analysis and interpretation of philosophical texts as well as elements for studying knowledge through comparison with other related disciplines (logic, psychology of knowledge, cognitive sciences, biology of knowledge, genetic and evolutionary epistemology).

At the end of the THEORY OF KNOWLEDGE course, students will have acquired a set of notions and categories through which they will be able to:

A) contextualize the problem of knowledge in both historical and systematic terms;

B) distinguish the different forms of knowledge, indicating its possibilities and limits;

C) use for this purpose the reference terminology, and reconstruct its origin and its semantic stratification;

D) expose, with appropriate textual references, the philosophical positions and arguments of the course by making comparisons within the history of theories of knowledge;

E) use acquired knowledge to address contemporary epistemological issues in other related disciplines;

F) produce conceptual maps to represent synthetic meaning connections between the theoretical contents of the course.

data.name: International Trade and Globalisation
data.description:
The goal of this course is to identify and to map, empirically and theoretically, the main phenomena of the current trade system in the global economy. The course provides insights into the reasons for trade at country and firm level, gains from trade, trade policy tools and international agreements, as well as contexts in which students can engage in debate, discussion, and reflections on the main issues related to trade policies.

By the end of the course students should have acquired:

• an in-depth understanding of the different advantages and costs of trade from various viewpoints of trade theory.

• the use of the necessary basic tools (f. i. some basic trade indices) to analyse, at country and firm level, the contemporary international and European trade relations.

• to apply theoretical perspectives in analysing related policy questions, especially the effects of trade barriers and industry protection.

• to understand the structure and functioning of international trading system and associated institutions (such as the WTO) and regional trade agreements.

data.name: Cultura e letteratura tedesca
data.description:
The aim of the course is the analysis of the ‘fantastic’ and the ‘supernatural’ as literary categories (in the definitions provided by many essayists and historians of literature, among them Tzvetan Todorov and Francesco Orlando) through a close reading of the short story Der unheimliche Gast (The Uncanny Guest, 1819) by E.T.A. Hoffmann, taken from the collection Die Serapions-Brüder (1819-1821). An intellectual biography of the author will be outlined, his way of constructing the story and the main narrative techniques will be analysed. The historical-cultural background, by which every literary phenomenon is conditioned, will be also taken into consideration (Napoleon’s campaigns, the victories of the French troops, the defeat of Prussia, the Restoration), as well as the cultural ‘discourses’ which were widespread at the time of the composition of the story (Naturphilosophie, animal magnetism, clairvoyance, telepathy, mesmerism, electrology, studies on sleepwalking, hypnosis). The course also aims at reflecting on the ways in which the link between literature and history can take shape and on the difficult balance, within the literary work, of aesthetic autonomy and historical-philosophical “Gehalt”.
In addition to the acquisition of the course content and knowledge of the cultural, literary and historical phenomena mentioned above, the students are expected to study and understand the content of the lectures, the texts scheduled in the syllabus, and the thematic insights. Students should also be able to apply the acquired knowledge, develop their autonomy of judgement (learn how to present and motivate their opinion in a discussion, know how to identify points of difficult comprehension within the program and ask the teacher for an explanation; know how to occasionally propose an interpretation or a judgment as the result of a personal critical reflection). Students are also expected to develop their communication skills (e.g. to be able to intervene in a discussion, to be able to ask questions to the teacher, to be able to share their work with their classmates, to be able to synthesise and present the knowledge acquired) and an effective method to consolidate the acquired knowledge.

data.name: Finanza aziendale progredito
data.description:
1. Learning objectives and course contents.
The purpose of the course is to provide students with an advanced understanding of the corporate investment and financing decisions. 
The first part focuses on the assessment of investments with leverage and enterprise value, with various approaches (the weighted average cost of capital method, the adjusted present value method and the flow-to-equity discounted cash flow method, multiples approach). The second part introduces the payout policy, in perfect market and in the presence of frictions. The third part analyses the typical sources of capital for corporation, in term of both equity and debt (bonds, leasing), with a medium/ long-term perspective. The fourth part introduces mergers and acquisition. The fifth part concerns finance for SMEs

2. Expected learning outcomes.

1. to describe the methods of evaluation of investment with leverage and to list the steps in computing each (define the input variables and describe how to compute their value; illustrate how the variables are used in the model; define and understand the output of the model);2. to understand and discuss the critical issues of each methods of evaluation (given the specific investment’s risk and leverage assumptions) and to identify the most suitable method of evaluation; to apply the methods of evaluation to examples / real cases;
3. to discuss the effect of dividend payment or share repurchase in a perfect capital market; to discuss the effect of taxes on dividend policy; to describe and discuss the effect of agency costs and information asymmetry on payout policy; 4. to describe the ways in which a private company can raise outside capital; to describe the bond indenture; to compare and discuss callable and convertible bonds with straight debt; 5. to identify the sources of synergies that are commonly cited as justification given for an acquisition; to discuss the premium; to calculate and discuss the maximum exchange ratio;6. to identify why and how SMEs are different from large companies in the financial decisions and to adapt to them the financing approaches.

data.name: Mechanics and materials for engineering design
data.description:
One of the most important subjects for any student of materials engineering is the behavior of materials, mechanical components and structures under load. The way in which they react to applied forces, the resulting deflections and the stresses and strains set up in the bodies concerned are all vital considerations when designing a mechanical component such that it will not fail under predicted load during its service lifetime. All the essential elements of a treatment of these topics are contained within this course, starting with the concepts of mechanics of materials (stresses-strains, beam theory, thick cylinders, plasticity, fracture mechanics) and moving on to the examination of strength and stiffness verifications on mechanical components such as cylinders, joints, springs, shafts, bearings and mechanical transmissions.

By the end of this course students should: (1) be able to analyze the stress and strain on mechanical components and understand, identify and quantify failure modes for mechanical parts; (2) know basic machine elements used in machine design and design machine elements to withstand the loads and deformations for a given application, while considering additional specifications; (3) be able to approach a design problem successfully, taking decisions when there is not a unique answer; (4) be familiar with team-working, mathematical computing and CAD software; (5) be able to present analyses in a proper format of a written report such that a technically qualified person can follow and obtain similar findings.

data.name: High Performance Computing for Data Science

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The course is intended to provide the fundamentals of High Performance Computing software for High-end Data Science. In particular we present convergent ecosystems of software and data frameworks at a large-scale in relevant scientific disciplines. The course will present both theoretical and practical aspects related to simulation-centric and data-centric paradigms; challenges related to end-to-end workflows joining both paradigms into large-scale experiments will be also presented; case studies from several domains (e.g. medical/health, financial, climate/weather) will be presented and discussed with follow-up hands-on sessions. By the end of the module, students will learn:

  • parallel computer memory architectures and parallel programming models;
  • principles of parallel algorithm design
  • how to develop and benchmark parallel code (using MPI);
  • analytics frameworks and approaches for High-end Data Analysis;
  • how to develop large-scale data analytics applications (using Dask or similar tools);
  • differences between simulation-centric paradigm and data-centric discovery;
  • the complementary role of big data, data science and HPC in tackling real-world problems.

The course consists of two modules, one introductory dedicated to the framing of the fundamental notions of administrative law, and one in-depth, dedicated to questions relating to environmental legislation, as a specific administrative sector.
The course aims to provide students with a method of understanding and analysis of the legal phenomenon, useful both on a cultural level and on the level of skills necessary to carry out professional activities in administrations or in private sectors subject to administrative regulation.
Even the non-jurist must in fact be in a position to evaluate, during the course of his study and professional activity, the main legal questions underlying the administrative regulation of the territory and the environment, understood as a necessary precondition for any planning and execution of human interventions on their own habitat.
The development of some fundamental legal skills allows not only to understand, on an interdisciplinary level, the complexity of the phenomena known and learned within the entire degree course, but also to develop further analytical and evaluative skills useful for the student and the future professional (logical skills , expositive and argumentative).

data.name: Diritto amministrativo
Fog and Cloud Computing

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
In the last few years, the cloud computing revolution heavily impacted the ICT world: cloud infrastructure, both public and private, hosts a significant portion of modern digital services and data. Cloud technologies and methodologies, such as virtualisation, containerisation, micro-service based architectures and service-meshes, are becoming prevalent among large technology providers, cloud operators and software developers. New software applications are, in turn, being developed following the so called cloud-native paradigm in order to exploit the benefits, such as scalability and reliability, offered by the cloud infrastructure and services.

Within this technological revolution, topics such as data locality and management are also attracting increasing interest. For this reason, one area of significant development in this space is that of edge computing resources, leading to the emergence of the fog computing paradigm. Indeed, more and more services are beginning to exploit, or even require, its benefits in terms of reduced latency, lower bandwidth consumption through near data source pre-processing, or simply guarantees around the geo-location of data.

This course provides an introduction to Cloud and Fog computing principles and technologies, following a practical, hands-on approach. More specifically, at the end of the course the student will: (1) learn about cloud and fog computing models, technologies and existing solutions; (2) acquire relevant knowledge on advanced topics related to networking, orchestration and security; (3) use and configure advanced open-source platforms to create and manage cloud computing infrastructures and to effectively and dynamically orchestrate workloads.

data.name: Advanced Academic Writing

data.name: Advanced Commutative Algebra
data.description:
The commutative algebra is an extremely versatile discipline. In addition to being itself a field of research in mathematics both classical and contemporary, it has important consequences both in computational framework that on the foundations of modern algebraic geometry, not to mention the recent uses in the application environment.
The purpose of this course is to provide a good understanding of the foundations of modern commutative algebra with a particular focus on computational methods and its use in algebraic geometry.
The final part of the course will introduce students to the most recent applications.
