data.description:
The course provides a solid knowledge in the history of Italian art between 1470 and 1530. The student will also develop skills in stylistic and iconographic interpretation of works of art.
At the end of the course it is expected that the student has acquired a good knowledge of the fundamental facts in Renaissance art history and specific skills for critical judgment and autonomous interpretation of the works, both on style and on contents.

data.name: Inglese giuridico C1
data.description:
General Learning Outcomes

This is a language course, not a law content course as the Law Faculty modules are. Legal topics and concepts are used in the course as vehicles to explore legal language. 

While a selection of legal terminology in each legal topic area is presented throughout the course, mastering legal English requires more than simply improving your knowledge of specialized vocabulary. 

By the end of the course the students should have acquired an enhanced knowledge of the main features of legal English, aspects of specialized lexis; the importance of legal collocations and formal register, considering different degrees of formality in text types within the large genre of legal English.

The course is based on the assumption that, in order to profit from the mobility programs/exchanges available in foreign universities, the needs of the students lie predominantly in improving their speaking skills, in addition to listening and reading comprehension strategies; therefore an essential component of the course is learning to produce and deliver an effective oral presentation of a legal topic. 

Due to constraints of time, written production and in particular legal drafting is not prioritized, although there are opportunities during the course to practice formal letter-writing, such as emails of advice, replies to letters before action and letters of application/motivation, which are marked and feedback given.

Specific Learning Outcomes

This course is focused on improving your language skills at the C1 level. This course will:
Strengthen speaking skills and enable students to engage more effectively in a range of speaking situations typical of the study of law and the practice of law, such as client interviews or discussions with colleagues and fellow students;
Improve the ability to read, understand, and applying analyze a range of legal texts, such as legislation and legal correspondence;
Improve comprehension of spoken English when it is used to speak about legal topics in lectures, presentations, interviews, and discussions appropriate to C1 level; and
Improve the ability to write basic but accurate legal correspondence.

Students will also improve their abilities to:
use legal language confidently and accurately, based on the knowledge of collocations and specific lexis acquired over the course;
make appropriate choices in register, based on the knowledge acquired over the course; and
use a range of databases, online dictionaries and legal resources, including an introduction to using linguistic corpora.
data.degreeProgram: Comparative, European and International Legal Studies (L2)

data.name: Sociologia economica e del lavoro

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description: This course aims at providing students with some tools for a sociological analysis of labour markets, and the processes of modernization and  economic development in different social and institutional contexts.

data.name: Progettazione di impianti di trattamento delle acque

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
The course is focused on conventional and advanced technologies for the treatment of civil and industrial wastewater, providing the skills for identifying the optimal treatment chain and for its design.

The exercises focus on the numerical application of the methods for the design of treatment plants for municipal and industrial wastewaters, applying both conventional and advanced processes. The exercises give the skills to: (1) analyze qualitative and quantitative data for wastewater characterization; (ii) perform the design of municipal wastewater treatment plants applying specific algorithms; (iii) apply simulation models for the dynamic simulation of the plant; (iv) combine a wastewater treatment plant with circular economy.
data.degreeProgram: Ingegneria per l'ambiente e il territorio (LM)

data.name: Global Markets and Security issues
data.description:
This course deals with the security concerns related to the globalisation and liberalisation of markets and the tensions between these phenomena and security, meant as human security, i.e., security against widespread and cross-cutting challenges to the survival, livelihood and dignity of people worldwide. These issues will be analysed from the perspective of both law and economics, focusing on their relations and interplay. The discussion will also deal with the ability of national states and international organisations to regulate globalised markets and their pitfalls. In this respect, the topics covered during this course will take into account the current global challenges.


By the end of the course students will be able to:

• strengthen and deepen their knowledge of the phenomena related to the globalization and liberalization of markets, focusing in particular on legal and economic aspects;

• strengthen their skills in analysing security issues in relation to national and international systems and the position of consumers, producers, individuals and communities in the globalisation and liberalisation of markets;

• develop the skills required for the understanding of the interaction between markets and security, both at the local and global level, and apply them for practical problem-solving;

• apply theoretical knowledge to the analysis of specific cases related to security in global markets, so as to be able to make critical assessments and devise practical solutions;

• develop communication skills required in order to be able to describe in a clear and comprehensive way the main characterstics of security issues related to the globalisation of markets, their critical aspects and practical implications.

data.name: Scientific programming

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description: This class aims at learning modern programming techniques for (geo-)scientists. After finishing the class, attendees should understand how numbers are handled by computers and be aware of numerical accuracy errors. They should be able to program in a structured, extendable and reproducible manner. In the process of this class students will get acquainted with various programming tools (IDEs, debugger, unit testing, object oriented programming, version control, open development practices).

data.name: Economia aziendale
data.description:
The course of "Economia Politica e Aziendale" is organised in two sections: ECONOMIA POLITICA and ECONOMIA AZIENDALE.

ECONOMIA POLITICA: The knowledge of the principles leading the decision making of economic operators is the goal of the first part of the course. The microeconomics, in fact, analyses the behaviour of rational operators, like consumers and firms. The knowledge of the causes determining the economic system equilibrium and the analysis of the interventions of fiscal and monetary authorities to stabilize the economy are the goal of the second part of the course (macroeconomics).

ECONOMIA AZIENDALE aims to provide students with insights into the analysis of the basic concepts of business economics with particular attention to structure, accounting and strategy aspects of enterprises.

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.name: Ethics for computer science and engineering

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: Explore the contemporary ethics of computer science and engineering with thought experiments, discussions, and case studies. Students will learn the central ethical principles guiding today’s information technology, and apply the theory in the real world. Ultimately, students will be equipped to respond to ethics committees, to develop an ethical understanding of their own work, and to produce ethical evaluations of technological projects.

data.name: Informatica

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description: The aim of the course is to provide students with the bases of computer programming using high-level languages. At the end of the course students should be able to write simple Python programs.

data.name: Distributed robot perception

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
The instructional goals of the course is to acquire a comprehensive overview of the distributed systems for measurement and automation used today in industrial and service application domains. The course focuses on the most advanced technological solutions adopted in industry as well as on the theoretical aspects that arise when control or estimation are applied in a distributed context. Particular emphasis will be given to robotic perception using Artificial Intelligence techniques to be applied to robotic problems.

During the course, the focus will be on the design and implementation of distributed estimators to be used for intelligent autonomous systems in industrial and service environments, analyzing the resulting problems from both a practical and theoretical point of view. Examples of the application of these techniques on real or realistic systems will be presented during the course.

At the end of the course, the student will be able to:

- Understand the complexity, the issues and the potentialities of distributed systems;

- Compare the various different technological solutions available for a distributed system;

- Evaluate and analyze the practical and theoretical implications of a distributed measurement and/or perception system;

- Analyse and design the distributed solution for a particular system;

- Critically asses the benefits and the limitations of a distributed solution.

data.name: Letterature comparate II
data.description: Through close reading of some complex texts, dedicated to the relationship between literature, history, and power - the backdating to the past, as alleged original characters, of the defects of the present Italy, and aesthetic effects of the Great War between Germany and England -, through the reading of some historical novels, Manzoni, Lampedusa, Eco, WuMing 4 (prof. Giglioli), and books of poems by Gottfried Benn and T.S. Eliot (prof. Comparini), students will learn to consider literature as a specific discursive regime that feeds on a continuous interchange with different languages (psychology, history, philosophy, political theory). No content enters in literature without being transformed. No content returns from literature to society without having proposed a new and unprecedented way of giving shape to one's own emotional and ideological frameworks. At the end of the class the student will be able to contextualize the texts as historical phenomena, read them with the critical and theoretical tools of the discipline, and deal with texts belonging ti different national literatures.

data.name: Diritto tributario 2
Diritto pubblico
data.description:
To provide the basic knowledge of the main categories of public  law, with special emphasis on the sources of law, their role in regulating the relationship among public actors and between the State and the citizens, the role and functioning of public  institutions in the decision-making process. To guide students towards the consultation of the sources of law and the interpretation of legal rules, particularly focusing on the Italian Constitution.
At the end of the course, students will have the basic notions of legal terminology and will be able to comprehend and properly describe the basic elements of the national system of public law. Moreover, they will have the basic tools to directly access legal sources, particularly at the Constitutional level.

data.name: Storia moderna II
data.description:
The course aims to provide an introduction to the study of modern history (fifteenth to the eighteenth centuries) and to identify the central themes that link that period, in Europe and beyond, to the contemporary world.

General learning outcomes:
a) to identify the major events, persons and ideas of the early modern history.
b) build relationships and ties between them.
c) to grasp the elements of continuity and rupture of early modern history.
d) to recognize, distinguish, differentiate, compare the most important aspects of European and non-European civilizations.
e) to place an historical source in time and space describing its content, origins, and motivations.
f) to use a suitable historiographic lexicon.
g) to organize the knowledges and communicate them clearly and concisely in a written form.

data.name: Topografia

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
The primary goal of this course is to convey knowledge and to permit the development of skills about land surveying and mapping.

Basic concepts are provided for the understanding and the evaluation of the various phases of a land survey, namely:
- choice of reference system and measurement technique(s),
- design of a measurement set-up and measurements acquisition,
- treatment of observations,
- critical analysis of the results,
- fusion of informations from different sources,
- representation.

Teaching includes lectures, instrumental exercises and numerical exercises.

The participation in the proposed activities, complemented by appropriate individual study activities, allows the knowledge of:
- concepts, purposes and problems about reference systems and their transformations at the global and local scales,
- conventional and modern, space-based, methods and techniques for measurements acquisition,
- models and methods for the treatment of observations and the estimation of unknown parameters,
- the probabilistic modeling of uncertainties in measurements,
- basic concepts about the representation of the Earth and of its surface, reference surfaces for altimetric and planimetric positioning,
- basic principles about cartography and the practical purposes and uses of mapping products.

At the end of the course the student will be able to:
- perform topographic measurements,
- design a simple topographical survey,
- perform simple topographical calculations,
- critically evaluate the results of a survey,
- use cartographic products.

The effective realization of a survey may require more technical-operational skills than those that can be gained in instrumental exercises, but acquired knowledge and skills should be sufficient for job setting and self-obtain the necessary complementary skills.

data.name: Global Economic Scenarios_
data.description:
The module intends to provide students with the technical means and knowledge necessary for critically understanding the features of the global economy, the ongoing processes, their consequences and evolution.
The aim of the module is to support students in acquiring knowledge of the fundamental features of the world economy, its dynamics and evolution, including among countries and groups of countries. Special attention is devoted to the long-term trends, their causes and economic and institutional changes.
At the end of the module, students are expected to master the fundamental features of the world economy, its working, and transformations under the pressure of different factors. Students will also be able to appreciate the reasons that led to the present situation, the complexity and implications of the process of globalization and its revision, and the consequences and challenges for individual countries. Students will also be able to critically assess the alternatives, existing or possible, and the necessary reforms.

data.name: Metodi di indagine in psicologia clinica

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description: The aim of this course is to provide general and applying knowledge about the three principal assessment methods in clinical psychology: test, interview and observation. Students will be able to acquire a general knowledge of the structure, functions and psychometric properties of the principal intelligence and personality tests. Moreover, they will be able to apply this knowledge to the consultation of tests’ manuals and to the choice of the appropriate tests for different testing situations. Students will be able to acquire a general knowledge of the features and techniques of psychological interviews, and to understand how these features and techniques apply to the different aims and contexts (i. e., assessment, therapy, research). Also, students will be able to develop and analyze interviews of different kind at a basic level. Students will acquire a general knowledge of the basic principles that allow to consider observation as a scientific method and they will learn to apply simple observational coding systems of individual and social behaviors. Finally, working on observation and interview techniques, students will reinforce their communicative skills including awareness of own and other communicative skills and empathic listening.

data.name: Thermodynamics of materials
data.description:
The course provides theoretical concepts and application tools to define the constitutive behaviour of materials and the energetic aspects which are involved in transformations. Particular attention will be given to the definition and the application of the thermodynamic functions to topics related to solid systems, thermodynamic equilibrium, phase diagrams, surfaces and interfaces. In addition, kinetic aspects of transformations will be discussed and applied to case studies of interest in the field of material science. Each topic will be approached both from the theoretical and applicative point of view, by proposing numerical examples and exercises in the field of materials and processing.

At the end of the course the student should:

-apply chemical thermodynamics to a quantitative description of phase stability of single and multicomponent.

-understand and apply the laws of thermodynamics and kinetics to describe material properties, phase transformations, chemical reactions, and processing operations.

-apply simple models describing the transformation involving different forms of energy, and its application to technological systems

-understand and apply the effects of surfaces and interfaces on the macroscopic properties of materials, phase transformations, and industrial processing operations.

-identify, formulate, and solve complex materials engineering problems by applying the principles of thermodynamics and kinetics.

data.name: Geometria e algebra lineare

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The course aims to:
provide the basic elements of Linear Algebra, with applications to the geometry in three-dimensional space and to vector calculus.
At the end of the course the student should:
- have a good knowledge and understanding of the theory of finite dimensional real vector spaces, as described in the course list of topics.
- know the basic concepts, be able to explain and describe them also with examples, identify the connections between them.
- be familiar with the mathematical tools which are needed to develop a suitable approach and solve Linear Algebra problems, such as, for example, operations between matrices, echelon form reduction algorithms, computation of determinants, of eigenvalues and eigenvectors.

data.name: Organizzazione del cantiere

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
The course deals with concepts and tools to be applied by civil engineers in building construction planning and management activities. The construction phase is analyzed within the whole building process (design, construction and service life). Basics of quality management in the building process are also dealt with specific reference to life-cycle costs, value analysis, planning techniques and regulatory constraints.
Contents stem from knowledge available, from state-of-the-art professional practice issues and from the most recent research results on subject of planning, manufacturing, construction and performance evaluation of building elements and systems. A specific attention is given to the context of economics and production issues, and to new tools for design, design management and construction management (BIM)

data.name: Lifestyles and consumption practices

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description: The course discusses the major social, cultural and economic changes in contemporary societies through the analysis of shifts that occurred in consumption patterns and practices. The main objective of this course is to provide an advanced introduction to consumer theory and the (interdisciplinary) field of consumption studies.
data.degreeProgram: Sociology and social research - Sociologia e ricerca sociale (LM)

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.name: Seminario: English for Academic Writing and Presentations

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.name: Epigenetics of Cancer

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description:
Epigenetics of Cancer is the study of the epigenetic mechanisms whose alterations favors tumor initiation and progression. The course will focus on understanding the role of epigenetics in controlling maintenance of cell identity, tissue homeostasis and adaption to environmental changes. In the context of tumorigenesis, the course will provide a framework on the interconnection between alterations of epigenetics, cancer genetics and aberrant environmental signals. Overall, the main objective of the course is to provide to the students a depth knowledge of the alterations of the epigenetic mechanisms that foster tumorigenesis and their possible involvement of designing targeted therapy.
At the end of the course the student will be able to:
- describe different types of epigenetic mechanisms 
- understand the role of epigenetics in controlling gene expression and genome stability
- gain knowledge on the most advanced technologies to profile the epigenome alterations in cancer
- Critically evaluate data regarding cancer epigenomics

data.name: Evidence Based Management
data.description:
The course describes firms as experimentation environments and places where to learn from decisions. The first part describes the organizational features of firms adopting an Evidence-based approach. The second part will deal with methods of causal analysis of decisions and measurement of their effect. The third part will introduce some debated issues on the use of Artificial intelligence, and its impact on Evidence-based management. During the course, students will be invited to work in group to examine some management practices, on the light of evidence from the scientific literature. With the course, students will acquire knowledge and skills that will help use experimental as well as observational data to address firms' decisions.


Expected learning outcomes:

Students are expected:

1. to gain a clear view of the Evidence Based approach, and its distinguishing features; 2. to be able to distinguish different learning processes, and to characterize causal learning;

3. to gain confidence with methods and instruments for the collection of evidence, from both experimental and observational data;

4. to obtain some basic knowledge of techniques of causal analysis.


By participating in the discussion classes, students will also:

1. acquire skills of problem analysis and of evaluating management practices in the light of evidence;

2. improve their ability to express personal views and to evaluate the view of others;

3. be able to summarize, present and discuss debated issues.

data.name: Comunicazione scientifica

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description:
The purpose of the course is to reflect on academic communication in Italian. To do this, the course requires the willingness to work during the weeks of lessons, alone and in groups, at home and in the classroom.


At the end of the course, students are expected to be able to write correct and coherent texts and to communicate effectively with clear language and a technical vocabulary, appropriate to academic and professional circumstances.

data.name: Administrative Law
data.description: The course aims to provide the tools and analytical techniques to understand the concept of Administrative Law, beyond the national borders. At the end of the course, students will be able to recognize, describe and understand the principles and foundations of administrative procedures.
data.degreeProgram: Comparative, European and International Legal Studies (L2)

data.name: Physiological flow and transport in porous tissues
data.description: The objective of the course is to provide the skills needed to develop flow and transport models relevant for biomedical applications. This will be accomplished by interpreting and modeling biological transport processes with the tools made available by fluid mechanics. The students will learn how to develop and apply models of flow and transport in biological tissues and in extracorporeal devices, in view of their design, as well as pharmacokinetics compartmental models.

data.name: Statistics Laboratory
data.description:
This is a crash course in statistics for the social sciences. The aim is to introduce statistical methods in a style that emphasise their concepts and their application to the social sciences rather than the mathematics and computational details behind them. This will be done by focusing on how the methods are used and interpreted rather than their theoretical derivations. As such, we will make use of recent papers employing statistical methods to analyse current and relevant issues for the social sciences.

By the end of the course, students will be able to understand and describe basic statistical concepts and methods, such as sampling, descriptive statistics, statistical inference and simple associations between variables. Students will be able to analyse and present in front of their peers basic descriptive statistics and other relevant information about different data. This will encourage students to develop a critical understanding of the use of statistical methods.

data.name: Stochastic processes (I modulo)

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description:
The course aims to provide the main concepts and results of probability theory that find applications in coding  and cryptography. It is essentially divided into two parts. The first part introduces the theory of discrete-state stochastic processes and their main applications. The second part provides basic elements of information theory, introducing the concept of entropy and illustrating Shannon's theorems.
 
At the end of the course the student will know some topics of probability theory and stochastic processes with discrete states, as well as some elements of information theory as specified by the course program. He will also be able to understand the mathematical modeling in terms of suitable stochastic processes of a large class of random phenomena.
The student will also be able to reason inductively and deductively in the solution of problems involving random phenomena. He will also be able to schematize a random phenomenon in rigorous terms, to develop logical arguments and produce correct proofs, as well as to explain them clearly.
The student must also be able to acquire and manage new information regarding random models.

data.name: Philosophical Insights
data.description:
Educational objectives

The course is thought as a multi-voiced reflection on relevant issues which have been the focus of philosophical inquiry from Antiquity to the present. The course is subdivided into five units, of six hours each, which will be taught in English (four) and German (one).

The structure in modules is designed to provide multidisciplinary and diachronic analyes. The aim of the course is to address the complexity of philosophical concepts and to explore philosophical debates in their historical development and the broader context of the relationships between philosophy and other branches of knowledge (history, literature, theology, religious studies, science).

The course is based on the reading of primary sources and a rigorous analysis of secondary literature. Students are expected to take part in classroom discussion and write a paper in English or German.

 

Expected learning outcomes

At the end of the course students

1. will be familiar with the technical vocabulary in a foreign language (English or German) on the topics covered;

2. will recognise and analyze the meaning of key concepts;

3. will be familiar with the topics examined, as well as the historical-cultural contexts, the methodological implications, and the historiographical debates.

 

Abilities

At the end of the course students are expected

1. to be able to carry out a critical analysis of the philosophical theories examined;

2. to be able to express in a foreign language their views on the course topics;

3. to be able to write a paper in a foreign language (English or German) according to the rules of academic writing on the topics that were covered during at least two of the teaching units.

data.name: Seminario: Elementi di analisi dei sistemi energetici

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description: The seminar develops the basic concepts necessary to frame the theme of the energy transition towards renewable sources, environmental/social sustainability, and the role of technology in the processes of energy transformation and conversion from both renewable and non-renewable sources. It is developed in 10 meetings of two hours each which progressively deal with the problems of the electricity needs according to the growth rate and the power plants necessary for its production, analyzing limits and perspectives according to the types of electricity. source used, the current and future technical characteristics of the conversion plants, the environmental effects that are produced, starting from the sustainability of the withdrawal rates to reach the chemical-physical alterations, and the occupation of the territory also in light of previous uses. The aim of the seminar is to provide the student with a broader view of the issues related to the world of energy, both from the technological point of view and from the point of view of environmental impact, in addition to the implications in energy planning processes. From a methodological point of view, a series of modeling skills and tools of a comparative nature will be provided based on the definition of technical-economic and environmental performance indices, helpful in choosing between alternatives. No specific skills are required besides those developed in mathematical and physical analysis courses.
data.degreeProgram: Ingegneria per l'ambiente e il territorio (LM)

data.name: Statistica per le ricerche di mercato
Bio-Medical Imaging
data.description:
The course will provide an introduction into the concepts of modern biomedical imaging, with emphasis on:
•Imaging sources (X-rays, Radio-isotopes, Magnetic fields, Visible light, ...) 
•Image acquisition techniques (Tomography, Magnetic Resonance, Microscopy, Super-resolution,...)
•Image processing methods (Image reconstruction, Filtering techniques, Image segmentation,...)
•Applications (Examples in Diagnostics, Therapy, Research)
Students at the end of the course will have a profound knowledge of all major medical and biological diagnostic and scientific imaging modalities. 
They will be able to distinguish different imaging modalities by their theoretical and technical foundations, their fields of application, and the physiological information they provide.
They will have seen the application of some of these methods in the daily routine of hospitals and laboratories.
They will be further capable to select and apply different image reconstruction methods to the raw data of the different imaging modalities. The hands-on MATLAB-laboratory will introduce them to this universal image processing tool. It will provide them with the skills to write their own code to extract quantitative measures on single objects from diagnostic images.
The students will be stimulated to read original scientific articles on recent advances in the field of biomedical imaging methods.
They will be able the extract novel concepts from these articles, to present them in a short seminar, and to discuss them with their fellow participants.

data.name: Economia dei sistemi agro-alimentari
data.description:
Objective of this course is to provide a framework for understanding and analyzing the role and the evolution of agro-food systems.
Attendance and active participation at three training activities proposed by the course (lectures, small assignments, team group work) and self-study will enable students to:
a) Summarize the structure of the agro-food system in Italy and its recent evolution 
b) Compare the different forms of environmental friendly agriculture based on their sustainability 
c) Interpret the results of simple econometric estimations of demand functions for agro-food products 
d) Compare different approaches to study the agro-food system 
e) Compare the different forms of organization in the agro-food system
f) Analyze the role of quality regulation and certification in the agro-food system.

The course aims to

  • provide the basic elements of Linear Algebra, with applications to the geometry in three-dimensional space and to vector calculus.

data.name: Physics of the Climate System

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description: Understanding physical relations in the climate system

data.name: Current Topics in Brain Connectivity
data.description: The course will provide an introduction into the concepts of brain connectivity. In this seminar course, we will read and discuss up-to-date scientific contributions in the field of general brain connectivity, focusing on both functional and anatomical connectivity measures. The goal of this introductory course is to provide a basic knowledge of the state-of-the-art methods and concepts of accessing brain connectivity measures. At the end of the course, students should have acquired a good overview of the current debates on brain connectivity and they will have learned the appropriate terminology and computational concepts. They will be familiarized with the concepts of experimental connectivity measures and they will be able to critically access new publications on the topic.

data.name: Atmospheric boundary layer and turbulence

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.name: Progettazione di sistemi integrati per il recupero di materia da rifiuti urbani

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
The module gives criteria useful for a correct design of waste treatment plants, in particular municipal solid waste.

A correct design must be based also on the knowledge of waste collection before treatment. For this reason collection and transport of waste are topics included in the module. At the end of the lessons the student will be able to participate to a design team for plants in the sector in EU-like contexts (for material recovery)

data.name: Filosofia della logica
data.description:
The course offers an introduction to three central and closely intertwined topics in the philosophy of logic: (a) logical consequence, (b) truth, (c) paradox. Regarding (a), we will start from informal accounts of logical consequence and then introduce the two main approaches to rendering the notion of logical consequence formally precise, i.e., the model-theoretic approach and the deductive-theoretic (or proof-theoretic) approach. Regarding (b), the main tenets of correspondence theories, Tarski’s semantic conception, deflationist theories, and epistemic conceptions of truth will be introduced and discussed with a view to their relevance for the debate on logical consequence. Regarding (c), we will look at various semantic and set-theoretic paradoxes and assess their relevance to philosophical debates on truth and logical consequence.

At the end of the course students will have acquired the prerequisites for

- following contemporary debates about logical consequence,

- finding their way through contemporary philosophical debates on truth,

- appreciating the relevance of semantic and set-theoretic paradoxes for philosophical debates on logical consequence and truth.

data.name: Protection of materials and structures
data.description:
The aim of the course is to provide the basics for knowledge of corrosion protection methods for industrial products and structures.

At the end of the course, the student should:

1. recognize the different possibilities to protect a product against corrosion.

2. be able to analyze and evaluate the possible solutions;

3.propose the best protection system(s) for a particular product, depending on the working environment and expected life time.
data.degreeProgram: Materials and production Engineering - Ingegneria dei materiali e della produzione (LM)

data.name: Human-Machine Dialogue

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: Robots that can talk or chat with humans are becoming pervasive in many industry domains and applications. Such agents are called conversational AI systems. In this course the student will learn the basic principles of human computer interaction, conversation linguistics, discourse analysis, computational dialogue models and architectures and their evaluation. In the second part of the course the student will develop a conversational system while  learning the design methodologies, data-driven training and dialogue development tools .

data.name: Psicologia della formazione e dell'orientamento

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description:
The course of Training and Vocational Psychology focuses on the main issues of the training process, the development of skills in training and work contexts, the processes and variables related to work transitions over the life span. 
The course aims to provide students with the opportunity to develop and broaden the knowledge and a range of skills regarding the psychological dimensions involved in the training process within the training and work contexts, as well as offering a series of theoretical and operational knowledge on the vocational and transition processes in the various phases of the school-professional career.
At the end of the course students will be able to:
A) Know and understand the fundamental elements of training and vocational processes, including: individual and contextual variables that can affect career processes, skills acquisition, training design, transfer from training to work, training as a tool for human resource management, individual learning and organizational change, the use of information and communication technologies (ICTs) to support training activities
B) Critically and autonomously apply the knowledge learned by selecting the most relevant ones to address the problems related to the training and vocational processes, and specifically to identify: the appropriate methodological choices in the phase that precedes, accompanies and follows the training activity, including the needs analysis and the different types of evaluation; create connections between knowledge on individual characteristics and on organizational and contextual characteristics to better develop the process of developing skills for training and guidance purposes.
C) To convey the knowledge acquired to prepare training and orientation projects to be communicated effectively to different types of actors (based on organizational contexts, contextual factors, training types, characteristics of users, etc.).

data.name: Elementi di meccanica
data.description:
The course introduces basic concepts of mechanics and provides the tools for the analysis and modelling of kinematics, statics and dynamics of point and rigid bodies using Newtonian and energy methods. In addition, the course provides the basics of statics with an in-depth study of structural elements such as beams, plates, shells and trusses. 

At the end of the course, the student will be able to deal with problems of static equilibrium and dynamics of planar and three-dimensional rigid bodies, in the presence of common types of constraints, friction and forces. The student will also be able to recognize the physical meaning of the models adopted and the scope of applicability to derive equations of motion and stress characteristics.

data.name: Research Methods in History

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
At the end of the course students will be able to:

• Reconstruct the debate concerning the relation between social sciences and history

• Articulate methodological issues and problems of historical research 

• Critically evaluate different kinds of historical sources

• Reflect on sources and approaches specifically related to the study of migration history

• Work effectively in groups to analyze sources and readings and prepare presentations and papers

• Analyze and discuss academic texts, demonstrating critical thinking

• Prepare and present an effective presentation with powerpoint slides

data.name: Elementi psicologici e sociali del lavoro nei servizi sociali

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
The aim of the course is to furnish theoretical and practical basis in order to understand and operate

in the context of social work and social services with respect in psychological and psychosocial

components. The course also aims to provide basic skills in the psychology of work as the

discipline that studies and intervenes in different organizational settings. The course also intends to

develop understanding of the interaction between the individual, the work environment and the

organizational setting. To this end, particular emphasis will be given to the characteristics of

workers (motivation; meanings attributed to work; skills) as crucial for understanding

organizational behavior. Other areas of study are organization development and career management, and stress and well being in organizations and

psychosocial risk in organizational environment with a focus on mobbing.

data.name: GPU computing

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
General Aspects

Regarding the aspect of "Knowledge and understanding", the student will be able to:




  • analyze and solve even complex problems in the area of Software Engineering for Information Systems with particular emphasis on the use of studies, methods, techniques, and technologies of empirical evaluation;
  • know in depth the scientific method of investigation applied to complex systems and innovative technologies that support information technology and its applications;
  • read and understand specialist scientific documentation, such as conference proceedings, articles in scientific journals, and technical manuals.


Regarding the aspect of "Applying knowledge and understanding", the student will be able to:


  • design and perform experimental analyses of information systems in order to acquire measures related to their behaviour and to evaluate experimental hypotheses in different fields of application, such as business, industrial or research;
  • extend and modify in an original way an existing technical solution or a formal model taking into account changed conditions, requirements and evolution of the technology.


Regarding the aspect of "Making judgments", the student will be able to:




  • select documentation from a variety of sources, including technical books, digital libraries, technical scientific journals, web portals, or open source software and hardware tools;
  • reconcile the objectives of the project that are in conflict, to trade-off cost, resources, time, knowledge or risk;
  • work with large autonomy, also assuming responsibility for projects and structures.


Regarding the aspect of "Communication skills", the student will be able to:




  • present the contents of a scientific/technical report to an audience, including non-specialists, at a fixed time;
  • structure and draft scientific and technical documentation describing project activities;
  • coordinate project teams and identify activities to achieve project objectives;
  • prepare and conduct technical presentations in English;
  • carry out research and projects in a collaborative manner;
  • synthesise knowledge gained from reading and studying scientific documentation.


Regarding the aspect of "Learning skills", the student will be able to:




  • extend the knowledge acquired during the course of study by reading and understanding scientific and technical documentation in English;
  • extend knowledge, even if incomplete, taking into account the final objective of the project (problem solving skills);
  • to formulate and validate theories and define new methods through empirical induction and new generation scientific investigation tools.


Specific objectives:

Regarding the technical aspects, the student will be able to :




  • analyze sequential algorithms by identifying performance bottlenecks;
  • design parallel algorithms and implement them on GPUs by considering their architectural aspects;
  • adapt existing parallel and optimization techniques in a contest of different problems;
  • manage and use tools and technologies to design efficient and scalable GPU code.
  • design experimental setup and reporting results.

data.name: Distributed Robot Perception

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The instructional goals of the course is to acquire a comprehensive overview of the distributed systems for measurement and automation used today in industrial and service application domains. The course focuses on the most advanced technological solutions adopted in industry as well as on the theoretical aspects that arise when control or estimation are applied in a distributed context. Particular emphasis will be given to robotic perception using Artificial Intelligence techniques to be applied to robotic problems.

During the course, the focus will be on the design and implementation of distributed estimators to be used for intelligent autonomous systems in industrial and service environments, analyzing the resulting problems from both a practical and theoretical point of view. Examples of the application of these techniques on real or realistic systems will be presented during the course.

At the end of the course, the student will be able to:

- Understand the complexity, the issues and the potentialities of distributed systems;

- Compare the various different technological solutions available for a distributed system;

- Evaluate and analyze the practical and theoretical implications of a distributed measurement and/or perception system;

- Analyse and design the distributed solution for a particular system;

- Critically asses the benefits and the limitations of a distributed solution.

data.name: Medicina narrativa
data.description:
This module aims at developing key life skills in medical training and professional settings, such as narrative competence, attentive listening, inter-relational skills and empathy. Focusing on literary and artistic representations of the human body and of illness, students will be involved in narrative medicine workshops.

The expected learning objectives are:

·      reflecting on and developing the capacity to fully comprehend illness stories, their complexity and contexts;

·      strengthening self-awareness and comprehension of one’s professional role by practicing attentive listening, close reading, and story-telling;

·      enhancing creativity and critical thinking.

data.name: Comparative Legal Systems
data.description:
The aim of the course is to introduce students to the law as observed and studied from a comparative perspective, as well as to equip them with the methodology and instruments of comparative law itself and to explain how legal relations among private persons are structured.
At the end of the course students will be able to:
- comprehend the relevant features of a legal system and of a legal family, as well as understand and discuss their characteristics;
- identify the key elements of a norm, concept or institute, also in comparison with similar models of other legal systems.
data.degreeProgram: Comparative, European and International Legal Studies (L2)

data.name: Nuclear Astrophysics
data.description:
The aim of the course is to provide the student with knowledge about the connection between nuclear physics and astrophysics. As byproduct the student is also introduced to the principle ideas physicists have about the evolution of the universe from the very first instants of the big bang up to the present-day universe.


At the end of the first part of the course (24 h) the student will be able to answer with competence questions about

a) the different scenarios that lead to the origin of the various chemical elements (nucleosynthesis);

b) the role of strong and electroweak processes relevant for a detailed understanding of the nucleosynthesis;

c) a detailed derivation of nuclear cross sections with electromagnetic interaction in case of real photons, including the roles of the corresponding electromagnetic multipole operators and of a gauge-invariant nuclear current operator.


At the end of the second part of the course (additional 24 h) the student will have acquired a wide-ranging knowledge about the phenomenology of neutron stars connected with nuclear physics, in particular about

a) the birth process of neutron stars as a consequence of core-collapse supernovae

b) the characteristics of the crust and the transition from ordinary nuclei to homogeneous nuclear matter;

c) the properties of the core of the neutron star in connection to the equation of states of nuclear matter;


Moreover he/she will have been introduced to the theoretical tools for the descriptions of these various scenarios like ab-initio methods for the calculation of properties of nuclei, nuclear matter and few-nucleon reaction cross sections as well as to non-relativistic and relativistic mean field theories

data.name: Impianti industriali
data.description: The objective of the course is to provide students with the necessary competences for the design, installation and management of industrial plants in order to maximize their technical and economic performances using appropriate mathematical models. Starting from the analysis of the target market, the course analyzes the choices dealing with the product to be manufactured, its production process, the required production capacity of the plant, the economic evaluation of the entire initiative, the development of alternative layouts for the production system, up to the installation of the industrial plant.

data.name: Funzioni esecutive e apprendimenti: sistemi di misura e training

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description:
Executive functions module (Michele Scaltritti)

The main goal of this part of the course is to understand some main cognitive models concerning executive functions. Through and active participation and individual study, students will be able to:


  • know and describe some of the main perspectives on executive functions
  • develop and analytical and critical approach to the issue of executive functions, on the basis of experimental evidence.
  • understand the links between executive functions and learning.


Habituation module (Massimo Turatto)

Habituation as mechanism of filtering of unwanted stimuli: features, models, factors affecting habituation, habituation in different neurological deficits.


Clinical module (lecturer to be defined)

The goal of this module is to provide students with some practical skills in the evaluation and rehabilitation of executive functions.

data.name: Decision and risk analysis
data.description:
By means of the analytic tools discussed during the lectures, at the end of the course the student will:
1. be able to analyze decisions and choose the best course of action in complex contexts. Moreover, he will properly cope with decisions in uncertain environments, and with multiple objectives.
2. understand the basic notions of strategic behavior and will be able to transpose them into real-life contexts.
3. recognize various sources of risk and  take proper actions to manage it and possibly mitigate it.

data.name: Servizi sociali innovativi

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
In the context of social work,  the nature and complexity of clients’ problems and challenges experienced by communities continuously evolves. These challenges call for social workers to lead and facilitate innovation that can have a lasting impact on communities and people.
The aim of the course is to provide understandings of how innovation takes place in the social services and what the important explanatory factors, as well as the professional and social consequences, are. The focus of the course is on practices and processes that managers, coordinators and professional use to manage innovation effectively in new and existing organizations and in networks.  
Upon completion of this course, students will be able to: 

1. To know models, tools, methods to promuovere innovation in social work practice
2. To develop critical and analytical reasoning about innovation in social work practice. 
3. To analyze and solve problems that arise in organizations that work on innovative projects. 
4. To learn how elaborate and present innovative project in the field of social work 
5. Making critical and autonomous judgments in the analysis of empirical cases of innovation and in the comparison of theoretical models and perspectives.

data.name: Academic Freedom and Human Rights: European and International Perspectives (J. Monnet module)
data.description:
Academic freedom refers to freedom of research, freedom to teach/learn, university institutional autonomy and liberty to express ideas in the public sphere. It is critical in European top-quality higher education and in democratic societies generally. It is anchored in the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights and in the Constitution of most member States. The course will map the historical development of this principle in different geopolitical areas and will reflect on the main violations of academic freedom and on the consequences this holds for universities and for society more broadly. One of the main aims of the course is to combine conceptual-theoretical discussion with advocacy research and campaign on current cases of violations of academic freedom.

 

By the end of the course students will have acquired (gained knowledge):

1.                 A detailed and critical knowledge about different interpretations of academic freedom in different times and contexts;

2.                 An understanding of how different disciplines have contributed to the understanding of one of the key principles of higher education and democratic societies;

3.                 The capacity to discuss the connections between academic freedom, freedom of expressions and other human rights;

4.                 The capacity to discuss and compare different cases of violations of academic freedom, the way they involve students, researchers, administrative staff and higher education communities more broadly, and how violations different between authoritarian and democratic contexts;

5.                 Awareness about the relevance of policies aiming at protecting academic freedom de jure and de facto at local, national and supranational levels;

6.                 The capacity to link theory and practice through advocacy research. 

 

By the end of the course students are expected to have acquired (practical and communication skills):

7.                 Propose and discuss their opinions within the class;

8.                 Organise and present work in progress to other students and in the public sphere;

9.                 Autonomy in managing group work and in developing an advocacy campaign, also in collaboration with students working on similar cases in other universities;

10.             Writing an advocacy report on the studied case;

11.             Conducting an interview with a key expert.

data.name: Distributed systems 1

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The goal of the course is to expose the students to the core concepts of distributed systems, and to the main technologies underlying distributed applications. 

The main portion of the course is devoted to a discussion of the fundamental concepts and challenges in distributed systems, that focuses on the illustration of several classical algorithms. These algorithms are chosen to exemplify commonly-used solutions and to highlight fundamental principles and techniques concerned with the problem at hand. A second portion of the course is devoted to the middleware technologies commonly used to develop distributed applications. Alongside standard lectures, this topic includes hands-on sessions in the lab. 

The course ends with a peek at advanced topics, showing how the general notion of distributed systems is declined in two very different scenarios: i) the data centers at the back-end of planetary-scale systems (e.g., Google, Amazon, Yahoo), and ii) the fluid and dynamic setting involving several tiny, resource-scarce, wireless devices envisioned by the Internet of Things.

By the end of the course, students are expected to have obtained of a broad understanding of the key challenges in distributed systems, of the classic solutions and associated trade-offs, as well as to have acquired the ability to autonomously design relatively simple applications.

data.name: Struttura della materia
data.description:
This course provides the necessary knowledge to understand the microscopic quantum mechanisms that determine the main properties of atoms and molecules.
At the end of the course students will be able to deepen and independently face problems concerning the structure of matter and its interaction with the electromagnetic radiation. The arguments are presented starting from the phenomenology and describing the microscopic physical mechanisms by applying the already acquired knowledge in quantum mechanics. For this purpose, some exercises of applications of quantum mechanics to problems of atomic and molecular physics are proposed, and then discussed in class.

data.name: Riabilitazione neurocognitiva

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description: The course aims to provide students with knowledge about cognitive rehabilitation in neurological patients. Participants will acquire knowledge about the principles underlying the rehabilitation of deficits in the main cognitive domains (language, attention, memory, visual-spatial disorders). They will also acquire knowledge about some of the tools and techniques available for cognitive rehabilitation. By the end of the course, students will be able to identify the appropriateness of rehabilitation interventions based on the characteristics of different clinical populations, to discriminate the characteristics of different neurocognitive rehabilitation interventions and to set the basis for a rehabilitation intervention.

data.name: Politica comparata

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description: The aim of this course is to provide an introduction to the concepts and methods of comparative political analysis as well as to examine the different ways in which governing is organised in different political systems and contexts. At the end of the course, students should be familiar with the different types of political systems we find in contemporary politics as well as with the instruments we use to understand them. The emphasis will be on the question of democracy and democratization. The objective is to identify those factors that may lead to democracy as well as those that might contribute to its decline. We will look at specific examples, ranging from European states to non-democratic regimes such as Russia and China.

data.name: Storia moderna II - LM
data.description:
The course aims at:


a) to recognize the concept of "people" in the most recent historical, sociological, political science research;


b) to understand the multiple aspects of the concept of "people" between the Early modern and the Modern age.


c) to acquire an accurate knowledge of European political history between the nineteenth and twentieth century;


d) to examine the different influences, factors and forces that shape the concept of "people";


e) to locate the concept of people in relation to other ideological concepts, such as nation, race and ethnicity.


f) to compare the differences that affect the concept of people in and outside the Western world;


g) to handle differente research situations according to different methodologies;


h) to be able to hold an accurate presentation of a paper/source on the topics covered in the course.

data.name: Casi ed esperienze di gestione delle imprese turistiche
data.description: The course in based on seminars held by managers and entrepreneurs operating in tourism sector. The aim is to focus on the operations and on the business models of the firms.

data.name: Processi di trasporto nell'ambiente

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
The course aims at providing the fundamental concepts to understand the processes of transport of mass and energy in the environment (in water bodies like rivers and lakes, in the atmosphere, etc.) and their mathematical modelling. The final goal is to acquire competences to study problems related with the quality of water (e.g., pollution, eutrophication) and air.

 

At the end of the course, the student will be able to:

• understand the theoretical aspects of transport mechanisms in the environment;

• evaluate the mixing capacity of a water body and the rate of contaminant dilution;

• interpret these processes by means of simplified analytical solutions;

• critically select numerical models to study complex problems related to water or air quality.

data.name: Diritto d'autore e arte
Storia della Cina moderna e contemporanea
data.description: The course aims to provide students with the tools and knowledge needed for understanding China's international relations from the end of World War II to today. On completion of the module, students will acquire adequate knowledge of China's international history and worldview, the principles and aims of Chinese foreign policy and the role of state and non-state actors in the development of relations between China and the rest of the world in different historical periods. Moreover, they will be able to use both primary and secondary sources to understand and critically interpret key questions in China's international strategy and global role and to discuss with other students and the teacher the topics of the course.

data.name: Psychological Humanities

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description:
This module aims at fostering the life skills (through English) that are useful in the research and professional contexts of psychology, by focusing on the interdisciplinary connections of the psychological humanities. This approach combines the psychological sciences with the humanities and arts in order to explore the human mind from multiple perspectives.

At the end of the module students are expected to have learned to:

i. adopt an interdisciplinary perspective on mental processes, human behaviour, illness, individual and collective traumas, and human behaviour, which interpolates the scientific-empirical approach with the humanistic-artistic approach;

ii. foster empathy, self-awareness, intersubjective and intercultural competences;

iii. integrate the language, research methods, and knowledge of the psychological studies and the humanities.

data.name: Principles of biomaterials and medical device design
data.description:
The interdisciplinary course is aimed at acquiring knowledge of the main requirements for engineering precision biomaterials, the nature of the interactions between these and biological tissues (work environment) and the design criteria of artificial systems in relation to the functional recovery of the tissue or organ. to be replaced, integrated, or rehabilitated, of the medical device validation process.

In details:

  • Have an understanding of the multi- and inter-disciplinary nature of the biomedical device field;
  • Understanding the concepts of system biocompatibility and its role in precision biomaterials and medical device design;
  • Understanding the biological mechanisms tissue-specific involved in biomaterials and in designing medical devices.
  • Understand of the basic concepts for biomedical devices innovation: from clinical needs to emerging technologies;
  • Understanding of the basic principles and procedures for biomedical products development: from advanced research to product design; personalized medicine, prototype development, regulatory issues and validation;
  • Students will experience practical lab work in a multidisciplinary environment, understanding communication among several disciplines needed for biomedical strategies and products development.

Transversal skills

  • Communicate effectively with professionals/researchers from other disciplines.
  • Access and evaluate appropriate sources of information

data.name: Calculus 1

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
1. Knowledge and understanding
In-depth knowledge of the basic methods of the calculus for functions of one variable, as specified by the course program. Ability to analyze and understand the main characteristics of differentiable and integrable real value functions. Ability to apply the methods to concrete problems and other scientific or industrial problems.

2. Ability to apply knowledge and understanding
Ability of inductive and deductive reasoning in dealing with problems of the nature of the analysis of functions. Ability to set up a problem and solve it using appropriate analysis tools.

3. Autonomy of judgment
Ability to develop logical arguments, to understand when a proof is rigorous and complete, and to extend and produce minor extensions of the proofs seen in the course. Ability to identify the most appropriate methods for analyzing and interpreting problems.

4. Learning skills
Ability to acquire and manage new information starting from the statements and proofs developed in the lectures.

data.name: Economia finanziaria
data.description:
The aim of the course is to provide students with notions and tools for analysis of modern financial and monetary systems, in an integrated perspective between micro and macro-level, and between professional approach and economic analysis.

At the end of the course students are expected to:
- understand and summarise the literature, both academic and professional, in the field of economic-financial analyses and forecasts
- analyse and explain the characteristics and evolution trends of financial systems, also comparatively
- understand the causes and implications of financial inefficiencies for security markets, financial choices of housholds, corporate governance and finance, bank-firm relationships
- elaborate in autonomy analyses of macro-financial scenarios, highlighting for instance critical elements; more in particular,
- apply main theories of determination of demand, supply and pricing of financial instruments
- analyse saving and portfolio diversification choices by housholds; investment and financing choices by firms; credit policies by bank intermediaries and their relationshps with firms.

data.name: Quantum mechanics

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description:
This module course aims to provide students with the basic competencies in quantum mechanics physics. 

At the end of the first module, students are expected to:

1) understand the main difference between the physical phenomenology at the macroscopic level ( governed by the laws of classical physics) and the phenomenology at the microscopic level, where quantum mechanical behavior takes place

2) understand the concept of particle-wave duality, and describe and critically analyze the main experiments which provide evidence of quantum uncertainty, wave-like properties of matter, and energy or magnetic moment quantization. 

3) understand the mathematical and physical significance of the wave-function and the related time-dependent and stationary Schrodinger equation.

4) Solve elementary problems in quantum mechanics (particle in an infinite square well, particle in a finite square potential, ground state of the harmonic oscillator)

5) understand and use the basic mathematical tools involved in physical modeling, including:

- Multi-dimensional calculus: partial derivatives, multi-dimensional integral, differential operators, partial differential equations. 

- Basic linear algebra, including matrix diagonalization, eigenvalues, and eigenvectors, commutation relationships. 

- Notion of Hilbert space and its representation theory

- Notion of Dirac-delta function
