data.description: The course means to supply the conceptual instruments of base in order to interpret, in geographic key, the two fundamental economic topics of the competitiveness and the development.

data.name: Archeologia classica
General Relativity and Cosmology
data.description:
The first part concerns the passage from special to general relativity and introduces the necessary mathematical and geometrical tools (manifold, curvature, parallel transport, Riemann tensor and its properties).
In the second part the Einstein equations are found and discusses, also using a variational principle.
In the third part we discuss the weak field limit and the gravitational waves.
In the fourth part we introduce the static and stationary spherically symmetric solutions: Schwarschild, compact stars, and Kerr, with some elements regarding the Penrose process and the black hole thermodynamics.
In the fifth and last part we discuss the cosmological solutions, the LCDM model, dark energy and inflation.

data.name: Letteratura inglese I
data.description: The course aims to provide students with the critical tools that will enable them to study the narrative techniques deployed by Jane Austen for the representation of the character’s inner life. By focusing on Northanger Abbey and Pride and Prejudice, the course intends to not only examine the stylistic and thematic peculiarities of Austen’s early works, but also put the literary texts in relation with the early 19th-century historical, ideological, artistic and epistemic context. At the end of the course, students will be expected to be able to place Austen’s works in this context, to recognize and analyze the main techniques that Austen uses to represent the protagonists’ moral, cognitive and emotional growth and to develop critical thinking when interpreting a literary text.

data.name: Geografia e progettazione strategica degli spazi turistici
data.description:
The course aims to provide students with basic and advanced conceptual tools for the understanding of the evolution of the tourism phenomenon, as well as for its effects on the environment, the society and the economy of a territory, using a critical and sustainable geographical perspective, also from a diachronic and geographical-historical point of view.
In particular, the main contemporary tourist systems will be presented within the framework of globalization, current socio-economic relations and today's geopolitical realities; some of the most recent dynamics (alternative tourism, Smart Tourism Technologies, international awards) will be analyzed through a critical approach applied to the tangible effects of tourist flows and spaces on the construction of images of tourist "landscapes". 
At the end of the course, students will have an in-depth overview of the most recent considerations on the geography of tourism at an international level, in particular with regard to the cultural and environmental sustainability of the tourism phenomenon in Italy. Thanks to the workshop hours, they will also acquire the tools for an initial planning of cultural and environmental tourist itineraries, also through thematic cartography.

data.name: Laboratory of Internet of Things
data.description:
The course provides an overview of the main platforms and technologies for the development of Internet of Things (IoT) products and services including devices for sensing, actuation, processing, and communication. The course will improve the design skills and experiences to employ in developing novel systems. The course has theory and lab sections and the lab sections consist of hands-on and practical IoT exercises of fast prototyping sensing, actuation and communication for IoT devices with WiFi-microcontrollers and multi-core programmable platforms (e.g. the Raspberry Pi Platform).


After completing the course, the students should be able to lead and conduct the

development process of data-driven IoT-enabled services or products, more specifically:

a. Acquire the necessary knowledge and thinking of collaborating with developers and engineers throughout the design process.

b. Integrate data science and software engineering methods in the design process to develop innovative IoT products and services.

c. Identify and select appropriate development tools and use them effectively throughout the development process.

d. Use statistical data methods to generate insights and knowledge from IoT data and make it intelligible for stakeholders.

e. Balance the interests of users, business and societal challenges regarding to ethical data issues such as data privacy, data confidentiality, data quality, data ownership, etc.

data.name: Valutazione economica dei progetti

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
Expected learning outcomes
Knowledge of the notions of economics and appraisal relevant to the activities of the engineer in the fields of development, conservation, and management of the man-made environment, with particular attention to the estimation of construction costs and the accounting of the works.

Knowledge and understanding
Acquisition of the technical lexicon of the valuation sector, of the paradigms of the discipline, of the operational logic, and of the legislation that conforms to the valuation sphere with respect to commercial and non-commercial goods.

Ability to apply knowledge and understanding
Knowledge of the sources that generate the data for value and cost estimates, knowing how to read and interpret documents and information to be included in the evaluation, being able to translate into a technical report (appraisal, bill of quantities, measurement booklet, or other) the logical phases of the valuation judgment.

Autonomy of judgment
Ability to discern the practical reason posed by the question, to select the estimation procedure based on the availability of data and the legal-economic characteristics of the asset being valued.

Communication skills
Knowing how to relate to experts from other disciplines, develop and cultivate team spirit, communicate the results of one's work in clear and effective terms.

Ability to learn
Being able to apply the methodological principles to the multiple and different areas of competence of the Discipline. Update their preparation in accordance with the development of analysis and information processing tools and the evolution of the reference regulatory framework.

data.name: Data Analysis and Statistics
data.description: The course is divided in two sections. The first one aims at introducing the concepts of data analysis by providing the students with the tools needed for describing a population via graphical representations and summary measures. The second one develops the basic elements of elementary probability theory and statistical inference, with the goal of inferring properties of a population from a sample. All the methods will be illustrated via real-data analysis and Monte Carlo simulations.

data.name: Laboratori

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.degreeProgram: Gestione delle diversità: inclusione ed equità (GEDIE) (M1)

data.name: Visual brain and design

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The objective of the course is to provide the basis for understanding the neural mechanisms underlying visual perception and visual attention so as to optimize visual design strategies from a neural perspective.

Initially, the study of several cognitive neuroscience paradigms will allow students to understand the general neural principles of visual and attentional systems, and to identify the neural processes most relevant to visual design. Next, the students will be directly involved in the perceptual assessment of webpages and mobile apps on the basis of learned neural principles.

At the end of the course, the students will know the general neurophysiological mechanisms underlying visual perception and attention, and will be able to analyze the implementation of visual interfaces on the basis of their efficacy in optimizing visual, attentional and cognitive processes from a neural perspective.

data.name: Turbulence in environmental flows

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.degreeProgram: Ingegneria per l'ambiente e il territorio (LM)

data.name: Gestione sostenibile delle risorse naturali
data.description:
Objective of the course is the acquisition of knowledge and skills relating to the sustainable management of renewable natural resources in a multi-functional perspective, also including the tourism function.

Attendance and active participation at three training activities offered by the course (lectures, seminars, mono-disciplinary laboratory) and self-study will enable students:
describe the natural resource management policies
compare natural resource management systems
compare models of natural resources governance 
interpret a natural resources management plan 
discover the relevant functions of natural resources to manage in a multifunctional perspective
organize and integrate data and information for natural resource management
discover management actions
evaluate a project of multi-functional management of a natural resource at local level

Regarding soft skills, active participation in all the proposed training activities make students able to organize a teamwork, apply problem solving techniques and presenting results by properly arguing.
data.degreeProgram: Management della sostenibilità e del turismo (LM)

data.name: Scientific computing
data.description:
Scientific computing is an important skill for any student of mathematics. 
 It requires both knowledge of algorithms and proficiency in an appropriate 
 programming language. The aim of this course is to introduce students 
 to efficient algorithms to solve various problems in the 
 mathematical sciences, and to enable them to implement these algorithms
 in a modern programming language.
 The objectives are that by the end of the course all students should have a 
 good familiarity with the essential elements of the Python programming 
 language, and be able to undertake programming tasks in a range of common 
 areas. Students will also be exposed to C++ as an example for a compiled
 programming language, and will appreciate the benefits of object oriented
 programming.

data.name: Teorie e tecniche delle comunicazioni di massa e digitali

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
The course has two complementary objectives. On the one hand, it aims to provide students with an overview of the main theories and approaches of study in the field of mass and digital communication processes. On the other, it aims to provide a systematic introduction to the study of the main dynamics of representation and participation in the current hybrid media ecosystem. Upon completion of the course, students will be able to:

1) Know and recognize the foundational elements of the study of communication processes as it has developed in relation to mass media

2) Know and recognize the peculiarities of the current hybrid communication context and understand some fundamental nodes of study that characterize it

3) Conceptually connect perspectives of analysis developed in different communicational contexts, recognizing traits of continuity and discontinuity over time

4) Reflect critically on the contemporary practices and study of mass and digital communication at the intersection of different theories

5) Apply the approaches outlined in the course to understand and analyze present and past political dynamics.

data.name: German Language Workshop
data.description:
To reach the level of B2 in German, students attend classes at the University Language Centre (CLA). The syllabi and course descriptions along with information regarding the final exam 'Prova di conoscenza' (Faculty Language Examination) can be viewed on the CLA website. http://www.unitn.it/en/cla
For any doubts or questions regarding the German Language Workshop contact catherine.riley@unitn.it
data.degreeProgram: EUROPEAN AND INTERNATIONAL STUDIES - STUDI EUROPEI E INTERNAZIONALI (LM)

data.name: Storia greca I - LM
data.description:
The specific educational aims of the course "War and peace in Ancient Greek poleis and ‘federal states’" are: 
 
-to develop students' knowledge and understanding of interpoleic relations, including in the ‘federal states’, with an emphasis on border wars and arbitrations
-to provide the intellectual tools needed to critically discuss the potential for conflict resolution by ‘federal states’
-to stimulate awareness of the 'Mediterranean' perspective of Greek history, with a particular focus on the so-called Magna Graecia (understood in its broad Mediterranean context of movements and connections)
-to provide the intellectual tools needed to critically discuss the relevant historical events 

Learning outcomes: 

a. Knowledge and understanding 
Students are expected 
-to get familiar with interpoleic relations, with an emphasis on border relations, including in ‘federal states’. 
-to understand the main problems related to the development and mechanisms of decision-making in ancient Greek ‘federal states’ 
-to get familiar with the formation processes, Mediterranean connections and historical-political developments in Magna Graecia

b. Skills. Students are expected: 
-to read and critically assess primary and secondary source materials and evaluate different sources of information 
-to recognize historical problems and to formulate their own questions about major historical issues concerning Ancient border relations 
-to develop their ability to approach historical problems with academic rigour 
-to develop their ability to approach the potential for conflict resolution by ‘federal states’
-to develop their ability to recognise the complexity of the Mediterranean connections and the forms of cultural exchange in Magna Graecia

data.name: Applied Immunology

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description:
The aim of the course is fourfold. First, it provides  students with the understanding of basic immunology including, innate immune responses and adaptive immunity. Second, the course offers the students an overview on the mechanisms of vaccine-induced immune responses, on how vaccines are designed and formulated, and  on the economics of vaccination. Moreover, details on the main vaccines currently in use for the prophylaxis of the main human diseases are provided. Third, the course covers the topics of cancer immunotherapy, and offers an understanding of the main immunotherapeutic strategies current in use to fight cancers. the role of microbiome in cancer development is also covered. Finally, the course allows the students to understand the mechanisms of allergy and autoimmune diseases 
At the end of this course, students will be able to:
a) Describe the difference between the different types of immune responses
b) Understand how vaccine are designed 
c) Understand the mechanisms of action of vaccines
d) Understand the role of the immune system in cancer and how our immune system can be exploited to develop anti-cancer therapies.
e) Describe the mechanisms of allergy and autoimmunity 
f) Describe the current strategies to fight allergy and autoimmunity

data.name: Informatica
Basi di dati
data.description:
We live in a world full of data. Almost every human activity nowadays produces data or needs access to data. As such, there is a need for effective and efficient solutions that will allow us to store, maintain, search and retrieve large volumes of data. This is what the data management systems do. The goal of this course is to teach the students the fundamental concepts of data  management, to train them in order to be able to design of good databases, give them the ability to build complex queries, and allow them to identify and solve performance problems in real life situations. 
Naturally the course focuses on relational databases since the relational model is the one that drives most of the existing data management systems in the industry nowadays, it has been around for more than 30 years and has been one of the most studied model, and has been the one with the most commercial tools in operation.

data.name: Lab. appl.: Gli atti processuali nel diritto amministrativo
data.description:
The workshop aims at providing a practical and case-oriented approach to administrative procedural law, through the acquisition of the basic skills required for the drafting of procedural documents.
The workshop also intends to guide students in the use of the main legal databases

data.name: Politica dei servizi sociali

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description: a
data.degreeProgram: Metodologia, Organizzazione e Valutazione dei Servizi Sociali (LM)

data.name: Corso di tedesco B1b - I periodo (estensivo)
Industrial Economics
data.description:
The course aims to provide the analytical basis for understanding business strategy and the competitive dynamics of markets and economic sectors. The topics will be analyzed using the tools provided by the modern theory of industrial organization.

The study of strategic interactions between companies and their relations with industrial policy and with regulations to protect competition occupies an important place.

At the end of the course the student will be able to:

- identify and explain the factors that influence the structure of markets and economic sectors;

- analyze the behavior and strategic conduct of companies in more or less competitive contexts;

- understand the implications of industrial policies, competition protection, and regulation.

data.name: Corso di tedesco A2a - I periodo (estensivo)
Machine learning

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description:
The aim of the course is to provide knowledge of both theoretical and practical aspects of machine learning, and present the main techniques of machine learning and probabilistic reasoning.


At the end of the course, students will be able to:


- describe the main machine learning techniques, with their characteristics and limitations


- master probabilistic reasoning techniques


- model simple probabilistic scenarios with Bayesian Networks


- realize learning programs tailored to the specific problem to be addressed.

data.name: Computer vision

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: The course aims to provide the student with an in-depth overview on the methods of analysis and management of multimedia data. Starting from the basics of image and video processing, the course will focus on the problems of motion modeling and detection, motion tracking, and object recognition, both by using monocular and multi-view systems.

data.name: Corso di cinese A1a - I periodo (estensivo)
Storia della lingua italiana II
data.description:
The course aims to refine the understanding and ability of textual and linguistic analysis of female students / students of the master's degree in a field that can be examined from various points of view and with different methods: the modern Venetian.

At the end of the course students will have to be able to: a) recognize the phonetic, morphological, syntactic and lexical features of the Venetian; b) analyze texts, literary and non-literary, with particular attention to communicative interaction (pragmatic features) and the varieties of the diasystem; c) analyze idiomatic and multilingualism with the use of specific vocabularies.

As part of the innovative teaching initiatives promoted by the CeASUm for the project on spoken Italian (head of Prof.ssa Baggio) and for teaching training, LM students are also offered exercises on the use of our Phonetics Cabinet with Dr. Fabio Ardolino (Experimental Phonetics).

data.name: Mechanics and materials for engineering design
data.description:
One of the most important subjects for any student of materials engineering is the behavior of materials, mechanical components and structures under load. The way in which they react to applied forces, the resulting deflections and the stresses and strains set up in the bodies concerned are all vital considerations when designing a mechanical component such that it will not fail under predicted load during its service lifetime. All the essential elements of a treatment of these topics are contained within this course, starting with the concepts of mechanics of materials (stresses-strains, beam theory, thick cylinders, plasticity, fracture mechanics) and moving on to the examination of strength and stiffness verifications on mechanical components such as cylinders, joints, springs, shafts, bearings and mechanical transmissions.

By the end of this course students should: (1) be able to analyze the stress and strain on mechanical components and understand, identify and quantify failure modes for mechanical parts; (2) know basic machine elements used in machine design and design machine elements to withstand the loads and deformations for a given application, while considering additional specifications; (3) be able to approach a design problem successfully, taking decisions when there is not a unique answer; (4) be familiar with team-working, mathematical computing and CAD software; (5) be able to present analyses in a proper format of a written report such that a technically qualified person can follow and obtain similar findings.

data.name: Disegno industriale
data.description: Technical drawing is an essential tool to communicate in the industrial field. The aim of this course is to give future engineers the foundations of drawing mechanical components and assemblies, particularly focusing on dimensions, dimensional tolerances, roughness, manufacturing and so on, according with the existing standards. By this way they can usefully work along with designers, technical and commercial staff (concurrent engineering).

data.name: Diritto penale dell'economia
data.description: The objective of this course is that of examining the main aspects of criminal law legislation as applied to the activity of enterprises. In this connection, particular attention will be devoted to the examination of the treatment of offenses in bankruptcy, corporate and tax legislation. At the end of the course the student will be able to: (a) discern the problems inherent in the identification of persons that are to be considered as criminally liable; (b) identify the potential criminal behavior that can be committed in the activity of enterprises; (c) assess possible criminal responsibility of the professional profiles

data.name: Pensiero ebraico I
Softwarized and Virtualized mobile networks

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The main objective of the course is to describe how softwarization will transform the mobile networks of the future. In the course, the major families of wireless networks in use (WLANs, Cellular Networks and Satellite Networks) will be described and the virtualization and softwarization techniques on such infrastructures will be then introduced. The architectural description of such systems will be aligned with the description of the major communication protocols in all the above architectures. By the end of the course, the student should be able to: 
1) know and design the main architectural components of WLANs, cellular networks and other wireless networks;
2) define new protocols and network paradigms to advance the state-of-the-art
3) understand the network virtualization techniques and be able to effectively use such concepts

data.name: Economia e gestione aziendale
data.description:
The course wishes to offer students  basic concepts and operational tools to make economic choices on farm machines and on risk management.
At the end of the course, the student will to be able to: a) determine the gross and net income of the farm; b) take the decision to purchase or rent farm machines and equipment; c) manage different types of risks; d) set up a sequential problem with different chronologically linked stages.

data.name: Inglese giuridico C1
data.description:
General Learning Outcomes

This is a language course, not a law content course as the Law Faculty modules are. Legal topics and concepts are used in the course as vehicles to explore legal language. 

While a selection of legal terminology in each legal topic area is presented throughout the course, mastering legal English requires more than simply improving your knowledge of specialized vocabulary. 

By the end of the course the students should have acquired an enhanced knowledge of the main features of legal English, aspects of specialized lexis; the importance of legal collocations and formal register, considering different degrees of formality in text types within the large genre of legal English.

The course is based on the assumption that, in order to profit from the mobility programs/exchanges available in foreign universities, the needs of the students lie predominantly in improving their speaking skills, in addition to listening and reading comprehension strategies; therefore an essential component of the course is learning to produce and deliver an effective oral presentation of a legal topic. 

Due to constraints of time, written production and in particular legal drafting is not prioritized, although there are opportunities during the course to practice formal letter-writing, such as emails of advice, replies to letters before action and letters of application/motivation, which are marked and feedback given.

Specific Learning Outcomes

This course is focused on improving your language skills at the C1 level. This course will:
Strengthen speaking skills and enable students to engage more effectively in a range of speaking situations typical of the study of law and the practice of law, such as client interviews or discussions with colleagues and fellow students;
Improve the ability to read, understand, and applying analyze a range of legal texts, such as legislation and legal correspondence;
Improve comprehension of spoken English when it is used to speak about legal topics in lectures, presentations, interviews, and discussions appropriate to C1 level; and
Improve the ability to write basic but accurate legal correspondence.

Students will also improve their abilities to:
use legal language confidently and accurately, based on the knowledge of collocations and specific lexis acquired over the course;
make appropriate choices in register, based on the knowledge acquired over the course; and
use a range of databases, online dictionaries and legal resources, including an introduction to using linguistic corpora.

data.name: Concurrency

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The focus of the course is on shared-memory concurrency, which is orthogonal to distributed concurrency.

The course covers fundamental algorithms, impossibility results, and classic verification techniques from the literature on concurrency.

At the end of the course, students will have a general knowledge about concurrency and multithreading at work in shared-memory models.

Most importantly, they will develop the ability to reason about what can go wrong under concurrent interference, and about what can be safely made more efficient by concurrent co-operation.

data.name: Agiografia - LM
data.description: The course aims to offer students a scientific preparation on the following theme: Between action and contemplation: the "Vita Roberti" of Marbodo of Rennes. At the end of the course, students are expected to be able to: 1) frame the text historically 2) translate and interpret the selected passages correctly (Knowledge of Latin is not required for "Art" students. See below: prerequisites).

data.name: International accounting
data.description:
Upon completion of the module students will: 
- know the differences in financial measurement and reporting practices that exist internationally, the reasons for these differences and their resultant financial statement effects:
- have learnt how to use the financial statements in order to evaluate the firm’s past and present performance and to predict likely future outcome;
- have developed analytical skills when using standard financial statement analysis tools including accounting analysis and ratio analysis based on financial statements that use different accounting standards.

data.name: Introduction to Economics
data.description:
The course aims to provide an introduction to economics as a scientific discipline, acquiring its main concepts and methods, and applying them to the behaviour of individuals and to the functioning of markets and the economic system as a whole.This will allow the student to understand how economists organize their thoughts when they are to think about the world around them, and understand how economic thinking allows us to address and solve some of the most important issues that a modern society faces.
By the end of the course, the student is expected to be familiar with the language of economics and the main methods and models used in this field. In addition, the student should be able to apply these methods and models to analyze situations that occur daily in a modern market economy and to critically consider the potential benefits, limits, and consequences of economic policies.

data.name: Sensing and Radar Technologies
data.description:
This course provides basic and advanced concepts as well as design capabilities in the framework of systems based on remote sensing (from satellites, airborne and UAV platforms), proximal sensing, in-situ (ground) sensing, and ancillary data for environmental monitoring, climate change analysis, civil protection, infrastructure monitoring, remote surveillance and planetary exploration. It introduces remote sensing methodologies, technologies and techniques that are fundamental for the design of the above-mentioned systems with the last generation of optical and radar sensors. It describes the approach to the design and implementation of systems for several applications and operative scenarios, including the design criteria for the choice of the sensors, the system architecture and data analysis techniques complementary to more general artificial intelligence and machine learning techniques presented in other mandatory courses.
There is a large part of the course that is common to all the students and another part (section 2) for which each attendee can select one between two modules: Module a) basics concepts in remote sensing and technologies for the acquisition of optical and radar images; or Module b) advanced concepts and design criteria for Earth observation and planetary exploration satellite missions. It is suggested that students that have not attended any basic remote sensing course follow Module a) while the others select Module b).
The theoretical lectures are complemented by practical examples on real systems including laboratory activities.

data.name: Intelligent distributed systems
data.description:
The instructional goals of the course is to acquire a comprehensive overview of the distributed systems for measurement and automation used today in industrial and service application domains. The course focuses on the most advanced technological solutions adopted in industry as well as on the theoretical aspects that arise when control or estimation are applied in a distributed context. Particular emphasis will be given to robotic perception using Artificial Intelligence techniques to be applied to robotic problems.

During the course, the focus will be on the design and implementation of distributed estimators to be used for intelligent autonomous systems in industrial and service environments, analyzing the resulting problems from both a practical and theoretical point of view. Examples of the application of these techniques on real or realistic systems will be presented during the course.

At the end of the course, the student will be able to:

- Understand the complexity, the issues and the potentialities of distributed systems;

- Compare the various different technological solutions available for a distributed system;

- Evaluate and analyze the practical and theoretical implications of a distributed measurement and/or perception system;

- Analyse and design the distributed solution for a particular system;

- Critically asses the benefits and the limitations of a distributed solution.

data.name: Letteratura artistica
data.description: This course introduces students to the historical moment in which we witness the formation of what later on becomes present-day science. This course introduces students to several ways in which art and scientific collections participated in the cultural acceptance of the New Science and represent universalisti ideas focusing on the display of nature and culture.

data.name: Logica e ragionamento

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description: The course provides a general overview of the topics and research methods employed in the study of Logic and Psychology of Reasoning. At the end of the course, students are expected to be able to determine the inferential structure of arguments, to draw their logical implications, and to identify possible reasoning fallacies.

data.name: People, Politics and the Planet
data.description:
Upon completion of this module students are expected to have acquired the following: 
1)	An understanding of major discourses of environmental politics.
2)	Knowledge of a variety of contemporary issues in global environmental politics.
3)	An understanding of a range of multilateral environmental agreements and their impacts for national and local politics.
4)	An understanding of the range of key actors in global environmental politics at the local, national and international levels. 
5)	The ability to apply critical thinking skills to the analysis of complex governance approaches to environmental problems.
6)	Consider how global environmental politics affects local experiences, and how civil society actions at different territorial levels may shape, and be shaped in turn by, global environmental politics. 

In addition, students who successfully complete this module should gain the following transferable skills:
7)	The ability to learn independently and to assume responsibility for the learning process.
8)	Broad academic skills in the areas of critical reading and analysis, library and online research, note-taking and time management.
9)	Confidence in participating respectfully in class discussion and dialogue.
10)	Skills in written academic argument and confidence in crafting academic papers of an appropriate standard of written academic English.
11)	Understanding of issues relating to academic research – evaluating research sources, research methodologies, citation of research materials, management of materials and the avoidance of plagiarism and intellectual dishonesty.
data.degreeProgram: EUROPEAN AND INTERNATIONAL STUDIES - STUDI EUROPEI E INTERNAZIONALI (LM)

data.name: Marketing_
data.description: The aim of the course is to develop the basis of marketing and to understand his strategic and operative role in a company. At the endo of the course students will be able to apply the inter-functional approach to define strategic and operational politics of marketing and to value the impact of ICT on marketing's decisions. The course dedicates part of the lessons to digital marketing, introducing the necessary concepts of analytics for web decision making. To this end, some artificial intelligence (AI) algorithms will also be introduced for opinion and text mining applications.

data.name: Academic writing
Lingua e traduzione spagnola e letteratura spagnola II
data.degreeProgram: Letterature euroamericane, traduzione e critica letteraria (LM)

data.name: Instabilità delle strutture

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
The course aims to deepen some aspects just mentioned in the course of Strength of Materials (such as the instability structures due to axial load), and examining new ones, with particular reference to the foundations of the theory of stability elastic structures.
In the course, attention is focused on various instability phenomena that may involve both isolated structural elements and structures as a whole (collapse due to instability of frames or arches), which the designer of structures should be aware, especially when faced with light structures.
At the end of the course the student will be able to: (i) understand and interpret the various types of structural instability with particular reference to conservative and non-conservative systems; (ii) calculate the critical load and analyze the post-critical behavior of discrete structures; (iii) apply non-linear second-order structural analysis for calculating the critical load / limit load of single beams, plates and beam systems; (iv) apply numerical methods (Rayleigh-Ritz and Finite Elements) for the approximate calculation of the critical load of slender structures.

data.name: Behavioural Economics

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
Behavioral economics is a relatively new branch of economics that aims to improve the descriptive and the predictive power of the economic analysis by integrating agents’ limited cognitive abilities and limited willpower that, together with informational incompleteness, cause agents to behave sub-optimally.
This course offers an overview of the theories and the empirical results in the Behavioral Economics field allowing students to orientate themselves towards future deeper elaborations into this field of research. More specifically, the course is aimed to provide students with the opportunity to: 1) acquire a general overview of several major topics and empirical evidence in Behavioral Economics; 2) learn the basic tools for designing and carrying out a Behavioral Economics experiment; 3) acquire the basic skills for applying the Behavioral Economics insights to real world applications

data.name: Ecologia applicata

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description: Aim of the course is to explore Applied Ecology, the branch of Ecology that uses the principles and the concepts of Base ecology to predict and manage the environmental changes caused by human impact on natural ecosystems. Applied Ecology includes natural resource conservation, natural flora and fauna management, water resource management, pest management, pollution and ecotoxycology, natural landscape change, climate change and global warming. Applied ecology and biodiversity study are profoundly intertwined, both in the monitoring phases and in the management choices. The recent and far past clearly shows that technical and engineering choices cannot ignore environmental and ecological sustainability, to avoid the repetition of dramatic disasters like desertification of vast areas, river rectification, Vajont, Stava, Lambro and Danube poisoning, radioactive poisoning in north and south Germany, Tchernobyl and Fukushima, plastic and micro-plastic sea and soil pollution. All these disasters will result in huge costs in environmental, economical terms and they will often directly affect local population health condition. The major causes of the current important economic crisis are due to an environmental crisis that lead to a lack of resources exacerbated by human induced Climate change. This picture was generated by overexploitation and inefficiency in the use of natural resources, caused by the underestimation of the consequences of environmental problems to ecosystem services in an holistic vision. The course will deal with the environments in temperate and boreal climates and with the tropical and subtropical regions. The course will deal with theoretical fundamental elements and practical examples to understand Applied Ecology, giving hints about future developments of this science. Among the topics treated in the course: Ecocertification, biomonitoring, Biosensors, GIS, dynamic landscape modeling, definition of criteria for protected areas planning and management. Species distribution models and prediction of future landscape change with Markov Chains and Cellular automata will be treated. Seminars held by experts and visits to Applied Ecology offices will be organized. The students shall be able to apply Applied Ecology knowledge to understand the consequences of anthropic disturbance on environment and ecosystems. They shall be able to know monitoring field and modeling tools that can help the management of applied ecology. The students will be requested to write an original research paper treating and analyzing a specific topic in a critical perspective.
data.degreeProgram: Ingegneria per l'ambiente e il territorio (LM)

data.name: Ethics for computer science and engineering

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: Explore the contemporary ethics of computer science and engineering with thought experiments, discussions, and case studies. Students will learn the central ethical principles guiding today’s information technology, and apply the theory in the real world. Ultimately, students will be equipped to respond to ethics committees, to develop an ethical understanding of their own work, and to produce ethical evaluations of technological projects.

data.name: Diritto delle reti di imprese
data.description:
The course will introduce the students to the main legal forms of inter-firm cooperation, as organisation models used to define the supply chain, both in the production and in the distribution phases, based on long-term collaboration and now recollected not only as economic models but also under a specific legal form of “inter-firm networks”.

The course includes four sessions. The first part will be devoted to the legal framework of business collaboration and of inter-firm networks, distinguishing those forms from the so called market relationships, which focus on the instant exchange of resources. The second part will analyse the main legal forms of business collaboration and inter-firm networks. The third part will focus on the in-depht study of the tax and labor law profiles.of inter-firm networks. In the latter part of the course students will be invited to present and discuss the main findings of a case study concerning a specific network.

At the end of the course, the student will be able to:

1.        understand and distinguish between the different objectives that firms can pursue through the creation and contractual regulation of a strategic collaboration;

2.        identify the main legal forms of these collaborations, in particular distinguishing between contractual forms, organizational and mixed forms;

3.        identify the main sources of legal rules applicable to relationships of strategic collaboration organized in the form of a network;

4.        know and employ adequate criteria of choice to identify the most appropriate legal instrument for the objectives pursued and relevant contextual elements;

5.        argue the use of these criteria on the basis of an appropriate legal and economic analysis;

6.        identify the main features of the legal instruments aimed at regulating the operation of contractual networks, with particular regard to the network contract, the franchise and the consortium, and outline, in its baselines, the contractual design which distinguishes them;

7.        address legal issues related to the functioning of network relationships, in particular with regard to the promotion of cooperative behaviour, the prevention and reduction of the risks of opportunism, and the liability resulting from torts.

8. identify the main tax implications deriving from the use of some legal forms for inter-firm collaboration, as well as address the main issues concerning the management of employment relationships in network contexts, with particular reference to the use of tools such as “distacco agevolato” and “codatorialità”, specifically provided for the network contract (contratto di rete).

data.name: Fondamenti di elaborazione dei segnali

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.name: Economia dei mercati e degli intermediari finanziari
data.description:
The course aims to train students to understand the financial contracts issued by intermediaries and / or traded in financial markets. 
The first part of the program will examine the contracts "to confidential information" (deposits, bank loans, factoring, leasing, etc.), the second part of the course instead of listed financial instruments (money market, bonds, equity, foreign exchange and derivatives), the third part of the course will examine the insurance contracts (life insurance) and the last part of the course the logical construction of the portfolios (portfolios and asset management tools). 
At the end of the course, the student will be able to: 
1. know the characteristics of the main contracts for confidential information; 
2. know the risk and return profile of market instruments (money market, bonds, equity, foreign exchange and derivatives) 
3. understand the purpose of insurance contracts and the underlying logic; 
4. understand how portfolio and asset management products can help to reduce financial risks and their economic space of utilization.

data.name: Recycling and sustainable materials
data.description:
Objectives:

This course is focused on materials and the environment: the eco-aspects of materials’ production, use, and disposal at end of life. The course also provides an overview of materials selection and design approaches that minimize the environmental impact.

 

After completing the course, the student will be able to:

- assess the sustainable development of a given articulation following a rigorous procedure;

- select an eco-sustainable material on the basis of its property profile and interaction with the environment;

- measure the main properties of biopolymers and wood-related materials according to the relevant standards;

- design a component taking the most suitable end-of-first-life options into proper account;

- design a life cycle assessment analysis on a practical case.

 

 

Learning outcomes:

At the end of the course, the student should be able to:

·      illustrate the concept of sustainable development and the ways in which it is evaluated for a given articulation;

·      explain the physical-mechanical properties and the applications of wood-related materials and materials for thermal insulation;

·      classify and compare the various families of biopolymers and their properties in the different applications, in order to select the best candidate material for a given application;

·      illustrate the recycling methods for the various materials, highlighting the pros and the cons of each of them;

·      explain the life cycle assessment (LCA) methodology in its theoretical and practical aspects

·      produce and characterize eco-sustainable materials, analyze the experimental data, and generate a technical report with the results and discussion of the analysis.

data.name: Databases

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
We live in a world full of data. Almost every human activity nowadays produces data or needs access to data. As such, there is a need for effective and efficient solutions that will allow us to store, maintain, search and retrieve large volumes of data. This is what the data management systems do. The goal of this course is to teach the students the fundamental concepts of data  management, to train them in order to be able to design of good databases, give them the ability to build complex queries, and allow them to identify and solve performance problems in real life situations. 
Naturally the course focuses on relational databases since the relational model is the one that drives most of the existing data management systems in the industry nowadays, it has been around for more than 30 years and has been one of the most studied model, and has been the one with the most commercial tools in operation.

data.name: Architettura e tecniche per l'edilizia sostenibile

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
Aim of the course is to provide students with methods and tools for the proper design and realization of different building typologies with high human inner comfort conditions, though respecting/using the surrounding environment. Issues regarding building sustainability, indoor comfort conditions, design of passive solar elements for warming and cooling are presented and discussed, in the frame of emerging Edilizia 4.0 iniziative, in a perspective of circularity and resilience of interventions.

After the course, the student will be able to: know an understand the the main theoretical concepts of indoor comfort and passive energy issues in buildings; design a housing or office building with attention to holistic indoor comfort conditions; define bioclimatic strategies for warming and cooling of the indoor environment; design, calculate and solve issues concerned with passive elements in buildings.

data.name: Steelmaking and foundry technologies
data.description:
The course aims to explain the main structural and functional aspects of steel-making plants for the production of semi-finished products, as a function of the required microstructural quality.

After completing the course, the students will be able to carry out preliminary mass and heat balances of these systems, and to manage the flow of material and energy efficiency of the processes.

Students will gain the ability to manage the steel casting processes (with particular emphasis to continuous casting), and the ability to understand the origin of possible product defects and then select appropriate solutions.

Students will know the operation of the main foundry processes (relative to steel, cast iron and Al alloys), and will be able to carry out a preliminar design of the sand casting process and to manage the pressure die-casting of aluminum alloys (including a cost evaluation).

Students will be able to identify the main environmental constraints of the studied systems.


Numerical exercises and a visit to an industrial factory are an important part of the course.

data.description:
The main objective of the course is to describe how softwarization will transform the mobile networks of the future. In the course, the major families of wireless networks in use (WLANs, Cellular Networks and Satellite Networks) will be described and the virtualization and softwarization techniques on such infrastructures will be then introduced. The architectural description of such systems will be aligned with the description of the major communication protocols in all the above architectures. By the end of the course, the student should be able to: 
1) know and design the main architectural components of WLANs, cellular networks and other wireless networks;
2) define new protocols and network paradigms to advance the state-of-the-art
3) understand the network virtualization techniques and be able to effectively use such concepts

data.name: Algebraic geometry I
data.description:
The course aim is to give an introduction to Algebraic Geometry.

    In particular the following topics will be treated:
    • Main definitions and foundational results (not all with a full proof): affine varieties, projective varieties, quasi-projective varieties, maps between them.
    • Projective curves and thei link to Riemann-Surfaces. Divisors, linear systems, Riemann-Roch (with a proof in the algebraic category), duality, Brill-Noether theory.
    • An introduction to schemes and sheaves.

    At the end of the course, in order to take the examination successfully, the student is expected:

    • To know and understand the definitions and the results presented during the course.
    • To be able to explain them also with examples and counterexamples and to give detailed and corrected proofs.
    • To use a correct and suitable mathematical language to treat the topics of the course.
    • To be able to recognize and use the links among the different topics.

data.description:
The course intends to provide students with theoretical elements and analytic tools to sociologically understand innovation processes. The aim of the course is to introduce students to the main theories and analytical approaches to innovation processes in order to acquire the ability to critically analyse both the social determinants of innovation and its social implications. At the end of the course students are expected to have acquired:

- The knowledge of the main analytical frameworks in innovation studies

- The ability to critically evaluate the different analytical frameworks

- The ability to recognise the social determinants of innovation

- The ability to critically analyse the social implications of innovation

- The ability to apply theoretical and analytical frameworks to the empirical analysis of innovation and innovation processes

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description:
This course wish to strengthen the chemical and physical knowledge about the chemistry of biological systems and giving a sweeping panorama of modern bio-analytical methods.
At the end of the course, the student will be able : 
a)	to understand the chemical foreground with particular emphasis to a more strict interpretation of intra- and intermolecular forces and to thermodynamics of the relevant chemical processes in biology.
b)	to move in the basic aspects of biological- physical chemistry by knowing the concepts of activity, ionic strength, chemical potential of species and by applying the principles of mass conservation and electroneutrality to the rigorous solution of acid-base, redox and complexation systems.
c)	to predict  the nature of intermolecular forces and their effect on macroscopic physical properties, in particular evaluate their presence and order their relative importance in chromatographic separation processes
d)	to know the basic principles of the most important spectroscopic techniques
e)	to predict the salient features of the UV spectra, IR, NMR and MS of biomolecules.
f)	to present and discuss, even in a popular context, chemical and biological problems with rigor,adequate language properties and competence by quoting the correct bibliographic sources

data.name: Negotiation
data.description:
“Let us never negotiate out of fear. But let us never fear to negotiate.” 
John F. Kennedy

Negotiations are an essential and fundamental moment in the life of individuals, organizations, institutions, and firms. In the last few decades, negotiation has moved from the industrial relations and political arena to the forefront of managerial interest. Negotiation, bargaining, and mediation traditionally refer to the arbitration of disputes between labour and management. However, scholars and practitioners now recognise that these skills operate in virtually every management function, including strategy formulation, mergers and acquisitions, purchasing, sales, international development and many others.

Negotiation is a common mechanism for resolving differences between and allocating resources among exchange partners such as supervisors, colleagues, corporate entities and even nations. Improving negotiation skills, as well as increasing the ability to negotiate effectively, is crucial in managerial, political, and business contexts.
This module explores the key aspects of negotiation. The primary aim of this module is to integrate negotiation theory and practice, through an integration of concepts, models, expertise and practical experience. It will typically examine, through a mix of theory and practice, the links among negotiation fundamentals, negotiation sub-processes and negotiation contexts.

Learning objectives

The purpose of this course is threefold. 
•	The first is to explore the major concepts and theories of negotiation, as well as the dynamics of interpersonal and intergroup conflict and its resolution. This will entail material about the structural (e.g. parties, issues, positions and interest) and process-oriented (cognitive, interactional) dynamics that are necessary for a sound critical background. 
•	The second objective is to develop skills relevant to a broad range of applied contexts. This involves direct training in identifying crucial elements of a negotiation situation and implementing appropriate resolution strategies. 
•	The third objective is to encourage participants to assume a “reflective” and “cooperative” posture about negotiations specifically and social influence broadly. 

On completion of the module you should be able to:

•	Analyse a negotiation situation and its possible solutions.
•	Identify the personal challenges we all have in dealing with negotiation.
•	Apply complex theory and practice of negotiation in particular and general contexts.

data.name: Conflict of Laws
data.description:
The course aims at providing knowledge of the basic elements of private international law, which is the body of rules applied by domestic courts in cases where a foreign element is present. The course takes mainly a European perspective, but, occasionally, extra-EU private international law rules are also considered by way of com-parison. In particular, by the end of the course students should:

- get acquainted with the complexity of cases involving more than one domestic legal system
- get familiar with the basic concepts relating to the functioning of the rules of private international law
- learn how the interplay of national (especially Italian), European and international rules of private international law works
- be able to determine which judge is competent to decide a case with a foreign element, in both commercial and non-commercial matters
- understand what law is applicable in cases with a foreign element, by identifying the correct conflict of laws rule
- know how issues pertaining to recognition and enforcement of foreign judgments are solved

data.name: Network Modeling and Simulation

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description:
Objectives

The student will learn about systems view of biological networks, where quantitative and dynamic considerations of biological properties are in the foreground. The biological entities will be studied with an emphasis on the emergent behavior resulting from the interactions of the network components. The student will thus be equipped with an interdisciplinary skill-set for studying such systems in a way that brings together notions from biology, applied mathematics and computer science.


Learning outcomes

At the end of the course the students will be able to:

a) Work on biological questions using analytical methods with the aim of providing systems level "holistic" answers.

b) Develop the critical thinking skills required to understand and evaluate the results introduced in a scientific paper in the area of modelling and simulation of biological dynamics.

c) Become familiar with a spectrum of techniques from applied mathematics and computer science with respect to their strengths and their limitations in various biological settings.

d) Use programming technologies to formalize various biological problems for simulation, sensitivity analysis and model calibration and choose the most appropriate computational strategy depending on the considered biological problem.

data.name: Sociologia urbana e Diritto urbanistico

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
The course aims to provide students with a series of fundamental notions concerning the legal discipline of territorial governance, in order to understand the interrelations between technical knowledge and legal knowledge in all activities concerning the use and transformation of soils .
The course therefore has two specific educational objectives.
The first objective is to provide students with a basic knowledge of the public institutions that deal with the government of the territory, within the coordinates provided by the Constitution and by the administrative organization of territorial bodies with specific expertise in the field (Regions, Autonomous Provinces, Municipalities and , albeit in residual terms, State administration).
From this point of view, the course therefore aims to provide the university and city student with a full knowledge of the role of law and legal organization in the overall management of public and private interests that revolve around the government of the territory.
The second objective is to provide students with an understanding of the procedures and acts through which the territorial governance is articulated: reference is made to the planning and planning tools provided by the state, regional and provincial urban planning regulations; to the strategic environmental assessment procedures provided for by Legislative Decree n. 152/2006; to the procedures for imposing landscape and historical-artistic constraints envisaged by Legislative Decree no. 54/2004; to the proceedings for the construction of the building titles provided for by the Presidential Decree n. 380/2001.
From this point of view, the course therefore aims to provide the future engineer or architect with a basic knowledge of the methods by which the technical knowledge acquired during university studies must be conveyed and translated into legal forms suitable for obtaining the guaranteed results.

data.name: Economics of Innovation Processes
International Trade and Competitiveness
data.description:
The goal of this course is to identify and to map, empirically and theoretically, the main phenomena of the current trade system in the global economy. The course provides insights into the reasons for trade at country and firm level, gains from trade, trade policy tools and international agreements, as well as contexts in which students can engage in debate, discussion, and reflections on the main issues related to trade policies.
By the end of the course students should have acquired:
•	An in-depth understanding of the different advantages and costs of trade from various viewpoints like country, sector and firm.
•	To identify, the main firm’s characteristics through adequate comparison by country, sector and firm of firms’ behavior and results.
•	To frame theoretical perspectives in analysing related policy questions, especially the effects of trade barriers and industry protection.
•	To understand the structure and functioning of international trading system and associated institutions (such as the WTO). 
•	To identify the reasons of the emergence of regional trade agreements and their consequences for firms’ behaviour in open economy.
•	To be familiar with info in the main websites and in the datasets utilized for empirical exercises (at least from WTO website).
