data.name: Fondamenti di robotica

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The landscape of robotics has gone through a deep change throughout the last decade. Up until the early years of this century, robots were seen as heavy and dangerous machines used to execute stiffly defined tasks within controlled and structured environments. The recent advances in artificial intelligence have had a profound impact on the type of tasks that a robot can perform and on the level of safety and reliability they can be executed with. Modern robots assist older adults or  impaired people, work side by side with human workers, drive on the highways with little or no assistance. This paradigm shift requires the robot to perceive and understand the situation in the surroundings, to autonomously plan a suitable course of actions for a task, and to see to its correct execution by properly reacting to unexpected events. 
To design a machine of this complexity, engineers need several competencies tapping diverse disciplines. Robots are physical machines created by humans, so their motion can be analysed and controlled through appropriate mathematical models. Robots move in a partially known environment, so they need to create a map of their surroundings, to localise themselves within the environment, to detect, classify and recognise the different objects they interact with. Robots are required to be autonomous or sem-iautonomous, so they need the ability to decide a sequence of actions (a plan), to implement it within appropriate safety bounds and to adapt it to changes as needed. Finally, robots embed computing machines that need to be programmed through appropriate languages and frameworks. 
The students will be introduced to each one of these different aspects and will receive the opportunity to put them into practice using our advanced educational laboratories and teaching facilities. After taking the course, they will be able to take on a career as developers of robotic applications and/or to continue with advanced studies in the area of intelligent robots.

data.name: Mathematical Modeling in Biology

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description:
The aim of the course is twofold: on the one hand, present the students several basic mathematical models in different areas of biology (enzymatic reactions, molecular and physiological networks, ecology, infectious diseases); on the other hand, provide operating competences in the analysis (linearization; equilibria and their stability; bifurcation; regular and singular perturbations) and numerical solution of ordinary differential equations.

The final part of the course will be devoted to the development of a group project on a subject presented during the course.

At the end of the course, students are expected to be able to build mathematical models for biological systems similar to those presented in the course, to perform simple qualitative analysis of systems of ordinary differential equations, to simulate systems of ordinary differential equations and of reaction-diffusion equations using Matlab. Moreover, thanks to the project to e developed, it is expected that all students will have improved in their ability to collaborate in an interdisciplinary setting, and to communicate the results that have been obtained.

data.name: Storia delle religioni
data.description: The History of Religions course aims to provide students with the fundamental contents, terminology, and methods of the discipline, reserving particular attention to the religions that have emerged and spread in Southeast Asia. In this way, the ability to critically reflect on the various issues relating to religions and the sciences of religions, on their meaning and their reciprocal connections, in a perspective of comparison and dialogue, will be enhanced, promoting the attitude to problematize the acquired knowledge through the recognition of its historical determination and educating respect for differences.

data.name: Stabilità dei pendii naturali e delle costruzioni in terra

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
At the end of the course, the students will be able to:

- Understand laboratory and insitu investigation methods to quantify the parameters needed for slope analysis

- Choose the most suitable method for slope stability analysis

- Carry out and differentiate slope stability analyses with different numerical methods

- Evaluate the suitability of different slope stabilization methods.
data.degreeProgram: Ingegneria per l'ambiente e il territorio (LM)

data.name: Design of digital production and assembly systems

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: The objective of this course is to provide students with the necessary competences for design and manage digital production and assembly systems which are typical of the novel manufacturing environment known as Industry 4.0. Mathematical models and quantitative methods are proposed to tackle the different aspect which distinguish such complex industrial systems, leveraging the opportunities that their digitization offers. Furthermore, advanced simulation techniques are prosed to let the students validate the design of production and logistic systems through a dynamic evaluation over time of their functioning through the adoption of professional software and tools.

data.name: Qualitative methods

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
The main aim of the course consists in acquiring the knowledge and skills necessary to the analysis of social and cultural phenomena through qualitative methods. The course aims at developing an analytical way of thinking, a peculiar "gaze" on social action and discourse based on interpretive, interactionist and phenomenological approaches and epistemologies.

The course aims at providing knowledge of the ethnographic tradition of social research and opportunities for practical experience of qualitative research. Students attending the course will carry out a qualitative research from start to finish, working in small groups. Their active participation will be required both in class and off class (e.g. fieldwork), both individually and in groups (see below).

At the end of the course, students will be able to:

  • design a research project in relation to a specific research question;
  • build research tools (interview guide, observation guide, focus group stimulus material, etc.);
  • apply several qualitative methods and techniques (ethnography and participant observation, in-depth interview, focus group, documentary analysis, visual methods, conversation analysis and video-based field studies);
  • analyse the diverse data collected through such methods (the Qualitative Methods Lab on the second semester will mainly serve such purpose);
  • present, both in oral and written form, the results of such an analysis.
data.degreeProgram: Sociology and social research - Sociologia e ricerca sociale (LM)

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.name: Archeologia e storia dell'arte greca
data.description:
This course is composed of two parts (Greek Archaeology and Art History and Roman Archaeology and Art History) and offers the students a broad overview of art and archaeology in the Greek and Roman worlds.
At the end of the course, students: 1. will have developed an overall knowledge of the main archaeological and artistic aspects of the Greek and Roman worlds; 2. will be able to discuss and analyse monuments and artworks presented to them through pictures and plans; 3. will have thorough awareness of the close relationships between artistic production and the historical and political context; 4. will have familiarised with the technical terminology.

data.name: Storia dei sistemi economici
data.description: At the end of the course students will be able to identify the fundamental dynamics of economic transformations from the preindustrial period to the present, with special regard to the industrialization processes. Moreover, students will be able to evaluate critically the complexity of economic systems, and the numerous factors which determined their evolution.

data.name: Filologia germanica II - LM
data.description:
The course aims at providing the students with basic knowledge of Middle High German
.
At the end of the course the students will be able:

a) to read texts in Middle High German with the aid of a dictionary
b) to analyze texts in Middle High German 
c) to recognize the relationship between the texts and the historical context in which they were produced.
data.degreeProgram: Letterature euroamericane, traduzione e critica letteraria (LM)

data.name: Gestione delle imprese
data.description: Concepts of business strategy and marketing. Main tools of strategy analysis and marketing mix analysis (product, price, promotion and place)

data.name: Letterature comparate - LT
data.description: The class aims to offer students formal, historical and interpretative tools for the study of lyric poetry. During the class, students will acquire historical and theoretical notions on the form of poetry through the study and analysis of exemplary texts and essays, so that, at the end of the class, students will be able to comment, analyze and discuss, on the one hand, the lyric text, and, on the other hand, to discuss the evolution of the lyric form from its origins to the present day. At the end of the course students will be able to contextualize the texts as historical phenomena, read them with the critical and theoretical tools of discipline, and to orient oneself among texts relating to the different national literatures.

data.name: Intelligenza artificiale e diritto
data.description:
The Course aims at giving the students a basic knowledge of ethical and legal principles in AI. We will analyse existing principles and ask ourselves whether they may be suitable to regulate AI or whether it is necessary to develop new ones. The AI act will receive particular attention.

At the end of the course, students will have legal and interdisciplinary skills that can guide them in carrying out their professional activity in a constitution-oriented and human-centered way.

In particular, the student will:

- Know the main ethical and legal principles of AI;

- Use the acquired skills to analyse and understand the ethical dilemmas and legal problems related to the use of AI;

- Know the main legal sources of AI in some relevant areas, such as autonomous vehicles, medicine or justice;

- Be aware of the potential and risks of an increasingly widespread and autonomous use of AI;

- Understand the importance of a plural debate and interdisciplinary approach in the study of AI

- Be able to participate actively in working groups and discussions on law and ethics of AI.

data.name: Letteratura del Rinascimento
data.description:
The course aims to provide students with a thorough knowledge of Italian Renaissance literature, to consolidate their skills in textual analysis and strengthen their ability to develop critical hypotheses autonomously.

At the end of the course, students will be able to:

-  contextualise and discuss with confidence authors and works from the early centuries of Italian literature (from the origins to the end of the sixteenth century);

-  paraphrase, analyse and comment upon medieval and Renaissance texts;

-  make appropriate use of the methods and competences required for the study of Renaissance texts;

-   adopt interdisciplinary approaches and interact with a range of scholarly traditions;

-   develop hypotheses with a significant degree of critical autonomy.

data.name: Tensor Decomposition for Big Data Analysis
data.description:
An introduction to big data science from the point of view of tensor decomposition.

The course will begin with concrete examples of big data problems. The central part of the course will be based on geometric structures for modeling the extraction of information from problems of large data collections. Part of the course will be devoted to computational aspects.

1. Knowledge and understanding skills.
Good knowledge of the basic arguments of tensor decomposition from the geometric point of view and concrete examples of big data.

2. Ability to apply knowledge and understanding.
Inductive and deductive reasoning ability to deal with issues that are provided individually or in a group from time to time.

3. Autonomy of judgment.
Ability to develop logical arguments and produce correct demonstrations. Ability to identify the most appropriate methods for analyzing, interpreting, and modeling information extraction issues from large data collections.

4. Communicative Skills.
Ability to expose subjects both at the written / computational level by carrying out exercises handed out by the instructor both at the oral level in the possible presentation of a topic taught at a lecture through a public seminar.

data.name: Laboratorio di sistemi informativi geografici e cartografia tematica
data.description: Students will learn the main features and functions of GIS software and in particular those for the production of thematic maps, a fundamental tool for geographical analysis and communication.

data.name: Equazioni differenziali ordinarie
data.description:
After attending the course, the students should know statements, proofs, examples and counterexamples related to the course topics.   
Moreover they should be able to:
1) apply such knowledge in order to solve exercises of the type considered by the teacher during the course;
2) expose synthetically the essential points of the proofs exposed in the course.

data.name: Geometry and Linear Algebra

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The course aims to

  • provide the basic elements of Linear Algebra, with applications to the geometry in three-dimensional space and to vector calculus.


At the end of the corse the student should:

  • have a good knowledge and understanding of the theory of finite dimensional real vector spaces, as described in the corse list of topics.
  • know the basic concepts, be able to explain and describe them also with examples, identify the connections between them.
  • be familiar with the mathematical tools which are needed to develop a suitable approach and solve Linear Algebra problems, such as, for example, operations between matrices, echelon form reduction algorithms, computation of determinants, of eigenvalues and eigenvectors.
data.degreeProgram: Ingegneria Informatica, delle Comunicazioni ed Elettronica (L2)

data.name: Calcolo delle probabilità

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: Introduction to probability and to statistics, as tools to understand non-deterministic phenomena. The course program consists of basic principles of probability. This course is introductory and aims at presenting methodologies for interpreting with probability phenomenas of causal nature. The course focus on general theoretical concepts and practical techniques, and aims at providing the student with good knowledge of how to use basic probability concepts.
data.degreeProgram: Ingegneria Informatica, delle Comunicazioni ed Elettronica (L2)

data.name: Lingua russa II
data.description:
The course will focus on some peculiarities of the Russian language and its culture, drawing on literary works written by well-known authors. The aim is to provide students with the linguistic tools for analysing an authentic (not simplified) text, with special attention to the verbal lexicon.

On successful attendance of language classes ("Esercitazioni Linguistiche"), students will also gain a basic knowledge of the language of tourism and intercultural mediation, as well as acquire a higher proficiency level in written and spoken Russian (slightly over B1).

data.name: Laboratorio di analisi dei mercati

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.name: Simulation and performance evaluation

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
Through lectures, homeworks, and the development of a final project, at the end of this course the student will be able to:
- correctly set up the characterization of a system through simulations, avoiding the most typical pitfalls
- structure the elements of a simulator
- empirically analyze a dataset, also using confidence and prediction intervals
- fit statistical models to data
- carry out and analyze the outcome of Monte-Carlo simulations
- build and employ discrete-time simulators
- analyze recent topics in the field of complex system simulation

data.name: Advanced Number Theory
data.description: The course has the goal to provide knowledge of modern tools and topics of number theory, which also have important applications in several fields (e.g., cryptography).

data.name: Industrial robotics
data.description: This course provides an overview of the field of industrial robots. Topics are mainly focused on aspects of representation, planning and control of motion of robotic manipulators. The student acquires theoretical and applied concepts of kinematics, statics, mechanism design, dynamics, simulation and basics of control architectures. Additionally, the course provides an outline of actuators, sensing, electronic components and control software architectures that are typically employed in industrial robots. During the course, the student learns to build simplified PC-based models of a robots and to handle problems for the modeling, design and control of robotic manipulators.

data.name: Sistemi meccanici e modelli
data.description:
Objectives:

- Introduce the fundamental principles for the analysis and simulation (Kinematics and Dynamics) of mechanical systems, both in 2D and 3D.

- Define models of forces acting on mechanical systems (among which forces arising at contact) and review the most frequent machine subsystems from the functional point of view. 

- Introduce the use of symbolic and numeric computation systems (Wolfram Mathematica) for the purpose of modelling mechanical systems.

- Introduce advanced topics such as the synthesis of mechanical systems, variational method for writing the equations of motions of systems, and basics of lubrication.


Learning outcomes. At the end of the course the students will be able to:

- Analyse a mechanism, derive the kinematic scheme, write and solve the equations of the kinematic problem.

- Analyse the actions applied to a mechanical system and write/solve the equations of the dynamics.

- Synthesise a mechanism.

- Build, analyse and document mathematical models of mechanical systems in Wolfram Mathematica.

data.name: Lab. appl.: Teoria e pratica della trascrizione delle conversazioni in contesti legali
data.description:
The laboratory is aimed at acquiring techniques of analysis of legal discourse from an interational point of view, meaning by this term the fact that interpersonal linguistic communication does not consist in an exchange of pre-established messages, but is the product of collaboration and negotiation among the participants.


The theoretical approach of the Analysis of the Conversation allows to understand the mechanisms of verbal interaction, observing in detail the "how" and "when" one says "what". The study approach can contribute to the strategic-rhetorical construction of the arguments.

data.name: Performance in Service: Managing Performance in Healthcare_
data.description:
By the end of the course the students should be able to: i) understand the complexity of the
governance of health care systems; ii) know the different frameworks in use at the
international level to analyze performance; iii) how to compare results; iv) how to work on
the determinants of performance ; v) the role of human resources management in healthcare

data.name: Semiotica della rappresentazione visiva

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description:
The course aims to provide students with methodological skills to tackle complex problem solving using design methodologies, applied to create communication systems, and specific skills for the design and implementation of communication products. Starting from the comprehension of signification processes and of their determinants (anthropological, social, relational, cognitive and emotional) the student will be guided to learn the principles of design and will be able to apply these principles to the design of communication systems. At the end of the course the student will also know the principles of graphic design with particular reference to the layout structure, color matching, text composition and treatment of vector and bitmap images. It will also be able to use the main functions of Indesign, Illustrator and Photoshop software for processing communication products.

Using the design thinking methodology to solving real problems will help students to develop soft cognitive, emotional and relational skills. Special attention will be given to the development of the ability to plan and organize, make decisions, manage relationships in a team to achieve a goal, manage stress, communicate effectively, have creative thinking.

data.name: Bio-Inspired Artificial Intelligence

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The goal of this course is to study two of the main paradigms of Bio-Inspired Artificial Intelligence, namely: Evolutionary Computation, inspired by evolutionary biology, and Swarm Intelligence, inspired by collective behaviors of social animals. First, the main theories and algorithms will be introduced. Then, it will be shown how these techniques can be applied, for instance, for solving complex optimization problems, training data-driven models, generating new contents (video-games, websites, art), finding bugs in software, automatically synthesizing or fixing computer programs, or finding innovative solutions in robotics, logistics, and engineering. Finally, it will be shown how these techniques can help the understanding of biological systems, in order to close the loop between biology and AI.

At the end of this course, students will be familiar with the most important Evolutionary Computation and Swarm Intelligence techniques, and will be able to apply them to different contexts in industry, research, or even entertainment. They will also know the fundamentals for developing new algorithms and adapt them to new problems.

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.name: Psicometria

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description:
The aim of the course is to give students an appropriate grounding in in measurement theory in the field of psychology and in the field of statistical data analysis, thereby providing them with the necessary knowledge required in order to develop the capacity to implement the main methods and models of statistical analysis used  in the psychological research. An understanding of the essential concepts and techniques of measurement and inferential statistics forms the essential core for the use of scientific methods in psychology and for the critical reading of books or articles related to research in the field of psychology.
At the end of the course, students will be able to:
1) interpret contextual information and select the appropriate tools for analysing the information
2) recognize phenomena governed by uncertainty
3) apply the tools to solve real problems
4) critically evaluate the tools used.
data.degreeProgram: Scienze e Tecniche di Psicologia Cognitiva (L2)

data.name: Diritto commerciale
data.description: Knowledge of the basic concepts of commercial law.

data.name: Diritto dell'energia
Macroeconomia

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The course aims at presenting and analyzing the key macroeconomic problems of growth, fluctuations, unemployment and inflation, the leading contemporary macroeconomic theories and their policy prescriptions. In addition, basic notions and instruments of internationally open economies will be introduced. Finally, the course will examine the main instructional features and principles of governance and economic policy of the European economic and monetary union.


The expected learning results are:

- become familiar with, and develop autonomous and critical interpretation of, main macroeconomic facts and problems and their relevant data; be able to understand and critically interpret the public debate on the macroeconomic policy issues

- know hypotheses, concepts and key results of the main contemporary macroeconomic theories, and their views and implications for economic policy

- be able to understand and apply the basic macroeconomic models

- understand and interpret competently the international dimension of macroeconomic problems and policy issues

- know the political-economic institutions of the European economic and monetary union; understand and critically discuss the main problems of monetary and fiscal policies in the Union

data.name: Analisi matematica 1

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
The course aim consists in providing the student of  Ingegneria Edile-Architettura with the calculus knowledge required by successive courses: Fisica Generale, Analisi Matematica 2, Statica, Fisica tecnica, Scienza delle costruzioni and others. In this course the fundamentals of infinitesimal calculus are introduce and studied: limits, continuity, differentiation, integration of one-variable functions. The course starts describing the historical evolution of numerical systems, showing that every extension was motivated by the need to solve more and more complex problems.  Mathematics is presented as matter in evolution, showing that some of the progress required centuries. Also the subsequent part of the course is presented by successive extensions, motivating the definitions and rigorously proving the fundamental theorems. The lectures are followed by exercise sessions, where problems related to the lectures subject are solved by elementary techniques. 
At the course end, the student is able to deal with the course subjects critically and rigorously, and has the mathematical background necessary for successive courses.

data.name: Geografia economica
data.description: The course means to supply the conceptual instruments of base in order to interpret, in geographic key, the two fundamental economic topics of the competitiveness and the development.

data.name: Produttività, innovazione e dinamiche d'impresa
data.description: Upon successful completion of this course, students: (i) will know the main definitions of "industry" and its most relevant dynamic characteristics; (ii) will know the main theories on firm growth and its determinants and will be able to discuss firm growth; (iii) will put firm dynamics and firm productivity into perspective within the process of (macro-)economic growth; (iv) will know the main elements of the debate on the micro- and macro-economic effects of Information and Communication Technologies (ICTs); (iv) will know the "Industry Life Cycle" framework; (vi) will interpret the results of the relevant empirical studies in Industrial Dynamics, by applying the concepts described in the previous points.

data.name: Psicopatologia clinica

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description:
The course's main aim is to lay the foundations of the understanding of the most important mental diseases' causes and development both in children and adults.

In particular students will able to :


A. Know the main diagnostic methods for mental disorders

B. Know the International systems of diagnostic classification for mental disease

C. Know the principal pathologies studied: the focus will be on inter subjectivity as well as on biologic and environmental/relational features

D. Analyse the key elements to make a clinical diagnosis (personal history, elements of cognitive functioning, personality structure)

E. Ability to study independently texts or scientific papers recommended by the teacher

data.name: Natural Resources and Energy Security
data.description:
The course will focus on the security aspects related to the allocation of natural resources and the production, trade and distribution of energy at the international level. The course will provide students with an overview of the main theoretical problems related to the ongoing debate on natural resources and energy security, with a multidisciplinary (legal and economic) perspective. The course will be structured around a number of specific topics selected on the basis of their relevance and interdisciplinary nature. 

By the end of the course students will have:

- strengthened their knowledge of the principles underlying the allocation of natural and energy resources and the associated norms in the international law system; 

- understood the role of the main institutional actors involved in the global natural resources and energy system; 

- learned to describe in a clear and comprehensive way the main security issues related to the production, trading, and distribution of energy, the use of natural resources and the implications for the environment and sustainable development; 

- developed their skills to analyse the different dimensions of energy security in relation to the functioning of the international market of energy, the trade-offs between different typologies of energy production, and the role of negative externalities; 

- learned to apply theoretical concepts to the analysis of case studies related to energy security and the management of natural resources at global level, identify solutions and discuss limits and benefits.

data.name: Science in Fiction

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.degreeProgram: Communication of Science and Innovation - SCICOMM (M1)

data.name: Advanced Programming

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The students will be fluent in the Rust programming language.

They will know how to write Rust code that compiles, and if it does not compile they will know why.


The students will be capable of coordinating a class-wide W3C-style Working Group that works on ill-formed specifications in order to make them well-specified and stable.

data.name: Economia industriale_
Fundamentals of mechanics and biomechanics
data.description:
The course aims to recall the fundamental concepts of applied and solids mechanics and apply them to the classical problems of biomechanics. The focus is on the human body, simple descriptive models will be presented to study the human ‘machine’. The analysis ranges from the kinematic and dynamic description of movement to the evaluation of the mechanical properties of tissues, and finally to the appropriate choice of materials and design methods for specific applications in occupational, clinic and sport biomechanics. In addition, attention is paid to the construction of analysis models, systems for experimental study of motor acts, and related signal analysis

At the end of the course the student should have acquired the competences and the ability to interact with specialists working in the field of bio-mechanics and biomedical engineering, contributing to the definition of the experiments and to the design of instruments and equipment.

data.name: Corporate Finance
data.description:
The course aims to provide students with the tools to set the financial decisions of a firm in order to create value for the owners and the creditors.
At the end of the course, the student will: (1) estimate the price of the principal financing instruments of a firm, equity and bonds; (2) calculate the cash flows of the investment projects of a firm and correctly apply the criteria of choice; (3) estimate the cost of capital and the cost of a firm's debt; (4) understand the real choices made by the firms regarding the financial structure.

data.name: Scientific Communication
data.description: The overall goal of the course is to sharpen the students’ verbal, written, and visualization skills to make them into a more effective communicator of scientific material. By the end of the course, students will be able to: -give a short conference-style slide presentation of primary scientific data to a semi-specialist audience. -prepare and present a conference poster. -prepare elegant and clear figures for publication in a scientific journal. -recognize and reproduce the basic textual and stylistic elements of a scientific publication.

data.name: Cultura e letteratura tedesca
data.description:
The aim of the course is the analysis of the ‘fantastic’ and the ‘supernatural’ as literary categories (in the definitions provided by many essayists and historians of literature, among them Tzvetan Todorov and Francesco Orlando) through a close reading of the short story Der unheimliche Gast (The Uncanny Guest, 1819) by E.T.A. Hoffmann, taken from the collection Die Serapions-Brüder (1819-1821). An intellectual biography of the author will be outlined, his way of constructing the story and the main narrative techniques will be analysed. The historical-cultural background, by which every literary phenomenon is conditioned, will be also taken into consideration (Napoleon’s campaigns, the victories of the French troops, the defeat of Prussia, the Restoration), as well as the cultural ‘discourses’ which were widespread at the time of the composition of the story (Naturphilosophie, animal magnetism, clairvoyance, telepathy, mesmerism, electrology, studies on sleepwalking, hypnosis). The course also aims at reflecting on the ways in which the link between literature and history can take shape and on the difficult balance, within the literary work, of aesthetic autonomy and historical-philosophical “Gehalt”.
In addition to the acquisition of the course content and knowledge of the cultural, literary and historical phenomena mentioned above, the students are expected to study and understand the content of the lectures, the texts scheduled in the syllabus, and the thematic insights. Students should also be able to apply the acquired knowledge, develop their autonomy of judgement (learn how to present and motivate their opinion in a discussion, know how to identify points of difficult comprehension within the program and ask the teacher for an explanation; know how to occasionally propose an interpretation or a judgment as the result of a personal critical reflection). Students are also expected to develop their communication skills (e.g. to be able to intervene in a discussion, to be able to ask questions to the teacher, to be able to share their work with their classmates, to be able to synthesise and present the knowledge acquired) and an effective method to consolidate the acquired knowledge.

data.name: Finanza aziendale avanzata
Leadership e Governance
data.description: On Leadership. This course focuses on providing students with an understanding of different leadership styles, teamwork theories, and group thinking methods through case studies. The first part of the course will focus on contemporary leadership theories. Seminars, discussions, and oral presentations on specific case studies will be conducted by students during the second part. Students will deliver an oral presentation on leadership and write a paper (2500/3000 words). They would demonstrate to be able to: 1) identify and analyze the different approaches to leadership, and 2) examine, describe, and compare how different approaches work to solve a particular issue. Students are expected to discuss other students' presentations actively. Adopting a student-centered approach, the course will provide opportunities for student engagement with a view to successfully achieving its learning objectives. The course will be structured to ensure meaningful and accessible learning for all students, and the assessment will be consistent with the teaching method. The course will adopt diversified tools to ensure that every student is able to follow the instructor, participate actively in open debates, ask specific and general questions of interest, and test his/her own understanding during the course. Students interested in attending the course and in taking the exam must enroll on the online Moodle page of the course as soon as possible.

data.name: Cryosphere in the climate system

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description: Understanding the basic mechanisms of glaciers and their role in the climate system.

data.name: Diritto internazionale dell'ambiente
data.description:
The course aims at providing knowledge of international law relating to the protection of the environment and sustainable development. It is a relatively young, but important, area of law, which has recently experienced a remarkable expansion, developing peculiar dynamics within international law.
At the end of the course, students:
- Will be able to understand and critically analyse the complex dynamics of the relationship between actors of the international community in environmental matters, including the institutional framework and the governance system in this field.
- Will have acquired a deep knowledge of the fundamental principles and norms of international environmental law, as well as of specific sectors of this field.
- Will be able to understand the functioning of negotiations and of the norm development process in international environmental law 
- Will be capable of properly interpreting and applying international environmental norms, also from the point of view of the scientific, economic and political context.
- Will have acquired the tools to undertake further research on more specific topics in this area in an independent manner.

data.name: Innovation and Entrepreneurship Basic

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The goal of the course is to provide students fundamentals in the field of innovation theory and entrepreneurial practice, while focusing on the development of “soft skills” such as presentation, writing, critical thinking and creativity.


At the end of the course, students will be able to:

- Analyse many perspectives on I&E and apply them to possible future scenarios;

- Create rough drafts of sustainable business models starting from an idea and/or product;

- Discuss the role of entrepreneurship in society and how different organizations function;

- Explain how technology can be seen both as a positive driver and as a source of disruption for contemporary society;

- Understand the main decisional models and apply them to analyse real cases;

- Evaluate the impact of an innovation on organizations and society at large;

- Present and defend their ideas in public;

- Discuss ethical implications of innovations, business models and technologies;

- Identify and discuss technological macro-trends and contextualise them in the I&E field;

- Positively work in a group setting, managing deadlines and internal group dynamics.

data.name: Storia economica - LM
Francese giuridico B2
data.degreeProgram: Comparative, European and International Legal Studies (L2)

data.name: Strumentazione ed elettronica industriale

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The educational objective of this course is to provide students with knowledge and skills on principles of operation, design criteria, performance parameters and measurement instruments for power electronics devices and electrical industrial systems. At the end of the course, students will be able to:

  • Understand structure and design criteria of electrical power systems;
  • Understand the principle of operation and the key performance parameters of several power electronic devices;
  • Understand architecture and design criteria of different electronic power converters (DC-DC, AC-DC and DC-AC);
  • Perform measurements of electrical quantities using different kinds of instruments;
  • Design and implement virtual instruments in LabVIEW for simulation, monitoring and control of industrial systems;
data.degreeProgram: Ingegneria Informatica, delle Comunicazioni ed Elettronica (L2)

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.name: Offensive Technologies

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
Scientific progress in computer security is driven by a mutual  understandings of attack and of defense. The course aims at advancing the concrete student's knowledge of attacks on operating systems, networks, and applications, and their societal implications. 

Students will learn how to set-up operational environments (complex networks) in the DETER Cyber Security Testbed. They will run several case studies for the set-up of a network and its defense (beside the attack).

Students will learn how to play alternatively attack and defense in a Capture The Flag Environment against each other.

Students will further learn how to present a technical demo in front of the audience potentially hostile.

data.name: Lab. appl.: Il ricorso tributario
data.description: The course aims te provide the student with the tools to understand the kind of protection needed by the tax payer before the tax Authorìties, showing at the same time, with simulations and practical examples, how to deal with the tax disputes and, more generally, with the litigation that may arise by filing an appeal against a tax assessment or to obtain a tax refund.

data.name: Fisica 2

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
The aim of the course is to provide students with a basic knowledge of electromagnetic phenomena (in static and dynamic conditions, in vacuum and matter) and on the physical laws governing them. Electromagnetism will be presented starting from experimental evidences and describing them in the framework of the Maxwell equations;  examples from technology and nature will be also discussed. The students will have:
a) a detailed knowledge the Maxwell's equations,
b) ability in their application to solve problems and exercices.
The couse will also provide the necessary knowledge to face the study of more complex electromagnetic phenomena such as the electromagnetic wave propagation and optics.

data.name: Metodi e modelli per l'ingegneria gestionale
data.description:
The couse will introduce the mathematical foundations of the most important methods used in complex problem solving. It will be, in large parts, inspired by the concept of Operations Research, which is defined, by the Merriem-Webster dictionary, as: "The application of scientific and especially mathematical methods to the study and analysis of problems involving complex systems".

At the end of the course, the student will be able to:
- recognize the main quantitative problems of industrial and production processes
- describe and model them from the mathematical point of view
- draw from the methods of operations research to solve various problems.

data.name: Geografia del paesaggio e dell'ambiente
data.description: The course means to supply the conceptual instruments of base in order to interpret, in geographic key, the two fundamental topics of the landscape and of the environment.

data.name: International Marketing
Cognitive neuroscience of infant development
data.description:
This module provides students with an advanced an in depth view of ongoing research in the filed of infant cognition. The module takes the format of a journal club, where students will read and present research papers on cognitive development. The module convenor will facilitate the discussion, creating a learning friendly atmosphere of open debate, where all participants are encouraged to engage in the discussion, expressing their opinion about open problems in cognitive development, making critical comments and asking clarification questions.

We will discuss empirical studies, contemporary theories and research techniques, including neuroscience methods, in the filed of cognitive development of human infants (below 2 years of age). Special attention will be dedicated to social cognitive development.

data.name: Interdisciplinary laboratory: Characterization techniques
data.description:
The course is aimed at improving and training the students’ experimental skills through laboratory practice and modeling activities. The main goal is to stimulate an active approach to some selected scientific and technical problems. The interdisciplinary course will be also a useful opportunity for improving team working ability.

After the course the students will be able:

1.    To apply the scientific method, i.e. to critically analyze the scientific/technical problem proposed and to find suitable solutions;

2.    To analyze the state of the art through critical reading of the literature;

3.    To know the experimental information provided and the suitability of available characterization techniques, such as atomic emission spectroscopy, infrared and optical spectroscopy, X-ray diffraction, nuclear magnetic resonance, electron microscopy and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy, etc.;

4.    To critically select the characterization tools, taking into account nature, shape and features of materials, particularly for elucidating structure-properties relationships

5.    To use suitable characterization techniques: set up the experiment; collect/present/analyze/discuss experimental results; calculate confidence levels; compare and correlate different data.

6.    To collaborate with other students through group working

7.    To use proper oral and/or written scientific communication for results dissemination.

8.    To answer questions made by an external audience.

data.name: Studies on human behaviour

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description: The aim of this course is to study the behaviour of people. The course is data intensive and hands on. It covers all the phases from experiment design, data collection, data preparation and data analysis. After a brief theoretical introduction, the course will consist of running real world experiments, on large amounts of data. This inter-disciplinary course bridges competences in sociology, ethics and computer science.

data.name: Arte gotica
data.description: Students are expected to know with awareness the details of the history of art in Mantua between the fourteenth and fifteenth centuries, know the main monuments and the artistic profile of the main protagonists of that lively artistic season.

data.name: Interdisciplinary laboratory: Polymeric materials
data.description:
The course is aimed at improving and training the students’ experimental skills through laboratory practice and designing/modeling activities. The main goal is to stimulate an active approach to some selected scientific and technical problems.

After the course the students will be able

-to apply the scientific method: to critically analyze the scientific/technical problem proposed and to find a suitable solution;

-to analyze the state of the art and literature data for selection of polymeric materials and design;

-depth study on fibres (rope design) and multilayer films (permeability design);

data.name: Storia economica
data.description:
The course aims to provide the knowledge and skills necessary to understand and explain the fundamental transformations of the European and world economy between the 18th and 20th centuries.

At the end of the course the student will be able to:

- recall the fundamental concepts relevant to the analysis of an economic system;

- describe the main historical manifestations of economic growth and crises;

- explain the causes and consequences of the economic phenomena examined;

- illustrate the relationship between economic, technological and institutional transformations;

- undertake the reading of short scientific and informative essays of a historical-economic nature.

data.name: Fisiopatologia e immunologia clinica
data.description:
The aim of the course is to describe the pathophysiological mechanisms responsible for the main alterations of the homeostatic systems of the body, the compensatory mechanisms activated following these alterations, and how they can themselves constitute pathophysiological mechanisms of disease.

In particular, the Clinical Pathophysiology Module aims to raise awareness of the pathophysiological mechanisms responsible for the main alterations of:

  • the hydro-electrolytic balance;
  • the acid-base balance;
  • the renal function;
  • the heart function;
  • the regulation of vascular tone and pressure homeostasis;
  • the respiratory function;
  • the liver function;
  • the hemostasis and thrombosis;
  • the formation and propagation of the cardiac electrical impulse;
  • the intestinal absorption of macro and micronutrients.

Istituzioni di diritto romano
data.description:
"the course aims to offer students a basic understanding and a critical comprehension of the main principles and institutions of  Roman private law, whith a specific focus on its dogmatic structure and historical development. The course also stresses that the Roman law constitutes the historical and conceptual basisof many legal systems throughout the world and it is the most essential foundations of the civilian tradition.
At the end of the course the student will be able to:

- understand the historical origin (in the social and economic context)of the main institutions of private law
- understand the main important elements of legal reasoning, which have always considered essential to the hermeneutical knowledge of the laywer
- understand the main logical techniques used by Roman lawyers in the scientific formulation of private law"

data.name: Bayesian statistics

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description:
Purpose of the course

The purpose of the course is to address the study of the foundations of Bayesian statistics starting from the basic principles of the probability calculus. The course is divided into two modules.


  • The first module is devoted to present the parametric Bayesian inferential framework and intends to explore the foundations of the Bayesian paradigm and highlight the similarities and differences with the classical Fisher’s approach. Particular attention will be posed on computational and simulation aspects.
  • The second module focuses mainly on nonparametric Bayesian framework and related methods exploring the implications of Dirichlet and Pitman-Yor process in nonparametric mixture models. Particular attention will also be devoted on computational aspects of nonparametric mixture models.


During the course, the students have the opportunity to familiarize themselves with the principal theorems, logical developments, ideas and issues that underlie the Bayesian techniques, learn to recognize them as natural extensions of the concepts introduced in the previous courses in probability and mathematical statistics and familiarize with their us in practical situations.


The students will be request to have a pro-active participation and a constant involvement in the training program.


Course expected results

After taking this course students should be able to

  • Choose appropriately prior distributions and obtain posterior distributions
  • Simulate values from posterior distributions and make appropriate Bayesian inference.
  • Construct Bayesian prediction intervals and write appropriate conclusions.
  • Construct hierarchical models and adapt mixture models to capture the richness and the variety of the real phenomena.
  • Use a statistical computer packages (mainly R) to implement the data analysis procedures covered in the course.

data.name: Logica
data.description: The course aims at introducing the basic elements of modern formal logic. After a first part, in which the students are supposed to get used to the general forms of deductive reasoning, the course will present the main notions concerning the formal languages of modern logic, both in the syntactic and the semantic perspective. At the end of the course, the students will be able to recognize the logic structure of arguments expressed in natural language. Moreover, they will have acquired a basic acquaintance with formal logic and with the main implication of logic for philosophy and, in selected cases, for mathematics and computer science. The final part of the course will provide a short introduction to the public use of logical and argumentative tools.

data.name: Finanza aziendale_
data.description: The analysis of business data to the evaluation of flows and borrowings. The aim of the course is to provide the basic instrument for assessing the data and financial strategies of companies

data.name: Basics of management
data.description: The purpose of the module is to provide a set of integrated frameworks highlighting why firms exist, and how these business organizations are structured and function. Drawing upon transaction cost thinking, each organisation is treated as a work in progress that has permeable boundaries and may always give birth to new enterprise. The module also aims at providing a practice-based introduction to understanding of business strategy and the relationship between business strategy and goals.

data.name: The Use of Force in International Politics
data.description:
This course seeks to examine dynamics of violent conflict within and between states in world politics. It does so by reviewing the multiple ways in which the use of force is represented, legitimized, or rather contested and resisted by different actors playing in international and transnational fields; analysing how violent conflict and conflict management, resolution and transformation can be defined and explained.

Students will be invited to consider how military power works within military and security institutions as well as societies, and how it relates to state formation and transformations. Furthermore, they will be expected to engage with a variety of lenses to reflect upon the changing character of war, warfare and the forms of political violence as well as, on the other hand, the strengths and weaknesses of various responses to threats, insecurities and conflict.

By the end of the course, students should:



  • Be familiar with the historical trajectories characterizing the use of armed forces in international relations;
  • Have an overall understanding of the changing relationship between political authorities, military organizations and societies across countries over time;
  • Be able to examine and interpret dynamics and processes pertaining to the threat, use and control of armed forces in international politics;
  • Be able to think analytically and critically about the politics of organized collective violence in a variety of contexts;
  • Understand and unpack different approaches to conflict analysis and crisis response, applying concepts and theoretical frameworks to specific case studies.

data.name: Machine learning

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description:
The aim of the course is to provide knowledge of both theoretical and practical aspects of machine learning, and present the main techniques of machine learning and probabilistic reasoning.


At the end of the course, students will be able to:


- describe the main machine learning techniques, with their characteristics and limitations


- master probabilistic reasoning techniques


- model simple probabilistic scenarios with Bayesian Networks


- realize learning programs tailored to the specific problem to be addressed.

data.name: Robot planning and its applications
data.description: In this course the student will be introduced to a complete methodology for designing production-ready robot applications. The considered applications will be those for which motion planning plays a major role. The student activities will revolve around a motivational application proposed in the form of a simple robotic competition, in which the robot has to complete a number of tasks in minimum time avoiding obstacles and dangerous spots. Contrary to a standard robotic competition, the student will have to discuss the theoretical underpinning of the method she/he chose to adopt for the competition.

data.name: Basi di dati

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
We live in a world full of data. Almost every human activity nowadays produces data or needs access to data. As such, there is a need for effective and efficient solutions that will allow us to store, maintain, search and retrieve large volumes of data. This is what the data management systems do. The goal of this course is to teach the students the fundamental concepts of data  management, to train them in order to be able to design of good databases, give them the ability to build complex queries, and allow them to identify and solve performance problems in real life situations. 
Naturally the course focuses on relational databases since the relational model is the one that drives most of the existing data management systems in the industry nowadays, it has been around for more than 30 years and has been one of the most studied model, and has been the one with the most commercial tools in operation.

data.name: Introduction to Computer and Network Security

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: This is an introductory course to the increasingly important area of computer and network security. The main goal is to enable students to (i) understand the theoretical and practical problems of information security, (ii) understand and recognize threats to fundamental security properties: confidentiality, integrity, and availability, and (iii) understand how the main security mechanisms - such as cryptography, authentication and authorization protocols, and access control - can be applied to mitigate vulnerabilities.

data.name: The microbiome of the environment and agri-food products
data.description:
The course provides the student with knowledge and skill on microbe-based processing, preservation and fermentation and on the biology, ecology and physiology of starter and probiotic bacteria/fungi and food-associated spoilage and pathogenic microorganisms. The course will also provide knowledge on the main related national and EU legislation.

At the end of the course the student should be able to identify and study the most important microorganisms associated to food and agricultural products, to implement innovative food products, processes and applications that are based on the use of microorganism, also referring to the relevant legislation.

The final aim is to train and specialize students, who will be able to implement innovations based on the use of microorganisms in food production from farm to fork or to develop programs at all levels in food industries or international organisms.

data.name: Introduction to Machine Learning

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: This course provides a broad introduction to machine learning and statistical pattern recognition.  The course will cover different topics ranging from supervised learning (parametric/non-parametric algorithms, kernel methods, feedforward neural networks), unsupervised learning (clustering, dimensionality reduction, autoencoders, deep generative models) and reinforcement learning. In the final part of the course some applications of machine learning will be presented in the field of computer vision, robotics and natural language processing. Theoretical discussion will be complemented with lab in Python using open-source libraries.

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
At the end of the course, students will:

1. learn the main theoretical concepts and models to define, distinguish and interpret social movements, and other forms of social conflict oriented to social, political or cultural changes.

2. be able to link the case studies discussed in the scientific literature with the theoretical elements covered during the course.

3. acquire some basic analytical skills to interpret phenomena and empirical evidence of contemporary society in light of the concepts and theories dealt with in the course.

data.name: Real time operating systems and middleware

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: The Real-Time Operating Systems and Middleware course will introduce the concept of real-time applications and will show the student the foundations of design, development, and implementation of a real-time software system. The course will also focus on the requirements of the operating system kernels targeted to real-time applications. The course will consider different kinds of Real-Time systems, each one aimed at a different class of applications ranging from multimedia (soft real-time) to control and automation.

data.name: Globalizzazione e diritto del lavoro
data.description: The course aims at examining the effects of globalisation on labour law, first of all at international, but also at European and national level. At the end of the course students will know these effects and will be able to understand why the International Labour Organisation (ILO), as a response to them, decided to focus on some workers' rights, considered as fundamental, and not on others. Finally, students will be aware of the enforcement problems characterizing the fundamental workers' rights in the globalized world.

data.name: Bio-Medical Imaging
data.description:
The course will provide an introduction into the concepts of modern biomedical imaging, with emphasis on:
•Imaging sources (X-rays, Radio-isotopes, Magnetic fields, Visible light, ...) 
•Image acquisition techniques (Tomography, Magnetic Resonance, Microscopy, Super-resolution,...)
•Image processing methods (Image reconstruction, Filtering techniques, Image segmentation,...)
•Applications (Examples in Diagnostics, Therapy, Research)
Students at the end of the course will have a profound knowledge of all major medical and biological diagnostic and scientific imaging modalities. 
They will be able to distinguish different imaging modalities by their theoretical and technical foundations, their fields of application, and the physiological information they provide.
They will have seen the application of some of these methods in the daily routine of hospitals and laboratories.
They will be further capable to select and apply different image reconstruction methods to the raw data of the different imaging modalities. The hands-on MATLAB-laboratory will introduce them to this universal image processing tool. It will provide them with the skills to write their own code to extract quantitative measures on single objects from diagnostic images.
The students will be stimulated to read original scientific articles on recent advances in the field of biomedical imaging methods.
They will be able the extract novel concepts from these articles, to present them in a short seminar, and to discuss them with their fellow participants.

data.name: Corso extracurriculare di inglese

The aim of this course is to acquire and apply economic and business language skills at a CEFR level B2/a. 
The course is aimed at third year undergraduate students (3rd year) who intend to continue their language learning at ESP level for future work placement at home or abroad, and/or continue their academic career.  
Attendance and active participation will enable the student to:
a) understand an economic text
b) use appropriate lexis
c) discuss university studies
d) describe simple economic visuals.

data.name: Psicologia economica
data.description:
Economic Psychology is the study of the psychological mechanisms that underlie economic behaviors. It is an area where psychology and economics intersect. Economic psychology, therefore, describes and explains economic preferences and choices, and factors influencing these. The focus of economic psychology is to understand human (and organizational) motivations behind economic decisions, such as consumer decisions, investment decisions, negotiations, savings, tax compliance and insurance decisions.
Economics deals also with the behavior of humans and hence should be considered as a behavioral science. It is mainly concerned with prescribing what economic agents should do, what they should choose, in order to maximize their personal outcomes (i.e., to be rational). Two broad theories of rational choice can be identified, Utility Theory has been proposed to understand individual decision making and Game Theory has been proposed to understand the behavior of individuals in interdependent situations. Psychologists and experimental economists have studied whether and how utility theory and game theory describe and predict the behavior of individuals. It appears that people systematically violate the assumptions of these theories. Therefore, in order to come to a better understanding of human behavior, a new approach that takes these violations into account should be developed. In this course we discuss these behavioral violations and the suggested alternative theories to economic behavior.
In this course you will:
	develop an understanding of differences between major theories and research practices in economics and psychology.
	learn when and why economic theories fail descriptively, and what alternative explanations for economic behavior have been proposed. 
	apply these ideas and findings to the formulation of solutions to real-life problems (e.g., problems in consumer choice, marketing, or questions of public policy)
	give a reasoned opinion of fundamental issues and debates on economic decision- making discussed during the lectures (e.g., freedom to choose, rationality, self-interest, fairness).

data.name: Cancer Metabolism

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description:
The course will provide an introduction to cancer metabolism. In the lectures, we will investigate the role of oncogenic signaling and tumor microenvironment as drivers of metabolic alterations in cancer and the oncogenic role of mutations in metabolic enzymes. I will present studies of the metabolic pathways most frequently altered in cancer and the consequences of the derailed metabolism. The methods and protocols used to assess metabolism in cancer will be discussed. An overview of the integration methods for “omics” data in order to construct metabolic maps of specific tumor types will be discussed. Therapeutic and diagnostic perspectives exploiting the signatures of altered metabolism in cancer will be critically evaluated. At the end of the course the students will have knowledge of:

•	Cancer as a metabolic disease
•	Role of oncogenes/tumor suppressors in cancer metabolism
•	Metabolic enzymes as cancer drivers
•	Pathways altered in cancer
•	Techniques to study metabolism in cancer
•	Integration of “omics” data in studying cancer metabolism
•	Role of the microenvironment in cancer metaolism
•	Therapeutic options to exploit/correct altered metabolism

data.name: Storia del pensiero economico
data.description:
The evolution of economic thought, similar to that of other disciplines, does not follow a linear path, characterized by the progressive solution and "archiving" of the problems faced. On the contrary, if we analyze the roots of the various and different approaches to economic theory between the middle of the last century and the present era (i.e. the evolution of the contemporary debate), we often come across concepts and problems that were at the attention of economics scholars hundreds of years ago. Similarly to what happens in other scientific fields - for example in the field of astronomy - the ability to observe reality and to process and interpret the data collected gradually increases; however there is a different trait - which is instead common to all the social sciences - given by the progressive change of the reality under study. In other words, we are not faced with an "immutable" reality, whose behavior follows laws that scientific research allows us to understand "better" (whatever the epistemological meaning of this expression), but an economic and social system whose characteristics change over time. But the problems reappear and concepts that were considered to have already been sufficiently elaborated recursively return to the center of the analysis. The production and distribution of income, economic development, the role of money - to mention some of the main problems - require increasingly sophisticated analyzes, which however have their roots in theoretical elaborations even very far in time. Hence the importance, even for those immersed in contemporary debates, of knowing the ways and forms in which these problems have presented themselves and have been addressed in the past, developing concepts that are still at the center of theoretical reflection.

The course therefore aims to provide students with a logical structure to frame the evolution of economic thought and the development of the most important theories, up to the threshold of contemporary debate. Its goal is to enable the student to:


a) Learn about the evolution of the economic thought, within the framework of the evolving historical facts
b) Recognize the main schools of thought and identify their critical issues and points
c) Recognize the specific origins and frameworks of the contemporary economic theories 
d) Assess the appropriateness of a given analytical framework with respect to the problems analyzed by the economist

data.name: Digital signal processing for mechatronics
Tecnologia dei cicli produttivi
data.description:
The course aims to outline the importance of the energy sector in developed countries as well as in developing countries. Energy production and consumption in addition to economic aspects and environmental effects are considered. Furthermore, the technological innovation as a key factor in the exploitation of new energy sources and the improvement in the use of traditional sources is analyzed.
Attendance and active participation at the course and self-study will enable students to:
1.Know the role of energy in the economic system
2.Know the environmental impacts associated with the exploitation of the different  energy sources
3.Compare efficiency in the use of different energy sources and their environmental and economic consequences
4.Analyze and interpret the trends of the international oil prices
5.Relate oil price trends to global geopolitical equilibrium.
6.Assess the importance of technological innovations in the energy sector

data.name: Filologia germanica II
data.description:
The course aims at providing the students with the necessary tools in order to analyze medieval Germanic texts.
At the end of the course the student will be able to:
a) place the texts  in their historical and cultural context
b) recognize Christian cultural contributions and traditional Germanic elements
c) analyze the processes of re-elaboration of the traditional narrative heritage in a new cultural context.

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
The course aims to provide technical, methodological, experimental and operational skills applied to final design, developing the various issues inherent in the relationship between design approach and building technique, with particular reference to compositional, structural, technological and environmental quality in buildings.

In considering final definition of the architectural design, the course integrates the aspects of technology, construction, structure and energy-building services, based on technical knowledge of the built system and practical application of the design on building scale in the Design Workshop.

At the end of the course, students will have acquired the basic theoretical and practical tools for the final design of simple and complex buildings and will be able to formulate technical and economic assessments of the efficacy of the most appropriate technical and building services solutions for various types of building.

data.name: Geometria

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
The course aims to:
 
- give the basic elements of linear algebra and analytic geometry, and touches on the field of projective geometry.  There is a particular emphasis on the applicative aspects.

In order to successfully complete the course, the student:

- should acquire a good knowledge and comprehension of the Euclidean geometry of the plane and of the space, and of their transformations, as well as of the tools of Linear Algebra that allow us to solve geometric problems, as specified in the programme.
- should know the basic concepts of the theory, being able to illustrating them by means of examples, and  identifying the connections between them.
- should also acquire familiarity with the tools necessary to formulate and solve problems of Linear Algebra, such as those related to operations with matrices, their reduction to echelon form, computation of determinants, eigenvalues, and eigenvectors.

data.name: Networks and culture

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
The aim of the course is to introduce the relational/network approach (Network Science) and allow students to practice basic research skills using Social Network Analysis concepts and methodology. The first part of the course describes theoretical and methodological bases of network studies; while the second part deals with empirical case studies by means of project and group work. Competences acquired by those actively participating are a) to understand the theoretical principles and methods of network analysis; b) to describe a specific thematic area/examples of application of network theory; c) to identify and analyse a case study using Social Network Analysis.

A specific attention will be given to the study of networks embedded in ommunicative/cultural exchanges and organizational relations, and their empirical analysis in power and economic structures. Selected topics such as communicative relations, cultural products and publics will be explored by means of multidisciplinary researches (economics, history, political science) and comparative social sciences studies.

data.name: Risoluzione alternativa delle controversie civili e giustizia riparativa
data.description:
The course aims at providing the students with the basic knowledge of alternative dispute resolution as a means of resolving civil and penal disputes (restorative justice, in criminal matters). This topic involves other legal systems.
It is therefore essential that there be a interdisciplinary, transnational and European approach to this problem.

data.name: Modeling and design with finite elements
data.description:
The finite element method (FEM) is the dominant discretization technique in process and product modelling. The objective of this course is to give the student a broad and integrative knowledge of this method and to introduce the student into its application to a variety of engineering problems.
By the end of this course students should: (1) know the behaviour and usage of each type of elements covered in this course; (2) be able to use finite element software to develop models of engineering systems; (3) be able to interpret and evaluate the quality of the results (know the physics of the problems); (4) be aware of the limitations of the FEM (don't misuse the FEM - a numerical tool!);  (5) be familiar with team-working, mathematical computing and FEM software; (6) be able to present FEM analyses in a proper format of a written report such that a technically qualified person can follow and obtain similar findings.

data.name: Storia culturale e sociale della medicina
Economia
data.description:
At the end of the course the students will know the main themes of a complete intermediate level microeconomics course (consumer theory and elasticity of demand, perfect competition and monopoly, oligopoly, game theory, information asymmetry, attitude towards risk, public goods and externalities). They will be able to explain conceptually and through the use of simple graphical and analytical tools the theories learned and to correctly report these theories in the context of a series of relevant examples and cases.

The course develops different insights into microeconomics: these insights are complementary and represent the next step compared to the program carried out in Introduction to Economics and have the purpose of forming some additional concepts and analysis tools that allow to reach an advanced knowledge of economic problems. most relevant companies.

A specific study is provided on the theory of tax and on the Italian tax system.

data.name: Advanced Commutative Algebra
data.description:
The commutative algebra is an extremely versatile discipline. In addition to being itself a field of research in mathematics both classical and contemporary, it has important consequences both in computational framework that on the foundations of modern algebraic geometry, not to mention the recent uses in the application environment.
The purpose of this course is to provide a good understanding of the foundations of modern commutative algebra with a particular focus on computational methods and its use in algebraic geometry.
The final part of the course will introduce students to the most recent applications.
