Stabilità dei pendii naturali e delle costruzioni in terra

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
At the end of the course, the students will be able to:

- Understand laboratory and insitu investigation methods to quantify the parameters needed for slope analysis

- Choose the most suitable method for slope stability analysis

- Carry out and differentiate slope stability analyses with different numerical methods

- Evaluate the suitability of different slope stabilization methods.
data.degreeProgram: Ingegneria per l'ambiente e il territorio (LM)

data.name: Behavioural Finance
data.description:
Main goal of the course is to introduce students to behavioral finance. This approach to financial issues relies on weaker rationality assumptions than traditional finance and seeks to improve the understanding of financial phenomena.

In the first part of the course, main concepts in behavioral economics are discussed, in an interactive and participated way. In the second part of the course, behavioral insights are applied to financial issues, with reference to both market and corporate dimension.

Students successfully completing the course will be able to critically examine financial phenomena and to understand potential market anomalies in a behavioral perspective.
data.degreeProgram: Behavioural and Applied Economics - Economia Comportamentale e Applicata (LM)

data.name: Energie rinnovabili

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description: The aim of the course consists in providing the engineering skills required in the design of energy plants and systems including renewable energies as a primary source. In particular, the methodologies currently utilized for the design of solar thermal systems and solar cooling, photovoltaic systems, heat pumps with particular regard to geothermal plants and the technologies used for the thermal exploitation of biomass will be proposed and investigated. The expected result of the course consists in providing to the student a basic background to be able to analyse the engineering problems pertaining to the design and integration of the proposed renewable energies technologies with traditional ones, also including an economic analysis for the evaluation of the main parameters inherent the profitability of the proposed energy systems.
data.degreeProgram: Ingegneria per l'ambiente e il territorio (LM)

data.name: Laboratory of Energy Conversion Processes
data.description: The course aims to provide the students with the basics of energy sources, both traditional and renewable. Such knowledge is essential for dealing with the problems, primarily environmental, linked to the growing demand for energy.

data.name: Network-based Data Analysis

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description:
The goal of this course is to enable students to analyze various types of high-dimensional data types commonly encountered in the practice of Molecular Biology using a range of methodologies, including established statistical approaches, machine learning, and recently introduced methods.

At the end of the course, students are expected to possess the following skills:

- familiarity with different types of Molecular Biology data and their specificity;

- good understanding of different conceptual methods for analyzing the data;

- familiarity with practical computational tools for carrying out the analysis;

- ability to frame the results of their analysis in a biological context using networks;

- ability to provide a functional interpretation of the results of their analysis;

- ability to complete a project, write a structured report, and orally present the results of their work.

data.name: Ethics and Law of Artificial Intelligence
data.description:
The Course aims at giving the students a basic knowledge of ethical and legal principles in AI. We will analyse existing principles and ask ourselves whether they may be suitable to regulate AI or whether it is necessary to develop new ones.

At the end of the course, students will have legal and interdisciplinary skills that can guide them in carrying out their professional activity in a constitution-oriented and human-centered way.

data.name: Logica Computazionale

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: The course aims at providing the basic logic notions and approach, where logic is presented as a formal specification languages for the modeling of reasoning and knowledge representation. The course covers the most important types of logics with applications in Automated reasoning, Artificial Intelligence, formal methods, and Web data modeling and use

data.name: Politiche del welfare sociale

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description: w

data.name: Human Language Technologies
data.description:
The course introduces how to computationally approach and manage human language technologies. The covered topics are creation of annotated corpora, syntax (e.g. parsing), semantics (e.g. similarity, word sense disambiguation), until more advanced  issues of pragmatics such as affective and emotion recognition, computational treatment of persuasive and creative language. Particular attention will be given to the use of out-of-the-shelf NLP tools, so that the students can gain hands on experience.

At the end of the course students will be able (i) to have knowledge of the main research areas in Computational Linguistics; (ii) to plan the steps to approach a Natural Language phenomenon in a computational way, (iii) to manage the basic tools useful in computational linguistics.

data.name: Costruzioni idrauliche

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description: The course introduces the students to the design and maintenance of the main hydraulic infrastructures. At the end of the lectures the students will master the functioning of hydraulic structures, the materials used for their construction and the techniques used for their design. They will be able to design, from a hydraulic point of view, the most diffused urban hydraulic infrastructures.

data.name: Filosofia della scienza

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description: Students will be provided with solid theoretic-philosophical instruments to understand the processes that lead to the genesis, validation and overcoming of scientific hypothesis. They will develop a critical and problematic point of view on scientific research, according to which there are not straightforward and fixed criteria to determine what science is and what it is not. They will become aware that there are a number of criteria that can be used to assess whether a discipline or a theory can be considered as scientific and that these must be considered and weighted up for each particular case. The critical analysis of different positions on which theories can/cannot be considered as scientific will help students improve, among other things, their reasoning and their capacity of making judgments because they will need to compare and assess different criteria of scientificity. Analyzing how the philosophical prospective on science and scientificity criteria developed and changed over time, students will furthermore get acquainted with the idea that theories are evolving systems, which are able to identify their own problems and to formulate solutions for them by modifying and improving past models. Finally, the part of the course devoted to the mind/body problem will increase the students’ competences in comprehending the various explanatory levels that characterize psychology and to critically reflect on their specificity and differences.
data.degreeProgram: Scienze e Tecniche di Psicologia Cognitiva (L2)

data.name: Psicobiologia e valutazione dello stress lavorativo

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description:
The aim of this course is to provide biological explanations to the effects of stress on health, with particular reference to psycho-physiological bases of stress. Moreover, the course aims to provide the necessary bases for the understanding of the interaction between the employees and work environment, with particular regard to the dynamics of work-related stress and safety in the workplace.

At the end of the course, the student is expected to understand how to investigate the effects of hormonal and nervous responses of stress on health in general and on the functionality of different body systems (for example, on the gastro-enteric and cardio-circulatory systems, on the immune system, on sleep and memory, on perception of pain, development and aging), how we can then manage stress in relation to personality traits, depression and social hierarchies. Moreover, the student is expected to be able to argue about major theoretical approaches to the psychosocial risk factors and to the evaluation and the interventions on the work-related stress.

At the end of the course, the student is expected also to convey the knowledge gained in a clear and fulfilled manner to the various interlocutors, also elaborating, applying and communicating original and autonomous ideas in new contexts.

data.name: Storia della filosofia dal tardoantico al medioevo
Disegno dell'architettura con Laboratorio

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description: ‘Architectural drawing’ teaches historical, scientific and operative fundamentals of the drawing discipline. The main purpose of the course is to offer the student the basic theoretical and technical knowledge necessary for spatial understanding and graphic representation of architecture. Therefore, the course aims to lead the student towards the conscious use of the elementary, conceptual and material, tools of traditional drawing and digital modelling, with particular attention to the realization of elaborates drawn up according to the rules of the drawing at different scales. At the end of the course the student will be able to: manage basic manual and digital visual communication; understand the shape of a space and translate it into a graphic table; use the forms of representation to communicate the geometric conformation of an architectural space through two-dimensional images; build and manage a simple 2D and 3D digital model; apply rules and codes of architectural drawing to different scales.

data.name: Meccanica computazionale delle strutture 1

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
The course aims to introduce the finite element method applied to the analysis of solids and linear elastic structures. The theoretical foundations of the methodology, specific aspects of particular structural contexts, and operational aspects related to the use of finite element software are illustrated. The course aims to provide the student with the knowledge necessary for the conscious use of such programs, which are now widely used on personal computers. Applications of the finite element method are used to solve real structural engineering problems.
At the end of the course the student will be able to: (i) formulate the differential approach (strong formulation) and the integral approach (weak formulation) of structural mechanical problems; (ii) to solve simple structures (truss structures and beam systems) with the finite element method; (iii) analyze 2D elasticity problems and define their proper discretization; (iv) use finite element software to solve beam systems and 2D elasticity problems.

data.name: Biologia cellulare

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description:
The main objective of this class is to give to provide the students with the concepts essential for understanding the structural and functional organization of the eukaryotic cell with particular emphasis on the animal cell. By providing examples of key cell biological experiments, another goal pursued by the class is to shed light on the relationship between the key concepts addressed and the experimental evidence supporting them. Moreover, the last objective of this class is to clarify the relationship between the proper operation of cellular processes and tissue and organ homeostasis. This is achieved by alluding to pathological conditions resulting from the malfunctions of the cellular processes tackled during the course.  

By the end of the class, successful students will be able to:

-describe the various types of biochemical constituents of the cell

-describe the structural organization of the cell critically addressing the functional relevance of every organelle

-manage the key notions associated to the central dogma of molecular biology and it compartmentalization within eukaryotic cells 

-predict the subcellular localization of a certain protein by knowing key aspects of it primary sequence

-describe structure and function of the different cytoskeletal elements, addressing similarities and differences among them

-understand the regulatory aspects allowing eukaryotic cells to duplicate

-understand the regulatory aspects allowing eukaryotic cells to undergo programmed death

-understand the key techniques utilized in cell biology with particular emphasis on the mammalian tissue culture and microscopy approaches

data.name: Diritto ecclesiastico
data.description:
The primary objective of this course is to outline and stress the evolution of Eclesiastic Law from its traditional interpretation of relationship between the State and the Catholic Church to a more modern relationship between the State and any form of organized religion. It is still the discipline which is the closest to the conscience and spiritual dimension of each individual.
Substantial migration flows are changing society and culture, and the Italian law system is facing an increasing number of religions, often very different from the religions Europe has familiarity with.
The aim of the course is to provide students with knowledge about Canon law, as well as the legal means available (constitutional, ordinary and sometimes regional) to meet the needs related to new religions.
Upon completion of the course, students will be able to:
- Know the key concepts of ecclesial law.
- Know the most recent legal trends for the topics covered in the course.
- Utilise correct terminology when defining concepts such as secularism, minister and religious freedom, and relate it to the constitution.
- Understand the new needs emerging from the presence of new religions

data.name: Storia moderna III
data.description:
Second part (prof. G. Ciappelli)


The course aims to examine a historiographic theme of growing interest in the studies of early modern history of the last thirty years, the history of Inquisition, from the late Middle Ages to the end of the early modern period, considering both the evolution of phenomena over time and the results of the different interpretative contributions. Therefore, precise notions will be provided concerning:

the historical-juridical origins of medieval Inquisition;

the birth (connected to the diffusion of Reformation), the organization and development of Roman Inquisition;

the policies followed in this matter by Popes before and after the Council of Trent;

the fields of intervention of Inquisition and their modifications over time;

the long-term historical consequences of the action of Inquisition.

The attendance of the planned training activities and individual study will ensure that at the end of the course the students are able to define and describe, both orally and in writing, the characteristics and details of the aforementioned areas of knowledge.

data.name: Recycling and sustainable materials
data.description:
Objectives:

This course is focused on materials and the environment: the eco-aspects of materials’ production, use, and disposal at end of life. The course also provides an overview of materials selection and design approaches that minimize the environmental impact.

 

After completing the course, the student will be able to:

- assess the sustainable development of a given articulation following a rigorous procedure;

- select an eco-sustainable material on the basis of its property profile and interaction with the environment;

- measure the main properties of biopolymers and wood-related materials according to the relevant standards;

- design a component taking the most suitable end-of-first-life options into proper account;

- design a life cycle assessment analysis on a practical case.

 

 

Learning outcomes:

At the end of the course, the student should be able to:

·      illustrate the concept of sustainable development and the ways in which it is evaluated for a given articulation;

·      explain the physical-mechanical properties and the applications of wood-related materials and materials for thermal insulation;

·      classify and compare the various families of biopolymers and their properties in the different applications, in order to select the best candidate material for a given application;

·      illustrate the recycling methods for the various materials, highlighting the pros and the cons of each of them;

·      explain the life cycle assessment (LCA) methodology in its theoretical and practical aspects

·      produce and characterize eco-sustainable materials, analyze the experimental data, and generate a technical report with the results and discussion of the analysis.
data.degreeProgram: Materials and production Engineering - Ingegneria dei materiali e della produzione (LM)

data.name: Metodologia e tecniche della ricerca sociale

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description: The purpose of the course is to introduce students to the quantitative and qualitative principles and procedures of research in social sciences. At the end of the course, students will be able to a) describe the main approaches in sociological research; b) understand methodological paradigms and their implications for research design, and c) know the main qualitative and quantitative techniques. Students will put in practice the content of the course participating to laboratory taking place during the course. For the 2021-2022 academic year, laboratories will be proposed, see the syllabi of each for further information.

data.name: Giustizia costituzionale
data.description:
The course aims - after a brief re-classification of the institutional categories - to provide an in-depth knowledge of the function of constitutional justice, paying attention to how it does not represent for the jurist a remedial dimension far from the issues of more immediate practical relevance, inserting instead in the daily life of the legal practitioner. A knowledge of the details of the procedures and the effectiveness of constitutional decisions brings with it the awareness of the role of constitutional justice in defining the rules to be applied daily and in outlining the real physiognomy, in action, of the legal system. The study in detail of the subject therefore intends to bring the figure of the constitutional judge closer to the student, as an actor whose intervention is of interest to any legal operator, even to those who do not come into direct contact with the Court.
In addition to examining technical-specialist profiles not covered in institutional courses, the course also aims to provide a modern and dynamic vision of the "constitutional adjudication", to underline its changes in the context of increasingly multi-level rights protection systems and of a system of sources of law transfigured by complex international and supranational relations. In the last part of the course we will therefore analyze, starting from concrete cases, the dialogue that the Italian constitutional judge has established with foreign, international and supranational jurisdictions; analysis that aims to provide the student with the tools for a better awareness of the logic and the ways in which our jurisdiction is part of a wider remedial system, with an European and international dimension.

data.name: Fisica generale III
Teorie e tecniche dei media digitali

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
1. Knowledge and critical understanding of main digital media, their use, their differences, strengths and weaknesses.
2. Ability to devise a digital strategy on the main social media, related to the traditional ones.
3. Ability to devise a content strategy and an editorial plan on the main social media.
4. Ability to appreciate brands in their global dimension, by coordinating brand identity, image and reputation in a coherent communication plan.
5. Ability to draw up and deliver effective presentations.

data.name: Introduction to Computer Programming (Matlab)
data.description:
This course is designed to teach you the fundamentals of programming using Matlab. The course will cover: variables, arrays, functions, conditional (if) statements, loops (for), user input (keyboard, mouse) as well as basic graphics and audio presentation. The course will emphasise the skills needed for the cognitive scientist and instruction will focus on developing experimental paradigms (using Psychtoolbox) and will also cover coding for data processing, analysis and visualisation. 

By the end of the course, students should have learned the fundamental concepts of coding, developed a range of skills useful for the cognitive scientist, and reached a point where they can further develop their coding repertoire independently.

data.name: Precision engineering: digital manufacturing

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The course aims to teach the basics of the design and implementation of precision measurement systems, understanding the importance of the correct definition of requirements and specifications, system design, and development of a measurement model and noise sources.


Furthermore, the practical part of the course also requires the learning of computer and programming techniques, also on microcontrollers, for the use of sensors and transducers in the realization of a complex measurement system.

data.name: Filosofia politica
data.description:
The course aims to provide: a) an introduction to political philosophy through an analysis of its historical evolution and its most important theoretical paradigms; b) an analysis of the political thought of Thomas Hobbes


At the end of the class, the students will be able to:

A) define the disciplinary field;

B) place the field within the wider context of philosophical scholarship;

C) identify the core questions of the field 

D) critically read and understand classical texts;

E) identify and discuss key terms and core concepts regarding the authors and texts studied during the course

F) grasp continuity and discontinuity in the historical evolution of political thought

data.name: Fondamenti di meteorologia e climatologia
Storia delle culture e delle tradizioni religiose nell'antichità classica
data.description:
The specific educational aims of the course " History of Cultures and Religious Traditions in Classical Antiquity " are:

- to stimulate awareness of the complexity of religious beliefs and practices in classical antiquity
- to stimulate awareness of the structural link between these practices and the politics, economy and societies of the ancient world
- to develop students' knowledge and understanding of some of the religious aspects of ancient civilisations
- to provide the intellectual tools needed to critically discuss the peculiarities of polytheism in ancient civilisations
- to develop students' knowledge and understanding of the reflections developed by ancient thinkers on religious beliefs and practices

Learning outcomes:

a. Knowledge and understanding
Students are expected

-to become familiar with the peculiarities of polytheism in ancient civilisations as well as their pervasive character in those civilisations of which they are an integral part.
-to understand the main problems related to some of the religious aspects of ancient civilisations
-to become familiar with the peculiarities of polytheism in ancient civilisations
-to understand the reflections developed by ancient thinkers on religious beliefs and practices


b. Skills. Students are expected:


-to recognize the main religious-historical issues and to formulate their own research questions
- to develop their ability to approach religious-historical issues with academic rigour
- to develop their ability to critically discuss the reflections developed by ancient thinkers on religious beliefs and practices
-to read and critically assess primary and secondary source materials and evaluate different sources of information

data.name: Advanced Number Theory
data.description: The course has the goal to provide knowledge of modern tools and topics of number theory, which also have important applications in several fields (e.g., cryptography).

data.name: Introduction to Islamic Law
data.description:
This course aims at offering an introduction to Islamic law from the historical and substantive perspectives. Students will be introduced to some of the core issues, which have animated Islamic law since its origins, and which are hotly debated in the contemporary age. References will also be made to some States’ past and contemporary experiences.

Upon completion of the course, students are expected to know the notions examined throughout the course, to develop a critical attitude on the issues concerned, to appreciate the contested nature of key concepts and topics, and to be able to express themselves in a methodologically correct way, by grounding their arguments on the relevant legal norms/literature, and by using the appropriate legal terminology.

data.name: Filologia germanica I
Advanced Calculus of Variations
data.description: Students should acquire and consolidate the knowledge of methods and tools of the Calculus of Variations and its applications, in particular to the study of integral functionals. Students should also understand and master the logical structure of the arguments and proofs presented in the course, and be able to modify them in order to tackle new problems independently.

data.name: Industrial Innovation in Communications, Radars and Sensing Systems
Academic Freedom and Human Rights: European and International Perspectives (J. Monnet module)

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
Academic freedom refers to freedom of research, freedom to teach/learn, university institutional autonomy and liberty to express ideas in the public sphere. It is critical in European top-quality higher education and in democratic societies generally. It is anchored in the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights and in the Constitution of most member States. The course will map the historical development of this principle in different geopolitical areas and will reflect on the main violations of academic freedom and on the consequences this holds for universities and for society more broadly. One of the main aims of the course is to combine conceptual-theoretical discussion with advocacy research and campaign on current cases of violations of academic freedom.

 

By the end of the course students will have acquired (gained knowledge):

1.                 A detailed and critical knowledge about different interpretations of academic freedom in different times and contexts;

2.                 An understanding of how different disciplines have contributed to the understanding of one of the key principles of higher education and democratic societies;

3.                 The capacity to discuss the connections between academic freedom, freedom of expressions and other human rights;

4.                 The capacity to discuss and compare different cases of violations of academic freedom, the way they involve students, researchers, administrative staff and higher education communities more broadly, and how violations different between authoritarian and democratic contexts;

5.                 Awareness about the relevance of policies aiming at protecting academic freedom de jure and de facto at local, national and supranational levels;

6.                 The capacity to link theory and practice through advocacy research. 

 

By the end of the course students are expected to have acquired (practical and communication skills):

7.                 Propose and discuss their opinions within the class;

8.                 Organise and present work in progress to other students and in the public sphere;

9.                 Autonomy in managing group work and in developing an advocacy campaign, also in collaboration with students working on similar cases in other universities;

10.             Writing an advocacy report on the studied case;

11.             Conducting an interview with a key expert.

data.name: Laboratorio Formula SAE
data.description: The laboratory course covers the activities carried out within the Formula SAE project. It is reserved to active members of the Formula SAE Team.

data.name: Sociologia dei processi culturali e comunicativi
data.description: Aimed at allowing an adequate understanding of the cultural processes that characterize the current phase of modernity (late modernity) and therefore making visible all the elements that differentiate it from previous events, the course aims to train students in a less precarious and fragmented reading of cultural processes. that characterize contemporary Italy. At the end of the course, the student is expected to be able to have full autonomy in the face of media reductions and cognitive trivializations that inevitably characterize current discourse. To achieve such an objective, he is expected to be able to appropriate and use the key concepts of sociological analysis (representations, beliefs, values, moral conscience) as well as to know the main phenomenologies that characterize contemporary Italian society and that the pandemic of Covid has brought out: individualization, awareness of the moral environment, relational dimension.

data.name: Tecniche di programmazione avanzata
data.description:
This course covers object-oriented programming and concurrent programming with C++ language. After a review of basic procedural programming constructs, (if-then-else, for cycles, functions, memory allocation), the student will be exposed to basic principles of object-oriented programming, focusing on the advanteges with respect to procedural paradigm. Special emphasis will be given to implementative aspects, which will allow students to acquire solid practical programming skills. At the end of the course, the students will be able to:
- understand pros and cons of different programming paradigms (procedural, object, concurrent)
- choose the appropriate programming paradigm for a specific application
- implementing C++ programs with procedural paradigm
- implementing C++ programs with object oriented programming
- implementing simple C++ programs to execute multiple operations in parallel

data.name: Diritto privato
Risk management

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: The course aims to introduce market risk, credit risk and operational risk. In particular, it introduces the most important risk measures, such as Value at Risk and Expected Shortfall for market risk, credit scoring and capital market models for credit risk and operational risk measurement.

data.name: Service Design and Engineering

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The course focuses on current methodologies, languages and tools to support the "service-oriented" approach to programming and business process management, based on the idea of composing applications by discovering and invoking network-available services rather than building new applications to accomplish some task. In this approach, services are self-contained processes - deployed over standard middleware platforms, e.g., J2EE, Heroku, Docker... - that can be described, published, located, and invoked over a network.

Learning objectives

Knowledge and comprehension:

LO1 Identify and master appropriate software technologies, architectures and systems related to service oriented computing

Analysis:

LO2: Analyze the user and organizational needs for services and their decomposition

LO3: Analyze different service-oriented computing approaches and open standards

Application and skills:

LO4: Model, design and integrate software intensive service applications and information systems

LO5: Apply Conceive-Design-Implement-Operate methodologies to develop software solutions to complex value-added service process and systems challenges

Synthesis and Evaluation:

LO6: Propose novel and innovative services supporting sustainable business processes.

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.name: Democratizing Security
data.description: This course focuses on the relationship between the concepts of security, politics, democracy and human rights. In the first part it offers an examination of the theoretical and historical underpinnings of uncertainty, fear, security and politics both at domestic and at international level. Selected readings by thinkers such as Machiavelli, Hobbes, Schmitt, Arendt, Neumann, Foucault will be analyzed and discussed. In the second part the course will focus on the relationship between security and democracy, human rights and the rule of law. This relationship will be analyzed both in general terms and with regard to selected topics (terrorism, torture, death penalty, etc.). During the second part, students will make oral presentations on specific case studies and lead discussions.

data.name: Current Topics in Brain Connectivity
data.description: The course will provide an introduction into the concepts of brain connectivity. In this seminar course, we will read and discuss up-to-date scientific contributions in the field of general brain connectivity, focusing on both functional and anatomical connectivity measures. The goal of this introductory course is to provide a basic knowledge of the state-of-the-art methods and concepts of accessing brain connectivity measures. At the end of the course, students should have acquired a good overview of the current debates on brain connectivity and they will have learned the appropriate terminology and computational concepts. They will be familiarized with the concepts of experimental connectivity measures and they will be able to critically access new publications on the topic.

data.name: Matematica
data.description:
The course intends to provide the fundamental mathematical tools for a quantitative analysis of economics and management, such as differential calculus in one or several variables, linear algebra, and free and constrained optimization.
The presence and active participation in the teaching activities proposed in the theory and exercise classes, together with individual study, are designed to allow students to reach the teaching goals of the course, namely the study of functions in one or several variables, the solution of linear systems, and the analysis of linear models in the economical context.

data.name: Peace and Conflict Studies: Theory and Methods
data.description: The module aim for students is to acquire the methodological and theoretical tools indispensable for understanding war and peace. At the end of the course the student should be familiar with main concepts and definitions associated with studies of conflict and peace, and with main methods and techniques of analysis. He should be able to apply theoretical models to empirical cases, and should be able to generalize the findings of single case-study to classes of political/military phenomena.
data.degreeProgram: EUROPEAN AND INTERNATIONAL STUDIES - STUDI EUROPEI E INTERNAZIONALI (LM)

data.name: Lingua francese I - LM
data.description: Idem

data.name: Arte contemporanea e istituzioni museali
data.description:
Deep knowledge of the most relevant Contemporary Arts events, theories and artworks from 1966 to the 2000s;

Knowledge of the innovation introduced by contemporary art in today Museology;

Critic and historical attitude in using the methodological tools of the discipline;

Ability to comment and evaluate the outcomes and the trouble spots (aesthetically, ideologically, and so on) of a contemporary exhibition or museum;

Capacity to properly argue about the content of the course and to show the apprehended skills;

Ability to relate together theory and practice, general notions and case study;

Ability to carry on autonomous researches in the field of contemporary exhibitions and museums

data.name: Lavoro e società

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
The course aims to provide a theoretical and critical overview of the intertwining of society and work, with specific attention to some of the major contemporary transformations, from globalisation, to precarisation, to digitalisation, to the increasing differentiation of the characteristics and experiences of workers. 

By the end of the course, students are expected to have acquired:

- a thorough knowledge of the key concepts, most relevant issues and fundamental questions of the sociology of work;

- the ability to critically read and interpret the main work transformations and the emerging phenomena, with a main but not exclusive focus on the Italian context;

- a basic knowledge with respect to strategies and ways of doing research on labor, as well as of representing and studying it.

data.name: Minorities, Regionalism and Borders in Europe
data.description:
The overarching objective of this course is to enhance students’ awareness, knowledge and understanding of the saliency of political processes based on the interactions between ethno-territorial identities and political institutions in Europe. The course aims to develop students’ capacity to critically engage with current issues in ethno-territorial politics in Europe from a theoretical, empirical and normative perspective.

By the end of the course, students should have acquired:

- an in-depth understanding of key concepts related to ethno-territorial, multi-level politics, and the concept of territoriality

- awareness of the main ‘hot issues’ in ethno-territorial politics in contemporary Europe, as well as of their political salience

- a solid knowledge of key explanatory theories (e.g. ethnicity and nationalism; state-formation; EU multi-level governance, etc.)

- an understanding of the different scales impacting on or influencing territorial disputes (e.g. local identities, geopolitical interests, globalization processes)  

- familiarity with normative debates on the relative weight of competing principles (e.g. state territorial integrity vs. self-determination of minorities within states)

- an understanding of the legal instruments related to federalism, regionalism, autonomy and cross-border cooperation and their constitutional impact and implications

- the capacity to conduct independent and critical analysis, by engaging effectively in empirical research (at least via secondary sources) and linking case studies to explanatory and normative theories
data.degreeProgram: EUROPEAN AND INTERNATIONAL STUDIES - STUDI EUROPEI E INTERNAZIONALI (LM)

data.name: Optoelectronics and quantum devices for sensing and automation
data.description:
The course provides the basic knowledge of optoelectronics and photonics both classical and quantum including the generation and measurement of light for various applications. At the end of the course the student will be able to:

- know the theoretical concepts at the base of optoelectronics and the interaction of light with matter;

- solve simple physical problems through correct modelling and use of the mathematical tools necessary to reach the quantitative solution.

Attendance and active participation in the training activities proposed by the course (lectures and classroom exercises) and individual study will allow students to:

1) be familiar with the basics of the scientific method applied to the topics of the course;

2) acquire the habit of critical analysis of concepts that enter into scientific and physical theories in particular;

3) participate in lab demonstrations on the topics of the course.

data.name: Economia e misurazione aziendale

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: This course aims to provide students with basic knowledge about organizations and business management, and to foster critical thinking on the role of enterprises in the contemporary economy. The course will begin with an overview of the ongoing debate on the firm’s ultimate goal from both the shareholders and the stakeholders’ views. Subsequent to a review of the core business activities, it will then provide the basic notions of accounting and performance evaluation metrics, and a detailed overview of quantitative decisions-making models, such as economies of scale, learning curves, break-even/profit points, operating leverage etc. Furthermore, it will offer an accurate presentation and discussion of models for strategic analysis, including those with a longitudinal perspective. The course will end with a thorough examination of corporate governance, inquiring into managerial interests, mis-management and potential remedies. At the end of the course, the students will be able: 1. to understand and illustrate, with competence and expertise, the debate on the nature and purpose of enterprises, as institutions aimed at resolving the tension between wealth creation and social demands; 2. to understand, use and evaluate accounting and measurement performance systems; 3. to understand and use quantitative models in support of operation and management decisions; 4. to understand and competently speak about the problem of corporate governance, with a particular focus on the role of managers and the internal/external mechanisms to align shareholders’ and managerial interests; 5. to evaluate and critically assess the functioning and strategies of enterprises in modern economies and their ability to pursue long term success, preserving the financial and institutional equilibria-

data.name: Interazione persona-macchina con elementi di comunicazione multimodale - corso avanzato

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description:
The aim of the course is to present the theoretical and methodological elements of the user experience design, and use them in the process of designing an application. The theoretical part will focus on the motivational aspects (goals, needs, values), the concepts of knowledge and experience, and the cognitive resources of the individuals. The methodological part will focus on the management of a project, the main methods of elicitation of the needs and the knowledge of the users, and the documents and deliverables of the project.

The theoretical models and the methodological tools will be used during the team work to design an application.

Expected learning results

At the end of the course, the student should be able to:

  • understand the theoretical models of motivational and cognitive psychology explained during the lessons
  • apply the research, elicitation, representation and design methodologies to the project
  • deliver a clear presentation of the project

data.name: Meccanica delle costruzioni con elementi in vetro delle tensostrutture e delle strutture murarie

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
The course aims to merge structural engineering and architectural vision, often believed to be opposite poles that are difficult to reconcile but whose integration is essential for the realization of multifunctional buildings.


The topics addressed during the course will first deal with the comprehensive vision typical of undergraduate courses and then with the pragmatic attitude of the professional world. This last aspect is essential to help students to enter the world of work. It will be accomplished thanks to the partnership with an expert operating in the civil engineering sector, in particular in the building of mega-structures, tensile structures, and retractable construction systems. Such an expert will show the various project phases, from the brainstorming up to the complete realization on site, with the final aim of providing the student with that "mindset" necessary for success in the professional world.

The first part of the course focuses on analyzing the local and global mechanical behavior of masonry and the cracking pattern. It will be shown that the design methods of the masonry structures based on the curve of pressure and the inverted catenary are conceptually similar to those used for the design of tensile structures, discussed in the second part of the course. The two structural systems are respectively not resistant to traction and not resistant to compression, hence the duality of the calculation techniques.

The second part of the course deals with the study of "special" structures realized with unconventional materials and technologies that require a significantly different design approach from that used where classic materials are employed. In particular, this part of the course deals with:

  • the design of glass facades. The theoretical concepts will be applied to the design of the main structural elements used in architecture and engineering (parapets, decks, beams, columns, fins, etc.) both by simplified strategies and by finite element simulations, accordingly to the CNR DT 210 guidelines; 
  • the form-finding and design of tensile structures, based on the concept of lightness (limited weight compared to the surfaces and volumes built) and sustainable architecture aimed at using light, low cost, and low environmental impact materials. The analysis of case studies will support the theoretical aspects.  
  • the details, cutting patterns, cables, and textile materials;
  • the principles underlying parametric design (or computational design). This design approach, considered the design method of the future, allows the designer a unique combination of forms and architectural composition.


At the end of the course, the student must demonstrate an understanding of the topics addressed during the course by applying the theoretical concepts to case studies.

data.name: Fisica e modellistica dell'atmosfera

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
The course provides an in-depth analysis of atmospheric processes relevant for various environmental engineering applications. Large space is dedicated to the modelling tools for weather forecasting, air pollution simulations and the assessment of renewable energy availability. 

At the end of the course the student should:

  • know the basics of atmospheric processes relevant for different environmental engineering applications, such as pollutant dispersion and the assessment of renewable energy resource availability
  • know the basics of meteorological and atmospheric dispersion models
  • know methodologies of data analysis and models to evaluate solar and wind energy availability
  • be able to interpret the output of meteorological models and realize simple weather forecasts
data.degreeProgram: Ingegneria per l'ambiente e il territorio (LM)

data.name: Cell Therapy

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description:
The main purpose of the course is to provide students with a broad and integrated knowledge of the biology of pluripotent and tissue-specific stem cells, of the experimental approaches useful for investigating their properties and for their exploitation as tools to understand and cure human diseases. 

The goal is to train students on recent discoveries in this area and to implement their communication and critical skills.

At the end of the course the student are expected to be able:
- to describe different types of stem cells and their classification
- to explain their potential use in therapeutical approaches and compare cell sources
- to read and understand scientific papers on experimental approaches to cell therapy
- to analyse and critically discuss the experiments and the steps required to move from basic research to clinical applications
- to combine the knowledge acquired in this course with the contents of the Gene Therapy course to design and present new therapeutic approaches to specific human diseases.

At the end of the course the student will be able to:
- describe different types of stem cells and their classification
- explain their potential use in therapeutical approaches and compare cell sources
- read and understand scientific papers on experimental approaches to cell therapy
- analyse and critically discuss the experiments performed in the experimental laboratories
- integrate the knowledge acquired in this course with the contents of the Gene Therapy course to design and present new therapeutic approaches to specific diseases.

data.name: Laboratorio di chimica
data.description:
The course aims to illustrate the main analytical chemical techniques, with reference to industrial applications in quality control of the products, and processing of experimental data.
At the end of the course the student should acquire the basic knowledge on the different analytical methods and be able to appropriately apply the analytical tools for identifying unknown compounds and quantifying  mixture components, considering the errors associated to the measurements.

data.name: Functions and Plasticity of the Central Nervous System

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description:
The view that neurons in the active brain may change in response to experience - a process identified as "plasticity" - has become a fundamental issue in neuroscience research. 
I - Common pathways for neuronal development and synaptic plasticity; it is becoming increasingly clear that molecular networks involved in tissue growth and differentiation during development also play distinct roles in the adult nervous system and may even participate in neurodegenerative processes. In this course we will deal with the plasticity of the developing brain emphasizing the critical role played by neuronal connections and activity in normal development. 
II - Broader themes of plasticity in the adult brain; we will focus on the search for the underlying  mechanisms of plasticity as biophysical, cellular and molecular  factors controlling neuronal plasticity. 
Achieving a central understanding of what causes neuronal plasticity could help the students to understand the learning capabilities of the healthy brain and the cognition deficits in neurological disorders.

data.name: Statistical Mechanics
data.description:
The objective of this course is to provide the students with the foundations of the theoretical methods employed in the investigation of ideal and interacting statistical systems. Specifically, the course will focus on the approximate calculation methods for the partition function, on phase transitions, and on the theoretical methods for the analysis of the latter. The discussion of these topics will be complemented with the study and application of specific mathematical tools.

The attendance to the lectures and individual study, carried out according to the indications provided during the course, will allow the students to:

- Strengthen the basic concepts of the statistical treatment of thermodynamic systems at equilibrium
- Get acquainted with approximate methods for the calculation of thermodynamic quantities and state equations, such as cluster expansion and virial expansion.
- Gain a sufficiently detailed knowledge of phase transitions, mean field theory, Landau theory, scaling and universality, and renormalisation group techniques.

data.name: Computer vision
data.description: The course aims to provide the student with an in-depth overview on the methods of analysis and management of multimedia data. Starting from the basics of image and video processing, the course will focus on the problems of motion modeling and detection, motion tracking, and object recognition, both by using monocular and multi-view systems.

data.name: European Union Law
data.description:
The course aims at providing the students with a theoretical and practical understanding of the functioning of the legal framework and the institutions of EU law. Students will be trained to assess the relevance of legal arguments with reference to a number of case studies drawn from the case law European judicial institutions. More specifically, the general learning outcomes of the course are as follows:

Understand the logic and the value added of legal reasoning within the European Union.
Discuss the functioning of the sources of the law and their normativity.
Critically assess the consequences of the breach of the law in specific situations.
Understand the role of diversified actors and institutions in the creation and application of EU Law.
Analyse the main areas of the European Union policy.
data.degreeProgram: Comparative, European and International Legal Studies (L2)

data.name: Gestione della produzione e della qualità
data.description:
The course's main objective is to analyze the operational function of the firm, highlighting the fundamental components of the production system, its design variables, and principles of operation and management, with a view limited to the organizational boundaries of the enterprise. The course is structured in four parts, devoted to analyzing the essential elements of production processes, single unit management, coordination between several production units, and finally, issues related to quality management.


Upon completion of the course, the student will be able to:

1. identify the fundamentals of production processes and the main characteristics from the perspective of control, design, and management;

2. identify and distinguish the main features of manufacturing production processes from those aimed at service production;

3. recognize and classify the essential patterns through which manufacturing processes are organized, including in direct observation of practical cases; analyze and describe production processes through mapping of physical and information flows;

4. identify the nature of problems that characterize the management of materials (in manufacturing processes) and utilities (in service processes) with the development of simple optimization solutions;

5. select and design simple planning models for the management of production systems, developing and evaluating production plans;

6. give solutions to the main problems of short-term planning, including the elaboration of simple operational solutions;

7. acquire the fundamentals of quality management models, with a focus on the main design options and operational tools;

8. design and process quantitative analyses for production and quality systems, critically discussing critical elements of the systems, including those related to open contexts.

data.name: Diritto processuale tributario
data.description:
The study of the taxation lawsuit is one of the most important issues in the tax law because it has constituted and still constitutes a mandatory step of passing for the establishment of important interpretative principles of substantive law. The course aims to analyze the procedural system with a wide involvement of students in the drafting of procedural acts.
The course is divided into two parts tending to the doctrinal and jurisprudential development of the institutes, the second to a procedural simulation.
At the end of the course the student will be able to:
• Recognize and Apply Proceedings, Know the Reference Doctrine, and Principal Jurisprudential Theses
• Make an appeal at first instance
• Draw an act of replies
• Prepare a precautionary claim
• Discuss and support defensive theses as well as the legitimacy of an administrative measure
• Set up a tax ruling

data.name: Embedded Software for the Internet of Things

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
Contemporary Internet of Things (IoT) systems comprise embedded computing devices that enable perceiving information about anything, at any time and from anywhere. These devices are interconnected, often embedded in the environment, small in size, battery-powered, and constrained in terms of computation and communication resources. These properties pose peculiar system-level challenges to develop IoT applications. 

The objective of this course is to expose students to programming languages, hardware platforms, operating systems, and, in general, the necessary software tools and techniques geared towards the development of IoT applications. By the end of this course, the students are expected to acquire the theoretical and practical skills to interface with state-of-the-art embedded computing platforms. They will be equipped with the fundamentals to design and develop IoT applications, including, but not limited to, electrocardiogram sensing and interpretation, image processing with low-resolution cameras, machine learning on the edge, wireless localization, and many more. 

Upon successful completion of this module, students should be able to:
- Characterize the main architectural components of microcontroller-based IoT platforms
- Use the development environments and toolchains to program and debug microcontrollers
- Design, implement and test embedded software by following the fundamental methodologies for IoT systems
- Assess IoT application performance and understand the techniques used for optimizing systems execution
- Characterize the basics of real-time scheduling and the main components of embedded real-time operating systems

data.name: Progettazione di infrastrutture idrauliche urbane

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
At the end of the course the student will be able to:

·      design hydraulic infrastructures for water collection, delivery, and distribution (aqueducts);

·      develop management and maintenance strategies for water distribution networks: theoretical notes and modeling applications to practical cases.

·      modify existing networks in order to adapt them to the changed situation due to anthropogenic and climatic changes;

·      evaluate the effects of climate change on the available water resource and on urban runoff;

·      evaluate the best design strategies capable of mitigating the effects of climate change in urban drainage networks and water resource distribution networks

data.name: Stochastic processes (I modulo)

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description:
The course aims to provide the main concepts and results of probability theory that find applications in coding  and cryptography. It is essentially divided into two parts. The first part introduces the theory of discrete-state stochastic processes and their main applications. The second part provides basic elements of information theory, introducing the concept of entropy and illustrating Shannon's theorems.
 
At the end of the course the student will know some topics of probability theory and stochastic processes with discrete states, as well as some elements of information theory as specified by the course program. He will also be able to understand the mathematical modeling in terms of suitable stochastic processes of a large class of random phenomena.
The student will also be able to reason inductively and deductively in the solution of problems involving random phenomena. He will also be able to schematize a random phenomenon in rigorous terms, to develop logical arguments and produce correct proofs, as well as to explain them clearly.
The student must also be able to acquire and manage new information regarding random models.

data.name: Machine learning
data.description:
The aim of the course is to provide knowledge of both theoretical and practical aspects of machine learning, and present the main techniques of machine learning and probabilistic reasoning.


At the end of the course, students will be able to:


- describe the main machine learning techniques, with their characteristics and limitations


- master probabilistic reasoning techniques


- model simple probabilistic scenarios with Bayesian Networks


- realize learning programs tailored to the specific problem to be addressed.

data.name: Basi di dati

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
We live in a world full of data. Almost every human activity nowadays produces data or needs access to data. As such, there is a need for effective and efficient solutions that will allow us to store, maintain, search and retrieve large volumes of data. This is what the data management systems do. The goal of this course is to teach the students the fundamental concepts of data  management, to train them in order to be able to design of good databases, give them the ability to build complex queries, and allow them to identify and solve performance problems in real life situations. 
Naturally the course focuses on relational databases since the relational model is the one that drives most of the existing data management systems in the industry nowadays, it has been around for more than 30 years and has been one of the most studied model, and has been the one with the most commercial tools in operation.

data.name: Fog and Cloud Computing

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
In the last few years, the cloud computing revolution heavily impacted the ICT world: cloud infrastructure, both public and private, hosts a significant portion of modern digital services and data. Cloud technologies and methodologies, such as virtualisation, containerisation, micro-service based architectures and service-meshes, are becoming prevalent among large technology providers, cloud operators and software developers. New software applications are, in turn, being developed following the so called cloud-native paradigm in order to exploit the benefits, such as scalability and reliability, offered by the cloud infrastructure and services.

Within this technological revolution, topics such as data locality and management are also attracting increasing interest. For this reason, one area of significant development in this space is that of edge computing resources, leading to the emergence of the fog computing paradigm. Indeed, more and more services are beginning to exploit, or even require, its benefits in terms of reduced latency, lower bandwidth consumption through near data source pre-processing, or simply guarantees around the geo-location of data.

This course provides an introduction to Cloud and Fog computing principles and technologies, following a practical, hands-on approach. More specifically, at the end of the course the student will: (1) learn about cloud and fog computing models, technologies and existing solutions; (2) acquire relevant knowledge on advanced topics related to networking, orchestration and security; (3) use and configure advanced open-source platforms to create and manage cloud computing infrastructures and to effectively and dynamically orchestrate workloads.
data.degreeProgram: Ingegneria Informatica, delle Comunicazioni ed Elettronica (L2)

data.name: Metodologia della ricerca qualitativa

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description:
The main objective of the course is to provide students with the basic knowledge and tools used in psychology qualitative research.

In particular, during lectures students will focus on three qualitative research techniques regularly used in psychology: observation (participant and non-participant), interviews and focus groups.


During the lectures and through individual study, students will achieve the following learning outcomes:

1. recognise the three qualitative research methods (observation, interviews, focus groups) and the relevant existing literature, analysing examples of how researchers have used them while simultaneously practicing and experiencing them in class.

2. Understand the appropriate use of different research techniques given a specific research question. 

3. Use observation, interviews and focus groups, understanding how the choice of each of these techniques can help them explore a topic or research question.


Finally, this course will help students to consolidate learning skills, critical judgement, teamwork and communication skills.
data.degreeProgram: Scienze e Tecniche di Psicologia Cognitiva (L2)

data.name: Corso di spagnolo A1 - I periodo (estensivo)
Grounded Language Processing

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The course deepens one of the holy grails of AI: the development of computational models that ground language into vision. Its goal is to (1) provide students with an overview of
the field showing how Computer Vision and Computational Linguistics
have been connected to develop multimodal models; (2) deep the
study of neural networks which understand and generate visually grounded
natural language; (3) know evaluation methods of multimodal models  as
well as their limitations; (4) familiarize students with scientific
papers and with the writing of scientific reports; (5) If time allows,
we will study the connections with Robotics and the comparison of
 humans’ neural representations and attention mechanisms
behind grounded NL and State-of-the-Art multimodal models.

At the end of the course, students will be able to (1) illustrate the
main research directions in the field, the long-standing ones as well
as the new challenges; (2) know the tools and resources at disposal
and apply interdisciplinary approaches
to the development of multimodal modal and; (3)
compare different approaches with appropriate evaluation methods; (4)  write a
scientific report on a research project.

data.name: Metodi quantitativi

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description: We will introduce the main methods to understand formal methods and to analyze empiric data through statistics. In particular, we will show how to summarize data through graphs and index measures and how the unknown measures of the population can be estimated by sample data. Moreover, the main data sources for social analysis will be introduced. Lastly, mathematic models of social and political behavior will be introduced (decision and game theory).

data.name: Propagazione mobile e wireless

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: The course provides the basic knowledge for the analysis and design of wireless systems and devices. Starting from the analysis of different applications and scenarios, the course presents the most important wireless technologies and architectures adopted in the state of the art, with a deep and comparative analysis of the relevant software and hardware parts. The objective of the course is to provide the basic instruments to the information engineer for the analysis, design and planning of wireless systems and devices currently adopted and of possible future use in application contexts of relevant scientific and industrial interest such as smart cities, internet of things (IoT), and industry 4.0.

data.name: Laboratorio di Programmazione
data.description:
By the end of the course, you should be able to understand the theoretical and practical problems of coding.


During the course, you will be introduced to more pragmatic considerations that need to be considered when coding that includes how to understand and use (a substantial part of) the Java programming language from the basic imperative constructs to more advanced features (e.g., Object Oriented Programming).


The ultimate goal is to enable you to make executable the algorithms that you may be interested to design while considering their correctness and efficiency.

data.name: Multimedia Data Security

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: Nowadays great facility to access information implies the need to study data protection techniques. The objective of the course is the investigation of some methodologies which guarantee secure access to multimedia data, through various data hiding and digital forensics techniques. The student at the end of the course will know a series of state-of-art methodologies for the active and passive forensics analysis of multimedia data and he/she will know how to apply them to digital images in simple scenarios.

data.description: The objective of this course is to provide the students the required concepts for the understanding, the design and the evaluation of advanced processing architectures, with emphasis on the various forms of parallelism. At the end of the course, the student will be able to comprehend the organization of recent central processing units, and to design customized architectures, analyzing and evaluating the effects of architectural choices, identifying the critical components, and comparing different solutions in terms of performance and cost, to select the optimal ones in various domains of application. The student will in particular acquire the skills to program applications for GPUs using CUDA.

data.name: Lingua tedesca II - LM
data.description:
To be able to explain the concept of communicative closeness and distance according to Koch/Oesterreicher (1985) and to apply it to the analysis;

To be able to analyse transcripts of oral communicative genres paying particular attention to the typical characteristics (e.g. personal and local deixis, discourse particles, turn-taking);
