data.name: Gestione sostenibile delle imprese
data.description:
The course aims to present how to incorporate sustainable methods into all aspects of an organization and to describe the most important tools for monitoring, managing and improving environmental performance.
Attendance and active participation at the course and self-study will enable students to:
1. Know the role of the management in developing an environmentally and socially responsible enterprise
2. Know and Apply Environmental Communication Tools
3. Organize the activities to carry out an environmental audit
4. Identify and Measure some environmental costs in the firms budget

data.name: Seminario: Contemporary health promotion for a changing world

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.name: Multimodal Electrophysiological Recording and Stimulation
data.description: Methods for recording electrophysiology (both invasively and non-invasively) are increasingly combined in brain research with the application of electrical and/or magnetic stimuli on the cerebral cortex. The main objective of this course (in the FIRST SEMESTER, 42 ore) is to set methodological foundations of two non-invasive techniques (also present at CIMeC): Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (TMS) and Electroencephalography (EEG): The course will provide an in-depth framework for both techniques for data acquisition, pre-processing as well as statistical analysis. At the end of the course, students should have acquired relevant concepts and appropriate terminology. Moreover, they should have acquired a deep knowledge of most well-known packages analysis pipelines for pre- and post-processing of data.

data.name: Informatica di base (abilità informatiche)
data.description:
The aim of the course is to make students familiar with the management, processing and presentation of experimental data, through the use of the most popular programs available on the market (Excel and Power Point).
The acquired skills will enable students to view and analyze data collected in experimental laboratories and to present them to an audience through oral and written presentations.

data.name: Storia del teatro latino
data.description: Knowledge of the history of Latin theatre from its origins to the Middle Ages in its literary and dramaturgical aspects, with reference to its fortune in the following centuries up to the contemporary age. Knowledge of Plautus' theatre and its comic and dramaturgical mechanisms.

data.name: Design methods for unmanned vehicles
Topics in continuum and structural mechanics

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.name: Economia dei mercati e degli intermediari finanziari

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The course aims to train students to understand the financial contracts issued by intermediaries and / or traded in financial markets. 
The first part of the program will examine the contracts "to confidential information" (deposits, bank loans, factoring, leasing, etc.), the second part of the course instead of listed financial instruments (money market, bonds, equity, foreign exchange and derivatives), the third part of the course will examine the insurance contracts (life insurance) and the last part of the course the logical construction of the portfolios (portfolios and asset management tools). 
At the end of the course, the student will be able to: 
1. know the characteristics of the main contracts for confidential information; 
2. know the risk and return profile of market instruments (money market, bonds, equity, foreign exchange and derivatives) 
3. understand the purpose of insurance contracts and the underlying logic; 
4. understand how portfolio and asset management products can help to reduce financial risks and their economic space of utilization.

data.name: Protezione idraulica dei territori montani

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
‎The primary objective of the course is to provide a qualitative and quantitative approach to the subject of hydraulic 'natural hazards' characterising mountain environments.


The course aims to provide the following knowledge:

========================================

• concepts of hazard and risk associated with natural hazards of the hydraulic type

• knowledge of the origin and dynamics of mountain natural hazards such as avalanches, torrential floods and debris flows;

• the physical-mathematical description of the phenomena underlying natural hazards (mathematical modelling) and the characteristics of the numerical tools used to simulate these hazards;

• typology and functioning of mitigation works, in relation to the different types of phenomena to which they are directed. In particular:

=> for avalanches:

> rigid support works (bridges and snow racks)

> flexible support works (snow nets)

> references to other types of works

=> For flows and torrential floods:

> storage areas

> open weirs

> gullies


• references to regulatory aspects relating to the subject.


It aims to develop the following skills:

=============================

• ability to use numerical modelling tools for avalanche phenomena, debris flows and intense torrential solid transport

• ability to interpret and assess the quality of the simulations carried out and to choose the calibration parameters appropriately;

• ability to draw up a danger map for avalanches and debris flows;

• ability to design, from a hydraulic point of view, mitigation works in relation to the different types of phenomena to which they are directed.



It is also planned to provide some seminars on civil protection issues.
data.degreeProgram: Ingegneria per l'ambiente e il territorio (LM)

data.name: Introduction to Computer and Network Security
data.description: This is an introductory course to the increasingly important area of computer and network security. The main goal is to enable students to (i) understand the theoretical and practical problems of information security, (ii) understand and recognize threats to fundamental security properties: confidentiality, integrity, and availability, and (iii) understand how the main security mechanisms - such as cryptography, authentication and authorization protocols, and access control - can be applied to mitigate vulnerabilities.

data.name: Robot Planning and its application

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: In this course the student will be introduced to a complete methodology for designing production-ready robot applications. The considered applications will be those for which motion planning plays a major role. The student activities will revolve around a motivational application proposed in the form of a simple robotic competition, in which the robot has to complete a number of tasks in minimum time avoiding obstacles and dangerous spots. Contrary to a standard robotic competition, the student will have to discuss the theoretical underpinning of the method she/he chose to adopt for the competition.

data.name: Elettrotecnica

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description: The course aims at teaching the the fundamentals of Electrical Engineering and the most important electric applications. Electric circuits both in stationary and sinusoidal state and the developments of the three-phase network are studied. Operating principles of electric machines and electric power systems are treated. At the end of the course, the student will be able to understand the main electric machines: transformers, generators, motors, power lines, overcurrent protection and electrical safety.
data.degreeProgram: Ingegneria per l'ambiente e il territorio (L2)

data.name: Environmental sustainability

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
The course introduces key concepts to analyse relationships between politics and the environment, on the basis of literature on policy studies, and on theory of the commons. Special attention will be devoted to the multilevel analysis of the Sustainable Development Goals. In particular the course will address urban sustainability, agricultural production, risk evaluation of chemical pollution and climate change mitigation. 
At the end of the programme students will be able to:
- Describe main characteristics of contemporary environmental issues, collecting available quantitative and qualitative data
- Acquire a technical glossary to understand environmental issues and policy
- Critically analyse principles and methods to achieve environmental sustainability.

data.name: Semantics and Cognition
data.description:
To gain knowledge of the practices and methodologies of state-of-the-art research at the intersection of semantics/pragmatics and cognitive science. Which new issues can be raised and answered by collaboration between semanticists and cognitive scientists?

To acquire methodological expertise and theoretical know-how to participate in collaborative projects involving linguists, computer scientists, and cognitive scientists.

To learn to critically read interdisciplinary papers and pursue interdisciplinary research projects (from linguistic analysis/formalization through (cognitive) computational modeling to experimental work and back).

To study recent literature combining semantic methods with cognitive science research.

data.name: Laboratorio di pianificazione finanziaria
data.description:
The Lab aims at providing competence and skills in the domain of financial analysis and planning, and management control in small and medium enterprises. Students will learn how to build financial models by means of specialised software tools in order to produce management reports on financial performance, cash budgets, cost and break-even analysis.
Nota bene: Erasmus students wishing to attend the course must contact the coordinator (Professor Luca Erzegovesi, luca.erzegovesi@unitn.it). They will be allowed to participate only if the duration of their stay at Trento is compatible with the special work plan of this class.

data.name: Cultura materiale dei cacciatori raccoglitori
data.description: Students will be able to develop specific skills on topics related to cultural anthropology and the scientific concept of culture in order to deepen their critical capacity in relation to the various forms that the material culture of hunter-gatherer human groups has acquired over time and in different geographical regions. Through theoretical understanding, subject knowledge, critical capacity and appropriate vocabulary, students will be able to make autonomous, personal and scientifically reliable judgements on the influence that anthropology and archaeology have and have had as tools for investigating the past.

data.name: Mechanics and materials for engineering design
data.description:
One of the most important subjects for any student of materials engineering is the behavior of materials, mechanical components and structures under load. The way in which they react to applied forces, the resulting deflections and the stresses and strains set up in the bodies concerned are all vital considerations when designing a mechanical component such that it will not fail under predicted load during its service lifetime. All the essential elements of a treatment of these topics are contained within this course, starting with the concepts of mechanics of materials (stresses-strains, beam theory, thick cylinders, plasticity, fracture mechanics) and moving on to the examination of strength and stiffness verifications on mechanical components such as cylinders, joints, springs, shafts, bearings and mechanical transmissions.

By the end of this course students should: (1) be able to analyze the stress and strain on mechanical components and understand, identify and quantify failure modes for mechanical parts; (2) know basic machine elements used in machine design and design machine elements to withstand the loads and deformations for a given application, while considering additional specifications; (3) be able to approach a design problem successfully, taking decisions when there is not a unique answer; (4) be familiar with team-working, mathematical computing and CAD software; (5) be able to present analyses in a proper format of a written report such that a technically qualified person can follow and obtain similar findings.

data.name: Biologia della cromatina

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description:
The course will focus on understanding the role of chromatin and epigenetics in controlling maintenance of cell identity, tissue development and homeostasis and adaption to environmental changes. Overall, the main objective of the course is to provide to the students a depth knowledge of the mechanisms determining the function of the chromatin in determining genome function in multiple contexts. The program will emphasize concepts and problem solving attitude over memorization. We will discuss the most advanced methodologies to study the chromatin function to address specific biological questions, including the function of chromatin in controlling gene expression, DNA damage response and transmission of epigenetic traits.
At the end of the course the student will be able to:
- understanding the basis of epigenetics  
- Role of chromatin function in controlling gene expression and genome stability
- Understanding the principle of the most advanced technologies to study chromatin biology
- Developing a solving attitudes and critical view on the function of chromatin

data.name: Applied Cryptography

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
By the end of the course, you should be able to understand the theoretical and practical problems of using cryptographic techniques.


The content of this course is not purely mathematical, you will be introduced to more pragmatic considerations that need to be considered when applying cryptography in real use case scenarios that includes

  • how to identify and understand threats to fundamental security properties (confidentiality, integrity, and availability) when applying cryptography and
  • which cryptographic techniques are useful to preserve each one of the basic security properties.

data.name: Epigenetics of Cancer

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description:
Epigenetics of Cancer is the study of the epigenetic mechanisms whose alterations favors tumor initiation and progression. The course will focus on understanding the role of epigenetics in controlling maintenance of cell identity, tissue homeostasis and adaption to environmental changes. In the context of tumorigenesis, the course will provide a framework on the interconnection between alterations of epigenetics, cancer genetics and aberrant environmental signals. Overall, the main objective of the course is to provide to the students a depth knowledge of the alterations of the epigenetic mechanisms that foster tumorigenesis and their possible involvement of designing targeted therapy.
At the end of the course the student will be able to:
- describe different types of epigenetic mechanisms 
- understand the role of epigenetics in controlling gene expression and genome stability
- gain knowledge on the most advanced technologies to profile the epigenome alterations in cancer
- Critically evaluate data regarding cancer epigenomics

data.description: The course is an introduction to group theory.

data.description: Basic understanding of atmospheric dynamics and concepts of weather phenomena from the planetary to the synoptic scale

data.name: Introduzione al diritto anglo-americano
data.description: The course aims to familiarize students with the main characteristics of the Common Law Systems. The study of the historical development of common law and its legal institution and the legal process will help students to appreciate both the similarities and the differences which exist between the two main legal systems of the Western Legal Tradition

data.name: Multisensory interactive systems

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The overall goal of the module is to provide a theoretical and practical basis for the design, development, and evaluation of interactive systems, which are multisensory, tangible, and networked. Students on this module will have the opportunity to explore physical computing concepts, use real-time programming languages, understand the bases of human sensory perception, and design networked interactions in both co-located and remote settings.

On successful completion of this course, students should be able to: 
- Understand fundamental notions on electronic hardware such as micro controllers, single board computers, sensors, and actuators of different kind
- Develop interactive applications based on both embedded systems and desktop solutions, which take inputs from sensors and control a variety of physical and digital outputs
- Apply acquired knowledge on fundamentals of multisensory perception to the design of interactive systems
- Apply techniques for prototyping multisensory interactive systems as well as for their evaluation at both technical and user experience level


Students will apply knowledge and skills from above in completing a semester project in teams. Students will be provided with a large variety of hardware items and software tools, which will enable them to create prototypes of networked, tangible and interactive multisensory systems.

data.name: Matematica
data.description:
The course intends to provide the fundamental mathematical tools for a quantitative analysis of economics and management, such as differential calculus in one or several variables, linear algebra, and free and constrained optimization.

The presence and active participation in the teaching activities proposed in the theory and exercise classes, together with individual study, are designed to allow students to reach the teaching goals of the course, namely the study of functions in one or several variables, the solution of linear systems, and the analysis of linear models in the economical context.

data.name: Diritto tavolare
data.description: The course aims to illustrate the principle features of the System of Land Registry (which records real estate ownership and is peculiar to the Trentino-South Tyrol region) compared to the Registrations system (which characterized the rest of Italy and record contracts), in the broader contest of transfer of immoveable property.

data.name: Laboratory: Data for Market Analysis
data.description: The course aims at providing students with the applied statistical skillset needed to model consumer and buyer preferences and predict marketplace behaviour to help the making of informed business and management decisions. Students are expected to learn how to identify, acquire, manage and analyze data – through the use of the open-source statistical environment R – to address relevant decision-making problems.

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description:
The course aims at providing the students with the basic legal notions needed for industrial and organizational psychologists. Specifically the course will introduce to contracts, individual and collective enterprises, and labour law.

At the end of the course the students will be able to understand the nature of the legal relations within productive organizations and the relative normative sources.

data.name: Language and Social Cognition
data.description: At the end of this course the student will be able to understand primary literature in the areas of beliefs and their impacts of behavior, in research fields including cognitive psychology, psycholinguistics and social cognition.

Fondamenti biologici del comportamento

data.name: Network-based Data Analysis

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
The goal of this course is to enable students to analyze various types of high-dimensional data types commonly encountered in the practice of Molecular Biology using a range of methodologies, including established statistical approaches, machine learning, and recently introduced methods.

At the end of the course, students are expected to possess the following skills:

- familiarity with different types of Molecular Biology data and their specificity;

- good understanding of different conceptual methods for analyzing the data;

- familiarity with practical computational tools for carrying out the analysis;

- ability to frame the results of their analysis in a biological context using networks;

- ability to provide a functional interpretation of the results of their analysis;

- ability to complete a project, write a structured report, and orally present the results of their work.

data.name: European and international commercial law
data.description: The course provides an overview of business law. After some elements of company law from an economic, European and comparative perspective, the course will examine the most relevant topics of company law. Students who have completed the course will be able to understand the essential features of company law in the Member States of the European Union and to provide basic legal advice on company law.

data.name: Introduction to Robotics

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The course offers a bird-eye view on the most important topics related to modern robotics, highlighting the main problems that need to be faced in order to make the robots operate correctly in the environment. Specifically, the course will cover the following topics: taxonomy of the different types of robots, physical modelling of robots (direct and inverse kinematics and dynamics), simulation of models, sensing and actuation solutions for perception and action.
Using the developed models, the most famous methodologies to control robot motion and interaction, will be presented. These methods will be first studied in theory, and then implemented in simulation (with the Python language) to gain practical experience.
Attention will be also paid to illustrate the most common non idealities and issues that are present when controlling robots. The course will adopt a combination of simulation models and lab experiences to consolidate the knowledge transmitted during the theoretical lessons.
After completing the course, students will be able to:
- select the most suitable sensors and actuators for a given robotic application
- model the kinematics and dynamics any kind of robot
- understand the working principles of several control algorithms for robotic systems
- choose the appropriate approach(es) to control a specific system for a given target application
- implement, tune, and test control algorithms with the Python language

data.name: Composizione architettonica 1 - Laboratorio progettuale

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
The course in Architectural Composition 1 aims to gradually introduce the student to the complexity of architectural design by learning the fundamentals, theoretical, analytical and instrumental knowledge required. 

The course aims to develop a more conscious look at the project dimension in the discipline of architecture, developing the basic knowledge of the theoretical and methodological aspects to trace, define, realise and finally transmit the process/design of an articulated architectural body. 

This process is aimed at increasing



a) Of the knowledge and understanding of the theoretical and applicative themes through:



  • The recognition of the elements that regulate the basic formal, spatial, functional and constructive aspects.
  • The analysis of the formation process of the architectural project with reference to the prefigurative and generative aspects of space.
  • The learning of the main themes that characterise the architectural project for contemporary living.

b) The development and consolidation of operative and applicative skills through: 



  • The critical analysis of an architectural project, through reading and breaking down and recomposing by elements.
  • The understanding and use of techniques and methods aimed at developing and transmitting a dimensionally limited architectural project.
  • The management and control of the formal, spatial, functional and constructive choices that an architectural body possesses.


c) Achieving autonomy in design choices and increasing communication skills: 



  • Acting and critically evaluating the interaction between formal, spatial, functional and constructive aspects.
  • By controlling the project and its phases of development also by developing communication strategies useful for the understanding of solutions that are coherent and compatible with the building body being studied.

data.name: Quality and innovation engineering
data.description:
This course covers the scientific and engineering basics of (i) quality management, (ii) innovation management. Specifically, the course main topics are: quality management paradigms, ISO 9000 series of standards, quality awards, process management, basics of risk management, statistical inference, relaibility, innovation management. After completing the course, the student will be able to:

- understand, summarize and compare the main quality management paradigms;

- understand and summarize the ISO 9000 series of standards and the quality awards;

- understand, summarize and analyse the fundamentals of risk management;

- understand, summarize and analyse the fundamentals of process management;

- understand and summarize the fundamentals of statistical inference;

- understand and summarize the fundamentals of innovation management;

- understand and summarize the impact of innovation on sustainability.

data.name: Sociologia dei processi culturali e comunicativi
data.description: Aimed at allowing an adequate understanding of the cultural processes that characterize the current phase of modernity (late modernity) and therefore making visible all the elements that differentiate it from previous events, the course aims to train students in a less precarious and fragmented reading of cultural processes. that characterize contemporary Italy. At the end of the course, the student is expected to be able to have full autonomy in the face of media reductions and cognitive trivializations that inevitably characterize current discourse. To achieve such an objective, he is expected to be able to appropriate and use the key concepts of sociological analysis (representations, beliefs, values, moral conscience) as well as to know the main phenomenologies that characterize contemporary Italian society and that the pandemic of Covid has brought out: individualization, awareness of the moral environment, relational dimension.

data.name: Experimental Mathematics Laboratory at School Level

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The course aims to provide the student with:

- a profound knowledge of elementary mathematics which is taught at Italian “scuola secondaria di secondo grado”, in a broad theoretical framework useful to clarify the links with the most advanced notions and the subtle problems studied in university courses;

- a definition of "good practices" and the competence to implement them to develope a methodology for the design of teaching units (relative to mathematics topics which are recurrent in secondary school curricula) and the subsequent presentation to a class in a defined context, mainly by the frontal-lesson modality.

At the end of the course, the student will be able to:

- Recognize the critical points in the informal presentations available in most math textbooks for the Italian “scuola secondaria di secondo grado”;

- Designing and implementing didactics units and paths, consistent with the "good practices" introduced in the course and applied by the student through a systematic laboratory activity based on the practice of lesson-simulation;

- Doing effective presentations (mainly by the frontal-lesson modality) of mathematics topics which are typical in the Italian “scuola secondaria di secondo grado”, through a conscious use of communicative components (gesture, language) and physical media for communication (first of all, the blackboard ).

- Adapting the content of didactic units/paths and presentations, according to the class context.

data.name: Business and Competition Law
data.description:
The course aims to provide the fundamental notions of business, company and competition law, which economics students must know to be prepared to work in a European and international market. During the course the law of the European Union will be studied in a comparative way, with frequent references to Italian law and that of other Member States.

The course is divided into two parts: 1) European Company Law; 2) European Competition Law.

1) The first part aims to achieve knowledge of the main company law institutes which, thanks to the process of harmonization of EU law, are common to all Member States. In particular, but not limited to, the constitution of the company, the protection of the share capital, shareholders’ rights, mergers and demergers will be studied. At the end of the first part, an in-depth study will be carried out on the jurisprudence of the Court of Justice of the European Union and some cases will be analysed collectively, while others will be assigned to groups of students who will have to present their research in class.

2) The second part will focus on the substantive competition rules, providing key concepts and categorisations, as well as detailed study of antitrust law. This means that cartel prohibitions and the ban of anti-competitive agreements will be analysed. Finally, the Merger Control Regulation will be studied.

Learning objectives. By the end of the course, students are expected to:

- have acquired a basic knowledge of the fundamental principles of European company and competition law;

- have acquired the ability to select, interpret and apply argumentatively the relevant regulation;

- identify the rationale of legal rules and to have acquired the ability to draw conclusions on the issues raised on the basis of a reasoned analysis;

- to be able to express their knowledge with property of language both in writing and orally.

data.name: Machine learning

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description:
The aim of the course is to provide knowledge of both theoretical and practical aspects of machine learning, and present the main techniques of machine learning and probabilistic reasoning.


At the end of the course, students will be able to:


- describe the main machine learning techniques, with their characteristics and limitations


- master probabilistic reasoning techniques


- model simple probabilistic scenarios with Bayesian Networks


- realize learning programs tailored to the specific problem to be addressed.

data.name: Storia moderna e metodologia della ricerca storica
Letteratura latina medievale II
data.description: This module aims at enhancing students' competences on the following subjects: The literary work of Marbodo of Rennes. At the end of the course, students should: 1) to historically contextualise the texts; 2) to translate and interpret the given texts.

data.name: Strategic product design
data.description:
The purpose of the course is to provide the basic knowledge relating to the aspects of product design and design management, which are fundamental in the production of a product and which allow you to design and produce a successful product.

 

At the end of course the student could be able to:


1. Recognize the importance of product design in the success of a product and a company;

2. Know the aspects of product design that are most important for designing and managing an industrial product;

3. Analyze and recognize features related to product design in a product;

4. Use creativity and lateral thinking techniques to address an industrial problem;

5. Have the basics to collaborate with a design team in the design process;

6. Having the basics of design management as a strategic guide with the ability to explain, inspire and demonstrate the ways in which design can contribute to business.

7. Having the basics to manage and complete a design project in an industrial reality

8. be critical, curious and be prone to considering both technical and perceptive news.

data.name: Fisica

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The course provides basic knowledge of Newtonian mechanics and classical electromagnetism, their experimental foundations and their operational capabilities in solving physical problems and developing technological applications.
At the end of the course the student will:
- know the physical laws underlying Newtonian mechanics and classical electromagnetism with their experimental foundations and their fields of application;
- be able to solve simple physical problems through proper modeling and proper use of the mathematical tools needed to reach the quantitative solution.
data.degreeProgram: Ingegneria Informatica, delle Comunicazioni ed Elettronica (L2)

data.name: Sustainable materials management
data.description:
The course is aimed at introducing sustainable materials management as a systemic approach to using and reusing materials more productively. By examining the flow of materials throughout their life cycle, the course will focus on the use of materials in the most productive way with an emphasis on using less, reducing environmental impacts throughout the material life cycle and assuring resources for today and future needs.

The goals and the learning outcomes of the course are to provide overview knowledge on circular economy for materials production, processing, use and end of life through lecturing and practical case studies.

After the course the students would be able to:

  • Understand basic concepts of circular economy, of materials flow (mining, processing, and manufacturing until end-of-life recycling and re-usage), issues and drivers for changes.
  • Recognize impacts (environmental, economic and social) of the current practice of materials processing from a sustainability aspect.
  • Find possible strategies for more sustainable use of materials.

data.name: Gestione delle acque e dei sedimenti per lo sviluppo sostenibile

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
The course deals with water, river sediment and development in a broad sense. It takes a multi-scale (international to local) and multi-dimensional approach and focuses on four main themes: global water and sediment issues, river management and development, access to basic water and sanitation services, water- and sediment-related hazards in the developing world. The course is based on integration among different disciplines – as in the frequently addressed case of eco-hydraulics – and between the technical / engineering and the social, cultural and economical context.


The learning goals of the course are:


1. To develop a critical understanding of the multiple linkages between water, sediment and sustainable human development at different spatial and temporal scales.


2: To understand the main challenges in linking water and sediment management with development issues at an international level, with particular focus on data-scarce contexts


3. To learn design criteria and operation and mainteinance requirements of water supply technologies at community scale


4. To learn the main phenomena, orders of magnitudes, and available data bases on global and continental scale availability and use of water and sediment resources

data.name: Optimisation Based Robot Control

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
This course focuses on control of robotic systems, with special attention to numerical optimal control and reinforcement learning. After reviewing the basic principles of robot modeling and numerical optimization, students will learn different control techniques, from the simplest and most well-known, to the most recent and advanced. Methods will be first studied in theory, and then implemented in simulation (with the Python language) to gain practical experience. Applications will focus on industrial manipulators and legged robots, but the same methods could be also applied to flying robots and wheeled robots. After completing the course, students will be able to:
- understand the working principles of several control algorithms for robotic systems
- choose the appropriate approach(es) to control a specific system for a given target application
- implement, tune, and test control algorithms with the Python language

data.name: Trends and Applications of Computer Vision

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: The course aims to expose the students to the most recent developments in the area of Computer Vision. To this end, the lecturers will introduce a selection of highly researched topics, also through ad-hoc hands-on experiences and open discussions on relevant scientific papers. At the end of the course, the students will learn the theoretical foundations and practical implications of the discussed topics. Through a project-based activity, students will further explore a chosen topic, on which they will gain in-depth knowledge and practical experience with technical tools. In this context, the students will develop their scientific competences (e.g., perform a literature search on a given topic, assess the principles and limits of single approaches), as well as soft skills in written and oral presentation.

data.name: Fog and Cloud Computing

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
In the last few years, the cloud computing revolution heavily impacted the ICT world: cloud infrastructure, both public and private, hosts a significant portion of modern digital services and data. Cloud technologies and methodologies, such as virtualisation, containerisation, micro-service based architectures and service-meshes, are becoming prevalent among large technology providers, cloud operators and software developers. New software applications are, in turn, being developed following the so called cloud-native paradigm in order to exploit the benefits, such as scalability and reliability, offered by the cloud infrastructure and services.

Within this technological revolution, topics such as data locality and management are also attracting increasing interest. For this reason, one area of significant development in this space is that of edge computing resources, leading to the emergence of the fog computing paradigm. Indeed, more and more services are beginning to exploit, or even require, its benefits in terms of reduced latency, lower bandwidth consumption through near data source pre-processing, or simply guarantees around the geo-location of data.

This course provides an introduction to Cloud and Fog computing principles and technologies, following a practical, hands-on approach. More specifically, at the end of the course the student will: (1) learn about cloud and fog computing models, technologies and existing solutions; (2) acquire relevant knowledge on advanced topics related to networking, orchestration and security; (3) use and configure advanced open-source platforms to create and manage cloud computing infrastructures and to effectively and dynamically orchestrate workloads.

data.name: Analisi dei dati e Statistica
data.description: The course is organized in two parts. The first part intends to help students in becoming familiar with data analysis by giving them the necessary tools to study and describe any social and economic phenomenon by the means of graphical methods and numerical summary measures. The second part of the course aims to provide the basic principles of probability calculus and inferential statistics as a collection ot theories, methods and techniques for the quantitative analysis of social and economic problems. For each proposed topic, applications to real data and Monte Carlo simulations with open source software R will be shown.

data.name: Professional English for Data Science

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description: The course aims to extend students’ knowledge of and ability to use grammatical, lexical and textual features of written academic English at B2 level, and to develop students’ skills in giving an academic presentation in English.   An active approach is used, with students producing written texts and then correcting them individually and as a group.  Students will give a presentation during the course.

data.name: Bibliografia e biblioteconomia II
data.description:
The student will acquire the fundamental knowledge and concepts of a modern vision of libraries and the disciplines that define and regulate how they work. The course starts from a survey of concrete cases inevitably connected to the current transition phase, proposes a critical and systematic discussion of the key themes concerning the characteristics, purpose, rules and regulations, and problems of libraries. It refers to the Italian scenario in particular, compared with relevant or emerging trends at an international level. It also provides essential references for concepts, models and procedures for cataloguing, retrieving and citing sources, and for library management.
By the end of the course, the student will have developed an understanding of the content, tools and languages to be more aware and independent in a library environment, cultivate personal interests and pursue future in-depth studies.

data.name: Chimica per il restauro
data.description: The aim of the course it to provide the student with the basis of the chemistry of the materials used in the production, conservation and restoration of the cultural heritage. Students are expected to understand the different properties of the materials of interest in the cultural heritage area, to gather the knowledge of the Physico-chemical factors which promote degradation, the analytical characterization techniques, the conservation methods and the restoration procedures.

data.name: Lab. appl.: Diritto societario della crisi
Storia della matematica e della fisica
Neurogenesis and Brain Regeneration

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description:
The aim of the course is to provide the students with the basis for the understanding of the principles of neurogenesis during development and postanatal life. Particular attention is devoted to mechanisms controlling neurogenesis in physiological and in pathological conditions and how manipulation of neurogenesis might be important to develop regenerative approaches to the diseased CNS. In particular, on completion of this course students will be able to:
1. explain the basic principles of neurogenesis during development and in adult mammalian brain
2. describe the principles of cellular and molecular properties of different mammalian Neural Stem Cell populations
3. explain the mechanisms that regulate neurogenesis in physiological and pathological conditions
4. understand the physiological roles of adult neurogeneis
5. describe the different in vitro systems exploitable for studying neurogenesis and for producing cells for regenerative approaches
6. explain the strategies for exploiting in vivo and in vitro neurogenesis for regenerative purposes

data.name: Introduction to security studies
data.description:
The course introduces students to the key concepts, methods and issues in the study of international security. By doing so, it engages with policy-oriented puzzles and scholarly debates, building on a wide literature including both classics and more recent, unorthodox developments of the discipline. 
The objectives are to develop an understanding of contending approaches to the study of international security, as well as the ability to critically analyse security policies and practices from a conceptual perspective. Such skills will provide a preliminary background to the study of specific security issues, including during the rest of the Master, and are expected to stimulate students to pursue their intellectual and professional interests and develop their own areas of specialization in the field of security.
At the end of the course, students should be able to:
Critically approach a wide range of international security problems
Use a variety of analytical tools towards security
Be conversant with the major policy challenges and theoretical debates regarding security

data.name: Laboratorio qualità prodotti vitivinicoli
Networking II

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The main objective of the course is to describe how softwarization will transform the mobile networks of the future. In the course, the major families of wireless networks in use (WLANs, Cellular Networks and Satellite Networks) will be described and the virtualization and softwarization techniques on such infrastructures will be then introduced. The architectural description of such systems will be aligned with the description of the major communication protocols in all the above architectures. By the end of the course, the student should be able to: 
1) know and design the main architectural components of WLANs, cellular networks and other wireless networks;
2) define new protocols and network paradigms to advance the state-of-the-art
3) understand the network virtualization techniques and be able to effectively use such concepts

data.name: Prova di conoscenza linguistica L.M. - Inglese in ambito economico
data.description:
On completion of the course, students will be able to:
1. understand the main facts and supporting details of a complex text on both concrete and abstract topics relevant to the sphere of economics and management, including current events.
2. interact with a degree of fluency and spontaneity in a variety of simulated contexts in the field of economics and management without strain. They will be able to speak about some specific topics related to business management, economics and relevant current events, as well as describe visual information depicting economic and business trends. They will also be able to talk about their own academic career.
3. compose a short professional business e-mail and/or report on specific issues in an appropriate style.
4. understand short conventional spoken narratives related to topics/practices common to economics and management.

data.name: Economia
data.description:
At the end of the course the students will know the main themes of a complete intermediate level microeconomics course (consumer theory and elasticity of demand, perfect competition and monopoly, oligopoly, game theory, information asymmetry, attitude towards risk, public goods and externalities). They will be able to explain conceptually and through the use of simple graphical and analytical tools the theories learned and to correctly report these theories in the context of a series of relevant examples and cases.

The course develops different insights into microeconomics: these insights are complementary and represent the next step compared to the program carried out in Introduction to Economics and have the purpose of forming some additional concepts and analysis tools that allow to reach an advanced knowledge of economic problems. most relevant companies.

A specific study is provided on the theory of tax and on the Italian tax system.

data.name: Circular economy for materials processing
data.description:
CEMP is a project-based introductory course to the circular economy. The goals and the learning outcomes of the course are to provide overview knowledge on circular economy for materials processing through lecturing (first part of the course) and in-depth knowledge and skills by the project work (second part of the course).

After the course the students would be able to understand:

1. Basic concepts of circular economy, knowledge on materials flow (from mining, processing, manufacturing until end-of-life recycling and re-usage), issues and drivers for changes.

2. Recognize impacts (environmental, economic and social) of the current practice of materials processing from a sustainability aspect.

3. Create new business opportunities to re-enter materials into circular economy.

4. Apply processing technologies to accelerate the implementation in business creation.

data.name: Matematica finanziaria progredito
data.description: The aim of the course is to provide the knowledge of financial mathematics preparatory to other more advanced finance courses, with particular attention to linear algebra, optimization, and their applications in the financial field (e.g. stylized facts, market efficiency, style analysis, portfolio optimization). The course requires students to apply their theoretical knowledge by exercises with Excel e MATLAB.

data.name: Scientific computing
data.description:
Scientific computing is an important skill for any student of mathematics. 
 It requires both knowledge of algorithms and proficiency in an appropriate 
 programming language. The aim of this course is to introduce students 
 to efficient algorithms to solve various problems in the 
 mathematical sciences, and to enable them to implement these algorithms
 in a modern programming language.
 The objectives are that by the end of the course all students should have a 
 good familiarity with the essential elements of the Python programming 
 language, and be able to undertake programming tasks in a range of common 
 areas. Students will also be exposed to C++ as an example for a compiled
 programming language, and will appreciate the benefits of object oriented
 programming.

data.name: Meccanica dei fluidi

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
EDUCATIONAL OBJECTIVES


The teaching objective is to:


- express the principles of conservation of physics in fluid mechanics through mathematical expressions;


- describe applications of the physical conservation principles in the fields of interest of fluid mechanics in civil (primarily) and environmental engineering;

- present modeling approaches for the analytical or numerical solution in the applications of interest.


EXPECTED LEARNING RESULTS


At the end of the course the student is expected to:


- know the mathematical formulation of conservation principles for fluid mechanics and know how to apply them to notable cases


- be able to frame the proposed themes starting from the identification of the hypotheses and the illustration of the physical scheme, and develop the mathematical steps to arrive at the meaningful expressions that quantify the phenomenon


- quantitatively solve application problems relating to the hydraulic systems addressed in the course.

data.name: Ambiti di intervento nella psicologia

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description: The course aims to provide students enrolled in the "Neuroscience" and "Clinical Psychology" curriculum with an overview of the potential areas of intervention of the psychologist. The aim of the course is to enrich students' knowledge with respect to the profession of psychologists, the concrete activities that the psychologist carries out in different contexts, the tools he/she uses and the critical aspects that can be encountered in the performance of the profession.

data.name: Advanced remote sensing systems

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
This course provides basic and advanced concepts as well as design capabilities in the framework of systems based on remote sensing (from satellites, airborne and UAV platforms), proximal sensing, in-situ (ground) sensing, and ancillary data for environmental monitoring, climate change analysis, civil protection, infrastructure monitoring, remote surveillance and planetary exploration. It introduces remote sensing methodologies, technologies and techniques that are fundamental for the design of the above-mentioned systems with the last generation of optical and radar sensors. It describes the approach to the design and implementation of systems for several applications and operative scenarios, including the design criteria for the choice of the sensors, the system architecture and data analysis techniques complementary to more general artificial intelligence and machine learning techniques presented in other mandatory courses.
There is a large part of the course that is common to all the students and another part (section 2) for which each attendee can select one between two modules: Module a) basics concepts in remote sensing and technologies for the acquisition of optical and radar images; or Module b) advanced concepts and design criteria for Earth observation and planetary exploration satellite missions. It is suggested that students that have not attended any basic remote sensing course follow Module a) while the others select Module b).
The theoretical lectures are complemented by practical examples on real systems including laboratory activities.

data.name: Sociologia dell'organizzazione (progredito)

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description: Aim of the course is to present the main concepts and interpretative tools for studying and critically understanding the processes through which various actors and group of actors create and reproduce dinamics of organizational structuration, coordination and interrelation, also in connection to the widespread of digital technologies in work and organizations.

data.name: Laboratorio per l'applicazione di test psicologici

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description:
The aim of this course is to provide applying knowledge about the use of psychological tests. At the end of the course, attending students will be able to:

1) Administer some widely used cognitive and personality tests.

2) Carry out scoring and coding procedures of such tests.

3) Discuss tests' results and present them through written reports.

4) Better cooperate with colleagues in team work.

data.name: Sistemi informativi aziendali
data.description:
The aim of the course is to prepare students to understand and exploit the information technology techniques and tools that support information systems.

At the end of the course, students will be able to:
1. master the core concepts and theories related to corporate information systems
2. Analyze the information systems of organizations 
3. grasp the implications in terms of information management and action opportunities for the organizations analyzed

data.name: Gender and Security
data.description:
The course aims at developing a critical understanding and an interdisciplinary overview of topical
issues concerning security from a gender-sensitive perspective. While the first part of the course
will be devoted to the exploration of the analytic category of gender and of the problem of genderbased discrimination through the relevant philosophical literature, during the second part will
address gender-related phenomena threatening mainstream as well as innovative understandings of
security. Throughout the course, special attention will be devoted to the analysis of the main
international documents which contribute to frame contemporary gender-related security
challenges and to envisage suitable policies to overcome them.
By the end of the course, the knowledge acquired will allow students to:
- familiarise with concepts and methodological tools to investigate broad social phenomena from a
gender-sensitive perspective;
- critically deconstruct crucial security issues from a gender perspective (e.g. economic violence,
war crimes and gender-based violence in conflict and post-conflict situations);
- analyse the intersection between gender and human rights approaches to security;
- detect and highlight the aporias implicit in the mainstream security/securitizing narratives
concerning gender.

data.name: Analisi e annotazione linguistica

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description: The aim of the course is to introduce the students to the main automatic tools for the analysis of language. We will investigate what linguistic annotation is and its fundamental role in the development of models for natural language processing (NLP). At the end of the course, students will be able to set their own annotation task to investigate linguistic inquiries and to master the use of several automatic tools for the analysis of language.

data.name: Advanced Formula SAE
data.description: The laboratory course covers the activities carried out within the Formula SAE project. It is reserved to active members of the Formula SAE Team.

Lab. I: Market Analysis
Laboratorio didattico di fisica

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description: The goal of the class is to introduce the 2nd year students to the laboratory practice, to the use of the instruments for the data acquisition. The concept of measurement and uncertainty  is also presented together with the basic techniques of data analysis (estimete of the parameters, research of relation among data and error propagation)
data.degreeProgram: Ingegneria per l'ambiente e il territorio (L2)

data.name: Macromolecular Imaging

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description: The aim of the course is to provide an introduction to the theoretical and applied aspects of basic and advanced microscopy-based molecular imaging methods. In particular, brightfield and fluorescent imaging will be covered, as well as the chemical tools used to explore molecular distribution and interactions. At the end of the course, the student will be able to: 1) describe the general principles of optics, the various microscopy techniques and their applications 2) select the most appropriate approach and imaging tools to study roles and distribution of macromolecules such as RNA and proteins 3) analyze a research question and design experimental paradigm to address it. After the laboratory, the student will be able to use various types of microscopes (from basic to high-end), critically analyze and appraise the results obtained.

data.name: Lingua e traduzione inglese e letteratura inglese I
data.degreeProgram: Letterature euroamericane, traduzione e critica letteraria (LM)

data.name: Storia moderna II
data.description:
The course aims to provide an introduction to the study of modern history (fifteenth to the eighteenth centuries) and to identify the central themes that link that period, in Europe and beyond, to the contemporary world.

General learning outcomes:
a) to identify the major events, persons and ideas of the early modern history.
b) build relationships and ties between them.
c) to grasp the elements of continuity and rupture of early modern history.
d) to recognize, distinguish, differentiate, compare the most important aspects of European and non-European civilizations.
e) to place an historical source in time and space describing its content, origins, and motivations.
f) to use a suitable historiographic lexicon.
g) to organize the knowledges and communicate them clearly and concisely in a written form.

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO
Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.name: Network Modeling and Simulation

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description:
Objectives

The student will learn about systems view of biological networks, where quantitative and dynamic considerations of biological properties are in the foreground. The biological entities will be studied with an emphasis on the emergent behavior resulting from the interactions of the network components. The student will thus be equipped with an interdisciplinary skill-set for studying such systems in a way that brings together notions from biology, applied mathematics and computer science.


Learning outcomes

At the end of the course the students will be able to:

a) Work on biological questions using analytical methods with the aim of providing systems level "holistic" answers.

b) Develop the critical thinking skills required to understand and evaluate the results introduced in a scientific paper in the area of modelling and simulation of biological dynamics.

c) Become familiar with a spectrum of techniques from applied mathematics and computer science with respect to their strengths and their limitations in various biological settings.

d) Use programming technologies to formalize various biological problems for simulation, sensitivity analysis and model calibration and choose the most appropriate computational strategy depending on the considered biological problem.

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: The course aims at studying the fundamentals of machine learning, covering supervised and unsupervised learning methods and deep learning approaches. It includes application examples as well as laboratory exercises. At the end of the course, it is expected that the student will acquire the skills useful to design methods and tools for the analysis of signals and data.

The experimental models and the main techniques for the study of electrophysiological phenomena in the heart and brain in physiological and pathological conditions will be described.

data.name: Intellectual property and competition law_
data.description:
Intellectual property (IP) and competition policy issues are increasingly relevant to undertakings, especially to those facing dynamic markets in an international environment. The course aims at providing students with solid theoretical and practical foundations in dealing with the legal facets of managing innovation. Both intellectual property law and competition policy can be said to pursue, by different means, the same primary aim of stimulating the innovation process. On the one hand, by allowing innovators to appropriate the results of their investments, incentives are created to take risks and engage in innovation activities. Competitive markets, on the other hand, allow for new products and services to emerge and be tested by consumers and/or other undertakings. However, as long as intellectual property rights (IPRs), like in particular patents and copyrights, are considered plain monopolies, there is arguably an inherent tension between the two above mentioned legal fields, in particular where such monopoly rights granted to creators and inventors stifle growth because of poorly designed “incentives” rules. 
In this vein, it is especially the role of IPRs as tools to motivate firms to invest in innovation activities that has been seriously questioned in the last two decades. The case for further and general strengthening of IPRs appears weak, and it is increasingly understood that a new balance needs to be struck between rewarding risk-takers and diffusing new knowledge. This course examines the interface between intellectual property and competition law, looking in particular at how competition law is already affecting intellectual property. Moreover, the course is aimed at analyzing the peculiarities of the legal management of the intellectual assets of firms acting in different economic sectors (e.g., fashion industry, information and communication technology markets, pharmaceutical industry). 
On completing this course, students will be able to: 
a) clearly identify those contexts in which innovation management decisions are influenced by intellectual property law and competition policy considerations
b) explain, in an interdisciplinary way, the core principles of intellectual property and competition law 
c) employ general analysis skills helping them to identify crucial issues and therefore to ask the right questions in the management and expansion of the firm's intellectual (property) assets
d) understand and follow international trends in the area of IPRs and competition policy especially relevant to dynamic industries (e.g., so called “search bias” as investigated by competition authorities on both sides of the Atlantic and its possible meaning and effects for other undertakings active in markets affected by such practices).

data.name: Criminal Procedure from a Comparative and International Perspective
data.description:
Course Descriptions

Criminal justice systems adopted worldwide and in Europe differ from State to State, and there appears to be no agreement whatsoever on what constitutes a satisfactory criminal process (R. Vogler, A world view of criminal justice, 2005).

Nevertheless, they are all governed by the principle of respect of fundamental rights, as enshrined in international conventions (above all, the European Convention of Human Rights and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights) and EU law.

The course will introduce the several criminal justice processes, drawing a comparison between different legal traditions (common law and civil law systems) and providing a general knowledge of basic principles relating to criminal procedure, which are common to most of national and international legal systems.

In this context, the course also provides with elementary knowledge of international cooperation in criminal matters (extradition, rogatory letters and other mutual legal assistance instruments), also dealing with the so called "EU criminal (procedural) law" (think of the European arrest warrant (EAW), the European investigation order and other instruments for mutual legal assistance and of transnational gathering of evidence, the European Public Prosecutor Office etc.).


Course Learning Objectives/Outcomes By the end of the course, student will be able to:

- Understand basic concepts and principle of criminal procedure, and the impact of social, political and economic world on the administration of criminal justice

- Compare and contrast criminal justice systems in terms of major legal traditions used in the world (e.g. common law, civil law); - Examine and compare the stages of the criminal process in different countries;

- Describe and compare major actors within the criminal justice systems (e.g. the police, courts, the prosecutor, the defense, the victim) and activities carried out by these actors in the different steps of the proceedings in different countries;

- Describe the main instruments for international cooperation in criminal matters, also under the so called "EU criminal (procedural) law";

- Improve oral communication and presentation skills;

- Develop the skills to conduct criminal justice research.
data.degreeProgram: Comparative, European and International Legal Studies (L2)

data.name: ICT Innovation - Product Design and Development
data.description: Course Objectives This course illustrates the key steps of product design and developement and guide students, forming multi-disciplinary teams, into the development of a “product” as opposed to just a “project”. We often see nice proof-of-concept research demonstration of useful tools in magazines or on web-sites. What does it take to make this a product? Everybody can sell a beautiful concept if you don't have to build it. Also anybody can build a amazing device if you don't have to sell it. This challenging course combines the two requirements. Students have to talk to customers to understand what features are relally needed and for what costs. Students have also to make sure they can actually deliver the technological solution (that the customers wanted). For example, you can design a scarecrow drone that flies over the crops with a predefined set-up. Unless you talk to farmers you'll never realize that random walk is necessary to actually scare the crows. Further, automatic charging as well as automated landing by computer vision and machine learning are mission critical, so that the farmer doesn't need to be there. All this with cheap mechanical, electronic, and computing solutions as the budget is extremely tight. You might have invented the idea of an iPod-style to provide news to the blind and your first technical solutions might have been to use Braille. Unless you talked (as the Joni group did) to the blind association, you are not going to discover that the majority of your customers in Italy have become blind later in life and a product that requires learning Braille at 50s-and-more is not going to be a great success. It is great for campers, to have an anti-theft device in your tent. Yet, what if it starts blasting if you just put a rucksack in the wrong position in your own tent? All these products, and many more, were built by students participating to this course. Overarching Learning Objectives - Creativity: How to solve problems when not all steps are completely specified (this what you should try to do with your design/architectural result) - Intellectual Transformation: How to transform an idea into a product (the first “brainstorming” step is your research canvas, the last one is the final product) by using conceptual tools from economics, mechatronic engineering, and computer science. - Leadership: Organize yourselves into a team and arrive to make a final product (you should try to leverage on each other’s competences) - Making value judgement: Decide which parts are important and which are not also on the basis of ethical and social considerations. Intended Learning Outcomes Regular and active participation in the teaching activities offered by the course (lectures, supervised and indipendent group work in multi-disciplinary teams) will enable students to: - Learn key steps of Product Design and Development (PD&D) - Create a product concept which will be presented as concept's idea canvas to illustrate the key strong points on their product and their interaction with stakeholders - Design a detailed architecture product architecture and present it in a poster explaining how their product will work and which would be their strong point - Produce a final product as each team will have a small budget for hardware/software and will have to actually demonstrate a working product - Market their concept idea as the teams will interact with stakeholders to make sure that the product that they intend to build has actually a market. This course should allow students to experience the creativity, intellectual transformation, leadership and value judgements skills which take to transform an idea into a working and sellable product.

data.name: Discrete Fourier analysis
data.description:
Learning Objective:

  • to be able to represent a finite abelian group through its group of characters and to prove the main properties of the Discrete Fourier Transform (DFT);
  • to understand the role of the DFT in the solution of problems from several branches of Discrete Mathematics: Graph Theory, Discrete Probability, Random Number Generation, Coding Theory, Computational Algebra and Quantum Computation.


By the end of the course, students should be able to present and explain the main properties of the DFT, and to apply standard DFT-based techniques to solve non-trivial problems involving the Fourier analysis on finite abelian groups.

data.name: Social interaction

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description:
The current course will highlight the social aspects of human-computer interaction and computer- and app-mediated communication. Throughout the course we will analyze the relevance of social psychological theories to predict the success of human computer-interactions and investigate the social effects of computer- and app-mediated communication. Instead of giving a broad overview of these different effects, we will analyze the role of some social psychological theories in human-computer interaction and some specific media effects. At the end of the course students are expected to be able to:

a) apply relevant social aspects in the concept and design of an interface or artifact that is made for human interaction

b) develop an in depth analysis and a critical view on the main social issues and theories that will be discussed during the course

c) communicate in a clear and detailed way ideas, problems, and solutions that are introduced during the course

d) collaborate actively in group discussions and a final group project.

data.name: Teoria e tecnica del dibattito
data.description: The centrality of cross-examination in forensic and extra-judicial practice (e.g., in contracts) is a fact acquired and recognized not only by scholars but also by the legal system itself, which in recent decades has provided itself with constitutional guarantees aimed at safeguarding this value at all levels of judicial activity. Moreover, training models based on frontal learning of notions (concept-based) and those based on the resolution of concrete problems (problem-based), although still essential, do not seem entirely suitable to provide the tools to consciously choose methods and conceptual vocabularies in a jagged horizon. Therefore, the primary objective of the course will be to know the debate and the techniques that allow to participate in it; how to build a legal argument and how to counter-argument what the other party claims. At the end of the course the student will be able to actively participate in a debate by organizing his or her own claim, while at the same time contesting the adverse claim. An increase in public speaking, the ability to organize one's own reasoning and one's ability to discuss is expected.

data.name: International Accounting and Finance II: International Corporate Finance

data.name: Diritto del lavoro
data.description:
The course is aimed at providing students with the knowledge and the understanding of contractual relationships based on the performance of work under personal subordination or under prevailing personal subordination, both in the private sector and in the so called “contractualized” public sector. 
To this end, the course will illustrate the fundamental legal framework and the various sources of labour law (i.e. national and European legislation, collective bargaining and individual employment contract), and it will endow students with a methodological guide (i.e. legal skills and reasoning) to solve practical cases.

At the end of the course the student shall be able:
-	to identify the relevant legal norms
-	to identify the collective agreement applicable to the case under consideration;
-	to compare the set of rules shaped and determined respectively by the law, by the collective agreement and, if it is the case, by the individual employment contract
-	to apprehend and evaluate the essential elements of the employment contract and of its performance, in order to determine the classification of the employment relationship (i.e. distinguishing autonomous subordinate work); 
-	to structure the intellectual process of legal case-analysis and select, different methods and techniques, the strongest and most persuasive legal
