data.name: Workshop in Behavioral finance
data.description:
Main goal of the course is to introduce students to behavioral finance. This approach to financial issues relies on weaker rationality assumptions than traditional finance and seeks to improve the understanding of financial phenomena.

In the first part of the course, main concepts in behavioral economics are discussed, in an interactive and participated way. In the second part of the course, behavioral insights are applied to financial issues, with reference to both market and corporate dimension.

Students successfully completing the course will be able to critically examine financial phenomena and to understand potential market anomalies in a behavioral perspective.

data.name: Anatomia umana II
data.description: The aim of this course is to enable students to describe the structure of the human body from the macroscopic, microscopic, and ultrastructural point of view as well as the relationship between structure and function. The expected outcome is the ability to describe in a 3D context the morphology of the human with special reference to the structures of the central nervous system (+ cranial nerves and special sense organs), the respiratory system, the digestive system, the urinary and reproductive systems, the integumentary system, the endocrine system.

data.name: Laboratory of Advanced Photonics
Radiation: detection and applications
data.description:
This course will provide the students with the bases to understand the interactions of ionizing radiation with matter and their application in particle therapy and radioprotection. The following topics will be addressed during the lectures:
i) Physical processes involved in the interaction of radiation with matter for both neutral and charge particles.
ii) Chemical processes involved in the interaction of radiation with matter and of importance for biological damaged radio-induced.
iii) Overview of biological damages induced by radiation.
iv) Introduction to particle therapy.
v) Introduction to radioprotection in space.
vi) Detection methods for neutral and charged particles used in radiotherapy and radioprotection experiments.
vii) Introduction to Monte Carlo codes used for simulating the transport of radiation in matter in biophysics and medical physics.

Five practical classes are included in the course:
1) Study of the x-rays interaction with matter.
2) Ion detection with a setup commonly used in applied nucelar physics experiments.
3) Data analysis of a nuclear physics experiment with application in ion particle therapy.
4 and 5) Simulation of physical and dosimetric quantities with a GEANT4-based Monte Carlo code (TOPAS) and comparison with experimental data.

At the end of the course, the students will have acquired a deeper knowledge of the physical processes occurring during the interaction of radiation. These concepts represent the basis for understanding the scientific challenges in radiotherapy and radioprotection in space. Some concepts treated in this class are discussed more in the details in the Biophysics and Medical Physics course.

data.name: Storia della scienza e delle tecniche
Dottrina dello stato
Paleografia II
data.description:
Access to the course Paleografia I requires that the students have attended Paleografia II. The course Paleografia I includes 60 hours of lesson + 30 of exercise = 12 credits

The first part (= 30 hours 6 credits) aims to introduce to the study of : 1) the metodology of the palaeographical expertise, to gain a critical approach to the ancient script; 2) the abbreviation system of the antiquity and medieval age; 3) the ‘carolina’ script (important to understand also our graphic system) and its historical development .

At the end of the first part the student will be able: a) to understand the abbreviation system; b) to read the graphic specimina of the Carolingian age; c) to give a critical interpretation of the handwriting’s changes during the four centuries of its use .

data.name: High Performance Computing for Data Science

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The course is intended to provide the fundamentals of High Performance Computing software for High-end Data Science. In particular we present convergent ecosystems of software and data frameworks at a large-scale in relevant scientific disciplines. The course will present both theoretical and practical aspects related to simulation-centric and data-centric paradigms; challenges related to end-to-end workflows joining both paradigms into large-scale experiments will be also presented; case studies from several domains (e.g. medical/health, financial, climate/weather) will be presented and discussed with follow-up hands-on sessions. By the end of the module, students will learn:

  • parallel computer memory architectures and parallel programming models;
  • principles of parallel algorithm design
  • how to develop and benchmark parallel code (using MPI);
  • analytics frameworks and approaches for High-end Data Analysis;
  • how to develop large-scale data analytics applications (using Dask or similar tools);
  • differences between simulation-centric paradigm and data-centric discovery;
  • the complementary role of big data, data science and HPC in tackling real-world problems.

data.name: Psicologia del lavoro e delle organizzazioni

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
The course represents an introduction to organizational psychology and the main topics that define the discipline from a research and practical point of view.

We intend to provide the student with some basic elements for studying and understanding relevant organizational dynamics, in order to provide models and basic elements to recognize and eventually propose interventions for diagnosis and organizational change.

The course will be divided into two thematic modules:

1. Introductory 24-hour module on concepts and methods of organizational psychology.

2. Thematic 24-hour module devoted to psychosocial risks in organizations and work stress.


The student at the end of the course will be able to: apply what they have learned on a practical level, in work contexts and in different research / study areas; select from the theoretical knowledge learned and the tools, what is useful / relevant in a specific practical application or in a specific work context.

data.name: Laboratorio di metallurgia
data.description: The course of Laboratory of Metallurgy aims to provide the student with the main skills in terms of analysis of metallic materials. In particular, the student will learn, both through frontal hours and hours of experimental activity in the laboratory, how to perform and analyze mechanical tests, thermal analysis and metallographic analysis. At the end of the course the student must have learned how to perform these tests, on the basis of which parameters are chosen, with which criteria they are set and what are the critical aspects related to each of them.

data.name: Meccanica quantistica
data.description:
The aim of the course is to provide students with the tools to understand the basics of quantum mechanics, grasping its physical principles and becoming familiar with its mathematical formalism.
At the end of the course, students should know the fundamental principles of non-relativistic quantum mechanics and how they apply in simple cases, such as the study of two-level systems, the harmonic oscillator, the hydrogen atom, stationary and time-dependent perturbations, systems of two or more identical particles.

data.name: Computational algebra
data.description:
The course will provide an introduction into various
famous algorithms in algebra. At the end of the course the student will be able to apply these algorithms in concrete situations, and will have knowledge of the proofs of some of the key results that underpin the algorithms.

data.name: Introduction to robotics
data.description:
The course offers a bird-eye view on the most important topics related to modern robotics, highlighting the main problems that need to be faced in order to make the robots operate correctly in the environment. Specifically, the course will cover the following topics: taxonomy of the different types of robots, physical modelling of robots (direct and inverse kinematics and dynamics), simulation of models, sensing and actuation solutions for perception and action.
Using the developed models, the most famous methodologies to control robot motion and interaction, will be presented. These methods will be first studied in theory, and then implemented in simulation (with the Python language) to gain practical experience.
Attention will be also paid to illustrate the most common non idealities and issues that are present when controlling robots. The course will adopt a combination of simulation models and lab experiences to consolidate the knowledge transmitted during the theoretical lessons.
After completing the course, students will be able to:
- select the most suitable sensors and actuators for a given robotic application
- model the kinematics and dynamics any kind of robot
- understand the working principles of several control algorithms for robotic systems
- choose the appropriate approach(es) to control a specific system for a given target application
- implement, tune, and test control algorithms with the Python language

data.description:
On completion of the course, students will be able to:

2. interact with a degree of fluency and spontaneity in a variety of simulated contexts in the field of economics and management without strain. They will also be able to talk about their own academic career.

data.name: Cancer Biology

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description: The aim of the course is to provide the students with the basis for the understanding of the main cellular characteristics that define the processes involved in neoplastic transformation. At the end of this course, the student will be able to: a) Explain the basic principles of cellular transformation; b) Describe in detail the "Hallmarks of cancer"; c) Explain the fundamental differences between tumor suppressor genes and oncogenes; d) Describe the role of key proteins involved in pathways often dysregulated in cancer; e) Understand the genetic steps underlying the inactivation or hyperactivation of specific genes involved in cancer development.

data.name: International Cooperation, Development and Security
Fisiologia della cellula e degli organismi
data.description:
The course's objective is to provide basic knowledge on living organisms: evolution and diversity, anatomy and physiology. Students will follow a path that will allow them to understand the steps towards multicellularity and the integration of signals of intercellular communication.

They will be able to understand the organization of tissues and organs, their mechanisms and their integration in a system biology approach.

At the end of the course, the students will have learned:


- Basic knowledge on the organization and functioning of the cell

- Basic knowledge on the organization of multicellular organisms

- Intercellular Communication

- Physiology of organs and systems

- Check-points, homeostasis and diseases


The course aims to provide basic elements of cellular and molecular biology possibly to be studied in deeper details in other areas such as the "Molecular biology of the cell" (second semester). The part of physiology of organs and tissues is instead specifically addressed within this course.

data.name: Criminologia
data.description: Criminology studies crime and deviance, the authors and the victims of crime and deviance and the social (institutional and non-institutional) responses to crime and deviance. The course of criminology aims at providing students with the essential elements to understand, in a comparative perspective, the evolution of deviant and criminal behaviors and of the related reactions of international, national and local systems.

data.name: Photonics
data.description:
The course introduces the student to the fundamental theory for understanding the functioning of light-based devices, namely based on the interaction between light and matter. The aim is that the student will be able to understand, design (a minima) and verify different photonic systems, in particular integrated photonic structures. The areas of applications include, e.g., long-distance optical communications, integrated photonic circuits for optical computation, and photonic sensors for biological interests. Photonics is both, a key technology transverse to many innovative industrial areas, as well as an area of intense research. This course is meant to be coupled with the course "Laboratory of advanced photonics", which is also offered by the Physics Department.
Learning outcomes:
1. Familiarity with rigorous and approximated methods for the analysis of problems relative to optical propagation and to light-matter interaction
2. Knowledge of fundamental components and devices for the transmission and elaboration of information with optical technologies
3. Basic design capabilities of optical integrated circuits

data.name: Labour Rights in the Global Economy
data.description: The course aims at providing students with a general overview about workers' rights in times of economic globalisation. At the end of the course students will know the contents of these rights and will be able to understand why the International Labour Organisation (ILO), as a response to the challenges of economic globalisation, decided to focus on some of them, considered as fundamental, and not on others. Finally, students will be aware of the enforcement problems characterizing the fundamental labour standard in the globalized world.

The goal of this course is to enable students to analyze various types of high-dimensional data types commonly encountered in the practice of Molecular Biology using a range of methodologies, including established statistical approaches, machine learning, and recently introduced methods.

At the end of the course, students are expected to possess the following skills:

- familiarity with different types of Molecular Biology data and their specificity;

- good understanding of different conceptual methods for analyzing the data;

- familiarity with practical computational tools for carrying out the analysis;

- ability to frame the results of their analysis in a biological context using networks;

- ability to provide a functional interpretation of the results of their analysis;

- ability to complete a project, write a structured report, and orally present the results of their work.

data.description:

At the end of the course, students will be able:  
a)	To handle combinatorial methods and to identify special probability distributions (e.g. Poisson, bionomial, normal). 
b)	To use probability distributions for the description of experimental outcomes.
c)	To understand when conditions for random sampling are satisfied in practical applications and to use appropriate methods for outcome analysis. 
d)	To critically handle different test of significance according to the experimental conditions.
e)	To critically interpret the results of test of significance.
f)	To deal with experimental design with a critical statistical approach.

data.name: Advanced materials for Energy Engineering

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
The course is intended to give the student a broad scope preparation in selecting and using materials for applications in energy engineering. In more detail, besides theory and general knowledge, learning Ashby approach to materials selection is an objective. 
Students are trained in laboratory practices, with hands-on activities related to the topics discussed in the classroom teaching; therefore, further objectives are learning basics principles and how to use instruments, including: testing materials durability (e.g., microhardness, mechanical fatigue), modifying materials (e.g., by shot-peening), characterizing materials properties (e.g., residual stress by XRD and Hole Drilling methods); electrical and electrochemical testing of solar cells, batteries, fuel cells, hydrogen production, wind energy generation, thermoelectric materials and devices.

data.name: Corso di inglese B2a - I periodo (estensivo)
Modelli di decisione per la gestione_
data.description:
The course has several educational objectives. The first is to introduce the student to the topic of decisions from a multidisciplinary perspective, becoming familiar with contributions developed within very different study traditions. The second is to understand the main formal, quantitative and qualitative models to support decisions, through a review of the main tools and methods for the analysis, structuring and resolution of a complex decision. The third is linked to the understanding of the human factor in decisions and how, in real choice contexts, the limits of human cognition translate into solution strategies that are only partially compatible with the indications of the normative models.
At the end of the course the student should have developed:
an awareness of the usefulness of models, stylized and simplified representations of complex situations, as interpretative tools to support decisions.
the recognition of the merits of formal models as tools for structuring the decision-making context and for identifying the optimal choice.
the ability to evaluate the effects of intuitive reasoning and the application of decision heuristics on the soundness of the final decision.
an understanding of the impact of uncertainty on decisions and of the main techniques for estimating and incorporating uncertainty in decisions.
the ability to recognize and manage the presence of multiple conflicting objectives and multiple stakeholders in a decision.
the ability to make a decision by structuring the overall decision-making process (from becoming aware of the existence of a problem, recognizing the important objectives to be achieved, identifying available alternatives, measuring the consequences and considering the possible role of uncertainty).
Overall, the student should develop a more effective approach to problem solving and decision making in both managerial and personal settings.

data.name: Automated Planning: Theory and Practice

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: Planning and Scheduling is the task of thinking before you act: use knowledge about the world to determine what and when to do an action to achieve a given goal. Automated planning and scheduling is a central topic in Artificial Intelligence (AI), and task and motion planning capabilities are essential to the construction of many robust autonomous systems. Research in planning and scheduling is active and exciting. Planning and scheduling problems have been tackled with a variety of new approaches to address efficiency, expressivity, and practical applicability. Planning and scheduling technologies are currently used with great success in several real applications ranging from production lines and elevators to unmanned aerial and sub-sea vehicles (UAVs) and space applications. The aim of this course is to provide a comprehensive theoretical view of a wide range of planning and scheduling techniques, as well as hands-on experience in constructing and modeling planning domains to solve specific planning problems, and if time allows to experiment the control of robotic agents. After the course, the student will be able to: • Evaluate and apply a variety of planning techniques and tools for classical planning and scheduling as well as planning and scheduling under different kind uncertainty (temporal and discrete). • Explain the practical advantages and disadvantages of different levels of expressivity in planning and scheduling models. • Model classical planning and scheduling problems in commonly used domain definition languages (e.g. PDDL), and if time allows, we will consider probabilistic planning problems as well. • Evaluate and apply common techniques for goal-directed planning, such as various forms of heuristics and control rules. • Experiment with realistic robotic agents (depending on time and availability of the robotic agents in the Robotic Lab or through simulations within ROS infrastructure).

data.name: Computational physics

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description:
After completion of the course the student should know the main algorithms commonly used in the numerical solution of physical problems, and have learned the basics of the main simulation techniques for interacting many-particle systems described within non-relativistic quantum physics.
The student should be able to prove she/he has learned the fundamental concepts of the theory, and should be able to:
a) Choose the most suitable algorithm to the solution of a given problem
b) Autonomously write working codes implementing the illustrated algorithms
c) Appropriately use existing software and libraries in support of the self-developed code.

data.name: Laboratorio di analisi dei mercati
data.description:
The aim of the course is to provide students with a deeper understanding of the functioning of markets and of the determinants and effectiveness of firms' strategies, through the analysis of a specific market using appropriate data.

By the end of the course, students will be able to:

- apply theoretical concepts learnt during the first-year courses to the analysis of a market and a business firm;

- identify the most appropriate data to describe the evolution of a specific market and of the phenomena that might have influenced it;

- identify the information content of data;

- represent processed data using graphical and statistical tools in order to extract relevant information;

- organize a team work;

- develop a research report;

- present and discuss the results to an audience.

data.name: Segnali, visione e riconoscimento

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The first module of the course goes through a brief recap about signals and their properties. It will then deal with the study of techniques and solutions for automatic recognition, with particular attention to mono signals (like audio and biomedical data) and bidimensional data (as images). The first module can be considered as a basic course, where the students will be provided with the relevant tools for simple recognition problems, through well-known techniques available in the literature.
The goal of the second module is to provide the student with basics related to digital and predictive transmission systems as well as the information theory. It is expected that the student will acquire the methodological skills necessary of the design of source and channel coding techniques of signals.
data.degreeProgram: Ingegneria Informatica, delle Comunicazioni ed Elettronica (L2)

data.name: Laboratorio di systems on chip

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The course aims at providing students with fundamental concepts of analysis and design of RF-MEMS components, i.e. Radio Frequency (RF) passives realized in Microsystem/MEMS (MicroElectroMechanical-Systems) technology. Moreover, the course will discuss how such components can be exploited in the design of reconfigurable antennas, with the target of tuning their fundamental operation characteristics, like the frequency response, polarization and radiation pattern.
The first lecture hours will provide a brief, yet comprehensive, overview on pillar aspects of MEMS and RF-MEMS technology, like the evolution of micro-fabrication techniques, the working principles of actuation/transduction, the classes of devices that broke into market applications and future perspectives. Basic concepts related to the multi-physical modelling and simulation, to packaging and integration along with experimental characterization techniques and setups for MEMS and RF-MEMS will also be covered.
Subsequently, hands-on exercises will be carried out, aimed at getting familiar with software tools for design and optimization of RF passive components in RF-MEMS technology. In details, practical work with software tools is arranged as follows:
- Optimization of multi-physical characteristics and of mechanical, electromechanical and electromagnetic performance of RF-MEMS devices;
- Integration of RF-MEMS components in the design of microstrip antennas and evaluation of the performance in terms of reconfigurability.
data.degreeProgram: Ingegneria Informatica, delle Comunicazioni ed Elettronica (L2)

data.name: Modeling and design with finite elements
data.description:
The finite element method (FEM) is the dominant discretization technique in process and product modelling. The objective of this course is to give the student a broad and integrative knowledge of this method and to introduce the student into its application to a variety of engineering problems.
By the end of this course students should: (1) know the behaviour and usage of each type of elements covered in this course; (2) be able to use finite element software to develop models of engineering systems; (3) be able to interpret and evaluate the quality of the results (know the physics of the problems); (4) be aware of the limitations of the FEM (don't misuse the FEM - a numerical tool!);  (5) be familiar with team-working, mathematical computing and FEM software; (6) be able to present FEM analyses in a proper format of a written report such that a technically qualified person can follow and obtain similar findings.

data.name: Cultura e letteratura inglese
data.description: The course, entitled “Victorian Detectives in Literary and Popular Imagination”, aims to provide students with the critical tools that will enable them to study Victorian culture through the lens of detective fiction, a genre that is still thriving in contemporary popular culture. The course will place two novels (The Moonstone by Wilkie Collins and A Study in Scarlet by Arthur Conan Doyle) in the context of important historical, artistic, ideological and epistemic Victorian issues. At the end of the course, students will be expected to be able to recognize and analyze the stylistic and thematic peculiarities of the literary texts and to put them in relation with Victorian culture. At the same time, students will be encouraged to develop critical thinking when considering the afterlives of Victorian detective fiction in contemporary popular culture.

It is also expected that she/he is able to set and complete the resolution of exercises and problems like the ones proposed during the course.

data.name: Foundations of Cognitive Psychology and Neuroscience I
data.description:
This course provides a comprehensive overview of the core topics in cognitive neuroscience, including perception, attention, action, memory, language, concepts, and social cognition. We will present both classical and recent research findings obtained with a variety of cognitive neuroscience methods (fMRI, EEG, MEG, TMS, behavior, neurological patients).


The objective of the course is to provide the students with the following competences:

- Knowledge of the main topics in cognitive neuroscience

- Knowledge of the main experimental techniques and methods

- Ability to define formulate specific experimental design to answer experimental questions

- Ability to critically understand experimental data and results

- Knowledge of the main open questions in cognitive neuroscience

data.description: Introduction to probability and to statistics, as tools to understand non-deterministic phenomena. The course program consists of basic principles of probability. This course is introductory and aims at presenting methodologies for interpreting with probability phenomenas of causal nature. The course focus on general theoretical concepts and practical techniques, and aims at providing the student with good knowledge of how to use basic probability concepts.

data.name: Basics of optoelectronics

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The course aims to provide students with the fundamental notions of opto-electronic systems.

The course introduces the scientific and engineering foundations of opto-electronic components used in the industrial field. In particular, the student will be able to understand the functioning of components such as laser and photoreceiver and able to evaluate the main characteristics of these components as a function of the constituent parameters (material and size).

After completing the course, the student will be able to:

• Analyze the constituent components of an opto-electronic system

• Analyze a semiconductor band diagram and calculate the charge distribution

• Understand the principle of operation of optical amplifiers

• Understand the operating principle of a laser and its main characteristics

• Analyze and design amplification stages and filters of a standard opto-electronic system

• Understand the behavior and characteristics of photo-detectors of different types (PN, PiN, APD, ...)

• Identify the limitations of an optical data transmission system

data.name: Sociologia dei processi culturali e comunicativi I
data.description: The course aims to analyze the process of cultural crisis connected to the transformations of the spirit of the modern world that took place during the 20th century, especially in the universe of consumption and lifestyles. It is in this sense that a specific analysis of the Italian case will be developed. At the end of the course, students of both degree courses must be able to: a) to have an adequate knowledge of the transformations that have taken place in the cultural sphere; b) to reconstruct the process of decomposition of the subject following the transformations that took place in the post-modern era. c) Be able to summarize the essential sociological aspects of contemporary Italian society.

data.name: Economia e misurazione aziendale
data.description: This course aims to provide students with basic knowledge about organizations and business management, and to foster critical thinking on the role of enterprises in the contemporary economy. The course will begin with an overview of the ongoing debate on the firm’s ultimate goal from both the shareholders and the stakeholders’ views. Subsequent to a review of the core business activities, it will then provide the basic notions of accounting and performance evaluation metrics, and a detailed overview of quantitative decisions-making models, such as economies of scale, learning curves, break-even/profit points, operating leverage etc. Furthermore, it will offer an accurate presentation and discussion of models for strategic analysis, including those with a longitudinal perspective. The course will end with a thorough examination of corporate governance, inquiring into managerial interests, mis-management and potential remedies. At the end of the course, the students will be able: 1. to understand and illustrate, with competence and expertise, the debate on the nature and purpose of enterprises, as institutions aimed at resolving the tension between wealth creation and social demands; 2. to understand, use and evaluate accounting and measurement performance systems; 3. to understand and use quantitative models in support of operation and management decisions; 4. to understand and competently speak about the problem of corporate governance, with a particular focus on the role of managers and the internal/external mechanisms to align shareholders’ and managerial interests; 5. to evaluate and critically assess the functioning and strategies of enterprises in modern economies and their ability to pursue long term success, preserving the financial and institutional equilibria-

data.name: Genetica

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
Students will acquire fundamental concepts of Heredity, Molecular Genetics and Population Genetics.

Specific emphasis will be placed on the mechanisms of inheritance and recombination, genome stability and on the origin, molecular nature and consequences of genetic variability and genotype/phenotype relationships.

Key methods for physical and genetic mapping and of functional genomics analyses will be covered.

During the laboratory module students will experience classical techniques used to manipulate yeast cells, including transformation, diploid selection, mutagenic PCR, and recombination-based cloning.

Data obtained will be presented and discussed in a group lab report.

data.name: Bio-Inspired Artificial Intelligence

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The goal of this course is to study two of the main paradigms of Bio-Inspired Artificial Intelligence, namely: Evolutionary Computation, inspired by evolutionary biology, and Swarm Intelligence, inspired by collective behaviors of social animals. First, the main theories and algorithms will be introduced. Then, it will be shown how these techniques can be applied, for instance, for solving complex optimization problems, training data-driven models, generating new contents (video-games, websites, art), finding bugs in software, automatically synthesizing or fixing computer programs, or finding innovative solutions in robotics, logistics, and engineering. Finally, it will be shown how these techniques can help the understanding of biological systems, in order to close the loop between biology and AI.

At the end of this course, students will be familiar with the most important Evolutionary Computation and Swarm Intelligence techniques, and will be able to apply them to different contexts in industry, research, or even entertainment. They will also know the fundamentals for developing new algorithms and adapt them to new problems.

data.name: Ecoidraulica

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
At a time in which humans have significantly affected the natural environment and yet society increasingly values the many services of natural ecosystems, accounting for ecological processes in engineering design is a major contemporary challenge for environmental engineers. This is the fundamental topic in Ecohydraulics, the discipline that focuses on the consequences of fluid and sediment processes on the organisms that inhabit aquatic environments. While still a young science, Ecohydraulics already endows the engineer with an overall understanding and quantitative tools to predict how physical processes shape habitat quality and quantity, and how, in turn, they are affected by ecological dynamics. This enables the integrated analysis of different management options for natural and man-made water bodies in terms of their ecosystem consequences. At the broadest scale, this class will contribute to the students' appreciation of the tight link between the natural and the built or impacted environment, and of the importance of considering both (and “how-to”) for harmonizing environmental quality with human river uses in river management and restoration.

At the end of the course the student will be able to: i) identify the different fluvial forms and their evolutionary trajectories; ii) use the hydro-morphological quality indexes and assess the status of alteration of river ecosystems; iii) understand the relations between hydro-morphology and biotic component, the causes of alteration of river ecosystems and tools to design ecological flow regimes in altered rivers; iv) appreciate the relevance of the integration of complementary disciplines for the sustainable management of water bodies.

The course aims to provide the students with techniques and mathematical tools used in the planning, design and management of water resources in the context of increasing anthropogenic pressure and climate change. The course will focus its attention on the hydraulic infrastructures present in river networks and on water supply systems.

At the end of the course the students will be able to: i) quantify the availability of water resources in river networks and aquifers, and ii) address and manage the problems related to the multiple and sustainable use of water resources. data.name: Applied Cryptography
data.description:
By the end of the course, you should be able to understand the theoretical and practical problems of using cryptographic techniques.


The content of this course is not purely mathematical, you will be introduced to more pragmatic considerations that need to be considered when applying cryptography in real use case scenarios that includes

  • how to identify and understand threats to fundamental security properties (confidentiality, integrity, and availability) when applying cryptography and
  • which cryptographic techniques are useful to preserve each one of the basic security properties.

data.name: Storia delle istituzioni politiche I
data.description:
Expected learning outcomes and educational goals 

The course aims to bring the student closer to the political-constitutional history of the German world of the long nineteenth century (1800-1918). The central object of the course will be
1. the late and contrasted transition from the absolute state to the constitutional one in the 2 main states of the German Confederation (1815-1866), namely Austria and Prussia,
2. the introduction here for the first time of the modern parliamentary-representative institutions, that is at least partially freely elected.
At the end of the course the student will be able to:
1. to know in broad terms times and circumstances of the transition from the cetual / absolute, or anyway  pre-constitutional state, to the constitutional one in the Austrian Empire and in Prussia / Germany,
2. to outline the period of introduction and the distinctive characteristics of the monarchical-constitutional form of government,
3. to frame the relationship established within the new form of monarchical-constitutional government between (monarchical) government on the one hand and parliament on the other,
4. to distinguish historically between a liberal state and one at least formally democratic, ie between different types and models of the modern state, as well as between two different forms of political government, ie between a at least formally constitutional monarchy and a solid parliamentary monarchy.
The course intends to bring the student closer to the political-constitutional history of the German world during the long nineteenth century, with particular attention to the late and contrasted transition process from the absolute regime to the constitutional one of the main states of the German Confederation (1815-1866), namely Austria and Prussia. At the end of the course the student will be able to: - know about the modalities, times and circumstances of the transition from the absolute (or cetual) regime to the constitutional regime, and to illustrate the new relationship established within the constitutional state between (monarchical) government and representative institutions.

data.name: Analisi matematica 2

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
Concerning the Mathematical Analysis part, the students are supposed to know and to be able to apply the basic concepts of the integro differential calculus for vector valued functions of several variables, with special regard to dimensions 1,2, and 3. More precisely, the student are expected:

- to describe the precise statements of theorems and definitions;

- to illustrate theorems and definitions through examples;

- to visualize, describe and give a graphical representation of the mathematical objects (curves, surfaces, solid figures, coordinates transformations, vector fields,...);

- to master the techniques of calculus and arguing properly;

- to solve problems with a degree of difficulty comparable to what they have seen during the exercises sessions;

- to describe the proofs of a selected number of theorems


An overall goal of the course is to consolidate the mathematical preparation acquired by the students during the previous semesters (Mathematical Analysis, Linear Algebra and Geometry), putting all the concepts in a unifying global perspective.

At the end of the module the student  should be able to: recall and discuss the techniques presented, reading the literature about similar techniques, preprocess and mine a specific instance of biological data, report and present the results.

data.name: Mathematical Biology
data.description:
Objectives

The aim of the course "Mathematical Modeling in Biology" is twofold: on the one hand, present the students several basic mathematical models in different areas of biology (ecology, infectious diseases, enzymatic reactions, molecular and physiological networks); on the other hand, provide operating competences in the analysis and numerical solution of ordinary and partial differential equations.

In particular, the module " Mathematical Modeling in Biology" is devoted to modelling biological systems through ordinary differential equations, and to the introduction of several techniques (linearization; equilibria and their stability; bifurcation; regular and singular perturbations). In the module " Spatio-temporal Models in Cell and Tissue Biology", after an introduction to partial differential equations and to some techniques for obtaining or approximating their solutions, some of the most interesting features of reaction-diffusion equations (travelling wave solutions, Turing mechanism) will be presented in a biological context (signal propagation in axons, morphogenesis).

Learning outcome

The final part of the course will be devoted to the development of a group project on a subject presented during the course. At the end of the course, students are expected to be able to build mathematical models for biological systems similar to those presented in the course, to perform simple qualitative analysis of systems of ordinary differential equations, to simulate systems of ordinary differential equations and of reaction-diffusion equations using Matlab. Moreover, thanks to the project to e developed, it is expected that all students will have improved in their ability to collaborate in an interdisciplinary setting, and to communicate the results that have been obtained.

data.name: GPU computing

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
General Aspects

Regarding the aspect of "Knowledge and understanding", the student will be able to:




  • analyze and solve even complex problems in the area of Software Engineering for Information Systems with particular emphasis on the use of studies, methods, techniques, and technologies of empirical evaluation;
  • know in depth the scientific method of investigation applied to complex systems and innovative technologies that support information technology and its applications;
  • read and understand specialist scientific documentation, such as conference proceedings, articles in scientific journals, and technical manuals.


Regarding the aspect of "Applying knowledge and understanding", the student will be able to:


  • design and perform experimental analyses of information systems in order to acquire measures related to their behaviour and to evaluate experimental hypotheses in different fields of application, such as business, industrial or research;
  • extend and modify in an original way an existing technical solution or a formal model taking into account changed conditions, requirements and evolution of the technology.


Regarding the aspect of "Making judgments", the student will be able to:




  • select documentation from a variety of sources, including technical books, digital libraries, technical scientific journals, web portals, or open source software and hardware tools;
  • reconcile the objectives of the project that are in conflict, to trade-off cost, resources, time, knowledge or risk;
  • work with large autonomy, also assuming responsibility for projects and structures.


Regarding the aspect of "Communication skills", the student will be able to:




  • present the contents of a scientific/technical report to an audience, including non-specialists, at a fixed time;
  • structure and draft scientific and technical documentation describing project activities;
  • coordinate project teams and identify activities to achieve project objectives;
  • prepare and conduct technical presentations in English;
  • carry out research and projects in a collaborative manner;
  • synthesise knowledge gained from reading and studying scientific documentation.


Regarding the aspect of "Learning skills", the student will be able to:




  • extend the knowledge acquired during the course of study by reading and understanding scientific and technical documentation in English;
  • extend knowledge, even if incomplete, taking into account the final objective of the project (problem solving skills);
  • to formulate and validate theories and define new methods through empirical induction and new generation scientific investigation tools.


Specific objectives:

Regarding the technical aspects, the student will be able to :




  • analyze sequential algorithms by identifying performance bottlenecks;
  • design parallel algorithms and implement them on GPUs by considering their architectural aspects;
  • adapt existing parallel and optimization techniques in a contest of different problems;
  • manage and use tools and technologies to design efficient and scalable GPU code.
  • design experimental setup and reporting results.

data.name: High Performance Computing for Data Science

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
The course is intended to provide the fundamentals of High Performance Computing software for High-end Data Science. In particular we present convergent ecosystems of software and data frameworks at a large-scale in relevant scientific disciplines. The course will present both theoretical and practical aspects related to simulation-centric and data-centric paradigms; challenges related to end-to-end workflows joining both paradigms into large-scale experiments will be also presented; case studies from several domains (e.g. medical/health, financial, climate/weather) will be presented and discussed with follow-up hands-on sessions. By the end of the module, students will learn:

  • parallel computer memory architectures and parallel programming models;
  • principles of parallel algorithm design
  • how to develop and benchmark parallel code (using MPI);
  • analytics frameworks and approaches for High-end Data Analysis;
  • how to develop large-scale data analytics applications (using Dask or similar tools);
  • differences between simulation-centric paradigm and data-centric discovery;
  • the complementary role of big data, data science and HPC in tackling real-world problems.

data.name: Elementi di astrofisica e cosmologia gravitazionale
data.description:
This course will provide an introduction to gravitational physics , so far successfully described by the Einstein's General Relativity , and some of its applications in astrophysics and cosmology.
Gravity is at the core of astrophysical phenomena involving blacks holes, is at the core of the final destiny of stars and of the universe evolution, and carries valuable informations thanks to the generation of a broad spectrum of gravitational waves .
General Relativity is central in cosmology and with the basic knowledge provided in the course we will be able to deal with the most basic observational facts with the simplest theoretical models.

The student will acquire the necessary basic elements of Special and General Relativity together with the basic mathematical tools to understand the geometry of space-time, but without going into details of the derivation of solutions to Einstein's equation. The student will be thus enabled to focus on the exploration of experimental gravitation, a particularly lively field  both in terms of increasingly accurate verification of the fundamental principles and predictions of General Relativity, and for the opportunities that are progressively opening up to use gravity to observe the Universe as never before.
We will illustrate and discuss the classic and most recent observations and experiments, on ground and in space, and for the future we will discuss in particular the prospects and issues related to the realization of an observatory for gravitational waves.

data.name: History and Politics of the Middle East: Conflicts, Ideologies and Democratisation
data.description:
This course aims at providing the students with the general understanding of the political and historical evolution of modern Middle East, starting from the decline of the Ottoman Empire up until present time. By introducing the theoretical framework of the process of modernization together with the theory of various political regimes, the courses main objective is to offer an in-depth analysis of modern Middle East, both from a historical and political perspectives. The course offers analytical background to the main sources of power (economic, military and symbolic) which have been and are yet fundamentally relevant within the Middle Eastern States, highlighting their role in the democratization process.

Students who have successfully completed the course will 1) obtain thorough knowledge of the historical period significant in social and cultural growth and development of the Modern Middle East, b) be able to apply their knowledge and analytical skills to better understand modern political and social processes in the Middle East, 3) be equipped with the tools to express their own critical views on historical developments in Middle East and 4) improve their analytical writing skills.

data.description: The objective of this course is to provide the students with the fundamental notions of digital circuits, with particular focus to the understanding, the analysis and the design of logic networks. At the end of the course, the student will be able to comprehend the operation of digital circuits that use logic gates and state machines, and to design complex digital processing systems by analyzing and evaluating the design choices. The student learns how to approach the design through the use of synchronous specification models, timing diagrams, and simulation and implementation using the VHDL language, identifying the critical components, and partitioning the design to handle its complexity. Exercises on design problems and laboratory sessions allow the students to apply the concepts in practice, and to gain familiarity with real components and design environments.

data.name: Viticoltura 2: Tecnica viticola con esercitazioni
data.description:
The teaching has a practical operational purpose and aims to provide the knowledge and skills for the management of the vineyard. Specifically: planting, training systems, pruning techniques, canopy management, nutrition and fertilization, irrigation and soil management.
The objectives will be achieved both through lectures and through numerous examples and practical exercises done in the vineyard. 
EXPECTED LEARNING ENDPOINTS
Lessons, exercise and laboratory activities, followed by an appropriate individual study, will allow the student to:

1) Motivate the physiological bases and apply the techniques for the practical execution of the correct winter pruning of the vineyard, both for the Guyot and ramified spur cordon system and for the pergolas and other systems expanded;

2) Draw up technical reports concerning the vocational characterization of the environments,
the choice of cultivar and rootstocks, the definition of training systems and the related planting materials. All in relation to the design and construction of new vineyards;

3) Apply phenology monitoring techniques,
control of vegetative growth and assessment of the physiological state of the vineyard in order to choose canopy management operations to optimize the quality of the grapes;

4) Recognize the symptoms of deficiency and excess of the main macro and microelements.
Explain the factors that influence mineral nutrition as well as how to control the nutritional status of the vine. Interpret the soil analyzes in order to define the nutritional needs and fertilization plans of the vineyard.
5) Calculate the daily and seasonal water consumption of the vineyard, diagnose the deficit and water stress, define irrigation strategies, motivate the choice of the different irrigation systems.

data.name: Distributed robot perception
data.description:
The instructional goals of the course is to acquire a comprehensive overview of the distributed systems for measurement and automation used today in industrial and service application domains. The course focuses on the most advanced technological solutions adopted in industry as well as on the theoretical aspects that arise when control or estimation are applied in a distributed context. Particular emphasis will be given to robotic perception using Artificial Intelligence techniques to be applied to robotic problems.

During the course, the focus will be on the design and implementation of distributed estimators to be used for intelligent autonomous systems in industrial and service environments, analyzing the resulting problems from both a practical and theoretical point of view. Examples of the application of these techniques on real or realistic systems will be presented during the course.

At the end of the course, the student will be able to:

- Understand the complexity, the issues and the potentialities of distributed systems;

- Compare the various different technological solutions available for a distributed system;

- Evaluate and analyze the practical and theoretical implications of a distributed measurement and/or perception system;

- Analyse and design the distributed solution for a particular system;

- Critically asses the benefits and the limitations of a distributed solution.

data.name: Judgment and Decision Making Laboratory
data.description:
The psychology of judgment and decision-making is the science that studies the basic mechanisms underlying human judgments and choices. The science originated in the 1970s but reached its peak in 2002, when Daniel Kahneman and Amos Tversky, psychologists, were awarded the Nobel Prize in economics for having integrated results of psychological research into economic science, especially with regard to human judgment and decision theory under conditions of uncertainty. A few years later, Richard Thaler, a behavioral economist and long-time collaborator of Kahneman and Tversky had the idea of using the results of their research to design interventions aimed at improving the well-being of citizens and workers. He summarized his ideas in a book published with Cass Sunstein in 2008 (Nudge). Nudging (gentle pushing) was born, an alternative practice to classic policies, for the conception of which Richard Thaler received the 2017 Nobel Prize in economics. In the year of the COVID-19 pandemic, the authors decided to revise and rewrite the 2008 book. On August 3, 2021, "Nudge: the final Edition" was published.


Today there is a wide spread around the world of Nudge Units (Behavioral Insights Teams).In 2018 the European Union also created a Behavioral Insight Unit. These units collect experimental research findings from various disciplines from behavioral sciences such as behavioral economics to social psychology and cognitive psychology and use them to devise "behavioral" interventions that benefit the decision maker. Old-fashioned policies often fail to take into account people's actual behavior. For example, few of us read the entire contract before downloading a new app on our cell phones, and many of us take impulsive actions that we regret later. The behavioral sciences provide empirical evidence to anticipate how people will react to interventions, and they seek to design interventions in ways that make it easier for citizens and workers to make decisions and more closely match their goals. Such nudging interventions have been used to increase savings, reduce consumption, increase health, improve care for the environment, etc.


In this course, you will be able to:

- develop an understanding of the basic mechanisms of human decision-making.

- understand how to design behavioral interventions that, by considering these mechanisms, reduce decision fatigue and increase the well-being of citizens and workers.

data.name: Enterprise information system
data.description:
The general goal of the Enterprise Information System course is to teach students to play an active role in decision making about investments in information technologies.

The course introduces the fundamental principles of information systems; teaches concepts and models to plan investments in information systems according to the activities to be supported and to the company's business model.

Focusing on web-based information systems, the second part of the course introduces a method to design an effective web presence strategy.

After completing the course, the student will be able to:

  • know and classify information systems and their application in business
  • apply requirements elicitation and analysis techniques
  • realize a feasibility study for an information system module starting from the business challenges of the company 
  • know the principles and the protocols of Internet and Web
  • model, evaluate and plan web presence strategies
  • evaluate website quality according to a goal-oriented approach
  • analyse and manage online reputation of a company.

data.description:
The objective of this course is to give the student a broad and integrative knowledge of moderate complexity design analysis (static, fatigue and vibrational analysis) and of the main mechanical components used in mechanical devices such as permanent and non-permanent joints, shafts, springs, bearings, gears, clutches, brakes and flexible mechanical elements. 
By the end of this course students should: (1) be able to analyse the stress and strain on mechanical components and understand, identify and quantify failure modes for mechanical parts; (2) know basic machine elements used in machine design and design machine elements to withstand the loads and deformations for a given application, while considering additional specifications; (3) be able to approach a design problem successfully, taking decisions when there is not a unique answer; (4) be familiar with team-working, mathematical computing and CAD software; (5) be able to present analyses in a proper format of a written report such that a technically qualified person can follow and obtain similar findings.

data.name: Electrochemical energy storage and Conversion

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
(1) Knowledge and understanding: profound and detailed scientific knowledge and understanding of the principles of electrochemistry.

(2) Applying Knowledge and understanding: main applications in electrochemical energy production, storage and conversion systems.

(3) Making judgments: skills and problem-solving capacity to analyze real cases of electrochemical energy storage and conversion.

(4) Communication skills: ability to structure and prepare scientific and technical documentation describing project activities.

(5) Learning skills: ability to independently work and update on developments in the most important sectors of electrochemical energy production, storage, and conversion.

data.name: Scienza delle costruzioni

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
The purpose of the course is to provide students with the basic knowledge necessary to handle the structural response of mechanical systems subject to static loading conditions. The course topics are preparatory for the subsequent structural and architectural courses.

The course will focus on:

i) the determination of the internal forces (axial force, bending moment, and shear force) of statically indeterminate structures (truss and frame structures);

ii) the theory of elasticity (kinematic and static analysis) and their relationship, introducing the so-called “Constitutive Equation”;

iii) the “de Saint Venant's Theory” for the 4 fundamental cases (Axial Load; Bending; Torsion; Bending-Shear);

iv) the theory of instability.


After the course, the student should be able to:

  • discuss the course arguments and repeat the main proofs;
  • perform the classification of structures from the kinematical viewpoint, and classify them as hypostatic, isostatic, and hyperstatic;
  • determine the constraint reaction forces and the internal forces of hyperstatic structures using different methods (Force method, Principle of virtual work, linearized Elastica, and energy methods);
  • determine the stress state of prismatic bars by applying Saint Venant's theory;
  • discuss the problems related to the instability theory and computing the critical load for compressed structural elements.

data.description:
Aim of the course is to give students an understanding of the main issues related to web architectures and with several web technologies. Students will acquire the fundamental concepts, which characterise the web and the use of distributed system for implementing complex web architectures. 
At the end of the course, students will be able to identify and describe the characteristics such technologies. They will be familiar with instruments for building complex and efficient web sites.

data.description:
The course aims to supply students both theoretical backgrounds and practical knowledge about the evaluation of and in social services. It specifically introduces the knowledge and a critical reflection of the main approaches and methodologies of the evaluation of social interventions.
The course requires students to practically experience an evaluation process, applying all evalutation steps to a specific project or program directed at responding to social needs. 
At the end of the course, the theoretical and practical approach will allow students to autonomously recognize and apply the right methodologies and to evaluate social services, projects,  social activities and interventions. They will also be able to evaluate and to propose critical analyses and policy suggestions.

data.description:
The course is essentially divided into two parts. The first part aims to introduce students to the analysis of the data and to provide them with the tools necessary for the study and description of socio-economic phenomena through graphical representations and summary measures. The second part of the course is being proposed to provide to the students the basic elements of probability theory and statistical inference as a set of theories, methods and quantitative analysis techniques directed to the study of phenomena that evolve stochastically over time and/or in the space.
At the end of the course the students will be able to address and propose solutions to simple problems of economic nature on the basis of the information contained in the available data and duly summarized through appropriate statistical analysis techniques.
For each of the proposed topics will be shown applications on real data with Excel.

data.name: Storia romana I - LM
data.description:
The course consists of two different sections (A, B), 6 CFU each (30 hours = 15 lectures each one); students needing to gain 12 CFU of Roman history LM are expected to attend both the sections (students needing to gain 6 CFU are given the choice between the two).

Section A, i.e. an "Introduction to Roman epigraphy", aims to introduce to the subject of inscriptions and provide some guidance towards reading and understanding the epigraphic texts (mostly in Latin). Students will be led to: acquire some basic technical skills of the epigraphic technique, firstly in reading and dating the inscriptions; know the historical development of the epigraphic science, as well as its main collections and editions. At the end of the course, students are expected to be able to read, translate, understand, and comment the given inscriptions, grasping their helpfulness and value as fundamental sources for any thorough study about ancient Roman world.

Section B, i.e. "The War of the Allies: for a Roman Italy or an Italy without Rome?", aims to provide the methodological and content knowledge which is required for a correct reassessment of the historical events and processes that reshaped the relationship between Rome and its Italic allies since the 2nd century B.C., leading to a conflict in 90 B.C. whose outcomes were decisive for the subsequent history of Italian civic communities. Particular attention will be paid to two crucial historical and historiographical problems: a) the political motivations and objectives of the revolt; b) the incorporation of the various communities and the eventual unification of Roman Italy. Students are expected to learn thoroughly the historical events from mid-2nd century B.C. onward in their correct chronological development; at the end of the course, they will be able to: 1) make a proper use of the different sources and documents; 2) explore and reconstruct historical processes and phenomena with adequate methodological awareness; 3) understand both the political context and the social background of the historical events considered.

data.name: Introduzione alla pedagogia
data.description: The purpose of this course - which also applies to the achievement of the 24 CFU (University credits) - is to enable students and teachers the acquisition of the basic elements of pedagogical thinking-acting in our sociocultural contexts, to work in school and in general education with competence and responsibility. The student/teacher will acquire basic knowledge on education as a process of building personal identity, on the educational function of the school, on the teaching/learning process. He/She also will gain knowledge of the intentional nature of the educational relationship, of the authority-freedom dialectic through which it evolves and develops, of the ethical dimension that characterizes it. He/she will develop skills and abilities in identifying the educational needs of students, in interpersonal and social relationship, in view of a pedagogically conscious project.

data.name: Archeologia e storia della produzione nel mondo classico
data.description:
This course aims to provide students with the basic research tools to the analysis of production in the Classical world, with a specific focus on the Roman and late antique periods. The course will be composed of frontal lectures (18-20 hours) and lab work (10-12 hours) under the supervision of Professor Vaccaro.  
This will be of crucial importance to test theoretical knowledge and to combine theory with lab work. 
At the end of the course, studentes will develop:
1. Technical terminology.
2. Knowledge of the main classes of materials analysed over the course;
3. Cataloguing, drawing and digitising skills, mostly applied to ceramics and glass.
4. Providing accurate descriptions of materials shown during the final exam.

data.name: Fisiologia della cellula e degli organismi

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The course's objective is to provide basic knowledge on living organisms: evolution and diversity, anatomy and physiology. Students will follow a path that will allow them to understand the steps towards multicellularity and the integration of signals of intercellular communication.

They will be able to understand the organization of tissues and organs, their mechanisms and their integration in a system biology approach.

At the end of the course, the students will have learned:


- Basic knowledge on the organization and functioning of the cell

- Basic knowledge on the organization of multicellular organisms

- Intercellular Communication

- Physiology of organs and systems

- Check-points, homeostasis and diseases


The course aims to provide basic elements of cellular and molecular biology possibly to be studied in deeper details in other areas such as the "Molecular biology of the cell" (second semester). The part of physiology of organs and tissues is instead specifically addressed within this course.

data.name: Lab. appl.: Il problema storico della cittadinanza
data.description:
The application laboratory provides the opportunity to conduct a personalised study and, more precisely, an exercise in interpretation and presentation of juridical texts, doctrinal documents and essays on the historical issue of citizenship from the Middle Ages to the modern era.

At the end of the laboratory the students will have a good knowledge of the specific aspects and issues that are explored during the application workshop; they will acquire the mastery of legal history methodologies for analyzing the legal sources and doctrinal texts presented and discussed during the course and they will be able to expound and criticize important ideas of selected medieval and modern legal theorists.

data.name: Geologia
Structural reliability and uncertainty quantification methods

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
Structural Reliability aims to compute the failure probability of systems due to uncertainties and lack of knowledge in their modeling, design, manufacturing, and loading conditions. In Engineering, Uncertainty Quantification methods aim to measure and model these uncertainties and study their effect on analytical and computational models. This course will address both topics in a unique and continuous approach paying attention to their historical development in Civil Engineering. 

•	To offer a complete and in-depth coverage of modern methods for structural and system reliability.
•	To introduce Forward Uncertainty Quantification methods for civil engineering problems.
•	Special emphasis is given to structural and geotechnical problems where uncertainties plays a pivotal role. 
•	Emphasis is placed on developing computer codes to apply theoretical concepts into real life applications.
•	The methods discussed in this course have broad applicability and can be used in many disciplines where risk and probabilistic analysis are needed. 
•	The student is expected to gain a solid background in reliability theory and uncertainty quantification methods for engineering, to be able to read the academic literature on these rapidly growing topics, and to apply the learned methods on real life applications.

data.name: Diritto penale dell'informatica
data.description: This course begins with an analysis of new forms of crime and unlawful behaviour which are apparent in every sphere of social and economic life, given the increasingly extensive and capillary use of computers. It seeks to provide students with a framework of the main gaps in the law and the need for protection which have emerged in the face of the impact of this new technology, while bearing in mind the principle of legality and the ban on analogies that disadvantage the defendant in criminal law.

data.name: Servizio sociale in pratica

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
The course aims to consolidate previous semesters' knowledge and strengthen its practice application. This purpose is achieved by giving special attention to the issue of decision-making, which is central for professional social workers. The course aims at improving students' competence in making professional decisions, alongside the different phases of the intervention. In particular, by the end of the course, the student will have increased their competence in:

  • Recognizing the different types and characteristics of decisions in social work
  • reflecting on what makes 'good' decisions
  • ensuring the participation in the decisions of the persons involved
  • recognising the structure of a rational decision-making process, using the 'decision tree' model -
  • explaining and justifying choices regarding the interventions -
  • Accompanying people in their own decisions making
  • taking positions regarding the protection of vulnerable persons in danger

To define evaluation criteria for complex non profit organizations.
At the end of the course students  will be able to understand:
a) the public administration system;
b) different functioning frameworks of public administrations,
c) the main characteristics of public management,
d) public administration's financing models ,
e) private public partnerships
f) public procurement systems

data.name: Introduction to Computer and Network Security

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: This is an introductory course to the increasingly important area of computer and network security. The main goal is to enable students to (i) understand the theoretical and practical problems of information security, (ii) understand and recognize threats to fundamental security properties: confidentiality, integrity, and availability, and (iii) understand how the main security mechanisms - such as cryptography, authentication and authorization protocols, and access control - can be applied to mitigate vulnerabilities.

data.name: Innovation and Entrepreneurship Studies in ICT

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
After completion of the I&E Studies course, students should…

• … have the ability to apply, synthesize, and evaluate prior I&E learning within a specific innovation or entrepreneurial project setting and a specific innovation area.
• … have the ability to conduct a business analysis, make decisions and formulate recommendations or justify actions in a real environment.
• … have the ability to choose and apply relevant concepts/methods and/or tools and collect relevant data for conducting a business analysis and making decisions in a real environment.
• … have the ability to produce a professional writing on a business analysis topic.

• … have the ability to reflect critically on issues related to the development of ICT solutions, and their potential pitfalls due to market and/or social reasons.
• … have developed a sense of "out of the box thinking" and creative approaches to problem solving, even in contexts that would otherwise suggest a technical solution.
• … have the ability to make value and ethical judgements about the development of technological and business solutions.
• … have the ability to work as a team with other students to complement each other's competences and perspectives.
