data.name: Mathematical Biology

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
Objectives

The aim of the course "Mathematical Modeling in Biology" is twofold: on the one hand, present the students several basic mathematical models in different areas of biology (ecology, infectious diseases, enzymatic reactions, molecular and physiological networks); on the other hand, provide operating competences in the analysis and numerical solution of ordinary and partial differential equations.

In particular, the module " Mathematical Modeling in Biology" is devoted to modelling biological systems through ordinary differential equations, and to the introduction of several techniques (linearization; equilibria and their stability; bifurcation; regular and singular perturbations). In the module " Spatio-temporal Models in Cell and Tissue Biology", after an introduction to partial differential equations and to some techniques for obtaining or approximating their solutions, some of the most interesting features of reaction-diffusion equations (travelling wave solutions, Turing mechanism) will be presented in a biological context (signal propagation in axons, morphogenesis).

Learning outcome

The final part of the course will be devoted to the development of a group project on a subject presented during the course. At the end of the course, students are expected to be able to build mathematical models for biological systems similar to those presented in the course, to perform simple qualitative analysis of systems of ordinary differential equations, to simulate systems of ordinary differential equations and of reaction-diffusion equations using Matlab. Moreover, thanks to the project to e developed, it is expected that all students will have improved in their ability to collaborate in an interdisciplinary setting, and to communicate the results that have been obtained.

data.name: Produttività, innovazione e dinamiche d'impresa
data.description: Upon successful completion of this course, students: (i) will know the main definitions of "industry" and its most relevant dynamic characteristics; (ii) will know the main theories on firm growth and its determinants and will be able to discuss firm growth; (iii) will put firm dynamics and firm productivity into perspective within the process of (macro-)economic growth; (iv) will know the main elements of the debate on the micro- and macro-economic effects of Information and Communication Technologies (ICTs); (iv) will know the "Industry Life Cycle" framework; (vi) will interpret the results of the relevant empirical studies in Industrial Dynamics, by applying the concepts described in the previous points.

data.name: Storia del diritto medievale e moderno I
data.description:
The course provides the general lines of the history of medieval and modern law; it develops some fundamental aspects and issues in the medieval and modern history of law, also through the analysis of legal sources and doctrinal texts that are of importance to the history of law and medieval and early modern legal thought in Europe.

At the end of the course, the students will have a good knowledge of the general lines of the medieval and modern law and, in particular, of the specific issues that are explored during the course; they will acquire the mastery of legal history methodologies for analyzing the legal sources and doctrinal texts presented during the course.

data.name: Global Economic Scenarios_
data.description:
The module intends to provide students with the technical means and knowledge necessary for critically understanding the features of the global economy, the ongoing processes, their consequences and evolution.
The aim of the module is to support students in acquiring knowledge of the fundamental features of the world economy, its dynamics and evolution, including among countries and groups of countries. Special attention is devoted to the long-term trends, their causes and economic and institutional changes.
At the end of the module, students are expected to master the fundamental features of the world economy, its working, and transformations under the pressure of different factors. Students will also be able to appreciate the reasons that led to the present situation, the complexity and implications of the process of globalization and its revision, and the consequences and challenges for individual countries. Students will also be able to critically assess the alternatives, existing or possible, and the necessary reforms.

data.name: Gestione delle acque e dei sedimenti per lo sviluppo sostenibile

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
The course deals with water, river sediment and development in a broad sense. It takes a multi-scale (international to local) and multi-dimensional approach and focuses on four main themes: global water and sediment issues, river management and development, access to basic water and sanitation services, water- and sediment-related hazards in the developing world. The course is based on integration among different disciplines – as in the frequently addressed case of eco-hydraulics – and between the technical / engineering and the social, cultural and economical context.


The learning goals of the course are:


1. To develop a critical understanding of the multiple linkages between water, sediment and sustainable human development at different spatial and temporal scales.


2: To understand the main challenges in linking water and sediment management with development issues at an international level, with particular focus on data-scarce contexts


3. To learn design criteria and operation and mainteinance requirements of water supply technologies at community scale


4. To learn the main phenomena, orders of magnitudes, and available data bases on global and continental scale availability and use of water and sediment resources
data.degreeProgram: Ingegneria per l'ambiente e il territorio (LM)

data.name: Comparative Private Law
data.description:
The course aims at providing students with the legal tools required for the in-depth analysis of private law issues in different legal systems, both national and transnational. It will focus on a selection of topics in the main areas of private law, namely contract law, tort law and property law, and discuss different types of materials: statutes, case law and works of legal doctrine. It will analyze some paradigmatic European and Western national legal systems, as well as relevant international and soft law instruments (such as the CISG, the Principles of European contract law (PECL) and the Draft Common Frame of Reference (DCFR)).
Through the study and critical discussion of these materials, students will learn to identify and explain similarities and differences among legal systems, not only from a formal point of view, but also in the law in action. They will learn how to frame a legal research, where to look for relevant materials, how to analyze them and develop a critical synthesis, and how to elaborate the results of their analysis, both orally and in writing.
data.degreeProgram: Comparative, European and International Legal Studies (L2)

data.name: Bacterial Pathogenesis

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description:
Objectives
The aim of the course is to provide the students with the understanding the bacterium-host relationships and to explore the virulence factors that promote colonization and survival of the infecting microorganisms, as well the virulence attributes that damage the host. The course will explore the evolutionary aspects of bacterial pathogenesis and the experimental approaches for investigating the bacterium-host inte-relationship, underlining the molecular mechanisms of pathogenicity for selected pathogens. The challenge facing the discovering and development of new antibiotics will also be discussed.
At the end of this course, students will be able to:
a) Describe the difference between the different types of symbiosis and their evolution
b) Understand what makes a bacterium a "pathogen" 
c) Describe the distinctive genetic traits of a bacterial pathogen 
d) Understand the difference between pathogenicity and virulence and how to assess them
e) Describe the main modes of bacterial transmission
f) Describe the molecular mechanisms of bacterial pathogenicity in defined bacterial models 
g) Describe the main anti-infectious strategies against bacteria

data.name: Psicologia del linguaggio e della comunicazione

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description:
The aim of the course is to introduce the student to the psychology of language. The course mostly regards the description of the processes underlying the comprehension and production of language. The psychology of reading will be discussed in detail. We will mantain an approach close to functional psychology: the theories we will discuss are functional in spirit and therefore focused on explaining behavioural data. 
Some concepts at the basis of computational psychology will also be introduced. 
By the end of the course the student will be able to recognize psycholignuistics phenomena, to make inferences from them, to contextualize them within the adequate theoretical frameworks, and to formulate theory-driven hypotheses.
data.degreeProgram: Scienze e Tecniche di Psicologia Cognitiva (L2)

data.name: Geomatica e telerilevamento

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description: The course provides basic elements about geodesy, terrestrial reference systems and height systems. Introduction to technologies and satellite missions for remote sensing and the observation of the Earth. Principles and methods involved in technologies for radio-positioning (GPS), for optical remote sensing (multispectral images) and for 3D data acquisition (LiDAR, range images). Geometric surveys are considered for the production of digital surface models; acquisition and processing of multi-spectral images for the study of environmental objects and phenomena. Design and execution of topographic surveys for control applications and special purposes. GPS survey in real-time mode for civil and high productive applications. Use of terrestrial LiDAR sensors for civil and monitoring goals. Review of the leas squares principle, the Helmert transformation, the principal component analysis and statistical hypothesis testing. Practical activities and laboratory works, from GPS and LiDAR surveys to data processing and analysis, and the processing of remote sensed imagery. Testing of devices based on Raspberry and low cost GNSS receivers will be carried out. Students will work on the design of a GNSS network for the deployment of a real time positioning service.

The main objective of the course is to provide students with a good knowledge of Italian medieval and Renaissance literature and to guide them in the acquisition of tools, competences and concepts that are essential for the analysis of lyric and narrative texts and more generally for the study of literary forms and genres.

At the end of the course, students will be able to:

- paraphrase, analyse and comment upon poetic texts, especially but not exclusively pre-modern;

- use accurately notions of prosody, rhetoric and theory of literature.

    In particular the following topics will be treated:
    • Main definitions and foundational results (not all with a full proof): affine varieties, projective varieties, quasi-projective varieties, maps between them.
    • Projective curves and thei link to Riemann-Surfaces. Divisors, linear systems, Riemann-Roch (with a proof in the algebraic category), duality, Brill-Noether theory.
    • An introduction to schemes and sheaves.

    At the end of the course, in order to take the examination successfully, the student is expected:

    • To know and understand the definitions and the results presented during the course.
    • To be able to explain them also with examples and counterexamples and to give detailed and corrected proofs.
    • To use a correct and suitable mathematical language to treat the topics of the course.
    • To be able to recognize and use the links among the different topics.

The course provides basic knowledge of Newtonian mechanics and classical electromagnetism, their experimental foundations and their operational capabilities in solving physical problems and developing technological applications.

data.name: Produzione e logistica progredito
data.description:
The course's main objective is to understand the salient elements of production systems and operations management through studying the enterprise as a comprehensive production system, both within organizational boundaries and by considering the relationship systems that develop in an open context. In addition, we will investigate some operating mechanisms of the supply chain/network and the most relevant managerial implications stemming from strategic design choices. Finally, the main production management issues and the characteristics of some operational methods and approaches will be deepened. 


The course is structured in two parts. The first one will address the elements that constitute production systems with a perspective based on complexity analysis. In the second part of the course, the course will focus on production system design and planning.


Upon completion of the course, the student will be able to: 



  • identify the complexity factors of extended manufacturing systems and the alternatives available for their control, design and management; 
  • recognize and classify basic models through which production processes are organized, including direct observation of practical cases; analyze and describe production processes by mapping real and information flows; 
  • identify the nature of problems that characterize the management of materials (in manufacturing processes) and utilities (in service processes), with the development of simple optimization solutions; 
  • select and apply suitable planning models in the management of production systems, including through the development and evaluation of hierarchical production plans; 
  • deal with the main problems of short-term operational planning, identifying their nature and devising solutions consistent with the characteristics of production contexts; 
  • analyze and evaluate the strategic arrangement of extended production systems (supply chains), with a focus on the main design decisions: integration/ outsourcing, specialization, strategic supply choices, choices of connections with the external market; 
  • develop quantitative analyses for production and logistics systems, and critically discuss critical elements of the systems.

data.name: Diritto ecclesiastico comparato
data.description:
This course aims at:

- examining the contemporary trends in the legal regulation of religion or belief in the European space;

- comparing and contrasting the legal norms, policies and strategies envisaged by states to solve tensions originating from religious diversity, identifying those that are consistent with the requirements of contemporary democracies;

- promoting an approach going beyond the mere transmission of factual knowledge, and encouraging a critical attitude.

 

Upon completion of the course, students are expected to achieve the following learning outcomes:

- knowledge of the basic notions concerning the legal regulation of religion or belief in contemporary European societies;

- ability to compare and contrast the variety of solutions offered to the same problem;

- engagement in autonomous judgment and development of a critical attitude as regards the issues examined throughout the course;

- ability to express the basic notions of the course as well as their own point of view in a methodologically correct way, by supporting their arguments with reference to the relevant legal norms, and by using the appropriate legal terminology.

data.name: Durabilità dei materiali da costruzione

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
The course objectives are: to acquaint students with the types, properties, uses, and variety of materials important in construction; to acquaint students with building and general construction products and their associated quality, durability and availability; to identify and classify various materials (such as metals, ceramics, polymers and composites) from their characteristic properties (such as mechanical and thermal properties); to provide a solid grounding that can be applied to the design and selection of materials for applications in civil engineering, so that the students must understand the properties of materials as well as their applications and fabrication. 
The student  will be able to understand "Why" materials have certain properties and "how" these can be tailored by processing.
The student will be able to select suitable materials for application in engineering practice and advanced study in engineering.

1.Describe and explain how legal norms are produced at a supranational level

2.Analyse the interplay between the different levels (National, Regional and International) of production and application of legal norms.

3. Distinguish the different sources of EU Law
4. Understand the role of the Court of Justice in the EU’s architecture and explain how EU Law is applied at national level.

data.name: Letterature comparate II - LM
data.description: Through the close analysis of complex texts focused on the struggle between the sexes, students will learn to consider literature as a specific discursive regime that feeds on a continuous interchange with different languages ​​(psychology, history, philosophy, political theory). No content enters literature without being transformed. No content returns from literature to society without having proposed a new and unprecedented way of giving shape to one's own emotional and ideological frameworks. The student must be able to orient himself with ease in this crossroads of knowledge and styles of thought of which the theme under consideration is only one of the many possible examples. At the end of the course the student will be able to contextualize the texts as historical phenomena, read them with the critical and theoretical tools of the discipline, and orient themselves among texts relating to the different national literatures.

Through group work (for attending students) or a report (for non-attending students) the course aims to give students the opportunity to apply the theoretical knowledge acquired to create and evaluate a social communication campaign; c) communicate in a clear and detailed way ideas, problems, solutions and information relating to social communication.

data.name: Storia contemporanea

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
The course aims to introduce students to key developments in the social, political, economic and cultural history of the ‘long twentieth century’ (ca. 1870-2001). As well as providing a background to further studies in sociology, the course encourages students to adopt a historical perspective and to consider the longer roots of phenomena that at first glance seem entirely recent. 
Adopting as global an approach as possible, particular attention is dedicated to various fundamental themes of social and cultural history, including: migration, technologies of communication, urbanization, social movements, gender and the family, consumerism, globalization. 
By the end of the course, students should be able to: a) understand the periodization and the most relevant aspects of this era of history, b) critically reflect on key problems in global history, c) make appropriate use of historiographical interpretations, d) be familiar with the foundations of historical methodology and its main approaches.

data.name: Applicazioni informatiche agli archivi
data.description:
In recent years, a number of reforms in the public administration have initiated a profound process of modernization of the "public administration machine", mainly due to the introduction of information technology. This has influenced the exchanging and sharing of information, prompting the legislator to introduce a set of regulations aimed at digitizing public administration.
Hence, a computerized management of documents is a basic issue on which public administrations focus in order to enhance the value of their documentary heritage.
The course aims at providing students with archival methodologies for the design, creation, maintenance, preservation and use of document management systems.
At the end of the course, the students are expected to know the digital context in which archives are formed and the archival tools for document management as established by the regulations.

data.description:
Computer processing is a key component of modern data analysis pipelines, and plays an increasingly important role in many fields of science. The goal of the course is to introduce the Python programming language, one of the most widely used scientific computing languages, and related technologies.


At the end of this course, the students should be able to:

A) Remember the syntax and semantics of the Python language;

B) Understand programs written by others individuals;

C) Analyze a simple data analysis task and reformulate it as a programming problem;

D) Evaluate which features of the language (and related scientific libraries) can be used to solve the task;

E) Construct a Python program that appropriately solves the task;

F) Evaluate the results of the program.

data.name: Protezione idraulica dei territori montani

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
‎The primary objective of the course is to provide a qualitative and quantitative approach to the subject of hydraulic 'natural hazards' characterising mountain environments.


The course aims to provide the following knowledge:

========================================

• concepts of hazard and risk associated with natural hazards of the hydraulic type

• knowledge of the origin and dynamics of mountain natural hazards such as avalanches, torrential floods and debris flows;

• the physical-mathematical description of the phenomena underlying natural hazards (mathematical modelling) and the characteristics of the numerical tools used to simulate these hazards;

• typology and functioning of mitigation works, in relation to the different types of phenomena to which they are directed. In particular:

=> for avalanches:

> rigid support works (bridges and snow racks)

> flexible support works (snow nets)

> references to other types of works

=> For flows and torrential floods:

> storage areas

> open weirs

> gullies


• references to regulatory aspects relating to the subject.


It aims to develop the following skills:

=============================

• ability to use numerical modelling tools for avalanche phenomena, debris flows and intense torrential solid transport

• ability to interpret and assess the quality of the simulations carried out and to choose the calibration parameters appropriately;

• ability to draw up a danger map for avalanches and debris flows;

• ability to design, from a hydraulic point of view, mitigation works in relation to the different types of phenomena to which they are directed.



It is also planned to provide some seminars on civil protection issues.

data.name: Big Data Technologies
data.description:
Nowadays we are producing data at rates that we have never seen before, creating datasets characterized by extreme Volume, Variety and Velocity. Unfortunately, traditional data management technologies have been proven limited in managing data with these characteristics. This led to the term Big Data, as a way to refer to this kind of data, and new technologies been developed to cope with it. This course is an introduction to Big Data Technologies. It aims at providing an understanding of the fundamental principles, frameworks and tools upon which Big Data systems are built.
The students will acquire an understanding of what is big data, why it is relevant, knowledge of some of the technologies/frameworks/tools available for building big data systems and how to combine them to analyse data at scale

The course focuses on the use of modern "statistical learning" techniques for prediction and classification in business and economic contexts. The course has an applied cut and the theoretical level of the topics is aimed at understanding the practical aspects of the applications. Free R software will be used and lab activities complement material discussed in class. At the end of the course, the student will be able to

• Analyze a multivariate data set

• Build models for analyzing and verifying hypotheses of interest and making predictions

• Understand the modeling component in the scientific-economic literature of the company

data.name: Human Computer Interaction

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The course has the general objective of providing students with the fundamental notions about the interaction between humans and computerized systems. In particular, the course is focused on the principles of the User-Centered-Design methodology, as well as on their application during the design and evaluation of interfaces of various types and for various domains.

Upon successful completion of this module, students should be able to:

- Design and critically assess the user interface of an interactive system as well as the interaction modalities afforded by it
- Use tools, techniques and models for the design and evaluation of the interaction
- Understand the needs and the role of the user and relate them to the design of usable interactive systems
- Know the fundamentals of the human cognitive processes and their implications for the design of interactive interfaces
- Develop prototypes of interfaces of websites and mobile apps, considering usability aspects as well as the peculiarities of the interaction
- Understand the concepts of accessibility, inclusiveness and Universal Design related to the design of interactive systems

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.name: Information, Knowledge and Service Management

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
Data, information, and knowledge are increasingly recognized as a crucial asset in modern organizations. The course intends to bring the students a solid general understanding of data, information and knowledge management focusing on concepts, methods and tools that can be used to enable innovation and change management within the organizations. A particular focus will be proposed on service science, an interdisciplinary approach to the study, design, and implementation of services systems. Organizations are complex systems in which specific interdependencies of people and technologies take actions and provide value. 
The course enable the student to deeply analyse from an organisational and managerial perspective Information and Knowledge management systems, Information system and data management, double side platforms, and some emerging technological phenomena such as crowdsourcing and gamification.

data.name: Lab. appl.: Interessi monetari ed usura
data.description: The course aims to provide an overview of the critical issues regarding the relationship between consumers and financial institutions in credit contract. Particular emphasis is devoted to the analysis of the topic of usury from an interdisciplinary perspective (contract law and criminal law). At the end of the course, students will be able to critically approach legal issues related to pecuniary obligations and interests rates as well as to highlight both private law and criminal law questions that these issues raise, through an interdisciplinary approach.

data.name: Multisensory interactive systems

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The overall goal of the module is to provide a theoretical and practical basis for the design, development, and evaluation of interactive systems, which are multisensory, tangible, and networked. Students on this module will have the opportunity to explore physical computing concepts, use real-time programming languages, understand the bases of human sensory perception, and design networked interactions in both co-located and remote settings.

On successful completion of this course, students should be able to: 
- Understand fundamental notions on electronic hardware such as micro controllers, single board computers, sensors, and actuators of different kind
- Develop interactive applications based on both embedded systems and desktop solutions, which take inputs from sensors and control a variety of physical and digital outputs
- Apply acquired knowledge on fundamentals of multisensory perception to the design of interactive systems
- Apply techniques for prototyping multisensory interactive systems as well as for their evaluation at both technical and user experience level


Students will apply knowledge and skills from above in completing a semester project in teams. Students will be provided with a large variety of hardware items and software tools, which will enable them to create prototypes of networked, tangible and interactive multisensory systems.

data.name: Progettazione di sistemi integrati per il recupero di materia da rifiuti urbani

data.description:
The module gives criteria useful for a correct design of waste treatment plants, in particular municipal solid waste.

A correct design must be based also on the knowledge of waste collection before treatment. For this reason collection and transport of waste are topics included in the module. At the end of the lessons the student will be able to participate to a design team for plants in the sector in EU-like contexts (for material recovery)

data.name: Letteratura, pregiudizi e stereotipi

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description:
What is reading literature for today? And how can you read the narratives?

The course aims at answering these questions with particular attention to prejudices and stereotypes about literature. At the end of the course, students are expected: to relate literary knowledge with the one of other subjects; to use the literary knowledge in order to critically read contemporary literature; to update knowledge and skills indipendently, by finding literary texts appropriate to personal research and working enviroments.

data.name: Idrodinamica

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
Aimed at students in the first year of the Master's Degree in Environmental and Land Engineering, this course extends concepts given in basic courses of Fluid Mechanics and provides the methodological framework and tools needed to understand and model free-surface flows. In particular, the course focuses on open channel flow under both steady and unsteady flow conditions, and provides an introduction to sediment transport processes and river morphodynamics.

At the end of the course the student will be able to:

i) understand the hypotheses, the range of applicability and the information required for the application of models in environmental hydraulics;

ii) determine qualitatively and quantitatively the flow behaviour in natural rivers under steady flow conditions, within the framework of the 1D cross section averaged model, accounting for various control structures and discharge variations;

iii) model open channel flow under unsteady conditions;

iv) understand the fundamental processes that control the long-term morphodynamical response of alluvial rivers;

v) implement and use computational procedures to evaluate the stage-discharge relationship in natural rivers, the backwater free surface profile under steady flow conditions and the long-term evolutionary trajectories of alluvial river beds;

vi) measure in the laboratory and in the field the hydraulic properties of free surface flows and test the experimental measurements with theoretical and numerical estimates.

data.name: Diritto delle istituzioni internazionali
Fisica 2

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
The aim of the course is to provide students with a basic knowledge of electromagnetic phenomena and the ability to make predictions on the basis of the laws governing these phenomena. Electromagnetism will be presented starting from phenomenological examples from technology and nature. By the end of the course, students will:
a)have learn the Maxwell's equations
b)be able apply them on true problems.
This is a foundation course preparing students for more specialised engineering courses. As the majority of students will not study the applications of electromagnetism in a systematic way (for example optics and electromagnetic waves) in their studies, this demanding course aims to provide students with a sound knowledge of concepts which will then enable them to widen their understanding of and to deal with problems relating to electromagnetism in an independent way.

data.name: Sensors and micro electro-mechanical systems
data.description:
This course offers a general, broad introduction to microsensors and microelectromechanical systems (MEMS), involving devices working across different physical domains. Specifically, the course main topics are: sensing and actuation principles, sensor categories and applications, material properties, fabrication technologies, design and modeling strategies, interface circuit issues, packaging.


After completing the course, the student will be able to:

- understand the physical operation principles of microsensors and actuators; 

- be familiar with state-of-the art processing technologies for microsensors and MEMS;

- describe examples of application of microsensors and actuators implemented in MEMS technology;

- understand the mathematical modeling of selected microsensors and MEMS; 

- perform detailed Finite Element simulations of semiconductor microsensors ;

- evaluate sensor performance and trade-offs between critical design parameters;

- read and understand scientific papers in the relevant field;

- write a scientific report and give an oral presentation in the relevant field.

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: The course presents innovative methodologies with emphasis on techniques based on Artificial Intelligence for the solution of imaging and diagnostics/prognostics problems for biomedical, industrial, and safety applications. Starting from a series of seminar lessons that present the different techniques developed at the state of the art, the course is dedicated to present the tools and methods for solving imaging and diagnostics/prognostics problems, addressing specific project activities through laboratory activities. The projects may have a numerical or experimental nature and can be chosen by the students from a set of possible alternatives.

data.name: Quality and innovation engineering
data.description:
This course covers the scientific and engineering basics of (i) quality management, (ii) innovation management. Specifically, the course main topics are: quality management paradigms, ISO 9000 series of standards, quality awards, process management, basics of risk management, statistical inference, relaibility, innovation management. After completing the course, the student will be able to:

- understand, summarize and compare the main quality management paradigms;

- understand and summarize the ISO 9000 series of standards and the quality awards;

- understand, summarize and analyse the fundamentals of risk management;

- understand, summarize and analyse the fundamentals of process management;

- understand and summarize the fundamentals of statistical inference;

- understand and summarize the fundamentals of innovation management;

- understand and summarize the impact of innovation on sustainability.

data.name: Electronic materials and technologies
data.description:
The aim of the course is to present electronic devices and technologies commonly used for manufacturing devices, sensors and large scale integrated circuits of common use for industrial and ICT applications. The course also introduces software tools used in the development of electron devices, emphasizing both the technological and design aspects.

At the end of the course, the students are expected to be familiar with the terminology and the problems commonly found in the field of semiconductor device physics and technology. They should be able to qualitatively describe the working principle and fabrication process of the semiconductor devices studied within the course and to solve numerical problems on these topics.

They should also acquire a basic operative knowledge on the use of TCAD simulation tools, and develop the ability to use them to solve simple design problems.

data.name: Analisi dei dati e Statistica
data.description:
The course is essentially divided into two parts. The first part aims to introduce students to the analysis of the data and to provide them with the tools necessary for the study and description of socio-economic phenomena through graphical representations and summary measures. The second part of the course is being proposed to provide to the students the basic elements of probability theory and statistical inference as a set of theories, methods and quantitative analysis techniques directed to the study of phenomena that evolve stochastically over time and/or in the space.
At the end of the course the students will be able to address and propose solutions to simple problems of economic nature on the basis of the information contained in the available data and duly summarized through appropriate statistical analysis techniques.
For each of the proposed topics will be shown applications on real data with Excel.

data.name: Machine Learning for NLP II
data.description: The course provides an introduction to advanced topics and techniques in machine learning for natural language processing and other data modalities, covering a variety of state-of-the-art architectures and machine learning tasks, including prediction, generation, adaptation to new domains and tasks, explanation, and debugging.  The course consists of both theoretical classes and practical sessions, in which the students learn hands-on how to (i) adapt existing architectures to specific tasks and develop new architectures from scratch, (ii)  train and fine-tune state-of-the-art models on a wide variety of data, (iii) evaluate the quality and behaviour of the learnt models, and (iv) explore what knowledge the models acquired and how it is being used to achieve specific predictions.  The students will be introduced to standard open source Python libraries for machine learning, chiefly scikit-learn and pytorch.  The project assignment will touch on natural language processing in the context of the topics covered during the course.

data.name: Lingua e traduzione inglese e lingue e letterature angloamericane I
data.degreeProgram: Letterature euroamericane, traduzione e critica letteraria (LM)

data.name: Computational linguistics
data.description:
The course introduces the basics of computational linguistics. Its goal is to (1) provide students with an overview of the field with focus on the syntax-semantics interface; (2) bring student to be aware on the one hand of several lexicalized formal grammars, on the other hand of computational semantics models and be able to combine some of them to capture the natural

language syntax-semantics interface; (3) evaluate several applications with a special focus to lexical semantics; (4) make students acquainted with writing scientific reports.


All these objectives will help students understand how methods from computer science, mathematics and statistics are applied to the modelling of natural language and start being propositive for new ideas.


At the end of the course students will be able to: (1) illustrate the main challanges addressed in the field, which are its consolidated results and which are the current research questions; (2) master, at introductory level, the basic rules of some formal grammars and of formal and distributional semantics languages and their integration based on the principle of compositionality; (3) compare approaches on computational linguistics tasks, and use some evaluation scripts; (4) apply interdisciplinary approaches to linguistics tasks and write a scientific report on their research in LaTex.

data.name: Sociologia dell'ambiente

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
The course aims to achieve the following educational objectives:
-Introduce students to the key issues dealt with by environmental sociology
- Introduce students to the main sociological theories and conceptual tools developed to analyze the relationship between society and the environment
-Analyze the main current environmental issues, such as environmental risks, environmental conflicts and the energy transition.
Upon completion of this course, students will acquire:

Furthermore, the active participation to the course will enable students to:

-develop analytical skills through the presentation of theoretical and empirical topics
- improve the bibliographic research capacity through the library and internet tools available;

data.name: Teoria di Galois
data.description:
The course will give an introduction into Galois
theory: the main themes will be the Galois group, and the Galois correspondence.
At the end of the course the student will be able to compute the Galois group of a polynomial equation, to explicitly compute the Galois correspondence, and to do the proofs of some of the main theorems of Galois theory.

data.name: Diritto delle reti di imprese
data.description:
The course will introduce the students to the main legal forms of inter-firm cooperation, as organisation models used to define the supply chain, both in the production and in the distribution phases, based on long-term collaboration and now recollected not only as economic models but also under a specific legal form of “inter-firm networks”.

The course includes four sessions. The first part will be devoted to the legal framework of business collaboration and of inter-firm networks, distinguishing those forms from the so called market relationships, which focus on the instant exchange of resources. The second part will analyse the main legal forms of business collaboration and inter-firm networks. The third part will focus on the in-depht study of the tax and labor law profiles.of inter-firm networks. In the latter part of the course students will be invited to present and discuss the main findings of a case study concerning a specific network.

At the end of the course, the student will be able to:

1.        understand and distinguish between the different objectives that firms can pursue through the creation and contractual regulation of a strategic collaboration;

2.        identify the main legal forms of these collaborations, in particular distinguishing between contractual forms, organizational and mixed forms;

3.        identify the main sources of legal rules applicable to relationships of strategic collaboration organized in the form of a network;

4.        know and employ adequate criteria of choice to identify the most appropriate legal instrument for the objectives pursued and relevant contextual elements;

5.        argue the use of these criteria on the basis of an appropriate legal and economic analysis;

6.        identify the main features of the legal instruments aimed at regulating the operation of contractual networks, with particular regard to the network contract, the franchise and the consortium, and outline, in its baselines, the contractual design which distinguishes them;

7.        address legal issues related to the functioning of network relationships, in particular with regard to the promotion of cooperative behaviour, the prevention and reduction of the risks of opportunism, and the liability resulting from torts.

8. identify the main tax implications deriving from the use of some legal forms for inter-firm collaboration, as well as address the main issues concerning the management of employment relationships in network contexts, with particular reference to the use of tools such as “distacco agevolato” and “codatorialità”, specifically provided for the network contract (contratto di rete).

Software vulnerabilities

data.description: The course consists of two didactic units: A) The first didactic unit, named "General Part", introduces to the most known sociological perspectives, to the most important scientific interests within sociology and to the fundamental concepts of the discipline by examining their applications to the main areas of social research. B) The second didactic unit, indicated as "Seminar", includes the presentation and discussion of some central themes in the contemporary sociological debate.

data.name: Circuiti elettronici digitali

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: The objective of this course is to provide the students with the fundamental notions of electronic digital design, with particular focus to the understanding, the analysis and the design of digital circuits using MOS technology. The student learns to analyze devices and basic digitial circuits in non-linear state, and size them to reach the desired static and dynamic performance, for both combinational and sequential circuits (flip flops and memories), also using circuit simulation tools (Spice). Exercises on design problems and laboratory sessions allow the students to apply the concepts in practice, and to gain familiarity with real components and instrumentation. At the end of the course, the student will be able to comprehend the operation of combinational and sequential logic gates, to evaluate and measure their characteristics, and to design them analyzing and evaluating the effect of design decisions.

data.name: Atmospheric radiation and remote sensing

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description: The objective of this course is to provide a profound overview of remote sensing methods for atmospheric research and meteorology from ground, airborne and spaceborne platforms. The emphasis of this course will be on active, optical remote sensing with lasers. Passive remote sensing methods will be discussed in comparison with active lidar techniques. The participants should learn how to analyse remote sensing data and gain some insights into recent research activities.

data.name: Filosofia della scienza
data.description: The course, of a rather general character, aims at providing an introduction to the birth of the philosophy of science in the first three decades of the XXth century, and its subsequent development. The final part of the course will be devoted to a focus on the notion of causation between philosophy and science. At the end of the course, the students will have a good acquaintance with main issues of the philosophy of science of the XXth century, with special reference to the origins of the philosophy of science as an autonomous discipline and to the role of logical empiricism in shaping the agenda of the philosophical investigation about the conceptual implications of natural sciences.

data.name: Corso di italiano A1a - I periodo (estensivo)
Embedded systems
data.description:
Embedded computers are found everywhere, from home appliances to automobiles to medical devices. Designing an embedded computing system is a challenging task because the requirements include manufacturing cost, performance, power consumption, user interface, hard deadlines, and rich functionality. 
The objective is to illustrate the embedded system design process, which includes requirements, specification, architecture, components, and system integration phases. The course will be backed up by real-life design examples to illustrate the design process, and also students will be asked to design embedded systems to gain experience.

1. Knowledge and understanding 
Conoscenza approfondita degli argomenti di base del calcolo delle probabilità e della statistica come specificato dal programma del corso. Capacità di individuare un modello probabilistico e di comprenderne le principali caratteristiche. Capacità di applicare la probabilità alla fisica e altri problemi scientifici o della vita comune.

2. Applying knowledge and understanding 
Capacità di ragionamento induttivo e deduttivo nell’affrontare problemi coinvolgenti fenomeni casuali. Capacità di schematizzare un fenomeno aleatorio in termini rigorosi, di impostare un problema e di risolverlo utilizzando opportuni strumenti della probabilità e della statistica. 

3. Making judgements

data.name: Arboricoltura generale, principi di fisiologia e genetica delle piante da frutto
data.description:
The general objective of this teaching is to provide students with the main notions inherent in the role of arboriculture in modern agriculture. The first part of the course will cover the basic concepts of general arboriculture, where the main tree structures and the various forms of farming, as well as pruning, will be explained for a better control of the fruiting. In this part, topics related to environmental vocationality and the principles of nursery will also be discussed. In the second part of the course, the physiology of the plant will be treated, with particular attention to the various hormones and bioregulators controlling the development of the plant itself. A fundamental part of this section of the course is the study of the ontogenic cycle, in which the various ripening processes of the fruit and their link with the definition of fruit quality will be illustrated. The last part of the course will be instead focused on the principles of genetic improvement of the fruit crops and their application for more efficient and sustainable fruit growing.

At the end of the course, the student:
• Will be aware of the role of modern arboriculture principles
• Will understand the various cultivation techniques addressed to a more performing and innovative fruit growing
• Will have the opportunity to know the various physiological processes underlying the development and ripening of fruits, and the role they play in defining the quality of the fruits themselves
• Will understand the role of post-harvest in modern fruit growing in maintaining fruit quality
• Will know the main genetic improvement strategies to ameliorate the quality characteristics of the fruit and the post-harvest performance
• Will be informed about modern biotechnological approaches aimed at obtaining superior ideotypes

Organizational behaviour and human resources management
data.description:
The main goal of this course is to understand and analyze some of basic concepts of Human Resource Management (HRM) and the most important variables affecting organizational and group behaviour. Students are expected to achieve an understanding of concepts that influence human behaviour in organizations and an understanding of how these concepts influence group-level performance. Among others, the course will focus on the following topics: workforce management, processes of recruitment and selection, training, performance assessing, organizational culture, and motivation. 

According to EPAS Accreditation, upon completion of the module students will:
• be able to analyse some of the basic concepts of Human Resource Management (HRM) and the most important variables affecting organizational and group behaviour (programme ILO K1)
• get aware of some of the more common problems faced in the management of personnel and be able to apply methodological and practical instruments to deal with them (programme ILO K2)
• have learnt to make convincing presentations (programme ILO S1)
• have learnt to discuss / work together as an international team (programme ILO S2 and IP2))
• consider ethical aspects in organizational and human resource decisions as important variables (programme ILO A2)
• look at organizational and human resource decisions from an international perspective (programme objective IP1)
• be able to apply behavioural theory in the organizational and human resource context to practical company problems (programme ILO BW1)

data.name: Finanza aziendale progredito
data.description:
1. Learning objectives and course contents.
The purpose of the course is to provide students with an advanced understanding of the corporate investment and financing decisions. 
The first part focuses on the assessment of investments with leverage and enterprise value, with various approaches (the weighted average cost of capital method, the adjusted present value method and the flow-to-equity discounted cash flow method, multiples approach). The second part introduces the payout policy, in perfect market and in the presence of frictions. The third part analyses the typical sources of capital for corporation, in term of both equity and debt (bonds, leasing), with a medium/ long-term perspective. The fourth part introduces mergers and acquisition. The fifth part concerns finance for SMEs

2. Expected learning outcomes.

1. to describe the methods of evaluation of investment with leverage and to list the steps in computing each (define the input variables and describe how to compute their value; illustrate how the variables are used in the model; define and understand the output of the model);2. to understand and discuss the critical issues of each methods of evaluation (given the specific investment’s risk and leverage assumptions) and to identify the most suitable method of evaluation; to apply the methods of evaluation to examples / real cases;
3. to discuss the effect of dividend payment or share repurchase in a perfect capital market; to discuss the effect of taxes on dividend policy; to describe and discuss the effect of agency costs and information asymmetry on payout policy; 4. to describe the ways in which a private company can raise outside capital; to describe the bond indenture; to compare and discuss callable and convertible bonds with straight debt; 5. to identify the sources of synergies that are commonly cited as justification given for an acquisition; to discuss the premium; to calculate and discuss the maximum exchange ratio;6. to identify why and how SMEs are different from large companies in the financial decisions and to adapt to them the financing approaches.

data.name: Glass engineering
data.description:
After completing this course, the students will be able to know, compare and select the fundamental properties and characteristics of glasses, with specific reference to silicate glasses, for their specific applications with respect to their composition and processing conditions.

More specifically students will be able to:

- summarize and analyze possible routes for producing a glass instead of a crystal

- summarize, evaluate and modify the fundamental properties (optical, mechanical, chemical) of oxide glasses for specific applications (architectural, electronic, biomedical, optical) as a function of the processing conditions

- summarize, evaluate and select the processing technology for specific real glass components


Additional learning outcomes include some soft skills the student will acquire, at least partially (but not only), especially after completing the laboratory activities; these regard teamwork (collaboration and cooperation during the activity), communication (writing the lab report), flexibility, responsibility and positive attitude.

data.name: Ermeneutica filosofica
data.description:
The aim of the course on PHILOSOPHICAL HERMENEUTICS is to provide students with knowledge about the main directions of the philosophical theory of interpretation, with reference 1) to the exegetical tradition of religious, juridical and literary texts; 2) to its methodological developments within human sciences, and 3) to its evolution as a form of understanding proper to the ontological relationship between man and world.


At the end of the course on PHILOSOPHICAL HERMENEUTICS, the student will have acquired notions and categories through which: A) he/she will be able to reflect on possibilities, limits and forms of interpretation; B) he/she will be motivated to recognize the hermeneutic background underlying the various existential, social and cultural contexts; C) he/she will be able to distinguish the explicit and latent aspects of the forms of experience and communication; D) he/she will have developed useful interaction skills for field research and work; E) he/she will be able to produce conceptual maps to represent synthetic meaning connections between the various theoretical contents of the course.

data.name: Bayesian statistics

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
Purpose of the course

The purpose of the course is to address the study of the foundations of Bayesian statistics starting from the basic principles of the probability calculus. The course is divided into two modules.


  • The first module is devoted to present the parametric Bayesian inferential framework and intends to explore the foundations of the Bayesian paradigm and highlight the similarities and differences with the classical Fisher’s approach. Particular attention will be posed on computational and simulation aspects.
  • The second module focuses mainly on nonparametric Bayesian framework and related methods exploring the implications of Dirichlet and Pitman-Yor process in nonparametric mixture models. Particular attention will also be devoted on computational aspects of nonparametric mixture models.


During the course, the students have the opportunity to familiarize themselves with the principal theorems, logical developments, ideas and issues that underlie the Bayesian techniques, learn to recognize them as natural extensions of the concepts introduced in the previous courses in probability and mathematical statistics and familiarize with their us in practical situations.


The students will be request to have a pro-active participation and a constant involvement in the training program.


Course expected results

After taking this course students should be able to

  • Choose appropriately prior distributions and obtain posterior distributions
  • Simulate values from posterior distributions and make appropriate Bayesian inference.
  • Construct Bayesian prediction intervals and write appropriate conclusions.
  • Construct hierarchical models and adapt mixture models to capture the richness and the variety of the real phenomena.
  • Use a statistical computer packages (mainly R) to implement the data analysis procedures covered in the course.

At the end of the course, students will be able to identify and describe the characteristics such technologies. They will be familiar with instruments for building complex and efficient web sites.

data.name: Macroeconomia
data.description:
The course aims at presenting and analyzing the key macroeconomic problems of growth, fluctuations, unemployment and inflation, the leading contemporary macroeconomic theories and their policy prescriptions. In addition, basic notions and instruments of internationally open economies will be introduced. Finally, the course will examine the main instructional features and principles of governance and economic policy of the European economic and monetary union.


The expected learning results are:

- become familiar with, and develop autonomous and critical interpretation of, main macroeconomic facts and problems and their relevant data; be able to understand and critically interpret the public debate on the macroeconomic policy issues

- know hypotheses, concepts and key results of the main contemporary macroeconomic theories, and their views and implications for economic policy

- be able to understand and apply the basic macroeconomic models

- understand and interpret competently the international dimension of macroeconomic problems and policy issues

- know the political-economic institutions of the European economic and monetary union; understand and critically discuss the main problems of monetary and fiscal policies in the Union

data.name: Psicologia dello sviluppo
data.description: This module is a general introduction to developmental psychology, with a focus on early infant development, from birth to 3 years of age. We will discuss the main perspectives in developmental psychology and the main theories. We will provide students with those basic information and basic skills that are necessary to develop critical thinking on developmental process, stages and causes of cognitive development. We will present and discuss classic theories and some recent theoretical approaches. Special attention will be dedicated to communication in early development. We will also discuss empirical data on developmental topics in the following areas: visual and auditory perception, attention, action understanding, social cognition, emotional development, language development. We will also explain methods and techniques used in developmental psychology. At the end of the module, students are expect to develop a critical understanding on the main developmental theories and to know some of the main progress of the field in the last decades. They should be able to link problems in developmental psychology and central problems in cognitive psychology.

data.name: Designing and programming the Internet of Things (IoT)

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
The course provides an overview of the main platforms and technologies for the development of Internet of Things (IoT) products and services including devices for sensing, actuation, processing, and communication. The course will improve the design skills and experiences to employ in developing novel systems. The course has theory and lab sections and the lab sections consist of hands-on and practical IoT exercises of fast prototyping sensing, actuation and communication for IoT devices with WiFi-microcontrollers and multi-core programmable platforms (e.g. the Raspberry Pi Platform).


After completing the course, the students should be able to lead and conduct the

development process of data-driven IoT-enabled services or products, more specifically:

a. Acquire the necessary knowledge and thinking of collaborating with developers and engineers throughout the design process.

b. Integrate data science and software engineering methods in the design process to develop innovative IoT products and services.

c. Identify and select appropriate development tools and use them effectively throughout the development process.

d. Use statistical data methods to generate insights and knowledge from IoT data and make it intelligible for stakeholders.

e. Balance the interests of users, business and societal challenges regarding to ethical data issues such as data privacy, data confidentiality, data quality, data ownership, etc.

data.name: Neurogenesis and Brain Regeneration

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description:
The aim of the course is to provide the students with the basis for the understanding of the principles of neurogenesis during development and postanatal life. Particular attention is devoted to mechanisms controlling neurogenesis in physiological and in pathological conditions and how manipulation of neurogenesis might be important to develop regenerative approaches to the diseased CNS. In particular, on completion of this course students will be able to:
1. explain the basic principles of neurogenesis during development and in adult mammalian brain
2. describe the principles of cellular and molecular properties of different mammalian Neural Stem Cell populations
3. explain the mechanisms that regulate neurogenesis in physiological and pathological conditions
4. understand the physiological roles of adult neurogeneis
5. describe the different in vitro systems exploitable for studying neurogenesis and for producing cells for regenerative approaches
6. explain the strategies for exploiting in vivo and in vitro neurogenesis for regenerative purposes

At the completion of this course students will need to show:
- Familiarity with the key issues in urban and rural sociology, as well as cross-cutting issues common to both spatial / disciplinary domains
- Being able to discuss and analyze these issues critically
- Familiarity with the different methodologies adopted by the sociology of the territory in relation to the different themes dealt with

Students who will take part in the seminar part of the course will, in addition:
• Improve bibliographic research ability through library and internet tools;
• Acquire teamwork and collaborative research skills;
• Improve oral presentation of academic issues

data.name: Roman Foundations of European Law
data.description: As a legal system, Roman law has had a profound impact on many legal systems across Europe (and not only). In particular, the principles, rules and categories of Roman law lie at the very heart of European law. The aim of the course is twofold. First, it intends to offer an overview of Roman legal history and the main Roman legal institutions. Furthermore, this course aims at offering a brief depiction of the reception of Roman law in Europe as a foundation of modern continental European legal systems.

data.name: Machine Learning for NLP II

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description: The course provides an introduction to advanced topics and techniques in machine learning for natural language processing and other data modalities, covering a variety of state-of-the-art architectures and machine learning tasks, including prediction, generation, adaptation to new domains and tasks, explanation, and debugging.  The course consists of both theoretical classes and practical sessions, in which the students learn hands-on how to (i) adapt existing architectures to specific tasks and develop new architectures from scratch, (ii)  train and fine-tune state-of-the-art models on a wide variety of data, (iii) evaluate the quality and behaviour of the learnt models, and (iv) explore what knowledge the models acquired and how it is being used to achieve specific predictions.  The students will be introduced to standard open source Python libraries for machine learning, chiefly scikit-learn and pytorch.  The project assignment will touch on natural language processing in the context of the topics covered during the course.

Economia delle risorse umane
data.description:
This is a course in Personnel Economics. This is an emerging field of research and human resource management in practice, where economic analysis is used to examine decisions (by individuals and management) within organisations. The main focus will be on the intuitions and descriptions of a wide range of decisions (by individuals as well as by organisations), more than on the presentation of formal economic models. Where possible, the discussion will focus on empirical evidence. The overriding goal of the course is to develop the capacity to understand, theoretically and empirically, the main decisions that take place within organisations: recruitment, selection, training, compensation, promotions, performance evaluation, and promotions.

By the end of the course, students: i) should have acquired an in-depth understanding of the main concepts and issues in personnel economics; ii) will be able to understand and explain the functioning of internal labour markets; iii) will have acquired the necessary analytical tools to analyse the decisions taken inside organisations by individuals and management.

data.name: Atomic Physics
Fondamenti di robotica

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The landscape of robotics has gone through a deep change throughout the last decade. Up until the early years of this century, robots were seen as heavy and dangerous machines used to execute stiffly defined tasks within controlled and structured environments. The recent advances in artificial intelligence have had a profound impact on the type of tasks that a robot can perform and on the level of safety and reliability they can be executed with. Modern robots assist older adults or  impaired people, work side by side with human workers, drive on the highways with little or no assistance. This paradigm shift requires the robot to perceive and understand the situation in the surroundings, to autonomously plan a suitable course of actions for a task, and to see to its correct execution by properly reacting to unexpected events. 
To design a machine of this complexity, engineers need several competencies tapping diverse disciplines. Robots are physical machines created by humans, so their motion can be analysed and controlled through appropriate mathematical models. Robots move in a partially known environment, so they need to create a map of their surroundings, to localise themselves within the environment, to detect, classify and recognise the different objects they interact with. Robots are required to be autonomous or sem-iautonomous, so they need the ability to decide a sequence of actions (a plan), to implement it within appropriate safety bounds and to adapt it to changes as needed. Finally, robots embed computing machines that need to be programmed through appropriate languages and frameworks. 
The students will be introduced to each one of these different aspects and will receive the opportunity to put them into practice using our advanced educational laboratories and teaching facilities. After taking the course, they will be able to take on a career as developers of robotic applications and/or to continue with advanced studies in the area of intelligent robots.
data.degreeProgram: Ingegneria Informatica, delle Comunicazioni ed Elettronica (L2)

data.name: Introduction to Robotics

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The course offers a bird-eye view on the most important topics related to modern robotics, highlighting the main problems that need to be faced in order to make the robots operate correctly in the environment. Specifically, the course will cover the following topics: taxonomy of the different types of robots, physical modelling of robots (direct and inverse kinematics and dynamics), simulation of models, sensing and actuation solutions for perception and action.
Using the developed models, the most famous methodologies to control robot motion and interaction, will be presented. These methods will be first studied in theory, and then implemented in simulation (with the Python language) to gain practical experience.
Attention will be also paid to illustrate the most common non idealities and issues that are present when controlling robots. The course will adopt a combination of simulation models and lab experiences to consolidate the knowledge transmitted during the theoretical lessons.
After completing the course, students will be able to:
- select the most suitable sensors and actuators for a given robotic application
- model the kinematics and dynamics any kind of robot
- understand the working principles of several control algorithms for robotic systems
- choose the appropriate approach(es) to control a specific system for a given target application
- implement, tune, and test control algorithms with the Python language

data.name: Data Analysis and Forecasting
Metodi matematici per la fisica
data.description:
The aim of the course it to lead the students to fully understand the mathematical tools that are essential to describe physical phenomena in classical physics electromagnetism, and quantum mechanics.

The theory is presented in axiomatic form and the main results are rigorously proved. These will be applied to numerous examples and exercises.

The main objectives of the course are:
(a) to develop the knowledge of the main mathematical results concerning complex-valued functions  
(b) to develop the knowledge of the main mathematical results concerning the theory of generalised functions.
(c) to recognise and solve the most important equations of modern physics

The main expected results are:
(a) to gain a sufficiently sound knowledge of the theory of complex functions and generalised functions.
(b) to be able to prove the main theorems
(c) to solve simple problems like the calculation of definite integrals, summation of series, Fourier transforms of integrable functions and distributions, the calculations of fundamental solutions of the main linear differential operators used in physics.

data.name: Data mining

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: This is a graduate level course on Data Mining. Data Mining is the science studying mathematical models, computational paradigms, algorithms and methodologies that look for patterns and regularities in large amounts of raw data. The aim is to allow us to understand natural phenomena, business operations and human behaviors, in ways that it will allow us to turn this knowledge into predictions, forecasting and performance improvements. The goal of the course is to introduce the students to the basic concepts, principles and techniques of Data Mining, to help them develop the required skills for using the state of the art data mining algorithms for solving practical problems, and to provide them with the required experience that will later allow them to operate independently, efficiently and effectively, in highly competitive markets. The course aims also to support students wishing to pursue a research carrier by teaching them the methodologies in performing independent and effective studies and research activities. The goals of the course will be achieved by teaching the students the strengths and limitations of the various data mining techniques, how they can be applied, under what conditions and what they should expect from each application. At the end of the course, the students will be finding themselves familiar with the most popular data mining concepts and will be able to identify and use the right solutions for any data analysis problem they may find themselves into. Last but not least, future data scientists will also learn how to perform the right experiments, how to interpret the results correctly and how to present them in the most effective way.

data.name: Service Design and Engineering

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The course focuses on current methodologies, languages and tools to support the "service-oriented" approach to programming and business process management, based on the idea of composing applications by discovering and invoking network-available services rather than building new applications to accomplish some task. In this approach, services are self-contained processes - deployed over standard middleware platforms, e.g., J2EE, Heroku, Docker... - that can be described, published, located, and invoked over a network.

Learning objectives

Knowledge and comprehension:

LO1 Identify and master appropriate software technologies, architectures and systems related to service oriented computing

Analysis:

LO2: Analyze the user and organizational needs for services and their decomposition

LO3: Analyze different service-oriented computing approaches and open standards

Application and skills:

LO4: Model, design and integrate software intensive service applications and information systems

LO5: Apply Conceive-Design-Implement-Operate methodologies to develop software solutions to complex value-added service process and systems challenges

Synthesis and Evaluation:

LO6: Propose novel and innovative services supporting sustainable business processes.

data.name: Cyber Security Risk Assessment
data.description:
Course's Objectives Most CS professionals will actually use, buy, or sell security technology and make security decisions. They don't design protocols, nor crypto algorithms, they decide which security technology they are going to use. The course provides the fundamentals to chose the appropriate security technology based on balancing threat and controls, costs, impact and likelihood of events. In other words the course will teach students to manage risk. The course will introduce students to the key principles of Security Risk Assessment (Risk and Threat Analysis, Risk Assessment, Control Frameworks) both qualitatively and quantitatively. The student will identify threats and the corresponding security controls appropriate for two industrial case studies. Intended Learning Outcomes Regular and active participation in the teaching activities offered by the course (lectures, laboratories and group work) and in independent study and project activities will enable students to:
  • understand the fundamentals of risk management;
  • identify the relevant assets and the corresponding impacts of possible threats for a moderately complex case study;
  • mitigate threats with control according to the risk appetite of a relevant stakeholder;
  • quantitatively estimate, for the particular case of cyber threats, the technical impact of vulnerabilities and the particular impact on their presence in a company's enviroment;
  • quantitatively estimate the overall risk for a large scale network.
In terms of soft skills, active participation in the group-based teaching activities will enable students to learn how to organize group work, apply problem-solving techniques, deliver a presentation, and support their results with compelling arguments. At the end students who successfully passed the course should be able to prepare and defend a cyber risk assessment, identifying the threats and the security controls and the residual risk for an industrial case study of moderate complexity.
