data.name: Conflict, Human Rights and Natural Resources
data.description:
The course aims at providing the students with a general understanding of the functioning of both the legal framework and the main institutions of the international system of human rights protection and conflict management. More specifically, it aims at illustrating the interrelation between human rights and natural resources under international law, with reference to the problem of resource conflicts. Students will be trained to assess the relevance of legal arguments in the qualification of the relationship between human activities and the environment, with reference to access to natural resources by individuals and groups.

The learning objectives of the course can be summarized as follows:


- Understanding the logic and the value added of legal reasoning in the field of human rights protection and conflict management;

- Understanding the functioning of methods of dispute settlement and the role of international organizations;

- Understanding the functioning of the international supervisory system for human rights protection;

- Understanding the role of human rights protection with respect to non-state actors, such as minorities, indigenous peoples, and transnational corporations;

- Assessing the possible linkage between natural resources and armed conflicts;

- Exposing both the contradictions and the complementarity of the legal regimes regulating human rights and access to natural resources.

On completing the course, students will be able to:

- read and understand judicial decisions and opinions dealing with international human rights law and the other topics dealt with in class;

- critically assess the interaction between international norms protecting the environment, norms regulating conflicts, and norms regulating access

to natural resources;

- take position on specific cases related to human rights, conflict management and the settlement of disputes on natural resources qualifying them in the light of international norms.

data.name: Diritto dell'economia

The course aims to enable students' understanding of the fundamental coordinates which the regulatory architecture relating to the exercise of economic activities is built on. The course deals with both the fundamental public law institutes (constitutional principles and European law; paradigm of the regulatory State; instruments of public intervention in the economy; principle of competition; regulation of services of general economic interest and other regulated sectors) and private law rules of market relationships.


At the end of the course, the student will be able to recognize the essential elements of the current legal framework regarding the regulation of economic activities and market structures, including the general institutes of the enterprise and commercial contracts law, as well as the relevant remedies.

data.name: Ecologia applicata

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description: Aim of the course is to explore Applied Ecology, the branch of Ecology that uses the principles and the concepts of Base ecology to predict and manage the environmental changes caused by human impact on natural ecosystems. Applied Ecology includes natural resource conservation, natural flora and fauna management, water resource management, pest management, pollution and ecotoxycology, natural landscape change, climate change and global warming. Applied ecology and biodiversity study are profoundly intertwined, both in the monitoring phases and in the management choices. The recent and far past clearly shows that technical and engineering choices cannot ignore environmental and ecological sustainability, to avoid the repetition of dramatic disasters like desertification of vast areas, river rectification, Vajont, Stava, Lambro and Danube poisoning, radioactive poisoning in north and south Germany, Tchernobyl and Fukushima, plastic and micro-plastic sea and soil pollution. All these disasters will result in huge costs in environmental, economical terms and they will often directly affect local population health condition. The major causes of the current important economic crisis are due to an environmental crisis that lead to a lack of resources exacerbated by human induced Climate change. This picture was generated by overexploitation and inefficiency in the use of natural resources, caused by the underestimation of the consequences of environmental problems to ecosystem services in an holistic vision. The course will deal with the environments in temperate and boreal climates and with the tropical and subtropical regions. The course will deal with theoretical fundamental elements and practical examples to understand Applied Ecology, giving hints about future developments of this science. Among the topics treated in the course: Ecocertification, biomonitoring, Biosensors, GIS, dynamic landscape modeling, definition of criteria for protected areas planning and management. Species distribution models and prediction of future landscape change with Markov Chains and Cellular automata will be treated. Seminars held by experts and visits to Applied Ecology offices will be organized. The students shall be able to apply Applied Ecology knowledge to understand the consequences of anthropic disturbance on environment and ecosystems. They shall be able to know monitoring field and modeling tools that can help the management of applied ecology. The students will be requested to write an original research paper treating and analyzing a specific topic in a critical perspective.

The aim of CopyrightX: Trento is to enable participation of five (5) students in the course (http://copyx.org/) affiliated to Harvard Law School (HLS) and the Berkman Klein Center for Internet and Society at Harvard University.

At the end of the course, students will:

- know the main features of US copyright law and be able to compare them with those featuring European and Italian copyright/author’s rights law, applying a sound comparative methodology;

data.description: The course focuses on the main contemporary sociological approaches to the study of social stratification and social mobility and the related empirical analyses. Hence, the most important types of scales of social stratification and class schemes used to represent the structure of inequality characterising contemporary societies will be presented and discussed. Then attention will be paid to the processes of social mobility, the factors influencing them and their variations over time and across countries. At the end of the course, students are expected to be able: i) to analyse the data of mobility table through log-linear and logit models; and ii) to interpret the results emerging of the analyses.
data.degreeProgram: Sociology and social research - Sociologia e ricerca sociale (LM)

data.name: Trasduzione del segnale

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description: Description and objectives of the course: How cells communicate and what are the signaling molecules and the mechanisms responsible to transduce these signals? How cells respond to the environment cues, nutrients, growth factors, and soluble circulating factors? The aim of the course is to describe the most relevant signaling pathways that control cell-cell communication and drive cell to growth, differentiate their specification and death. These networks of signals are responsible for normal physiological organogenesis and animal growth, however when uncontrolled they may result in tumor growth. This course will cover the basic concepts of signal transduction, describe the most relevant signaling pathways and their function to control physiological conditions important for development and animal growth and in pathological situations. Goals: The primary goals of this course are: 1) for students to understand what signal transduction means and what are the basis of its biological principles; 2) to appreciate and understand how to decode the huge diversity of the existing signaling mechanisms (ligand-receptor phosphorylation, cell-adhesion, post-translational modifications, second messengers signals, adaptors molecules, etc) (this part -is sustained also by 20 hrs of laboratory); 3) to learn how study signal transduction and to compare signaling in human health and in diseases; 4) to be able to understand, read and be critical on signal transduction literature. Formative aims and learning outcome: Understanding the molecular mechanism that control cell communication is at the basis not only to animal physiology but also to medical situations. Students will be exposed and stimulated to discuss topics from molecular signaling, signal transduction and molecular medicine, proteomics, structural analysis and genomic approaches. The learning outcome will bee: 1) to understand the concepts of cell-cell communication; 2) to analyze and discuss the molecular mechanisms involved in signal transduction understand the complexity of the interactions between signaling pathways within cells and how to analyze and apply their to apply their knowledge to their own research; 3) understand signaling in normal and pathological conditions and their applications to novel models that studies organ growth and tumorigenesis, i.e. tissues regeneration and the use of organoids to study signaling pathways.

data.name: Medicina personalizzata: nuove frontiere nelle terapie a DNA e RNA
data.description:
at the end of this course students will be able to:



  • List possible DNA- and RNA-based therapies.
  • Describe the problem with the delivery of RNA Therapeutics.
  • Describe how DNA and RNA therapies are approved.
  • Describe the CRISPR/Cas9 system and its possible uses.
  • List DNA vectors for gene therapy.
  • Give examples of approved gene therapies.
  • Explain the mechanism of RNA interference and list its possible applications and limitations
  • Describe therapeutical approaches based on RNA interference and bring examples of approved drugs.
  • Describe Antisense OligoNucleotides (AONs) and their application in the correction of RNA splicing (exon skipping and exon inclusion) and bring examples of approved drugs.
  • Describe Antisense OligoNucleotides (AONs) and their application in the degradation of target RNAs via RNAseH.
  • Explain how non-coding RNAs and circular RNAs can be used in therapy and diagnostics.
  • Explain how do mRNA vaccines work
  • Describe how ribozymes, aptamers, microRNAs and their inhibitors can be used in therapy.

data.name: Diritto della regolazione
Programming

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description:
Computer processing is a key component of modern data analysis pipelines, and plays an increasingly important role in many fields of science. The goal of the course is to introduce the Python programming language, one of the most widely used scientific computing languages, and related technologies.


At the end of this course, the students should be able to:

A) Remember the syntax and semantics of the Python language;

B) Understand programs written by others individuals;

C) Analyze a simple data analysis task and reformulate it as a programming problem;

D) Evaluate which features of the language (and related scientific libraries) can be used to solve the task;

E) Construct a Python program that appropriately solves the task;

F) Evaluate the results of the program.

data.name: Psicologia sociale
Mobile and satellite communications

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The course presents the fundamental principles of antennas and phased arrays in electromagnetic engineering, introduces the main figures of merit for characterizing complex radiating devices, and illustrates basic and advanced antenna analysis and synthesis methods for mobile and satellite applications, with main emphasis to communication scenarios. To this end, the course features theoretical, methodological, and practical aspects, and it introduces the most challenging applicative problems in these frameworks.
The course consists in lectures and software/hardware emulator exercitations. Additional seminars given by relevant experts from other Universities, Agencies, and Companies will be advertised during the course.

data.name: Criminal Law
data.degreeProgram: Comparative, European and International Legal Studies (L2)

data.name: Ultracold Atoms
data.description:
The main goal of this course is to introduce some of the recent research lines in the field of ultracold atoms, including the most applied ones such as atom-based sensors, the ones that investigate fundamental physical problems and those in which highly controllable superfluids are used as quantum simulators of other complex systems.
Students will acquire the basic tools and competences to be able to read and understand scientific papers dealing with these topics and in general with the physics of quantum gases and liquids.
The lectures will be given by an experimentalist (Dr. Lamporesi - 30 hours) and by a theoretician (Dr. Recati - 18 hours) in order to provide a broad and more complete point of view on the phenomena that are observable in experiments with atoms and gases at extremely low temperatures.
At the end of the series of lectures, students are expected to have a broad knowledge on many  topics that are currently studied worldwide using ultracold atoms and quantum gases. 
A good level of comprehension and discussion on scientific papers dealing with such themes is expected.

Storia medievale I

Analisi delle politiche pubbliche

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
The course aims at acquiring and applying competences on policy design. It addresses the main issues around agenda setting, advocacy, formulation, implementation, evaluation and policy change. 
By the end of the course students will be able to:
critically analyse policy-making processes, actors and dynamics;
compare and evaluate pro and contra of policy tools
formulate alternative policy designs
know main methods for the evaluation of public policies

data.name: Neuroscience of meditation and altered states of consciousness

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description: The course aims to introduce students to the understanding of mental processes and the nervous system (central and peripheral) associated with meditative practices and altered (non-ordinary) states of consciousness. The topics covered concern the neurological (brain circuits and activities, neurotransmitters, neurophysiology), phenomenological (quality of subjective experience) and cultural components of non-ordinary states of consciousness, and also their applications (existing or potential) in personal development, in clinical settings and organizational contexts (schools, companies).

data.name: Management dei servizi e della consulenza
data.description: The course provides in the first part the specific hard skills and in the second part the main soft skills for the management and marketing of professional firms

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.name: Law and Religion
data.description: This course aims at - examining the contemporary trends in the legal regulation of religion, from the perspective of both State law and religious law; - assessing the problems posed by contemporary multireligious and multicultural societies; - comparing and contrasting the legal norms, policies and strategies envisaged by states to solve tensions, identifying those that are consistent with the requirements of contemporary democracies; - promoting an approach going beyond the mere transmission of factual knowledge, and encouraging a critical attitude. Upon completion of the course, students are expected to achieve the following learning outcomes: - knowledge of the basic notions concerning the legal regulation of religion in contemporary societies; - ability to compare and contrast the variety of solutions offered to the same problem; - engagement in autonomous judgment and development of a critical attitude as regards the issues examined throughout the course; - ability to express the basic notions of the course as well as their own point of view in a methodologically correct way, by supporting their arguments with reference to the relevant legal norms, and by using the appropriate legal terminology.
data.degreeProgram: Comparative, European and International Legal Studies (L2)

Independently research, organize and write a clear, concise and cohesive academic text relating to economics, respecting academic conventions.

data.name: Gestione integrata delle risorse idriche

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
The course aims to provide the students with techniques and mathematical tools used in the planning, design and management of water resources in the context of increasing anthropogenic pressure and climate change. The course will focus its attention on the hydraulic infrastructures present in river networks and on water supply systems.

At the end of the course the students will be able to: i) quantify the availability of water resources in river networks and aquifers, and ii) address and manage the problems related to the multiple and sustainable use of water resources. Furthermore, the student will learn techniques and methodologies for designing hydraulic works used in the integrated management of water resources.

Through the learning of design thinking techniques and methods, and professional tools, students will learn to operate autonomously by addressing design problems of various kinds.

data.name: Lingua spagnola II - LM
data.description:
Students will know values and regulation about UNESCO and the defense fo the World Heritage, both Cultural and Natual, with special regard to spanish-speaking countries. Students will be able to analyse different web sites, database, statistics in order to present the value and the touristic impact on those countries.

Students will be asked to present in Spanish the sites of UNESCO World Heritage.

data.name: Fundamentals of mechanics and biomechanics
data.description:
The course aims to recall the fundamental concepts of applied and solids mechanics and apply them to the classical problems of biomechanics. The focus is on the human body, simple descriptive models will be presented to study the human ‘machine’. The analysis ranges from the kinematic and dynamic description of movement to the evaluation of the mechanical properties of tissues, and finally to the appropriate choice of materials and design methods for specific applications in occupational, clinic and sport biomechanics. In addition, attention is paid to the construction of analysis models, systems for experimental study of motor acts, and related signal analysis

At the end of the course the student should have acquired the competences and the ability to interact with specialists working in the field of bio-mechanics and biomedical engineering, contributing to the definition of the experiments and to the design of instruments and equipment.
data.degreeProgram: Materials and production Engineering - Ingegneria dei materiali e della produzione (LM)

data.name: Conservazione, recupero e ristrutturazione degli edifici

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
Design for restoration involves several disciplines and requires historical, critical, urban planning, environmental, socio-economic, technical and building skills. The aim of the course is to provide the basic knowledge and principal technical and operational tools to contribute to a conservation, valorisation and reutilisation project where attention is focussed on the materials and construction characteristics of an existing building.
At the end of the course, students will have acquired the basic practical and theoretical tools inherent in restoration of the built heritage and will be able to formulate cultural, technical and economic assessments on the efficacy of the technical solutions and perform restoration of a building.

data.name: Emozionare con la scienza
data.description: The course is designed for those who want to learn how to communicate science through the techniques of storytelling. The primary objective is to find the keys so that the narration of science can excite and consequently can create a bond of trust with the audience. The theoretical knowledge will be related to the construction of a story with all its basic elements, while the practical part will be related to the public performance of the scripts that will be written by the students. At the end of the course, the students will be able to face an audience by communicating scientific issues in an informed and engaging way.

data.name: Psicologia generale
data.description:
The aims of the course are the followings:

a) to provide students the basic principles of Psychology, in order to allow them to follow and understand also more advanced courses. To this aim students will be introduced to Psychology intended as a scientific discipline, and to some basic notions of Neurosciences. The will also be introduced to the study of the basis cognitive functions, such as memory, learning, and their relations with emotions.

b) students will be provided basic intellectual tools to develop their own critical view on the different theories, emphasising both the strengths and weakness of such theories. Students will be introduced to the scientific method, intended as a systematic approach common to all the scientific disciplines

data.name: Energie rinnovabili

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description: The aim of the course consists in providing the engineering skills required in the design of energy plants and systems including renewable energies as a primary source. In particular, the methodologies currently utilized for the design of solar thermal systems and solar cooling, photovoltaic systems, heat pumps with particular regard to geothermal plants and the technologies used for the thermal exploitation of biomass will be proposed and investigated. The expected result of the course consists in providing to the student a basic background to be able to analyse the engineering problems pertaining to the design and integration of the proposed renewable energies technologies with traditional ones, also including an economic analysis for the evaluation of the main parameters inherent the profitability of the proposed energy systems.

The course aims at providing the students with basic knowledge of Old English.
At the end of the course the students will be able:

a) to read texts in Old  English with the aid of a dictionary
b) to analyze texts in Old English 
c) to recognize the relationship between the texts and the historical context in which they were produced.

data.name: Innovation Management
data.description: The course will supply the students with the tools needed to understand core competencies and learning processes in different organizations. These tools will enable the students to manage product development processes, services development processes and product-service systems. Moreover, the course will propose a critical view of the innovation processes.

data.name: Matematica finanziaria
data.description:
Course Objectives and Expected Learning Outcomes
The aim of the course is to introduce quantitative models and methods used to evaluate financial instruments, yields structure, and fair prices of fixed income securities.
Reference is made to risk management investment models (financial immunization),  followed by fundamental concepts on financial derivatives (if time permits).
At the end of the course the student will be able to carry out basic evaluations of financial instruments, compare the bond market prices, and to deal with choice problems in finance .
The course intends to stimulate the financial awareness and critical analysis skills required in an employee in the financial sector.

data.name: Stochastic processes (I modulo)
data.description:
The course aims to provide the main concepts and results of probability theory that find applications in coding  and cryptography. It is essentially divided into two parts. The first part introduces the theory of discrete-state stochastic processes and their main applications. The second part provides basic elements of information theory, introducing the concept of entropy and illustrating Shannon's theorems.
 
At the end of the course the student will know some topics of probability theory and stochastic processes with discrete states, as well as some elements of information theory as specified by the course program. He will also be able to understand the mathematical modeling in terms of suitable stochastic processes of a large class of random phenomena.
The student will also be able to reason inductively and deductively in the solution of problems involving random phenomena. He will also be able to schematize a random phenomenon in rigorous terms, to develop logical arguments and produce correct proofs, as well as to explain them clearly.
The student must also be able to acquire and manage new information regarding random models.

data.name: Fisica tecnica

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.name: Museologia
data.description:
The course aims to


  • broaden students' knowledge about museums, particularly from an international point of view;
  • make students aware that the issue of restitution has been neglected by museums in Italy, as well as in Spain and Portugal;
  • confront students with a number of debated cases which will help them develop a critical approach;
  • urge students to take a stand about crucial questions such as the nature of cultural property (who owns cultural goods really?) and the true mission of museum in the multicultural and global society we live in.

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.name: Nonverbal behavior and interaction

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description:
Nonverbal behavior such as facial expressions, body movements, gaze, and touch gestures communicate interpersonal attitudes, social relations, affective states, and personality traits to the interaction partners (humans or artificial agents). During the course, students will learn basic concepts of social psychology and psychology of emotions, and how these concepts can be modeled with the AI techniques (e.g., machine/deep learning). Examples of such models are: automatic recognition/classification of humans’ internal states by processing the data of their nonverbal behavior (e.g., videos), or synthesis of nonverbal behavior by artificial agents (e.g., virtual characters) interacting with a human partner. In this context, the data may consist of video recordings (e.g., facial expressions) but it can also be provided with other sensors and devices such as RGB-D cameras, microphones, accelerometers, and so on. The basic tools and devices to collect and process such data, as well as, to build simple computational models will be introduced during the course.


Upon completion of this course students will be able to:

  • apply basic psychological theories of emotions, social relations, attitudes to design computational models of nonverbal behavior,
  • design data collection protocols, choose appropriate techniques and technologies to collect human nonverbal behavior data,
  • collect the nonverbal behavior data in single-person and interactive scenarios,
  • process such data, i.e., perform manual annotation as well as apply basic methods of automatic feature extraction,
  • create simple computational models, e.g., for classification of internal states using machine learning techniques.

data.name: Sviluppo neurocognitivo tipico e atipico

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description: The general aim of the course is to provide a critical update of the state-of-the-art on a number of central topics in cognitive development.  The main aim is to give students an in-depth knowledge of some remarkable progresses that have been achieved thanks to the experimental research on both typically and atypically developing children. The course is concerned with the whole life-span, but the focus will be primarily on cognitive development in infants and young children. The student is expected to acquire the capacity to discuss the fundamental concepts and propositions of several theories on motor, perceptual, conceptual and linguistic development. The student is also expected to exercise the ability to compare critically specific theoretical propositions and the results of relevant experimental works.  Finally we will emphasize the possible educational and clinical implications of recent empirical results.

data.name: Architettura tecnica

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
Building Technology is a course of building design that aims to explore the technical and constructive aspects of a building. The main constructive principles, which constitute the basis of the building project, are defined in order to achieve a synthesis between the design concept, the construction process and the interpretation of the building itself from a technical perspective. The building is presented as a sum of elements with specific roles in relation to static principles, to the definition of the living spaces as well as of suitable indoor comfort conditions.
After the course, the student will be able to: design a project of a simple building with particular reference to the shape and materials of components and sub-components; define the correlation between the building parts in order to guarantee static safety and environmental comfort; use appropriate tools and methods to make  informed and intelligent choices in the building design process.

data.name: Inquinanti emergenti e strategie di risanamento

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
Aim of the course is to discuss how many outputs snd negative impacts the pollution could have on natural and urban environment, and how they could be reduced through research of innovative, sustainable treatments.

The student will be able: to carry out simple Life Cycle assessment of materials; to chose procedures and select analytical devices for treating polluted environments and sites.
data.degreeProgram: Ingegneria per l'ambiente e il territorio (LM)

data.name: Electrochemistry for energy and environment
data.description:
The aim of the course is to provide the students with fundamental concepts of electrochemistry concerned with the quantitative relations among the chemical, surface, and electrical properties of systems. The students will gain knowledge about the structure of electrolyte solutions as well as the phenomena occurring at the interfaces between metallic electrodes and electrolyte solutions. The lectures are a blend between theoretical aspects (frontal lessons) and laboratory activities. The course is divided into 3 sections (Book I, Book II, Book III), each of which is divided into 4 subsections (Chapters 1-12). The total number of sections corresponds to the 12 weeks course duration, which includes classroom lectures and laboratory activity. Approximately, one classroom lecture and one lab session each week. 


The course will provide the students with hands-on laboratory experience in the field of electrochemistry, specifically within the context of energy and environment-related applications. The expected outcomes are:

- Solidify the students’ theoretical knowledge of electrochemistry;

- apply these concepts in the context of energy and environment-related applications;

- get the students acquainted with different electrochemical techniques

- get the students acquainted with application-relevant materials and preparation methods.

data.name: Sociologia dell'ambiente

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
The course aims to achieve the following educational objectives:
-Introduce students to the key issues dealt with by environmental sociology
- Introduce students to the main sociological theories and conceptual tools developed to analyze the relationship between society and the environment
-Analyze the main current environmental issues, such as environmental risks, environmental conflicts and the energy transition.
Upon completion of this course, students will acquire:
- Analytical skills using the main theoretical paradigms developed by environmental sociology;
- Knowledge of key issues in the field of environmental sociology
-The ability to critically discuss environmental issues using relevant sociological literature

Furthermore, the active participation to the course will enable students to:
-develop dialectical skills;
-develop analytical skills through the presentation of theoretical and empirical topics
- improve the bibliographic research capacity through the library and internet tools available;

data.name: Software engineering

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
General Aspects


Regarding the aspect of "Knowledge and understanding" the student will be able to:




  • know the fundamentals, techniques and methods of design, customization and implementation of software to support the automation of new generation information systems for industrial production and business;

Regarding the aspected of " Applying knowledge and understanding" the student will be able to:





  • design and perform experimental analyses of information systems in order to acquire measures related to their behavior and to evaluate experimental hypotheses in different fields of application, such as business, industrial or research;
  • define an innovative technical solution to an application problem that meets technical, functional and organizational constraints and requirements;


Regarding the aspected of "Making judgments" the student will be able:




  • to plan and re-plan a technical project activity and carry it out in accordance with defined deadlines and objectives;
  • to reconcile the objectives of the project that are in conflict, to trade-off cost, resources, time, knowledge or risk.


Regarding the aspected of "Communication skills" the student will be able:




  • to coordinate project teams and to identify activities to achieve project objective;
  • to present the contents of a scientific/technical report to an audience, including non-specialists, at a fixed time;
  •  to prepare and conduct technical presentations in English;
  • to carry out research and projects in collaborative manner;


Regarding the aspected of "Learning skills" the student will be able:



  • to keep up to date independently with developments in the most important areas of information technology;
  •  extend the knowledge acquired during the course of study by reading and understanding scientific and technical documentation in English.


Specific objectives


At the end of the class the stunded will be able to:


  • design the most suitable development process and model for the analysis and the design of the software under consideration;
  • represent by using different types of diagrams the requirements, the architecture, the interaction among components, entities and the deployment of the system;
  • define and manage the functional as well as no functional requirements of a software system by highlighting priorities and potential issues;
  • design the architecture of a software system by adopting architectural styles and principles of refinement, abstraction, modularity, functional independence, and refactoring;
  • describe requirements, the components and implement them in an agile manner, with short development cycles to ensure periodic and frequent delivery of software to users;
  • design, implement and descirbe a RESTfull compliant web service, collaborate on the code development test it, and "deploy'' the software through a continuous, automated process.

data.name: Progettazione di impianti di trattamento delle acque

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
The course is focused on conventional and advanced technologies for the treatment of civil and industrial wastewater, providing the skills for identifying the optimal treatment chain and for its design.

The exercises focus on the numerical application of the methods for the design of treatment plants for municipal and industrial wastewaters, applying both conventional and advanced processes. The exercises give the skills to: (1) analyze qualitative and quantitative data for wastewater characterization; (ii) perform the design of municipal wastewater treatment plants applying specific algorithms; (iii) apply simulation models for the dynamic simulation of the plant; (iv) combine a wastewater treatment plant with circular economy.
data.degreeProgram: Ingegneria per l'ambiente e il territorio (LM)

data.name: Diritto parlamentare e delle assemblee elettive
data.description:
In the course, we will examine the most important institutions of Parliamentary Law, in order to examine their enforcement in the law of the other assemblies, such as, in particular, the Regional Councils and the Councils of the Autonomous Provinces.
At the end of the course, the student will be able to:
- master the various normative sources of the Parliamentary Law, identifying how to overcome any antinomies among them;
- reconstruct the ways in which parliamentary decisions are taken and their transposition into legal acts.

data.name: Genetica

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description:
Students will acquire fundamental concepts of Heredity, Molecular Genetics and Population Genetics.

Specific emphasis will be placed on the mechanisms of inheritance and recombination, genome stability and on the origin, molecular nature and consequences of genetic variability and genotype/phenotype relationships.

Key methods for physical and genetic mapping and of functional genomics analyses will be covered.

During the laboratory module students will experience classical techniques used to manipulate yeast cells, including transformation, diploid selection, mutagenic PCR, and recombination-based cloning.

Data obtained will be presented and discussed in a group lab report.

data.name: Civil Societies and Contentious Politics
data.description: Students completing this course will gain knowledge of the principal definitions, theoretical reflections and debates on civil society, global civil society, and contentious politics. They will study how thinkers have linked ideas of civil society to war or conflict and the consequences of this. They will also study critiques of so-called classical, or Enlightenment-based, ideas of civil society by post-modern and post-colonial thinkers who have pointed out the detrimental effects these ideas have had. In their study of contentious politics (confrontations of different types between collective actors and authorities or power holders), students will reflect on the ways that these are embedded in broader social and political processes. They will gain knowledge of key concepts such as cycles of contention, radicalization, institutionalization and NGOization, which are useful for the empirical analysis of contentious episodes. Students will learn how text analysis can aid scholars to understand the discursive power, action choices and outcomes of contentious politics, and be able to design and conduct basic text analysis using appropriate software. They will also be able to apply the theories and concepts covered during the course to analyse episodes of contentious politics.

data.name: Managerial Decision Making
data.description:
The course has several educational objectives. The first is to introduce the student to the topic of decisions from a multidisciplinary perspective, becoming familiar with contributions developed within very different study traditions. The second is to understand the main formal, quantitative and qualitative models to support decisions, through a review of the main tools and methods for the analysis, structuring and resolution of a complex decision. The third is linked to the understanding of the human factor in decisions and how, in real choice contexts, the limits of human cognition translate into solution strategies that are only partially compatible with the indications of the normative models.
At the end of the course the student should have developed:
an awareness of the usefulness of models, stylized and simplified representations of complex situations, as interpretative tools to support decisions.
the recognition of the merits of formal models as tools for structuring the decision-making context and for identifying the optimal choice.
the ability to evaluate the effects of intuitive reasoning and the application of decision heuristics on the soundness of the final decision.
an understanding of the impact of uncertainty on decisions and of the main techniques for estimating and incorporating uncertainty in decisions.
the ability to recognize and manage the presence of multiple conflicting objectives and multiple stakeholders in a decision.
the ability to make a decision by structuring the overall decision-making process (from becoming aware of the existence of a problem, recognizing the important objectives to be achieved, identifying available alternatives, measuring the consequences and considering the possible role of uncertainty).
Overall, the student should develop a more effective approach to problem solving and decision making in both managerial and personal settings.

data.name: Mechanics and materials for engineering design
data.description:
One of the most important subjects for any student of materials engineering is the behavior of materials, mechanical components and structures under load. The way in which they react to applied forces, the resulting deflections and the stresses and strains set up in the bodies concerned are all vital considerations when designing a mechanical component such that it will not fail under predicted load during its service lifetime. All the essential elements of a treatment of these topics are contained within this course, starting with the concepts of mechanics of materials (stresses-strains, beam theory, thick cylinders, plasticity, fracture mechanics) and moving on to the examination of strength and stiffness verifications on mechanical components such as cylinders, joints, springs, shafts, bearings and mechanical transmissions.

By the end of this course students should: (1) be able to analyze the stress and strain on mechanical components and understand, identify and quantify failure modes for mechanical parts; (2) know basic machine elements used in machine design and design machine elements to withstand the loads and deformations for a given application, while considering additional specifications; (3) be able to approach a design problem successfully, taking decisions when there is not a unique answer; (4) be familiar with team-working, mathematical computing and CAD software; (5) be able to present analyses in a proper format of a written report such that a technically qualified person can follow and obtain similar findings.

data.name: Comparative neuroanatomy and evolution

data.name: Tecnologie delle macromolecole

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description:
The main objective of the course is to provide the necessary tools to study the structure, function and interaction of macromolecules in living organisms. At the end of the course, students will be able to:
1. Understand the most common and recent techniques to study macromolecules in biological contexts
2. Design experimental protocols to prepare biological samples, purify proteins, study their structure, function and interactions with other factors.
3. Plan experiments aimed at separating and identifying complex mixtures of macromolecules (e.g. proteomic analyses)
4. Analyze protein folding and misfolding by computational and laboratory techniques
5. Read and deeply understand scientific articles in the fields of biomolecular and biomedical technologies

data.name: Lab. appl.: La contabilità spiegata ai giuristi
data.description:
The aim of the teaching activity is to allow students, in the context of their legal training, to enrich the typical knowledge of a potential business lawyer by bringing them closer to the economic and financial analysis of a budget, through the reading and understanding of it.
The topics covered will be dealt according to criteria of logical-legal priority. It will therefore begin with the explanation of the traditional accounting systems and the functioning of the double entry, to come finally to the illustration of the postulates and budgetary principles continuing with the explanation of the structure and content of the statement of assets and liabilities and the Income Statement. All these topics will be explained in a practical key with review of the regulatory references that oversee the subject, examples and practical-professional way.
At the end of the course, students will be able to describe the aims and purposes of bookkeeping. Moreover, students will acquire the skills to demonstrate the operational knowledge of the main accounting systems commonly adopted with particular reference to the double entry method. Students will also assimilate the main notions for the understanding of the contents of the financial statements with particular reference to the Statements, statement of assets and liabilities and Income Statement, and to the related documents provided for by the rules of the Civil Code and national and international accounting standards.

data.description:
The course intends to deepen some of the topics covered during the course of Labor Law with the aim of developing the interpretative and argumentative skills of students as well as to acquire a method of analyzing problems related to legal regulation of employment relationships (subordinate and autonomous ) and how to manage staff.
The course will focus on three main themes:
- role and regulation of trade union organizations
- employment and social role of flexible employment contracts,
- tools for productive decentralization and effects on labor relations.

At the end of the course students will need to be able to know the discipline of the various types of flexible employment contracts, to know the role of trade unions in the use of various labor relations management institutes; they will also have to know the various tools of productive decentralization and the constraints and opportunities provided by labor law.

data.name: Gestione integrata delle risorse idriche

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
The course aims to provide the students with techniques and mathematical tools used in the planning, design and management of water resources in the context of increasing anthropogenic pressure and climate change. The course will focus its attention on the hydraulic infrastructures present in river networks and on water supply systems.

At the end of the course the students will be able to: i) quantify the availability of water resources in river networks and aquifers, and ii) address and manage the problems related to the multiple and sustainable use of water resources. Furthermore, the student will learn techniques and methodologies for designing hydraulic works used in the integrated management of water resources.
data.degreeProgram: Ingegneria per l'ambiente e il territorio (LM)

data.name: Bibliografia e biblioteconomia
data.description:
The student will acquire the fundamental knowledge and concepts of a modern vision of libraries and the disciplines that define and regulate how they work. The course starts from a survey of concrete cases inevitably connected to the current transition phase, proposes a critical and systematic discussion of the key themes concerning the characteristics, purpose, rules and regulations, and problems of libraries. It refers to the Italian scenario in particular, compared with relevant or emerging trends at an international level. It also provides essential references for concepts, models and procedures for cataloguing, retrieving and citing sources, and for library management.
By the end of the course, the student will have developed an understanding of the content, tools and languages to be more aware and independent in a library environment, cultivate personal interests and pursue future in-depth studies.

data.name: Ceramic materials engineering
data.description:
After completing this course students will be able to know, compare and select the fundamental properties and characteristics of ceramic materials for their specific applications with reference to their composition, microstructure and production technique.

More specifically, students will be able to:

- summarize, evaluate and select the proper processing technology for producing ceramic components, especially starting from powders

- summarize, evaluate and modify the behaviour and physical / rheological properties of powder systems, colloidal suspensions or pastes useful to create a ceramic component

- summarize and analyse the powders sintering/densification phenomenon and processes even in presence of specific additives

- exemplify and analyse the mechanical behaviour and the fundamental electrical properties of ceramics as function of their composition and microstructure and summarize the fundamental applications

- compare the fundamental ceramic materials used in medicine


Additional learning outcomes include some soft skills the student will acquire, at least partially (but not only), especially after completing the laboratory and bibliographic activities; these regard teamwork (collaboration and cooperation during the activity), communication (writing the lab report), flexibility, responsibility and positive attitude.

data.name: Inglese giuridico B2
data.description:
General Learning Outcomes

This is a language course, not a law content course as the Law Faculty modules are. Legal topics and concepts are used in the course as vehicles to explore legal language. 

While a selection of legal terminology in each legal topic area is presented throughout the course, mastering legal English requires more than simply improving your knowledge of specialized vocabulary. 

By the end of the course the students should have acquired a basic knowledge of the main features of legal English, aspects of specialized lexis; the importance of legal collocations and formal register, considering different degrees of formality in text types within the large genre of legal English.

The course is based on the assumption that, in order to profit from the mobility programs/exchanges available in foreign universities, the needs of the students lie predominantly in improving their speaking skills, in addition to listening and reading comprehension strategies; therefore an essential component of the course is learning to produce and deliver an effective oral presentation of a legal topic. 

Due to constraints of time, written production and in particular legal drafting is not prioritized, although there are opportunities during the course to practice formal letter-writing, such as emails of advice, replies to letters before action and letters of application/motivation, which are marked and feedback given.

Specific Learning Outcomes

This course is focused on improving your language skills at the B2 level. This course will:
Strengthen speaking skills and enable students to engage more effectively in a range of speaking situations typical of the study of law and the practice of law, such as client interviews or discussions with colleagues and fellow students;
Improve the ability to read, understand, and applying analyze a range of legal texts, such as legislation and legal correspondence;
Improve comprehension of spoken English when it is used to speak about legal topics in lectures, presentations, interviews, and discussions appropriate to B2 level; and
Improve the ability to write basic but accurate legal correspondence.

Students will also improve their abilities to:
use legal language confidently and accurately, based on the knowledge of collocations and specific lexis acquired over the course;
make appropriate choices in register, based on the knowledge acquired over the course; and
use a range of databases, online dictionaries and legal resources, including an introduction to using linguistic corpora.

data.name: Protezione idraulica dei territori montani

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
‎The primary objective of the course is to provide a qualitative and quantitative approach to the subject of hydraulic 'natural hazards' characterising mountain environments.


The course aims to provide the following knowledge:

========================================

• concepts of hazard and risk associated with natural hazards of the hydraulic type

• knowledge of the origin and dynamics of mountain natural hazards such as avalanches, torrential floods and debris flows;

• the physical-mathematical description of the phenomena underlying natural hazards (mathematical modelling) and the characteristics of the numerical tools used to simulate these hazards;

• typology and functioning of mitigation works, in relation to the different types of phenomena to which they are directed. In particular:

=> for avalanches:

> rigid support works (bridges and snow racks)

> flexible support works (snow nets)

> references to other types of works

=> For flows and torrential floods:

> storage areas

> open weirs

> gullies


• references to regulatory aspects relating to the subject.


It aims to develop the following skills:

=============================

• ability to use numerical modelling tools for avalanche phenomena, debris flows and intense torrential solid transport

• ability to interpret and assess the quality of the simulations carried out and to choose the calibration parameters appropriately;

• ability to draw up a danger map for avalanches and debris flows;

• ability to design, from a hydraulic point of view, mitigation works in relation to the different types of phenomena to which they are directed.



It is also planned to provide some seminars on civil protection issues.

data.name: Engineering properties of materials
data.description:
The course introduces the students to the description of the most important physical properties of engineering materials, with particular attention to the description of the methodological aspects to evaluate their performances. After an introduction on the possible approaches for materials selection and on the statistical methods for the evaluation of their engineering properties, the course focuses on the description and on the evaluation strategies of the most relevant physical properties, such as: mechanical, rheological, thermal and electrical properties. Moreover, the main techniques for structural, microstructural and surface analysis of the materials will be presented with emphasis on experimental setup and information available from the experiments. Some selected examples about applications in materials engineering and structure-properties relations will be discussed. After completing the course, the student will be able to:

- apply engineering and statistical approaches to select the most suitable material for a specific application

- collect, analyze and present experimental data and draw some valid conclusions out of them

- select suitable testing techniques to determine the main physical properties of engineering materials

- to model the main physical properties of engineering materials (rheological, mechanical, thermal, electrical)

- to establish the reliability and correctness of materials properties dataset available in the technical and scientific literature even in relation to the existing technical regulations (ISO and ASTM standard)

- to recognize the main aspects, the experimental information provided and the suitability of each characterization technique.

The student at the end of the course will know a series of state-of-art methodologies for the active and passive forensics analysis of multimedia data and he/she will know how to apply them to digital images in simple scenarios.

data.name: Ecoidraulica

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
At a time in which humans have significantly affected the natural environment and yet society increasingly values the many services of natural ecosystems, accounting for ecological processes in engineering design is a major contemporary challenge for environmental engineers. This is the fundamental topic in Ecohydraulics, the discipline that focuses on the consequences of fluid and sediment processes on the organisms that inhabit aquatic environments. While still a young science, Ecohydraulics already endows the engineer with an overall understanding and quantitative tools to predict how physical processes shape habitat quality and quantity, and how, in turn, they are affected by ecological dynamics. This enables the integrated analysis of different management options for natural and man-made water bodies in terms of their ecosystem consequences. At the broadest scale, this class will contribute to the students' appreciation of the tight link between the natural and the built or impacted environment, and of the importance of considering both (and “how-to”) for harmonizing environmental quality with human river uses in river management and restoration.

At the end of the course the student will be able to: i) identify the different fluvial forms and their evolutionary trajectories; ii) use the hydro-morphological quality indexes and assess the status of alteration of river ecosystems; iii) understand the relations between hydro-morphology and biotic component, the causes of alteration of river ecosystems and tools to design ecological flow regimes in altered rivers; iv) appreciate the relevance of the integration of complementary disciplines for the sustainable management of water bodies.

data.name: Finanza aziendale
data.description:
The course aims to provide students with the tools to effectively set up a company's financial decisions in order to create value for the benefit of owners and creditors.

By the end of the course, students will be able to: (1) estimate the price of a company's main financing instruments, shares and bonds; (2) calculate the cash flows of a company's investment projects and correctly apply the selection criteria; (3) estimate the cost of capital and the cost of debt of a company; (4) understand the actual choices made by companies regarding financial structure.

data.name: Circular economy for materials processing
data.description:
CEMP is a project-based introductory course to the circular economy. The goals and the learning outcomes of the course are to provide overview knowledge on circular economy for materials processing through lecturing (first part of the course) and in-depth knowledge and skills by the project work (second part of the course).

After the course the students would be able to understand:

1. Basic concepts of circular economy, knowledge on materials flow (from mining, processing, manufacturing until end-of-life recycling and re-usage), issues and drivers for changes.

2. Recognize impacts (environmental, economic and social) of the current practice of materials processing from a sustainability aspect.

3. Create new business opportunities to re-enter materials into circular economy.

4. Apply processing technologies to accelerate the implementation in business creation.

data.name: Metodi e tecniche del lavoro nei servizi sociali (corso avanzato)

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
The course aims to provide students with the knowledge and development of social work skills necessary in the function of specialist social workers and service managers, also with reference to the themes of participation, advocacy and political practice. The course is divided into two parts.

The first part of the course aims to provide the elements to critically reflect on the role of responsibility of managers/executives in social services, with particular reference to communication skills and the skills for reflective practice and learning organisation. In this context, particular attention will be given to preventing and dealing with professional and organizational errors and manifestations of aggression on the part of users, as sentinel phenomena of the presence of dysfunctions within the services.

The second part aims to provide students with a knowledge of participatory processes, activities of involvement of users and anti-oppressive practices, advocacy and political practices of social work. Students will learn the main methods and techniques through which these processes are supported, both in the role of service manager and as an operator with specific skills.

At the end of the module the student  should be able to: recall and discuss the techniques presented, reading the literature about similar techniques, preprocess and mine a specific instance of biological data, report and present the results.

data.name: Digital signal processing

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
This course provides an introduction to fundamental concepts and techniques in digital signal processing. The course starts with a detailed explanation of discrete-time signals/systems and with the analysis of discrete time linear time invariant systems. Subsequently, the discrete-time Fourier transform and the discrete Fourier transform are introduced, followed by an overview of fast algorithms for the computation of the discrete Fourier transform. Afterwards, the z-transform and its properties are introduced. Finally, the design of FIR and IIR filters is introduced. 
The Lab lectures by using MATLAB are given to provide practical knowledge in processing real signals with examples from speech and audio.

data.name: Experimental Mathematics Laboratory at School Level
data.description:
The course aims to provide the student with:

- a profound knowledge of elementary mathematics which is taught at Italian “scuola secondaria di secondo grado”, in a broad theoretical framework useful to clarify the links with the most advanced notions and the subtle problems studied in university courses;

- a definition of "good practices" and the competence to implement them to develope a methodology for the design of teaching units (relative to mathematics topics which are recurrent in secondary school curricula) and the subsequent presentation to a class in a defined context, mainly by the frontal-lesson modality.

At the end of the course, the student will be able to:

- Recognize the critical points in the informal presentations available in most math textbooks for the Italian “scuola secondaria di secondo grado”;

- Designing and implementing didactics units and paths, consistent with the "good practices" introduced in the course and applied by the student through a systematic laboratory activity based on the practice of lesson-simulation;

- Doing effective presentations (mainly by the frontal-lesson modality) of mathematics topics which are typical in the Italian “scuola secondaria di secondo grado”, through a conscious use of communicative components (gesture, language) and physical media for communication (first of all, the blackboard ).

- Adapting the content of didactic units/paths and presentations, according to the class context.

data.name: Economia delle risorse umane
data.description:
This is a course in Personnel Economics. This is an emerging field of research and human resource management in practice, where economic analysis is used to examine decisions (by individuals and management) within organisations. The main focus will be on the intuitions and descriptions of a wide range of decisions (by individuals as well as by organisations), more than on the presentation of formal economic models. Where possible, the discussion will focus on empirical evidence. The overriding goal of the course is to develop the capacity to understand, theoretically and empirically, the main decisions that take place within organisations: recruitment, selection, training, compensation, promotions, performance evaluation, and promotions.

By the end of the course, students: i) should have acquired an in-depth understanding of the main concepts and issues in personnel economics; ii) will be able to understand and explain the functioning of internal labour markets; iii) will have acquired the necessary analytical tools to analyse the decisions taken inside organisations by individuals and management.

data.description: By the end of the course, students should have acquired a comprehensive knowledge of the theoretical approaches to the study of everyday life, in their historical evolution and different streams. This will primarily be the aim of the frontal lectures. Seminars will be devoted to more empirical and substantive approaches to everyday life, as well as to current debates: from existing inquiries to a discussion of the methodologies available.

data.name: Gestione delle risorse umane

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
The goal of the course consists of highlighting the characteristics of the different organizational and human resource management systems in comparative perspective at the international level in relation to the role exerted by institutions and actors (companies, unions, workforce). Additional analyses will be devoted to small firms, given their specific characteristics, to the deployment of atypical work and to the development of lasting cooperative employment relations.


At the end of the course, students will be able to:


-Recognize the advantages and disadvantages of different organization and human resource management systems;

-Identify the relevance of institutions and actors for human resource magement in different economic sectors;

-Understand the specificities of small enterprises;

-Analyse the interactions among factors contributing to limit the deployment of atypical work;

-Develop the elements favouring the realization of long-term collaborative employment relations within organizations.

data.name: Quantum Computing
data.description: During this lecture, you will acquire the foundations of quantum information theory in order to understand the working principles of quantum computers, to reproduce and design basic algorithms, and to critically assess their possibilities and limitations. By discussing experimental platforms, you will also be able to put the state of art of hardware into context. The lecture is accompanied by practical exercises, which are carried out in the class room and which will allow you to obtain a hands-on experience with quantum computing.

data.name: Privacy and Intellectual Property Rights

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The aim of the course is to introduce the students to the basic principles of Privacy and Intellectual Property, taking into account both legal and technological issues with reference to some specific case studies.
At the end of the course the students will be able to understand the nature of the legal issues related to intellectual property rights and privacy.

data.name: Circuiti elettronici digitali

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: The objective of this course is to provide the students with the fundamental notions of electronic digital design, with particular focus to the understanding, the analysis and the design of digital circuits using MOS technology. The student learns to analyze devices and basic digitial circuits in non-linear state, and size them to reach the desired static and dynamic performance, for both combinational and sequential circuits (flip flops and memories), also using circuit simulation tools (Spice). Exercises on design problems and laboratory sessions allow the students to apply the concepts in practice, and to gain familiarity with real components and instrumentation. At the end of the course, the student will be able to comprehend the operation of combinational and sequential logic gates, to evaluate and measure their characteristics, and to design them analyzing and evaluating the effect of design decisions.
data.degreeProgram: Ingegneria Informatica, delle Comunicazioni ed Elettronica (L2)

data.name: Personalità e motivazione

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description: The course aims to provide students with the basics of the scientific investigation of personality and the motivation behind human activity. The purpose of the course is to allow the student to learn and understand the main theories of personality: from typological theories to the theories of the traits, from the psychodynamic model to the cognitive-behavioral model; to appreciate the main personality survey tools; and to deepen the understanding of the pathological traits of personality. Some lessons will be devoted to the brain and genetic bases of personality.The student will also learn the main theories of human motivation . It is expected that at the end of the course the student will acquire the knowledge of the topics dealt with and be able to understand, apply and analyze the fundamental methods of the science of personality and motivation.

Upon completion of the course, students will be able to: (1) know the main investment instruments and bond derivative securities available in the financial market, (2) appropriately use these instruments for investment and portfolio management strategies, including with Matlab software, (3) empirically analyse theoretical concepts with Matlab software.

data.description:
The learning objective is to endow students with the tools needed to understand economic problems, mechanisms and phenomena. The focus will be on the concepts of optimization, equilibrium and empirism.

Classes attendance and individual study will allow students to:

a) Undestant economic problems, mechanisms and phenomena;

b) Identify the key elements for economic analyses

c) Apply the proposed tools to understand and solve economic problems, mechanisms and phenomena

data.name: Microeconomia_
data.description: This course deals at an intermediate level with all the topics covered by a first course in microeconomics. We place particular emphasis on game theory. At the end of the course, the student will be able to tackle any advanced topic in economics, from public economics to industrial organization.

data.name: Innovazione, tecnologia e società

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description: This course explores, in a concrete way, the main guidelines concerning innovation policies and the design of activities in the technical and scientific fields. Students will be able to approach the main tools for analyzing innovation processes in the technological and scientific fields. Particular attention will be paid to the critical study of strategies for the development of responsible and innovative research according to the guidelines of the European Commission (RRI).Through the analysis of relevant cases, it will be possible to study how innovation is socially constructed and influences policies and activities design. The use of some free access computer tools will enable students to design projects using graphical display to represent data, activities, and concepts.

data.name: Introduction to Machine Learning

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
The course aims to provide a broad introduction to machine learning techniques. The course includes theoretical lessons and computer exercises in order to learn a base of algorithms for different application cases.
The course therefore provides a practical "hands-on" approach that includes all issues from data acquisition, management of the training process and the development of an inference software.
During the course, students will learn to decide the approach to follow for the solution of a machine learning project in its entirety. Students will be able to evaluate the type of machine learning method to follow (supervised, unsupervised, classification or regression, etc.), evaluating the results by hand, learning to work towards objectives.
Practical lessons will be carried out in Python using open-source libraries. The project topics will range on topics mainly related to computer vision.

data.name: Advanced Hands on fMRI Analysis
data.description: Functional Magnetic Neuroimaging (fMRI) is a popular technique to study the human brain. Since its advent, the technique and its analyses have kept moving forward thus helping to better capture the complex organization of the brain and its functions. This course will introduce the students to advanced fMRI analyses such as multivariate pattern analysis, representational similarity analysis, pattern classification algorithms, and resting-state functional connectivity, with a particular focus on providing the students with extended hands-on experience on these forefront methods. By the end of this course, students will be able to apply cutting-edge analytic techniques to neuroimaging data.

data.name: Analisi dei dati e Statistica
data.description:
The course is essentially divided into two parts. The first part aims to introduce students to the analysis of the data and to provide them with the tools necessary for the study and description of socio-economic phenomena through graphical representations and summary measures. The second part of the course is being proposed to provide to the students the basic elements of probability theory and statistical inference as a set of theories, methods and quantitative analysis techniques directed to the study of phenomena that evolve stochastically over time and/or in the space.
At the end of the course the students will be able to address and propose solutions to simple problems of economic nature on the basis of the information contained in the available data and duly summarized through appropriate statistical analysis techniques.
For each of the proposed topics will be shown applications on real data with Excel.

data.name: Biologia dell'RNA

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description: The aim of the course is to make the students aware of the importance and centrality of RNA as a key player in gene expression, and of new insights into RNA structure and function which have revolutionised our view of molecular biology, several times in the recent years. A constant focus of the course is that RNA molecules have a range of biological functions beyond that of the messenger RNA, including roles as catalysts and regulatory molecules. In particular, at the end of this course students will be able to: -List and describe RNA’s different functions - List and describe differences between DNA and RNA. - Name and draw common secondary structure motifs found within RNA molecules. - Use tools for bioinformatic prediction of RNA secondary and tertiary structure. - Explain experimental methods for the study of RNA secondary and tertiary structure. - Draw non-canonical base pairs found in RNA. List modified bases found in RNA. Explain the bonds that keep together RNA tertiary structures. Name and describe common tertiary structure motifs in RNA. -Explain in vitro transcription. - Describe a SELEX experiment. - Explain what a riboswitch is and name its parts. - Explain riboswitches’ different mechanisms of action in Prokarya and Eukarya. - Describe the properties of RNA which enable its catalytic function. - Differentiate large and small ribozymes on the basis of the reaction they perform. - Name and describe different small ribozymes, their structure and where they have been found. - Name and describe different small ribozymes, their structure and their function. - Explain the functions of RNA-binding proteins in cellular processes. - Name and describe different RNA-binding domains, their structure and mode of binding to RNA, and give examples of proteins in which they have been found. Explain different experimental approaches to the study of RNA-binding proteins and their interaction to RNA. List different types of short non-coding RNAs and explain their differences - Describe how was RNA interference discovered. - Explain the mechanism of RNA interference and discuss the experiments which demonstrated the main steps of this mechanism. - Describe the main proteins involved in RNA interference. - List the possible applications and limitations of RNA interference - Explain different ways to elicit RNA interference in living organisms - Design effective siRNAs - Describe the discovery of microRNAs. -Explain microRNAs’ biogenesis pathway. - Describe different types of RNA Therapeutics. - List different RNA editing processes and explain their mechanism and function. - Describe the structure and function of ADARs (Adenosine Deaminases RNA-dependent). - List different types of long non-coding RNAs. - Explain how long non-coding RNAs can regulate gene expression at the epigenetic and transcriptional level, and bring examples. Productively se software for circular RNA discovery, for primers' design and to identify miRNA/RBP binding sites on circular RNAs. Successfully perform RNA extraction from cells, quality and quantity control of RNA, Reverse Transcription and quantitative PCR.

data.name: Psicologia dello sviluppo

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description: The main aim of this course is to provide the student with the foundational knowledge necessary to reflect in a critical and competent way on the phases, processes and causes of mental development and on the methods employed to study it. Our focus will be both on core theoretical issues and on empirical studies on the development of perceptual processes and mental representations, inductive reasoning and early knowledge in some core domains such as physics, biology, language, emotions and the social world. The problems of the acquisition of mental capacities will be tackled by presenting the classical developmental theories and the most recent models and theoretical perspectives, and by discussing several experimental studies and the research methods employed in the field.
