The final goal is to bring about in the students a critical understanding of the main developmental theories. We expect that by the end of the course students will also know several recent progresses in the main areas of developmental psychology and will be able to link critically the problems tackled in developmental psychology with core issues in the study of cognitive architecture.
data.degreeProgram: Scienze e Tecniche di Psicologia Cognitiva (L2)

data.name: Lab. appl.: Saper parlare: esercizi (a teatro) per potenziare la capacità di comunicare in pubblico
data.description:
Discovering and developing the communication potential of body and voice to make a

performance (lecture, exam, conference, interview, meeting etc.) more brilliant and effective.


Comprehending the nature of language and speech acts.

data.name: Lingue e letterature anglo-americane
data.description:
Angloamerican Language and Literatures (6 credits in the third year) offers a further study of US language and literature particularly useful for those students who intend to write their "prova finale" on topics in American Studies and for those who plan to enroll in the magistrale with a specialization in American Studies.

The course invites to study US literary and cultural history, by taking into consideration three keywords ("nature," "wilderness," "land"). It aims to the improvement of academic language competence through oral presentations and the writing of a short research paper. It offers the main critical and methodological skills for interpreting literary texts and placing them in their historical and socio-political contexts.

data.name: Metodi di indagine in psicologia clinica

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description: The aim of this course is to provide general and applying knowledge about the three principal assessment methods in clinical psychology: test, interview and observation. Students will be able to acquire a general knowledge of the structure, functions and psychometric properties of the principal intelligence and personality tests. Moreover, they will be able to apply this knowledge to the consultation of tests’ manuals and to the choice of the appropriate tests for different testing situations. Students will be able to acquire a general knowledge of the features and techniques of psychological interviews, and to understand how these features and techniques apply to the different aims and contexts (i. e., assessment, therapy, research). Also, students will be able to develop and analyze interviews of different kind at a basic level. Students will acquire a general knowledge of the basic principles that allow to consider observation as a scientific method and they will learn to apply simple observational coding systems of individual and social behaviors. Finally, working on observation and interview techniques, students will reinforce their communicative skills including awareness of own and other communicative skills and empathic listening.

data.name: Progettazione di sistemi integrati per il recupero di materia da rifiuti urbani

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
The module gives criteria useful for a correct design of waste treatment plants, in particular municipal solid waste.

A correct design must be based also on the knowledge of waste collection before treatment. For this reason collection and transport of waste are topics included in the module. At the end of the lessons the student will be able to participate to a design team for plants in the sector in EU-like contexts (for material recovery)
data.degreeProgram: Ingegneria per l'ambiente e il territorio (LM)

data.name: Algorithms for Bioinformatics

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
Goal of the course is to provide the student with notions about the main algorithms used in bioinformatics and skills for their implementation.
At the end of the module the student should be able to:  recall and discuss the algorithms presented, reading the literature about an algorithm in the same class and implement it.

data.name: Low-power wireless networking for the Internet of Things

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The vision fostered by the Internet of Things (IoT) rests on the ability to establish untethered and opportunistic communication among devices deployed in the environment or attached to people or other moving entities. Therefore, low-power wireless communication technologies, which remove altogether the need for wires, are a key enabler of IoT. The last few years witnessed a surge of these technologies, striking different tradeoffs in terms of range, data rate, power consumption as well as additional capabilities like distance
estimation. These technologies enable a plethora of applications, e.g., monitoring and control of physical phenomena (wireless sensor networks) or smart environments where users are automatically localized and able to
opportunistically interact with objects.

The course aims at providing students with a first-hand introduction to this exciting field; this is achieved through a synergy of theory and practice.

Traditional classroom lectures will concisely present the salient aspects of several low-power wireless technologies, with an emphasis on wireless sensor networks (a key enabler of many IoT scenarios) and focusing primarily on the networking stack. Instead, laboratory sessions will be the opportunity for students to experiment "hands-on" with some of the technologies illustrated in the lectures, and understand their peculiarity.

By the end of the course, students are expected to have obtained a broad understanding of the key challenges in low-power wireless networking for the IoT, of the state-of-the-art solutions and associated trade-offs, as well as to have acquired the ability to autonomously design relatively simple IoT system components and applications on popular hw/sw platforms.

data.name: Diritto delle reti di imprese integrato
Storia della musica III
data.description: Introduction to a deep musical knowledge, with special attention to language, form and style of twentieth-century music in relation to social, cultural and historical context.

data.name: Networking

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: The course goal is to discuss the main concepts related to computer networks using a top-down approach (from the application downto the physical layer). At the end of the course, the student will know the TCP/IP protocol stack used in the Internet and the main protocols, and will know how to analyze network traffic and understand the behavior of a LAN and of the Internet.
data.degreeProgram: Ingegneria Informatica, delle Comunicazioni ed Elettronica (L2)

data.name: Psicologia del ciclo di vita

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.name: Current debates in cognitive neuroscience

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description:
This course aims to train students not only to the knowledge of important and fundamental debates that currently animate the research in cognitive neuroscience, but also, and above all, to stimulate and improve their critical thinking. The sudents will be active during the courses in that they will have to animate most courses in the first person, along with his colleagues: for each topic students will gather in groups where they will:
1) understand the terms of the problem and the theoretical and practical challenges it involved
2) synthesize one of the dominant theoretical positions, and expose it to his colleagues
3) actively reflect in groups to identify, in a free and creative way, possible research directions to solve the open questions.
data.degreeProgram: Scienze e Tecniche di Psicologia Cognitiva (L2)

data.name: Prova di conoscenza linguistica L.M. - Inglese in ambito economico
data.description:
On completion of the course, students will be able to:
1. understand the main facts and supporting details of a complex text on both concrete and abstract topics relevant to the sphere of economics and management, including current events.
2. interact with a degree of fluency and spontaneity in a variety of simulated contexts in the field of economics and management without strain. They will be able to speak about some specific topics related to business management, economics and relevant current events, as well as describe visual information depicting economic and business trends. They will also be able to talk about their own academic career.
3. compose a short professional business e-mail and/or report on specific issues in an appropriate style.
4. understand short conventional spoken narratives related to topics/practices common to economics and management.

data.name: Fisica e modellistica dell'atmosfera

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
The course provides an in-depth analysis of atmospheric processes relevant for various environmental engineering applications. Large space is dedicated to the modelling tools for weather forecasting, air pollution simulations and the assessment of renewable energy availability. 

At the end of the course the student should:

  • know the basics of atmospheric processes relevant for different environmental engineering applications, such as pollutant dispersion and the assessment of renewable energy resource availability
  • know the basics of meteorological and atmospheric dispersion models
  • know methodologies of data analysis and models to evaluate solar and wind energy availability
  • be able to interpret the output of meteorological models and realize simple weather forecasts
data.degreeProgram: Ingegneria per l'ambiente e il territorio (LM)

data.name: Storia del teatro e dello spettacolo II - LM
data.description: Aim of the course is the cquisition of the critical and methodological intruments for the reconstruction of the theatrical events; the evaluation of the stagings of the past through a correct interpretation of the literary and iconographical sources; the analysis of the most interesting performances through a comparative standpoint the most significant stage experiences from a comparative standpoint. At the end of the course the student will be able to understaand the proposed topis with the help of the didactic material, to put these events into their correct context, to employ the specific language appropriate to the subject
data.degreeProgram: Letterature euroamericane, traduzione e critica letteraria (LM)

data.name: Laboratory of biological data mining

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
Goal of the module is to provide the student with the notions of data mining that are necessary in order to mine genomic and transcriptomic data and the practical skills to preprocess and mine biological data.
At the end of the module the student  should be able to: recall and discuss the techniques presented, reading the literature about similar techniques, preprocess and mine a specific instance of biological data, report and present the results.

data.name: Storia della pedagogia - LM
data.description: The module aims to analyse the "copernican revolution" in pedagogy which started between the XIX and XX centuries from the new education movement in Europe and America and which was closely connected with the centrality of the person being educated. This centrality will be examined using different approaches and from various viewpoints (scientific, philosophical and religious) that characterise the movement.

data.name: Research methodology - quantitative

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description: This course provides a first introduction to some methodological aspects of carrying out research in the HCI field according to a quantitative perspective.  It covers a variety of techniques for recording and analyzing empirical data collected using human participants. Topics to be covered include the definition of measurement scales and how they impact the selection of statistical models to analyze empirical data. The course introduces also different types of behavioral research ranging from experimental design to surveys (or questionnaires). The associated statistical techniques are also presented and illustrated by using the statistical package R.

data.name: Laboratorio di analisi dei mercati
Embedded systems

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
Embedded computers are found everywhere, from home appliances to automobiles to medical devices. Designing an embedded computing system is a challenging task because the requirements include manufacturing cost, performance, power consumption, user interface, hard deadlines, and rich functionality. 
The objective is to illustrate the embedded system design process, which includes requirements, specification, architecture, components, and system integration phases. The course will be backed up by real-life design examples to illustrate the design process, and also students will be asked to design embedded systems to gain experience.

data.name: Economia e misurazione aziendale
data.description: This course aims to provide students with basic knowledge about organizations and business management, and to foster critical thinking on the role of enterprises in the contemporary economy. The course will begin with an overview of the ongoing debate on the firm’s ultimate goal from both the shareholders and the stakeholders’ views. Subsequent to a review of the core business activities, it will then provide the basic notions of accounting and performance evaluation metrics, and a detailed overview of quantitative decisions-making models, such as economies of scale, learning curves, break-even/profit points, operating leverage etc. Furthermore, it will offer an accurate presentation and discussion of models for strategic analysis, including those with a longitudinal perspective. The course will end with a thorough examination of corporate governance, inquiring into managerial interests, mis-management and potential remedies. At the end of the course, the students will be able: 1. to understand and illustrate, with competence and expertise, the debate on the nature and purpose of enterprises, as institutions aimed at resolving the tension between wealth creation and social demands; 2. to understand, use and evaluate accounting and measurement performance systems; 3. to understand and use quantitative models in support of operation and management decisions; 4. to understand and competently speak about the problem of corporate governance, with a particular focus on the role of managers and the internal/external mechanisms to align shareholders’ and managerial interests; 5. to evaluate and critically assess the functioning and strategies of enterprises in modern economies and their ability to pursue long term success, preserving the financial and institutional equilibria-

data.name: Tecnica delle costruzioni

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
• Understand the fundamentals of structural reliability;
  • Learn to calculate design loads and actions on buildings;
  • Learn the mechanical properties of construction materials;
  • Familiarize with the fundamentals of reinforced concrete design;
  • Learn to design simple reinforced concrete elements at the cross-section level.

data.name: Diritto penale corso avanzato
data.description:
The course will begin with a general introduction to the special part of criminal law (classification of offences), which will be followed by a close examination of the part dedicated to the offences against the administration of justice and against public order.

In particular, the course aims to give an overview of the Italian criminal justice system, mentioning the choices made by Italian legislators who only partly included a description of punishable behaviour in the criminal code, leaving a vast area of cases to complementary legislation. The course then moves on to focus on the internal systematics of the criminal code with emphasis on the evolution and reform of the offences.

Finally, the course turns to general questions regarding offences against the administration of justice and against public order and examines each offence, while bearing in mind the need to provide an overall context, which encourages the development of critical skills and an awareness of the historical, political and normative influences involved, with particular regard to the role of case-law in the interpretation of the norms.

data.name: Law and Data
Diritto dei trasporti
data.description: The Course aims to deepen, through a detailed analysis of the legislation and the jurisprudential debate, the study of the regulation of transport services by air, sea, road and rail with specific attention to the competition rules applying to the present matter and to the financial public support to transport services. The Course will also analyze the management of transport infrastructures (airports and ports), the related access and the services, provided in the said infrastructures, which are ancillary to the transfer of people and goods. The Course will also focus on the analysis of the contract of carriage, the regime of liability of the carrier, the shipping contract and transport documents.

data.name: Letteratura portoghese I
data.degreeProgram: Letterature euroamericane, traduzione e critica letteraria (LM)

data.name: Biomaterials and biomedical technologies
data.description:
Natural and synthetic materials have increasingly wider applications for the fabrication of devices and prostheses used to repair or substitute damaged body tissues, organs and functions. Due to the complexity of the phenomena affecting the relationships between the body and prosthetic material, and to the variety and the duration of their functions, prosthetic materials must be carefully selected and designed, following biological, physico-chemical and engineering considerations.

The course is addressed to students wishing to acquire knowledge of the use and characteristics of biomaterials, and will provide information on the design of a biomaterial or a prosthesis.
data.degreeProgram: Materials and production Engineering - Ingegneria dei materiali e della produzione (LM)

data.name: Questioni di genere nella ricerca politica e sociale

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description: The aim of the course is to present and discuss theories and methods of doing gender research in political and social science.

data.name: Finanza sostenibile e fattori ESG (Environmental, Social and Governance)
data.description:
The course aims at introducing students to the fundamental notions related to sustainability in finance, its regulation at a European and global level and existing market practices.

After an overview of this phenomenon's origins, its driving forces and its relationship with the market paradigm endorsed by the European Union Treaty («sustainable growth» under art. 3 TUE), the course in intended to analyze the economic and political rational underlying sustainable finance, also providing students with the description of the applicable regulatory framework and of the current market practices.

At the end of the course the student will have to be able to understand the core elements of sustainable finance, to orient themselves in the regulatory landscape and to understand the specific features of different sustainable financial instruments and loans.

data.name: Storia del Cristianesimo e delle Chiese II
data.description:
At the end of the course, the student will be able to:

(a) remember the main events related to the history of Christianity and Christian Churches;

(b) use an appropriate vocabulary;

(c) present, at least in general terms, a historical source related to the history of Christianity and Christian Churches, describing the characteristics and articulations of its form and content.

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science
Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.name: Analisi del linguaggio politico
data.description: By reading a number of Michel Foucault's texts, the course aims at clarifying the relationship between power, knowledge and language, and discussing the very concept of "power". At the end of the course the student will be able to: define the disciplinary field; identify and discuss core political questions and concepts; critically read and understand classical texts; identify and explain the philosophical object examined during the course; contextualize it both historically and systematically; use correct and appropriate arguments to support his or her thesis

data.name: Management delle imprese di famiglia
data.description:
EDUCATIONAL OBJECTIVES Knowledge of the events and of the situations that impact on the life of the family business. Specific reference is made to :

- stock- and stakeholdership and distribution of the property among the family members

- family and corporate governance

- generational transfer

- way out of the family from the family business.


The domain of reference is that of small and medium size family companies Knowledge of the methods and of the tools useful to manage these events and resolve the issues related to the ownership of the business by the family, with specific reference to Family Businesses.

data.name: Management dei servizi e della consulenza
data.description: The course provides in the first part the specific hard skills and in the second part the main soft skills for the management and marketing of professional firms

data.name: Statistical Field Theory
data.description:
This course provides an introduction to modern field theory as a tool to model the dynamics and thermodynamics of complex physical systems. At the end of the course, students are expected to:

1) understand the physical motivations implications of renormalisation-group based multi scale methods. Understand the path integral formalism and its advantages with respect to first-quantisation approaches in the study of complex many-body systems. 

The emphasis is given on multi-scale approaches, i.e. on the application of the renormalization group and of the effective field theory formalism to both classical and quantum systems.

2) Use field theory methods to obtain predictions for physical systems characterised by a decoupling of low- and high- energy/momentum scales.

data.name: Didattica della storia

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.name: Storia della filosofia classica tedesca
data.description:
The aim of the course is to investigate authors, questions and concepts of classical German philosophy. The objectives are: a) the lexical and conceptual analysis of significant texts of German thought between 18th and 19th century; b) the reconstruction of the historico-philosophical and systematical contexts; c) the assessment of the critical debate.


The course will provide the students with an in-depth knowledge of the topics dealt with in the lectures; students will also acquire some specific skills, allowing them a) to place the authors, the texts and the topics within the historico-philosophical context; b) to examine and interpret the texts proposed by the teacher, paying special attention to the lexicon and properly referring to the critical literature; c) to discuss the topics of the course by making proper use of argumentative discourse and of specific vocabulary.
data.degreeProgram: Letterature euroamericane, traduzione e critica letteraria (LM)

data.name: Fondamenti di elettronica digitale e azionamenti elettrici
data.description:
PART 1: ELECTRIC DRIVES (3 CFU)

After introducing the concept of electric drive and its relevance for the development of a sustainable society, the first part of the course will provide a theoretical and practical overview on the operating principles of the main electrical machines used in industrial applications. Specifically, the structure and operating principles of dc machines, permanent magnet synchronous machines and asynchronous machines will be analyzed.

Practical examples and exercises will be proposed to support the theory.

After completing the course, the student will be able to:

-  understand the operating principles and fields of operation of the main electrical machines and drives;

-  master terminology and parameters characterizing the considered electrical machines;

-  read and correctly interpret nameplate data of the considered electrical machines. 

 

PART 1: DIGITAL ELECTRONICS (6 CFU)

This part of the course covers the scientific and engineering basics of digital electronic systems and computing systems. Specifically, the course main topics are: logic networks, digital electronic circuits, and basic computer architectures.

After completing the course, the student will be able to:

-  understand the working principles of a digital electronic circuit;

-  analyse the processing algorithm performed by a combinatorial network;

-  understand the processing algorithm performed by a sequential network;

-  understand the architecture of a microprocessor-based system.

data.name: Laboratory Techniques for Mathematics Teaching
data.description:
The course is a laboratory which aim is to deal with the problem of designing a math lab for secondary school (up to the compulsory school), taking into account the framework of Mathematics Education and some aspects related to "engineering teaching ". The first part of the course will focus on experiencing with some math labs, taking apart each step and critically analyzing the various planning moments, including those related to the tools used. This provides students with the instruments to address the second part of the course, which will consist in revisiting one of the proposed laboratory, with the aim of experimenting it in a Secondary School class.
Learning goals.
1. Students will know the topics of Mathematics Education addressed in the course. They will be able to link them to the lab activities encountered in the course, identifying at what moments of designing and implementing a didactic laboratory they play an important role. Students will be able to use appropriately these aspects in planning experimentation, justifying each choice they make.
2. Students will know the topics in Mathematics addressed in the course. They will be able to identify conceptual nodes and learning goals of each lab, to link learning objectives with teaching strategies, with the sequence of proposals and with the formulation of each laboratory requests.
3. Students will be aware of which strategies facilitate communication with students and discussion among them.
4. Students will know instruments used in each laboratory. They will analyse how to use the tools and how to link them to the learning goals.
5. Students will be able to propose again a lab by identifying the appropriate tools, by designing a personal sequence of active learning activities that involve the manipulation of the chosen tools. Students will be able to plan a guided discussion that, with teacher mediation, can highlight the Mathematical meanings of the activity.
6. Students will be able to produce a written report, identifying and motivating the learning objectives of a self-planned laboratory, the elements that led the planning, the didactic methods involved.
7. Students will be able to explain the modalities and the subject of an observation, to analyze an experimentation ex post, identifying elements of success and criticality.

data.name: Storia dei sistemi economici
data.description: At the end of the course students will be able to identify the fundamental dynamics of economic transformations from the preindustrial period to the present, with special regard to the industrialization processes. Moreover, students will be able to evaluate critically the complexity of economic systems, and the numerous factors which determined their evolution.

data.name: Lingua spagnola I - LM
data.description:
The course is aimed to serve as a guide through the translation of texts specialised in touristic topics. Texts will be chosen among these originally written in Italian language and to be translated into Spanish language. Activities carried on in the course of the assistantship lessons aim to take students to a proficiency level in which they show fully linguistic competence even in complex communicative contexts.


By the end of the course students should be able to:

a) understand with ease virtually everything heard or read;

b) summarize information from different spoken and written sources, reconstructing arguments and accounts in a coherent presentation;

c) express themselves spontaneously, very fluently and precisely, differentiating finer shades of meaning even in the most complex situations.

d) develope critical metalinguistical analysis with regard to linguistic systems at the basis of Spanish and Italian languages, divergent despite its great affinity.

e) be able to communicate cultural concepts and values, often linked to a specific social group, in a language other than the student’s mother tongue.

data.name: Business Strategy in the Digital Economy
data.description:
The course is designed to help students gain the ability to understand and interpret the rationale of strategic decisions. It also provides students with the knowledge of patterns in strategy formation for start-ups with a specific focus on those in the digital economy. 

The practice and theory of making decisions is a core ability for future managers. The critical analysis of both contents and process of decision making requires mastering the basic strategic management concepts as well as understanding how innovation impacts on the ability to succeed in a fast evolving environment.

The course stems from the recall of basic strategy and innovation management concepts to move on and define what is a successful business models and how to perceive a sustainable business models innovation.
Based on case studies and active participation of students in debates, the course sets the scene to apply a business model thinking to the analysis of firms and the design of new ventures.

The course investigates platform business models and explores how platforms develop their strategies.
data.degreeProgram: Behavioural and Applied Economics - Economia Comportamentale e Applicata (LM)

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.name: Workshop: ECJ Moot Court: Participating in a Preliminary Ruling Procedure
data.description: The aim of this course is to give an overview and a practical insight into the jurisdiction of the European Court of Justice (ECJ). In the centre of this course is a moot court of a preliminary ruling procedure. The students shall be given the opportunity to re-enact a hearing of a real case and to learn how the ECJ has actually decided the case at hand
data.degreeProgram: Comparative, European and International Legal Studies (L2)

data.name: Introduction to Climate change

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.name: Advanced Academic Writing
data.description:
On completion of the course, the student will be able to:

Independently research, organize and write a clear, concise and cohesive academic text relating to economics, respecting academic conventions.

data.name: International Accounting and Finance I: International Accounting

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
Upon completion of the module students will: 
- know the differences in financial measurement and reporting practices that exist internationally, the reasons for these differences and their resultant financial statement effects:
- have learnt how to use the financial statements in order to evaluate the firm’s past and present performance and to predict likely future outcome;
- have developed analytical skills when using standard financial statement analysis tools including accounting analysis and ratio analysis based on financial statements that use different accounting standards.

data.name: Laboratorio di pratica riflessiva

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
Reflective practice is one of the most powerful sources of learning and strengthening the skills needed by social workers to face complex situations. In this context the outcomes are better when this cognitive activity is not left to improvisation, but is guided by systematic habits and the use of suitable tools to strengthen the ability to evaluate and understand the single episode analyzed, to imagine more effective future actions  and to recognise the deep connections existing between the "case" and the ethical, methodological, social, psychological, legal and political dimensions connected to it.
The purpose of the workshop is to propose elements of understanding of how reflexive practice can be acted out in social work, providing an initial framework of definitions from which to offer the opportunity to learn and experiment tools and strategies useful for the development of a reflective professional.
At the end of the workshop the students will be able to:
1. constantly develop a reflexive practice on one's work, emotions and on being a practitioner,
2. develop and deepen skills in continuous form,
3. use a critical and responsible approach to ethical and deontological problems,
4. develop and implement critical reflection strategies and tools in collaboration with other people,
5. correctly write reflexive papers using a proper terminologyn.

data.name: Microeconomia_
data.description: This course deals at an intermediate level with all the topics covered by a first course in microeconomics. We place particular emphasis on game theory. At the end of the course, the student will be able to tackle any advanced topic in economics, from public economics to industrial organization.

data.name: Mechanics and Structural Design for Energy Engineering

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description: The course investigates good practice in the design of steel structures, presenting requirements, standards and methodologies that have to be followed in order to design efficient yet reliable structures. The students attending this course are expected to learn how to design key components in steel structures to be implemented in systems for energy applications, including wind energy, hydraulic energy, solar energy and bioenergy and relevant industrial plants.

data.name: Istituzioni di diritto dell'Unione Europea
Relativistic and Multimessenger Astrophysics
data.description:
The purpose of this lecture is to present the principles and the basic phenomenology of relativistic and multimessenger astrophysics on a theoretical-modelling side. In this course, multimessenger astrophysics refers to the study of astrophysical transients for which the radiative emission is characterized by different kinds of radiation, in particular: gravitational waves, electromagnetic waves and neutrinos. On the one hand, these emissions testify the relevance of all fundamental interactions; on the other hand, they allow to investigate more deeply and more completely phenomena and regimes otherwise inaccessible. These kinds of phenomena are often related with compact objects (i.e. black holes and neutron stars), whose description requires relativity. To be concrete and timely, the specific topics will be: 1. accreting black holes; 2. isolated and merging neutron stars; 3. core-collapse supernovae.

At the end of the lecture, students will be able to understand and model multimessenger emissions from relativistic systems of astrophysical interst.

data.name: Innovation and Entrepreneurship Studies in ICT

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
After completion of the I&E Studies course, students should…

• … have the ability to apply, synthesize, and evaluate prior I&E learning within a specific innovation or entrepreneurial project setting and a specific innovation area.
• … have the ability to conduct a business analysis, make decisions and formulate recommendations or justify actions in a real environment.
• … have the ability to choose and apply relevant concepts/methods and/or tools and collect relevant data for conducting a business analysis and making decisions in a real environment.
• … have the ability to produce a professional writing on a business analysis topic.
• … have the ability to apply concepts, methods and tools pertaining to identifying and assessing the impact/value of a technology in an industry, market and/or organization and the innovation / business opportunities it creates.
• … have the ability to reflect critically on issues related to the development of ICT solutions, and their potential pitfalls due to market and/or social reasons.
• … have developed a sense of "out of the box thinking" and creative approaches to problem solving, even in contexts that would otherwise suggest a technical solution.
• … have the ability to make value and ethical judgements about the development of technological and business solutions.
• … have the ability to work as a team with other students to complement each other's competences and perspectives.

data.name: Scienza delle costruzioni

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
This course provides the understanding of the deformation and strength of solids and structures employed in structural engineering, with special reference to isotropic linear elasticity. At the end of the course, some environmental applications will be described, introducing the basis of finite element modelling.

At the end of this course, students will be able to:

1. Recognize and manage constraints and structures both in statics and kinematics;

2. Analyze statically and solve the determinate structures and their elastic displacements;

3. Analyze statically and solve the indeterminate structures (including their elastic displacement);

4. Compute stresses in an elastic prismatic bar, due to acting forces.

5. Evaluate and determine the critical loads for the collapse of structures subjected to elastic instability, fracture or plasticity
data.degreeProgram: Ingegneria per l'ambiente e il territorio (L2)

data.name: Diritto pubblico
data.description:
To provide the basic knowledge of the main categories of public  law, with special emphasis on the sources of law, their role in regulating the relationship among public actors and between the State and the citizens, the role and functioning of public  institutions in the decision-making process. To guide students towards the consultation of the sources of law and the interpretation of legal rules, particularly focusing on the Italian Constitution.
At the end of the course, students will have the basic notions of legal terminology and will be able to comprehend and properly describe the basic elements of the national system of public law. Moreover, they will have the basic tools to directly access legal sources, particularly at the Constitutional level.

data.name: Pianificazione ecologica del territorio

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.degreeProgram: Ingegneria per l'ambiente e il territorio (LM)

data.name: Telerilevamento e radar

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
Remote sensing optical and radar systems are one of the most complex information engineering systems, as they  involve many technologies and methodologies (satellites, passive sensors, radar sensors for the acquisition of images, data transmission techniques, advanced signal and image processing techniques, data storage and management techniques).
The course analyses the main elements of remote sensing systems and develops a basic level of competence in processing and automatic recognition of images and signals.
The programme is divided into 5 parts  The first part looks at remote sensing systems in general, and the principles upon which they are based.  The second part focuses on the acquistion phase of remote sensing images; covering satellites, sensors and data transmission systems.  The third part is dedicated to the automatic techniques used for the processing of remotely sensed images, and advanced methodologies for the analysis of multispectral optical images and radar images.  The fourth part of the course examines techniques for automatic recognition of remote sensing images and signals.  The final part of the course presents examples of the application of remote sensing systems and image analysis techniques to real problems.
The student wll also develop practical exercises in laboratory to consolidate the understanding of the theory, and gain experience of the techniques described in lectures.  There will also be some specialist seminars held by experts in the sector from national and international research institutes and from industry.

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.name: Informatica ed elementi di programmazione I

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.name: Economia dell'impresa e responsabilità sociale
Sociology of collective action

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
Students will:

  1. become familiar with the basic tenets of the dominant theoretical models for the study of collective action;
  2. develop the ability to assess strengths and weaknesses of each approach
  3. develop the ability to apply concepts and theoretical models to the explanation/interpretation of specific dynamics of collective actions.
  4. enhance the ability to connect the theories presented with empirical research through the in-depth study of a number of empirical studies. These will be based on the use of various empirical research methods and techniques, including public opinion surveys, protest-event-analysis (PEA) and social network analysis (SNA).
  5. acquire some skills to formulate research questions, develop a literature review, and understand appropriate methods to be able to examine phenomena related to collective action. This course, supplemented with appropriate methodological knowledge, enables students to initiate qualitative or quantitative empirical research in the field of collective action

data.name: Etica
data.description: The course aims to provide a concise but exhaustive knowledge of the main issues of ethics, in dialogue with other thought forms (music, in particular). It also aimss to stimulate in students an autonomous and critical reflection on the difficulties of ethical decisions in contemporary society and on the social role of philosophy and culture in general in dealing with ethical problems.

data.name: Reti logiche

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: The objective of this course is to provide the students with the fundamental notions of digital circuits, with particular focus to the understanding, the analysis and the design of logic networks. At the end of the course, the student will be able to comprehend the operation of digital circuits that use logic gates and state machines, and to design complex digital processing systems by analyzing and evaluating the design choices. The student learns how to approach the design through the use of synchronous specification models, timing diagrams, and simulation and implementation using the VHDL language, identifying the critical components, and partitioning the design to handle its complexity. Exercises on design problems and laboratory sessions allow the students to apply the concepts in practice, and to gain familiarity with real components and design environments.

data.name: Ultrasound Technologies for Medical Applications

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: This course consists of two parts. In the first part, core topics such as the piezoelectric phenomenon, the physics of ultrasound propagation, modeling, and nonlinear acoustics will be introduced. This will provide the students with the basic knowledge necessary to understand the potentials and the limitations of ultrasound technologies. The second part will then focus on probe design, system architecture of ultrasound scanners, image formation and beam forming, and emerging medical applications (e.g. lung ultrasonography, brain and cancer imaging). The objective of the course is to form students that are not only familiar with the fundamentals and state-of-the-art applications of ultrasound technology, but also able to critically evaluate the technology itself and potentially improve it further.

data.name: Antimatter Physics
data.description:
The course aims to give a picture as complete as possible on what concerns the use and study of antimatter from an experimental point of view.

At the end of the course, the student is expected to have acquired skills not only regarding the physics of antimatter but also on the realization of experiments with antimatter, observation and detection of antimatter, and its use for the study of some aspects of matter.

data.name: Programmazione 2

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: The course is taught in Italian, please see the corresponding description.
data.degreeProgram: Ingegneria Informatica, delle Comunicazioni ed Elettronica (L2)

data.name: Psicopatologia clinica

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description:
The course's main aim is to lay the foundations of the understanding of the most important mental diseases' causes and development both in children and adults.

In particular students will able to :


A. Know the main diagnostic methods for mental disorders

B. Know the International systems of diagnostic classification for mental disease

C. Know the principal pathologies studied: the focus will be on inter subjectivity as well as on biologic and environmental/relational features

D. Analyse the key elements to make a clinical diagnosis (personal history, elements of cognitive functioning, personality structure)

E. Ability to study independently texts or scientific papers recommended by the teacher

data.name: Educational technology

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description:
This course aims to provide students with an understanding of the wide spectrum of ways, inwhich ICTs can support learning processes. A major emphasis will be devoted to the role of ICTs in providing an inclusive education for students with special educational needs (SEN).
Students will acquire the fundamental concepts, which characterizes e-learning, and the use
of technology in general to support teaching and learning. The main objective of the course is to stimulate reflection on the use of new media (and multimedia production) for teaching.
Moreover, the course will deal with the use of video games (educational and not). During the lessons, the topics will be explored on a theoretical and practical level, providing sufficient skills to get hands-on with these tools and to develop a dialogue (in class) about their potential in the educational field.
 Finally, improve verbal and written presentation skills, improve their critical thinking capacities, making a judgment about the present, current and future use of ICT
within the educational context.

data.name: Ingegneria per lo sviluppo sostenibile internazionale. Metodi e progetto

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.degreeProgram: Ingegneria per l'ambiente e il territorio (LM)

data.name: Fondamenti di neuropsicologia

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description:
The aim of the course is to provide an introduction to cognitive and clinical neuropsychology, promoting (1) understanding of specificities of the neuropsychological approach to human cognition, including its methods; (2) knowledge of the main neuropsychological syndromes and manifestations; (3) basic understanding of the cognitive neuropsychological models

At the end of the course students should be able to (1) read and understand the textbook and other materials provided for the course; (2) select the relevant neuropsychological concepts when reporting a clinical case; (3) build an logical argument using neuropsychological concepts.
data.degreeProgram: Scienze e Tecniche di Psicologia Cognitiva (L2)

data.name: Modelli statistici per l'economia e la finanza
data.description: The aim is to provide the statistical tools necessary to enable the students to carry out empirical analyses of economic relationships and to provide the statistical instruments for carrying out empirical analysis of financial time-series analyses.

data.name: Neural Foundations of Human Behavior
data.description:
• The educational objective of the course is to acquire a knowledge base on the functioning of the central nervous system in mammals with particular reference to primates and humans. Brain function will be addressed at the level of the different systems (macro-scale) that compose it and how each of them is responsible for certain behavioral phenomena such as voluntary movement, affective behavior, memory or communication.
  • The contents will therefore cover the disciplines of neuroanatomy and neurophysiology. Particular emphasis will also be given to methodological aspects and to the possibility of transferring knowledge obtained in non-human models to the human brain.
  • Expected knowledge at the end of the course: to know the anatomy and physiology of brain systems.
  • Expected skills at the end of the course: mapping different behavioral functions onto the central nervous system’s anatomy. Formulate realistic hypotheses on the brain-behavior relationship

data.name: Azionamenti elettrici
data.description:
The course will provide a review on the operating principles of the main electrical machines used in industrial applications and will deepen the modeling and analysis of dc machines, permanent magnets synchronous machines, asynchronous machines and reluctance machines.

The main control techniques for such machines will be also introduced, besides the description of the power electronic components/systems used for their control.

Practical examples and exercises will be proposed to support the theory.

After completing the course, the student shall be able to:

  • Understand the operating principles and fields of operation of the main electrical machines and drives.
  • Master terminology and parameters characterizing electric drives.
  • Design simple current and speed controllers for dc and ac drives.
  • Read and correctly interpret nameplate data of the considered electrical machines and drives.

data.name: Human-Machine Dialogue

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: Robots that can talk or chat with humans are becoming pervasive in many industry domains and applications. Such agents are called conversational AI systems. In this course the student will learn the basic principles of human computer interaction, conversation linguistics, discourse analysis, computational dialogue models and architectures and their evaluation. In the second part of the course the student will develop a conversational system while  learning the design methodologies, data-driven training and dialogue development tools .

data.name: Industrial robotics
data.description: This course provides an overview of the field of industrial robots. Topics are mainly focused on aspects of representation, planning and control of motion of robotic manipulators. The student acquires theoretical and applied concepts of kinematics, statics, mechanism design, dynamics, simulation and basics of control architectures. Additionally, the course provides an outline of actuators, sensing, electronic components and control software architectures that are typically employed in industrial robots. During the course, the student learns to build simplified PC-based models of a robots and to handle problems for the modeling, design and control of robotic manipulators.

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.name: Multisensory interactive systems

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The overall goal of the module is to provide a theoretical and practical basis for the design, development, and evaluation of interactive systems, which are multisensory, tangible, and networked. Students on this module will have the opportunity to explore physical computing concepts, use real-time programming languages, understand the bases of human sensory perception, and design networked interactions in both co-located and remote settings.

On successful completion of this course, students should be able to: 
- Understand fundamental notions on electronic hardware such as micro controllers, single board computers, sensors, and actuators of different kind
- Develop interactive applications based on both embedded systems and desktop solutions, which take inputs from sensors and control a variety of physical and digital outputs
- Apply acquired knowledge on fundamentals of multisensory perception to the design of interactive systems
- Apply techniques for prototyping multisensory interactive systems as well as for their evaluation at both technical and user experience level


Students will apply knowledge and skills from above in completing a semester project in teams. Students will be provided with a large variety of hardware items and software tools, which will enable them to create prototypes of networked, tangible and interactive multisensory systems.

data.name: Modellistica ambientale avanzata e applicazioni

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.degreeProgram: Ingegneria per l'ambiente e il territorio (LM)

data.name: Fisiologia umana II
data.description: The primary objective of the PHYSIOLOGY II course is the in-depth knowledge of the function of the cardiovascular, respiratory, renal and digestive systems and their control by the nervous and endocrine systems. The interactions between the different systems will also be explored. At the end of the course the student must be able to describe the integrated contribution of each of the systems and in generating and maintaining the homeostasis of the internal medium in normal conditions, in extreme environments and in some paradigmatic pathological conditions.

data.name: Fondazioni

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
The course aims at providing the basic knowledge usually adopted to approach the geotechnical design of a foundation under static loads.


By attending in-person lectures and in-class tutorials, the students will:

- Learn how to approach the geotechnical design of a foundation subjected to static loads based on the latest Italian technical regulations (NTC 2018).

- Interpret the results of the most common geotechnical investigations used to support the geotechnical design of a foundation system.

- Learn how to assess the stability of a foundation with respect to general failure conditions induced by static loads.

- Analyse the behaviour of a foundation and the soil-foundation interaction under serviceability conditions.

- Select the most appropriate foundation type based on the available ground conditions and the conditions imposed by the super-structure.

data.name: Lab. appl.: L'imputazione nel sistema processuale penale: regole giuridiche e tecniche di formulazione
data.description: The course aims at investigating the meaning and scope of the demand for prosecution within the criminal proceedings, both at a theoretical and practical level. In particular, it will be offered an overview of the relevant case-law by analyzing specific cases and documents. By the end of the course the student will acquire the essential notions to deal with the most relevant problems related to criminal charge.

data.name: Lingua e cultura russa II
data.description: On successful completion of this course, students are expected to: a) know and understand the most crucial historical and cultural aspects of the Russian civilisation, from the Bolshevik Revolution to the present day; b) reach an A2 level of proficiency in Russian, and be able to handle basic communication in the area of tourism (as a tour guide, receptionist at tourist facilities etc.)

data.name: Linguistica russa I
data.description:
The course aims to provide the theoretical and methodological tools to understand and comment on the content of informative texts concerning some areas of the history of Russian civilization. At the end of the course, the student must be able to 1) understand and analyze from both a linguistic and cultural point of view, 2) translate, even in written form, into Italian, 3) to re-elaborate and present orally in Russian the contents relating to texts of a mostly informative nature.
With regard to language exercises, the student will reach the B1 active / B2 passive language proficiency level in the specialized language of tourism.

data.name: Finanza aziendale
data.description:
The course aims to provide students with the tools to effectively set up a company's financial decisions in order to create value for the benefit of owners and creditors.

By the end of the course, students will be able to: (1) estimate the price of a company's main financing instruments, shares and bonds; (2) calculate the cash flows of a company's investment projects and correctly apply the selection criteria; (3) estimate the cost of capital and the cost of debt of a company; (4) understand the actual choices made by companies regarding financial structure.

data.name: Radar and 5G Architectures and Systems

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The course is aimed to introduce the students to the basics of radar and 5G principles and to teach modern active architectures and systems focusing on electromagnetic functionalities and principal applications, also providing insights on the latest advances as well as envisaged evolutions of future radars and mobile communications.
The course is divided into six parts. The first two parts are devoted to present the general architecture of a radar system, the basic radar terminology, and the mathematical and physical description of the radar problem. The third part focuses on modern radar architectures, highlighting the relationships between radar requirements, system deployment, and design of the sensing layout. The fourth and fifth parts are aimed to discuss the principal functionalities of modern active radar systems and present a selection of electromagnetic radar applications. The last part is aimed at showing how the technologies and architectures typical of radar systems will be widely used in the new 5G mobile communications systems.
At the end of the course, the student is expected to become aware of the principles for external radar and 5G design (i.e., starting from the problem objectives and requirements/constraints specify the general architecture) and the internal design (i.e., starting from the general architecture specify the HW and SW implementations) and to acquire the knowledge for the study, analysis and design of modern and future radar and communications systems.

data.name: Culture and society

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.degreeProgram: Sociology and social research - Sociologia e ricerca sociale (LM)

data.name: Statistics of Stochastic Processes
data.description: Knowledge on the problems concerning the statistical analysis of dependent data, especially time series. Develop good competences on of linear ARMA models and Hidden Markov Models, their specification, properties, inferential and computational aspects.

data.name: Optimization techniques

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The goal of this course is to provide the fundamentals of numerical optimization. We will focus on various kinds of optimization techniques, ranging from continuous to discrete optimization methods, including global and local search methods, derivative-based and derivative-free algorithms, as well as traditional operational research techniques such as those used for solving integer programming, linear programming, and quadratic programming problems. We will address both theoretical and practical considerations, complementing each lecture on the theory with a dedicated lab. During the labs, the students will have the opportunity to test the various techniques on synthetic and real-world optimization problems.

At the end of this course, the students will be familiar with the fundamentals of numerical optimization, and will be able to apply various kinds of optimization algorithms to different contexts. They will also know the basic theory needed for developing new algorithms, or adapting/tuning them to handle new problems.

data.name: Fundamental Hands on Functional Neuroimaging Analysis
data.description:
The main objective of this FIRST SEMESTER course is to teach basic image analyses steps commonly usedin functional neuroimaging studies with magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and magnetoencephalography(MEG).

2-hour classes will take place at Rovereto three times per week in a computer lab where students will useneuroimaging analyses tools and data. Lectures will cover basic introductory topics but will be mostlyfocused on a tutorial style showing how to perform basic analyses, both with guided-class and take-homeexercises. Students will choose one of the two methods (MRI or MEG), and at the end of the course theyshould be able to perform the basic analyses steps listed in the program below.

data.name: Diritto e processo penale nell'antica Roma
data.description:
This course intends to offer an overview on Roman criminal law and Roman criminal law procedure, from the time of the archaic Rome to the Late Antiquity. A special focus would be devoted to the evolution of the repressive system during the  Principate.
The course would begin with some considerations on the method applied to the study of Roman criminal law and, furthermore, on the role Roman criminal law research plays within the field of Roman law studies. 
To achieve the abovementioned aims of the course, time would be devotyed to the analysis of some important ancient sources as well as to the evolution of the idea of capital punishment over the centuries and, in particular, between the end of the Republic and the beginning of the Principate. 
Reading materials aimed at a better understanding of the issues that would be discussed during the classes would be uploaded in advance.

data.name: Analog electronics

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The course introduces the scientific and engineering foundations of analog and digital electronic circuits with a particular focus on the analog fundamentals.

In particular, the topics of the course are:

• An introduction of the main discrete components and the methodology of analysis of the circuits containing them

• The main active components (diode, both bipolar and field-effect transistors) and the methods of analysis of analog electrical networks containing diodes and / or transistors

• The operational amplifier and its main applications

• Transistor-level analysis of the basic electronic circuits used for data and signal processing

• Frequency filters and oscillators

• An introduction to the different sources of noise, methods of analysis and mitigation for the design of precision analog circuits

After completing the course, the student will be able to:

• To analyze electronic circuits based on diodes operating in steady and transient conditions

• Design simple diode electronic circuits (for example limiters and rectifiers)

• Understand the principle of operation of transistor-based amplifiers

• To analyze and design single-stage amplifier stages, determining their main figure of merits

• Understand the principle of circuits based on operational amplifiers with negative feedback operating in steady state and transient conditions and AC ;

• Analyze and design amplifier stages and filters based on operational amplifiers;

• Understand the behavior of circuits based on operational amplifiers with positive feedback operating in steady state and transient conditions;

• Understanding the behavior of combinational CMOS digital circuits;

• Analyze and design waveform generating circuits based on operational amplifiers;

• Analyze the effect of electronic noise sources and understand the measures needed to compensate for
data.degreeProgram: Ingegneria Informatica, delle Comunicazioni ed Elettronica (L2)

data.name: Progettare e valutare processi formativi e attività culturali

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description: The course aims at providing students with on the job skills, which are required to draft and evaluate cultural and educational projects, including the ability to properly address funding schemes currently available. Lectures will introduce participants to the most appropriate project management techniques (including planning and evaluation), enabling students to compete in main EU programmes, with special reference to education and culture sectors.

data.name: Programmazione Funzionale

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The course describes and analyses the characteristics of various programming languages, introduces paradigms of programming, and studies in detail the functional paradigms (with reference to the language ML)

The student should become familiar with basic concepts of programming languages (memory management, scope rules, visibility of identifiers, structured code and data, anstractions).

data.name: Storia dell'arte contemporanea II - LM
data.degreeProgram: Letterature euroamericane, traduzione e critica letteraria (LM)

data.name: Climate and Cryosphere Modeling

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description: The basic principles of dynamic processes in Glaciology (ice dynamics, subglacial processes, ice surface processes) will be reviewed. Building upon these basics, numerical models of key processes will be developed, including the required numerical methods to code such models. Coupling of the models to external drivers (mass balance, energy balance) will be reviewed as well.

data.name: Introduzione all'economia
data.description: By the end of the course, the student is expected to be familiar with the language of economics and the main methods and models used in this field. In addition, the student should be able to apply these methods and models to analyze situations that occur daily in a modern market economy and to critically consider the potential benefits, failures, and unwanted consequences of economic policies.

data.name: Sociologia dei processi culturali e comunicativi - LM
data.description: The course aims to analyze the process of cultural crisis connected to the transformations of the spirit of the modern world that took place during the 20th century, especially in the universe of consumption and lifestyles. It is in this sense that a specific analysis of the Italian case will be developed. At the end of the course, students of both degree courses must be able to: a) to have an adequate knowledge of the transformations that have taken place in the cultural sphere; b) to reconstruct the process of decomposition of the subject following the transformations that took place in the post-modern era. c) Be able to summarize the essential sociological aspects of contemporary Italian society.

data.name: Electronic materials and technologies
data.description:
The aim of the course is to present electronic devices and technologies commonly used for manufacturing devices, sensors and large scale integrated circuits of common use for industrial and ICT applications. The course also introduces software tools used in the development of electron devices, emphasizing both the technological and design aspects.

At the end of the course, the students are expected to be familiar with the terminology and the problems commonly found in the field of semiconductor device physics and technology. They should be able to qualitatively describe the working principle and fabrication process of the semiconductor devices studied within the course and to solve numerical problems on these topics.

They should also acquire a basic operative knowledge on the use of TCAD simulation tools, and develop the ability to use them to solve simple design problems.

data.name: Risks in economics: individual choices and societal challenges
Movimenti sociali, politica e società

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
At the end of the course, students will:

1. learn the main theoretical concepts and models to define, distinguish and interpret social movements, and other forms of social conflict oriented to social, political or cultural changes.

2. be able to link the case studies discussed in the scientific literature with the theoretical elements covered during the course.

3. acquire some basic analytical skills to interpret phenomena and empirical evidence of contemporary society in light of the concepts and theories dealt with in the course.

4. delve, through the analysis of specific case studies, into qualitative or quantitative empirical research approaches in the study of social movements

data.name: Metodologie e tecnologie per l'insegnamento del diritto (Legal Education)
data.description:
The course aims to provide a pattern of skills to achieve the goal of training trainers in legal issues.
To do this the course will develop: 
a) Critical analysis of the main teaching methodologies developed in legal science didactics research, also in reference to the specific role of the teacher, to the conceptual, epistemological and didactic nodes of law teaching and learning also in function of the development of semiotic skills as well as the widening of expressive and cognitive potential in the legal field; 
(b) Design and development of legal science teaching activities: illustration of the principles and methodologies for the construction of activities and, more generally, of a legal science curriculum in which the technical-legal language and the consolidation of the communication skills necessary to achieve the objectives of training and education in legal subjects are enhanced. 
c) Knowledge of the tools offered by new technologies, in teaching, learning and knowledge of law; the indication of the processes of teaching and learning of law mediated by the use of technologies, with particular attention to new digital technologies; the analysis of the potential and criticality of the use of technological tools for teaching and learning of law, in particular with reference to normative, jurisprudential and doctrinal research and legal research in foreign legal systems.
4) Analysis of teaching practices for teaching and learning law mediated by the use of technologies, with particular attention to the specific role of the teacher and to conceptual, epistemological and didactic nodes.
Expected results:
- ability to understand and analyze different legal and training models
- ability to choose the best legal/training model in the required context
- ability to use technologies for learning, teaching and legal knowledge
- significant increase in communication skills

data.name: Linguistica russa II
data.description:
1. The course aims at providing students with the necessary linguistic knowledge to express themselves in a grammatically correct and pragmatically appropriate manner, whichever the context;

2. The course aims at providing students a synthetic yet exhaustive theoretical overview on some complex morphosyntactic issues (a.o., the formation and use of participial forms; passivization strategies; the taxonomy and use of -sja verbs; temporal and causal adjuncts; notes on the syntax of adjunct clauses, with special reference to temporal, relative, causal, and conditional subordinates);

3. The course aims at helping students develop specific skills related to the reading and passive comprehension of medium-sized argumentative texts.


Language classes, held by Dr. Rimma A. Urkhanova, span over both semesters and aim both at strengthening students' active skills and at getting them acquainted with common lexical and grammatical structures of special languages (tourism- and business-related; cultural mediation). It is expected that students reach a CEFR level of B1 or higher.

data.name: Storia medievale I
Etica della ricerca e deontologia professionale

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description:
The course will provide insights and knowledge tools related to ethics for professional psychologists. General principles of the "Codice deontologico degli psicologi italiani", of the "Codice etico" of AIP (Italian Psychological Association), and of the "Ethic Metacode" of EFPA (European Federation of Psychological Associations) will be presented and discussed.
At the end of the course, students are expected to have achieved the following competences: having a good knowledge of deontological duties and ethics principles; linking theory and practice; consolidating critical thinking, communication skils and problem solving abilities.
Particular attention will be devoted to the contents of the two tracks of the course. Examples and issues will be drawn from the professional and research areas of both organizational psychology and clinical psychology.

data.name: Consumer Empowerment
data.degreeProgram: Management della sostenibilità e del turismo (LM)

data.name: Judgment and Decision Making Laboratory
data.description:
The psychology of judgment and decision-making is the science that studies the basic mechanisms underlying human judgments and choices. The science originated in the 1970s but reached its peak in 2002, when Daniel Kahneman and Amos Tversky, psychologists, were awarded the Nobel Prize in economics for having integrated results of psychological research into economic science, especially with regard to human judgment and decision theory under conditions of uncertainty. A few years later, Richard Thaler, a behavioral economist and long-time collaborator of Kahneman and Tversky had the idea of using the results of their research to design interventions aimed at improving the well-being of citizens and workers. He summarized his ideas in a book published with Cass Sunstein in 2008 (Nudge). Nudging (gentle pushing) was born, an alternative practice to classic policies, for the conception of which Richard Thaler received the 2017 Nobel Prize in economics. In the year of the COVID-19 pandemic, the authors decided to revise and rewrite the 2008 book. On August 3, 2021, "Nudge: the final Edition" was published.


Today there is a wide spread around the world of Nudge Units (Behavioral Insights Teams).In 2018 the European Union also created a Behavioral Insight Unit. These units collect experimental research findings from various disciplines from behavioral sciences such as behavioral economics to social psychology and cognitive psychology and use them to devise "behavioral" interventions that benefit the decision maker. Old-fashioned policies often fail to take into account people's actual behavior. For example, few of us read the entire contract before downloading a new app on our cell phones, and many of us take impulsive actions that we regret later. The behavioral sciences provide empirical evidence to anticipate how people will react to interventions, and they seek to design interventions in ways that make it easier for citizens and workers to make decisions and more closely match their goals. Such nudging interventions have been used to increase savings, reduce consumption, increase health, improve care for the environment, etc.


In this course, you will be able to:

- develop an understanding of the basic mechanisms of human decision-making.

- understand how to design behavioral interventions that, by considering these mechanisms, reduce decision fatigue and increase the well-being of citizens and workers.

data.name: Corso di italiano A2 - I periodo (estensivo)
Laboratorio di ricerca su tecnologia e organizzazione

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
The main aim of the course consists in acquiring the knowledge and skills necessary to the analysis of organizational and technological processes through qualitative methods. This includes theoretical, epistemological, methodological, and applicative aspects.


The course is characterized by a transdisciplinary and challenge-based approach. Research work will be conducted in collaboration with the course Laboratorio di ricerca su sistemi informativi (Prof. D’Andrea). Students attending the two courses, organized in small groups, will carry out an empirical research from start to finish, working in close contact with several start-up in the territory. They will analyze the organizational dimension and the processes of technological design and development of the start-ups, and they will contribute ideas and "solutions" to the start-up’s needs. We will work in collaboration with the BOOGIE-U project (https://eit-hei.eu/projects/boogie-u/) and Hub Innovazione Trentino (HIT).


At the end of the course, students will be able to:

  • understand and critically discuss, in dialogue with relevant literature, the social, technological and organizational aspects concerning innovation processes;
  • design a research project in relation to a specific research question (research design);
  • build research tools (interview guide, observation guide, etc.);
  • apply several qualitative methods and techniques;
  • analyse the data collected through such methods;
  • present, both in oral and written form, the results of such an analysis.
