data.name: Architettura degli elaboratori
data.description:
The goal of this course is to provide the basic notions about the organization and architecture of computing machines, either general-purpose computers, or specialized architectures designed to handle specific tasks. Furthermore, the course provides basic knowledge about the assembly language (in particular using as a reference RISC-V and briefly discussing the Intel and ARM architectures), the HW/SW interface, and the low-level mechanisms of a computer. Finally, the course also provides the fundamental knowledge needed to attend advanced courses focused on the design of computer systems from the hardware perspective.

This course does not require any preliminary knowledge. The structure of the course is especially suited for students with a CV oriented towards software and systems, who during their Bachelor Degree have the chance to learn about computer architectures only through this course. On the other hand, the course will also provide the fundamental knowledge needed to attend advanced courses focused on the design of computer systems from the hardware perspective.

data.name: Progettazione di infrastrutture idrauliche urbane

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
At the end of the course the student will be able to:

·      design hydraulic infrastructures for water collection, delivery, and distribution (aqueducts);

·      develop management and maintenance strategies for water distribution networks: theoretical notes and modeling applications to practical cases.

·      modify existing networks in order to adapt them to the changed situation due to anthropogenic and climatic changes;

·      evaluate the effects of climate change on the available water resource and on urban runoff;

·      evaluate the best design strategies capable of mitigating the effects of climate change in urban drainage networks and water resource distribution networks

data.name: Corporate Strategy
data.description:
The aim of the course is to provide students with the tools and skills to analyze and understand the sources of competitive advantage in highly competitive sectors characterized by rapid changes in market conditions.

At the end of the course, students will be able to: analyze and understand the different levels of corporate strategy (corporate, business and functional) of a company; identify the mission, vision and strategy of a company as well as the ways in which strategic decisions are made; analyze the external environment in which a company operates and relate it to the wealth of resources and skills to assess the basis of competitive advantage; identify and discuss the strengths and weaknesses of a strategy; use the theoretical foundations of strategy and know how to apply them in the analysis of business cases.

On completion of the module students should be able to:

  • Describe the key elements associated with corporate strategy and strategic management
  • Discuss the dynamic nature of corporate strategy and strategic management
  • Assess, analyze and appraise business and corporate strategies
  • Identify major opportunities and threats coming from the markets
  • Identify strength and weaknesses of organizations
  • Identify and evaluate strategic choices for the future.

data.name: Bacterial Pathogenesis

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description:
Objectives
The aim of the course is to provide the students with the understanding the bacterium-host relationships and to explore the virulence factors that promote colonization and survival of the infecting microorganisms, as well the virulence attributes that damage the host. The course will explore the evolutionary aspects of bacterial pathogenesis and the experimental approaches for investigating the bacterium-host inte-relationship, underlining the molecular mechanisms of pathogenicity for selected pathogens. The challenge facing the discovering and development of new antibiotics will also be discussed.
At the end of this course, students will be able to:
a) Describe the difference between the different types of symbiosis and their evolution
b) Understand what makes a bacterium a "pathogen" 
c) Describe the distinctive genetic traits of a bacterial pathogen 
d) Understand the difference between pathogenicity and virulence and how to assess them
e) Describe the main modes of bacterial transmission
f) Describe the molecular mechanisms of bacterial pathogenicity in defined bacterial models 
g) Describe the main anti-infectious strategies against bacteria

data.name: Communications Systems

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The course of Communication Systems targets to provide Master Degree Students with advanced knowledge about telecommunication systems operating on real channels, in particular by emphasizing the digital transmission over wireless and mobile channels. 
At the end of the course, the student will acquire a wide range of useful concepts allowing him/her to analyze and design an "end-to-end" transmission system, considering the quality-of-service impairment factors, related both to propagation nonidealities and to the presence of distortions in the modulation/demodulation chain.

data.name: Sociology of collective action

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
Students will:

  1. become familiar with the basic tenets of the dominant theoretical models for the study of collective action;
  2. develop the ability to assess strengths and weaknesses of each approach
  3. develop the ability to apply concepts and theoretical models to the explanation/interpretation of specific dynamics of collective actions.
  4. enhance the ability to connect the theories presented with empirical research through the in-depth study of a number of empirical studies. These will be based on the use of various empirical research methods and techniques, including public opinion surveys, protest-event-analysis (PEA) and social network analysis (SNA).
  5. acquire some skills to formulate research questions, develop a literature review, and understand appropriate methods to be able to examine phenomena related to collective action. This course, supplemented with appropriate methodological knowledge, enables students to initiate qualitative or quantitative empirical research in the field of collective action

data.name: Introduzione al diritto cinese
data.description: The aim of the course is to provide a basic knowledge of Chinese legal culture and Chinese law in its most characteristic aspects. After the course the student will have all the necessary tools to undertake further research.

data.name: Bioetica
data.description: The course aims to provide a critical understanding of the dynamics, themes and significant contexts of bioethical reflection. Particular attention will be paid to the research and tecnology acquisitions of the biological, biotechnological and medical sciences (adequately framed in their historical, legal, and social context of reference).

data.name: Virus-Cell Interaction

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description:
The aim of the course is to provide the students with the understanding of the molecular basis of the interaction between viruses and their host cells, and the modern research strategies applied to the investigation of the mechanisms regulating the virus-cell interface. At the end of this course, students will be able to:
a) Describe the different types of interaction between viruses and cell 
b) Understand the molecular mechanisms which govern the interaction between viruses and cells.
c) Describe the main techniques used to investigate the dynamics and the mechanisms of the virus-cell interaction
c) Explain the mechanisms of reciprocal adaptation between viruses and their hosts
d) Understand the causes, dynamics, and basic pathogenic mechanisms underlying viral infections.
e) Describe the main strategies used to interfere with the virus interaction with its host
f) Understand the causes and consequences of the host-virus interaction at the population level.
g) Comprehend the contribution of virus research for the advancement of our knowledge of the mechanisms governing the eukaryotic cell
h) Understanding the principles driving the development of virus-based technologies aimed at manipulating eukaryotic cells.

data.name: Glass engineering
data.description:
After completing this course, the students will be able to know, compare and select the fundamental properties and characteristics of glasses, with specific reference to silicate glasses, for their specific applications with respect to their composition and processing conditions.

More specifically students will be able to:

- summarize and analyze possible routes for producing a glass instead of a crystal

- summarize, evaluate and modify the fundamental properties (optical, mechanical, chemical) of oxide glasses for specific applications (architectural, electronic, biomedical, optical) as a function of the processing conditions

- summarize, evaluate and select the processing technology for specific real glass components


Additional learning outcomes include some soft skills the student will acquire, at least partially (but not only), especially after completing the laboratory activities; these regard teamwork (collaboration and cooperation during the activity), communication (writing the lab report), flexibility, responsibility and positive attitude.

data.name: Research Methodology: Quantitative

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description: This course provides a first introduction to some methodological aspects of carrying out research in the HCI field according to a quantitative perspective.  It covers a variety of techniques for recording and analyzing empirical data collected using human participants. Topics to be covered include the definition of measurement scales and how they impact the selection of statistical models to analyze empirical data. The course introduces also different types of behavioral research ranging from experimental design to surveys (or questionnaires). The associated statistical techniques are also presented and illustrated by using the statistical package R.

data.name: Bilancio e principi contabili delle compagnie di assicurazione
Cyber Security Risk Assessment

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
Course's Objectives Most CS professionals will actually use, buy, or sell security technology and make security decisions. They don't design protocols, nor crypto algorithms, they decide which security technology they are going to use. The course provides the fundamentals to chose the appropriate security technology based on balancing threat and controls, costs, impact and likelihood of events. In other words the course will teach students to manage risk. The course will introduce students to the key principles of Security Risk Assessment (Risk and Threat Analysis, Risk Assessment, Control Frameworks) both qualitatively and quantitatively. The student will identify threats and the corresponding security controls appropriate for two industrial case studies. Intended Learning Outcomes Regular and active participation in the teaching activities offered by the course (lectures, laboratories and group work) and in independent study and project activities will enable students to:
  • understand the fundamentals of risk management;
  • identify the relevant assets and the corresponding impacts of possible threats for a moderately complex case study;
  • mitigate threats with control according to the risk appetite of a relevant stakeholder;
  • quantitatively estimate, for the particular case of cyber threats, the technical impact of vulnerabilities and the particular impact on their presence in a company's enviroment;
  • quantitatively estimate the overall risk for a large scale network.
In terms of soft skills, active participation in the group-based teaching activities will enable students to learn how to organize group work, apply problem-solving techniques, deliver a presentation, and support their results with compelling arguments. At the end students who successfully passed the course should be able to prepare and defend a cyber risk assessment, identifying the threats and the security controls and the residual risk for an industrial case study of moderate complexity.

data.name: Introduzione all'economia
data.description: By the end of the course, the student is expected to be familiar with the language of economics and the main methods and models used in this field. In addition, the student should be able to apply these methods and models to analyze situations that occur daily in a modern market economy and to critically consider the potential benefits, failures, and unwanted consequences of economic policies.

data.name: Managing Drug Discovery: from concept to market
data.description:
The aim of the course is to provide the students with an understanding of the biotechnological approaches at the basis of the development of therapeutic products, the basics of drug discovery and development, and the management of a portfolio of therapeutics in pharmaceutical R&D

Upon successful completion of the course, the students will be able to:

  • Understand the basic principles of modern biotechnology
  • Discriminate the main classes of therapeutic agents
  • Describe the key steps of drug discovery, from target identification to launch
  • Explain how biomarkers, diagnostics and immunotherapy are enabling for personalized medicine Understand the key factors for the assessment of pharma projects intended as investments from a business point of view
  • Discuss the basics of decision making in pharma R&D when assessing the cost/benefit ratio and the economical evaluation of a pharmaceutical research project
  • Critically evaluate a portfolio of therapeutic products at different stages of development

data.name: Antropologia filosofica
data.description: The course of philosophical anthropology aims to stimulate in participants the reflection on man and the human condition. In the latter, biological factors, cultural elements, and the quest for the meaning of individual existence interact and integrate in a complex manner. Although fully belonging to contemporary moral philosophy, the discipline from which it draws its overall coherence, philosophical anthropology is highly interdisciplinary and thus requires students to actively focus on anthropological-cultural, sociological, and ethnographic problems.

data.name: Embedded systems

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
Embedded computers are found everywhere, from home appliances to automobiles to medical devices. Designing an embedded computing system is a challenging task because the requirements include manufacturing cost, performance, power consumption, user interface, hard deadlines, and rich functionality. 
The objective is to illustrate the embedded system design process, which includes requirements, specification, architecture, components, and system integration phases. The course will be backed up by real-life design examples to illustrate the design process, and also students will be asked to design embedded systems to gain experience.

data.name: Microeconomics
data.description: This course deals at an intermediate level with all the topics covered by a first course in microeconomics. We place particular emphasis on game theory. At the end of the course the student will be able to tackle any advanced topic in economics, from public economics to industrial organization.

In questo modo, si intende favorire l’apprendimento – da parte dello studente – di metodi espositivi adeguati e tecniche argomentative efficaci, sia per quanto concerne la produzione scritta, sia dal punto di vista della comunicazione orale.

data.name: Comparative Legal Systems
data.description: The aim of the course is to introduce students to the law as observed and studied from a comparative perspective. Moreover, the course will offer students an introduction to the main legal systems of the world and equip them with methodologies and instruments of comparative law. Some lectures will also show how legal relations among private persons are structured. At the end of the course students will be able to: - identify the main features of a legal system and of the mail legal families of the world; - acquire skills aimed at placing the main systems of the Western legal tradition in a current European and global perspective; - identify the characteristics and the different methods of comparative law as a science: functionalism, structuralism and other epistemological paradigms of more recent definition; - identify the key elements of an institute which are relevant for uncovering its function and compare it with a similar model (functionalism); identify the different formants and evaluate their convergence or dissociation (structuralism) with regard to a specific factual situation.

Selected readings by thinkers such as Kant, Hegel, Cobden, Marx, Kelsen, Schmitt, Morgenthau, Aron and others will be analyzed and discussed. The course includes lectures and active student participation. Students will make oral presentations on specific case studies and lead discussions.

data.name: Engineering system design
data.description:
The course aims to introduce the general concepts, formal tools and techniques commonly adopted in planning conducting and managing the design process.

The course is intended to support the student to actively acquire the skills by experimenting with the necessary activities on specific project work. By the end of the course, the student will have developed the skills to plan, undertake, and manage the project and effectively communicate its outcomes.

Particular attention is given to the close link between the design process and the product life cycle (design - production - testing/verification - operation – service life - reuse and/or recycling). In this context, the concepts of Design for X will be addressed.

The course defines the formal conceptual design process, methods for developing creativity, development of physical/prototype and mathematical models, shaping and dimensioning techniques, choice of materials and production processes, performance testing and evaluation, and finally tools for management and economic planning.

data.name: Comportamento umano in contesti sociali

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
The main objective of the course is to provide social work students with the necessary conceptual tools to understand the motivations and psychological processes underlying human behavior in social contexts. The theoretical approach adopted is that of social psychology.

In particular, during the lessons and through individual study, students should achieve the following formative results
- acquire a good command of the specific language of the discipline and the theories addressed in the course and in the readings;
- acquire a good knowledge of psychological processes and motivations underlying human behavior when in interaction (real or imagined) with other people, as well as attitudes and group dynamics.
- relate theoretical knowledge and analysis of social contexts of interest to social service workers (e.g. by selecting, among the learned theoretical models, those that can provide tools for reading and interpreting a specific social context).
- apply this knowledge to specific issues of particular relevance to social service contexts, such as poverty, exclusion and immigration.

In addition, together with the other courses, this one should help consolidate learning, independent judgment and communication skills.

data.name: Comparative Constitutional Law
data.description:
The course explores the institutional setting of constitutional systems belonging to the Western legal tradition. After a general overview on the origins, purposes and methodologies of comparative constitutional law, the first part of the course examines the definitions of constitution, the processes of constitution-making and constitution-amending, the territorial organisation of political power. In the second part, the course analyses the territorial allocation of power, the forms of government, parliaments and political decision-making, the organization of the judiciary, judicial review of legislation and constitutional rights.

Upon completion of the course, students will be able to:

- Define and classify a variety of constitutions;

- Recognise and classify a variety of patterns of constitution-making and amending;

- Identify the main models of territorial organisation of political power;

- Identify and reconstruct the evolution of the main models of form of government;

- Reflect critically on the problems of judicial independence and accountability;

- Reflect critically on the organization of judicial review of legislation;

- Recognise the types of constitutional rights and the particular challenges emerging in their protection.

data.name: Introduzione alla Psicologia per l'insegnamento
data.description: The course aims at providing students with basic knowledge about the main mental processes (cognitive, affective, and relational) that may support teaching. The following outcomes of the course are expected: acquisition of knowledge about (a) aspects and mechanisms involved in learning, memorizing, and using knowledge; (b) cognitive strategies that qualify and modulate information processing;(c) main features of human motivation; (d) affective and relational aspects of interactions in the school setting. Students will learn about how to promote growth processes through appreciation of individual differences. The prospective teacher should be able to recognize the nature and quality of interactions with the threefold aim of being aware of his/her interaction style with students and the other adults in the school setting: of promoting the capacity to reflect upon his/her actions and their possible consequences in teaching; of being able to empower his/her positive attitudes in order to contribute to the overall level of wellbeing of the school environment.

data.name: Innovation and Entrepreneurship Basic

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The goal of the course is to provide students fundamentals in the field of innovation theory and entrepreneurial practice, while focusing on the development of “soft skills” such as presentation, writing, critical thinking and creativity.


At the end of the course, students will be able to:

- Analyse many perspectives on I&E and apply them to possible future scenarios;

- Create rough drafts of sustainable business models starting from an idea and/or product;

- Discuss the role of entrepreneurship in society and how different organizations function;

- Explain how technology can be seen both as a positive driver and as a source of disruption for contemporary society;

data.name: Ecologia applicata

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description: Aim of the course is to explore Applied Ecology, the branch of Ecology that uses the principles and the concepts of Base ecology to predict and manage the environmental changes caused by human impact on natural ecosystems. Applied Ecology includes natural resource conservation, natural flora and fauna management, water resource management, pest management, pollution and ecotoxycology, natural landscape change, climate change and global warming. Applied ecology and biodiversity study are profoundly intertwined, both in the monitoring phases and in the management choices. The recent and far past clearly shows that technical and engineering choices cannot ignore environmental and ecological sustainability, to avoid the repetition of dramatic disasters like desertification of vast areas, river rectification, Vajont, Stava, Lambro and Danube poisoning, radioactive poisoning in north and south Germany, Tchernobyl and Fukushima, plastic and micro-plastic sea and soil pollution. All these disasters will result in huge costs in environmental, economical terms and they will often directly affect local population health condition. The major causes of the current important economic crisis are due to an environmental crisis that lead to a lack of resources exacerbated by human induced Climate change. This picture was generated by overexploitation and inefficiency in the use of natural resources, caused by the underestimation of the consequences of environmental problems to ecosystem services in an holistic vision. The course will deal with the environments in temperate and boreal climates and with the tropical and subtropical regions. The course will deal with theoretical fundamental elements and practical examples to understand Applied Ecology, giving hints about future developments of this science. Among the topics treated in the course: Ecocertification, biomonitoring, Biosensors, GIS, dynamic landscape modeling, definition of criteria for protected areas planning and management. Species distribution models and prediction of future landscape change with Markov Chains and Cellular automata will be treated. Seminars held by experts and visits to Applied Ecology offices will be organized. The students shall be able to apply Applied Ecology knowledge to understand the consequences of anthropic disturbance on environment and ecosystems. They shall be able to know monitoring field and modeling tools that can help the management of applied ecology. The students will be requested to write an original research paper treating and analyzing a specific topic in a critical perspective.

data.name: Vaccinologia
data.description:
The aim of the course is threefold. First, it provides  students with the understanding of basic immunology including, innate immune responses and adaptive immunity. Second, the course offers the students an overview on the mechanisms of vaccine-induced immune responses, on how vaccines are designed and formulated, and  on the economics of vaccination. Moreover, details on the main vaccines currently in use for the prophylaxis of the main human diseases are provided. Third, the course covers the topics of cancer immunotherapy, and offers an understanding of the main immunotherapeutic strategies current in use to fight cancers. the role of microbiome in cancer development is also covered. 
At the end of this course, students will be able to:
a) Describe the difference between the different types of immune responses
b) Understand how vaccine are designed 
c) Understand the mechanisms of action of vaccines
d) Understand the role of the immune system in cancer and how our immune system can be exploited to develop anti-cancer therapies.

data.name: Behavioural Economics
data.description:
Behavioral economics is a relatively new branch of economics that aims to improve the descriptive and the predictive power of the economic analysis by integrating agents’ limited cognitive abilities and limited willpower that, together with informational incompleteness, cause agents to behave sub-optimally.
This course offers an overview of the theories and the empirical results in the Behavioral Economics field allowing students to orientate themselves towards future deeper elaborations into this field of research. More specifically, the course is aimed to provide students with the opportunity to: 1) acquire a general overview of several major topics and empirical evidence in Behavioral Economics; 2) learn the basic tools for designing and carrying out a Behavioral Economics experiment; 3) acquire the basic skills for applying the Behavioral Economics insights to real world applications

data.name: Statistical Field Theory

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description:
This course provides an introduction to modern field theory as a tool to model the dynamics and thermodynamics of complex physical systems. At the end of the course, students are expected to:

1) understand the physical motivations implications of renormalisation-group based multi scale methods. Understand the path integral formalism and its advantages with respect to first-quantisation approaches in the study of complex many-body systems. 

The emphasis is given on multi-scale approaches, i.e. on the application of the renormalization group and of the effective field theory formalism to both classical and quantum systems.

2) Use field theory methods to obtain predictions for physical systems characterised by a decoupling of low- and high- energy/momentum scales.

data.description:
The course offers the "Economic Analysis of Criminal Law" bases, a discipline born at the turn of the 50s and 60s by US economists, which analyzes criminal law and the sanctioning system to check their efficiency (the ability to the reach the goal, in particular the recidivism’s rate reduction, at the lowest possible social cost, humans and economic), through the use of economic principles and models and the contribution of many different disciplines (such as criminology, statistics, sociology, psychology, economics, etc.),.
The course aims to convey a method and provide tools, useful to evaluate the criminal policy’s choices efficiency level.

data.name: Archeologia e storia dell'arte greca e romana
Recycling and sustainable materials
data.description:
Objectives:

This course is focused on materials and the environment: the eco-aspects of materials’ production, use, and disposal at end of life. The course also provides an overview of materials selection and design approaches that minimize the environmental impact.

 

After completing the course, the student will be able to:

- assess the sustainable development of a given articulation following a rigorous procedure;

- select an eco-sustainable material on the basis of its property profile and interaction with the environment;

- measure the main properties of biopolymers and wood-related materials according to the relevant standards;

- design a component taking the most suitable end-of-first-life options into proper account;

- design a life cycle assessment analysis on a practical case.

 

 

Learning outcomes:

At the end of the course, the student should be able to:

·      illustrate the concept of sustainable development and the ways in which it is evaluated for a given articulation;

·      explain the physical-mechanical properties and the applications of wood-related materials and materials for thermal insulation;

·      classify and compare the various families of biopolymers and their properties in the different applications, in order to select the best candidate material for a given application;

·      illustrate the recycling methods for the various materials, highlighting the pros and the cons of each of them;

·      explain the life cycle assessment (LCA) methodology in its theoretical and practical aspects

·      produce and characterize eco-sustainable materials, analyze the experimental data, and generate a technical report with the results and discussion of the analysis.

data.name: Bioinks and 3D printing
data.description:
Instructional goals: 

The course aims at developing knowledge about: 

- properties and formulation of (bio)materials for additive manufacturing;

- bioinks requirements for 3D printing;

- rheology of bioinks and viscoelastic properties of printed objects;

- use of 3D printers to design and fabricate devices for biomedical applications.


ILOs:

Regular and active participation and independent research activities will enable students to: 

1) Understand physico-chemical and biocompatibility properties of bioinks;

2) Understand rheological and viscoelastic properties of hydrogels, with reference to 3D printing, for tissue engineering and regenerative medicine;

3) Understand design criteria and requirements to formulate bioinks for 3D printing;

4) Knowledge of 3D printing and additive manufacturing principles;

5) Knowledge of existing biomedical products;

6) Design a 3D CAD model for 3D printing;

7) Evaluate and identify issues with printing while using viscous bioinks;

8) Understand, evaluate and identify issues with printing to match design criteria and product requirements;

9) Explain and analyze existing 3D printed technologies in the context of their field of applications (e.g. 3D scaffolds, organ-on-a-chip, perfusion systems)

10) Ability to work independently and as part of a group to design and develop a 3D printed hydrogel scaffold.

data.name: Diritto urbanistico e delle opere pubbliche
data.description:
This course studies planning law and, more generally, the legal problems involved in regulating land, including the area concerned with public works. In addition, the course aims to extend and apply what students have already learnt about administrative law.
The course also aims to illustrate (if possible, in a comparative perspective as well) the practical aspects of administrative law through a direct analysis of the most important case-law of recent years and of any other practical materials where relevant.
At the end of the course, students will be able to comprehend and properly describe the fundamental elements of the rules on planning law, in light of the distribution of powers among institutional levels. Moreover, they will be able to grasp some innovative sides, in the perspective of the future development.

data.name: Optimization techniques

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The goal of this course is to provide the fundamentals of numerical optimization. We will focus on various kinds of optimization techniques, ranging from continuous to discrete optimization methods, including global and local search methods, derivative-based and derivative-free algorithms, as well as traditional operational research techniques such as those used for solving integer programming, linear programming, and quadratic programming problems. We will address both theoretical and practical considerations, complementing each lecture on the theory with a dedicated lab. During the labs, the students will have the opportunity to test the various techniques on synthetic and real-world optimization problems.

At the end of this course, the students will be familiar with the fundamentals of numerical optimization, and will be able to apply various kinds of optimization algorithms to different contexts. They will also know the basic theory needed for developing new algorithms, or adapting/tuning them to handle new problems.

data.name: Storia medievale I - LM
Probabilità e statistica

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description:
The aim of the course is to provide students with an introduction to non-deterministic reasoning and a wide range of methods for studying random phenomena. To this purpose, the fundamentals of probability calculation, modelling of random processes and statistical inference will be presented, with both a theoretical and simulative approach using R software.
At the end of the course the student will be able to:
1) identify contexts governed by uncertainty
2) interpret contextual information by selecting appropriate tools for analysing the information
3) implement probability rules, modelling and inferential techniques in the solution of application problems
4) critically evaluate the methods used
5) develop simulations with the R software to generate numerical solutions to application problems, also using libraries available on the CRAN site (Comprehensive R Archive Network).

data.name: Biomedical metallic materials and technologies
data.description: The aim of the course is to introduce the most important metallic biomaterials and their manufacturing processes. The student will acquire useful competencies for microstructural analysis and to determine the most suited process to achieve specific properties. Moreover, he will recognize the principal metallurgical defects and will learn the principles to avoid them during manufacturing. Selected biomedical applications (orthopedic prostheses, dental implants…) will be analyzed to highlight the main degradation phenomena of metallic materials for biomedical devices and to illustrate the main selection criteria.

data.name: Neuroimaging for Data Science

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: Neuroimaging methods are pervasively used in brain and cognitive neuroscience research, and crucially depend on a multidisciplinary approach leveraging on advanced computer and data science, statistics, neuro-computational modeling, and large-scale data repositories conforming to an open-science and big-data perspective. The main objective of this course is to lay out the methodological foundations of three widely employed brain imaging techniques that are also available at CIMeC (Unitn), namely magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), magnetoencephalography (MEG), and electroencephalography (EEG). For both techniques, the course will furthermore provide an in-depth overview of state-of-the-art methods for data acquisition, data processing, statistical analysis, and multi-scale data organization. At the end of the course, students should have acquired a good overview of advanced MRI, MEG, and EEG methods, and should have learned the relevant concepts and appropriate terminology. Moreover, they should have gained an in-depth knowledge of the widely recommended resources and pipelines for data handling and processing, based on the current consensus in the neuroscientific community.

At the end of the course the student will be able to analyse and develop programs in the social field in compliance with the regulatory and procedural constraints  in the field, as well as to write correctly, also in collaborating with other people, elaborated in the field of planning and social planning using a disciplinary technical vocabulary.

data.name: Negotiation
data.description:
“Let us never negotiate out of fear. But let us never fear to negotiate.” 
John F. Kennedy

Negotiations are an essential and fundamental moment in the life of individuals, organizations, institutions, and firms. In the last few decades, negotiation has moved from the industrial relations and political arena to the forefront of managerial interest. Negotiation, bargaining, and mediation traditionally refer to the arbitration of disputes between labour and management. However, scholars and practitioners now recognise that these skills operate in virtually every management function, including strategy formulation, mergers and acquisitions, purchasing, sales, international development and many others.

Negotiation is a common mechanism for resolving differences between and allocating resources among exchange partners such as supervisors, colleagues, corporate entities and even nations. Improving negotiation skills, as well as increasing the ability to negotiate effectively, is crucial in managerial, political, and business contexts.
This module explores the key aspects of negotiation. The primary aim of this module is to integrate negotiation theory and practice, through an integration of concepts, models, expertise and practical experience. It will typically examine, through a mix of theory and practice, the links among negotiation fundamentals, negotiation sub-processes and negotiation contexts.

Learning objectives

The purpose of this course is threefold. 
•	The first is to explore the major concepts and theories of negotiation, as well as the dynamics of interpersonal and intergroup conflict and its resolution. This will entail material about the structural (e.g. parties, issues, positions and interest) and process-oriented (cognitive, interactional) dynamics that are necessary for a sound critical background. 
•	The second objective is to develop skills relevant to a broad range of applied contexts. This involves direct training in identifying crucial elements of a negotiation situation and implementing appropriate resolution strategies. 
•	The third objective is to encourage participants to assume a “reflective” and “cooperative” posture about negotiations specifically and social influence broadly. 

On completion of the module you should be able to:

•	Analyse a negotiation situation and its possible solutions.
•	Identify the personal challenges we all have in dealing with negotiation.
•	Apply complex theory and practice of negotiation in particular and general contexts.

data.name: Mathematical models for the Physical, Natural and Social Sciences
data.description:
Knowledge and understanding

Students will be able to define what a mathematical model is (and what it is not) and will be able to state, understand and explain specific models. They will be able to recall the historical and theoretical development that led to their formulation.

Application and analysis

Students will be able to use a mathematical model with data in order to make predictions, as well as interpret the results obtained. They will also be able to analyse different models and compare their assumptions and structure.

Evaluation and creation

Students will be able to evaluate a model and its use. They will be able to notice the mathematical structure involved in real-world phenomena and develop simple mathematical models to describe them.

Communication skills

Students will be able to design suitable presentations, at different levels of rigour and detail depending on the audience, the context, the medium and the format.

They will be able to search the literature and other resources for suitable examples and ideas to flesh out a presentation. They will be able to self-assess their work and appraise those of others, understand the feedback received and implement it to improve their work.

data.name: Design methods for industrial engineering
data.description: The aim of this course is to give future engineers the basic criteria to plan and define the design step, as a part of the lifecycle of industrial products, by means of the methods for the design of components and assemblies, also considering functionality, reliability, manufacturing, assembly, verification, maintenance and recycling. After the course students will be able to exploit the most recent methodologies for data management and communication tools, specific design methods for creativity enhancement, performance evaluation, and Robust Design. They will properly approach the industrial design process, by means of the methods, which allow defining for each product shape, materials and production processes according to the required functionality.
data.degreeProgram: Materials and production Engineering - Ingegneria dei materiali e della produzione (LM)

data.name: Cartografia numerica e GIS

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
The course aims to provide notions and tools for the correct use of numerical cartography and GIS Geographic Information System).
Theoretical knowledge is provided to understand the basis of numerical cartography and how these effects the potentiality and limits of the GIS implementations and their applications. Digital tools for the management and analysis of spatial information are described, with particular regard to environmental applications. An overview of the available map data and GIS software is provided along with practical examples. The use of a GIS package is described in detail, with use demonstration.

At the end of the course the student will be able to:
- find and collect digital cartography and connected information for an Italian area
- organize and manage a digital maps dataset, applying transformations of format and datum
- design and implement an environmental model and evaluate its application in a critical manner, applying quantitative analyses in a GIS

data.name: Economia ed estimo civile

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
The course deals with fundamental topics in Economic Theory (Micro and Macro Economics) and Economic Appraisal practice, the latter concerned as a specific branch of the applications of Economic Theory. Although aimed at the real needs of Engineering and Architecture, the course has a high cultural inspiration. Thus, it takes place giving particular emphasis to the conceptual and founding aspects of the covered topics, which are addressed with extensive use of mathematical tools (Mathematical Analysis, Statistics, Financial Mathematics, and Operational Research) and presented in their historical genesis.

At the end of the course, the expected results from students mainly consist of a scientific viewpoint growth. It deals with the knowledge of rigorous analysis tools, which are essential to face the relevant economic aspects that characterize the current technical practice (i.e., Technical and Economic Analysis in their most diversified articulations), including some issues in the Economic Apparaising.

-They will also be familiar with (and will be able to discuss) the reasearch designs and the main contributions of national and international theoretically driven empirical research in the field of economic sociology; more specifically, they will be able to consider and discuss the relation between institutional configurations, macro level factors, alternative policy settings, and group-specific micro-level exposure to distinct socio-economic conditions

Contrary to a standard robotic competition, the student will have to discuss the theoretical underpinning of the method she/he chose to adopt for the competition.

data.name: ICT Innovation

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: Course Objectives This course illustrates the key steps of product design and developement and guide students, forming multi-disciplinary teams, into the development of a “product” as opposed to just a “project”. We often see nice proof-of-concept research demonstration of useful tools in magazines or on web-sites. What does it take to make this a product? Everybody can sell a beautiful concept if you don't have to build it. Also anybody can build a amazing device if you don't have to sell it. This challenging course combines the two requirements. Students have to talk to customers to understand what features are relally needed and for what costs. Students have also to make sure they can actually deliver the technological solution (that the customers wanted). For example, you can design a scarecrow drone that flies over the crops with a predefined set-up. Unless you talk to farmers you'll never realize that random walk is necessary to actually scare the crows. Further, automatic charging as well as automated landing by computer vision and machine learning are mission critical, so that the farmer doesn't need to be there. All this with cheap mechanical, electronic, and computing solutions as the budget is extremely tight. You might have invented the idea of an iPod-style to provide news to the blind and your first technical solutions might have been to use Braille. Unless you talked (as the Joni group did) to the blind association, you are not going to discover that the majority of your customers in Italy have become blind later in life and a product that requires learning Braille at 50s-and-more is not going to be a great success. It is great for campers, to have an anti-theft device in your tent. Yet, what if it starts blasting if you just put a rucksack in the wrong position in your own tent? All these products, and many more, were built by students participating to this course. Overarching Learning Objectives - Creativity: How to solve problems when not all steps are completely specified (this what you should try to do with your design/architectural result) - Intellectual Transformation: How to transform an idea into a product (the first “brainstorming” step is your research canvas, the last one is the final product) by using conceptual tools from economics, mechatronic engineering, and computer science. - Leadership: Organize yourselves into a team and arrive to make a final product (you should try to leverage on each other’s competences) - Making value judgement: Decide which parts are important and which are not also on the basis of ethical and social considerations. Intended Learning Outcomes Regular and active participation in the teaching activities offered by the course (lectures, supervised and indipendent group work in multi-disciplinary teams) will enable students to: - Learn key steps of Product Design and Development (PD&D) - Create a product concept which will be presented as concept's idea canvas to illustrate the key strong points on their product and their interaction with stakeholders - Design a detailed architecture product architecture and present it in a poster explaining how their product will work and which would be their strong point - Produce a final product as each team will have a small budget for hardware/software and will have to actually demonstrate a working product - Market their concept idea as the teams will interact with stakeholders to make sure that the product that they intend to build has actually a market. This course should allow students to experience the creativity, intellectual transformation, leadership and value judgements skills which take to transform an idea into a working and sellable product.

data.name: Experimental Physics Laboratory at High School Level II
data.description:
The course aims to prepare students as future teachers of experimental physics courses by introducing them to experimental techniques, teaching methodologies and the design of didactic experiences.
This course aims to provide an introduction to the methodological aspects with particular reference to the organization of the didactic aspects, the conduction of a lesson and the design of teaching sequences.
Finally, the course aims to acquire familiarity with experimental equipment of the didactic laboratory, data acquisition and analysis software, simulation environments and new teaching technology.

Various experimental activities will be presented from an educational point of view and some case studies will be considered by adopting both traditional laboratory equipment and new technologies applied to the didactic laboratory of physics.
Practical activities will be carried out directly by students divided into working groups.

At the end of the course, the student will be able to
1) independently design experience and educational sequences
2) Perform experiments using appropriately the equipment of the physics lab
3) Analyze experimental data using commonly used software
4) use video analysis software
5) build simulations using appropriate software

data.name: Analisi matematica III
International political economy

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description: The scholarly field of International Political Economy (IPE) is broadly concerned with the interrelationship between political and economic processes in international relations. The course introduces students to this subfield of political science aiming to attain three broad sets of objectives. First, the course aims to offer students a comprehensive set of conceptual and theoretical tools to understand the political dynamics that underpin, and are engendered by, international economic processes. The first part of the course introduces students to the main theoretical approaches to the study of the international political economy, offering an overview of the main contending perspectives on key questions within this field of inquiry (e.g. Who are the main actors? Under what conditions do relevant actors mobilize politically and exert political influence? Which factors facilitate processes of institutionalized international cooperation?). Second, the course aims to familiarize students with both theoretical and normative debates on the politics of international economic relations across six key issue areas: international trade, international monetary relations, international finance, Foreign Direct Investments, foreign aid, and the globalization/nation state nexus. For each of these issue areas, this second part of the course offers 1) an overview of the politics underpinning the patterns of economic exchange that we observe today and throughout history 2) an in-depth analysis of selected seminal theory-driven contributions in the field, and 3) a discussion of the related real-world normative trade-offs. Third, the course aims to train students in a critical reflection of different options for applying theories and methods in the context of simulated “real-world” decision making processes. The activities carried out within the “laboratory” section of the course will be instrumental to achieving this aim by 1) training students to write a policy-memo, and 2) simulating a negotiation concerning a particular international political issue.

data.description: By the end of the course, the student is expected to be familiar with the language of economics and the main methods and models used in this field. In addition, the student should be able to apply these methods and models to analyze situations that occur daily in a modern market economy and to critically consider the potential benefits, failures, and unwanted consequences of economic policies.

data.name: Algebra commutativa
data.description:
At the end of the course the student should obtain the following abilities:
1) Knowledge and understanding: A good comprehension and grasp of the basic arguments of commutative algebra as specified in the program of my course.  To get it the students we (myself together with the other students) will discuss the solutions of homeworks (which may be done together by groups of students). Optional are short manuscripts or expositions of parts of the program.
2) Applying knowledge and understanding: Ability to apply their knowledge and comprehension.To be able to do abstract logical deductions and euristic deductions in problems related to congruences and the use of multivariate polinomials and in linear algebra over a ring, e.g. the integers or a ring of polynomials.
3) Autonomy and making judgements: To be able to produce logical arguments and make correct proofs. To be able to guess the tools and the methods useful for the analysis and the resolutions of problems related to the program. To be able to frame a concrete problem as an abstract one, if useful to solve it.
4) Communication skills: At the end the student should be able to discuss several questions and topics related to algebra, even in elementary situations (e.g. congruences and linear algebra over the integers) and see their use for computational problems.
5) Learning skills and comprehension: To get new informations and to be able to handle them, mostly related either to computational problems or to geometrical problems or of elementary number theory.

data.description:
What is reading literature for today? And how can you read the narratives?

The course aims at answering these questions with particular attention to prejudices and stereotypes about literature. At the end of the course, students are expected: to relate literary knowledge with the one of other subjects; to use the literary knowledge in order to critically read contemporary literature; to update knowledge and skills indipendently, by finding literary texts appropriate to personal research and working enviroments.

data.name: ICT Innovation - Product Design and Development

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: Course Objectives This course illustrates the key steps of product design and developement and guide students, forming multi-disciplinary teams, into the development of a “product” as opposed to just a “project”. We often see nice proof-of-concept research demonstration of useful tools in magazines or on web-sites. What does it take to make this a product? Everybody can sell a beautiful concept if you don't have to build it. Also anybody can build a amazing device if you don't have to sell it. This challenging course combines the two requirements. Students have to talk to customers to understand what features are relally needed and for what costs. Students have also to make sure they can actually deliver the technological solution (that the customers wanted). For example, you can design a scarecrow drone that flies over the crops with a predefined set-up. Unless you talk to farmers you'll never realize that random walk is necessary to actually scare the crows. Further, automatic charging as well as automated landing by computer vision and machine learning are mission critical, so that the farmer doesn't need to be there. data.description: Understanding how institutional and technological environment influence firms' behaviour

data.name: Innovation processes and the new production of users
data.description:
The course equips students with concepts and methods to apply in order to take into account the active role of users in innovation processes and, at the same time, how organizations and designers stimulate users to engage with innovations.
Although traditionally dismissed by managers and engineers, the productive role of users is under constant development. Nowadays, users play different roles in innovation, production and consumption than they did previously. Users develop new forms of innovative collectives that enable their engagement with products and technologies; users generate contents, products and ideas; users face creative managers, designers and producers who will develop new strategies for involving and analyzing other users. Focusing on the new production of users therefore means both detecting the new production by users and highlighting organizational efforts to produce active and reliable users.

data.name: Tecniche psicometriche e analisi dei dati

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description:
The course aims to provide knowledge and skills related to the analysis of data from observational or experimental studies in psychosocial research.
At the end of the course, students will be able to identify the type of experimental design used and analyze the results obtained by choosing the appropriate inferential technique.

data.name: Advanced social network analysis

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description: Through this course, students: a) will learn how social network analysis can help answer research questions in areas, such as sociology, anthropology, psychology, epidemiology, criminology, political science, communication science, management, and educational research; b) will become familiar with (statistical) methods to explore such social network research questions; c) will actively learn how to apply their knowledge to specific datasets.

data.name: Political Philosophy
data.description: This course aims at analyzing some of the most important political-philosophical concepts applied to international politics, following their historical development. Selected readings by thinkers such as Kant, Hegel, Cobden, Marx, Kelsen, Schmitt, Morgenthau, Aron and others will be analyzed and discussed. The course includes lectures and active student participation. Students will make oral presentations on specific case studies and lead discussions.

data.name: Biomedical metallic materials and technologies
data.description: The aim of the course is to introduce the most important metallic biomaterials and their manufacturing processes. The student will acquire useful competencies for microstructural analysis and to determine the most suited process to achieve specific properties. Moreover, he will recognize the principal metallurgical defects and will learn the principles to avoid them during manufacturing. Selected biomedical applications (orthopedic prostheses, dental implants…) will be analyzed to highlight the main degradation phenomena of metallic materials for biomedical devices and to illustrate the main selection criteria.
data.degreeProgram: Materials and production Engineering - Ingegneria dei materiali e della produzione (LM)

data.name: Storia della banca e della finanza
data.description: The course in History of Banking and Finance aims at providing students with an interpretative framework of the patterns of growth and transformation of financial and credit businesses. Objective of the course is to let students develop knowledge on how banking structures have changed across time, in response to the needs emerging in the different phases of social and economic transformation. The students must therefore be able to grasp, through historical-cultural reasoning, how the current dynamics of the banking firm have emerged. A broad view combining the investigation on the role of credit intermediaries with analysis of the economic transformations in the early modern and contemporary periods, will enable students to understand the role of banks and bankers in all their complexity, in order to evaluate their operating effectiveness. Special attention will be devoted to the origins and subsequent development of cooperative credit, which will be examined both in its strengths and critical aspects, against the backdrop of the different phases of economic transformations in which it operated.

data.name: Laboratory of biological data mining
data.description:
Goal of the module is to provide the student with the notions of data mining that are necessary in order to mine genomic and transcriptomic data and the practical skills to preprocess and mine biological data.
At the end of the module the student  should be able to: recall and discuss the techniques presented, reading the literature about similar techniques, preprocess and mine a specific instance of biological data, report and present the results.

data.name: History of Western Legal Tradition - advanced course
data.description:
Students will acquire knowledge of the history of legal status of Jews in Western legal tradition as a paradigm and model of citizenship and of the relationship between rulers and governed.

They will also learn to read and use the main sources of that legal tradition, alone and in relation to the theological and philosophical ones.

data.name: Advanced mechanical systems
data.description:
In this course, students learn how to model, design, and describe multi-physics systems of technical relevance, with a special focus on electro-mechanical and fluidic drives and transducers.

At the end of the course, students will be able to

-         Build lumped-parameter models of transducers and multi-physics systems

-         Build and solve numerically (with Matlab & Simulink) dynamic models of simple multi-physics systems

-         Understand and describe the operating principle of technically relevant systems (electrostatic machines, electromagnetic drives, pneumatic and hydraulic drives)

-         Read datasheets and understand the technological constraints of different types of drives

-         Process and interpret data from experiments, and use them to identify/fit a model of the system

 

The course starts with an introduction on energy methods to describe multi-physics systems, and then presents a gallery of technically relevant systems (electrostatic machines, electromagnetic drives, pneumatic and hydraulic drives). For each of the considered technologies, modelling approaches, design principles, technological constraints are discussed. Finally, some fundamental concepts of experimental data analysis and system identification are reviewed, with reference to the considered technical systems.

 Theoretical concepts are supported by exercises and examples carried out in Matlab & Simulink environment.

data.name: Fluid Machines Engineering

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
The course discusses the main power generating systems, either fossil-fueled or renewable.

Innovative systems and technologies like wind turbines, run-off hydro turbines, and high-temperature gas turbines are presented and discussed.

Plants are detailed and discussed from the point of view of efficiency.

The student will also be able to analyze power-generating systems from a technical-economic point of view.

 


Knowledge and understanding:

Basic knowledge of work, power, and efficiency of fluid machines and power-generating systems.

 

Applying knowledge and understanding:

The student will be able to analyse fluid machines to quantify the functioning parameters, obtain the efficiency and carry out basic design calculations.

 

Making judgements:

The student will be able to select the proper equipment and compare alternative solutions.

 


Communication skills:

The student will be able to discuss, set specifications, and form educated questions concerning fluid machines and power-generating systems.

 

Ability to learn:

The student will be able to self-improve his know-how through a critical end selective acquisition of information on the discipline of fluid machines.

data.name: Psicobiologia degli apprendimenti culturali

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description: The aim of the course is to provide the student with an understanding of the cognitive and neural bases of two important culturally transmitted "high - level" cognitive functions: reading and maths. The course will be structured in two parts. The first part will deal with the psychobiological bases of reading. The second part will address the cognitive basics of calculation skills, and their neural correlations, with particular emphasis on evolutionary aspects, both phylogenetic and ontogenetic. In both modules the arguments will be constructed by illustrating examples from different fields (neuropsychology, electrophysiology, psychophysics, both on humans and on non-human animals), thus providing the student with the opportunity to deepen his / her knowledge of different methods of investigation in cognitive neuroscience. Students are expected  to become familiar with the neurocognitive architectures subtending these basic skills, and to be able to critically evaluate, in light of such knowledge, the various existing and potential educational and/or rehabilitation tools for dyslexia and dyscalculia.
data.degreeProgram: Scienze e Tecniche di Psicologia Cognitiva (L2)

data.name: Introduzione alla meccanica statistica
data.description:
The course aims at providing the basic elements of statistical mechanics, in particular on the description of classical systems in thermodynamical equilibrium with N degrees of freedom and the basic elements of quantum statistical mechanics.

At the end of the course the student will be able to: 1) Understand the relationship between the microscopic dynamics of a classical system of interacting particles and its thermodynamic properties; 2) Predict the thermodynamic properties of systems described by simple Hamiltonian functions; 3) Describe a thermodynamic system in quantum mechanics, specifying the difference between bosons and fermions; 4) Understand when and how quantum effects become important in the description of a many-body system.

data.name: Start-up Lab_
data.description:
The course introduces to the topic of business design, a methodology for designing truly innovative products and services: desired by customers, economically sustainable, through an iterative and incremental methodology that allows you to test the main assumptions underlying the business model before launching on the market your product or service.

The course combines traditional elements of market analysis and business strategy with contents and methods taken from the disciplines of design thinking and human-centred design, in order to help the rapid prototyping of value propositions for the customer, revenue and capture of value and methods of delivering value (partnerships, sales channels) to the end customer.  Whether you want to learn how to work on new projects within an existing business or organization, or you want to become an entrepreneur ready to start a startup, this course will help you reduce the risks of launching the product on the market, helping to develop entrepreneurial ideas representing an innovative solution to a problem felt for a specific market segment.

By the end of this course, students will learn:
how to work in a multidisciplinary team with teammates coming from different cultures.
how to develop an entrepreneurial approach to problems, to look for innovative solutions creatively and to define projects that suit customers needs effectively.
the necessary vocabulary, knowledge, and skills to develop a solution for solving a market need and to define a viable business model for it.
how to use design thinking, lean validation methodologies, business modelling techniques and other startup tools to define an innovative business project.
how to apply basic tools of market analysis, financial modelling, cash flow analysis, project management to your innovative business idea.
how to communicate effectively your project to teammates, stakeholders, mentors, and how to present it in front of an international jury.

After the language classes, students will reach the Passive C1 level in English for tourism, according to the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages.

data.name: Introduzione all’analisi empirica della società

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
The course has two complementary objectives:

-To provide examples of social research and to illustrate the first elements of empirical research methods, through an introduction to the logic and aims of social research, an illustration of the procedures for selecting different types of available data, their systematisation, a description of the variables and characteristics of the units of analysis and their use in explaining different social phenomena. It will be shown and discussed in the classroom with students how basic statistical tools can be used to empirically answer substantive sociological questions.

-Beginning with the reading and interpretation of data available in the sociological literature and/or in the production of statistical institutes, the aim is to provide a picture of the main characteristics and transformations of Italian society in recent decades


The students will be able to analytically decline a research question starting from a sociologically relevant question, to define the outlines of the phenomenon under examination, to choose and find the data useful for conducting the study, to select the variables and factors relevant to the analysis, to empirically process the data by means of simple descriptive statistics tools

data.name: Introduction to Machine Learning

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: This course provides a broad introduction to machine learning and statistical pattern recognition.  The course will cover different topics ranging from supervised learning (parametric/non-parametric algorithms, kernel methods, feedforward neural networks), unsupervised learning (clustering, dimensionality reduction, autoencoders, deep generative models) and reinforcement learning. In the final part of the course some applications of machine learning will be presented in the field of computer vision, robotics and natural language processing. Theoretical discussion will be complemented with lab in Python using open-source libraries.

data.name: Statistical Models

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: At the end of this module, the students will be able to use modern regression techniques, such as generalized linear models, to study the relation between continuous or discrete variables and predictors. They will be able to use both supervised and unsupervised learning techniques. They will have a basic knowledge of the fundamental theoretical aspects and they will know how to apply them to practical cases through the use of a statistical software.

data.name: Physics 2

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: The present course aims to provide the basic physical knowledge related to the analysis of electrical networks. The methodologies for measuring the physical quantities in play and the parameters relevant for the characterization of linear components will be discussed. The methodologies for the analysis of circuits in continuous and alternating current regime will also be presented. In particular, the analysis in the time domain and by Laplace transform will be discussed. Finally, notes on the generation, distribution and use of electricity will be provided.
data.degreeProgram: Ingegneria Informatica, delle Comunicazioni ed Elettronica (L2)

data.name: Calcolatori

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The goal of this course is to provide the basic notions about the organization and architecture of computing machines, either general-purpose computers, or specialized architectures designed to handle specific tasks. Furthermore, the course provides basic knowledge about the assembly language (in particular using as a reference RISC-V and briefly discussing the Intel and ARM architectures), the HW/SW interface, and the low-level mechanisms of a computer. Finally, the course also provides the fundamental knowledge needed to attend advanced courses focused on the design of computer systems from the hardware perspective.

This course does not require any preliminary knowledge. The structure of the course is especially suited for students with a CV oriented towards software and systems, who during their Bachelor Degree have the chance to learn about computer architectures only through this course. On the other hand, the course will also provide the fundamental knowledge needed to attend advanced courses focused on the design of computer systems from the hardware perspective.

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: N/A
