data.name: Sensing and Radar Technologies

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
This course provides basic and advanced concepts as well as design capabilities in the framework of systems based on remote sensing (from satellites, airborne and UAV platforms), proximal sensing, in-situ (ground) sensing, and ancillary data for environmental monitoring, climate change analysis, civil protection, infrastructure monitoring, remote surveillance and planetary exploration. It introduces remote sensing methodologies, technologies and techniques that are fundamental for the design of the above-mentioned systems with the last generation of optical and radar sensors. It describes the approach to the design and implementation of systems for several applications and operative scenarios, including the design criteria for the choice of the sensors, the system architecture and data analysis techniques complementary to more general artificial intelligence and machine learning techniques presented in other mandatory courses.
There is a large part of the course that is common to all the students and another part (section 2) for which each attendee can select one between two modules: Module a) basics concepts in remote sensing and technologies for the acquisition of optical and radar images; or Module b) advanced concepts and design criteria for Earth observation and planetary exploration satellite missions. It is suggested that students that have not attended any basic remote sensing course follow Module a) while the others select Module b).
The theoretical lectures are complemented by practical examples on real systems including laboratory activities.

data.name: People, Politics and the Planet

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
Upon completion of this module students are expected to have acquired the following: 
1)	An understanding of major discourses of environmental politics.
2)	Knowledge of a variety of contemporary issues in global environmental politics.
3)	An understanding of a range of multilateral environmental agreements and their impacts for national and local politics.
4)	An understanding of the range of key actors in global environmental politics at the local, national and international levels. 
5)	The ability to apply critical thinking skills to the analysis of complex governance approaches to environmental problems.
6)	Consider how global environmental politics affects local experiences, and how civil society actions at different territorial levels may shape, and be shaped in turn by, global environmental politics. 

In addition, students who successfully complete this module should gain the following transferable skills:
7)	The ability to learn independently and to assume responsibility for the learning process.
8)	Broad academic skills in the areas of critical reading and analysis, library and online research, note-taking and time management.
9)	Confidence in participating respectfully in class discussion and dialogue.
10)	Skills in written academic argument and confidence in crafting academic papers of an appropriate standard of written academic English.
11)	Understanding of issues relating to academic research – evaluating research sources, research methodologies, citation of research materials, management of materials and the avoidance of plagiarism and intellectual dishonesty.

data.name: Linguistica francese I
data.description:
The course aims to improve capacity in oral and written French through the study of the following aspects : the forms and functions of oral narrative genres.

Students will acquire the ability to analyse the structure and function of certain oral narrative genres produced in the context of natural verbal interactions, to identify the narrative strategies employed according to context, and to examine the type of relationship established with interlocutors.

An integral part of the present course is the written entrance test of language proficiency. Only after having passed the test, students can take the final exam. More information will be provided by the language instructors.

data.name: Geografia I - LT
data.description:
Landscape, environment, and territory have become crucial in the national and international debate about governance and heritage.

The course aims to provide students with basic and advanced conceptual tools of the geohistorical and historical geographic approach, for the purpose to develop a critical and diachronic approach to territorial, environmental, and landscape issues, also with application and enhancement aims.

Students will acquire skills in reading and interpreting the main sources for geohistorical and historical geographic research (textual, iconographic, cartographic, territorial).

At the end of the course, students:

1. will have an in-depth overview of the considerations on geographic-historical and geohistorical epistemology at an international level;

2. will develop an analytical mastery of historical sources and geographical and thematic maps; therefore, they will be able to develop a diachronic reading of territorial and landscape elements also with applicative purposes such as the identification of the historical-environmental heritage and the planning of laboratories for the learning of history and geography;

3. will become aware of the most advanced methods and tools of geographical-historical research;

4. will consolidate the knowledge of the geographical language and of new digital technologies applied to the discipline, both for research purposes and for their use in specific teaching and learning processes of history and geography.

data.name: Diritto della contabilità pubblica
data.description:
The regulation of public finance is a matter of great legal importance, not only for its relevance in defining the interweaving between national law and the European Union, but - since its origins  - for its position as a sector of the legal system that (although specialist) conditions transversally the most general institutes of constitutional, administrative, civil and criminal law.
The examination of the rules through which the State spends, engaging in pecuniary obligations functional to the performance of its activities, is in fact crucial for the better understanding of many other areas of legal studies, from the extension of the protection of social rights to the articulation of the administrative procedure, from the effectiveness of territorial autonomy to the framework of the responsibilities of public officials, etc.
From a very sectorial topic (closed within the national level), therefore, public accounting has increasingly become a discipline open to the European dimension and in dialogue with the other branches of the legal system, as instrumental or conditioning for the related decisions. Accounting harmonization is indeed - increasingly - the true common alphabet of administration, especially in a phase of strong rationalization of public spending, and - on this basis - the understanding of account rules is both one of the main common competences required for competitions to serve in all public administrations, so as a fundamental cultural skill of legal operators that operate close to the public administrations.
The presence of a special judge for public accounting, if on the one hand has contributed to make the study of the subject specialized, on the other hand makes the interest for the discipline culturally relevant also for its peculiarities on the technical-legal level. The jurisprudence of the Court of Auditors offers to the study of the subject not only a rich and varied series of cases, but also some refined institutions and mechanisms - both in the areas of control and in the jurisdictional competence - where the jurists can find many ideas also for the best critical understanding of the most general institutes of the legal system.
The aim of the course is therefore to provide a preliminary, summarized and comprehensible image of the essential contents and of the transversal vocation of public accounting. On the one hand to allow those who want to deepen study the issue to start from a solid institutional basis, and on the other side to provide those who will deal with other sectors of the legal system (both in administrative law, as well as in criminal law and in the various areas of private law) with the tools useful to dialogue about the technicalities of accounting when their profession will be in touch with the public sphere.

data.name: Processi partecipativi di governance

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
What role do citizens have in a democracy? What challenges do citizens face? What is the relation between representative democracy and citizens’ participation? What deliberation means in this context? These questions invite to think critically about what we mean by “democracy”, “participation” and “deliberation”. This course will explore these concepts and will introduce the students to the new main tools and strategies used by local governments to involve citizens in the policy-making process.
This course is designed to enable students to:
•	Significantly deepen their understanding of a variety of models and theories of democracy, and how these models conceptualize the nature and practice of citizenship and politics
•	Explore the theory of participatory and deliberative democracy, in particular
•	Develop a critical view of the roles that scientific methods, expertise, and knowledge do, might, and/or should play in addressing public problems.

data.name: Geotecnica

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
The aim of the course is to equip the students with the basic notions of the mechanical behaviour of saturated soils, of laboratory and in-situ tests for characterizing the hydraulic and mechanical response of soils and of the methods used in engineering practice for analysing service and limit state conditions. These notions are needed for understanding and studying the subsequent, applicative courses of Geotechnical Engineering
At the end of the course, the students will be able to:
- Evaluate the in-situ stress state with and without groundwater flow and the stress changes induced by external loadings 
- Analyse confined and unconfined groundwater flows with simple graphical methods or write the basic relationships for their numerical solution with the finite difference method
- Select the laboratory and in-situ tests that are the most suitable for a given engineering problem and evaluate the experimental results for characterizing mechanical and hydraulic properties
- Evaluate the settlements induced by primary and secondary consolidation induced by simple loading conditions (e.g. a large embankment or a change of pore pressures at the boundaries)
- Use the critical state model for predicting the mechanical soil response
- Evaluate the horizontal earth pressure with the different methods proposed in literature and used in engineering practice
- Know the basics of limit analysis and its application to simple practical cases.

data.name: Protezione idraulica dei territori montani

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
‎The primary objective of the course is to provide a qualitative and quantitative approach to the subject of hydraulic 'natural hazards' characterising mountain environments.


The course aims to provide the following knowledge:

========================================

• concepts of hazard and risk associated with natural hazards of the hydraulic type

• knowledge of the origin and dynamics of mountain natural hazards such as avalanches, torrential floods and debris flows;

• the physical-mathematical description of the phenomena underlying natural hazards (mathematical modelling) and the characteristics of the numerical tools used to simulate these hazards;

• typology and functioning of mitigation works, in relation to the different types of phenomena to which they are directed. In particular:

=> for avalanches:

> rigid support works (bridges and snow racks)

> flexible support works (snow nets)

> references to other types of works

=> For flows and torrential floods:

> storage areas

> open weirs

> gullies


• references to regulatory aspects relating to the subject.


It aims to develop the following skills:

=============================

• ability to use numerical modelling tools for avalanche phenomena, debris flows and intense torrential solid transport

• ability to interpret and assess the quality of the simulations carried out and to choose the calibration parameters appropriately;

• ability to draw up a danger map for avalanches and debris flows;

• ability to design, from a hydraulic point of view, mitigation works in relation to the different types of phenomena to which they are directed.



It is also planned to provide some seminars on civil protection issues.
data.degreeProgram: Ingegneria per l'ambiente e il territorio (LM)

data.name: Tecnica urbanistica

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
The course aims at introducing students to urban planning developing a teaching programme that is theoretical, analytical and project-oriented.
The subject is introduced by illustrating the plurality of issues involved (urban regeneration, TDR, planning history, and so on) and the variety of theories and approaches adopted (incremental planning, participatory planning, ecological planning), providing the students with a framework for urban analysis and the identification of the effects of development decisions and localization of activities in territorial and urban contexts. Methods and tools for urban design and planning will be provided.
During the course the following topics will be covered: the relationship between man and the environment, urban development processes, urban morphology and urban components, the legal framework for regional and urban planning. 
A key role is played by the study of analytical methods, also by means of a practical exercise, which will allow to consolidate analytical abilities and to better understand the effects of the building activity and engineering works on territorial and urban contexts.
The development of a project will require the comprehension of the theoretical contents and the operational tools furnished and implies an appropriate use of the knowledge and competences acquired in other subjects characterizing the civil engineering course, in order to combine the diverse components of the urban physical space (roads, buildings, equipment, etc.) into a coherent structure characterized by living qualities. 
At the end of the course, students will be able to make use of analytical and operational tools that are appropriate for spatial and urban issues.
In particular, they will be able to analyze a territorial and urban context, to understand and apply land use plans prescriptions and building regulations, to elaborate syntheses for supporting urban scale interventions.

data.name: Elementi di pensiero teologico
data.description:
The educational objective of the ELEMENTS OF THEOLOGICAL THINKING course, located in the first year of the master's degree course in "Philosophy and Languages ​​of Modernity", in the light of the provisions of the educational offer of the degree course, consists, first of all, in putting students in a position to master themes and theoretical knots of Christian theology in a mature way. Secondly, the course intends, through the in-depth understanding of a topic or a relevant author in the field of theological thought, to guide students to deal with issues related to the relationship between philosophy and theology.


Expected learning outcomes

Attendance and active participation in the lessons of the course, as well as individual study will ensure that students, at the end of the teaching of ELEMENTS of THEOLOGICAL THOUGHT will be able to

a) identify and confidently expose the key terms and conceptual nodes examined during the course;

b) reconstruct the thought of the authors treated in a detailed way and contextualize it in the more general context of the relationship between philosophy and theology;

c) analyze in depth the texts addressed from time to time;

d) expose the in-depth study conducted on one of the specifically indicated texts in a seminar context.

data.name: Economia e misurazione aziendale
data.description: This course aims to provide students with basic knowledge about organizations and business management, and to foster critical thinking on the role of enterprises in the contemporary economy. The course will begin with an overview of the ongoing debate on the firm’s ultimate goal from both the shareholders and the stakeholders’ views. Subsequent to a review of the core business activities, it will then provide the basic notions of accounting and performance evaluation metrics, and a detailed overview of quantitative decisions-making models, such as economies of scale, learning curves, break-even/profit points, operating leverage etc. Furthermore, it will offer an accurate presentation and discussion of models for strategic analysis, including those with a longitudinal perspective. The course will end with a thorough examination of corporate governance, inquiring into managerial interests, mis-management and potential remedies. At the end of the course, the students will be able: 1. to understand and illustrate, with competence and expertise, the debate on the nature and purpose of enterprises, as institutions aimed at resolving the tension between wealth creation and social demands; 2. to understand, use and evaluate accounting and measurement performance systems; 3. to understand and use quantitative models in support of operation and management decisions; 4. to understand and competently speak about the problem of corporate governance, with a particular focus on the role of managers and the internal/external mechanisms to align shareholders’ and managerial interests; 5. to evaluate and critically assess the functioning and strategies of enterprises in modern economies and their ability to pursue long term success, preserving the financial and institutional equilibria-

data.name: Chimica agraria e biochimica con esercitazioni
data.description:
The aim of the course is to provide basic knowledge to understand the main properties of a soil and of its fertility as well as the chemical reactions occurring in the cell and their impact on grape production.
At the end of the course the student will be able to describe the key properties of a soil, to evaluate its fertility and the presence of nutritional deficiencies. The student will also be able to discuss the function of the main biomolecules within the cellular structures, including enzymes and their properties, the basics of bioenergetics and trans-membrane transport, the main metabolic pathways and their regulation and their impact on viticulture.

The objective of the course is the investigation of some methodologies which guarantee secure access to multimedia data, through various data hiding and digital forensics techniques. The student at the end of the course will know a series of state-of-art methodologies for the active and passive forensics analysis of multimedia data and he/she will know how to apply them to digital images in simple scenarios.

data.name: Fisica nucleare e subnucleare
data.description:
The course aims to give to the students some basic notions of nuclear and subnuclear physics, taking into account of the general level and of the knowledge of the formalism of quantum mechanics that can be reached by a student at the third year of the Bachelor. It is a pretty phenomenological exposition, with particular focus on the experiments, aiming to provide the basic notions that are part of the common heritage of physics graduates, besides giving the inspiration for a possible deeper study of the subject during the Master courses. At the end of the course the student is expected to:
1) Give proof of knowledge of the basic notions constituting the language of nuclear and subnuclear physics (e.g. the concepts of particle/antiparticle, use of natural units, scattering processes...)
2) Be aware of the main experiments, of the phenomenology and on general aspects of the thories that contributed to our present knowledge of the world of subatomic particles;
3) Be able to solve simple exercises demonstrating that the student is indeed mastering the concepts acquired in the course.

data.name: Psicologia del lavoro

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description:
The course aims to introduce students the basic concepts of work psychology. Specifically, we want to:
(A) Encourage the acquisition of knowledge of the discipline, its areas of study and intervention, providing elements for understanding the interaction between individuals and working environments, with particular reference to technological innovation, to recent changes in labor market and organizational dynamics; To foster the ability to re-elaborate knowledge in a critical and original way and to build links with professional practice through, for example, group and class discussions and case study exercises; Foster the understanding of the texts for the preparation of final exam.
B) Encourage the acquisition of communicative skills through activities where synthetic, targeted and original oral and / or digital presentations will be requested; Encourage the acquisition of transversal skills (working in team, proactivity and critical approach) through group exercises.
Regular attendance at the lessons and activities included in the course will enable students to:
A) Understand the theoretical models and the principles underlying the discipline with particular reference to the application of the concepts acquired in the observation of working groups and contexts, in reading the phenomena relating to the labor market, study and research; Build links between theoretical models and the problems of professional practice by providing critical and original solutions to the problems faced in the classroom.
B) Communicating in a clear and detailed way their ideas to the group, contributing to the construction of original solutions to the issues or cases provided in the classroom, communicating in a concise manner through oral and digital presentations; Actively participate in teams.

data.name: Science, Technology and Global Affairs
data.description:
This course aims to provide students with a thorough understanding of the role of science and technology in global affairs. The course will focus on the complex interrelatedness and feedback loops between, on the one hand, techno-scientific developments and, on the other hand, external (i.e. international) and internal (i.e. homeland) security dynamics. The focal point is security because this is the area in International Relations (IR) which is mostly affected and transformed by scientific innovations and the deployment of related technologies, such as drones, satellites, nuclear weapons, communications infrastructures, surveillance systems and malware agents.

By the end of this course, students will be able to:

- Connect socio-political phenomena and techno-scientific processes in their analyses of global affairs, with a particular emphasis on internal and external security dynamics.
- Study the transformative power that techno-science exerts in global affairs and (inter)national security.
- Think critically about the causes and consequences of techno-scientific innovations in the field of internal and external security. 
- Conduct independent analyses of complex issues related to the interplay between science, technology and global affairs.

The course will also enable students to develop their: (a) research, (b) writing, (c) teamwork and (d) presentation skills.

data.name: Steelmaking and foundry technologies
data.description:
The course aims to explain the main structural and functional aspects of steel-making plants for the production of semi-finished products, as a function of the required microstructural quality.

After completing the course, the students will be able to carry out preliminary mass and heat balances of these systems, and to manage the flow of material and energy efficiency of the processes.

Students will gain the ability to manage the steel casting processes (with particular emphasis to continuous casting), and the ability to understand the origin of possible product defects and then select appropriate solutions.

Students will know the operation of the main foundry processes (relative to steel, cast iron and Al alloys), and will be able to carry out a preliminar design of the sand casting process and to manage the pressure die-casting of aluminum alloys (including a cost evaluation).

Students will be able to identify the main environmental constraints of the studied systems.


Numerical exercises and a visit to an industrial factory are an important part of the course.

data.name: Immunologia

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description:
The course will provide students with the basic tools to understand the molecular and cellular mechanisms of immune response, the involvement of the immune response in diseases and how this knowledge can be applied to the development of prophylactic and therapeutic vaccines 
At the end of the course the student should be capable of:
1. understanding the mechanism of antigen recognition
2. describe the mechanisms of innate and adaptive immunity
3. explain how innate and adaptive immunity cooperate to protect the organism from microbial infections and from the insurgency of neoplastic diseases
4. Understanding the implications of the immune system deficiencies in human disease.
5. Explain the molecular basis of immunotherapy and vaccines 
6. Describe the most popular techniques used to study the immune response

data.name: Methods for traceability, protection and authenticity detection of agri-food products
data.description:
The aim of the course is to provide the student with advanced knowledge and critical understanding of the concepts of analytical traceability, authenticity, and adulteration of agri-food products.

Learning outcomes:

• Understand the significance of the concepts of analytical traceability, product authenticity and link with the geographical area, authenticity, and adulteration

• Be introduced into the plan of analytical controls made by official organisms on agri-food products

• Account for methods, techniques, and the most innovative instruments used in analytical traceability and authenticity verification

• Acquire critical views on the concepts of variability factors of the accounted analytical parameters

• Investigate real cases of application of the accounted analytical techniques for tracing the origin and detecting the authenticity of agri-food products.

• Understand the concept of meat authenticity and traceability.

• Acquire the basic knowledge of blockchain technology: Transforming meat supply chains.

• Understand the consumer perception of traceability in the meat chain.

• Knowing the principles of the most widely used molecular genetic techniques for the authentication and traceability of fresh and processed agrifood products, their recent advances, and applications.

• Ability to discuss the main advantages and limitations of these techniques compared to other analytical approaches.

• Understanding of the issues related to the genetic traceability of plants obtained with new breeding technologies.

The course develops different insights into microeconomics: these insights are complementary and represent the next step compared to the program carried out in Introduction to Economics and have the purpose of forming some additional concepts and analysis tools that allow to reach an advanced knowledge of economic problems. most relevant companies.

data.name: Chimica organica
data.description:
Aim of the course of Organic Chemistry, 9 credits [145036]is to provide a general knowledge of organic chemistry, useful for next studies in biochemical and biological fields. At the end of the teaching the student will have acquired theoretical knowledge on the structure and reactivity of organic molecules. Specifically, the student will know the main classes of both synthetic and natural organic compounds, will apply the basic rules of the IUPAC nomenclature, will be able to deduce the physico-chemical and stereochemical properties from the molecular structure, as well as to predict the reactivity according to the main reaction mechanisms, will know how to apply the studied reactions in simple synthetic sequences for the production of a target molecule, arguing the choices.


Aim of the course of Organic Chemistry, 6 credits [145207] is to provide the useful knowledge for a molecular approach to biosystem physics, the study of biomaterials and the application of physical methods to the investigation of organic and bioorganic matter. At the end of the course the student will have acquired theoretical knowledge on the structure and reactivity of the main classes of both synthetic and natural organic compounds. Specifically, the student will know the main classes of both synthetic and natural organic compounds, will apply the basic rules of the IUPAC nomenclature, will be able to deduce the physico-chemical and stereochemical properties from the molecular structure, as well as to predict the reactivity according to the main reaction mechanisms,will apply the molecular properties to the structural analysis, mainly based on the UV-visible and IR spectroscopy.

data.description:
The course deals with sustainability, walking around and starting from the direct perception of the issues and of the opportunities for territories and people. The route is the Way of the Gods, from Bologna to Florence.
The course aims also to revisit the relationship between students and professors, and the concepts of community and leadership, sharing experiences, emotions, and physical efforts.
At the end of the course students, although pretty tired, should be able to:
- understand the concept of sustainability, learning more and becoming more aware
- contextualize the concept in a daily and real context, pointing out the role, and the limits, of the law
- develop their critical skills and their curiosity for the social phenomena that law tries to regulate
- develop their team-working skills

Also, it aims at stimulating a critical approach to microeconomics, which is a prerequisite for active participation in the scientific debate.

Radar and radiolocalization

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
This course provides advanced knowledge and design capabilities in the framework of active systems for detection, localization, measurements and modelling of points and distributed targets. It provides a general overview on the main properties of radio and microwaves systems (radar), light wave systems (lidar) and acoustic wave systems (sonar). Then it focuses on radar and lidar systems providing a detailed analysis on: i) the main principles of active systems; ii) the criteria for designing them; iii) their applications; and iv) the related most recent developments. 
The programme of the course is organized into four main parts. The first part presents the basic concepts and physics of active systems and introduces a taxonomy with related application examples. The second part (which takes the largest portion of the course) is devoted to a detailed analysis of radar systems. It studies different radar concepts and applications, including surveillance radars, meteorological radars, ultra-wideband radars, ground penetrating radars and radar sounders, radar tracking strategies, radar architectures for air traffic control, and synthetic aperture radar for imaging. It also addresses specific issues related to the design and performance evaluation of a radar system. The third part illustrates active systems operating with light (laser) electromagnetic sources (i.e. lidar systems), with special focus on lidar developed for altimetry measurements, environmental applications, object modelling and speed control. Finally, the fourth part (which will be distributed during the course) is based on practice experiments in laboratory aimed to provide examples of real problems and related solutions of radar and lidar signal processing and applications.

They will also be able to understand and reproduce some graphical analyses of microeconomic models (consumer choices, market demand and supply) and macroeconomic models (production possibilities frontier, aggregate demand and supply).

data.name: Nuclear and subnuclear physics
data.description:
The aim of the course is twofold: to provide the student with an advanced knowledge of nuclear and particle physics, emphasizing the unifying ideas and common tools, and to develop the student's ability to apply such a knowledge to simple problems. A further goal of the course is to present the student a strategy for the development of a theory in a virgin field of physics by using the interplay of symmetries and conservation laws. Moreover, the student will have the occasion to see applications of various concepts of Quantum Mechanics and basic Quantum Field Theory.
At the end of the course the student
a) will be able to answer with competence questions about the phenomenological description of the weak interaction and the basics of the electroweak theory,
b) will have understood that the strong interaction has various facets, the fundamental QCD level with quarks and gluons, whereas for the nuclear (hypernuclear) level the interaction can be described with various different effective degrees of freedom,
c) will be able to calculate some quantities relevant for the physics described in a) and b).

data.name: Analisi matematica 2
data.description:
1. Knowledge and understanding
Knowledge of the basic topics of differential and integral calculus for functions of several variables and knowledge of some basic concepts on differential equations, as specified by the course program. In the written tests, students will be able to carry out exercises on the topics of the course and in the oral exam they will be able to illustrate the concepts that they have studied.

2. Ability to apply knowledge and understanding
Ability to apply differential and integral calculus techniques for functions of several variables in modeling and solving problems related to physics (eg mechanics or electromagnetism). Ability to analytically describe (through appropriate parameterizations) sets of three-dimensional space (eg curves and regular surfaces). Ability to set up a problem and to solve it with suitable differential and / or integral calculus techniques.

3. Autonomy of judgment
Ability to identify the most appropriate methods for analyzing, interpreting and solving problems.

4. Communication skills
Ability to present mathematical arguments with the necessary precision. In particular, they will be able to state precisely the definitions and theorems indicated in the lesson register.

5. Learning skills
Ability to acquire and manage new information concerning the mathematical modeling of concrete problems. Finally, students are expected to mature and acquire a more solid and comprehensive command of the fundamental concepts studied in Analysis 1 and Linear Algebra and Geometry.

data.name: Strumenti quantitativi per la gestione
data.description:
Intermediate statistics course aimed at the development of modeling skills and data analysis. The course focuses on the use of modern "statistical learning" techniques for prediction and classification in business and economic contexts. The course has an applied cut and the theoretical level of the topics is aimed at understanding the practical aspects of the applications. Free R software will be used and lab activities complement material discussed in class. At the end of the course, the student will be able to

• Analyze a multivariate data set

• Build models for analyzing and verifying hypotheses of interest and making predictions

• Understand the modeling component in the scientific-economic literature of the company

data.name: Medicinal Chemistry

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description:
Aim of the course is to provide the current knowledge on medicinal chemistry to students who are interested in learning  the role of chemistry  in its pharmaceutical applications.The teaching is planned  to be intedisciplinary (chemistry-biology-biotechnology-medicine), focusing on  the molecular aspects  in organic synthesis and in the studies of action modes and structure-activity relationships, for both currently used drugs and biologically active substances as potential chemotherapeutic agents.
At the end of the teaching the student will have acquired knowledge on:
a) the molecular structure of bioactive molecules, both of natural and synthetic origin, 
b) the production of their analogues and 
c) their interactions with the main molecular targets involved in human diseases. 
Specifically, the student will know :
a)the main classes of biologically active molecules, 
b)to discuss the phases in drug development and 
c)to discuss the innovative aspects in academic and industrial research.

data.name: Deep learning
data.description: The course aims at studying the fundamentals of machine learning, covering supervised and unsupervised learning methods and deep learning approaches. It includes application examples as well as laboratory exercises. At the end of the course, it is expected that the student will acquire the skills useful to design methods and tools for the analysis of signals and data.

data.name: Digital social data

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
The interdisciplinary course of Digital Social Data, aims to offer an introduction to the various approaches that computer scientist, economists, lawyers and sociologists adopt to approach a highly complex issue as Big data and Open data.
The Digital Social Data course is divided into two parts. In the first part, the course aims to provide an introduction to the different theoretical, methodological and technical implications of the advent of digital data in the field of social science research. The student will be provided with cross-language skills that are useful in dealing with a multidisciplinary subject. At the end of this part, the student will be able to distinguish the different theoretical / disciplinary approaches to Big Data themes.
The second part of the course will have a methodological and applied character and will introduce the student to the use of the big data. In this part, will be given to the student notions of programming and data analysis in R@ in highly complex contexts.
At the end of this second part, the student: a) will know how to identify the different methodological approaches in handling Big Data; b) will be able to evaluate the main types of analysis that can be conducted on the Big Data; c) apply the main programming tools in R @ to the Big Data; and, d) will independently conduct elemental analysis of highly complex data in R@.

data.name: Mathematical Physics - Differential Geometric Methods
data.description: Year 2021-2022 (Pagani). The course, for Master degree students of Mathematics and Physics, treats some advanced topics of mathematical Physics, and some applications to Analytical Mechanics, Calculus of Variations, Continuum Mechanics, Special and General Relativity. The student is required to learn the mathematical tools and the physical theories developed in the course.

data.name: Fondamenti di meccanica
data.description:
The course introduces basic concepts of mechanics and provides the tools for the analysis and modelling of kinematics, statics and dynamics of point and rigid bodies using Newtonian and energy methods. In addition, the course provides the basics of statics with an in-depth study of structural elements such as beams, plates, shells and trusses. 

At the end of the course, the student will be able to deal with problems of static equilibrium and dynamics of planar and three-dimensional rigid bodies, in the presence of common types of constraints, friction and forces. The student will also be able to recognize the physical meaning of the models adopted and the scope of applicability to derive equations of motion and stress characteristics.

data.name: Laboratory of Didactics of Mathematics
data.description:
The course is proposed as a laboratory in which to present basic methods and knowledge to analyze, design and implement educational proposals for secondary school students; students will be provided with methodological and disciplinary knowledge useful for the communication of mathematics, presenting the "mathematics laboratory" as teaching methodology; focus will be placed on the design of educational activities (task design) and their implementation in the school environment, with a priori and a posteriori analysis of some aspects of teaching and learning. 

At the end of the course, students will know the key points of design-based research (project-based research), will have improved their skills of didactic design of experimental activities for the teaching of mathematics. Students will also be able to analyze different classroom contexts and dynamics and design and realize units and educational paths consistent with the "good practices" introduced in the course; effectively present the mathematics topics considered in the course, through a conscious management of communication components (gestures, language, management of the tools used or the whiteboard) and physical media used for communication.

data.description: Epistemology of the Social Sciences is a theoretical course. The student learns to distinguish the types of explanation and scientific law, as well as the reasons that distinguish the different sciences in relation to the objects they deal with and the methods necessary to understand their characteristics. Systems theory (and in particular the theory of social systems) and fundamental properties of systems (positive and negative feedback loops) will provide the general language for understanding the difference between fragile, robust and antifragile systems.

data.description:
At the end of the course the student will be able to:

·      design hydraulic infrastructures for water collection, delivery, and distribution (aqueducts);

·      develop management and maintenance strategies for water distribution networks: theoretical notes and modeling applications to practical cases.

·      modify existing networks in order to adapt them to the changed situation due to anthropogenic and climatic changes;

·      evaluate the effects of climate change on the available water resource and on urban runoff;

data.name: Sociologia dello sviluppo internazionale

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
Inequalities of opportunity continue to persist, within and between countries. In some parts of the world, these divisions are becoming more pronounced. The standard of living of people around the world varies significantly depending on the region and/or country they live in. What factors can explain why some areas enjoy considerable wealth whilst others are poor? How and why do some countries manage to improve (or worsen) their situation? What social factors contribute to the development of a country, a continent, a region? What is the connection between a country's level of development and other key phenomena in contemporary society, particularly international migration?

At the end of the course, students are expected to have acquired an adequate knowledge of the major topics concerning international development and notably: 

- the development of economic and social inequalities between different world areas

- the main factors interacting in development processes and, in particular, the characteristics of the development-migration nexus;

- a familiarity with the main debates in the field of sociology of development;

- the ability to frame, discuss and critically analyze these debates.

data.name: Party Politics and Democracy in Europe
data.description:
The overall objective of this course is to provide students with a deep understanding of the role of political parties in contemporary politics. In so doing, the course stimulates students critical engagement with salient academic and political debates, such as on political representation, populism, institutional design, EU multilevel governance and globalization.

By the end of the course students are expected to have acquired:

- close familiarity with the technical terminology and basic concepts, such as political party, party system, party family, cleavage, representation, electoral alignment, electoral volatility, convergence/polarization, etc.

- thorough understanding of the historical changes in the relationship between political parties, civil society and the state; as well as of how these changes have generated different types of parties.

- solid grasp of different theories of party competition and party strategies 

- deep knowledge of the process of adaptation of European parties to European integration and multilevel governance, including the functioning of parties in EU institutions.

- full awareness of the hot issues in contemporary party politics debates, such as the crisis of parties and the responsiveness vs. responsibility dilemma.

- understanding of the causal links between the crisis of (traditional) parties and the emergence of populist parties, as well as the potential impact of populist politics on the quality of democracy.

- capacity to conduct independent and critical analysis, by engaging effectively in research (at least via secondary sources) and linking case studies to explanatory theories and normative debates.

data.description:
The course revolves around four themes that correspond to four timely and key psychological and societal issues. Throughout the course we will analyze these themes primarily through the lenses of social psychological theory and research findings, but ensuring their relevance for students interested in clinical, organizational and neuropsychological dynamics and applications.
At the end of the course students are expected to: 
a) show a thorough understanding of the concepts that will be discussed in class with the capacity to elaborate and reflect on these ideas
b) develop an in depth analysis and critical view on the main social concepts and theories that will be discussed during the course

data.name: Embodied cognition in theory and practice

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description:
The course aims to provide students with comprehensive theoretical knowledge on the theories revolving

around the concept of embodied cognition. The main authors and texts that have contributed to the definition

of an embodied perspective of cognitive processes will be presented, along with the possible declinations of

this approach in various disciplines of cognitive sciences (psycholinguistics, moral psychology, social

psychology). Next to the theory, there is going to be a more practical side of the course, in which the

students will perform mini experiments in which they will experience the influence of "bodily" factors on their

behavioral responses. They will take turns as experimenters and participants, as the execution of the small

experiments will be entrusted to the students divided into small work groups. Therefore, they will learn to put

into practice the logistical aspects of data collection. The students will dedicate a first part of the work to

planning the experimental setting, which will be then performed in the classroom during dedicated lessons,

where they will collect data from colleagues and finally make basic statistical analysis.

At the end of the course the students will have an in-depth knowledge of the embodied cognition theories

and will be able to relate what they have learned with other theoretical frameworks. They will also be able to

deal with the practical aspects of conducting a small behavioral experiment. Finally, they will learn to present

the collected data and discuss it publicly in the classroom.

data.name: Data mining

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: This is a graduate level course on Data Mining. Data Mining is the science studying mathematical models, computational paradigms, algorithms and methodologies that look for patterns and regularities in large amounts of raw data. The aim is to allow us to understand natural phenomena, business operations and human behaviors, in ways that it will allow us to turn this knowledge into predictions, forecasting and performance improvements. The goal of the course is to introduce the students to the basic concepts, principles and techniques of Data Mining, to help them develop the required skills for using the state of the art data mining algorithms for solving practical problems, and to provide them with the required experience that will later allow them to operate independently, efficiently and effectively, in highly competitive markets. The course aims also to support students wishing to pursue a research carrier by teaching them the methodologies in performing independent and effective studies and research activities. The goals of the course will be achieved by teaching the students the strengths and limitations of the various data mining techniques, how they can be applied, under what conditions and what they should expect from each application. At the end of the course, the students will be finding themselves familiar with the most popular data mining concepts and will be able to identify and use the right solutions for any data analysis problem they may find themselves into. Last but not least, future data scientists will also learn how to perform the right experiments, how to interpret the results correctly and how to present them in the most effective way.

data.name: Aspetti criminologici e giuridici del fenomeno mafioso (corso libero)
data.description:
The course aims to deepen, in an interdisciplinary key (criminology / sociology of deviance and criminal law), the development and characteristics of the mafia phenomenon and national law enforcement strategies, allowing students to reflect on the interaction between law and social phenomena.

The course is part of the numerous didactic, training and research activities that the University of Trento has been organising for some time on the mafia phenomenon and on the economic, legal and social aspects of the same (also in relation to the previous Memorandum of Understanding with the Commissione Parlamentare Antimafia).

data.name: Major issues in international politics

data.description: The aim of this course is to explore the ways on which global processes and structures are changing domestic and international politics. The central questions that we will address will focus on understanding how the nature of political power and its organization is being changed and is responding to pressures that come from beyond the state. The course will strengthen your understanding of the theories of international politics by looking at a range of global issues, such as the politics of food, trade and energy.

data.name: Molecular and Cellular Biophysics
data.description:
The objective of the course is the comprehension of the biological integrated processes in terms of molecular and cellular biophysical mechanisms. Basic knowledge of molecular and membrane biophysics is required. Starting from this knowledge, the biomolecules and the mechanisms of regulation and integration of cell activity will be studied. The final goal is to approach some current issues of biophysics and acquire a methodology to investigate advanced biophysical problems. For this reason, the lessons are focussed on specific biomolecules and mechanisms and the topics at the frontiers of the research in biophysics will be privileged.
According to their interests and specific individual curriculum, students are allowed to emphasize different aspects and methodological approaches of the research in biophysics and the presentation of a thematic seminar will contribute substantially to the final evaluation. In particular, :
a) students attending the Master's degree in Physics are invited to emphasize the physical methods of investigation (physical technologies to study cell function and man) and the involvement of the mechanisms of regulation and integration of cell activity in human pathologies.
b) students attending the Master Degree in Mathematics are required to emphasize the relationship between mechanism of regulation of biological processes and physiology and their modelling.
At the end of the course, students should be able to:
acquire and analyze critically scientific information from the current literature, utilize the skills and the knowledge that is proper of a physicist or of a mathematician to propose innovative solutions to biophysical research, demonstrate written and/or oral presentation skills to communicate scientific knowledge.

data.name: Bio-Inspired Artificial Intelligence

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The goal of this course is to study two of the main paradigms of Bio-Inspired Artificial Intelligence, namely: Evolutionary Computation, inspired by evolutionary biology, and Swarm Intelligence, inspired by collective behaviors of social animals. First, the main theories and algorithms will be introduced. Then, it will be shown how these techniques can be applied, for instance, for solving complex optimization problems, training data-driven models, generating new contents (video-games, websites, art), finding bugs in software, automatically synthesizing or fixing computer programs, or finding innovative solutions in robotics, logistics, and engineering. Finally, it will be shown how these techniques can help the understanding of biological systems, in order to close the loop between biology and AI.

At the end of this course, students will be familiar with the most important Evolutionary Computation and Swarm Intelligence techniques, and will be able to apply them to different contexts in industry, research, or even entertainment. They will also know the fundamentals for developing new algorithms and adapt them to new problems.

data.name: Calcolo delle variazioni
data.description:
The course will give an introduction to the classical problems and methods of the calculus of variations, and also to the direct methods mainly in dimension one. 

The student can consolidate the knowledge of the classical results concerning the optimization problems encountered in various courses of the biennio (in particular, minimum problems for functions of one or more variables) and will have to acquire and know some classical results concerning optimization problems of the calculus of variations. It is expected that the student knows how to grasp the similarities and differences of the new results presented (with respect to the knowledge previously acquired) and is able to show that even through the examples/exercises that will be discussed in the lessons.

At the end of the course, students are expected to be able to determine the structure of decisions and of (inductive or deductive) arguments, to identify possible biases and fallacies, and to interpret the results of experiments on thinking processes.

The main goal is to enable students to (i) understand the theoretical and practical problems of information security, (ii) understand and recognize threats to fundamental security properties: confidentiality, integrity, and availability, and (iii) understand how the main security mechanisms - such as cryptography, authentication and authorization protocols, and access control - can be applied to mitigate vulnerabilities.

Geomatica e telerilevamento

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description: The course provides basic elements about geodesy, terrestrial reference systems and height systems. Introduction to technologies and satellite missions for remote sensing and the observation of the Earth. Principles and methods involved in technologies for radio-positioning (GPS), for optical remote sensing (multispectral images) and for 3D data acquisition (LiDAR, range images). Geometric surveys are considered for the production of digital surface models; acquisition and processing of multi-spectral images for the study of environmental objects and phenomena. Design and execution of topographic surveys for control applications and special purposes. GPS survey in real-time mode for civil and high productive applications. Use of terrestrial LiDAR sensors for civil and monitoring goals. Review of the leas squares principle, the Helmert transformation, the principal component analysis and statistical hypothesis testing. Practical activities and laboratory works, from GPS and LiDAR surveys to data processing and analysis, and the processing of remote sensed imagery. Testing of devices based on Raspberry and low cost GNSS receivers will be carried out. Students will work on the design of a GNSS network for the deployment of a real time positioning service.

data.name: Tensor Decomposition for Big Data Analysis

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
An introduction to big data science from the point of view of tensor decomposition.

The course will begin with concrete examples of big data problems. The central part of the course will be based on geometric structures for modeling the extraction of information from problems of large data collections. Part of the course will be devoted to computational aspects.

1. Knowledge and understanding skills.
Good knowledge of the basic arguments of tensor decomposition from the geometric point of view and concrete examples of big data.

2. Ability to apply knowledge and understanding.
Inductive and deductive reasoning ability to deal with issues that are provided individually or in a group from time to time.

3. Autonomy of judgment.
Ability to develop logical arguments and produce correct demonstrations. Ability to identify the most appropriate methods for analyzing, interpreting, and modeling information extraction issues from large data collections.

4. Communicative Skills.
Ability to expose subjects both at the written / computational level by carrying out exercises handed out by the instructor both at the oral level in the possible presentation of a topic taught at a lecture through a public seminar.

data.name: Diritto pubblico europeo

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
Among the most relevant consequences of globalization, we may certainly include the progressive erosion of the idea that the State is the only, or at least the most important, law-maker. The supranational integration processes - within Europe, especially in the EU case - are clear evidence of the so called "internationalization of constitutional law". This concept highlights the influence that the EU legal order determines on domestic legal orders in terms of competences, institutional relations (parliament and government) or as regards the relationship between citizens and the State.
At the same time, another trend has been slowly emerging. It is represented by the fact that the EU tends to reproduce some of the features of modern constitutionalism. This is most evident in relation to the EU case (the discussion about the Constitution-Treaty for the EU or the ECJ case law concerning the supremacy and direct effect of EC law).
European public law is thus the intersection of the eu and national legal orders and in the filed of human rights of the action of the European Court of Human Rights.
The course, which is primarily aimed at providing a basic understanding of the normative and institutional framework of the domestic and European Union legal order respectively, will try to present them by highlighting the increasing interrelation and reciprocal influences.

data.name: Calcolo stocastico progredito
data.description: The aim of the course is to introduce some stochastic models related to the dynamics of interest rates . In the first part of the course we introduce the short rate models and the term structure equation. Then  we consider the martingale short rate models and we focus on the most common affine one factor models . In the second part of the course we introduce the forward rate models and the forward measures which are particularly useful when dealing with interest rate derivatives. General bond option pricing formulas for short rate models and forward rate models will be provided.

data.name: Letteratura tedesca I
Economic History
data.description:
The objective of the course is to provide (1) adequate knowledge of the major transformations of the European and world economies from the pre-industrial age to the contemporary era and the underlying factors; (2) the skills necessary to understand, analyze and critically interpret these transformations.

Upon completion of the course, the student will be able to:

- remember the basic concepts useful in the analysis of an economic system;

- describe the main historical manifestations of economic growth/development and crises;

- explain their causes and consequences, grasping the interaction between economic aspects and technological, institutional, cultural and geographical factors;

- communicate effectively in oral and written form, and argue on an economic historical topic.

data.name: Crash course - Introduction to Quantitative Methods
data.description: At the end of the course the students will be able to: 1) address and propose solutions to simple problems of economic nature on the basis of the information contained in the available data and duly summarized through appropriate statistical analysis techniques; 2) be able to analyze a data set with the software R.
