department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
Students will be taught the fundamentals of the psychology of decision-making. The rationality of choice and its descriptive component will be analyzed. Also, how people perceive risks will be discussed.
Students will learn the fundamentals of psychology of judgment/decision-making that will allow them to better describe and predict third party decision-making. It will also help them to empower their decision-process.

data.name: Diritto tributario
Introduction to Financial Accounting
data.description:
The course's aims are the followings:
 1) providing with the basics of Accounting
2) providing with an understanding of the importance of accounting in economics and management
3) understanding the logic of double entry
4) understanding the structure of the financial statements
5) understanding the main double-entry entries

data.name: Archeologia e storia dell'arte romana
data.description:
This course is composed of two parts (Greek Archaeology and Art History and Roman Archaeology and Art History) and offers the students a broad overview of art and archaeology in the Greek and Roman worlds.
At the end of the course, students: 1. will have developed an overall knowledge of the main archaeological and artistic aspects of the Greek and Roman worlds; 2. will be able to discuss and analyse monuments and artworks presented to them through pictures and plans; 3. will have thorough awareness of the close relationships between artistic production and the historical and political context; 4. will have familiarised with the technical terminology.

data.name: Set theory
data.description: The course is an introduction to the Zermelo-Fraenkel set theory with emphasis on its connectionss with the mathematical practice. The goal is to become familiar with the basic notions and techniques from set theory so to be able to correctly use them in the mathematical practice.

data.name: Etica, università e comunità
data.description:
The course is experimental and highly participatory. The main goal is to share, pleasantly, an educational experience, even before transmitting notions, skills and knowledge. Challenging goal: I will need your cooperation and your sense of responsibility.

For these reasons, continuous attendance (it is not possible to take the exam as a non-attending student) and active participation (which will be evaluated) are required. 

That said, not surprisingly we will deal with ethics, university and community, especially in terms of mutual integration.

At the end of the course, you should:
- know the rules of your environment, with particular reference to the Code of Ethics and other regulations dedicated to you
- have the tools to understand dynamics, objectives, strengths and weaknesses of the university environment
- develop independent judgment and critical skills
- be able to defend your opinions, remaining open to dialogue
- acquire skills (and desire?) to collaborate with others
- be aware of being part of various communities

data.name: Relazioni internazionali e diritti umani

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description: The central objective is to give the students an overview of decision-making processes pertaining to human rights in the context of international relations.

data.name: Filosofia della religione - LM
Bibliografia e biblioteconomia I
data.description:
The student will acquire the fundamental knowledge and concepts of a modern vision of libraries and the disciplines that define and regulate how they work. The course starts from a survey of concrete cases inevitably connected to the current transition phase, proposes a critical and systematic discussion of the key themes concerning the characteristics, purpose, rules and regulations, and problems of libraries. It refers to the Italian scenario in particular, compared with relevant or emerging trends at an international level. It also provides essential references for concepts, models and procedures for cataloguing, retrieving and citing sources, and for library management.
By the end of the course, the student will have developed an understanding of the content, tools and languages to be more aware and independent in a library environment, cultivate personal interests and pursue future in-depth studies.

data.name: Technical English

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
Obiettivi Formativi:
The course aims to extend students’ knowledge of and ability to use grammatical, lexical and textual features of written academic English in a scientific context to B2 level, to develop students’ fluency in speaking English and to develop students’ skills in giving an academic presentation.   An active approach is used, with students producing written texts and then correcting them individually and as a group.  Students will both give a presentation to the class and give feedback on other students’ presentations.

data.name: Advanced optimization-based robot control
data.description:
This course focuses on control of robotic systems, with special attention to numerical optimal control and reinforcement learning. After reviewing the basic principles of robot modeling and numerical optimization, students will learn different control techniques, from the simplest and most well-known, to the most recent and advanced. Methods will be first studied in theory, and then implemented in simulation (with the Python language) to gain practical experience. Applications will focus on industrial manipulators and legged robots, but the same methods could be also applied to flying robots and wheeled robots. After completing the course, students will be able to:
- understand the working principles of several control algorithms for robotic systems
- choose the appropriate approach(es) to control a specific system for a given target application
- implement, tune, and test control algorithms with the Python language

data.name: Diritto commerciale
data.description:
The course aims to explain the rules that govern the functioning of the individual and collective enterprise, with particular attention to the reasons underlying the choices made by the legislator and verifying the extent to which they give rise to an efficient balancing of the interests involved. Where necessary, the guidelines followed by the case law and the solutions adopted in other jurisdictions will be considered. The goal is to provide the student with the basics of business law and the critical
ability to use them to solve real problems with correct methods.

data.name: Neurogenesis and Brain Regeneration

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description:
The aim of the course is to provide the students with the basis for the understanding of the principles of neurogenesis during development and postanatal life. Particular attention is devoted to mechanisms controlling neurogenesis in physiological and in pathological conditions and how manipulation of neurogenesis might be important to develop regenerative approaches to the diseased CNS. In particular, on completion of this course students will be able to:
1. explain the basic principles of neurogenesis during development and in adult mammalian brain
2. describe the principles of cellular and molecular properties of different mammalian Neural Stem Cell populations
3. explain the mechanisms that regulate neurogenesis in physiological and pathological conditions
4. understand the physiological roles of adult neurogeneis
5. describe the different in vitro systems exploitable for studying neurogenesis and for producing cells for regenerative approaches
6. explain the strategies for exploiting in vivo and in vitro neurogenesis for regenerative purposes

data.name: Metodi per la rilevazione e l'analisi delle preferenze/scelte dei consumatori
data.description:
Objective of the course is the acquisition of knowledge and skills to investigate and analyze consumer preferences/choices, also including those for tourism products.

Attendance and active participation at three training activities offered by the course (lectures, analysis of empirical research published in scientific journals, multidisciplinary laboratory) and self-study will enable students:
- describe the methods to investigate and analyze consumers’ preferences/choices 
- discuss the scientific literature and empirical applications that use the studied methods
- compare the methods discussed in the course to highlight the specific characteristics
- discover the most appropriate method to analyze preferences/choices for a specific product/good in a specific context
- judge the validity of empirical applications that employ the studied methods
- design surveys with discrete choice models for the analysis of consumer preferences/choices for a new product/good

Regarding soft skills, active participation in all the proposed training activities make students able to organize a teamwork, apply problem solving techniques and presenting results by properly arguing.
data.degreeProgram: Management della sostenibilità e del turismo (LM)

data.name: Economia dell'ambiente e del territorio
data.description:
The course aims at providing students with knowledge of key principles of environmental economics   and sustainable development, specifically:   
1)	Knowledge, understanding and analysis of the notions of sustainability and sustainable development as well as the role of environment in local development with emphasis on tourism. 
2)	Knowledge, understanding and analysis of the foundations of environmental economics, environmental valuation and cost-benefit analysis.
3)	Knowledge, understanding and analysis of financial and market-based policy instruments generally used to promote environmental sustainability.
4)	Knowledge, understanding, analysis, and empirical applications of sustainability indicators with particular emphasis on tourism.

Attendance and active participation to the three typologies of offered training activities (lectures, seminars and multidisciplinary lab activities), in addition to the individual studying activities, allow students to achieve the following learning outcomes:
a)	Describe, summarize and compare the most important theories and models of economic growth and sustainable development
b)	Describe, summarize and compare the key financial policy instruments used to promote sustainable development
c)	Describe, summarize and empirically apply the notion of total economic value and key principles of environmental valuation
d)	Describe, summarize and compare the key elements of the most used environmental valuation techniques 
e)	Describe, summarize and empirically apply some environmental valuation techniques
f)	Describe and summarize foundations and phases of the benefit-cost analysis 
g)	Describe, summarize and compare sustainability indicators
h)	Make use of sustainability indicators in tourism management

Attendance and active participation to the course allow students to develop the following soft skills:
a)	Write an essay on specific issues
b)	Organize teamwork
c)	Oral presentation individually and in groups
d)	Improve problem solving skills
data.degreeProgram: Management della sostenibilità e del turismo (LM)

data.name: Modelli di organizzazione per il servizio sociale

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
Provide the coordinates for reading and understanding the organizational contexts of social and social-health services.
At the end of the course, students are expected to be able to recognize and analyze differentiated organizational models, identifying actors, functions and competencies that they are responsible for, as well as identifying tools that allow optimal programming, management and delivery of services.

data.name: Privacy and Intellectual Property Rights

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The aim of the course is to introduce the students to the basic principles of Privacy and Intellectual Property, taking into account both legal and technological issues with reference to some specific case studies.
At the end of the course the students will be able to understand the nature of the legal issues related to intellectual property rights and privacy.

data.name: Statistica matematica
data.description:
Purpose of the course

The purpose of the course is to address the study of the foundations of statistical theory starting from the early principles of probability. The central part of the course will be devoted to the estimation theory and hypotheses testing through the likelihood approach.


Course expected results

At the end of the course students will have had the opportunity to become familiar with logical developments, demonstrations, ideas and issues that underlie the different statistical techniques and they will learn to recognize them as natural extensions and consequences of the concepts previously introduced in the probability calculus courses.

data.name: Revisione aziendale 2
data.description:
At the end of the training sessions the student has learned the metodology to apply to plan an audit work, having understood the principles to be applied in order to identify:
- strenght and weaknesses of a company
- the major internal control points
- key risks
- the audit procedures to be applied in order ti minimize the audit risk.

data.name: Environmental measurements

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
The course will provide an overview of the instruments and techniques to monitor the main meteorology-related environmental variables. 
	The course will also give the basic criteria to select the proper instruments for the quantification of the environmental variables and processes. 
	The course will show how to collect, interpret and analyze environmental data according to WMO standards and recommendations. 
	The course will also present the fundamentals of weather radar, introducing the operation principle of radar-based meteorological observation and the physical interactions between the radar signals and the atmosphere.

At the end of the course the student will be able to: 

	Define which one can be the proper instrument to measure the selected environmental variable.
	Understand the functioning principles of instruments and sensors 
	Evaluate the quality of the collected data through proper statistical elaborations.
	Manage and organize environmental data
	Understand the operation principles of weather radar and the guidelines for the design of its fundamental parameters.
	Understand the concept of Doppler Power Spectrum, reflectivity factor, base velocity.
	Read and analyze base reflectivity images, wind map images, and precipitation images.

data.name: Environmental physical chemistry

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
The course intends to apply physical-chemistry concepts and tools to atmospheric chemistry and atmospheric processes. It will provide students with the fundamental physical and chemical processes that affect the composition and dynamics of the Earths atmosphere. Some of the topics covered will be an introduction to concepts that will be developed in other courses, with special reference to the course Atmospheric Chemistry and biogeochemistry.

At the end of the course students:
-  will have a firm foundation in the properties and thermodynamics of solutions, phase transitions, nucleation and be able to apply them to the modelling of atmospheric processes (e.g. aereosol and cloud formations) 
-  will be able to define, explain and correctly use terms and concepts of chemical thermodynamics and kinetics
-  will be able to apply the concepts and machineries of radiation-matter interaction and spectroscopy to model the photochemistry of important atmospheric species
-  will have a sound knowledge of the principal mechanisms and components of atmospheric pollution 
-   will be able to explain several important atmospheric phenomena from the molecular to the global scale (e.g. global warming, stratospheric ozone depletion, photochemical smog)

data.name: Neurophysiology of language

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description:
The aim of the course is to understand and interpret models of language-related cognitive processes in their neurophysiological implementation. An active participation to the activities of the course (lectures, annotated bibliography, seminars for discussions and debates) and individual study will enable the students to

- know and describe some of the main neurocognitive models of language processing.

- develop an analytic and critical approach with respect to neurocognitive models of language and in the examination of the related experimental evidence.

- examine scientific articles and understand their input with respect to the general theoretical issue.

- be able to present and discuss currently relevant and controversial issues in the field of neurophysiology of language through the methodologies addressed during the lectures.

- gain experience with the writing style required for scientific communication

data.name: Storia del pensiero medievale e premoderno
Distributed robot perception

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The instructional goals of the course is to acquire a comprehensive overview of the distributed systems for measurement and automation used today in industrial and service application domains. The course focuses on the most advanced technological solutions adopted in industry as well as on the theoretical aspects that arise when control or estimation are applied in a distributed context. Particular emphasis will be given to robotic perception using Artificial Intelligence techniques to be applied to robotic problems.

During the course, the focus will be on the design and implementation of distributed estimators to be used for intelligent autonomous systems in industrial and service environments, analyzing the resulting problems from both a practical and theoretical point of view. Examples of the application of these techniques on real or realistic systems will be presented during the course.

At the end of the course, the student will be able to:

- Understand the complexity, the issues and the potentialities of distributed systems;

- Compare the various different technological solutions available for a distributed system;

- Evaluate and analyze the practical and theoretical implications of a distributed measurement and/or perception system;

- Analyse and design the distributed solution for a particular system;

- Critically asses the benefits and the limitations of a distributed solution.

data.name: Misurazione e rendicontazione sociale e ambientale
data.description:
1. Teaching objectives and contents.

The purpose of the course is to acquire knowledge and skills related to the management of corporate social responsibility and non-financial measurement systems (mission report, social and environmental report, integrated report, social impact measurement) in private profit and non-profit organizations.

In today's economic contexts where the boundaries between profit and non-profit worlds are becoming less and less marked, and in which corporate social responsibility in the management of the corporate resources is becoming a major competitive element for companies, this course aims to overcome traditional approaches and develop an understanding of the issues related to corporate social responsibility and its social and environmental reporting. The course will enable you to explore the most innovative concepts of corporate social responsibility, shared value, accountability, social and environmental accounting and reporting (SEAR), social impact measurement, and integrated reporting in an international perspective.

 

2. Expected results.

At the end of the course, the student will be able to:

1. recognize different ethical approaches to Corporate Social Responsibility and become more aware of the role of the company in the market;

2. Interpreting stakeholder theory in managerial view and implementing stakeholder engagement systems taking into account elements of stakeholder salience;

3. Define the concept of accountability and distinguish the application of this notion in different business contexts;

4. Analyze and structure of social and environmental accounting and reporting (SEAR) systems;

5. identify, evaluate and develop integrated reporting systems that are capable of combining not only economic-financial but also non-financial dimensions (such as social and environmental);

6. Identify various social impact measurement systems, describe their limits and potentialities and develop metrics and impact indicators consistent with the business context object of analysis;

7. Express an improved ability to work in groups and critically present/discuss issues related to social responsibility.

data.name: Natural Language Understanding

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: Natural Language Understanding is the fundamental component of artificial intelligence systems ( AIS ) that communicate with humans. AIS communicate directly with humans via the conversational interfaces of social robots. AIS may be able to read and comprehend vast amounts of human language data ( speech, text or multimedia ) and makes sense. In the first part of the course we will provide the students the basic knowledge about the natural language structure from the lexicon to the document level, formal models for representing the lexicon, the sentence and the discourse. We will present and provide the machine learning models to learn language structures from language corpora. In the last part of the course we will describe use cases of Natural Language Understanding in AIS. Students will be trained to train  natural language understanding models for different use cases and tasks.

data.name: Costruzione di strade

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
The course is divided into two parts. In the first part (about 30 hours) the basics in order to properly (following the current guidelines) design an highway segment will be provided. Reviews on highway geometric design, roadway’s elements (enbankments, highway cuttings, etc.), types of bridges, viaducts, retaining walls, etc. and pavements.
For pavements also some of the most used calculation criteria are shown.
In the second part (about 30 hours) will be provided the knowledge of Traffic Engineering will be deepened (functional evaluation of highways and intersections with several common case study).
At the end of the course the Student will be able to:
-	comprehend and deal with the main problems recurring in highway design and construction
-	comprehend and solve the problems about highway and intersection traffic condition evaluation (using Traffic Engineering results)
The Student will be also able to calculate Level of Service for freeways, highways, at-grade intersections and roundabouts and to choose between different intersection design solutions.

data.description:
The course deals with the theory and the design of timber buildings and timber structures. It introduces the main concepts for the analysis and design of timber structural systems to be applied in residential, public, industrial buildings, and bridges, both in Italy and Europe, starting from the peculiar aspects related to wood material.
After the course, the student should be able to: i) define the project of simple timber structures, taking into account the problems of durability, ii) design timber structures, composed by beam or plane elements, subjected to normal or accidental actions, iii) design and verify the connections used in timber structures.

data.name: Soluzioni basate sulla natura per la sostenibilità urbana

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
Upon completion of this course, students will be able to:

1.      Understand contemporary sustainability issues in urban areas, and the role that nature can play for more livable, resilient and healthier cities;

2.      Analyze the supply and demand of ecosystem services provided by urban green and blue spaces, by applying suitable mapping and assessment methods;

3.      Understand the main typologies of nature-based solutions and the key principles for effective and context-specific planning, design and implementation;

4.      Assess the environmental and socio-economic impacts of nature-based solutions through quantitative and qualitative indicators;

5.      Critically review and discuss current thinking and experiences in cities and landscapes in Europe and around the world.

data.name: Databases

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
We live in a world full of data. Almost every human activity nowadays produces data or needs access to data. As such, there is a need for effective and efficient solutions that will allow us to store, maintain, search and retrieve large volumes of data. This is what the data management systems do. The goal of this course is to teach the students the fundamental concepts of data  management, to train them in order to be able to design of good databases, give them the ability to build complex queries, and allow them to identify and solve performance problems in real life situations. 
Naturally the course focuses on relational databases since the relational model is the one that drives most of the existing data management systems in the industry nowadays, it has been around for more than 30 years and has been one of the most studied model, and has been the one with the most commercial tools in operation.

data.name: Sviluppo e istituzioni: analisi comparata

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
The goal of this course is to invite students to think about the linkage between institutions and economic development. The main idea is that:
- economic and political development must proceed in lockstep in ways that differ depending on the particular historical period and on the cultural, geographic, institutional and political context;
- to attribute economic development to a recipe that is valid for all places and at all times is anlytically unfounded and is often based on an "ideological" vision. 
The tendency is to define as a "development model" any successful case of economic and political development by cursorily refering to a set of favorable conditions that encompass culture and geography, legal and political institutions - being then forced to change model and recipe as soon as a new, unexpected successful case emerges. 
At the end of the course students will have familiarized themselves with some of the main debates on economic development and the role of institutions; they will be able to critically assess economic statistics and statements about institutional reforms necessary for economic development; and they will have acquired the capacity to present their ideas in a structured manner and to defend them in a public debate.

data.name: Ultrasound Technologies for Medical Applications

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: This course consists of two parts. In the first part, core topics such as the piezoelectric phenomenon, the physics of ultrasound propagation, modeling, and nonlinear acoustics will be introduced. This will provide the students with the basic knowledge necessary to understand the potentials and the limitations of ultrasound technologies. The second part will then focus on probe design, system architecture of ultrasound scanners, image formation and beam forming, and emerging medical applications (e.g. lung ultrasonography, brain and cancer imaging). The objective of the course is to form students that are not only familiar with the fundamentals and state-of-the-art applications of ultrasound technology, but also able to critically evaluate the technology itself and potentially improve it further.

data.description: This course aims to provide students with basic knowledge about organizations and business management, and to foster critical thinking on the role of enterprises in the contemporary economy. The course will begin with an overview of the ongoing debate on the firm’s ultimate goal from both the shareholders and the stakeholders’ views. Subsequent to a review of the core business activities, it will then provide the basic notions of accounting and performance evaluation metrics, and a detailed overview of quantitative decisions-making models, such as economies of scale, learning curves, break-even/profit points, operating leverage etc. Furthermore, it will offer an accurate presentation and discussion of models for strategic analysis, including those with a longitudinal perspective. The course will end with a thorough examination of corporate governance, inquiring into managerial interests, mis-management and potential remedies. At the end of the course, the students will be able: 1. to understand and illustrate, with competence and expertise, the debate on the nature and purpose of enterprises, as institutions aimed at resolving the tension between wealth creation and social demands; 2. to understand, use and evaluate accounting and measurement performance systems; 3. to understand and use quantitative models in support of operation and management decisions; 4. to understand and competently speak about the problem of corporate governance, with a particular focus on the role of managers and the internal/external mechanisms to align shareholders’ and managerial interests; 5. to evaluate and critically assess the functioning and strategies of enterprises in modern economies and their ability to pursue long term success, preserving the financial and institutional equilibria-

data.name: Virus-Cell Interaction

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description:
The aim of the course is to provide the students with the understanding of the molecular basis of the interaction between viruses and their host cells, and the modern research strategies applied to the investigation of the mechanisms regulating the virus-cell interface. At the end of this course, students will be able to:
a) Describe the different types of interaction between viruses and cell 
b) Understand the molecular mechanisms which govern the interaction between viruses and cells.
c) Describe the main techniques used to investigate the dynamics and the mechanisms of the virus-cell interaction
c) Explain the mechanisms of reciprocal adaptation between viruses and their hosts
d) Understand the causes, dynamics, and basic pathogenic mechanisms underlying viral infections.
e) Describe the main strategies used to interfere with the virus interaction with its host
f) Understand the causes and consequences of the host-virus interaction at the population level.
g) Comprehend the contribution of virus research for the advancement of our knowledge of the mechanisms governing the eukaryotic cell
h) Understanding the principles driving the development of virus-based technologies aimed at manipulating eukaryotic cells.

data.name: Intellectual Property and Competition Law

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
Intellectual property (IP) and competition policy issues are increasingly relevant to undertakings, especially to those facing dynamic markets in an international environment. The course aims at providing students with solid theoretical and practical foundations in dealing with the legal facets of managing innovation. Both intellectual property law and competition policy can be said to pursue, by different means, the same primary aim of stimulating the innovation process. On the one hand, by allowing innovators to appropriate the results of their investments, incentives are created to take risks and engage in innovation activities. Competitive markets, on the other hand, allow for new products and services to emerge and be tested by consumers and/or other undertakings. However, as long as intellectual property rights (IPRs), like in particular patents and copyrights, are considered plain monopolies, there is arguably an inherent tension between the two above mentioned legal fields, in particular where such monopoly rights granted to creators and inventors stifle growth because of poorly designed “incentives” rules. 
In this vein, it is especially the role of IPRs as tools to motivate firms to invest in innovation activities that has been seriously questioned in the last two decades. The case for further and general strengthening of IPRs appears weak, and it is increasingly understood that a new balance needs to be struck between rewarding risk-takers and diffusing new knowledge. This course examines the interface between intellectual property and competition law, looking in particular at how competition law is already affecting intellectual property. Moreover, the course is aimed at analyzing the peculiarities of the legal management of the intellectual assets of firms acting in different economic sectors (e.g., fashion industry, information and communication technology markets, pharmaceutical industry). 
On completing this course, students will be able to: 
a) clearly identify those contexts in which innovation management decisions are influenced by intellectual property law and competition policy considerations
b) explain, in an interdisciplinary way, the core principles of intellectual property and competition law 
c) employ general analysis skills helping them to identify crucial issues and therefore to ask the right questions in the management and expansion of the firm's intellectual (property) assets
d) understand and follow international trends in the area of IPRs and competition policy especially relevant to dynamic industries (e.g., so called “search bias” as investigated by competition authorities on both sides of the Atlantic and its possible meaning and effects for other undertakings active in markets affected by such practices).

data.name: Enterprise information system

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
The general goal of the Enterprise Information System course is to teach students to play an active role in decision making about investments in information technologies.

The course introduces the fundamental principles of information systems; teaches concepts and models to plan investments in information systems according to the activities to be supported and to the company's business model.

Focusing on web-based information systems, the second part of the course introduces a method to design an effective web presence strategy.

After completing the course, the student will be able to:

  • know and classify information systems and their application in business
  • apply requirements elicitation and analysis techniques
  • realize a feasibility study for an information system module starting from the business challenges of the company 
  • know the principles and the protocols of Internet and Web
  • model, evaluate and plan web presence strategies
  • evaluate website quality according to a goal-oriented approach
  • analyse and manage online reputation of a company.

data.name: Network-based Data Analysis

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description:
The goal of this course is to enable students to analyze various types of high-dimensional data types commonly encountered in the practice of Molecular Biology using a range of methodologies, including established statistical approaches, machine learning, and recently introduced methods.

At the end of the course, students are expected to possess the following skills:

- familiarity with different types of Molecular Biology data and their specificity;

- good understanding of different conceptual methods for analyzing the data;

- familiarity with practical computational tools for carrying out the analysis;

- ability to frame the results of their analysis in a biological context using networks;

- ability to provide a functional interpretation of the results of their analysis;

- ability to complete a project, write a structured report, and orally present the results of their work.

data.name: Single Cell and Spatial Omics

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description:
Objectives

Thanks to the revolution of single cell sequencing, we can obtain genome-wide data (omics) from single cells. By looking at thousands of cells one at a time, we can capture the diversity of cell populations with unprecedented resolution. Spatially resolved omics technologies have also emerged very recently, combining sequencing with imaging to provide new insights into the spatial organization of cell states within tissues.

Single cell and spatially resolved omics data can be generated with multiple and rapidly changing technologies, and their analysis requires specific methods to deal with their complexity and challenges. The course will present the available technologies, biomedical applications, data analysis and visualization methods for single cell and spatial omics.

Learning outcomes

Students will be able to:

  • a)    Know different experimental technologies and platforms used to generate single cell and spatially resolved omics: their strengths, their limitations and their applications in biomedicine.
  • b)    Understand, critically evaluate and choose appropriately the approaches necessary for the analysis, integration, visualization and interpretation of single cell and spatial omics data.
  • c)    Retrieve, analyze, integrate, visualize and interpret single cell and spatial omics datasets within the R environment.

data.name: Analisi matematica con elementi di algebra

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.name: Minorities, Regionalism and Borders in Europe

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
The overarching objective of this course is to enhance students’ awareness, knowledge and understanding of the saliency of political processes based on the interactions between ethno-territorial identities and political institutions in Europe. The course aims to develop students’ capacity to critically engage with current issues in ethno-territorial politics in Europe from a theoretical, empirical and normative perspective.

By the end of the course, students should have acquired:

- an in-depth understanding of key concepts related to ethno-territorial, multi-level politics, and the concept of territoriality

- awareness of the main ‘hot issues’ in ethno-territorial politics in contemporary Europe, as well as of their political salience

- a solid knowledge of key explanatory theories (e.g. ethnicity and nationalism; state-formation; EU multi-level governance, etc.)

- an understanding of the different scales impacting on or influencing territorial disputes (e.g. local identities, geopolitical interests, globalization processes)  

- familiarity with normative debates on the relative weight of competing principles (e.g. state territorial integrity vs. self-determination of minorities within states)

- an understanding of the legal instruments related to federalism, regionalism, autonomy and cross-border cooperation and their constitutional impact and implications

- the capacity to conduct independent and critical analysis, by engaging effectively in empirical research (at least via secondary sources) and linking case studies to explanatory and normative theories

data.name: Prototyping interactive systems

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description:
The main objective of the course is to provide theoretical and practical knowledge on prototyping in a design process, with a specific focus on graphical user interfaces. On the completion of the course, the students will be able to: - articulate the rationale for prototyping as a design tool - proficiently use at least one appropriate tool to create prototypes - name, recognize and apply the main principles of interaction design at the micro-level - analyze and criticize a graphical interface in terms of micro-level design principles.


Furthermore, the course aims at fostering soft skills regarding effective communication of results by clear and adequate oral presentation.

data.name: Modellistica ambientale

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description: This advanced course on numerical methods for hyperbolic, parabolic, and elliptic partial differential equations (PDE) gives the students a broad overview of the most important numerical methods available for environmental engineers to solve relevant problems in their scientific field that are governed by partial differential equations arising in solid and fluid mechanics and to implement these mathematical algorithms in form of computer programs. In particular, examples of linear and nonlinear parabolic equations are considered such as Stefan equation of solidification (icing), Richards equation of filtration, Exner equations of sediment transport, as well as their coupling with nonlinear hyperbolic shallow water equations. Therefore, great emphasis is being put on laboratory exercises (coding sessions), which should make the student familiar with the issues of the programming of advanced mathematical algorithms in Matlab.
data.degreeProgram: Ingegneria per l'ambiente e il territorio (LM)

data.name: International sustainable development

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
PART I


Part I has the following learning goals: make the student acquire basic knowledge, skills, and competencies to apply concepts, principles, strategies, and theoretical-practical tools of sustainable development in their professional and working activities (in companies, in public administrations, in third sector bodies, in education/training institutions), with particular attention to the international dimension, as well as to cultivate job or volunteer opportunities in the vast field of sustainability and international cooperation. The course is also useful as a professional refresher and retraining path.

Consequently, as expected learning outcomes, the student, upon passing the related tests, will be able to:

a) build and enhance a good critical understanding of specific international and local contexts in which sustainable development and in particular environmental sustainability will be applied;

b) understand and use the basic concepts and principles related to sustainable development, especially in the environmental sphere, and the advanced ones peculiar to its application in the field of international cooperation;

c) to know and interact with the many subjects involved in various capacities in the areas covered by the course;

d) understand, analyse, and apply the sustainable development goals set by the system of the relevant global and local agendas, as well as the goals of other relevant global agendas (contents and methods);

e) use and adapt to their contexts the main tools and methods for sustainable development and international cooperation, with special attention to those for environmental sustainability; in particular, apply the Environmental Mainstreaming Approach.



PART II


The learning goals of Part II are: providing students with a "toolbox" to read, analyse and understand the contexts in which they operate and manage interventions that involve a variety of stakeholders, intervening in a sustainable way to promote economic and social development even in situations of conflict.

As expected learning outcomes, the student, upon passing the related tests, will be able to:

• produce a critical reading of the contexts in which he/she is called to operate, with particular attention to: the relationship between stakeholders and the environment, ethnic diversity, power relations, organization, and territorial innovation;

• carry out an analysis of conflicts, with particular reference to environmental ones, and experiment with some methods for managing them;

• know some project methods, with particular reference to those typically used in the field of sustainability in international contexts, through the practical experimentation of some of them.
data.degreeProgram: Ingegneria per l'ambiente e il territorio (LM)

data.name: Distributed systems 1

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The goal of the course is to expose the students to the core concepts of distributed systems, and to the main technologies underlying distributed applications. 

The main portion of the course is devoted to a discussion of the fundamental concepts and challenges in distributed systems, that focuses on the illustration of several classical algorithms. These algorithms are chosen to exemplify commonly-used solutions and to highlight fundamental principles and techniques concerned with the problem at hand. A second portion of the course is devoted to the middleware technologies commonly used to develop distributed applications. Alongside standard lectures, this topic includes hands-on sessions in the lab. 

The course ends with a peek at advanced topics, showing how the general notion of distributed systems is declined in two very different scenarios: i) the data centers at the back-end of planetary-scale systems (e.g., Google, Amazon, Yahoo), and ii) the fluid and dynamic setting involving several tiny, resource-scarce, wireless devices envisioned by the Internet of Things.

By the end of the course, students are expected to have obtained of a broad understanding of the key challenges in distributed systems, of the classic solutions and associated trade-offs, as well as to have acquired the ability to autonomously design relatively simple applications.

data.name: Diritto civile e scienze cognitive
data.description: The acquisitions of cognitive sciences and neurosciences offer new tools to the civil law. These means, together with the traditional conceptual baggage of the jurist, allow us to aim at an ever greater rationality of decisions. The course aims to introduce students to the study of these new relationships between civil law and psychology.

data.name: Security and states of emergency: A constitutional law perspective
Advanced geometry
data.description:
Goal of the course is to give to the students the basic notions of real and complex differential topology. 

At the end of the course the student will have acquired the basic knowledge in the theory of real (including the case with boundary) and complex differential manifolds. He will be able to compute De Rham cohomology rings, to determine through cohomological computations topological properties like orientability, connectedness or the existence of some intersection among submanifolds. Finally he will be able to solve, in simple cases, problems like if we can comb a manifold or if a self map has fixed points, translating them in cohomological computations.

data.degreeProgram: Comparative, European and International Legal Studies (L2)

data.name: International Economics
data.description:
The goal of this course is to identify and to map, empirically and theoretically, the main phenomena of the current trade system in the global economy. The course provides insights into the reasons for trade at country and firm level, gains from trade, trade policy tools and international agreements, as well as contexts in which students can engage in debate, discussion, and reflections on the main issues related to trade policies.

By the end of the course students should have acquired:

• an in-depth understanding of the different advantages and costs of trade from various viewpoints of trade theory.

• the use of the necessary basic tools (f. i. some basic trade indices) to analyse, at country and firm level, the contemporary international and European trade relations.

• to apply theoretical perspectives in analysing related policy questions, especially the effects of trade barriers and industry protection.

• to understand the structure and functioning of international trading system and associated institutions (such as the WTO) and regional trade agreements.

Thanks to the revolution of single cell sequencing, we can obtain genome-wide data (omics) from single cells. This course provides the mathematical tools essential for the understanding of some numerical methods with particular emphasis on their stability and accuracy properties and the algorithmic aspects.
Learning outcomes: understand the main features of the methods in order to be able to choose and implement  the more appropriate method to use on a particular situation; familiarize the student with the technical terminology and concepts of the subject.

data.name: Gestione delle acque e dei sedimenti per lo sviluppo sostenibile

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
The course deals with water, river sediment and development in a broad sense. It takes a multi-scale (international to local) and multi-dimensional approach and focuses on four main themes: global water and sediment issues, river management and development, access to basic water and sanitation services, water- and sediment-related hazards in the developing world. The course is based on integration among different disciplines – as in the frequently addressed case of eco-hydraulics – and between the technical / engineering and the social, cultural and economical context.


The learning goals of the course are:


1. To develop a critical understanding of the multiple linkages between water, sediment and sustainable human development at different spatial and temporal scales.


2: To understand the main challenges in linking water and sediment management with development issues at an international level, with particular focus on data-scarce contexts


3. To learn design criteria and operation and mainteinance requirements of water supply technologies at community scale


4. To learn the main phenomena, orders of magnitudes, and available data bases on global and continental scale availability and use of water and sediment resources

data.name: Social inequalities and education

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description: The aim of this course is to develop knowledge on the relations between education, social inequalities and the labour market in contemporary societies. Regular attendance and active participation in class, together with individual- and group-based study, will allow the students to: 1) recall the main institutional and organizational features of educational systems and their changes over time; 2) identify the various forms of social inequality in education and their changes over time; 3) compare different theories on the reproduction of social inequalities in education; 4) critically discuss theories about the occupational returns to education; 5) acquire theoretical and methodological skills needed to conduct theory-driven quantitative empirical research on the relations between education, social inequalities and the labour market.

The course will provide an introduction into various
famous algorithms in algebra. At the end of the course the student will be able to apply these algorithms in concrete situations, and will have knowledge of the proofs of some of the key results that underpin the algorithms.

data.name: Diritto penitenziario
Geostoria
data.description:
Landscape, environment, and territory have become crucial in the national and international debate about governance and heritage.

The course aims to provide students with basic and advanced conceptual tools of the geohistorical and historical geographic approach, for the purpose to develop a critical and diachronic approach to territorial, environmental, and landscape issues, also with application and enhancement aims.

Students will acquire skills in reading and interpreting the main sources for geohistorical and historical geographic research (textual, iconographic, cartographic, territorial).

At the end of the course, students:

1. will have an in-depth overview of the considerations on geographic-historical and geohistorical epistemology at an international level;

2. will develop an analytical mastery of historical sources and geographical and thematic maps; therefore, they will be able to develop a diachronic reading of territorial and landscape elements also with applicative purposes such as the identification of the historical-environmental heritage and the planning of laboratories for the learning of history and geography;

3. will become aware of the most advanced methods and tools of geographical-historical research;

4. will consolidate the knowledge of the geographical language and of new digital technologies applied to the discipline, both for research purposes and for their use in specific teaching and learning processes of history and geography.

data.name: Clinical Neurology and Neuropsychology
data.description: Knowledge: 1. Basic neuroanatomy 2. Epidemiology, pathogenesis and natural history of the most common neurological disorders. 3. History of neuropsychology. 4. Methodology in neuropsychology: clinical tests vs. research. 5. Neuropsychological examination: clinical examination and psychometric tests. 6. The main neuropsychological syndromes. Understanding: 1. The impact of neurological disease on behavior 2. Differences between clinical approach (diagnostic / localization) and research approach. 3. Interpretation of the results of a neuropsychological procedure: dissociations, localization vs. function. Ability to apply knowledge and understanding: 1. Interpretation of the literature. 2. Prediction of a person's behavior based on brain injury. 3. Ability to set up and perform a clinical neuropsychological examination. 4. Formulate a diagnostic orientation based on clinical data

data.name: Programmazione 2

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: The course aims at providing students with a broad understanding of object-oriented and event-based programming. The fundamental concepts that characterize each programming language (memory management, scope rules, visibility of identifiers, structured code and data structures, abstraction), and those that characterize object-oriented programming (OOP) will be acquired: class, object , inheritance, polymorphism, information hiding, static and dynamic binding. The student will also be introduced to functional programming (FP). At the end of the course, the student will be able to identify and describe the characteristics of the different paradigms and choose the one most suitable for solving specific problems. He will also be able to correctly structure a program using OOP, identifying and implementing its constituent classes, using a basic UML representation that will be deepened in subsequent courses and documenting the code. He will be able to use the Standard ML and Java languages, and will be familiar with the latter's APIs. S/he will also have a basic knowledge of the OOP constructs of the C ++ language. The knowledge acquired will allow the student to self-learn other languages in the future with little effort (eg Python and C #).

data.name: Diritto del commercio e dell'arbitrato internazionale
data.description:
The course aims at providing an overview of international commercial arbitration as the preferred instrument for resolving disputes arising from cross-border trade.
At the end of the course, the student should:
- have acquired basic knowledge of arbitration as the main method of extra-judicial dispute resolution;
- have developed a critical attitude towards common usages of globalized trade, especially with regard to advantages and disadvantages of private justice.

data.name: Experimental Physics Laboratory at High School Level I

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
This course aims to provide an introduction to the fundamental concepts of Physics Education Research and to the design of experimental activities for teaching physics.

The course also aims to discuss the basic theory of measurement and error and examine the main features of the Laboratory instruments.


Some experimental activities will be presented from an educational point of view and some case studies will be considered by adopting both traditional laboratory equipment and new technologies applied to the laboratory of physics.

Experimental activities will be performed directly by students working in small groups.


At the end of the course, the student will be able to

1) autonomously design experiments

2) Perform experiments using appropriately the equipment of the physics lab

3) Analyze experimental data using the theory of measurement and error


Ultimately the course aims to prepare students as future teachers of experimental physics courses by introducing them to experimental techniques, teaching methodologies and the design of didactic experiments.

At the end of the course, the student will know the main microorganisms of agricultural interest, their biological characteristics and the methodologies for their isolation, identification and cultivation (where possible). The student will acquire the ability to identify microorganisms with both classical microbiology techniques and the most innovative techniques based on molecular methods. The student will acquire knowledge about the metabolism, multiplication and industrial production of microorganisms of agricultural interest. At the end of the course, the student will be able to handle bacterial and fungal cultures of agricultural interest. And also cover aspects of the biochemistry, physiology and genetics of microorganisms

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

The aim of the course is to introduce students to the application of cognitive science to support interaction design between humans and artificial (digital and non-digital) systems, with a special interes for applications concerning wellbeing and happiness.
At the end of the course students will have acquired (individually and in groups) theoretical and practical tools for designing and evaluating products, services, work, systems and environments that are compatible with human well-being, that is, with human needs, limits, abilities and aspirations, and the full expression of her/his potential.

data.name: Marketing progredito
Reti
data.description:
We all take it for granted that our smartphone can access a story on social media, that our messages and photos reach their destination, that video calls with family and friends work at the push of a button. But none of these things could exist without the (complex) telecommunication infrastructure that allows them to exchange data: the Internet.


This course introduces the fundamentals (and many details) of the Internet, and computer networks in general. After a first part dedicated to the theoretical foundations of communication networks (e.g., what is a protocol? What architecture do networks have?), the course explores why (that is, for which applications) we need a global network infrastructure; how we ensure end-to-end communications (both in best effort mode and with error control); how data is routed in distributed networks, and how the use of shared communication channels is managed (especially in wireless networks).


At the end of the course the student

  • will know how the Internet and computer networks work
  • will understand the details of the protocols that underpin computer networks

and thanks also to laboratory activities

  • will be able to configure the a network by acting on the main network-layer and transport-layer protocols.

data.name: Next generation networks

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: In the past two decades, the Internet has grown from a research tool to a fundamental part of society. This course will explore why the infrastructure was designed this way, and the underlying principles and design decisions. The course will focus on emerging issues and paradigms, including virtualization and softwarization (VLAN, VXLAN, SD-WAN, SDN, NFV), cloud computing (VMs, containers), Internet of Things, vehicular networks, 5G and beyond, and other technologies shaping the Internet of the Future. A specific dedicated set of hands-on sessions will enable students to learn how to manage the above technologies and how to use state-of-the-art network programmable and virtualization platforms (NI USRPs, Docker, etc.).

data.name: Bio-Inspired Artificial Intelligence

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The goal of this course is to study two of the main paradigms of Bio-Inspired Artificial Intelligence, namely: Evolutionary Computation, inspired by evolutionary biology, and Swarm Intelligence, inspired by collective behaviors of social animals. First, the main theories and algorithms will be introduced. Then, it will be shown how these techniques can be applied, for instance, for solving complex optimization problems, training data-driven models, generating new contents (video-games, websites, art), finding bugs in software, automatically synthesizing or fixing computer programs, or finding innovative solutions in robotics, logistics, and engineering. Finally, it will be shown how these techniques can help the understanding of biological systems, in order to close the loop between biology and AI.

At the end of this course, students will be familiar with the most important Evolutionary Computation and Swarm Intelligence techniques, and will be able to apply them to different contexts in industry, research, or even entertainment. They will also know the fundamentals for developing new algorithms and adapt them to new problems.

data.name: Storia della critica d'arte II
data.description: Baroque Aesthetics: The course aims to be an introduction to the art criticism of Baroque Italy and the shaping of the seventeenth-century critical discourse on artistic work, with particular reference to Italy, emphasizing the importance of direct consultation and interpretation of primary textual sources. In parallel with this study of primary sources, contemporary, often contradictory analyses of this period will also be read.

The methods developed in class will be studied in detail, implemented on a computer, and tested on several examples.

At the end of this course each student should be able to set up numerical methods and produce the expected results.

Organizzazione aziendale

Critical thinking and the application of the scientific method are the basis of problem solving and decision-making, particularly in decision-making processes for digital innovation. The course also introduces computational models useful for decision making. Models will be presented to transform data into better organizational decisions.


A simulated organizational environment will offer the possibility to put the acquired knowledge into practice. Expert visits will enable students to understand career options in this rapidly changing space.

Teorie e tecniche di riconoscimento

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description: The aim of the course is to introduce students to the basic principles of recognition and machine learning based on artificial neural networks, as in the so-called Connectionist approach (or Parallel Distributed Processing). The course illustrates how these principles provide a theoretical and technological tool to support the creation of artificial intelligence technologies on the other hand the understanding of human cognition. The course is divided in a theoretical part and a practical part consisting in the development of artificial neural network models with a simulator.

data.name: Storia del pensiero economico
data.description:
The evolution of economic thought, similar to that of other disciplines, does not follow a linear path, characterized by the progressive solution and "archiving" of the problems faced. On the contrary, if we analyze the roots of the various and different approaches to economic theory between the middle of the last century and the present era (i.e. the evolution of the contemporary debate), we often come across concepts and problems that were at the attention of economics scholars hundreds of years ago. Similarly to what happens in other scientific fields - for example in the field of astronomy - the ability to observe reality and to process and interpret the data collected gradually increases; however there is a different trait - which is instead common to all the social sciences - given by the progressive change of the reality under study. In other words, we are not faced with an "immutable" reality, whose behavior follows laws that scientific research allows us to understand "better" (whatever the epistemological meaning of this expression), but an economic and social system whose characteristics change over time. But the problems reappear and concepts that were considered to have already been sufficiently elaborated recursively return to the center of the analysis. The production and distribution of income, economic development, the role of money - to mention some of the main problems - require increasingly sophisticated analyzes, which however have their roots in theoretical elaborations even very far in time. Hence the importance, even for those immersed in contemporary debates, of knowing the ways and forms in which these problems have presented themselves and have been addressed in the past, developing concepts that are still at the center of theoretical reflection.

The course therefore aims to provide students with a logical structure to frame the evolution of economic thought and the development of the most important theories, up to the threshold of contemporary debate. Its goal is to enable the student to:


a) Learn about the evolution of the economic thought, within the framework of the evolving historical facts
b) Recognize the main schools of thought and identify their critical issues and points
c) Recognize the specific origins and frameworks of the contemporary economic theories 
d) Assess the appropriateness of a given analytical framework with respect to the problems analyzed by the economist

data.name: Architetture digitali avanzate

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.name: Recycling and sustainable materials
data.description:
Objectives:

This course is focused on materials and the environment: the eco-aspects of materials’ production, use, and disposal at end of life. The course also provides an overview of materials selection and design approaches that minimize the environmental impact.

 

After completing the course, the student will be able to:

- assess the sustainable development of a given articulation following a rigorous procedure;

- select an eco-sustainable material on the basis of its property profile and interaction with the environment;

- measure the main properties of biopolymers and wood-related materials according to the relevant standards;

- design a component taking the most suitable end-of-first-life options into proper account;

- design a life cycle assessment analysis on a practical case.

 

 

Learning outcomes:

At the end of the course, the student should be able to:

·      illustrate the concept of sustainable development and the ways in which it is evaluated for a given articulation;

·      explain the physical-mechanical properties and the applications of wood-related materials and materials for thermal insulation;

·      classify and compare the various families of biopolymers and their properties in the different applications, in order to select the best candidate material for a given application;

·      illustrate the recycling methods for the various materials, highlighting the pros and the cons of each of them;

·      explain the life cycle assessment (LCA) methodology in its theoretical and practical aspects

·      produce and characterize eco-sustainable materials, analyze the experimental data, and generate a technical report with the results and discussion of the analysis.

data.description: The purpose of this course is to introduce students to the institution of the museum using the operational-architectural tools of museography and the theoretical-historical analysis of museology.

data.name: Neurodegenerative Diseases

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description:
This is a course that illustrates the molecular and cellular basis of neurodegenerative diseases and the underlying mechanisms of pathology. The genetics, biochemistry and cell biology of the major human neurodegenerative diseases will be discussed, taking advantage of recently published scientific papers. The course will explore their pathogenic commonalities and differences, also including discussions of animal models and prospects for therapeutics. This course will provide students with a timely update on this rapidly advancing area of investigation. 
At the end of the course students will be able to: 1) remember the spectrum of neurodegenerative diseases and their complex genetic, pathological, biochemical and cellular features; 2) explain prospects for therapeutic development; 3) understand and correlate the common pathogenic mechanisms; 4) defend the leading hypotheses regarding the biochemical and cellular dysfunctions that cause neurodegeneration; 5) mostly, derive a critical thinking on how to progress the research on neurodegenerative diseases.

data.name: Ingegneria degli acquiferi e dei siti contaminati

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description: The course provides the students with the skills needed for the design of remediation actions and management of contaminated sites, as well as the design of sustainable utilization systems of subsurface water resources in view of the impact of climate change and the growing anthropic pressure. Attention is given to the interaction between groundwater and underground structures and groundwater protection. The first part of the course deals with the design of remediation systems for groundwater and contaminated sites, as well as the design of efficient and sustainable groundwater exploitation systems. The second part of the course deals with the study of the physical and biogeochemical processes controlling the occurrence and the quality of groundwater. Flow and transport modeling is considered here because instrumental to the modern design of water exploitation and remediation systems for contaminated sites. The students will acquire the skills needed for the design of effective remediation systems of contaminated sites, the design of groundwater utilization systems as well as to quantify the interaction between groundwater and underground infrastructures.

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
The aim of the course is to provide the students  with the analytical tools to understand the legal problems connected to the development of digital technologies, with specific reference to intellectual property and privacy. Other legal institutions  affected by the recent technological developments will be also investigated.

Traditional legal institutions will be analyzed with reference to their economic and social functions and in the light of information and communication technologies. At the end of the course students should be able the deal with the covered legal issues by analyzing them and finding proper solutions with reference to the relevant regulations, case law and legal analysis.

data.name: Organizzazione aziendale

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description:
The course analyses the organisation as a scaffold designed to cope with the inter-dependencies arising from the division of labour and specialisation. After a description of inter-dependencies, some tools available to economic organisations are analysed: property and control, organisational structures, rules and procedures, and their recent evolution. A seminar in the last part of the course is devoted to the study of of family business.


Learning outcomes:

At the end of the course, students are expected to:

1. Know the most important inter-dependencies among agents, and their representation tools;

2. Acquire a theoretical comprehension of how organization help manage inter-dependencies;

3. Be capable to understand in real contexts how a firm uses the organizational tools;

4. Be able to design organizational improvements in real contexts.


Moreover, the attending student is expected to improve teamworking and public presentation skills.

data.description:
The main objective of the course is to provide the basis for the design of reinforced concrete and steel structures using the current Italian and European standards.

 

At the end of the course, the student will be able to:

 

- perform load analysis of civil structures.

- apply load combinations according to the current Italian and European standards.

- estimate basic seismic actions according to the current Italian and European standards.

- know the mechanical properties of the most common construction materials.

- design and verify at limit states (ultimate and serviceability) reinforced concrete structural elements such as beams and columns.

- design and verify at limit states (ultimate and serviceability) structural steel elements such as beams and columns.

At the end of the course the students will be able to:

data.name: Neuroimaging for Data Science

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description: Neuroimaging methods are pervasively used in brain and cognitive neuroscience research, and crucially depend on a multidisciplinary approach leveraging on advanced computer and data science, statistics, neuro-computational modeling, and large-scale data repositories conforming to an open-science and big-data perspective. The main objective of this course is to lay out the methodological foundations of three widely employed brain imaging techniques that are also available at CIMeC (Unitn), namely magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), magnetoencephalography (MEG), and electroencephalography (EEG). For both techniques, the course will furthermore provide an in-depth overview of state-of-the-art methods for data acquisition, data processing, statistical analysis, and multi-scale data organization. At the end of the course, students should have acquired a good overview of advanced MRI, MEG, and EEG methods, and should have learned the relevant concepts and appropriate terminology. Moreover, they should have gained an in-depth knowledge of the widely recommended resources and pipelines for data handling and processing, based on the current consensus in the neuroscientific community.

data.name: Advanced Topics in Machine Learning and Optimization

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: The course aims at introducing students to some selected advanced topics on machine learning and optimization. The topics are chosen so as to cover relevant recent research directions and challenges for the machine learning and artificial intelligence community, as well as promising technological advancements.

data.name: Mental illness in English literature

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description:
This course aims at developing students’ comprehension of how dementia syndrome and Alzheimer’s disease are represented in both literary-cultural and scientific-medical discourses in English, and of how the humanistic-artistic and the bio-medical and empirical approaches can be complementaryǝ. By analysing literary texts and films that represent the complexities of human mind and identity, students will be able to enhance their understanding of the interrelation of language, memory and representation.

At the end of the course, students are expected to have achieved the following competences: interdisciplinary competences, autonomous judgement, and communication skills.
data.degreeProgram: Scienze e Tecniche di Psicologia Cognitiva (L2)

data.name: Fonti e tendenze della ricerca storica
Network Modelling and Simulation
data.description:
Objectives

The student will learn about systems view of biological networks, where quantitative and dynamic considerations of biological properties are in the foreground. The biological entities will be studied with an emphasis on the emergent behavior resulting from the interactions of the network components. The student will thus be equipped with an interdisciplinary skill-set for studying such systems in a way that brings together notions from biology, applied mathematics and computer science.


Learning outcomes

At the end of the course the students will be able to:

a) Work on biological questions using analytical methods with the aim of providing systems level "holistic" answers.

b) Develop the critical thinking skills required to understand and evaluate the results introduced in a scientific paper in the area of modelling and simulation of biological dynamics.

c) Become familiar with a spectrum of techniques from applied mathematics and computer science with respect to their strengths and their limitations in various biological settings.

d) Use programming technologies to formalize various biological problems for simulation, sensitivity analysis and model calibration and choose the most appropriate computational strategy depending on the considered biological problem.
