Rilievo dell'architettura con Laboratorio Progettuale

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description: “Architectural survey” teaches the historical, scientific and operational fundamentals of the survey discipline on an architectural and urban scale. The main goal of the course is to provide students with the basic theoretical and technical knowledge necessary for the development of a properly codified geometric model, as for the achievement of a critical and qualitative interpretation of the built work. Therefore, the course aims to lead the student towards a conscious use and a critical experimentation of the procedures useful for the description, measurement, classification, representation and communication of the architectural artifact, its elements and the place where it rises. At the end of the course the student will be able to: use the open air survey as a direct tool for understanding reality; plan and perform metric data acquisition using traditional and advanced methods; analyze the visible forms and derive information on historical characters, structural reasons, material and constructive peculiarities; compare direct experience with historical and archival research; build a 3D digital model based on the topographic and photogrammetric data; visualize the outcomes of survey through graphic tables and thematic multi-scale maps; simulate particular aspects or purposes by means of multimedia and interactive applications; apply the critical terms “measure” and “model” in the analytical and planning field.

data.name: Lab. appl.: La traduzione del diritto dell'Unione Europea/Workshop on legal translation of the Law of the European Union
data.description: The course will introduce the students to the problems deriving from translating legal concepts and to the knowledge of legal language, European in particular. The activity of translation of linguistic expressions transmitting legal data implies the transposition of concepts from one legal system to a different one (or to more than ones); as a consequence, the correct use of the methodology of comparative law, as well as of the methodological tools of other scientific sciences (e.g. linguistic) is needed. Nowadays this activity has become particularly important because of the process of European integration, as being the translation a crucial phase of the drafting, interpretation and application of directives and regulations; similarly, translation is important in the publication of the decisions of the Court of Justice of the European Union and in the creation of principles of European law. Therefore, during the course particular attention will be dedicated to the translation of European Union law, to national law implementing directives and to European private law. At the end of the workshop the students will: - understand the characteristic of the legal language of the EU; - compare the different language versions and, in case of divergences, uncover the concept (or concepts) which transfers the ratio legis of that specific European legal act; - have learned examples of legal terminology of the EU in the chosen language (legal English, German or French).

data.name: Automated Planning: Theory and Practice

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: Planning and Scheduling is the task of thinking before you act: use knowledge about the world to determine what and when to do an action to achieve a given goal. Automated planning and scheduling is a central topic in Artificial Intelligence (AI), and task and motion planning capabilities are essential to the construction of many robust autonomous systems. Research in planning and scheduling is active and exciting. Planning and scheduling problems have been tackled with a variety of new approaches to address efficiency, expressivity, and practical applicability. Planning and scheduling technologies are currently used with great success in several real applications ranging from production lines and elevators to unmanned aerial and sub-sea vehicles (UAVs) and space applications. The aim of this course is to provide a comprehensive theoretical view of a wide range of planning and scheduling techniques, as well as hands-on experience in constructing and modeling planning domains to solve specific planning problems, and if time allows to experiment the control of robotic agents. After the course, the student will be able to: • Evaluate and apply a variety of planning techniques and tools for classical planning and scheduling as well as planning and scheduling under different kind uncertainty (temporal and discrete). • Explain the practical advantages and disadvantages of different levels of expressivity in planning and scheduling models. • Model classical planning and scheduling problems in commonly used domain definition languages (e.g. PDDL), and if time allows, we will consider probabilistic planning problems as well. • Evaluate and apply common techniques for goal-directed planning, such as various forms of heuristics and control rules. • Experiment with realistic robotic agents (depending on time and availability of the robotic agents in the Robotic Lab or through simulations within ROS infrastructure).

data.name: Partial Differential Equations
data.description:
Aim of the course is that of presenting the most relevant types of partial differential equations (elliptic, parabolic, hyperbolic: especially in the linear case), together with the physical models that they describe. Specifically, the functional framework is introduced and it is shown to be suitable for clarifying under which conditions the problems associated with these differential equations are well-posed (existence, uniqueness, stability); [Only for 9-credit course: the students are then introduced to elliptic regularity and maximum principles.]

At the end of the course the student will be able to get oriented among the various types of partial differential equations, to know which are the characteristic qualitative properties of the solutions, to have a deeper knowledge of the mathematical approach to these problems as well as some fluency in the use of modern techniques for the study of these themes.

data.name: Multi-scale methods in soft matter physics

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description:
The module aims at providing students with the fundamental theoretical knowledge to set up and solve computational physics problems in the area of soft matter.

At the end of the course, students will be capable of:

1) Formalising, from the mathematical and modelling point of view, a soft matter problem.
2) Choosing and employing the most appropriate tool (be that an approach, an algorithm, or a computational one) to solve the specific problem under examination.
3) Developing soft matter system models and employ them in analytical or computational calculations.
4) Analysing the results and comprehend their implications.
5) Critically examining the pertinent scientific literature in the field of soft matter.

data.name: Etica sociale
Scienza delle costruzioni

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
This course provides the basic tools for the analysis and the understanding of the resistant and deformational mechanisms of structural systems employed in structural engineering, with special reference to isotropic linear elasticity.

At the end of this course, students will be able to:

1. Recognize and manage structural constraints both in statics and kinematics;

2. Classify and analyze statically determinate structures;

3. Classify and analyze statically indeterminate structures;

4. Evaluate and determine the critical loads of beams and structures under compressive loads;

5. Compute and represent stresses on the cross-section of an elastic prismatic beam, due to combinations of acting forces.

The course given by Prof Bigoni is addressed to students of Civil Engineering, while the course given by Prof Pugno is dedicated to students of Environmental Engineering. For Civil Engineering more emphasis will be given on structural analysis, while for Environmental Engineering on the design of dams and the finite element methods.

Human-Machine Dialogue

data.description: Robots that can talk or chat with humans are becoming pervasive in many industry domains and applications. Such agents are called conversational AI systems. In this course the student will learn the basic principles of human computer interaction, conversation linguistics, discourse analysis, computational dialogue models and architectures and their evaluation. In the second part of the course the student will develop a conversational system while  learning the design methodologies, data-driven training and dialogue development tools .

data.name: Storia dei paesi islamici I
data.description: This course aims at providing the students with the general understanding of the political and historical evolution of modern Middle East, starting from the decline of the Ottoman Empire up until present time. By introducing the theoretical framework of the process of modernization together with the theories of  international relations, this course main objective is to offer an in-depth analysis of modern Middle East, both from a historical and international relations perspectives. The course offers analytical background to the main sources of power (economic, military and symbolic) which have been and are yet fundamentally relevant within the Middle Eastern States, highlighting their role in the political process of the Middle East..

data.name: Gestione sostenibile delle imprese
data.description:
The course aims to present how to incorporate sustainable methods into all aspects of an organization and to describe the most important tools for monitoring, managing and improving environmental performance.
Attendance and active participation at the course and self-study will enable students to:
1. Know the role of the management in developing an environmentally and socially responsible enterprise
2. Know and Apply Environmental Communication Tools
3. Organize the activities to carry out an environmental audit
4. Identify and Measure some environmental costs in the firms budget

data.name: Digital social data

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
The interdisciplinary course of Digital Social Data, aims to offer an introduction to the various approaches that computer scientist, economists, lawyers and sociologists adopt to approach a highly complex issue as Big data and Open data.
The Digital Social Data course is divided into two parts. In the first part, the course aims to provide an introduction to the different theoretical, methodological and technical implications of the advent of digital data in the field of social science research. The student will be provided with cross-language skills that are useful in dealing with a multidisciplinary subject. At the end of this part, the student will be able to distinguish the different theoretical / disciplinary approaches to Big Data themes.
The second part of the course will have a methodological and applied character and will introduce the student to the use of the big data. In this part, will be given to the student notions of programming and data analysis in R@ in highly complex contexts.
At the end of this second part, the student: a) will know how to identify the different methodological approaches in handling Big Data; b) will be able to evaluate the main types of analysis that can be conducted on the Big Data; c) apply the main programming tools in R @ to the Big Data; and, d) will independently conduct elemental analysis of highly complex data in R@.

data.name: Artificial and biological neural systems

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: Students will acquire the ability to understand principles of cognitive neuroscience that are relevant for understanding current thinking in AI and Cognitive Computational Neuroscience. They will be able to consider application of neuroscience to AI, and conversely, potential applications of AI to neuroscience, taking into consideration both similarities and differences in the representations of the human and artificial systems.

data.name: Numerical methods for PDEs
data.description:
This course covers the theory of the finite element method for the 
approximation of the solution of partial differential equations.
The methods studied will be implemented in the laboratory using Matlab and 
FreeFem.
The learning outcomes include the understanding of the main features of 
the finite elements method for the approximation of the solution of elliptic 
and parabolic partial differential equations, and its theoretical properties. 
Having attended the course, the students will be familiar with the technical 
terminologies and concepts of the subject, and will have a good grasp of how
to implement the methods in practice.

data.description:
The course provides competences in the understanding and use of quantitative methods for the analysis of social science phenomena. It will follow a theory guided empirical research approach, introduce the translation of a research question in an empirical research, and the choice of most appropriate data and methods to test theoretically derived hypothesis. data.name: High-Throughput Screening

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description:
The goal of this module is to provide the basis for the understanding of modern biomedical research technologies, including high-throughput screening (HTS) and functional genomics, relevant in the drug discovery process. In addition, the course will cover knowledge on biophysical techniques used to characterize biomolecular structures/interactions and tools for the development of new experimental models: cellular and in vivo models, cell reprogramming, genome editing. 

On completion of this course the students will be able to describe and use: 
Module 1
Upon successful completion of this module, students should:
Know the main steps of the Drug Discovery process
Distinguish among different approaches
Learn from the example of the discovery of Gleevec
Know about paradigm shift in innovation: from closed innovation to open innovation
Familiarize with High Throughput Screening terminology 
Explain  the differences between experiments on the bench and in HT setting
Understand the rationale of HTS in academia

Module 2
Upon successful completion of this module, students should:
Know about the main players of the HTS process
Familiarize with the library formats, miniaturization and Microplates choice 
Understand the principle of liquid handling technologies
Learn about a pooled screening approach: DNA Encoded Libraries
Illustrate the requirements of a Bioassay for HTS and the possible classification
Apply different detection methods to the correct assay
Be able to go through the data analysis process
Be aware of the methods for multidimensional data analysis
List the canonical targets of common drugs and be aware of the druggable space 

Module 3
Upon successful completion of this module, students should:
Distinguish between biochemical and cell based assays
Be able to choose the right assay for the right target
Know the basics of target-compound interaction
List the existing  biophysical techniques for molecules interaction
Design a cell-based screening
Describe the strategy to assess Cytotoxicity/Viability/Apoptosis 
Illustrate the modern tools for reporter gene assays
Learn from a reporter screening case
Familiarize with advanced models for cell-based screening assays: stem cells, iPS cells, 3D models

Module 4
Upon successful completion of this module, students should:
Distinguish between target based and phenotypic screening,
Know about High Content Screening: the  workflow,  instrumentation and software
Understand the principle of High Content Analysis
Apply the right  staining to the right assay
Learn from HCS cases
Know about the principle of functional genomics
Describe the tools for RNA interference, miRNA regulation, CRISPR/Cas9 technology
Familiarize with RNAi screening: arrayed and pooled
Learn from RNAi screening cases

data.name: Social demography

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description: This course provides an overview of concepts, methods and current debates in social demography, offering students the tools necessary to describe population prospects around the world; retrieve, analyse and interpret demographic data; compare and contrast theories of demographic change; critically evaluate the consequences of demographic change for societies and social policy.
data.degreeProgram: Sociology and social research - Sociologia e ricerca sociale (LM)

data.name: Advanced Cognitive Psychology and Neuroscience
data.description:
The course consists in in-depth discussions on topics from different areas of cognitive science and neuroscience (perception, attention, action, memory and learning, decision making). The course will mainly cover recent studies that use different and complementary methods of investigation (fMRI, EEG, MEG, TMS, psychophysics, experimental psychology, with healthy subjects and with brain-injured patients) and will address specific issues, many of which are still the subject of active scientific debate. Students will be invited to actively participate in these discussions and debates by reading, presenting, and discussing scientific articles, among themselves and with the teachers in class.
The educational objectives of the course are to provide the following skills to students:
- Knowledge of the main results and the main issues in cognitive neuroscience, and especially those that are still widely debated.
- Ability to understand and critically analyze experimental studies in the field of cognitive neuroscience.
- Ability to design experimental designs to answer specific theoretical questions in this discipline.

data.name: Storia contemporanea II - LM
data.description:
at the end of the course, students will be able to:

  • know the different definition of human rights offered during the 20th century
  • know the main tools for human rights promotion and the main moments and turning points in human rights history
  • know the main historiographical debates about human rights
data.degreeProgram: Letterature euroamericane, traduzione e critica letteraria (LM)

data.name: Brain Development and Disease
data.description:
This course will address molecular, cellular, anatomical and functional aspects of development and disorders of the central nervous system. Specific topics will include embryonic development, postnatal critical periods of visual, auditory and language areas, neurodevelopmental disorders, and neurodegenerative disorders. The objective is to present an updated view of our understanding of human brain development and its impact on brain pathologies, making the student able to understand what are the biological mechanisms of brain development and their potential pathological outcomes.


At the end of the course, the student should be able to:

- describe basic mechanisms of gene expression in the brain;

- describe the most relevant approaches to study gene function in vivo:

- describe the salient mechanisms of embryonic and postnatal brain development;

- describe the salient mechanisms of neurodevelopmental and neurodegenerative disorders.

data.name: Foundations of Cognitive Psychology and Neuroscience I
data.description:
This course provides a comprehensive overview of the core topics in cognitive neuroscience, including perception, attention, action, memory, language, concepts, and social cognition. We will present both classical and recent research findings obtained with a variety of cognitive neuroscience methods (fMRI, EEG, MEG, TMS, behavior, neurological patients).


The objective of the course is to provide the students with the following competences:

- Knowledge of the main topics in cognitive neuroscience

- Knowledge of the main experimental techniques and methods

- Ability to define formulate specific experimental design to answer experimental questions

- Ability to critically understand experimental data and results

- Knowledge of the main open questions in cognitive neuroscience

data.name: Economic History
data.description:
The objective of the course is to provide (1) adequate knowledge of the major transformations of the European and world economies from the pre-industrial age to the contemporary era and the underlying factors; (2) the skills necessary to understand, analyze and critically interpret these transformations.

Upon completion of the course, the student will be able to:

- remember the basic concepts useful in the analysis of an economic system;

- describe the main historical manifestations of economic growth/development and crises;

- explain their causes and consequences, grasping the interaction between economic aspects and technological, institutional, cultural and geographical factors;

- communicate effectively in oral and written form, and argue on an economic historical topic.

data.name: Basi di dati

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
Data now pervades our world. Almost all human activities, to date, produce data or need to access data. Hence, solutions are needed that allow the storage, maintenance, search, and extraction of large amounts of data, in an effective and efficient way. Data management systems do just that. The objective of this course is to introduce students to the fundamental concepts of data management, teach good database design principles, let students learn how to construct complex queries, and allow them to identify and solve problems related to performance in real contexts.



The course will focus on relational databases, since the relational model is the most commonly employed data model in data management systems used in industry. Conceived now more than 30 years ago, the relational model is the most studied data model, and boasts the largest number of commercial tools currently active on the market.

data.name: Economia dell'impresa e responsabilità sociale
Economia delle risorse umane
data.description:
This is a course in Personnel Economics. This is an emerging field of research and human resource management in practice, where economic analysis is used to examine decisions (by individuals and management) within organisations. The main focus will be on the intuitions and descriptions of a wide range of decisions (by individuals as well as by organisations), more than on the presentation of formal economic models. Where possible, the discussion will focus on empirical evidence. The overriding goal of the course is to develop the capacity to understand, theoretically and empirically, the main decisions that take place within organisations: recruitment, selection, training, compensation, promotions, performance evaluation, and promotions.

By the end of the course, students: i) should have acquired an in-depth understanding of the main concepts and issues in personnel economics; ii) will be able to understand and explain the functioning of internal labour markets; iii) will have acquired the necessary analytical tools to analyse the decisions taken inside organisations by individuals and management.

data.description: At the end of the course, if proficiently followed, students will be able to formulate, analytically manage, and possibly solve, a control problem as well as an optimal control problem both coming from the applications and from a theoretical point of view. In particular, students will be able to recognize all the essential aspects of the mathematical model (both linear and nonlinear), to know the main questions and the possible answers about it. Moreover, students will know many of the theorems concerning the theory, their proofs, and their applications in order to study examples and counterexamples.

data.name: The Economics of European Integration
data.description: The aim of this course is to ensure that students understand economic and institutional aspects of the European economic integration process. By introducing a theoretical framework to analyse EU policies, students will improve their understanding of the economic rationale for European economic integration and their familiarity with the fiscal and monetary framework. The course will make students knowledgeable about the economics of the common agricultural policy, the EU regional/cohesion policy and the competition policy. By the end of this course, students should be able to apply economic theories to interpret and discuss the economic developments in the region, the crisis of and the proposed solutions to the European economic governance framework, Brexit and the pandemic crisis

data.name: Environmental sustainability

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
The course introduces key concepts to analyse relationships between politics and the environment, on the basis of literature on policy studies, and on theory of the commons. Special attention will be devoted to the multilevel analysis of the Sustainable Development Goals. In particular the course will address urban sustainability, agricultural production, risk evaluation of chemical pollution and climate change mitigation. 
At the end of the programme students will be able to:
- Describe main characteristics of contemporary environmental issues, collecting available quantitative and qualitative data
- Acquire a technical glossary to understand environmental issues and policy
- Critically analyse principles and methods to achieve environmental sustainability.

data.name: Storia medievale I - LM
Microbiologia e microbiologia clinica
data.description:
The course will provide students with the basics and essential tools to understand the principles and basic aspects of mycology, with particular reference to the main pathogenic fungi for humans, the means to fight them and the methods to identify them.

At the end of the course the student should be able to:

1. describe the peculiar structure and composition characteristics of the different fungi

2. to know the transmission and pathogenetic mechanisms of fungal diseases

3. know the mechanisms of action of antifungal drugs

4. know the main fungi capable of causing disease in humans and the methods for the diagnosis of the diseases they cause.

data.name: Storia delle istituzioni politiche
data.description:
The course aims to bring the student closer to political-constitutional history in the belief that this contributes to make it more aware of being part not only of a family and of a civil and economic society, but also of a historically determined political-institutional system.
Two historical transitions to the constitutional state, namely that of Great Britain and that coinciding with the founding of the United States of America will be presented in the course. It will be taken care to highlight, through a historical-comparative perspective, the unavoidable interconnections between them.
At the end of the course the student will be able to recognize, in relation to the examined historical-political-constitutional events, what kind of form of government (if absolute, constitutional or parliamentary) was established, and the main distinctive features of  the parliamentary institution and of cabinet, of legislative and executive power, etc..

data.name: Economia e gestione delle imprese turistiche
data.description: The aim of the course is to discuss key issues concerning the management of tourism enterprises. Attention will be given to hotel business and to their strategies and marketing choices.

data.name: Advanced Topics in Motor Cognition
data.description:
This course provides a comprehensive overview of advanced topics in motor neuroscience and of the involvement of the motor system in cognitive functions. We will present recent findings obtained with a variety of advanced methods (fMRI, EEG, MEG, TMS, behavior, neurological patients).

The objective of the course is to provide the students with the following competences:
- Knowledge of the main topics in motor neuroscience
- Knowledge of the advanced experimental techniques and methods
- Ability to define formulate specific experimental design to answer experimental questions
- Ability to critically understand experimental data and results

data.name: Psicologia della percezione e dell'attenzione

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description:
The aim of the course is to provide students with basic theoretical and methodological notions related to the study of attention and perception, as well as their interaction in the formation of a mental representation of the external world.

By the end of the course, students attending (those students who will attend at least 75% of the lectures and will participate in the group work) should:

-Know the main theoretical topics related to attention and perception.

-Show critical and original thinking related to the material learned, with appropriate use of scientific language

-Understand the key aspects of an experimental study in the field of attention and perception

Non-attending students should:

-Know the main theoretical topics related to attention and perception.

-Show critical and original thinking related to the material learned, with appropriate use of scientific language

data.name: Embedded systems
data.description:
Embedded computers are found everywhere, from home appliances to automobiles to medical devices. Designing an embedded computing system is a challenging task because the requirements include manufacturing cost, performance, power consumption, user interface, hard deadlines, and rich functionality. 
The objective is to illustrate the embedded system design process, which includes requirements, specification, architecture, components, and system integration phases. The course will be backed up by real-life design examples to illustrate the design process, and also students will be asked to design embedded systems to gain experience.

data.name: Next generation networks

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: In the past two decades, the Internet has grown from a research tool to a fundamental part of society. This course will explore why the infrastructure was designed this way, and the underlying principles and design decisions. The course will focus on emerging issues and paradigms, including virtualization and softwarization (VLAN, VXLAN, SD-WAN, SDN, NFV), cloud computing (VMs, containers), Internet of Things, vehicular networks, 5G and beyond, and other technologies shaping the Internet of the Future. A specific dedicated set of hands-on sessions will enable students to learn how to manage the above technologies and how to use state-of-the-art network programmable and virtualization platforms (NI USRPs, Docker, etc.).
data.degreeProgram: Ingegneria Informatica, delle Comunicazioni ed Elettronica (L2)

data.name: Chimica e biochimica
data.description:
Biochemistry is the study of the structure, function and interaction of biomolecules in living organisms.  At the end of this course, student will be able to:
a) Explain the basic principles of protein folding, as well as the possible events underlying protein misfolding and related human diseases
b) Describe the main techniques to study protein folding and expression, as well as the approaches to characterize entire proteomes
c) Use the main protein data banks to retrieve basic information of protein sequence, conformation and functional organization 
d) Explain the role of enzymes in catalyzing the wide variety of chemical reactions in living organisms
e) Describe the chemical diversity of biological macromolecules (proteins, carbohydrates, lipids and nucleotides), including their synthesis and catabolism, as well as their main roles in biological processes
f) Understand the key steps of the main metabolic pathways (Glycolysis, Gluconeogenesis, Pentose Phosphate Pathway, Citric Acid Cycle, Oxidative Phosphorylation and photosynthesis, Urea cycle), their interconnection and common mechanisms of regulation.

data.name: Fondamenti logici della matematica
data.description: The course is a revision and a detailed study of various notions that are common to all the areas of mathematics. The aim is to become familiar with their use in the mathematical practice.

data.name: Street Law - Illustrare la Costituzione
data.description:
As the jurist training requires notions and technical skills as well as relational and communicative abilities, the course focuses on the American Street Law approach, which began in the United States in 1972 and is still followed in Law Schools.
Street Law uses interactive teaching methodologies to teach practical law to common people. The course combines legal principles and communication skills to form University students in order to let them teach practical law lessons to high school students. Through peer education, the learning process is thus exalted.
At the end of the course, students will be able to expose constitutional law topics, thus achieving the objective of "illustrating the Constitution".

data.name: Macroeconomia progredito_
data.description:
The purpose of this course is to provide students with the notions and tools needed to understand the functioning of a modern macroeconomic system. Particular attention will be given to the analysis of the business cycle, the role played by financial markets in determining its evolution, and how economic policy can guide its dynamics. The course will be divided into two parts. In the first part, the methodologies of empirical analysis and the analytical aspects underlying modern dynamic macroeconomic theory will be analyzed. The second part will illustrate some of the major theoretical innovations following the outbreak of the global financial crisis of 2007-09.


At the end of the course, students will be able to:

  • know the main empirical and theoretical methods underlying the modern approach to macroeconomic analysis;
  • link the economic theory, financial facts and institutional features of international macroeconomic systems in order to interpret their dynamic features, formulate quantitative forecasts on possible future evolutions, and address the main topics of debate between scholars and policy-makers.

data.name: Information system and knowledge management
data.description:
Data, information, and knowledge are increasingly recognized as a crucial asset in modern organizations. The course intends to bring the students a solid general understanding of data, information and knowledge management focusing on concepts, methods and tools that can be used to enable innovation and change management within the organizations. A particular focus will be proposed on service science, an interdisciplinary approach to the study, design, and implementation of services systems. Organizations are complex systems in which specific interdependencies of people and technologies take actions and provide value. 
The course enable the student to deeply analyse from an organisational and managerial perspective Information and Knowledge management systems, Information system and data management, double side platforms, and some emerging technological phenomena such as crowdsourcing and gamification.

data.name: Economic and labour sociology

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
Course taught in English. Students are expected to give their presentations in English.

The course aims at presenting the institutionalist approach to economic sociology, comparative political economy and labour market economy&sociology. 
The course will be mainly built as a seminar course, with a preliminary part mainly 'front lesson' that will introduce the basis of the discipline (economic sociology and comparative political economy plus some labor sociology).
Basic sociological tool for the course is the "Coleman Boat" macro-micro-macro approach proposed by James Coleman (Foundations of Social Theory, 1990: the introduction). In the second part of the course/seminar, students will have to prepare (and present) their own 'Coleman Boat' applied to their specific topic of interest. Other students will act as discussants of each presentation. 
A great deal of activation is requested to students: readings and public discussion of papers, articles and books indicated by the teacher (for those student who attend the course) at the beginnning of the course or later on according to topics and discussions.
A preliminary, mandatory, list of readings will be distributed at the beginning of the course, but students will be pushed to propose additional/alternative lectures on the basis of their own research interests/thesis etc. Of course, readings etc will have to be - by and large - compatible with Economic Sociology.

At the end of the course, students are expected to have understood the meaning of doing "Sociology as Social Science" and of performing "Theory based empirical research". 

STUDENTS WHO DO NOT ATTEND THE COURSE but nonetheless should be willing to give the exam (f.e. students in double degree or however abroad during the second year of the MA course) are requested to get in touch with the teacher, in order to define an ad hoc paper that they will have to deliver.

It is highly appreciated that students have previously attended the BA course on Economic and Labour Sociology, taught by Prof. Barbieri. Those who did not attend the BA course are requested to prepare the Gosta Esping-Andersen 1990 book "The Three Words of Welfare Capitalism". (This text will have to be prepared also by students who do not attend the MA course).

data.name: Analisi matematica II
Animal Models of Disease

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description:
The main objective of this course is to teach students how different experimental models can contribute to understanding and curing human diseases.
At the end of the course, the student will demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:
- how different experimental systems have been used to model key aspects of specific diseases
- how these disease models help defining the molecular pathways implicated in the pathogenic mechanisms 
- the use of disease models in developing effective therapeutics for human diseases
- the ethical and regulatory aspects of animal research
She/he will also demonstrate an ability in:
- discussing the contribution of animal models to the understanding of the physiopathology of human diseases
- integrating the information gained from different models to identify the pathogenic mechanisms of a particular disease and the existence of commonalities among different diseases 
- critically evaluating the advantages and limitations of different experimental models.

data.name: Advanced remote sensing systems

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
This course provides basic and advanced concepts as well as design capabilities in the framework of systems based on remote sensing (from satellites, airborne and UAV platforms), proximal sensing, in-situ (ground) sensing, and ancillary data for environmental monitoring, climate change analysis, civil protection, infrastructure monitoring, remote surveillance and planetary exploration. It introduces remote sensing methodologies, technologies and techniques that are fundamental for the design of the above-mentioned systems with the last generation of optical and radar sensors. It describes the approach to the design and implementation of systems for several applications and operative scenarios, including the design criteria for the choice of the sensors, the system architecture and data analysis techniques complementary to more general artificial intelligence and machine learning techniques presented in other mandatory courses.
There is a large part of the course that is common to all the students and another part (section 2) for which each attendee can select one between two modules: Module a) basics concepts in remote sensing and technologies for the acquisition of optical and radar images; or Module b) advanced concepts and design criteria for Earth observation and planetary exploration satellite missions. It is suggested that students that have not attended any basic remote sensing course follow Module a) while the others select Module b).
The theoretical lectures are complemented by practical examples on real systems including laboratory activities.

data.name: Storia del cristianesimo e delle chiese II - LM
data.description: The course aims to introduce students to a specific topic about history of the Church in Early Modern and Modern Age, to show them a research method and to provide them with skills to carry out individual research. At the end of the course, the student will be able to: (a) report the main contents of the course, using an appropriate vocabulary; (b) expose methods that have been used in the research path to reach determined conclusions; (c) analyse a historical source about the subjects covered in the teaching describing the features and articulations of its form and content (d) judge the results of the research critically, hypothesising different solutions or proposing further research.

data.name: Storia moderna II
data.description:
The course aims to provide an introduction to the study of modern history (fifteenth to the eighteenth centuries) and to identify the central themes that link that period, in Europe and beyond, to the contemporary world.

General learning outcomes:
a) to identify the major events, persons and ideas of the early modern history.
b) build relationships and ties between them.
c) to grasp the elements of continuity and rupture of early modern history.
d) to recognize, distinguish, differentiate, compare the most important aspects of European and non-European civilizations.
e) to place an historical source in time and space describing its content, origins, and motivations.
f) to use a suitable historiographic lexicon.
g) to organize the knowledges and communicate them clearly and concisely in a written form.

data.name: Advanced Cryptography
data.description: To get at the boundary of research or research/oriented stages of current research. The students will be encouraged to do advanced exercises, seminars or projects.

data.name: Psicologia del consumatore
data.description:
The general purpose of this course is to explore the psychology of judgement and decision-making and how it can help make sense of consumer judgements and choices. In terms of judgement, the course will predominantly focus on the heuristics and biases approach, and in particular its new interpretation within dual process theories. Students will learn that many of our judgements do not involve deliberate thought or reasoning, as standard economic theory assumes, but rather are based on intuition. In terms of decision-making, students will learn about prospect theory that aims to describe how people decide rather than how they ought to decide. For example, you will learn how the framing of a choice (whether the outcomes are described in terms of gains or losses) can have a big impact on decisions. In turn, all these theories and concepts will be related to consumer judgement.
By the end of the course students should have acquired:
-an in-depth understanding of psychological research on judgement and decision making, and its relevance for understanding consumer judgement and choice. This includes the ability to summarise the theories and define their central concepts.
-the ability to critically evaluate the theories in light of empirical evidence.
-the ability to read journal articles, discuss the main theoretical points and findings, and to critically evaluate the theories.

data.name: Product design
data.description:
The purpose of the course is to provide the basic elements of industrial design for the production of a manufactured product. Expressive and communicative aspects of an industrial product will be considered and two design paths (industrial and technical design) will be illustrated to create a successful product.

At the end of course the student could be able to:

1. recognize the importance of product design in the success of a product and a company;

2. Know the aspects of product design that are most important for designing and managing an industrial product;

3. to analyze and recognize features related to product design in a product;

4. Use creativity and lateral thinking techniques to address an industrial problem;

5. Have the basics to collaborate with a design team in the design process;

6. identify and select the most suitable materials and technologies in a design in function of the requirements;

7. propose possible solutions in an industrial design, considering the intangible aspects and customer satisfaction;

8. be critical, curious and be prone to considering both technical and perceptive news.

data.name: Inquinanti emergenti e strategie di risanamento

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
Aim of the course is to discuss how many outputs snd negative impacts the pollution could have on natural and urban environment, and how they could be reduced through research of innovative, sustainable treatments.

The student will be able: to carry out simple Life Cycle assessment of materials; to chose procedures and select analytical devices for treating polluted environments and sites.

data.name: Concurrency

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The focus of the course is on shared-memory concurrency, which is orthogonal to distributed concurrency.

The course covers fundamental algorithms, impossibility results, and classic verification techniques from the literature on concurrency.

At the end of the course, students will have a general knowledge about concurrency and multithreading at work in shared-memory models.

Most importantly, they will develop the ability to reason about what can go wrong under concurrent interference, and about what can be safely made more efficient by concurrent co-operation.

data.name: Computer Architectures

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The goal of this course is to provide the basic notions about the organization and architecture of computing machines, either general-purpose computers, or specialized architectures designed to handle specific tasks. Furthermore, the course provides basic knowledge about the assembly language (in particular using as a reference RISC-V and briefly discussing the Intel and ARM architectures), the HW/SW interface, and the low-level mechanisms of a computer. Finally, the course also provides the fundamental knowledge needed to attend advanced courses focused on the design of computer systems from the hardware perspective.

This course does not require any preliminary knowledge. The structure of the course is especially suited for students with a CV oriented towards software and systems, who during their Bachelor Degree have the chance to learn about computer architectures only through this course. On the other hand, the course will also provide the fundamental knowledge needed to attend advanced courses focused on the design of computer systems from the hardware perspective.

(2) To select a suitable mathematical model in order to solve the assigned problem. (3) To solve the problem by using an appropriate algorithm.

data.name: Big Data Technologies

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
Nowadays we are producing data at rates that we have never seen before, creating datasets characterized by extreme Volume, Variety and Velocity. Unfortunately, traditional data management technologies have been proven limited in managing data with these characteristics. This led to the term Big Data, as a way to refer to this kind of data, and new technologies been developed to cope with it. This course is an introduction to Big Data Technologies. It aims at providing an understanding of the fundamental principles, frameworks and tools upon which Big Data systems are built.
The students will acquire an understanding of what is big data, why it is relevant, knowledge of some of the technologies/frameworks/tools available for building big data systems and how to combine them to analyse data at scale

data.name: Lingua tedesca II
data.description:
Lehr- und Lernziele
Hauptziel des Kurses ist der Erwerb notwendiger Kenntnisse über den Spracherwerbsprozess sowohl der ersten als auch der fremden Sprache mit besonderer Rücksicht auf die deutsche Sprache als Erst - Zweit - und Fremdsprache.
Die Haupthypothesen bezüglich der Erstsprachenaneignung werden illustriert, erklärt und diskutiert; dazu werden die Thesen über das Zweit- bzw. Fremdsprachenlernen, die Lern- und Lehrmethoden und die Geschichte der Sprachdidaktik im XX Jahrhundert erleuchtet. Überlegungen über das Ende der Methoden anhand der neurobiologischen Forschungserkenntnisse werden vorgeschlagen.
Am Ende des Kurses müssen die Studierenden in der Lage sein:
a) Die Spracherwerbshypothesen genau zu definieren (L1, L2, L3)
b) Die Hypothesen mit den jeweiligen Kulturbewegungen verbinden zu können
c) Die im Spracherwerbsprozess involvierten Bestandteile, sowie, z. B. folgende Begriffe: Interlingua, Input, Output, Intake, Latenzphase, die Prinzipien von Krashen und die Hypothese von Pienemann zu beschreiben und argumentieren
d) Die richtige Terminologie zu benutzen 
e) Die jeweiligen Hypothesen miteinander zu vergleichen
f) Sich unter den verschiedenen Lehr - und Lernmethoden des Deutschen innerhalb der Spracherziehung orientieren zu können, die didaktischen Entwürfe und Aktivitäten zu erkennen und die Begründung der jeweiligen Ansätzen erklären zu können
g) Hypothesen, Theorien und Methoden miteinander verbinden zu können.
Label
Das Label der exzellenten Leistung besteht aus:
a) Der persönlich bearbeiteten Bewertung der illustrierten Kenntnisse; 
b) der argumentierten und begründeten Illustrierung der eigenen Bewertung



d)

data.name: Progettazione sociale

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
At the end of the course, the student will be able to develop a social project.
The student will acquire practical and theoretical knowledge to develop solutions to social issues through tools and methodologies typical of the social economy.
In particular, apart from the most modern social design techniques,  tools for enterprise startup of profit organizations as well as social enterprises will be studied. This will allow to identify sustainable solutions to emerging issues.
Below we summarize some of the theories and methodologies of reference:

Design
Theory of Change, (Toronto Center for Social Innovation - Problem theory - change theory - action theory), the project cycle (PESTLE analysis, stakeholder analysis, problem tree, objective analysis, SWOT analysis, Risk Analysis, Strategic Analysis), and elements of social innovation, and social impact assessment and environmental impact (SROI Social Return on Investment, Carbon Footprint and Emission Trading).

Social Startup
The Social Business Model, Social Business Canvas (A. Osterwalder) - Shared Value (M. Porter) - Social Business (M.Yunus) - Social Enterprise in Italy and the World. Strategy and innovation: The Big Bang Disruption (L.Downes, P.Nunes) - The Blue Ocean Strategy (WC Kim and R. Mauborgne) - The Design Driven Innovation (R. Verganti) - La Lean StartUp (E.Ries), Lateral Thinking  (De Bono)

Project Management
Project Management Elements (WBE, Budget, Accountability ... Graham RJ), Organizational Behavior (Individual, Group, Leadership ... D. Marangon)

The point of view is historical, staring from ''ancient'' theorems and proofs, with the pourpose to be complete
(i.e. offer the student all needed details).

data.name: Algorithms and Data Structures

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description:
Algorithmics is the science of algorithms. It includes algorithm design, the art of building a procedure which can solve correctly and efficiently a problem; and algorithm analysis, the science of quantifying the amount of resources needed by an algorithm to solve a problem.


The overall goal of this course is to introduce students to the design and analysis of algorithmic solutions, through the presentation of the most important class of algorithms and the evaluation of their performance. The course is shared between the Quantitative and Computational Biology degree and the Data Science Degree. For this reasons, after a common theoretical part, students will be subdivided in two groups for the lab exercises, one devoted to computational biology and one devoted to data science.


At the end of the course, students are expected to:

A) describe classic algorithms on strings, trees, and graphs and understand their behavior;

B) understand, at the basic level, the most important algorithm design techniques

C) evaluate algorithmic choices and select the ones that best suit their problems

D) analyze the complexity of algorithms

E) design simple algorithmic solutions to basic problems, and to implement them using the Python language

data.name: Fisiologia della cellula e degli organismi

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The course's objective is to provide basic knowledge on living organisms: evolution and diversity, anatomy and physiology. Students will follow a path that will allow them to understand the steps towards multicellularity and the integration of signals of intercellular communication.

They will be able to understand the organization of tissues and organs, their mechanisms and their integration in a system biology approach.

At the end of the course, the students will have learned:


- Basic knowledge on the organization and functioning of the cell

- Basic knowledge on the organization of multicellular organisms

- Intercellular Communication

- Physiology of organs and systems

- Check-points, homeostasis and diseases


The course aims to provide basic elements of cellular and molecular biology possibly to be studied in deeper details in other areas such as the "Molecular biology of the cell" (second semester). The part of physiology of organs and tissues is instead specifically addressed within this course.

data.name: Logica - LM
data.description: The course is an introduction to the logical foundations of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and the connected philosophical issues. The first part will present the emergence of AI in the general framework of cognitive science, with special attention to the logical roots of AI in the work of John McCarthy. The second part will be focused on the main logic-based areas of AI (knowledge representation, formalization of reasoning, non-monotone logics, machine learning), with special attention to the methodological and epistemological aspects.

data.name: Fisica

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The course provides basic knowledge of Newtonian mechanics and classical electromagnetism, their experimental foundations and their operational capabilities in solving physical problems and developing technological applications.
At the end of the course the student will:
- know the physical laws underlying Newtonian mechanics and classical electromagnetism with their experimental foundations and their fields of application;
- be able to solve simple physical problems through proper modeling and proper use of the mathematical tools needed to reach the quantitative solution.
data.degreeProgram: Ingegneria Informatica, delle Comunicazioni ed Elettronica (L2)

data.name: How to be a better speaker: Golden rules for presenting your work with style
data.description:
This course will provide participants with a structured framework and the right set of skills that will enable each to deliver successful presentations that meet the objectives and bring results.
Participants will go from simply being capable and confident enough to speak, to having more impact when speaking - whether in meetings or to large groups, - and keeping the audience engaged with their ability to entertain and inspire.

data.name: Storia della lingua italiana II
data.description:
The course aims to refine the understanding and ability of textual and linguistic analysis of female students / students of the master's degree in a field that can be examined from various points of view and with different methods: the modern Venetian.

At the end of the course students will have to be able to: a) recognize the phonetic, morphological, syntactic and lexical features of the Venetian; b) analyze texts, literary and non-literary, with particular attention to communicative interaction (pragmatic features) and the varieties of the diasystem; c) analyze idiomatic and multilingualism with the use of specific vocabularies.

As part of the innovative teaching initiatives promoted by the CeASUm for the project on spoken Italian (head of Prof.ssa Baggio) and for teaching training, LM students are also offered exercises on the use of our Phonetics Cabinet with Dr. Fabio Ardolino (Experimental Phonetics).

data.name: Principi, deontologia e etica del servizio sociale

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
The teaching of principles, ethics and ethics of social work is an introduction to the study of social work as a discipline and as a profession.
Students will be accompanied to identify the ethical elements of values ​​and ethics, founding professional action, so you can develop reflexivity on and practice and anchor the knowledge that they will gain in the degree course.
Specific objectives are:
- Know and understand the value-ethical foundations of social work;
- Acquire knowledge of the elements that characterize the identity of social work (as a discipline and as a profession)
- Capture and reflect on the social service definitions (international and national)
- Provide in-depth knowledge on the inspiring values, operating principles and professional social worker's professional attitudes
- Develop a thorough understanding of ethics and professional conduct through the analysis and study of the Code of Ethics (approved by the National Council on february 2020)
- Identify issues, problems and ethical dilemmas that arise in everyday operational in three-dimensional work (persons, communities and organization) and acquire a reflexive attitude of coping.

data.name: Cognitive Neuroscience of Multisensory Perception

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description:
The goal of this advanced course is to introduce the students to the current research topics in the field of multisensory perception. The course purports to promote active learning and participation. At the end of the course, the students should be able to:
	analyze critically the scientific literature on multisensory perception.
	present the content of a scientific article together with their personal view on it.

data.name: Politics and global transformations

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
The course addresses the complexities of governing global transformations and looks at how these impact domestic and international politics. We will cast a wide net to give a sense for the scope and reach of the challenges deriving from the international context and we will underscore the difficulties of dealing with them. In the first part of the course, we will take a long-term perspective and see how the transformations that exploded in the 21st century have been in the making already in the second half of the 20th. In the second half, we will examine some of the challenges that derive to current political systems from the choices made then and. in the third, we will discuss the transformations in democratic governance that they necessitate.  
At the end of this course you should have a clear sense for how past choices influenced current developments and how, therefore, the choices that we make now will impact our future. You will also get a sense for how world-wide phenomena have differential local repercussions and what local communities can do to address and manage the particular problems that beset them. The course will further alert you to the interconnectedness that characterizes our economies, societies and polities and expose you to the institutional solutions adopted to deal with this interconnectedness. The emphasis will be on the tensions that our democracies are subjected to and how their apparently disappointing performance is due to the difficulty of conjugating responsiveness to national and local needs and preferences with responsibility towards the citizens of other national communities, in Europe and elsewhere.

data.name: Innovation Management
data.description: The course will supply the students with the tools needed to understand core competencies and learning processes in different organizations. These tools will enable the students to manage product development processes, services development processes and product-service systems. Moreover, the course will propose a critical view of the innovation processes.

data.name: Foundations of Brain Imaging
data.description:
Foundations of Brain Imaging [154102] The main objective of this course (42 hours) is to teach the basic knowledge of brain imaging methods used to investigate the human brain in cognitive neuroscience research. The emphasis of the course will be on brain imaging methodologies that students can access at CIMeC. In particular, but not limited to, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and magnetoencephalography (MEG) (Jovicich ~ 22 hours; Baldauf ~ 20 hours).


Learning outcomes. At the end of the course students should be able to answer, with a level of detail compatible with the class discussions, the following questions about each one of the brain imaging methods discussed:

To define what signal sources are being measured by the different methods

To define what is the main equipment used and why

To explain what are the relative advantages and limitations of the methods

To describe what are the common data analyses steps used and why

To describe and interpret example of applications in neuroscience research


The group work leading to the paper presentation in class should promote the practice and development of soft skills, such as the capacity of group planning, comprehension of the chosen research topic, comprehension of what the other group members understand, making judgments about the various perspectives, use of verbal and written communication skills to prepare and present.

data.name: Introduction to Computer and Network Security

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: This is an introductory course to the increasingly important area of computer and network security. The main goal is to enable students to (i) understand the theoretical and practical problems of information security, (ii) understand and recognize threats to fundamental security properties: confidentiality, integrity, and availability, and (iii) understand how the main security mechanisms - such as cryptography, authentication and authorization protocols, and access control - can be applied to mitigate vulnerabilities.

data.name: Psicologia generale

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description:
The aims of the course are the followings:

a) to provide students the basic principles of Psychology, in order to allow them to follow and understand also more advanced courses. To this aim students will be introduced to Psychology intended as a scientific discipline, and to some basic notions of Neurosciences. The will also be introduced to the study of the basis cognitive functions, such as memory, learning, and their relations with emotions.

b) students will be provided basic intellectual tools to develop their own critical view on the different theories, emphasising both the strengths and weakness of such theories. Students will be introduced to the scientific method, intended as a systematic approach common to all the scientific disciplines
data.degreeProgram: Scienze e Tecniche di Psicologia Cognitiva (L2)

data.name: International Corporate Strategy
Stochastic Processes
data.description: The course provides some basic elements of the theory of stochastic processes: Gaussian processes,  Markov processes and martingales, having in mind the prototypical example of such processes, i.e., the Brownian Motion.

It includes application examples as well as laboratory exercises. At the end of the course, it is expected that the student will acquire the skills useful to design methods and tools for the analysis of signals and data.

data.name: Medical Biophysics
data.description:
Primary goal of the course is to introduce the student to the physical and biological aspects related to exposure to ionising radiation, together with the main applications in the medical field.

At the end of the course, the student:

- will be able to understand, define and summarise the mechanisms that lead to biological damage starting from the physical interaction.

- will be familiar with the main applications in the medical field, with special focus on applications in medical physics for photons and protons radiation therapy, which the students can describe and compare.

- will be able to illustrate the different physical and biological aspects related to the exposure to different types of ionising radiation, which he/she will be able to distinguish and to compare, analysing and to discussing cases of interest (e.g. experimental results taken from literature)

- can use software tools (TOPAS, matRad), which can be used to support the analysis of cases of interest and to develop the final report.

data.name: Mathematical Physics - Quantum Relativistic Theories
data.description:
The course, for Master degree students of Mathematics and Physics, treats some advanced topics of mathematical Physics, and some applications to Special and General Relativity, Quantum and Quantum Relativistic Theories (QFT in curved spacetime in the algebraic formalism).
The specific program depends on the lecturer and may be different from year to year.

data.description: The course aims to extend students’ knowledge of and ability to use grammatical, lexical and textual features of written academic English at B2 level, and to develop students’ skills in giving an academic presentation in English.   An active approach is used, with students producing written texts and then correcting them individually and as a group.  Students will give a presentation during the course.

data.name: Fundamental Interactions
data.description:
Basic knowledge of interactions between fundamental constituents of Nature, quarks and leptons. Knowledge of the most accredited models and theories, as well as of the most common experimental techniques. Knowledge of open questions about the comprehension of fundamental interactions.
At the end of the course the student will be able to read and understand texts taken from the recent scientific literature on the topics addressed.

data.name: Storia della filosofia dall'idealismo all'età contemporanea
data.description:
The aim of the course is to examine – from a strictly historical-philosophical point of view, but also by means of the conceptual analysis and with connections with other philosophical disciplines – relevant authors, texts and questions in nineteenth and significant texts of the philosophy from Idealism to contemporary era.


The course will provide the student with a solid knowledge of the topics dealt with during the lessons.


The student will also acquire the specific skills that will allow him/her to

a) place the questions, authors and texts analysed during the course within their historical and cultural contexts;

b) develop a critical and analytical approach to the philosophical texts, paying special attention to the conceptual structures and lexicon

c) expose and discuss the course topics using appropriate language and suitable logical-argumentative tools.
