data.name: Innovazioni tra stato, mercato e comunità
Lingua spagnola II
data.description:
The course will provide students the  knowledge of specific aspects of Spanish grammar in relation to the construction of the sentence, and the expansion of knowledge related to phraseology (colocaciones, locuciones, enunciados fraseológicos), as well as an in-depth study of some aspects related to pragmatics (marcadores del discurso) and sociolinguistics (contextual use of the lexicon, idiomatic phrases).
It also aims to develop writing skills and to strengthen students' discourse skills. 
In order to encourage metalinguistic awareness on contrastive differences between Italian and spanish, classroom activities based on back translation will be carried out.
By the end of the course students should be able to:
a) produce clear, detailed text on a wide range of subjects;
b) different syntantic construction;
c) use the main Spanish text markers according to the various aspects of lexical, semantic and pragmatic coherence in discourse.

data.name: Economia dei mercati e degli intermediari finanziari
data.description:
The course aims to train students to understand the financial contracts issued by intermediaries and / or traded in financial markets. 
The first part of the program will examine the contracts "to confidential information" (deposits, bank loans, factoring, leasing, etc.), the second part of the course instead of listed financial instruments (money market, bonds, equity, foreign exchange and derivatives), the third part of the course will examine the insurance contracts (life insurance) and the last part of the course the logical construction of the portfolios (portfolios and asset management tools). 
At the end of the course, the student will be able to: 
1. know the characteristics of the main contracts for confidential information; 
2. know the risk and return profile of market instruments (money market, bonds, equity, foreign exchange and derivatives) 
3. understand the purpose of insurance contracts and the underlying logic; 
4. understand how portfolio and asset management products can help to reduce financial risks and their economic space of utilization.

data.name: Embedded Software for the Internet of Things

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
Contemporary Internet of Things (IoT) systems comprise embedded computing devices that enable perceiving information about anything, at any time and from anywhere. These devices are interconnected, often embedded in the environment, small in size, battery-powered, and constrained in terms of computation and communication resources. These properties pose peculiar system-level challenges to develop IoT applications. 

The objective of this course is to expose students to programming languages, hardware platforms, operating systems, and, in general, the necessary software tools and techniques geared towards the development of IoT applications. By the end of this course, the students are expected to acquire the theoretical and practical skills to interface with state-of-the-art embedded computing platforms. They will be equipped with the fundamentals to design and develop IoT applications, including, but not limited to, electrocardiogram sensing and interpretation, image processing with low-resolution cameras, machine learning on the edge, wireless localization, and many more. 

Upon successful completion of this module, students should be able to:
- Characterize the main architectural components of microcontroller-based IoT platforms
- Use the development environments and toolchains to program and debug microcontrollers
- Design, implement and test embedded software by following the fundamental methodologies for IoT systems
- Assess IoT application performance and understand the techniques used for optimizing systems execution
- Characterize the basics of real-time scheduling and the main components of embedded real-time operating systems
data.degreeProgram: Ingegneria Informatica, delle Comunicazioni ed Elettronica (L2)

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.name: Robotic Perception and Action
data.description:
The course provides the basic elements of two of the pillars of Industry 4.0: Mobile Robotics and Mixed Reality using concepts of both measurement (Perception) and planning/control (Action).

As far as mobile robotics are concerned, the theoretical bases of localization methods, kinematics, planning and route control by robotic vehicles are illustrated.

As regards Mixed Reality, the technological and cognitive bases are illustrated together with the main software tools (Unity) and hardware (different sensors such as time-flight cameras, electromyographic, physiological, eye trackers, etc.).

data.name: Machine learning

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description: The course aims at studying the fundamentals of machine learning, covering supervised and unsupervised learning methods and deep learning approaches. It includes application examples as well as laboratory exercises. At the end of the course, it is expected that the student will acquire the skills useful to design methods and tools for the analysis of signals and data.

data.name: Molecular and Cellular Biophysics
data.description:
The objective of the course is the comprehension of the biological integrated processes in terms of molecular and cellular biophysical mechanisms. Basic knowledge of molecular and membrane biophysics is required. Starting from this knowledge, the biomolecules and the mechanisms of regulation and integration of cell activity will be studied. The final goal is to approach some current issues of biophysics and acquire a methodology to investigate advanced biophysical problems. For this reason, the lessons are focussed on specific biomolecules and mechanisms and the topics at the frontiers of the research in biophysics will be privileged.
According to their interests and specific individual curriculum, students are allowed to emphasize different aspects and methodological approaches of the research in biophysics and the presentation of a thematic seminar will contribute substantially to the final evaluation. In particular, :
a) students attending the Master's degree in Physics are invited to emphasize the physical methods of investigation (physical technologies to study cell function and man) and the involvement of the mechanisms of regulation and integration of cell activity in human pathologies.
b) students attending the Master Degree in Mathematics are required to emphasize the relationship between mechanism of regulation of biological processes and physiology and their modelling.
At the end of the course, students should be able to:
acquire and analyze critically scientific information from the current literature, utilize the skills and the knowledge that is proper of a physicist or of a mathematician to propose innovative solutions to biophysical research, demonstrate written and/or oral presentation skills to communicate scientific knowledge.

data.name: Lingua inglese II
data.description:
The course will focus on two main aspects: pragmatics and the analysis of English texts and discourses. Classes will focus on the analysis of specialized text genre, with special attention to journalistic discourse and its cultural variables.

Students are expected to improve their ability to both understand and produce oral and written texts; they will also acquire specific notions of linguistics and analysis of specialized and non-specialized texts.

data.name: Robot Planning and its application

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: In this course the student will be introduced to a complete methodology for designing production-ready robot applications. The considered applications will be those for which motion planning plays a major role. The student activities will revolve around a motivational application proposed in the form of a simple robotic competition, in which the robot has to complete a number of tasks in minimum time avoiding obstacles and dangerous spots. Contrary to a standard robotic competition, the student will have to discuss the theoretical underpinning of the method she/he chose to adopt for the competition.

data.name: Plant physiology applied to agricultural production
data.description:
The aim of the course is to provide advanced knowledge on the physiological processes of plan growth and plant nutrition and on the mechanisms of response and adaptation to abiotic stresses of the main fruit and vegetable crops of the alpine environment. Students will be guided to know and develop innovative strategies for the sustainable use of natural resources and for the optimization of plant physiological processes using new approaches for crop irrigation, fertilization and protection against abiotic stresses derived from climate changes (e.g. water stress, low and high temperature stress, nutritional excess and deficiency and multiple stresses). The course will provide expertise on the role of microorganisms in the soil fertility and in the plant adaptation to stresses, as well as on the application of innovative soil management strategies aimed at maximizing the quality of agrifood production with a sustainable use of resources.
At the end of the course, the student should be able: to describe the defence mechanisms of plants against abiotic stresses and the physiological processes of plant growth and nutrition, to apply innovative methods for the management of agrifood production with a sustainable use of natural resources, to use microbial strains and communities to increase the plant tolerance to stresses, to exploit and improve the soil microbiological quality with optimised fertilization and irrigation strategies.

data.name: Ambiti di intervento nella psicologia

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description: The course aims to provide students enrolled in the "Neuroscience" and "Clinical Psychology" curriculum with an overview of the potential areas of intervention of the psychologist. The aim of the course is to enrich students' knowledge with respect to the profession of psychologists, the concrete activities that the psychologist carries out in different contexts, the tools he/she uses and the critical aspects that can be encountered in the performance of the profession.

data.name: Teorie e approcci al servizio sociale

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
This course is designed to provide students with an overview of the social work theories. Social work is a complex acticity underpinned by a wide and diverse theorietical basis. Social workers drawn on understandings of people and their needs fron a range of theories and theoretical perspectives. Be able to operating within a framework that grounds pratice in a theoretical context is a central feature of effective social work. The course provide an introduction to the main theoretical tradition informing the practice of social work and the keys to supporte a critical application of theoretical knowledge on the practice.  

Upon completion of this course, students will be able to: 

1. Recognize the relationship between theory and practice of social work 
2. Know the key theories, models and approaches that inform social work practice and their strengths and limitations; 
3. Understand the influence of the social and political context on social work theories and practice; 
4. Demonstrate competence in applying the explanatory concepts of theories to the assessment of adults and children of varied populations, especially those at risk. 
5. demonstrate competence in applying explanatory concepts of the theories to the formulation of a plan in the treatment of adults and children of varied populations, especially those at risk.

data.name: Mountain Meteorology

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description: Students are familiar with the basic principles of mountain meteorology, specifically the influence of topography on atmospheric processes and the associated weather.

data.name: Storia contemporanea II
Natural Language Understanding

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: Natural Language Understanding is the fundamental component of artificial intelligence systems ( AIS ) that communicate with humans. AIS communicate directly with humans via the conversational interfaces of social robots. AIS may be able to read and comprehend vast amounts of human language data ( speech, text or multimedia ) and makes sense. In the first part of the course we will provide the students the basic knowledge about the natural language structure from the lexicon to the document level, formal models for representing the lexicon, the sentence and the discourse. We will present and provide the machine learning models to learn language structures from language corpora. In the last part of the course we will describe use cases of Natural Language Understanding in AIS. Students will be trained to train  natural language understanding models for different use cases and tasks.

data.name: Calcolo stocastico e mercati finanziari
data.description:
The aim of the course is to introduce  the basic concepts of Option Pricing Theory.
First the option evaluation problem will be illustrated using the simplified approach of Cox, Ross and Rubinstein . Then  the essential tools of stochastic calculus will be provided and investigation of the Black, Scholes and Merton stochastic model (martingale approach) will follow. Finally non standard options evaluation will be introduced.
At the end of the course the student will have full mastery of the essential tools for stochastic models of financial assets (Ito calculus, martingales representation theorem, Girsanov theorem, Feymann-Kac stochaStic representation theorem) and mastered topics such as replication  replicating portfolios of uncertain payoffs, Black-Scholes formulas and fair prices of standard and exotic options, and  two fundamental theorems of mathematical finance.

data.name: Storia della filosofia dal rinascimento all'illuminismo - LT
data.description:
The course aims to analyze – from a strictly historical-philosophical point of view, while identifying possible links with more current issues – important points, authors and significant texts in thought from the fifteenth to the eighteenth century.
By the end of the course the student will have acquired a solid knowledge of the topics addressed and the specific skills that will allow him/her  to 1) place these topics and authors within their historical and cultural contexts, and understand their meaning and value in the overall picture of the history of Western thought; 2) critically analyze and interpret the required texts; 3) discuss the course content and one’s own reasoning using appropriate language and suitable logical-argumentative tools.

data.name: Filosofia teoretica
Metodologia della giurisprudenza romana
data.description:
The Roman jurists were the most important element in the development of Roman private law. The course aim to offer students a specific understanding of method and of forms of legal reasoning of Roman jurists.
At the end of course the student will be able to:
- make use of the main tools for a direct access to reading and interpretation of Roman legal sources
- increase the critical capacity and the skills of legal reasoning of students by means of methodological knowledge of Roman jurists

data.name: Filosofia morale
data.description: The aim of course FILOSOFIA MORALE, part of first year of the three-year degree in Philosophy, is - first of all - to make students capable of understanding  the specific issues of moral questions  through an analysis of its historical genesis and historical evolution. Secondly, to provide tools to interpret the intrinsic ethical content of every philosophy.

data.name: Letteratura italiana II - LM
data.degreeProgram: Letterature euroamericane, traduzione e critica letteraria (LM)

data.name: Quantum Mechanics, Fields and Symmetries
data.description:
The course introduces the student to an advanced level of quantum mechanics. Some of the taught subjects that the student should already know on a more introductory level are treated in greater depth like the theory of angular momenta in quantum mechanics, the role of symmetries in physics and the theory of scattering processes. On the other hand the student will also become acquainted with new subjects like for example with second quantization and relativistic wave equations.

At the end of the course the student
a) will have a solid basis to understand the various facets of the microscopic world visible in physics of matter, atomic and molecular physics, nuclear and subnuclear physics,
b) will be able to calculate reaction cross sections due to his/her advanced knowledge in scattering theory, angular momentum techniques and density matrix formalism,
c) will be able to treat also processes with relativistic particles, which, for example, will enable the student to understand phenomenological theories of relativistic nature.

data.name: GPU computing

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
General Aspects

Regarding the aspect of "Knowledge and understanding", the student will be able to:




  • analyze and solve even complex problems in the area of Software Engineering for Information Systems with particular emphasis on the use of studies, methods, techniques, and technologies of empirical evaluation;
  • know in depth the scientific method of investigation applied to complex systems and innovative technologies that support information technology and its applications;
  • read and understand specialist scientific documentation, such as conference proceedings, articles in scientific journals, and technical manuals.


Regarding the aspect of "Applying knowledge and understanding", the student will be able to:


  • design and perform experimental analyses of information systems in order to acquire measures related to their behaviour and to evaluate experimental hypotheses in different fields of application, such as business, industrial or research;
  • extend and modify in an original way an existing technical solution or a formal model taking into account changed conditions, requirements and evolution of the technology.


Regarding the aspect of "Making judgments", the student will be able to:




  • select documentation from a variety of sources, including technical books, digital libraries, technical scientific journals, web portals, or open source software and hardware tools;
  • reconcile the objectives of the project that are in conflict, to trade-off cost, resources, time, knowledge or risk;
  • work with large autonomy, also assuming responsibility for projects and structures.


Regarding the aspect of "Communication skills", the student will be able to:




  • present the contents of a scientific/technical report to an audience, including non-specialists, at a fixed time;
  • structure and draft scientific and technical documentation describing project activities;
  • coordinate project teams and identify activities to achieve project objectives;
  • prepare and conduct technical presentations in English;
  • carry out research and projects in a collaborative manner;
  • synthesise knowledge gained from reading and studying scientific documentation.


Regarding the aspect of "Learning skills", the student will be able to:




  • extend the knowledge acquired during the course of study by reading and understanding scientific and technical documentation in English;
  • extend knowledge, even if incomplete, taking into account the final objective of the project (problem solving skills);
  • to formulate and validate theories and define new methods through empirical induction and new generation scientific investigation tools.


Specific objectives:

Regarding the technical aspects, the student will be able to :




  • analyze sequential algorithms by identifying performance bottlenecks;
  • design parallel algorithms and implement them on GPUs by considering their architectural aspects;
  • adapt existing parallel and optimization techniques in a contest of different problems;
  • manage and use tools and technologies to design efficient and scalable GPU code.
  • design experimental setup and reporting results.

data.name: Protection of materials and structures
data.description:
The aim of the course is to provide the basics for knowledge of corrosion protection methods for industrial products and structures.

At the end of the course, the student should:

1. recognize the different possibilities to protect a product against corrosion.

2. be able to analyze and evaluate the possible solutions;

3.propose the best protection system(s) for a particular product, depending on the working environment and expected life time.

data.name: Knowledge and Data Integration

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
This course is concerned with one of the five issues (the % V's) which are core to big data, namely "variety". It creates skills which are core to the role of Data Scientist


The goal of the course is to provide students with tools, methodologies, technologies needed in order to build a KG successfully and with minimal effort

data.name: Sviluppo psicologico tipico e atipico

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description:
The course aims to analyze typical and atypical psychological development from a multidisciplinary perspective. The course presents the concepts, theories and methods of Developmental Clinical Psychology. The topics include the study of typical and atypical psychological development during the first years of life, individual differences, cultural and biological influences, and the impact of developmental delay and related disabilities on the daily life.
At the end of their educational path, students will be able to:
A.	understand the basic principles of growth and the basics of development from conception to adolescence, including genetic and environmental influences
B.	identify, compare, contrast and evaluate research methodologies of developmental psychology and experimental paradigms of clinical neuroscience
C.	think critically, scientifically and apply understanding about theoretical constructs and frameworks, research practices and scientific findings on child development
D.	describe the characteristics in the domains of motor and perceptual, cognitive and communicative, social and emotional development for each stage of development
E.	recognize individual and cultural differences in children's development and socialization
F.	formulate diagnostic hypotheses of neurodevelopmental disorders on patients experiencing a condition of atypical development
G.	discriminate how to create environments, educational programs and interactions that support the development of young children, including those with special needs, individually and in groups

data.name: Computational Social Science
data.description:
The module aims at providing an understanding of the main computational research methods that are specific to online media data and to analyse social processes.  This module offers a unique overview of research methods developed to analyse media and online data with an emphasis to 'big data' sources. The module presents an overview of current cutting-edge methodology in quantitative methods related to online social research. Web surveys, online experiments, opinion mining techniques, social network analysis, computational statistical models will be discussed as means to use of the web to analyse cultural, social and political phenomena. Such techniques have a wide range of applications in social scientific research as well as marketing and consumer research.
At the end of the module, students will be able to:
•	Understanding the main principles at the core of the different computational methods that are applied to social science datasets. 
•	A firm grasp of the coding process using software for automatic text analysis
•	Apply social network analysis to the context of combining network information with other type of data
•	Assess the use of online media data as social and cultural indicators using quantitative data
•	Understanding what is opinion mining and what are its core principles and techniques
•	Use computational models to analyse large survey data through techniques such as model based recursive partitioning, latent class analysis, relational class analysis.
•	Grasp the importance of Data visualization and presentation to relevant stakeholders

data.name: Relazioni e organizzazioni internazionali

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
Within Jean Monnet Chair EUWeBER - The European Union and the Western Balkans: Enlargement and Resilience

This class introduces students to the main international relations theories (liberalism, realism, critical theory, constructivism) and to the study of international organizations. It aims at providing students with the knowledge and competences necessary to acquire a thorough understanding of international organizations, with particular reference to the European Union. The class is organized with the Jean Monnet Chair "The Western Balkans: Enlargement and Resilience," (EUWeBER) which is managed by the instructor (prof. Roberto Belloni) together with the Osservatorio Balcani and Caucaso (a think-tank based in Trento). Thus, while while being coherently structured as a free-standing class, this course is also conceived as preparatory to "The European Union and its Neighbors," which is offered by the Department at the third years. 
During the semester, the class will introduce the main international relations theories and apply them to three main groups of organizations: those dealing with peace and security (ONU, NATO, EU), economics and finance (World Bank, IMF, WTO) and humanitarian and social issues (UNHCR, International Criminal Tribunal, UN Environmental Programme). Particular attention will be given to the foreign policy of the European Union. 
At the end of the class, the students will be able to define and understand the main international relations theories and to apply them to different international organizations, evalutating their functions and impact.

The course is focused on conventional and advanced technologies for the treatment of civil and industrial wastewater, providing the skills for identifying the optimal treatment chain and for its design.

The exercises focus on the numerical application of the methods for the design of treatment plants for municipal and industrial wastewaters, applying both conventional and advanced processes. The exercises give the skills to: (1) analyze qualitative and quantitative data for wastewater characterization; (ii) perform the design of municipal wastewater treatment plants applying specific algorithms; (iii) apply simulation models for the dynamic simulation of the plant; (iv) combine a wastewater treatment plant with circular economy.

data.name: Electromagnetic safety and security

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: The course, after reviewing fundamentals and main issues of electromagnetic propagation in wired and wireless systems, will focus on the classical and mostly recently design methodologies aimed at avoid electromagnetic interfering phenomenas, discussing capabilities, and limits of applications. Moreover a part of the course is devoted to prevent the so called Electromagnetic terrorism, and how to remove threads due to dangerous remote controlled devices, such as improved explosive devices (IED), drones and unwanted communication (for police and security operations). Practical examples concerning real device commonly used for protect telecommunication systems will corroborate the theoretical concepts. In particular, the course provides the students with the methodologies necessary for the analysis, the design and the protection of complex telecommunication systems. This kind of knowledge is of great importance for telecommunication engineers involved in the development of telecommunication systems. All telecommunication products or systems must be protected from electromagnetic interferences  in order to work properly in proximity of other devices. In the course the basics concepts of the electromagnetic compatibility and a working knowledge of how to detect and protect electric and electronic devices, will be given. At the end of the course the student will be able to design and fabricate complex telecommunication system avoiding any kind of electromagnetic interfering problems. The didactic content of the course will be integrated with some software and experimental activities related to the study and the protection from electromagnetic interfering signals. Moreover, the standard electromagnetic compatibility measurements methodologies will be explained.

data.name: Fog and Cloud Computing

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
In the last few years, the cloud computing revolution heavily impacted the ICT world: cloud infrastructure, both public and private, hosts a significant portion of modern digital services and data. Cloud technologies and methodologies, such as virtualisation, containerisation, micro-service based architectures and service-meshes, are becoming prevalent among large technology providers, cloud operators and software developers. New software applications are, in turn, being developed following the so called cloud-native paradigm in order to exploit the benefits, such as scalability and reliability, offered by the cloud infrastructure and services.

Within this technological revolution, topics such as data locality and management are also attracting increasing interest. For this reason, one area of significant development in this space is that of edge computing resources, leading to the emergence of the fog computing paradigm. Indeed, more and more services are beginning to exploit, or even require, its benefits in terms of reduced latency, lower bandwidth consumption through near data source pre-processing, or simply guarantees around the geo-location of data.

This course provides an introduction to Cloud and Fog computing principles and technologies, following a practical, hands-on approach. More specifically, at the end of the course the student will: (1) learn about cloud and fog computing models, technologies and existing solutions; (2) acquire relevant knowledge on advanced topics related to networking, orchestration and security; (3) use and configure advanced open-source platforms to create and manage cloud computing infrastructures and to effectively and dynamically orchestrate workloads.

data.name: Metodi di indagine in neuroscienze cognitive e cliniche

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description:
Metodi di indagine in neuroscienze cognitive e cliniche [152050, 6 units of formative creditsi]

The main objective of this FIRST SEMESTER course is to teach the basic knowledge of brain imaging methods used to investigate the human brain in cognitive neuroscience research. The emphasis of the course will be on brain imaging methodologies that students can access at the Center for Main/Brain Sciences - CIMeC. In particular, but not limited to, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) functional and structural, electroencephalography (EEG), transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) transcranical electrical stimulation (TES), and other electrophysiological markers.

Learning outcomes. At the end of the course students should be able to answer, with a level of detail compatible with the class discussions, the following questions about each one of the brain imaging methods discussed:
 - Describe the signal sources measured by the different methods
 - Describe the main components of the equipment used in each methodology, with the main motivation for each component. 
 - Describe eventual safety issues.
 - Differentiate and explain what are the relative advantages and limitations of the methods
 - Describe and motivate the typical data analyses steps with the various methodologies when used in cognitive neuroimaging studies.  
 - Describe and motivate sample applications of the various methodologies in basic neuroscience and clinical research.

data.name: Digital signal processing

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description:
This course provides an introduction to fundamental concepts and techniques in digital signal processing. The course starts with a detailed explanation of discrete-time signals/systems and with the analysis of discrete time linear time invariant systems. Subsequently, the discrete-time Fourier transform and the discrete Fourier transform are introduced, followed by an overview of fast algorithms for the computation of the discrete Fourier transform. Afterwards, the z-transform and its properties are introduced. Finally, the design of FIR and IIR filters is introduced. 
The Lab lectures by using MATLAB are given to provide practical knowledge in processing real signals with examples from speech and audio.

data.description:
The course provides the basic tools and techniques to understand and design graphical user interfaces for web and mobile starting from users’ needs and complaining with the rules of specific frameworks and by using a rapid prototyping tool. At the end of the course, the students will be able to: - Identify the main phases of a process of design for a graphical user interface - define, discuss and apply some specific techniques to move from users’ needs and technical requirements to design concepts - recognize the importance of the frameworks of design as well as identify and properly use one of them - proficiently use a tool for rapid prototyping - pitch a design idea and defending the design choices.


Furthermore, the course aims at fostering soft skills regarding (i) active collaboration in a working team to pursue common objectives and (ii) effective communication of results by clear and adequate oral presentation.

data.name: Softwarized and Virtualized Mobile Networks

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The main objective of the course is to describe how softwarization will transform the mobile networks of the future. In the course, the major families of wireless networks in use (WLANs, Cellular Networks and Satellite Networks) will be described and the virtualization and softwarization techniques on such infrastructures will be then introduced. The architectural description of such systems will be aligned with the description of the major communication protocols in all the above architectures. By the end of the course, the student should be able to: 
1) know and design the main architectural components of WLANs, cellular networks and other wireless networks;
2) define new protocols and network paradigms to advance the state-of-the-art
3) understand the network virtualization techniques and be able to effectively use such concepts

data.name: Chimica

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
The course provides the basics of general and inorganic chemistry and organic chemistry. The aim of the course is to provide students with the basic knowledge of chemistry for the environmental engineer, i.e. the ability to describe matter in its various states, to predict reactivity from chemical and structural properties and to apply such concepts to the understanding of the environmental phenomena.
At the end of the course the student should be familiar with the electronic structure of the atom, the chemical bond, state of matter and state passages, the properties of the solutions, the chemical thermodynamics and kinetics, and the chemical equilibrium. 
The student should be able to describe inorganic and organic molecules using appropriate structural formulas and nomenclature, solve problems of stoichiometric calculation and chemical equilibria, assess both spontaneity and dynamics of chemical transformations.

data.name: Physics of disordered systems
data.description:
These lessons are meant to provide the student with an introduction to the physics of disordered systems: liquids, glasses, colloids and soft matter in general. These materials are difficult to describe since they present no spatial periodicity. The use of special experimental, theoretical and computational techniques is then necessary to study these materials.

At the end of the course, the student will be able to describe the structure and the dynamics of a disordered system and will have an overall picture of the state-of-the-art concerning the study of these materials. Consequently, the student will be able to read and understand scientific papers on this topic.

data.name: Fisica 1
Quantum mechanics

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description:
This module course aims to provide students with the basic competencies in quantum mechanics physics. 

At the end of the first module, students are expected to:

1) understand the main difference between the physical phenomenology at the macroscopic level ( governed by the laws of classical physics) and the phenomenology at the microscopic level, where quantum mechanical behavior takes place

2) understand the concept of particle-wave duality, and describe and critically analyze the main experiments which provide evidence of quantum uncertainty, wave-like properties of matter, and energy or magnetic moment quantization. 

3) understand the mathematical and physical significance of the wave-function and the related time-dependent and stationary Schrodinger equation.

4) Solve elementary problems in quantum mechanics (particle in an infinite square well, particle in a finite square potential, ground state of the harmonic oscillator)

5) understand and use the basic mathematical tools involved in physical modeling, including:

- Multi-dimensional calculus: partial derivatives, multi-dimensional integral, differential operators, partial differential equations. 

- Basic linear algebra, including matrix diagonalization, eigenvalues, and eigenvectors, commutation relationships. 

- Notion of Hilbert space and its representation theory

- Notion of Dirac-delta function

data.name: Automated Planning: Theory and Practice

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: Planning and Scheduling is the task of thinking before you act: use knowledge about the world to determine what and when to do an action to achieve a given goal. Automated planning and scheduling is a central topic in Artificial Intelligence (AI), and task and motion planning capabilities are essential to the construction of many robust autonomous systems. Research in planning and scheduling is active and exciting. Planning and scheduling problems have been tackled with a variety of new approaches to address efficiency, expressivity, and practical applicability. Planning and scheduling technologies are currently used with great success in several real applications ranging from production lines and elevators to unmanned aerial and sub-sea vehicles (UAVs) and space applications. The aim of this course is to provide a comprehensive theoretical view of a wide range of planning and scheduling techniques, as well as hands-on experience in constructing and modeling planning domains to solve specific planning problems, and if time allows to experiment the control of robotic agents. After the course, the student will be able to: • Evaluate and apply a variety of planning techniques and tools for classical planning and scheduling as well as planning and scheduling under different kind uncertainty (temporal and discrete). • Explain the practical advantages and disadvantages of different levels of expressivity in planning and scheduling models. • Model classical planning and scheduling problems in commonly used domain definition languages (e.g. PDDL), and if time allows, we will consider probabilistic planning problems as well. • Evaluate and apply common techniques for goal-directed planning, such as various forms of heuristics and control rules. • Experiment with realistic robotic agents (depending on time and availability of the robotic agents in the Robotic Lab or through simulations within ROS infrastructure).

data.name: Machine learning

After completing the course, the student will be able to:

data.name: Diritto romano e fondamenti del diritto europeo
data.description:
"Comparison involves history": this sentence of an oustanding scholar of Comparative law tellingly summarizes the method of this course, named “historical-comparative” method, which combines the history with tha comparative method in order to find out the common foundations of current European private laws. Following this perspective the historical knowledge could be a critical tool to verify the current conceptual frame of private law in Europe. Also, it constitutes  an important and useful key to understand identities and differences whether amid civil law systems or regarding common law system. Upon completion of the course, students will be able to:
-Understand the significant role that Roman law have had in the civilian tradition
-Be aware of “historicity” of the common foundations of European laws
-Understand the differences and the identities of legal rules amid different European legal systems in the light of the historical perspective.

data.name: Foundations of Analysis
data.description: The goal of the course is the deep study of the field of real numbers with notions to the historical path leading to the modern axiomatization. All important notions and structures of analysis will be (re-)treated, such as: supremum of a set, monotonicity, continuity, differentiation, ordered fields, archimedean fields, complete fields, metric spaces, topological spaces, completeness, compactness, metrizability, cardinality.

data.name: Deep Learning
data.description: The course aims at studying the fundamentals of machine learning, covering supervised and unsupervised learning methods and deep learning approaches. It includes application examples as well as laboratory exercises. At the end of the course, it is expected that the student will acquire the skills useful to design methods and tools for the analysis of signals and data.

data.name: Global cultures and societies

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
The main goal of the course is to make the student able to navigate competently the long-standing debates on globalization in the social sciences.


A related goal is to make the student able to choose for himself/herself the theoretical stances on these key debates. To 'choose' in this context implies having a sufficient understanding of the stakes involved, sufficient knowledge of the main position in the debate, and the ability to justify one's theoretical preferences in the light of alternatives.


The course will also provide the student with an occasion to exercise a set of skills that are crucial for any graduate student: reading closely and carefully a variety of different (sometimes difficult) texts, analyzing a variety of theoretical standpoints, and debating honestly and cunningly in class.


Here follows a brief list of the topics that the student will deal with:

1. How can Globalization be defined?

2. How can Globalization be defined? (II)

3. The Historical Development of Globalization Processes I

4. The Historical Development of Globalization Processes II

5. The Historical Development of Globalization Processes III

6. Thinking Global Connections before Globalization: Marxism

7. Thinking Global Connections before Globalization: World-System Theory

8. Thinking Global Connection before Globalization: Modernization Theory

9. Cultural Globalization I: Cultural Diffusion

10. Cultural Globalization II: Global Mélange

11. World Population and Mobility I

12. World Population and Mobility II

13.The political trilemma of globalization

14.Globalization and sovereignty

15.Globalization and democracy

16.Globalization and the liberal international order

17.International institutions and global governance

18.Globalization versus geopolitics

19.Regional dimensions of globalization

20.The political backlash to globalization

data.name: Storia della banca e della finanza
data.description: The course in History of Banking and Finance aims at providing students with an interpretative framework of the patterns of growth and transformation of financial and credit businesses. Objective of the course is to let students develop knowledge on how banking structures have changed across time, in response to the needs emerging in the different phases of social and economic transformation. The students must therefore be able to grasp, through historical-cultural reasoning, how the current dynamics of the banking firm have emerged. A broad view combining the investigation on the role of credit intermediaries with analysis of the economic transformations in the early modern and contemporary periods, will enable students to understand the role of banks and bankers in all their complexity, in order to evaluate their operating effectiveness. Special attention will be devoted to the origins and subsequent development of cooperative credit, which will be examined both in its strengths and critical aspects, against the backdrop of the different phases of economic transformations in which it operated.

data.name: Bioinformatics Resources

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description:
This module will provide an overview of the most common databases and computational resources available to implement standard bioinformatics analyses. For all arguments introduced in the course, R will be used as common programming environment to perform data analysis examples and exercises. At the end of the course, students will be able:

a) Interrogate and use the main databases and online tools storing publicly available biological data.

b) Use the R programming environment to search, install and use computational resources related to the bioinformatics analyses object of the course.

c) Build a computational pipeline to analyze and characterize biological data.

data.name: Biopesticides and innovative techniques for plant protection
Materials for energy
data.description:
At the end of the course students will know:

(i) the principles of combustion science and will be able to make mass and energy balances;

(ii) they will know the main types of pollutants and how these depend on the type of flame.

They will also be familiar with the main types of materials (and their developmental issues) used for electricity storage (batteries and supercapacitors), energy transformation (fuel cell), hydrogen storage and CO2 capture, and for the removal of pollutants in combustion processes. Finally they will have the knowledge and skills to design innovative ceramic materials obtained from preceramic polymers and to use them in the field of energy materials.

data.name: Diritto della regolazione
Network Modeling and Simulation

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description:
Objectives

The student will learn about systems view of biological networks, where quantitative and dynamic considerations of biological properties are in the foreground. The biological entities will be studied with an emphasis on the emergent behavior resulting from the interactions of the network components. The student will thus be equipped with an interdisciplinary skill-set for studying such systems in a way that brings together notions from biology, applied mathematics and computer science.


Learning outcomes

At the end of the course the students will be able to:

a) Work on biological questions using analytical methods with the aim of providing systems level "holistic" answers.

b) Develop the critical thinking skills required to understand and evaluate the results introduced in a scientific paper in the area of modelling and simulation of biological dynamics.

c) Become familiar with a spectrum of techniques from applied mathematics and computer science with respect to their strengths and their limitations in various biological settings.

d) Use programming technologies to formalize various biological problems for simulation, sensitivity analysis and model calibration and choose the most appropriate computational strategy depending on the considered biological problem.

• … have the ability to produce a professional writing on a business analysis topic.
• … have the ability to apply concepts, methods and tools pertaining to identifying and assessing the impact/value of a technology in an industry, market and/or organization and the innovation / business opportunities it creates.
• … have the ability to reflect critically on issues related to the development of ICT solutions, and their potential pitfalls due to market and/or social reasons.
• … have developed a sense of "out of the box thinking" and creative approaches to problem solving, even in contexts that would otherwise suggest a technical solution.
• … have the ability to make value and ethical judgements about the development of technological and business solutions.
• … have the ability to work as a team with other students to complement each other's competences and perspectives.

data.description: In its first part, the course aims to present the constitutive elements of the birth and development of religious action during the civilization process and, in particular, in the formation of the spirit of the modern world. In the second part, the specific case of interaction between the religious dimension and contemporary modernity will be examined through the study of the French and Italian cases. data.description:
The course provides an overview of the main platforms and technologies for the development of Internet of Things (IoT) products and services including devices for sensing, actuation, processing, and communication. The course will improve the design skills and experiences to employ in developing novel systems. The course has theory and lab sections and the lab sections consist of hands-on and practical IoT exercises of fast prototyping sensing, actuation and communication for IoT devices with WiFi-microcontrollers and multi-core programmable platforms (e.g. the Raspberry Pi Platform).


After completing the course, the students should be able to lead and conduct the

development process of data-driven IoT-enabled services or products, more specifically:

a. Acquire the necessary knowledge and thinking of collaborating with developers and engineers throughout the design process.

b. Integrate data science and software engineering methods in the design process to develop innovative IoT products and services.

c. Identify and select appropriate development tools and use them effectively throughout the development process.

d. Use statistical data methods to generate insights and knowledge from IoT data and make it intelligible for stakeholders.

e. Balance the interests of users, business and societal challenges regarding to ethical data issues such as data privacy, data confidentiality, data quality, data ownership, etc.

The course will provide an overview of the interactions between climate and plants in different terrestrial biomes, for both forest and agricultural systems. 
The course will also examine how plants and atmosphere interact in terms of water, energy and gases exchanges. 
The course will show how knowledge of climatic and local weather factors can be of use to agricultural practices to optimize crop production in a climate change perspective. 

At the end of the course the student will be able to: 

	understand the distribution and characteristics of vegetation in the main terrestrial biomes 
	understand and interpret the chemical and physical interactions between vegetation and climate
	predict how climate can affect vegetation growth and distribution in a changing perspective
	hypothesize how vegetation can affect local weather and/or climate 
	plan the necessary agricultural intervention to protect crops from weather adversities
	analyze and evaluate the role of vegetation in the terrestrial carbon cycle

data.name: Effective Managerial Decision Making
data.description:
Throughout their personal and professional lives, managers have to take multitudes of decisions. The general purpose of this course is to familiarise you with problems associated with unaided managerial decision making, as well as with structured decision aiding techniques aiming to overcome these problems. Students will also obtain an understanding of the thinking processes that underlie judgement and decision making, and its systematic errors and biases.

The course will be organised in two parts. (1) The first, smaller, part will focus on the psychology of judgement and decision-making. You will be familiarized with psychological research demonstrating that humans have bounded rationality and are susceptible to systematic errors and biases. We will briefly cover the heuristics and biases approach and prospect theory. (2) The second, more substantial, part concerns decision aiding tools. You will be presented with structured decision aiding techniques that aim to improve the quality of managerial decisions in the realm of business as well as public policy. Their core concept is simplification, breaking a complex problem into a number of simpler problems. For each technique, you will be presented with the steps that it involves and how to apply it to real-life problems. We will discuss SMART, planning networks, decision trees, simulation, and financial analysis. We will also discuss how to be more effective in bargaining and negotiation, which is another central activity in management.

By the end of the course students should have acquired:
-an in-depth understanding of why unaided decision making is often biased. This involves attaining a good grasp of the psychology of judgement and decision making. Students should also be able to cite and critically evaluate empirical evidence.
-an understanding of the various decision-aiding techniques including: the contexts in which each technique should be applied, the steps that they involve, and the benefits/shortcomings of each. Importantly, the students should have also acquired the ability to apply such techniques to solve novel problems.
-an understanding of Raiffa's decision-analytic approach to negotiation, and the ability to apply it to negotiation problems.
-the ability to read journal articles, understand and discuss the main theoretical points and evidence, and critically evaluate them.

data.name: Finite elements modeling
data.description:
The finite element method (FEM) is the dominant discretization technique in process and product modelling. The objective of this course is to give the student a broad and integrative knowledge of this method and to introduce the student into its application to a variety of engineering problems.
By the end of this course students should: (1) know the behaviour and usage of each type of elements covered in this course; (2) be able to use finite element software to develop models of engineering systems; (3) be able to interpret and evaluate the quality of the results (know the physics of the problems); (4) be aware of the limitations of the FEM (don't misuse the FEM - a numerical tool!);  (5) be familiar with team-working, mathematical computing and FEM software; (6) be able to present FEM analyses in a proper format of a written report such that a technically qualified person can follow and obtain similar findings.

data.name: Restauro architettonico con Laboratorio Progettuale

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
The contemporary debate on the destiny of the existing buildings underlines the containment of soil consumption, the reuse of the built environment, and the sustainable development as central themes. The architectural restoration, which by its statute deals with the fate of cultural heritage, has always deeply contributed to this debate by proposing, over time, different ways to address it. The course covers the understanding of the objectives, the methods and techniques of a complex and operationally design discipline, closely intertwined with other fields such as architectural composition, history, the sciences and structural techniques. It follows a project method based on the knowledge of monuments, achieved through numerous analytical research that aims to understand the value of the monument and this preserve it.

The learning outcomes (knowledge and skills) are:

1. KNOWLEDGE AND COMPREHENSION.

The student will acquire through the theoretical lessons and classroom activities knowledge and comprehension of the theoretical and practical issues of restoration discipline with particular reference to the following aspects:

1.1 the student is encouraged to became critically aware of the actions he/she takes in the conservation of a historic structure, and the affects this actions can have on the outcome learning the importance of the “care” that needs to be taken in such work. This awareness then acts as a guide when facing the potential problems that can arise in the moment in which the structural stability and/or use of a given historic construction is either improved or modified.

1.2 Make the student able to elaborate a restoration project with the procedures necessary for the public institutions of the protection of monuments.

To achieve these learning outcomes the course will provide students with:

1.1. basic knowledge of principles of architectural restoration (preservation)

1.2. theoretical and practical for the elaboration of project on a multilayered context.

2 ABILITY TO APPLY KNOWLEDGE AND COMPREHENSION

The student will acquire through classroom and laboratory exercises, practical skills for the project of architectural restoration with particular reference to the following fields of activity:

2.1 diagnostic project to recognize the problems of material conservation and the value of testimony of a multi-layered historical context;

2.2 reuse proposals compatible with pre-existence.

3. AUTONOMY OF JUDGMENT, SKILLS AND LEARNING ABILITIES

The student will acquire, through group exercises and team work, the ability to:

3.1. act, communicate and evaluate, critically and autonomy of judgement, the principles and techniques necessary to carry out a restoration project compatible with the value of a historical context.


The expected learning result is the ability to set up and develop a restoration project based on knowledge of the techniques of analysis and interpretation of a stratified architectural and urban context; the ability to design a project proposal focusing on the recognition of the existing as a witness value, on architectural design tools intended as a poetic transformation, between memory and invention; the ability to apply methodologies and intervention techniques as a response to conservation and innovation issues; the ability to communicate, through narration, graphic board, 3D models, the spatial, formal and technical of the architectural project.

data.name: Economic History
data.description:
The objective of the course is to provide (1) adequate knowledge of the major transformations of the European and world economies from the pre-industrial age to the contemporary era and the underlying factors; (2) the skills necessary to understand, analyze and critically interpret these transformations.

Upon completion of the course, the student will be able to:

- remember the basic concepts useful in the analysis of an economic system;

- describe the main historical manifestations of economic growth/development and crises;

- explain their causes and consequences, grasping the interaction between economic aspects and technological, institutional, cultural and geographical factors;

- communicate effectively in oral and written form, and argue on an economic historical topic.

data.name: Signal, Image and Video

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: The course provides the basic competences in the field of digital signal processing, with special attention to images and video sequences. Starting from the fundamentals of 1D signal analysis and processing, analog and numerical, in time and frequency domains, we then extend the concepts to the multi-dimensional case of signals in space. Then, we introduce the more important approaches for image filtering and extraction of image descriptors. These concepts are further extended to deal with motion pictures. Finally, the problem of image compression is introduced, focusing on most known techniques for image and video coding, as well as their standard implementations. The approach of the course is rather practical, with the explanation of theoretical concept followed by their translation into algorithmic terms.

Interpretation of the results of a neuropsychological procedure: dissociations, localization vs. function. Ability to apply knowledge and understanding: 1. Interpretation of the literature. 2. data.name: Automated Reasoning

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
IMPORTANT NOTE: Starting from academic year 2020/21, the course "Formal Methods" is split into two consecutive modules:
Module I:  "Automated Reasoning" [6CFU, of which 4.5CFU theory + 1.5CFU lab]
Module II: "Model Checking" [6CFU, of which 4.5CFU theory + 1.5CFU lab]
which are borrowed respectively as single courses
* Automated Reasoning [6CFU, of which 4.5CFU theory + 1.5CFU lab]
* Model Checking [6CFU, of which 4.5CFU theory + 1.5CFU lab]
from the degree course in Artificial Intelligence Systems.
The first module/course is a prerequisite for the second.

Part of both modules/courses consists on lab sessions, for 3CFU overall (1.5 CFU Automated Reasoning + 1.5 CFU Model Checking)

As such, the first module/course  "Automated Reasoning" will start at the beginning of the semester and end in the middle of the semester, whereas the second module/course "Model Checking" will start in the middle of the semester and terminate at the end of the semester.

Module I:  "Automated Reasoning" [6CFU, of which 4.5CFU theory + 1.5CFU lab]

Automated (logical) reasoning techniques are widely used in many fields, mainly in Artificial Intelligence --as backend "engines" in several automated reasoning, inference and planning tools-- and in the field of formal specification and validation of complex systems --as backend "engines" on top of which automated-verification tools are build.
Module I "Automated Reasoning" introduces the main methodologies and instruments for automated (logical) reasoning.  

Students will experience in laboratory the usage of automated reasoning tools, in particular, e.g., of SAT and SMT solvers. 

At the end of the course, the student:
- will know the main automated reasoning techniques
- will be able to model simple problems and solved them via automated reasoning tools, like e.g. SAT or SMT solvers.

Module II: "Model Checking" [6CFU, of which 4.5CFU theory + 1.5CFU lab]

Formal methods are increasingly used as powerful specification, verification and early debugging methods in the development of industrial SW and HW systems. This course provides an introduction to Formal Techniques and Tools for the specification and verification of Hardware and Software platforms. The main and most-successful fall in the "Model Checking" family, which use automated-reasoning techniques as backend engines. 
Module II "Model Checking" introduces the main specification and formal verification techniques of SW and HW devices. The course will concentrate mainly on formal verification and techniques and, in particular, on Model Checking (MC).

A laboratory will be given in which the students will experience MC techniques by means of the MC NuXmv and SPIN. 

At the end of the course, the student:
- will know the main formal specification and verification techniques, in particular Model Checking
- will be able to formalize simple HW and SW systems and verify their properties by means of the model checker NuXmv.

data.name: Procedure concorsuali
data.description:
The course aims to deepen the legal discipline of insolvency law with particular regard to the new Code of Business Crisis and Insolvency. The student will have to demonstrate at the end of the course that he have assimilated the knowledge relating to the instruments for regulating the crisis and insolvency, with particular reference to the “concordato preventivo” and judicial liquidation. A further training objective is represented by the study of the fundamental principles of the Insolvency Directive 2019/1023 recently transposed into the legal system.


At the end of the course, the student who has successfully learned the subject will have an in-depth knowledge of the topics and will have acquired a method of reasoning suitable for dealing with specific and complex legal issues relating to insolvency law and business crisis.

In particular, the expected results from the teaching are the following:

 Knowledge and understanding: through the lessons and in-depth study of the teaching material, the student will be able to acquire adequate knowledge and an effective understanding of the rules that make up the legal system of reference relating to insolvency law and business crisis.

 Applied knowledge and understanding: students will be able to apply the knowledge acquired and understand operational tools for the regulation of the crisis and insolvency.

 Autonomy of judgment: students will have to know how to use the acquired knowledge both on a conceptual and operational level with autonomous assessment skills and skills in the different application contexts, also orienting themselves in the evaluation of the different theories and in the solution of practical problems.

 Communication skills: students will be able to acquire the technical language typical of the discipline in a clear and unambiguous way with specialist and non-specialist interlocutors.

 Learning abilities: through the lessons in the classroom and the problems that will be submitted to them by the teacher during the same, students will be able to develop adequate learning abilities that will allow them to continue to deepen independently the main issues of the discipline, especially in professional contexts in which they will find themselves working on, acquiring the technical and cultural tools of the profession.

data.name: Macroeconomics
data.description: The aim of the course is to equip students with a framework for understanding macroeconomics that maps the workhorse model for macroeconomic modelling adopted by governments and central banks. Students will develop a systematic way of thinking through the macroeconomic problems affecting our times, and learn how to connect the behaviour of various economic actors with aggregated macroeconomic outcomes. Students will develop notions of open economy macroeconomics, necessary to address issues such as global imbalances and the Euro zone. The course will make students knowledgeable about the national and international economic trends, and they will be able to participate in policy debates about them. By the end of this course, students should be able to build a picture of how the world economy has evolved in the last century and use macroeconomic models to interpret them.

data.name: Negotiation
data.description:
“Let us never negotiate out of fear. But let us never fear to negotiate.” 
John F. Kennedy

Negotiations are an essential and fundamental moment in the life of individuals, organizations, institutions, and firms. In the last few decades, negotiation has moved from the industrial relations and political arena to the forefront of managerial interest. Negotiation, bargaining, and mediation traditionally refer to the arbitration of disputes between labour and management. However, scholars and practitioners now recognise that these skills operate in virtually every management function, including strategy formulation, mergers and acquisitions, purchasing, sales, international development and many others.

Negotiation is a common mechanism for resolving differences between and allocating resources among exchange partners such as supervisors, colleagues, corporate entities and even nations. Improving negotiation skills, as well as increasing the ability to negotiate effectively, is crucial in managerial, political, and business contexts.
This module explores the key aspects of negotiation. The primary aim of this module is to integrate negotiation theory and practice, through an integration of concepts, models, expertise and practical experience. It will typically examine, through a mix of theory and practice, the links among negotiation fundamentals, negotiation sub-processes and negotiation contexts.

Learning objectives

The purpose of this course is threefold. 
•	The first is to explore the major concepts and theories of negotiation, as well as the dynamics of interpersonal and intergroup conflict and its resolution. This will entail material about the structural (e.g. parties, issues, positions and interest) and process-oriented (cognitive, interactional) dynamics that are necessary for a sound critical background. 
•	The second objective is to develop skills relevant to a broad range of applied contexts. This involves direct training in identifying crucial elements of a negotiation situation and implementing appropriate resolution strategies. 
•	The third objective is to encourage participants to assume a “reflective” and “cooperative” posture about negotiations specifically and social influence broadly. 

On completion of the module you should be able to:

•	Analyse a negotiation situation and its possible solutions.
•	Identify the personal challenges we all have in dealing with negotiation.
•	Apply complex theory and practice of negotiation in particular and general contexts.

data.name: Questionnaire Design
data.description:
The course will be held in English. The purpose of the course is to provide students with both practical and theoretical knowledge of questionnaire design and to develop critical skill in evaluating already constructed questionnaires.
The student will learn to:
- understand different research designs in which questionnaires are used
- identify different levels of measurement of the variables
- construct a questionnaire plan (sections, objectives, questions, analysis)
- carefully choose words to use in questions (wording)
- Choose the appropriate type of response format
- construct a cover letter
- Implement the questionnaire using online systems
- Build a coding plan 
- Enter data into a spreadsheet
- construct simple measurement scales and indices
- perform simple statistics on instrument reliability (Cronbach's alpha, factor analysis).
The course is intended as a laboratory in which students will be asked to demonstrate the acquisition of acquired skills through personal or group laboratory activities.
