data.name: Bacterial Pathogenesis

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description:
Objectives
The aim of the course is to provide the students with the understanding the bacterium-host relationships and to explore the virulence factors that promote colonization and survival of the infecting microorganisms, as well the virulence attributes that damage the host. The course will explore the evolutionary aspects of bacterial pathogenesis and the experimental approaches for investigating the bacterium-host inte-relationship, underlining the molecular mechanisms of pathogenicity for selected pathogens. The challenge facing the discovering and development of new antibiotics will also be discussed.
At the end of this course, students will be able to:
a) Describe the difference between the different types of symbiosis and their evolution
b) Understand what makes a bacterium a "pathogen" 
c) Describe the distinctive genetic traits of a bacterial pathogen 
d) Understand the difference between pathogenicity and virulence and how to assess them
e) Describe the main modes of bacterial transmission
f) Describe the molecular mechanisms of bacterial pathogenicity in defined bacterial models 
g) Describe the main anti-infectious strategies against bacteria

data.name: Physics Education: Theoretical and Experimental Approaches
data.description:
The course aims to prepare students as future teachers of experimental physics courses by introducing them to experimental techniques, teaching methodologies and the design of didactic experiences.
This course aims to provide an introduction to the methodological aspects with particular reference to the organization of the didactic aspects, the conduction of a lesson and the design of teaching sequences.
Finally, the course aims to acquire familiarity with experimental equipment of the didactic laboratory, data acquisition and analysis software, simulation environments and new teaching technology.

Various experimental activities will be presented from an educational point of view and some case studies will be considered by adopting both traditional laboratory equipment and new technologies applied to the didactic laboratory of physics.
Practical activities will be carried out directly by students divided into working groups.

At the end of the course, the student will be able to
1) independently design experience and educational sequences
2) Perform experiments using appropriately the equipment of the physics lab
3) Analyze experimental data using commonly used software
4) use video analysis software
5) build simulations using appropriate software

data.name: Letteratura inglese - LM
data.description:
English language: Entitled Literary adaptation as intersemiotic process, the course aims to provide students with critical and methodological tools for the multimodal analysis of film adaptations of literary texts, specifically short stories. By the end of the course, students will be able to a) understand the complexity of film adaptations of literary texts, b) identify affordances and constraints of modes and modal resources, c) carry out the multimodal analysis of an adaptation and discuss the results consistently.

English literature 1: This course, entitled Experimentation, Complexity, and Representation in Modernist Writing, aims at enhancing students hermeneutical competence in analyzing a literary text, both in its experimental features and in relation to its epistemic context.
At the end of the course students will be able to master the contents of the course with an adequate critical attitude.

English literature 2: (In)Human Monsters, Post-Human Selves. The course aims to provide students with the critical tools that will enable them to recognise and analyse the stylistic as well as ideological peculiarities of Kazuo Ishiguro's Never Let Me Go (2005) and Jeanette Winterson's Frankissstein: A Love Story (2019). Moreover, both texts will be placed in the context of the debate about human and post-human identity in contemporary British fiction. At the end of the course students will be expected to adopt a critical perspective (textual and contextual) on literary texts so as to recognise their aesthetic, ethical and political peculiarities.
data.degreeProgram: Letterature euroamericane, traduzione e critica letteraria (LM)

data.name: Storia globale in età moderna - LT
data.description:
The aim of the course is
* To provide an updated and varied framework of relations growing in a global context during the modern Age
* To focus and to reflect on the complexity of economic, social, cultural interactions, with a special focus on English Atlantic and the English presence in Asia
* To develop plural perspectives, analyzing a range of textual and iconographical sources 
* To offer historiographical elements related to Global History and his methodology 
* To provide tools for teaching history, presenting plural perspectives and a Global History approach
* To increase methodological awareness and critical thinking skills
* To develop transversal skills: teamworking skills, problem solving skills, presentations skills

At the end of the course students 
* Will mature in their understanding and have varied knowledges about relations and exchanges among different areas of the world during the modern age, particularly with regard to the English colonial context
* will acquire elements of historical methodologies
* will develop a conscious use of concepts developed in the context of Global History studies 
* will be able to read, analyze and discuss a scientific paper/or: sources related to global interactions, demonstrating a critical thinking
* will be able to insert correctly phenomena into a geographical space and to use maps and outline maps
* will be able to held a well-prepared and effective presentation of a paper/source on a Global History topic

data.name: European Security: Politics and Policies
data.description:
The module aims to assess the multidimensional nature of the concept of security in the European Union. In the last
decade, the EU has been dealing with crises of different nature, posing a threat to the security of its citizens. From the
economic-financial crisis to the conflicts in Ukraine and Syria; from the emergence and consolidation of populist
parties to the possibility of ‘dis-integration’ prompted by Brexit; from the migration and refugee crisis to the success of
regimes of illiberal democracy in Central-Eastern Europe, the EU has gone through a decade of poly-crises.
The module seeks to understand the impact of such different crises – socio-economic, political, military and cultural –
on the security policies of the EU. What are the most important actors and institutions in the different sub-areas of
European Security? How has their role changed in the last ten years? The module will explore in detail several
policies where European security is at risk, from climate change to data protection, from energy policy to terrorism.
The institutional context, the key actors and the substantive content will be analysed in detail for each policy.
At the end of the module, students will have developed the conceptual baggage and the analytical toolkit to
understand and critically assess – both theoretically and in a more applied perspective – the security policies of the
European Union.

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.name: Cultural Anthropology

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description:
This course introduces students to some key concepts and research interests of contemporary cultural anthropology. Anthropology offers a way of understanding both the commonalities of the human experience and the diversity of human societies and cultures. It offers tools for making sense of the experience of people whose lives are different from our own, as well as casting our familiar world in a new perspective. This course aims at providing an overview of some of the research topics that concern anthropologists, with a specific attention to areas of interests that also concern the psychological sciences, such as emotions, identity, care and mental health in transcultural perspective. At the end of the course, students will achieve the following learning goals:

 

·     An introductory knowledge of the main theoretical and methodological tools employed by contemporary cultural anthropology.

·     The building up of interdisciplinary competences, through the analysis of case studies and research topics at the centre of the interests of both anthropological and psychological sciences.

·     The ability to understand and critically use some key concepts, such as culture, ethnocentrism and cultural relativism.

·     The development of the following soft skills: in-depth analysis of a subject of interest or case study; ability to present opinions and discuss in a clear and organized way; collective work and oral presentation of a topic to an audience, with clarity, originality, and appropriate use of the terminology.
data.degreeProgram: Scienze e Tecniche di Psicologia Cognitiva (L2)

data.name: Electromagnetic safety and security

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: The course, after reviewing fundamentals and main issues of electromagnetic propagation in wired and wireless systems, will focus on the classical and mostly recently design methodologies aimed at avoid electromagnetic interfering phenomenas, discussing capabilities, and limits of applications. Moreover a part of the course is devoted to prevent the so called Electromagnetic terrorism, and how to remove threads due to dangerous remote controlled devices, such as improved explosive devices (IED), drones and unwanted communication (for police and security operations). Practical examples concerning real device commonly used for protect telecommunication systems will corroborate the theoretical concepts. In particular, the course provides the students with the methodologies necessary for the analysis, the design and the protection of complex telecommunication systems. This kind of knowledge is of great importance for telecommunication engineers involved in the development of telecommunication systems. All telecommunication products or systems must be protected from electromagnetic interferences  in order to work properly in proximity of other devices. In the course the basics concepts of the electromagnetic compatibility and a working knowledge of how to detect and protect electric and electronic devices, will be given. At the end of the course the student will be able to design and fabricate complex telecommunication system avoiding any kind of electromagnetic interfering problems. The didactic content of the course will be integrated with some software and experimental activities related to the study and the protection from electromagnetic interfering signals. Moreover, the standard electromagnetic compatibility measurements methodologies will be explained.

data.name: European Transport Law
data.description: The Course aims to deepen, through a detailed analysis of the legislation and the jurisprudential debate, the study of the regulation of transport services by air, sea, road and rail in the European context. The course will also focus on the analysis of the infrastructural profiles of the matter and the rights of passengers.

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.name: Partial differential equations
data.description:
Aim of the course is that of presenting the most relevant types of partial differential equations (elliptic, parabolic, hyperbolic: especially in the linear case), together with the physical models that they describe. Specifically, the functional framework is introduced and it is shown to be suitable for clarifying under which conditions the problems associated with these differential equations are well-posed (existence, uniqueness, stability); [Only for 9-credit course: the students are then introduced to elliptic regularity and maximum principles.]

At the end of the course the student will be able to get oriented among the various types of partial differential equations, to know which are the characteristic qualitative properties of the solutions, to have a deeper knowledge of the mathematical approach to these problems as well as some fluency in the use of modern techniques for the study of these themes.

data.name: Typical and Atypical Development

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description:
The course aims to analyze typical and atypical psychological development from a multidisciplinary perspective. The course presents the concepts, theories and methods of Developmental Clinical Psychology. The topics include the study of typical and atypical psychological development during the first years of life, individual differences, cultural and biological influences, and the impact of developmental delay and related disabilities on daily life.

At the end of their educational path, students will be able to:


A. understand the basic principles of growth and the basics of development from conception to adolescence, including genetic and environmental influences

B. identify, compare, contrast and evaluate research methodologies of developmental psychology and experimental paradigms of clinical neuroscience

C. think critically, scientifically and apply understanding about theoretical constructs and frameworks, research practices and scientific findings on child development

D. describe the characteristics in the domains of motor and perceptual, cognitive and communicative, social and emotional development for each stage of development

E. recognize individual and cultural differences in children's development and socialization

F. formulate diagnostic hypotheses of neurodevelopmental disorders on patients experiencing a condition of atypical development

G. discriminate how to create environments, educational programs and interactions that support the development of young children, including those with special needs, individually and in groups

data.name: Diritto penale e dell'esecuzione della pena

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
Teaching Objectives:
The course aims to provide a general undertsanding of the system of criminal law and some of the main issues that apply to social assistance through an examination of existing laws and rules, as well as practical cases.
The course will also focus on the purposes of criminal punishment, especially on individual deterrence and prevention, and on the system of criminal punishment.
Particular attention will be devoted to the enforcement of penalties and the so-called «flexible enforcement».
Expected teaching results:
At the end of the course, the student is expected to show:
-	knowledge of the most important topics in criminal law and crimes concerning social assistance's activities;
-	comprehensive knowledge of the Italian sanctioning system;
- ability to use the technical language in an appropriate and precise fashion.

data.name: Atmospheric physics and modelling
data.description:
The course provides an in-depth analysis of atmospheric processes relevant for various environmental engineering applications. Large space is dedicated to the modelling tools for weather forecasting, air pollution simulations and the assessment of renewable energy availability. 

At the end of the course the student should:

  • know the basics of atmospheric processes relevant for different environmental engineering applications, such as pollutant dispersion and the assessment of renewable energy resource availability
  • know the basics of meteorological and atmospheric dispersion models
  • know methodologies of data analysis and models to evaluate solar and wind energy availability
  • be able to interpret the output of meteorological models and realize simple weather forecasts

data.name: Algorithms and Data Structures

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description:
Algorithmics is the science of algorithms. It includes algorithm design, the art of building a procedure which can solve correctly and efficiently a problem; and algorithm analysis, the science of quantifying the amount of resources needed by an algorithm to solve a problem.


The overall goal of this course is to introduce students to the design and analysis of algorithmic solutions, through the presentation of the most important class of algorithms and the evaluation of their performance. The course is shared between the Quantitative and Computational Biology degree and the Data Science Degree. For this reasons, after a common theoretical part, students will be subdivided in two groups for the lab exercises, one devoted to computational biology and one devoted to data science.


At the end of the course, students are expected to:

A) describe classic algorithms on strings, trees, and graphs and understand their behavior;

B) understand, at the basic level, the most important algorithm design techniques

C) evaluate algorithmic choices and select the ones that best suit their problems

D) analyze the complexity of algorithms

E) design simple algorithmic solutions to basic problems, and to implement them using the Python language

data.name: Data mining
data.description: This is a graduate level course on Data Mining. Data Mining is the science studying mathematical models, computational paradigms, algorithms and methodologies that look for patterns and regularities in large amounts of raw data. The aim is to allow us to understand natural phenomena, business operations and human behaviors, in ways that it will allow us to turn this knowledge into predictions, forecasting and performance improvements. The goal of the course is to introduce the students to the basic concepts, principles and techniques of Data Mining, to help them develop the required skills for using the state of the art data mining algorithms for solving practical problems, and to provide them with the required experience that will later allow them to operate independently, efficiently and effectively, in highly competitive markets. The course aims also to support students wishing to pursue a research carrier by teaching them the methodologies in performing independent and effective studies and research activities. The goals of the course will be achieved by teaching the students the strengths and limitations of the various data mining techniques, how they can be applied, under what conditions and what they should expect from each application. At the end of the course, the students will be finding themselves familiar with the most popular data mining concepts and will be able to identify and use the right solutions for any data analysis problem they may find themselves into. Last but not least, future data scientists will also learn how to perform the right experiments, how to interpret the results correctly and how to present them in the most effective way.

data.name: Real time operating systems and middleware

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: The Real-Time Operating Systems and Middleware course will introduce the concept of real-time applications and will show the student the foundations of design, development, and implementation of a real-time software system. The course will also focus on the requirements of the operating system kernels targeted to real-time applications. The course will consider different kinds of Real-Time systems, each one aimed at a different class of applications ranging from multimedia (soft real-time) to control and automation.

data.name: The City and the Futures. Perspectives and Experiences for Resilient Communities

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
We consider climate change as a key factor requiring the development of resilience in addition with other megatrends which might create synergies and reinforcing effects (both positive and negative), depending on the preparedness of social-economic  systems and actors. The interaction among participants will consist of a facilitated discussion inspired to several "system thinking" tools, using the platform MURAL and MIRO and original template (created for the course). Students will be actively involved in the interactive activities with the aim to achieve new knowledge on theories and practices on climate adaptation and urban resilience, as well as innovative tools for engaging communities. Description of activities:
- short and intensive lectures on design approaches and future studies methodologies.
- applied exercise where participants work in groups on future-proofing for climate resilient communities themes in order to test the proposed methodology.
- collective restitution of the results in groups and to the larger audience.

At the end of the course, students are expected to be able to: (a) recognize the minerals and rocks most frequently found in archaeological contexts; (b) synthetically describe archaeological sediments and soils and reconstruct formation processes and environments; (c) correctly describe archaeological stratifications and reconstruct their sequence of formation; (d) correctly build a Harris matrix; and (e) fill essential excavation data.

data.name: International Law
data.description:
The broad aim of the course is to introduce students who have not studied international law before to its core principles, sources and techniques of legal reasoning. Students will study how international law is made, who are its subjects, what international law does in case of conflict (i.e. settlement) and what is the content of the most important international law rules. 
At the end of the course students will be familiar with the international legal order being conceived not just as a collection of rules but as a way of thinking about and organising the world. They will be able to understand how international law is applied to specific, including current, events in order to develop and to be able to discuss critically their own personal view.

data.description: The general aim of the course is to provide the students with the analytical tools to reflect critically on the late modern (contemporary) history of the Twentieth Century and to offer a key to understand of the historical roots of current events. The course will focus on the international history of the early Twentieth century. The student is expected to be able to use bibliographic tools and working materials to understand contemporary society.

data.name: Pensiero ebraico II - LT
Management pubblico
data.description:
1. Educational objectives

The main purpose of this course is to introduce students to the knowledge and the general understanding about the operating of public administrations according to the managerial reforms of the public sector.
In the first part we analyze general aspects of public administrations with comparisons with principal european and Anglo-Saxon experiences. Especially: the role, functions of public administrations; processes of managerial reform both at international and national level; the various forms of managing public intervention: direct, public agencies, public and private companies both profit and no-profit.
In the second part we discuss about  managerial functions essential to improve the relationships between public administrations and both companies and citizens: strategic programmation of an local authority; organization of human resources; organization of services and management of relationships with citizens according to principles of citizen satisfaction management.

2. Expected learning outcomes
-	clear understanding of  Public Administration decision making processes
-      factors effectively affecting changing process within  public 
        administrations
-      evolution of relationships between public administrations and 
       citizens
-      public service management system according to citizen 
       satisfaction management

data.name: Virus-Cell Interaction

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description:
The aim of the course is to provide the students with the understanding of the molecular basis of the interaction between viruses and their host cells, and the modern research strategies applied to the investigation of the mechanisms regulating the virus-cell interface. At the end of this course, students will be able to:
a) Describe the different types of interaction between viruses and cell 
b) Understand the molecular mechanisms which govern the interaction between viruses and cells.
c) Describe the main techniques used to investigate the dynamics and the mechanisms of the virus-cell interaction
c) Explain the mechanisms of reciprocal adaptation between viruses and their hosts
d) Understand the causes, dynamics, and basic pathogenic mechanisms underlying viral infections.
e) Describe the main strategies used to interfere with the virus interaction with its host
f) Understand the causes and consequences of the host-virus interaction at the population level.
g) Comprehend the contribution of virus research for the advancement of our knowledge of the mechanisms governing the eukaryotic cell
h) Understanding the principles driving the development of virus-based technologies aimed at manipulating eukaryotic cells.

In particular, the study will have a special focus on the legal status of religious minorities, starting from late Antiquity and up to the contemporary age.

data.name: Psicologia economica
data.description:
Economic Psychology is the study of the psychological mechanisms that underlie economic behaviors. It is an area where psychology and economics intersect. Economic psychology, therefore, describes and explains economic preferences and choices, and factors influencing these. The focus of economic psychology is to understand human (and organizational) motivations behind economic decisions, such as consumer decisions, investment decisions, negotiations, savings, tax compliance and insurance decisions.
Economics deals also with the behavior of humans and hence should be considered as a behavioral science. It is mainly concerned with prescribing what economic agents should do, what they should choose, in order to maximize their personal outcomes (i.e., to be rational). Two broad theories of rational choice can be identified, Utility Theory has been proposed to understand individual decision making and Game Theory has been proposed to understand the behavior of individuals in interdependent situations. Psychologists and experimental economists have studied whether and how utility theory and game theory describe and predict the behavior of individuals. It appears that people systematically violate the assumptions of these theories. Therefore, in order to come to a better understanding of human behavior, a new approach that takes these violations into account should be developed. In this course we discuss these behavioral violations and the suggested alternative theories to economic behavior.
In this course you will:
	develop an understanding of differences between major theories and research practices in economics and psychology.
	learn when and why economic theories fail descriptively, and what alternative explanations for economic behavior have been proposed. 
	apply these ideas and findings to the formulation of solutions to real-life problems (e.g., problems in consumer choice, marketing, or questions of public policy)
	give a reasoned opinion of fundamental issues and debates on economic decision- making discussed during the lectures (e.g., freedom to choose, rationality, self-interest, fairness).

data.name: Psicologia delle organizzazioni

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description:
The course is an in-depth study of organizational psychology. In addition to an introduction on the basic characteristics of the scientific discipline, some key issues that have a strong applicative relevance will be addressed. We intend to provide the student with some basic elements for applying psychological interventions in organizations. Methodological knowledge will be examined to show different ways of conducting organizational diagnosis and interventions to produce organizational change. The relationship between new technologies and organizational models will be treated through specific readings. The organization of the course will be as follows (each section will be approximately 8-12 hours of lessons):


1- Introductory section on concepts and methods of organizational psychology. Examples and insights will refer in particular to health and education organizations.

2- Section dedicated to the theme of organizational change and organizational socialization. How to introduce elements of innovation in organizations and how to deal with possible resistance to change.

3- Section dedicated to the introduction of new technologies in organizations. What are the new opportunities and risks.

4- Section by prof. D. Truxillo (visiting professor): recruitment and selection from the point of view of applicants; self-regulation and self-awareness at work; job analysis and job crafting; diversity, equity and inclusion at work.

data.name: Bioinformatics Resources

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
This module will provide an overview of the most common databases and computational resources available to implement standard bioinformatics analyses. For all arguments introduced in the course, R will be used as common programming environment to perform data analysis examples and exercises. At the end of the course, students will be able:

a) Interrogate and use the main databases and online tools storing publicly available biological data.

b) Use the R programming environment to search, install and use computational resources related to the bioinformatics analyses object of the course.

c) Build a computational pipeline to analyze and characterize biological data.

data.name: Crash course - International Business
data.description:
This intensive course aims to form students’ knowledge in the area of International Business. Specifically students will develop capabilities to identify, frame and understand problems related to the management of international operations. Throughout the course issues are discussed in both theoretical and practical terms to stimulate students to relate models and concepts with practical situations.

By the end of the course the students will be able to:
•	discuss implications of globalization and cultural differences 
•	understand the implications of operating across national borders 
•	compare different internationalization processes 
•	describe how firms operate in different markets
•	analyze different international strategies and organizational structures
•	evaluate and criticize different leadership and control models
•	describe the specificity of different functions and units within the international firm
•	understand the basis for the competitive advantage of international firms

data.name: Innovative and sustainable techniques for minor and speciality crops in the Alps
data.description:
The aim of the course is to provide the knowledge and the skills necessary to develop minor crops in order to increase the farm income in Alpine regions, with particular attention to the sustainability of production/distribution/consumption and to landscape and rural tourism.


The learning outcomes are:

- knowing and understanding the agronomic and physiological principles of the production, conservation and transformation of those minor vegetable crops that can increase the income of the Alpine region and the main potentially available elements of innovation; 

- knowing and understanding the chemical-physical and organoleptic characteristics of the products of minor crops, with particular focus on bioactive compounds and identifying possible food transformations for their enhancement; 

- evaluating the production systems of minor crops in terms of impact on the sensory characteristics and consumer's preference with particular attention to rapid innovative methods applicable in the producing company; 

the most innovative genetic approaches for the identification of the crop species and their varieties;

- assessing the positive impact on pesticide reduction, biodiversity, pollinators and landscape of minor crops in the Alpine Region.


At the end of the course the student will be able to:

- improve plant production in terms of quality, profitability and environmental sustainability, making traditional agri-food chains more competitive thanks to the introduction of new species;

- apply crop protection strategies by combining environmental sustainability and productivity considering the European and national regulatory context; 

- orienting the production choice towards plant species more suited to the health and demand of the consumer on the basis of knowledge of the nutritional and nutraceutical aspects of derived foods and market trends;

- implement adequate strategies to preserve the nutritional and sensory characteristics of food products derived from minor species during their production and subsequent storage and evaluate the adequacy of the various processing technologies according to the final quality of the food product to be obtained.

- take advantage of genetic characterization in promoting minor crops to a relevant role in modern/local agriculture and to authenticate their seeds and related food items.


By working on a selected case study in close contact with growers and food industries/restaurants the student will be able to apply the techniques and strategies for introducing a new crop and defining the best processes in production, transformation/storage, distribution and consumptions for the innovation.

Finally, the student will know how to plan and conduct an analysis, process the collected data and critically interpret the results and be able to write or interpret an analysis report and present the results to a professional public.

data.description: The goal of the course is  to give a good knowledge of the programming language C implementing algorithm and cryptographic protocols. A part of the course is dedicated to the use of Java in cryptographic area.

data.name: Fondamenti di robotica

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The landscape of robotics has gone through a deep change throughout the last decade. Up until the early years of this century, robots were seen as heavy and dangerous machines used to execute stiffly defined tasks within controlled and structured environments. The recent advances in artificial intelligence have had a profound impact on the type of tasks that a robot can perform and on the level of safety and reliability they can be executed with. Modern robots assist older adults or  impaired people, work side by side with human workers, drive on the highways with little or no assistance. This paradigm shift requires the robot to perceive and understand the situation in the surroundings, to autonomously plan a suitable course of actions for a task, and to see to its correct execution by properly reacting to unexpected events. 
To design a machine of this complexity, engineers need several competencies tapping diverse disciplines. Robots are physical machines created by humans, so their motion can be analysed and controlled through appropriate mathematical models. Robots move in a partially known environment, so they need to create a map of their surroundings, to localise themselves within the environment, to detect, classify and recognise the different objects they interact with. Robots are required to be autonomous or sem-iautonomous, so they need the ability to decide a sequence of actions (a plan), to implement it within appropriate safety bounds and to adapt it to changes as needed. Finally, robots embed computing machines that need to be programmed through appropriate languages and frameworks. 
The students will be introduced to each one of these different aspects and will receive the opportunity to put them into practice using our advanced educational laboratories and teaching facilities. After taking the course, they will be able to take on a career as developers of robotic applications and/or to continue with advanced studies in the area of intelligent robots.

data.name: Computer vision

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: The course aims to provide the student with an in-depth overview on the methods of analysis and management of multimedia data. Starting from the basics of image and video processing, the course will focus on the problems of motion modeling and detection, motion tracking, and object recognition, both by using monocular and multi-view systems.

data.description: Becoming familiar with the historical and artistic resources of the territory as well as developing a critical knowledge of the related enhancement activities.

data.name: Imaging and diagnostic techniques

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: The course presents innovative methodologies with emphasis on techniques based on Artificial Intelligence for the solution of imaging and diagnostics/prognostics problems for biomedical, industrial, and safety applications. Starting from a series of seminar lessons that present the different techniques developed at the state of the art, the course is dedicated to present the tools and methods for solving imaging and diagnostics/prognostics problems, addressing specific project activities through laboratory activities. The projects may have a numerical or experimental nature and can be chosen by the students from a set of possible alternatives.

data.name: Ingegneria degli acquiferi e dei siti contaminati

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description: The course provides the students with the skills needed for the design of remediation actions and management of contaminated sites, as well as the design of sustainable utilization systems of subsurface water resources in view of the impact of climate change and the growing anthropic pressure. Attention is given to the interaction between groundwater and underground structures and groundwater protection. The first part of the course deals with the design of remediation systems for groundwater and contaminated sites, as well as the design of efficient and sustainable groundwater exploitation systems. The second part of the course deals with the study of the physical and biogeochemical processes controlling the occurrence and the quality of groundwater. Flow and transport modeling is considered here because instrumental to the modern design of water exploitation and remediation systems for contaminated sites. The students will acquire the skills needed for the design of effective remediation systems of contaminated sites, the design of groundwater utilization systems as well as to quantify the interaction between groundwater and underground infrastructures.

data.name: Letterature comparate III - LM
data.description: Through the close analysis of complex texts, students will learn to consider literature as a specific discursive regime that feeds on a continuous interchange with different languages ​​(psychology, history, philosophy, political theory). No content enters literature without being transformed. No content returns from literature to society without having proposed a new and unprecedented way of giving shape to one's own emotional and ideological frameworks. The student must be able to orient himself with ease in this crossroads of knowledge and styles of thought of which the theme under consideration is only one of the many possible examples. At the end of the course the student will be able to contextualize the texts as historical phenomena, read them with the critical and theoretical tools of the discipline, and orient themselves among texts relating to the different national literatures.

data.name: Diritto penale comparato
data.description:
The course concerns on the application of comparative methodology in criminal law referring both to civil law and common law systems. 
Particularly the course will focuses on the German criminal law, analysing the constitutional grounds and the fundamentals of the criminal law system and highlighting the most relevant differences between the Italian and German law.
The study of central topics in the present international scientific debate will be object of the course too. In particular, the course will take in account the role of the criminal law in the contemporary multicultural society and the so-called enemy criminal law, related to the fight against organised crime and international terrorism. 
At the end of the course, the student is supposed:
-	To critically analyse the criminal law models object of the course, aware of their relativity. 
-	To examine each studied branch of the German criminal law related to the different purposes of the comparative method (comprehension of the law system, study of the social function of the criminal law, evaluation of the possible practice applications).
-	To solve practical cases in relation both to the German and the Italian criminal code.

data.name: Lab. appl.: I rapporti tra Stato e Regioni nella giurisprudenza costituzionale
data.description: Provide the basics of Italian regionalism, after illustrating the federal and regional models, in particular in light of the judgments of the Constitutional Court relating to Title V, Part II of the Constitution.

data.name: Softwarized and Virtualized mobile networks

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The main objective of the course is to describe how softwarization will transform the mobile networks of the future. In the course, the major families of wireless networks in use (WLANs, Cellular Networks and Satellite Networks) will be described and the virtualization and softwarization techniques on such infrastructures will be then introduced. The architectural description of such systems will be aligned with the description of the major communication protocols in all the above architectures. By the end of the course, the student should be able to: 
1) know and design the main architectural components of WLANs, cellular networks and other wireless networks;
2) define new protocols and network paradigms to advance the state-of-the-art
3) understand the network virtualization techniques and be able to effectively use such concepts

data.name: Diritto processuale civile
data.description:
The course makes students able to understand how civil law applies in civil litigation. 
At the end of the course, students will be able to know which are the differences among procedural remedies, and to understand when and how they should be applied.

data.name: Fisiologia umana
data.description:
Obiettivo primario del corso è di portare lo studente a conoscere e saper descrivere i meccanismi attraverso i quali il corpo umano ottiene e mantiene l'omeostasi del suo mezzo interno a livello molecolare, cellulare e tissutale, nel contesto delle modificazioni dell'ambiente circostante. A tal scopo lo studente dovrà apprendere: 1) i principi di biofisica, nonché i meccanismi elettrofisiologici e funzionali, alla base dei sistemi di trasporto e comunicazione nelle membrane biologiche e della contrattilità; 2) i fondamenti neurobiologici e psicofisiologici relativi al comportamento e alle interazioni cognitive ed emotive fra il soggetto e l'ambiente; 3) i meccanismi e le interrelazioni di tutte le funzioni vegetative, analizzando il funzionamento integrato dei diversi organi e apparati al variare dei principali parametri fisiologici e nel corso delle attività motorie.
Infine, per quanto concerne i crediti di psicologia generale, lo studente dovrà acquisire le conoscenze di base su alcune funzioni cognitive che sono particolarmente rilevanti per la formazione medica, quali la memoria, l’apprendimento, il ragionamento, e la presa di decisione.

data.name: Infrastrutture viarie

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
The course is divided into four parts. In the first part (about 32 hours) the basics of highway geometry (horizontal and vertical alignement; cross section) design will be provided. In the second part (about 12 hours) will be provided the basics of Traffic Engineering needed to  evaluate the road circulation quality (measure of effectiveness – MoE - and Level of Service - LoS). The part n. 3 (about 8 hours) is on the typical issues f pavemnt engineering. the part n. 4 (about 8 hours) gives the fundamentals of railway and airport engineering. 

At the end of the course the Student will be able to:
-	calculate, on the basis of current guidelines and rules, the fundamental road elements: straights, circular curves, transit curves, ascending and descending stretches, vertical curves (crests and sags);
-	comprehend the meaning of main traffic variables (flow rate, speed and headway); the relationships between them and how they are used to evaluate traffic conditions on roads and intersections. The evaluation of traffic conditions is called “Level of Service evaluation”.
- design a Flexible pavement  using Empirical or semi-empirical methods (about 10  hours).

data.name: Quality and innovation engineering
data.description:
This course covers the scientific and engineering basics of (i) quality management, (ii) innovation management. Specifically, the course main topics are: quality management paradigms, ISO 9000 series of standards, quality awards, process management, basics of risk management, statistical inference, relaibility, innovation management. After completing the course, the student will be able to:

- understand, summarize and compare the main quality management paradigms;

- understand and summarize the ISO 9000 series of standards and the quality awards;

- understand, summarize and analyse the fundamentals of risk management;

- understand, summarize and analyse the fundamentals of process management;

- understand and summarize the fundamentals of statistical inference;

- understand and summarize the fundamentals of innovation management;

- understand and summarize the impact of innovation on sustainability.

data.name: Electronic materials and technologies
data.description:
The aim of the course is to present electronic devices and technologies commonly used for manufacturing devices, sensors and large scale integrated circuits of common use for industrial and ICT applications. The course also introduces software tools used in the development of electron devices, emphasizing both the technological and design aspects.

At the end of the course, the students are expected to be familiar with the terminology and the problems commonly found in the field of semiconductor device physics and technology. They should be able to qualitatively describe the working principle and fabrication process of the semiconductor devices studied within the course and to solve numerical problems on these topics.

They should also acquire a basic operative knowledge on the use of TCAD simulation tools, and develop the ability to use them to solve simple design problems.

data.name: Advanced analysis
data.description: Selected topics of Real and Functional Analysis and some their applications to partial differential equations (PDEs) will be introduced in the course. These topics will be applied, later,  in more advanced Analysis courses.

data.name: Circuiti ad alta frequenza per systems on chip

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: The course, after reviewing fundamentals and main issues of microwave design, will focus on the classical and mostly recently microwave design methodologies discussing capabilities, and limits of applications. Practical examples concerning real device commonly used for microwave systems will corroborate the theoretical concepts. In particular, the course provides the students with the methodologies necessary for the analysis and the design of complex microwave devices, starting from simple microwave devices like attenuators and filters up to complex active devices like microwave generators. This kind of knowledge is of great importance for telecommunication engineers involved in the development of telecommunication systems. All telecommunication products or systems require wired structures in order to work properly. In the course the basics concepts of the wired propagation and a working knowledge will be given. At the end of the course the student will be able to design and fabricate complex microwave device for low power as well as for high power. The didactic content of the course will be integrated with some software and experimental activities related to the study of electromagnetic propagation. Moreover, the standard microwave measurements methodologies will be explained.

data.name: Fundamentals of Artificial Intelligence

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
Artificial Intelligence (AI) is an umbrella term, covering a large and heterogeneous amount of disciplines. This course aims at providing an overview of the foundations of AI and of its main disciplines (e.g. problem solving, knowledge representation and reasoning, planning, uncertain knowledge, ...) in an organic way. Examples and exercises will be provided during the course.

The course consists also in a series of lab sessions, where student will be required to run simple exercises consisting in modeling and solving simple problems by means of AI tools, and to solve simple exercises by hand. 

At the end of the course, the student:
- will acquire a global vision of the main displines of Artificial Intelligence
- will acquire a knowledge of the main AI problems, and of the main modeling and solving techniques for such problems
- will be able to tackle simple modeling and solving exercises by means of AI tools

data.name: Global Civil Society

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
Notions of national civil society have a long history in political writings. Since the 1980s and the end of the Cold War, academic interest in popular involvement in political life and the ideas and development of a 'global civil society' has grown. This module will consider the historical origins of global civil society, diverse and competing contemporary meanings of global civil and ‘uncivil’ society, and what ‘global civil society’ might look like in terms of actors, the relationships among them, and notions of legitimacy and power. Case studies will allow students to further reflect on these issues and the relationship of global civil society in its different manifestations to global institutions, forces of globalization, states and individuals. Fundamental questions addressed concern how global civil society impacts global (and regional) governance.

Upon completion of this module students are expected to have acquired the following: 

1)	An understanding of different theoretical approaches to global civil society.
2)	Knowledge of a variety of global civil society campaigns.
3)	The ability to recognise how non-state global civil society actors exert power at different territorial levels and on different themes through their strategies.
4)	An understanding of critical views of global civil society.
5)	An overview of how global civil society, and scholarly work about global civil society, has evolved and changed over time.

In addition, students who successfully complete this module should gain the following transferable skills:

6)	The ability to learn independently and to assume responsibility for the learning process.
7)	Broad academic skills in the areas of critical reading and analysis, library and online research, note-taking and time management.
8)	Confidence in participating respectfully in class discussion and dialogue.
9)	Skills in written academic argument and confidence in crafting academic papers of an appropriate standard of written academic English.
10)	Understanding of issues relating to academic research – evaluating research sources, research methodologies, citation of research materials, management of materials and the avoidance of plagiarism and intellectual dishonesty.

data.name: Introduzione all'economia
data.description: The course aims to provide an introduction to economics as a scientific discipline, through the analysis of the main concepts and methods. By the end of the course, the student is expected to be familiar with the language of economics and the main methods and models used in this field. In addition, the student should be able to apply these methods and models to analyze situations that occur daily in a modern market economy and to critically consider the potential benefits, failures, and unwanted consequences of economic policies.

data.name: Diritto pubblico

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
The course aims to provide a critical assessment of the main features of Italian public law, with a focus on the institutional architecture. The programme includes the study of the distinctive features of the legal order, the analysis of the concept of “forma di stato”, the notion of Constitution and the ways to protect it (amending power and judicial review of legislation), the Italian institutional framework. The EU legal order will be also analysed, with particular attention to its interrelations with the Italian public legal order.
Students are expected:
1. to acquire legal vocabulary and be be able to use it properly;
2. to be able to find out legal materials such as bills or courts' decisions
3. to learn the basic categories of public and european law; to comprehend their context and their reciprocal interrelations
4. to acquire the ability to contestualise the main institutional actor, their functions and interrelations

data.name: Organizational Behaviour
Ecologia applicata

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description: Aim of the course is to explore Applied Ecology, the branch of Ecology that uses the principles and the concepts of Base ecology to predict and manage the environmental changes caused by human impact on natural ecosystems. Applied Ecology includes natural resource conservation, natural flora and fauna management, water resource management, pest management, pollution and ecotoxycology, natural landscape change, climate change and global warming. Applied ecology and biodiversity study are profoundly intertwined, both in the monitoring phases and in the management choices. The recent and far past clearly shows that technical and engineering choices cannot ignore environmental and ecological sustainability, to avoid the repetition of dramatic disasters like desertification of vast areas, river rectification, Vajont, Stava, Lambro and Danube poisoning, radioactive poisoning in north and south Germany, Tchernobyl and Fukushima, plastic and micro-plastic sea and soil pollution. All these disasters will result in huge costs in environmental, economical terms and they will often directly affect local population health condition. The major causes of the current important economic crisis are due to an environmental crisis that lead to a lack of resources exacerbated by human induced Climate change. This picture was generated by overexploitation and inefficiency in the use of natural resources, caused by the underestimation of the consequences of environmental problems to ecosystem services in an holistic vision. The course will deal with the environments in temperate and boreal climates and with the tropical and subtropical regions. The course will deal with theoretical fundamental elements and practical examples to understand Applied Ecology, giving hints about future developments of this science. Among the topics treated in the course: Ecocertification, biomonitoring, Biosensors, GIS, dynamic landscape modeling, definition of criteria for protected areas planning and management. Species distribution models and prediction of future landscape change with Markov Chains and Cellular automata will be treated. Seminars held by experts and visits to Applied Ecology offices will be organized. The students shall be able to apply Applied Ecology knowledge to understand the consequences of anthropic disturbance on environment and ecosystems. They shall be able to know monitoring field and modeling tools that can help the management of applied ecology. The students will be requested to write an original research paper treating and analyzing a specific topic in a critical perspective.

data.name: Economy and society

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
Students will get acquainted with the central concepts and related theories necessary for the understanding of economic and societal processes and their change, in a comparative perspective.

Students will also get the instruments to contribute to current “hot” topics in societal debates with a scientific contribution and get to know the relevant empirical research contributions to various substantive fields. They will familiarize with theory-driven empirical research on the treated topics, will learn how to define accurately macro and micro concepts and their linkages; obtain an understanding of causal mechanisms of social change; and will learn to critically discuss approaches and results of comparative social science research.
data.degreeProgram: Sociology and social research - Sociologia e ricerca sociale (LM)

data.name: Filosofia del diritto corso avanzato
data.description:
The course represents a logical-philosophical development of topics discussed in the basic courses (undergraduate) and dealing with legal studies, mostly applied in judicial context.

In particular, the issue of judicial reasoning will be analyzed as it is formed in the pleadings, in its components in law and in fact.

The course aims at providing students with a series of notions on the problems of argumentation, legal logic (formal and informal) possibly applicable to legal reasoning, procedural epistemology (s.c. legal syllogism and building by evidence).

At the same time, the course aims at developing a series of logical-argumentative abilities through the constant use of examples (real and fictitious), in the perspective of training skills and modelling a self-sufficient critical competence in analyzing philosophical and logical-linguistic issues related to the notion of truth.

data.name: Etnomusicologia
Machine learning

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The aim of the course is to provide knowledge of both theoretical and practical aspects of machine learning, and present the main techniques of machine learning and probabilistic reasoning.


At the end of the course, students will be able to:


- describe the main machine learning techniques, with their characteristics and limitations


- master probabilistic reasoning techniques


- model simple probabilistic scenarios with Bayesian Networks


- realize learning programs tailored to the specific problem to be addressed.

data.name: Organic and Biological Chemistry

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description: The general objective of the course is to provide the basic knowledge of the biochemistry of biological systems. At the end of the course the student will know the main classes of organic and biological molecules, the chemistry of biological processes, the fundamental metabolic pathways (carbohydrates, fatty acids, amino acids) and their regulation. Specific objectives are: 1) to define the principles of general and organic chemistry needed for the understanding of biological systems, 2) to illustrate properties and reactivity of the main classes of organic and biological molecules 3) to analyze protein folding and the main enzymatic properties 4) finally, to examine the main metabolic pathways and their regulation. At the end of the course students will master the basic concepts of biochemistry and enzymology, will be able to describe the properties of molecules of biological interest, will know the metabolism of the main classes of biomolecules.

data.name: Strumenti d'investimento e derivati
data.description:
The teaching aims to provide students with the investment instruments and bond derivatives available in the financial market.

Upon completion of the course, students will be able to: (1) know the main investment instruments and bond derivative securities available in the financial market, (2) appropriately use these instruments for investment and portfolio management strategies, including with Matlab software, (3) empirically analyse theoretical concepts with Matlab software.

data.name: Design methods for industrial engineering
data.description: The aim of this course is to give future engineers the basic criteria to plan and define the design step, as a part of the lifecycle of industrial products, by means of the methods for the design of components and assemblies, also considering functionality, reliability, manufacturing, assembly, verification, maintenance and recycling. After the course students will be able to exploit the most recent methodologies for data management and communication tools, specific design methods for creativity enhancement, performance evaluation, and Robust Design. They will properly approach the industrial design process, by means of the methods, which allow defining for each product shape, materials and production processes according to the required functionality.

data.name: Sensory quality of agri food products and consumer preference
data.description:
The aim of the course is to provide the student with advanced knowledge and the skills required to analyze the perceivable quality of agrifood products and interpret and predict consumer responses, with the aim to provide insights to Research, Quality Control, and Marketing teams to guide commercial development and communication strategies.


At the end of the course the student will be able to:

  • choose the most suitable sensory techniques to measure the sensory characteristics of the products and /or analyze and predict consumer responses according to the objective and product type;
  • plan and conduct a sensory analysis in compliance with good working practices, analyze the data collected and critically interpret the results;
  • present and discuss the results of sensory assessments and write an analysis report.

data.name: Statistica, probabilità e inferenza
data.description: The course intends to help students in becoming familiar with some statistical methods for the study and modelling of the association amongst qualitative and quantitative variables by following an approach focusing on the concepts and applications of the economic and social context. With the primary purpose of a good practice of Statistics, the use and interpretation of the method will be privileged with respect to the theoretical demonstrations and mathematical aspects. Therefore, the handling of real data will play an important role during the course. In order to conduct the analysis, the software R will be used.

data.name: Advanced Topics in the Economics of Technical Change
data.description:
The course will equip the students with theoretical frameworks and analytical tools
that are necessary to inform strategic decisions on the funding, management and
governance of innovation. The students will learn how to apply first principles to key
societal challenges (e.g. technology and unemployment; the environment and health)
whose origins or possible solutions involve technological change.

data.name: Advanced Academic Writing
data.description:
On completion of the course, the student will be able to:

Independently research, organize and write a clear, concise and cohesive academic text relating to economics, respecting academic conventions.

data.name: Sociologia della conoscenza

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
The course aims to provide students with basic theoretical and analytical elements of the sociology of knowledge. The course will provide students with the basic analytical and theoretical tools to analyse the costruction and the function of expert, practical, and common-sense systems of knowledge. The course is particularly focused on the sociology of scientific knowledge and on the social implications of the production and use of expert knowledge .
At the end of the course students are expected to:
- Be familiar with the main approaches in the sociology of knowledge
- Be able to critically discuss the different theoretical and analytical approaches
- Be able to employ these theoretical and analytical tools to analyse the use of expert knowledge in the practical social contexts 

ATTENTION: Lessons are held in Italian.

data.name: Fisiologia della cellula e degli organismi
data.description:
The course's objective is to provide basic knowledge on living organisms: evolution and diversity, anatomy and physiology. Students will follow a path that will allow them to understand the steps towards multicellularity and the integration of signals of intercellular communication.

They will be able to understand the organization of tissues and organs, their mechanisms and their integration in a system biology approach.

At the end of the course, the students will have learned:


- Basic knowledge on the organization and functioning of the cell

- Basic knowledge on the organization of multicellular organisms

- Intercellular Communication

- Physiology of organs and systems

- Check-points, homeostasis and diseases


The course aims to provide basic elements of cellular and molecular biology possibly to be studied in deeper details in other areas such as the "Molecular biology of the cell" (second semester). The part of physiology of organs and tissues is instead specifically addressed within this course.

Archeologia medievale III
data.description: The module aims to introduce students to the major themes of medieval archeology. At the end of the course it is expected that the student is able to understand the issues proposed,to frame materials and archaeological contexts presented during the course, to use an appropriate technical language.

data.name: Individuo e ambiente: strumenti di lettura

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description:
The main goal is to provide students with keys to understanding the complex relationships between individuals and social contexts that could be useful for future professional educators. The theoretical approach adopted is that of social psychology.


Specifically, the expected educational goals of attending lectures and of the individual study are:

  • Having a good knowledge of (a) social interactions with other people and within groups, with a specific focus on working groups; (b) social-psychological processes and motivations involved in self and social representations; (c) causes and consequences of prejudice and social exclusion.
  • Getting mastery of scientific language and theories in social psychology.
  • Linking theory and practice.
data.degreeProgram: Educazione professionale (abilitante alla professione sanitaria di Educatore professionale) (L2)

data.name: Storia del collezionismo
data.description: The course aims to outline the framework of the main Venetian collections of antique sculptures and paintings. At the end of the course students should know the historical context of Venice and the main Venetian collections of the 16th century, with particular regard to their founders and landmark works of art.

data.name: Istituzioni di diritto privato II
data.description: The course is the continuation of the study of Private Law Foundations begun in the first year. The purpose of the course is to provide students with understanding of notions and legal rules regarding the areas of property rights, family and succession law. Students should acquire knowledge not only of the rules governing such institutes, but also of the fundamental role of the jurisprudence and legal doctrine, as far as application of rules and legal solutions are concerned. Thus, students should develop the ability to critically analyze and verify the Law in action, even by studying concrete issues and cases which will be presented and discussed during the lectures. At the end of the course the students should have acquired the ability to explain the meaning of legal rules by interpreting them from an evolutionary perspective and within the context of the national legal system. The course is aimed not only at depicting the subject itself but also, and primarily, at providing the students with a correct method in order to enabling them to assign the proper meaning to legal rules. It will be essential to make explicit and direct reference to rules and general principles of the national legal system, but also to the sources of European and Transnational Law which, directly or indirectly, may deeply affect the institutes of Private Law analyzed during the course.

data.name: Meccanica dei fluidi

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
‎TRAINING OBJECTIVES‎

‎The aim of the course is to:‎

‎> provide the basic mathematical tools to express the principles of conservation of physics in Eulerian optics suitable for fluid mechanics;‎

‎> provide a qualitative and quantitative description of significant fluid mechanics problems;‎

‎> develop an engineering approach to the problems concerning fluid mechanics in the Civil and Environmental fields;‎


‎EXPECTED LEARNING OUTCOMES‎

‎At the end of the course the student is expected to have achieved the following results:‎

‎> knows and knows how to derive the integral and differential mathematical formulation of the principles of conservation in Eulerian form for fluid mechanics‎

‎>sapply apply the principles in full to notable cases;‎

‎>show to frame the topics proposed in the course starting from the qualitative and schematic description of the phenomenon, passing through the identification of the simplifying hypotheses and finally know how to elaborate the mathematical steps necessary to arrive at a quantitative description;‎

‎> knows how to set up and quantitatively solve engineering application problems related to hydraulic systems used in the field of Civil and Environmental Engineering.‎
data.degreeProgram: Ingegneria per l'ambiente e il territorio (L2)

data.name: Gestione integrata delle risorse idriche

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
The course aims to provide the students with techniques and mathematical tools used in the planning, design and management of water resources in the context of increasing anthropogenic pressure and climate change. The course will focus its attention on the hydraulic infrastructures present in river networks and on water supply systems.

At the end of the course the students will be able to: i) quantify the availability of water resources in river networks and aquifers, and ii) address and manage the problems related to the multiple and sustainable use of water resources. Furthermore, the student will learn techniques and methodologies for designing hydraulic works used in the integrated management of water resources.
data.degreeProgram: Ingegneria per l'ambiente e il territorio (LM)

data.name: Statistica per le decisioni economiche e il management
data.description:
Purpose of the course

The course aims to provide students with the acquisition of knowledge and skills for data analysis aimed at solving management problems and the construction of performance indicators on sustainable management of companies and organizations, with particular attention to those operating in the tourism and environmental sector.


Course expected results

The frequency and proactive participation at all the three educational activities (lectures, lab activities and multidisciplinary laboratory), combined with the self-study, will enable students to become familiar with the fundamentals of the statistical analysis and learn how to:

  • analyze situations described through large and complex databases as frequently happens in many multidimensional phenomena characterizing the environment and the territory;
  • understand and apply procedures aimed at the measurability of environmental, social and economic relevant aspects;
  • create synthesis of the available data by preserving the relevant part of the contained information and generate useful information for supporting operational and decision purposes;
  • classify statistical units (and variables) on the basis of their similarities and dissimilarities;
  • apply multivariate analysis techniques for the construction of economic and environmental indicators for level and performance;
  • understand, interpret and evaluate in a critical way the results and conclusions reached through the statistical analysis performed on the data.

In terms of soft skills, active participation in all the proposed training activities will enable the students to know how to organize a group work, apply problem solving techniques by arguing and by presenting the results achieved properly.
data.degreeProgram: Management della sostenibilità e del turismo (LM)

data.name: Laboratorio di progettazione sulle metodologie didattiche attive

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

In connection with the Dublin Descriptors, during the lectures and through group activities and individual

study, students will achieve the following learning outcomes:

Knowledge and understanding:

● describe the peculiarities of the proposed methodologies, tools and teaching strategies

data.degreeProgram: Scienze e Tecniche di Psicologia Cognitiva (L2)

data.name: Filosofia del linguaggio
data.description: The course of philosophy of language aims to offer a solid knowledge basis about the philosophical reflection on language and the linguistic faculty of human beings. It will take into consideration both the philosophers of language in the strict sense (whose production usually coincides with the 'linguistic turn' of the beginning of the twentieth century, or follows it), and the theses and reflections developed, even earlier, in the classic works of western thinking. The course intends to investigate  the semiotic and communicative functions of language on the one hand and, on the other, the links that the linguistic faculty shows with the cognitive sphere of humans. The theoretical connections between the philosophical reflection on natural language and related disciplines such as zoosemiotics and the philosophical study of artificial intelligence will also be considered, at least at an introductory level.

data.name: Polymeric materials engineering
data.description:
This revised version of the course Polymeric materials engineering [146017/1] is organized 6 credits, and it is Module-1 of the Course Polymeric and Composite Materials Engineering [146017].

The purpose of the course is for students to acquire knowledge and understand basic principles of polymer science and plastics engineering. In particular thermoplastic, elastomers and thermosetting polymeric materials, their properties, processing technologies and applications are examined.

An integral part of the course are the laboratory sessions which give students practical experience in plastics analysis. In each group, students have the opportunity to start learning team-working with practical experience, and to organize their activities in cooperative manner, following the indications of lab-assistant and the corrections of Lab-Reports .

Concerning the learning outcomes at the end of this course, students are expected to be able to:

-know and classify polymeric materials (thermoplastics, elastomers and thermosets);

-understand and evaluate their properties and the technologies of production;

-carry out the laboratory work in groups, starting from the understanding of laboratory activities, discussion of results, research data, up to the joint production of reports;

In summary, knowledge and skill in the purposed topics will help students to improve competence in the specific field of material engineering.

data.name: Storia moderna II
data.description:
The course aims to provide an introduction to the study of modern history (fifteenth to the eighteenth centuries) and to identify the central themes that link that period, in Europe and beyond, to the contemporary world.

General learning outcomes:
a) to identify the major events, persons and ideas of the early modern history.
b) build relationships and ties between them.
c) to grasp the elements of continuity and rupture of early modern history.
d) to recognize, distinguish, differentiate, compare the most important aspects of European and non-European civilizations.
e) to place an historical source in time and space describing its content, origins, and motivations.
f) to use a suitable historiographic lexicon.
g) to organize the knowledges and communicate them clearly and concisely in a written form.

data.name: Iconografia Teatrale
data.description: Aim of the course is 1) acquisition of the necessary skills to fully understand the theatrical events of the past, in order to be able to understand and evaluate them in a comparative geographical and historical context 2) acquire all the critical means necessary to analyse the contemporary stagings in all their elements, from acting to scenery. At the end of the course the student will be able to understand the proposed topics with the help of the didactic material; to put these events into their correct context; to employ the specific language appropriate to the subject

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description: The course aims at (a) providing basic elements to understand the economic-managerial processes involved in bringing an initial idea about a communication tool to its effective completion; (b) presenting some examples of start-up, spin-off or professional role in an organization. By the end of the course, students should have acquired: the ability to analyze profession-linked administrative-financial constraints (and possibilities); the ability to identify exemplars of good practices; the ability to apply their competences in simulative situations.
