data.name: Decision and risk analysis
data.description:
By means of the analytic tools discussed during the lectures, at the end of the course the student will:
1. be able to analyze decisions and choose the best course of action in complex contexts. Moreover, he will properly cope with decisions in uncertain environments, and with multiple objectives.
2. understand the basic notions of strategic behavior and will be able to transpose them into real-life contexts.
3. recognize various sources of risk and  take proper actions to manage it and possibly mitigate it.

data.name: Advanced Hands on fMRI Analysis

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description: Functional Magnetic Neuroimaging (fMRI) is a popular technique to study the human brain. Since its advent, the technique and its analyses have kept moving forward thus helping to better capture the complex organization of the brain and its functions. This course will introduce the students to advanced fMRI analyses such as multivariate pattern analysis, representational similarity analysis, pattern classification algorithms, and resting-state functional connectivity, with a particular focus on providing the students with extended hands-on experience on these forefront methods. By the end of this course, students will be able to apply cutting-edge analytic techniques to neuroimaging data.

data.name: Diritto di famiglia

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
The aim is to give students a general knowledge of the principles and institutions of private law,
focusing on the legal provisions which regulate the birth, life and end of legal relationships between
family members and to the legal protection of children and of vulnerable adults.
Consistent with the objectives of the degree programme in Social Work (i.e. attention to the principles
of justice and social inclusion, as well as the protection and promotion of rights, especially those
belonging to vulnerable groups), the course will focus on developing the ability to understand the
issues of private law and family law that may arise in social work and to use the knowledge acquired
to solve these issues.

Students are expected to acquire  knowledge and comprehension of the general principles and institutions of private law and family law.  Specific attention will be given to the development of the ability to understand and to solve the legal problems concerning families and children that can arise in social work and to master legal terminology.

data.name: Multisensory interactive systems

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description:
The overall goal of the module is to provide a theoretical and practical basis for the design, development, and evaluation of interactive systems, which are multisensory, tangible, and networked. Students on this module will have the opportunity to explore physical computing concepts, use real-time programming languages, understand the bases of human sensory perception, and design networked interactions in both co-located and remote settings.

On successful completion of this course, students should be able to: 
- Understand fundamental notions on electronic hardware such as micro controllers, single board computers, sensors, and actuators of different kind
- Develop interactive applications based on both embedded systems and desktop solutions, which take inputs from sensors and control a variety of physical and digital outputs
- Apply acquired knowledge on fundamentals of multisensory perception to the design of interactive systems
- Apply techniques for prototyping multisensory interactive systems as well as for their evaluation at both technical and user experience level


Students will apply knowledge and skills from above in completing a semester project in teams. Students will be provided with a large variety of hardware items and software tools, which will enable them to create prototypes of networked, tangible and interactive multisensory systems.

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.name: Network security

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The aim of the course is to present and make students understand the technological and infrastructural issues of  computer networks security. The course covers both the defensive aspects and attack aspects of network security. The course also covers a practical part, to give students the opportunity to immediately apply some acquired knowledge. The practical part covers also soft skill as the ability to communicate and present technical work to peers.
At the end of the training the student will know the main security technologies used for the protection of computer networks, the methods and technologies used to attack the networks and those used to defend them against such attacks. The student will also be able to experiment with many of these technologies and evaluate their complexity. Finally, the student will be able to present and replicate a laboratory exercise on security technologies to his/her peers

data.name: Data Mining

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description: This is a graduate level course on Data Mining. Data Mining is the science studying mathematical models, computational paradigms, algorithms and methodologies that look for patterns and regularities in large amounts of raw data. The aim is to allow us to understand natural phenomena, business operations and human behaviors, in ways that it will allow us to turn this knowledge into predictions, forecasting and performance improvements. The goal of the course is to introduce the students to the basic concepts, principles and techniques of Data Mining, to help them develop the required skills for using the state of the art data mining algorithms for solving practical problems, and to provide them with the required experience that will later allow them to operate independently, efficiently and effectively, in highly competitive markets. The course aims also to support students wishing to pursue a research carrier by teaching them the methodologies in performing independent and effective studies and research activities. The goals of the course will be achieved by teaching the students the strengths and limitations of the various data mining techniques, how they can be applied, under what conditions and what they should expect from each application. At the end of the course, the students will be finding themselves familiar with the most popular data mining concepts and will be able to identify and use the right solutions for any data analysis problem they may find themselves into. Last but not least, future data scientists will also learn how to perform the right experiments, how to interpret the results correctly and how to present them in the most effective way.

data.name: Tecnica delle costruzioni in c.a. e acciaio

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
The course aims to provide students with a basic knowledge of structural design applied to reinforced concrete structures and steel structures as established by the most up-to-date Italian and European codes for practical design. By applying and deepening the knowledge acquired in previous courses, with particular reference to the theory of elasticity and structural analysis courses, students are introduced to the design of the main structural components of framed reinforced concrete and steel systems.


By the end of the course, students are expected to have:

- acquired the capacity of modelling, designing and analyzing framed reinforced concrete and steel structural systems;

- capability to face basic problems of structural design;

- developed simplified tools for the design of reinforced concrete sections subjected to elementary states of stress;

- by the development of a design exercise, improved her/his autonomy in identifying, solving structural problems and selecting design solutions;

- acquired ability to present, in a clear and exhaustive way, the results of the design also by means of graphic tools and tables.

China and the World from the Cold War Years to the Global Era (1949-2020)
data.description: The course aims to provide students with the tools and knowledge needed for understanding China's international relations from the end of World War II to today. On completion of the module, students will acquire adequate knowledge of China's international history and worldview, the principles and aims of Chinese foreign policy and the role of state and non-state actors in the development of relations between China and the rest of the world in different historical periods. Moreover, they will be able to use both primary and secondary sources to understand and critically interpret key questions in China's international strategy and global role and to discuss with other students and the teacher the topics of the course.

data.name: Diritto comparato della privacy
data.description: The course will provide students with some basic concepts on the evolution of the right to privacy and to personal data protection. The teachers will deal with the subject through the methodology of comparative law, adopting an interdisciplinary analysis of the evolution of privacy and a “law and technology” approach. At the end of the course, student will be able to analyse concrete cases relating to privacy issues and to compare the different solutions that different systems would give to the same problem.

data.name: Energie rinnovabili

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description: The aim of the course consists in providing the engineering skills required in the design of energy plants and systems including renewable energies as a primary source. In particular, the methodologies currently utilized for the design of solar thermal systems and solar cooling, photovoltaic systems, heat pumps with particular regard to geothermal plants and the technologies used for the thermal exploitation of biomass will be proposed and investigated. The expected result of the course consists in providing to the student a basic background to be able to analyse the engineering problems pertaining to the design and integration of the proposed renewable energies technologies with traditional ones, also including an economic analysis for the evaluation of the main parameters inherent the profitability of the proposed energy systems.

data.name: Relatività
data.description:
The course involves a careful and comprehensive study of the theory of special relativity, with an introduction to the principles and methods of the general theory, including Einstein's field equations of the gravitational field. The theory is introduced in axiomatic form and the main results deduced by mathematical reasoning, as Einstein did. The physical explanations and motivations will be presented throughout. The main objectives are:
(a) to develop and train the critical thinking
(b) to be able to formulate and use relativistic equations
(c) to learn the principal elements characterizing the General Theory of Relativity. 

The expectations are:
(a) to be able to deduce consequences from the axioms, and to develop some capacity to write down relativistic field equations
(b) to be able to apply the equation to specific problems
(c) to achieve the full understanding of the four dimensional formulation of the theory
(d) to be able to make approximations to otherwise complicated equations.

data.name: Law, economics and digital policy
data.description:
Intellectual property (IP) and competition policy issues are increasingly relevant to undertakings, especially to those facing dynamic markets in an international environment. The course aims at providing students with solid theoretical and practical foundations in dealing with the legal facets of managing innovation. Both intellectual property law and competition policy can be said to pursue, by different means, the same primary aim of stimulating the innovation process. On the one hand, by allowing innovators to appropriate the results of their investments, incentives are created to take risks and engage in innovation activities. Competitive markets, on the other hand, allow for new products and services to emerge and be tested by consumers and/or other undertakings. However, as long as intellectual property rights (IPRs), like in particular patents and copyrights, are considered plain monopolies, there is arguably an inherent tension between the two above mentioned legal fields, in particular where such monopoly rights granted to creators and inventors stifle growth because of poorly designed “incentives” rules. 
In this vein, it is especially the role of IPRs as tools to motivate firms to invest in innovation activities that has been seriously questioned in the last two decades. The case for further and general strengthening of IPRs appears weak, and it is increasingly understood that a new balance needs to be struck between rewarding risk-takers and diffusing new knowledge. This course examines the interface between intellectual property and competition law, looking in particular at how competition law is already affecting intellectual property. Moreover, the course is aimed at analyzing the peculiarities of the legal management of the intellectual assets of firms acting in different economic sectors (e.g., fashion industry, information and communication technology markets, pharmaceutical industry). 
On completing this course, students will be able to: 
a) clearly identify those contexts in which innovation management decisions are influenced by intellectual property law and competition policy considerations
b) explain, in an interdisciplinary way, the core principles of intellectual property and competition law 
c) employ general analysis skills helping them to identify crucial issues and therefore to ask the right questions in the management and expansion of the firm's intellectual (property) assets
d) understand and follow international trends in the area of IPRs and competition policy especially relevant to dynamic industries (e.g., so called “search bias” as investigated by competition authorities on both sides of the Atlantic and its possible meaning and effects for other undertakings active in markets affected by such practices).

data.name: Sociology of collective action

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
Students will:

  1. become familiar with the basic tenets of the dominant theoretical models for the study of collective action;
  2. develop the ability to assess strengths and weaknesses of each approach
  3. develop the ability to apply concepts and theoretical models to the explanation/interpretation of specific dynamics of collective actions.
  4. enhance the ability to connect the theories presented with empirical research through the in-depth study of a number of empirical studies. These will be based on the use of various empirical research methods and techniques, including public opinion surveys, protest-event-analysis (PEA) and social network analysis (SNA).
  5. acquire some skills to formulate research questions, develop a literature review, and understand appropriate methods to be able to examine phenomena related to collective action. This course, supplemented with appropriate methodological knowledge, enables students to initiate qualitative or quantitative empirical research in the field of collective action

data.name: Storia del pensiero economico
data.description:
The evolution of economic thought, similar to that of other disciplines, does not follow a linear path, characterized by the progressive solution and "archiving" of the problems faced. On the contrary, if we analyze the roots of the various and different approaches to economic theory between the middle of the last century and the present era (i.e. the evolution of the contemporary debate), we often come across concepts and problems that were at the attention of economics scholars hundreds of years ago. Similarly to what happens in other scientific fields - for example in the field of astronomy - the ability to observe reality and to process and interpret the data collected gradually increases; however there is a different trait - which is instead common to all the social sciences - given by the progressive change of the reality under study. In other words, we are not faced with an "immutable" reality, whose behavior follows laws that scientific research allows us to understand "better" (whatever the epistemological meaning of this expression), but an economic and social system whose characteristics change over time. But the problems reappear and concepts that were considered to have already been sufficiently elaborated recursively return to the center of the analysis. The production and distribution of income, economic development, the role of money - to mention some of the main problems - require increasingly sophisticated analyzes, which however have their roots in theoretical elaborations even very far in time. Hence the importance, even for those immersed in contemporary debates, of knowing the ways and forms in which these problems have presented themselves and have been addressed in the past, developing concepts that are still at the center of theoretical reflection.

The course therefore aims to provide students with a logical structure to frame the evolution of economic thought and the development of the most important theories, up to the threshold of contemporary debate. Its goal is to enable the student to:


a) Learn about the evolution of the economic thought, within the framework of the evolving historical facts
b) Recognize the main schools of thought and identify their critical issues and points
c) Recognize the specific origins and frameworks of the contemporary economic theories 
d) Assess the appropriateness of a given analytical framework with respect to the problems analyzed by the economist

data.name: Proteomics and Protein characterization

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description: The main objective of the course is to provide the knowledge necessary to use modern technological platforms for the characterization of proteins, protein complexes and complex proteomes. At the end of the course, the student will be able to: 1. Understand the principles underlying the expression, purification and characterization of proteins. 2. Discuss the importance of using mass spectrometry in the study of proteins in complex biological samples, explaining their potential and limitations. 3. Critically choose the proteomic approach for the qualitative and quantitative analysis that is best suited to answer the scientific question of interest. 4. Evaluate the appropriate method for sample preparation considering compatibility with mass spectrometry analyses, as well as the purpose of the experiment. 5. Understand the principle of operation of the main components of the mass spectrometer, optimizing the parameters that determine its performance. 6. Read mass spectra (e.g., de novo sequencing) and understand the logic of complex dataset analyses via software. 7. Consult online databases and use the most common software for processing experimental data. 8. Interpret, process and present experimental results. 9. Understand the principles behind X-ray crystallography for the structural analysis of proteins and protein complexes. 10. Read and understand scientific articles in the field of protein analysis.

data.name: Matematica finanziaria
data.description:
Course Objectives and Expected Learning Outcomes
The aim of the course is to introduce quantitative models and methods used to evaluate financial instruments, yields structure, and fair prices of fixed income securities.
Reference is made to risk management investment models (financial immunization),  followed by fundamental concepts on financial derivatives (if time permits).
At the end of the course the student will be able to carry out basic evaluations of financial instruments, compare the bond market prices, and to deal with choice problems in finance .
The course intends to stimulate the financial awareness and critical analysis skills required in an employee in the financial sector.

data.name: Lab. appl.: Dalla ricerca bibliografica alla stesura del testo: linee guida per la redazione di una tesi di laurea

The course aims to develop the following skills:

  • undertake bibliographic search using the library's print and electronic resources;
  • identify and locate library services and resources; 
  • use search strategies appropriate to the tool used;
  • recognize the essential elements of a citation and different citation styles;
  • write a correct bibliography.

data.name: Neurologia clinica

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description:
The teaching course aims to provide to the student knowledge on anatomy and physiology of the central nervous system, on main degenerative disorders affecting central nervous system and the correlation with the cognitive disorders which represents the clinical pictures of greatest interest for the psychologist.
The aim is to acquire knowledge on the different clinical presentations of the neurological disorders and the impact of the related cognitive disorders 
At the end of the course the students will be able to formulate a diagnostic orientation based on clinical data and possibly a prognosis of a neurological clinical picture.

data.name: Storia medievale II
Sociologia della famiglia

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
The aim of this course is that students will acquire knowlede and understanding of the changes in families in Italy and Europe, their causes and consequences. 
the course is composed of two main parts, a general (covering about 60% of the course) one presenting concepts and theories, and a more specific (for the remaining 40%) one treating some specific related topics of current societal relevance, privileging and interdisciplinary and international prospective. 
The participants will acquire knowledeg of the basic concepts of this themaic and research area, some of the major theories dealing with the family and its changes in international context. At the end of the course students will be aware of the current international research on the family and demographic changes, and able to critically discuss their findings. 
Moreover, the course will provide the occasion for students to further develop their basic research competences, among them: bibliographic work, selecting and managmento of relevant international literature, presentation of adequate data to describe and to correctly interpret social phenomena regarding the family and demographic aspects, selection of a topic, definition of a small research question, writing a course paper with autonomous literature review, presentation in class and discussion of findings. Finally, there will also be occasions to familarize with the basic ethical principles of (social science) research and the honor code.

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.name: Sociologia della religione

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
Like all cultural phenomena, even the religious one tends to be unproblematized and to be summarized in the evidence that materializes before our eyes. In reality, religious phenomena have a founding and structuring role, that is, they are sources of normative action that changes the face of entire societies. The main purpose of the course is precisely to acquire such awareness.
For these reasons the course is divided into two parts.
The first aims to provide the constitutive elements of religiously oriented action.
In this, Weber's analysis of religious action will be treated. In the second part, of monographic orientation, the position and functions of Catholicism in the Italian context will be analyzed.

data.name: Diritto internazionale
data.description:
The course aims at providing students with the knowledge of the main characteristics and basic principles of the international legal order. At the end of the course, the students:

- will be able to understand and assess critically the complex relationships between the subjects of the international legal order

- will be able to analyse, interpret and apply international legal norms

- will acquire knowledge of the fundamental institutions, principles and rules of the international legal order, including those pertaining to specific sectors

- will be able to assess the legal consequences deriving from the breach of international law

- will acquire knowledge of the most important mechanisms to assess and enforce international law

- will understand the relationship between the international and domestic legal frameworks

data.name: Short cycle breeding and innovative techniques to improve product quality
data.description:
The aim of the course is to provide students with scientific and technical knowledge regarding the most innovative approaches in short-cycle breeding and aquaculture, for the improvement of animal welfare and nutritional and organoleptic-sensory quality of products. The course aims to provide knowledge on animal management, as well as advanced techniques and technologies, which make the entire supply chain more competitive. In addition, the topic of animal nutrition will be addressed, being one of the key points to obtain quality products. 
At the end of the course, the student will be able to design short-cycle breeding and aquaculture with traditional species and newer introduction, with particular attention to the alpine mountain environment. In addition, the student acquires the basic knowledge on the requirements and nutrition of the main species bred (fish, poultry and rabbit) and to assess in particolar the effect of nutrition on the quality of animal products.

data.name: Lingua e cultura cinese II
data.description: The course aims at consolidating the knowledge of Chinese language and culture. By the end of the course the students will have acquired knowledge of Chinese language at the intermediate level (A2/B1) and will be able to read and comprehend 600 words, read and translate Chinese texts at the intermediate level, carry out simple conversations in Chinese and translate sentences at the same level from Italian to Chinese. Besides, they will have acquired: a) general knowledge of the history of the People's Republic of China and the process that brought the country towards becoming a global superpower; b) knowledge of the main political, social and cultural institutions and the transformations resulting from China's modernization process in the last 40 years c) ability to critically discuss issues related to China's contemporary history, d) ability to apply knowledge through practical activities foreseen during the lectures, such as participation in working groups and classroom debates.

data.name: Neuroscienze cognitive

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description: Cognitive neurosciences constitute a recent, wide and rapidly evolving research field. They aim to shed light on the neurofunctional mechanisms of cognition, determining in which ways the cognitive capacities of humans and other animals emerge from brain structure and function. They offer biologically based perspectives to the study of cognitive processes, which build on the detailed knowledge of theories and methods in cognitive and experimental psychology, as well as general competences in the domain of brain anatomy and function and in the techniques used for brain imaging and stimulation.. The teaching aim is to promote in students the ability to recognize and understand neuroscientific interpretations of behavior, generate arguments based on valid neuroscientific bases, and acquire relevant competences to establish to what extent conclusions are supported by empirical evidence. At the end of the course students should have learned to (1) elaborate and explore further the concepts discussed during the course, supporting their arguments with reference to specific empirical studies; (2) infer the methodology and/or the theoretical paradigms from research articles; (3) deal with the complexity of the discipline avoiding generic statements.

data.name: Storia moderna II - LM
data.description:
The course aims at:


a) to recognize the concept of "people" in the most recent historical, sociological, political science research;


b) to understand the multiple aspects of the concept of "people" between the Early modern and the Modern age.


c) to acquire an accurate knowledge of European political history between the nineteenth and twentieth century;


d) to examine the different influences, factors and forces that shape the concept of "people";


e) to locate the concept of people in relation to other ideological concepts, such as nation, race and ethnicity.


f) to compare the differences that affect the concept of people in and outside the Western world;


g) to handle differente research situations according to different methodologies;


h) to be able to hold an accurate presentation of a paper/source on the topics covered in the course.

data.name: Bioinks and 3D printing
data.description:
Instructional goals: 

The course aims at developing knowledge about: 

- properties and formulation of (bio)materials for additive manufacturing;

- bioinks requirements for 3D printing;

- rheology of bioinks and viscoelastic properties of printed objects;

- use of 3D printers to design and fabricate devices for biomedical applications.


ILOs:

Regular and active participation and independent research activities will enable students to: 

1) Understand physico-chemical and biocompatibility properties of bioinks;

2) Understand rheological and viscoelastic properties of hydrogels, with reference to 3D printing, for tissue engineering and regenerative medicine;

3) Understand design criteria and requirements to formulate bioinks for 3D printing;

4) Knowledge of 3D printing and additive manufacturing principles;

5) Knowledge of existing biomedical products;

6) Design a 3D CAD model for 3D printing;

7) Evaluate and identify issues with printing while using viscous bioinks;

8) Understand, evaluate and identify issues with printing to match design criteria and product requirements;

9) Explain and analyze existing 3D printed technologies in the context of their field of applications (e.g. 3D scaffolds, organ-on-a-chip, perfusion systems)

10) Ability to work independently and as part of a group to design and develop a 3D printed hydrogel scaffold.
data.degreeProgram: Materials and production Engineering - Ingegneria dei materiali e della produzione (LM)

data.name: Business and Consumer Transactions
data.description:
The goal of the course is to provide students with an in-depth knowledge of the meaning and relevance of the great divide between business and consumer contracts. Exploring the contents of the two halves of contract law allows students to grasp the most significant developments taking place in this branch of private law. These developments are driven by three factors: new business models and new markets, new technologies, and new meanings of contractual justice. While the first two factors are external to contract law, the third one reflects dynamics taking place within the legal domain. All the three factors affect both domestic and international transactions. The course will discuss the rules applying to business and consumer contracts in each stage of the contractual lifecycle: drafting and negotiation, formation, performance, non-performance, and conflict management. Examples from EU law, national contract law, the UN Convention on the International Sale of Mobile Goods and the Unidroit Principles on International Commercial Contracts will be provided. 
By the end of the course, students will be able to: 
-	Understand the organizing principles for business and consumer contracts
-	Understand the differences between business and consumer contracts
-	Read and interpret the main contract terms for business and consumer contracts
-	Deal with the international dimension of business and consumer contracts
-	Apply their knowledge to new cases involving disputes on business and consumer contracts.

data.name: Introduction to Computer Programming (Matlab)
data.description:
This course is designed to teach you the fundamentals of programming using Matlab. The course will cover: variables, arrays, functions, conditional (if) statements, loops (for), user input (keyboard, mouse) as well as basic graphics and audio presentation. The course will emphasise the skills needed for the cognitive scientist and instruction will focus on developing experimental paradigms (using Psychtoolbox) and will also cover coding for data processing, analysis and visualisation. 

By the end of the course, students should have learned the fundamental concepts of coding, developed a range of skills useful for the cognitive scientist, and reached a point where they can further develop their coding repertoire independently.

data.name: Research methodology - qualitative

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description:
This course will introduce you to the basic tools and concepts of qualitative research. In class we will focus on three qualitative research methods commonly used in HCI: observation (in-person and virtual), interviews and focus groups.

During the lectures and through the individual study, students should achieve the following training results:
1. Learn the methods of qualitative research by reading, discussing and analysing the existing literature and experiencing first hand the use of a specific research technique.
2. Develop the necessary competences that will guide them in the proper use of a specific research technique given a particular research question. Moreover, they will also learn how to evaluate researchers' submissions based on the elements they submit.
3. Learn to use observation, interviews and focus groups, understanding how the choice of each of these techniques can help them explore a topic or a research question of their choice.

In addition, along with other courses, this course should contribute to consolidating learning skills, judgment autonomy and communicative skills.

Learning Objectives

Introduce the students to Security Testing principles, techniques and tools

Make students familiar with fundamental principles of security testing, and provide them basic knowledge and understanding of existing methods, techniques and tools

  •  How to apply security testing methods and techniques
  •  State-of-the-art of existing tools
  •  How to detect vulnerabilities in software projects

Highlights

Security testing: Attacks models and taxonomy

Software vulnerabilities

Vulnerability detection

·       Static analysis

·       Dynamic analysis

·       Machine-learning methods


Expected learning outcome

The student will be able to identify and detect in large systems the most frequent software vulnerabilities by applying existing solutions and tools

data.name: Processi di trasporto nell'ambiente

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
The course aims at providing the fundamental concepts to understand the processes of transport of mass and energy in the environment (in water bodies like rivers and lakes, in the atmosphere, etc.) and their mathematical modelling. The final goal is to acquire competences to study problems related with the quality of water (e.g., pollution, eutrophication) and air.

 

At the end of the course, the student will be able to:

• understand the theoretical aspects of transport mechanisms in the environment;

• evaluate the mixing capacity of a water body and the rate of contaminant dilution;

• interpret these processes by means of simplified analytical solutions;

• critically select numerical models to study complex problems related to water or air quality.

data.name: Applied Cryptography

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
By the end of the course, you should be able to understand the theoretical and practical problems of using cryptographic techniques.


The content of this course is not purely mathematical, you will be introduced to more pragmatic considerations that need to be considered when applying cryptography in real use case scenarios that includes

  • how to identify and understand threats to fundamental security properties (confidentiality, integrity, and availability) when applying cryptography and
  • which cryptographic techniques are useful to preserve each one of the basic security properties.

data.name: Simulation and performance evaluation

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
Through lectures, homeworks, and the development of a final project, at the end of this course the student will be able to:
- correctly set up the characterization of a system through simulations, avoiding the most typical pitfalls
- structure the elements of a simulator
- empirically analyze a dataset, also using confidence and prediction intervals
- fit statistical models to data
- carry out and analyze the outcome of Monte-Carlo simulations
- build and employ discrete-time simulators
- analyze recent topics in the field of complex system simulation

data.name: Finanza aziendale progredito
data.description:
1. Learning objectives and course contents.
The purpose of the course is to provide students with an advanced understanding of the corporate investment and financing decisions. 
The first part focuses on the assessment of investments with leverage and enterprise value, with various approaches (the weighted average cost of capital method, the adjusted present value method and the flow-to-equity discounted cash flow method, multiples approach). The second part introduces the payout policy, in perfect market and in the presence of frictions. The third part analyses the typical sources of capital for corporation, in term of both equity and debt (bonds, leasing), with a medium/ long-term perspective. The fourth part introduces mergers and acquisition. The fifth part concerns finance for SMEs

2. Expected learning outcomes.

1. to describe the methods of evaluation of investment with leverage and to list the steps in computing each (define the input variables and describe how to compute their value; illustrate how the variables are used in the model; define and understand the output of the model);2. to understand and discuss the critical issues of each methods of evaluation (given the specific investment’s risk and leverage assumptions) and to identify the most suitable method of evaluation; to apply the methods of evaluation to examples / real cases;
3. to discuss the effect of dividend payment or share repurchase in a perfect capital market; to discuss the effect of taxes on dividend policy; to describe and discuss the effect of agency costs and information asymmetry on payout policy; 4. to describe the ways in which a private company can raise outside capital; to describe the bond indenture; to compare and discuss callable and convertible bonds with straight debt; 5. to identify the sources of synergies that are commonly cited as justification given for an acquisition; to discuss the premium; to calculate and discuss the maximum exchange ratio;6. to identify why and how SMEs are different from large companies in the financial decisions and to adapt to them the financing approaches.

data.name: Valutazione delle politiche contro la criminalità (corso libero)
data.description: The course presents and describes the tools for evaluating policies against crime, an area in which criminology meets law. The aim is to make students acquire the elements to understand if and how crime prevention and fight policies work and how it is possible to make them more effective and efficient. The course, after introducing the theories and approaches to evaluate policies, offers the opportunity to think about how and why policies work or don't work through specific case studies. Participants will acquire the most appropriate methods and indicators for evaluating the impact, costs and benefits of crime fighting / prevention policies.

Providing students with in-depth knowledge on machines and plants operation for the production, storage and transformation of agri-food products, and on design and selective criteria with attention to the most innovative aspects.

To acquire knowledge about the physical processes involved and the principles of sensors, control systems and data analysis in particular in the application for the production, storage and transformation of agri-food products.


Students will have a complete view of the problems of rural area, plants and project management.

data.name: Numerical methods for PDEs
data.description:
This course covers the theory of the finite element method for the 
approximation of the solution of partial differential equations.
The methods studied will be implemented in the laboratory using Matlab and 
FreeFem.
The learning outcomes include the understanding of the main features of 
the finite elements method for the approximation of the solution of elliptic 
and parabolic partial differential equations, and its theoretical properties. 
Having attended the course, the students will be familiar with the technical 
terminologies and concepts of the subject, and will have a good grasp of how
to implement the methods in practice.

data.name: Digital signal processing
data.description:
This course provides an introduction to fundamental concepts and techniques in digital signal processing. The course starts with a detailed explanation of discrete-time signals/systems and with the analysis of discrete time linear time invariant systems. Subsequently, the discrete-time Fourier transform and the discrete Fourier transform are introduced, followed by an overview of fast algorithms for the computation of the discrete Fourier transform. Afterwards, the z-transform and its properties are introduced. Finally, the design of FIR and IIR filters is introduced. 
The Lab lectures by using MATLAB are given to provide practical knowledge in processing real signals with examples from speech and audio.

data.name: Gestione delle risorse umane
data.description:
The goal of the course consists of highlighting the characteristics of the different organizational and human resource management systems in comparative perspective at the international level in relation to the role exerted by institutions and actors (companies, unions, workforce). Additional analyses will be devoted to small firms, given their specific characteristics, to the deployment of atypical work and to the development of lasting cooperative employment relations.


At the end of the course, students will be able to:


-Recognize the advantages and disadvantages of different organization and human resource management systems;

-Identify the relevance of institutions and actors for human resource magement in different economic sectors;

-Understand the specificities of small enterprises;

-Analyse the interactions among factors contributing to limit the deployment of atypical work;

-Develop the elements favouring the realization of long-term collaborative employment relations within organizations.

data.name: Epidemiologia e prevenzione
data.description: The physician's training must include knowledge of public health related to epidemiology and prevention of diseases with the highest social impact, particularly regarding those preventable with vaccinations (VPD) and the non communicable diseases (cardiovascular and tumoral) , the prevention strategies and the global health and health promotion. At the end of the course, the student must know the meaning of the health indicators; the general Italian and international health situation. The student must know the fundamental concepts of prophylaxis of infectious diseases (with particular regard to epidemics) and the prevention of non communicable diseases, the most important determinants of health and disease (risk factors), have general notions of health-environment relationship and hospital hygiene. The student must have clear the role that public health plays at the different institutional levels for the improvement of the health status of populations.

data.name: Diritto penale internazionale
data.description:
The course aims at providing a theoretical framework of International Criminal Law and International Criminal Justice. To this end, students will examine not only the Statute and the jurisprudence of the International Criminal Court (ICC), but also the most significative decisions related to International crimes and rendered by national courts or in the context of regional jurisdictions, ad hoc tribunals and hybrid tribunals.
The student shall be able to have a wider vision, which does not ignore pluralism of mechanisms and the importance of the legal, historical and political context in which a decision is rendered.

data.name: Storia d'Europa
data.description:
This course will critically explore old and new approaches to the history of the phenomena of globalization from the late eighteenth to the early twentieth century. In the first part, the course will examine the stages of colonial conquest, the relations between nation-states and empires, the contrasts, the interference but also the processes of imitation and adaptation which were created in the encounter between European and non-European societies during the 'long nineteenth century'. In the second - more monographic - part, the lectures will be focused on the history of the Russian empire, the most important and durable non-european empire that ever subsisted in the modern age. In particular, will be addressed the questions related to the conflicts with the European powers till the revolution and the final dissolution due to the revolution and the First World War.

This course aims to:


a) develop a solid knowledge and understanding of the main events of European and extra-European modern history;

b) learn to use the conceptual tools of "world / global history" and of the "connected history";

c) identify the various phases of European imperial expansion during the Eighteenth and the Nineteenth century;

d) understand the effect of the colonial expansion

e) compare societies, institutions, economic systems of Western and "Asian" empires (Russian and Ottoman, in particular);

f) know the history of the Russian empire from the modern age to the nineteenth century; the causes of its expansion in the Asiatic regions and the outbreak of the revolution;

g) know the salient aspects of the Russian polity and society;

h) know the effects of the peace treaties that led to the dissolution of the Russian empire.

data.name: Laboratory of Advanced Electronics
data.description:
Digital signal processing (DSP) makes up the key topic of modern electronics. Its applications are widespread in fundamental research in experimental physics as well as in a great number of other scientific and technological contexts. DSP is carried out by means of codes running on standard CPUs or, much more efficiently, implemented on programmable logic devices.
The course (56 hours) is devoted to both theory (24 hours) and laboratory practice (32 hours) on advanced topics in modern electronics: signal sampling, digital simulation of a linear, time-invariant physical system by means of a digital system, field-programmable gate arrays (FPGAs). A particular attention is devoted to the application of these techniques to the practice of experimental physics.
At the end of the course, students are expected to master the basics of the topics described above and to use them to implement control systems and real-time processing units by using programmable logic devices.

data.name: Tecnica urbanistica con Laboratorio Progettuale

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
At the end of the course, students will be able to:

  • set up the knowledge base to support urban planning decisions;
  • develop urban and territorial analyses using data and information from different sources through appropriate methods and tools for their collection, elaboration, synthesis, and representation;
  • decipher planning documents at different scales, understanding their development process, structure, and main contents;
  • understand in details the contents of an urban plan (municipal level), including textual documents, cartography, and regulations.
  • prepare new development plans on the basis of city plan's regulations and provisions.
  • acquire a basis of GIS software for spatial analysis
  • Acquire knowledge with reference to sustainable development, resilience and ecological planning to face contemporary challenges.

data.name: Corso di italiano B1a - I periodo (estensivo)
Low-power wireless networking for the Internet of Things

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The vision fostered by the Internet of Things (IoT) rests on the ability to establish untethered and opportunistic communication among devices deployed in the environment or attached to people or other moving entities. Therefore, low-power wireless communication technologies, which remove altogether the need for wires, are a key enabler of IoT. The last few years witnessed a surge of these technologies, striking different tradeoffs in terms of range, data rate, power consumption as well as additional capabilities like distance
estimation. These technologies enable a plethora of applications, e.g., monitoring and control of physical phenomena (wireless sensor networks) or smart environments where users are automatically localized and able to
opportunistically interact with objects.

The course aims at providing students with a first-hand introduction to this exciting field; this is achieved through a synergy of theory and practice.

Traditional classroom lectures will concisely present the salient aspects of several low-power wireless technologies, with an emphasis on wireless sensor networks (a key enabler of many IoT scenarios) and focusing primarily on the networking stack. Instead, laboratory sessions will be the opportunity for students to experiment "hands-on" with some of the technologies illustrated in the lectures, and understand their peculiarity.

By the end of the course, students are expected to have obtained a broad understanding of the key challenges in low-power wireless networking for the IoT, of the state-of-the-art solutions and associated trade-offs, as well as to have acquired the ability to autonomously design relatively simple IoT system components and applications on popular hw/sw platforms.

data.name: Cultura e letteratura russa
data.description: At the end of the course the student will have to know the main moments in the history of modern Russian culture and literature. The student must also have acquired the fundamental notions and basic methodological tools for understanding and studying Russian civilization .

data.name: Experimental Physics Laboratory at High School Level I
data.description:
This course aims to provide an introduction to the fundamental concepts of Physics Education Research and to the design of experimental activities for teaching physics.

The course also aims to discuss the basic theory of measurement and error and examine the main features of the Laboratory instruments.


Some experimental activities will be presented from an educational point of view and some case studies will be considered by adopting both traditional laboratory equipment and new technologies applied to the laboratory of physics.

Experimental activities will be performed directly by students working in small groups.


At the end of the course, the student will be able to

1) autonomously design experiments

2) Perform experiments using appropriately the equipment of the physics lab

3) Analyze experimental data using the theory of measurement and error


Ultimately the course aims to prepare students as future teachers of experimental physics courses by introducing them to experimental techniques, teaching methodologies and the design of didactic experiments.

data.name: Tedesco giuridico B1
data.description:
Obiettivi generali
Il corso di tedesco giuridico si propone di far acquisire una padronanza della lingua giuridica tedesca di base, sia scritta che orale (a livello ricettivo e produttivo) con l’obiettivo principale di permettere agli studenti di comprendere e usare in maniera semplificata ma autentica varie tipologie di testi giuridici. 
Obiettivi specifici 
Priorità degli obiettivi linguistici specifici a livello ricettivo (orale):
- comprensione di brevi sequenze video, tratte da trasmissioni in lingua tedesca che trattano argomenti di carattere giuridico. 
A livello ricettivo (scritto) scritto:
 - comprensione di comunicati stampa e testi divulgativi su argomenti di politica e attualità in ambito giuridico.
- comprensione di documenti autentici, scritti e orali, distinguendo tra generi e tipologie testuali, relativi all’ambito giuridico.
- conoscenza base dell’ordinamento giuridico dei paesi germanofoni.

Priorità degli obiettivi linguistici specifici a livello produttivo (scritto e orale) :
- redigere testi di 130-150 parole, riformulando su traccia, argomenti giuridici specifici. 
- esprimersi oralmente su tematiche giuridiche, presentando propri report, relativi agli argomenti trattati durante il corso.
Strutturato in 40 ore accademiche, il corso pone l'attenzione sul contesto situazionale attuale tarato ad hoc mediante l’utilizzo di materiali autentici e strumenti audio e video, a cui gli studenti possono accedere anche autonomamente sulla piattaforma ai fini dello studio autonomo.
Particolare attenzione verrà posta allo sviluppo e il perfezionamento di strategie di reperimento del lessico giuridico oltre al training di strutture sintattiche relative a questa lingua di specialità con l’obiettivo di fornire agli studenti gli elementi linguistici di base necessari a un uso della lingua in ambito lavorativo e/o di ricerca a un livello di padronanza linguistica B1+ sia passivo (comprensione scritta e orale) che attivo (produzione scritta e orale).

data.name: Network modelling and design

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: The goal of the course is to provide advanced know-how on modeling and design of tlc networks. The student will learn analytical methodologies for performance analysis of communication networks and will be able to apply those to current and future networks; he/she will learn the behaviour of Internet transport protocols; he/she will be able to understand the architecture and mechanics of next generation networks and to design networks for fixed and mobile operators as well as new protocols and architectures.

data.name: Ecoidraulica

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
At a time in which humans have significantly affected the natural environment and yet society increasingly values the many services of natural ecosystems, accounting for ecological processes in engineering design is a major contemporary challenge for environmental engineers. This is the fundamental topic in Ecohydraulics, the discipline that focuses on the consequences of fluid and sediment processes on the organisms that inhabit aquatic environments. While still a young science, Ecohydraulics already endows the engineer with an overall understanding and quantitative tools to predict how physical processes shape habitat quality and quantity, and how, in turn, they are affected by ecological dynamics. This enables the integrated analysis of different management options for natural and man-made water bodies in terms of their ecosystem consequences. At the broadest scale, this class will contribute to the students' appreciation of the tight link between the natural and the built or impacted environment, and of the importance of considering both (and “how-to”) for harmonizing environmental quality with human river uses in river management and restoration.

At the end of the course the student will be able to: i) identify the different fluvial forms and their evolutionary trajectories; ii) use the hydro-morphological quality indexes and assess the status of alteration of river ecosystems; iii) understand the relations between hydro-morphology and biotic component, the causes of alteration of river ecosystems and tools to design ecological flow regimes in altered rivers; iv) appreciate the relevance of the integration of complementary disciplines for the sustainable management of water bodies.
data.degreeProgram: Ingegneria per l'ambiente e il territorio (LM)

data.name: Processi partecipativi di governance

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
What role do citizens have in a democracy? What challenges do citizens face? What is the relation between representative democracy and citizens’ participation? What deliberation means in this context? These questions invite to think critically about what we mean by “democracy”, “participation” and “deliberation”. This course will explore these concepts and will introduce the students to the new main tools and strategies used by local governments to involve citizens in the policy-making process.
This course is designed to enable students to:
•	Significantly deepen their understanding of a variety of models and theories of democracy, and how these models conceptualize the nature and practice of citizenship and politics
•	Explore the theory of participatory and deliberative democracy, in particular
•	Develop a critical view of the roles that scientific methods, expertise, and knowledge do, might, and/or should play in addressing public problems.

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.name: Computability and computational complexity

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The course sets the theoretical bases for being able to discuss two fundamental properties of computational problems.
Given a problem, we will be concerned about its computability:
- Is there a method to solve the problem?
- Can we describe this method in an unequivocal way?
- Is there a universal "language" for such task?
When a problem is found out to be solvable, we can wonder how efficiently it can be done.
- What are the meaningful criteria to express how hard a problem is?
- Is there a meaningful way to classify problems with respect to their hardness?
- Does this classification tell us something about the limits of our capability to solve problems?

At the end of the course, the students will be able to:
- Describe problems and problem instances in a formally precise way.
- Describe the solution of simple problems in terms of a universal computational model (the Turing Machine).
- Prove that a specific problem (Turing's halting problem) is not computable.
- Apply the formal notion of reduction in order to extend properties of known problems to new ones.
- Identify quantitative criteria to describe the complexity of an algorithm with respect to instance size.
- Describe the main time and space complexity classes, and their inclusion relationships.
- Define what it means for a problem to be complete for a class.
- Prove that a specific problem (SATISFIABILITY) is complete in the NP class (Cook's Theorem).
-Use reductions for proving completeness of other problems in the class NP.
- Discuss the P vs. NP problem and its main implications on various branches of computer science.
- Identify upperbounds to problems via Turing Machines with oracles.

data.name: Sistemi cyber-fisici wireless per radar e comunicazioni mobili

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: The course aims to provide the student with the theoretical skills and methodological knowledge for the analysis and design of modern wireless systems capable of reconfiguring according to the surrounding electromagnetic scenario through software and hardware solutions. In the first part, the course provides the fundamental principles of the radiated propagation of electromagnetic waves and the radiation from elementary sources of electromagnetic field, as well as the description of the basic parameters for the characterization of the antennas. In the second part, the objective is to provide the students with the basic knowledge on the methods and strategies for the analysis and synthesis of suitable radiation diagrams as function of the application context. The course is based on rigorous theoretical contents, but is expressly oriented to wireless applications with a focus on radar and mobile communications systems. During the course, guided exercises will be carried out with the help of SW programs used for the design of radiant systems in the industrial field.
data.degreeProgram: Ingegneria Informatica, delle Comunicazioni ed Elettronica (L2)

data.name: Optimization techniques

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The goal of this course is to provide the fundamentals of numerical optimization. We will focus on various kinds of optimization techniques, ranging from continuous to discrete optimization methods, including global and local search methods, derivative-based and derivative-free algorithms, as well as traditional operational research techniques such as those used for solving integer programming, linear programming, and quadratic programming problems. We will address both theoretical and practical considerations, complementing each lecture on the theory with a dedicated lab. During the labs, the students will have the opportunity to test the various techniques on synthetic and real-world optimization problems.

At the end of this course, the students will be familiar with the fundamentals of numerical optimization, and will be able to apply various kinds of optimization algorithms to different contexts. They will also know the basic theory needed for developing new algorithms, or adapting/tuning them to handle new problems.

data.name: Multisensory interactive systems

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The overall goal of the module is to provide a theoretical and practical basis for the design, development, and evaluation of interactive systems, which are multisensory, tangible, and networked. Students on this module will have the opportunity to explore physical computing concepts, use real-time programming languages, understand the bases of human sensory perception, and design networked interactions in both co-located and remote settings.

On successful completion of this course, students should be able to: 
- Understand fundamental notions on electronic hardware such as micro controllers, single board computers, sensors, and actuators of different kind
- Develop interactive applications based on both embedded systems and desktop solutions, which take inputs from sensors and control a variety of physical and digital outputs
- Apply acquired knowledge on fundamentals of multisensory perception to the design of interactive systems
- Apply techniques for prototyping multisensory interactive systems as well as for their evaluation at both technical and user experience level


Students will apply knowledge and skills from above in completing a semester project in teams. Students will be provided with a large variety of hardware items and software tools, which will enable them to create prototypes of networked, tangible and interactive multisensory systems.

data.name: Tecnologia e chimica applicata con elementi di chimica

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.name: Scientific programming
data.description:
Computer processing is a key component of modern data analysis pipelines, and plays an increasingly important role in many fields of science. The goal of the course is to introduce the Python programming language, one of the most widely used scientific computing languages, and related technologies.


At the end of this course, the students should be able to:

A) Remember the syntax and semantics of the Python language;

B) Understand programs written by others individuals;

C) Analyze a simple data analysis task and reformulate it as a programming problem;

D) Evaluate which features of the language (and related scientific libraries) can be used to solve the task;

E) Construct a Python program that appropriately solves the task;

F) Evaluate the results of the program.

data.name: Laboratorio di ricerca su sistemi informativi

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
The goal of this lab is to give the students an introduction to information systems analysis and design, focusing on social practices, innovation, and social research. The core of the lab will consist of experimenting in practice the methodologies for the analysis, modeling and design for social innovation. Critical reflection on the entire process will be stimulated. The lab aims at supporting the preparation of the master dissertation, as well as providing students with competences useful for their professional careers.

The main activity is the preparation, as group-work, of a proposal for a social or cultural innovation project.


The students will be required to design and carry on a qualitative research project. The project will be done in collaboration with the course Qualitative methods and research lab (Prof. Bassetti).


Learning Objectives (LO):

LO1: connect social research, information system design, and social/cultural innovation.

LO2: collect and use auto-ethnographic data.

LO3: analyze and model/formalize business processes.

LO4: build simple prototypes of information system interfaces.

LO5: analyze project sustainability.


For attending students, LO are meant as practical (group work) and theoretical/reflective (individual) work. For non-attending students, LO are meant as as mostly theoretical/reflective work.

data.name: International Sustainable Development: Methods and Projects

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
PART I


Part I has the following learning goals: make the student acquire basic knowledge, skills, and competencies to apply concepts, principles, strategies, and theoretical-practical tools of sustainable development in their professional and working activities (in companies, in public administrations, in third sector bodies, in education/training institutions), with particular attention to the international dimension, as well as to cultivate job or volunteer opportunities in the vast field of sustainability and international cooperation. The course is also useful as a professional refresher and retraining path.

Consequently, as expected learning outcomes, the student, upon passing the related tests, will be able to:

a) build and enhance a good critical understanding of specific international and local contexts in which sustainable development and in particular environmental sustainability will be applied;

b) understand and use the basic concepts and principles related to sustainable development, especially in the environmental sphere, and the advanced ones peculiar to its application in the field of international cooperation;

c) to know and interact with the many subjects involved in various capacities in the areas covered by the course;

d) understand, analyse, and apply the sustainable development goals set by the system of the relevant global and local agendas, as well as the goals of other relevant global agendas (contents and methods);

e) use and adapt to their contexts the main tools and methods for sustainable development and international cooperation, with special attention to those for environmental sustainability; in particular, apply the Environmental Mainstreaming Approach.



PART II


The learning goals of Part II are: providing students with a "toolbox" to read, analyse and understand the contexts in which they operate and manage interventions that involve a variety of stakeholders, intervening in a sustainable way to promote economic and social development even in situations of conflict.

As expected learning outcomes, the student, upon passing the related tests, will be able to:

• produce a critical reading of the contexts in which he/she is called to operate, with particular attention to: the relationship between stakeholders and the environment, ethnic diversity, power relations, organization, and territorial innovation;

• carry out an analysis of conflicts, with particular reference to environmental ones, and experiment with some methods for managing them;

• know some project methods, with particular reference to those typically used in the field of sustainability in international contexts, through the practical experimentation of some of them.

data.name: Geometria e algebra lineare
data.description: The course aims to provide the students with the main notions of Linear Algebra and Analytic Geometry. Particular attention will be paid to the most important tools for engineering applications. The students should acquire skills on identifying the numerous relationships among the learnt concepts. At the end of the course, the students should be able to solve the submitted problems by suitably choosing the most convenient mathematical tools among the possibly alternative ones.

data.name: Automated Reasoning

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
IMPORTANT NOTE: Starting from academic year 2020/21, the course "Formal Methods" is split into two consecutive modules:
Module I:  "Automated Reasoning" [6CFU, of which 4.5CFU theory + 1.5CFU lab]
Module II: "Model Checking" [6CFU, of which 4.5CFU theory + 1.5CFU lab]
which are borrowed respectively as single courses
* Automated Reasoning [6CFU, of which 4.5CFU theory + 1.5CFU lab]
* Model Checking [6CFU, of which 4.5CFU theory + 1.5CFU lab]
from the degree course in Artificial Intelligence Systems.
The first module/course is a prerequisite for the second.

Part of both modules/courses consists on lab sessions, for 3CFU overall (1.5 CFU Automated Reasoning + 1.5 CFU Model Checking)

As such, the first module/course  "Automated Reasoning" will start at the beginning of the semester and end in the middle of the semester, whereas the second module/course "Model Checking" will start in the middle of the semester and terminate at the end of the semester.

Module I:  "Automated Reasoning" [6CFU, of which 4.5CFU theory + 1.5CFU lab]

Automated (logical) reasoning techniques are widely used in many fields, mainly in Artificial Intelligence --as backend "engines" in several automated reasoning, inference and planning tools-- and in the field of formal specification and validation of complex systems --as backend "engines" on top of which automated-verification tools are build.
Module I "Automated Reasoning" introduces the main methodologies and instruments for automated (logical) reasoning.  

Students will experience in laboratory the usage of automated reasoning tools, in particular, e.g., of SAT and SMT solvers. 

At the end of the course, the student:
- will know the main automated reasoning techniques
- will be able to model simple problems and solved them via automated reasoning tools, like e.g. SAT or SMT solvers.

Module II: "Model Checking" [6CFU, of which 4.5CFU theory + 1.5CFU lab]

Formal methods are increasingly used as powerful specification, verification and early debugging methods in the development of industrial SW and HW systems. This course provides an introduction to Formal Techniques and Tools for the specification and verification of Hardware and Software platforms. The main and most-successful fall in the "Model Checking" family, which use automated-reasoning techniques as backend engines. 
Module II "Model Checking" introduces the main specification and formal verification techniques of SW and HW devices. The course will concentrate mainly on formal verification and techniques and, in particular, on Model Checking (MC).

A laboratory will be given in which the students will experience MC techniques by means of the MC NuXmv and SPIN. 

At the end of the course, the student:
- will know the main formal specification and verification techniques, in particular Model Checking
- will be able to formalize simple HW and SW systems and verify their properties by means of the model checker NuXmv.

data.name: Intelligent vehicles and autonomous driving
data.description:
Objectives

To provide the basic knowledge and skills to design and implement an autonomous driving system.

In detail:

1) Understanding of the various levels of automation (SAE levels) and driving support systems (ADAS).

2) Definition of the main perception systems.

3) Definition of the main control algorithm architectures acting on various levels.

4) Providing the appropriate implementation skills.


Expected outcomes

  • Explain the different automation levels.
  • List the ADAS systems and their characteristics.
  • Explain the basic perception system of an autonomous driving system (Lidar, Radar, RGB camera, HD maps).
  • Illustrate the main components of an autonomous driving system's architecture from the low to the high level.
  • Develop a simplified autonomous agent.

data.name: Psicologia della memoria e dell'apprendimento

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description: This course unit aims at providing students with a general overview of the basic mechanisms and most prominent theories of learning and memory, as well as of their relationships with attentive and executive control processes. At the end of the course, students are expected to have achieved a good knowledge of such mechanisms and of the experimental paradigms used to investigate them. They should also be able to link theory, empirical research and practice and discuss properly results of the scientific studies described during the course lessons.

data.name: Diritto amministrativo

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.name: Distributed robot perception
data.description:
The instructional goals of the course is to acquire a comprehensive overview of the distributed systems for measurement and automation used today in industrial and service application domains. The course focuses on the most advanced technological solutions adopted in industry as well as on the theoretical aspects that arise when control or estimation are applied in a distributed context. Particular emphasis will be given to robotic perception using Artificial Intelligence techniques to be applied to robotic problems.

During the course, the focus will be on the design and implementation of distributed estimators to be used for intelligent autonomous systems in industrial and service environments, analyzing the resulting problems from both a practical and theoretical point of view. Examples of the application of these techniques on real or realistic systems will be presented during the course.

At the end of the course, the student will be able to:

- Understand the complexity, the issues and the potentialities of distributed systems;

- Compare the various different technological solutions available for a distributed system;

- Evaluate and analyze the practical and theoretical implications of a distributed measurement and/or perception system;

- Analyse and design the distributed solution for a particular system;

- Critically asses the benefits and the limitations of a distributed solution.
