data.name: Relazioni interpersonali e comunicazione sociale

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description: The course provides students with knowledge of the basic elements of communication processes, in general and in social work. It then explores some key aspects of empathy and emotional intelligence and knowledge about main communication strategies to build collaborative relations with different subjects. EXPECTED LEARNING OUTCOMES By the end of the course, students will increase their capacity to: - Recognise the main features of human communication and communicate effectively - Take into account the 'reality-building' effect of communication - Recognise the different contexts, actors and purposes of relationships in social work - Know the main features of empathy and emotional intelligence, identifying emotional experiences and their possible use in relationships - To be aware of the impact of communication in building trusting relationships and to use a supportive and capacitating language - using different communication strategies with diverse subjects

data.name: Finite elements modeling
data.description:
The finite element method (FEM) is the dominant discretization technique in process and product modelling. The objective of this course is to give the student a broad and integrative knowledge of this method and to introduce the student into its application to a variety of engineering problems.
By the end of this course students should: (1) know the behaviour and usage of each type of elements covered in this course; (2) be able to use finite element software to develop models of engineering systems; (3) be able to interpret and evaluate the quality of the results (know the physics of the problems); (4) be aware of the limitations of the FEM (don't misuse the FEM - a numerical tool!);  (5) be familiar with team-working, mathematical computing and FEM software; (6) be able to present FEM analyses in a proper format of a written report such that a technically qualified person can follow and obtain similar findings.
data.degreeProgram: Materials and production Engineering - Ingegneria dei materiali e della produzione (LM)

data.name: Storia del diritto romano
data.description:
After a series of necessary considerations on the utility for modern law students of studying the history of law as well as on the history of Roman law and methods of investigation, the course aims above all to illustrate the constitutional changes which characterised the history of ancient Rome. With the Roman model in mind an attempt will be made to identify what - in the institutional vicissitudes of a nation - constitute the legal methods which may lead to a radical change in its fundamental structure. For Rome this coincided with the move from a Monarchy to a Republic and from a Republic to a Principate and finally, with unstoppable force, from a Principate to an absolute monarchy (called the Dominate).
Particular emphasis will be placed on the study of the sources of law and, with special reference, criminal trials.

data.name: Sociologia

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
Il corso intende fornire un inquadramento della disciplina sociologica per gli studenti del primo anno del corso di laurea in Studi Interazionali. Il corso fornisce dunque un’introduzione al lessico e ai concetti sociologici fondamentali per consentire ai discenti di proseguire in un percorso di formazione nell’ambito delle scienze sociali. Il corso introdurrà la nascita e la formazione della disciplina sociologica e i principali orientamenti che la caratterizzano. 

Al termine dell’insegnamento, lo studente sarà in grado di: • conoscere i principali orientamenti e le principali teorie sociologiche; • padroneggiare i concetti sociologici fondamentali; • familiarizzarsi con lo sguardo sociologico (la sociologia come modo di vedere la società); • leggere e interpretare un testo sociologico classico; • analizzare e sintetizzare un’argomentazione sociologica; • inquadrare un fenomeno sociale contemporaneo in termini e con categorie sociologiche.

data.name: Introduction to Robotics

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The course offers a bird-eye view on the most important topics related to modern robotics, highlighting the main problems that need to be faced in order to make the robots operate correctly in the environment. Specifically, the course will cover the following topics: taxonomy of the different types of robots, physical modelling of robots (direct and inverse kinematics and dynamics), simulation of models, sensing and actuation solutions for perception and action.
Using the developed models, the most famous methodologies to control robot motion and interaction, will be presented. These methods will be first studied in theory, and then implemented in simulation (with the Python language) to gain practical experience.
Attention will be also paid to illustrate the most common non idealities and issues that are present when controlling robots. The course will adopt a combination of simulation models and lab experiences to consolidate the knowledge transmitted during the theoretical lessons.
After completing the course, students will be able to:
- select the most suitable sensors and actuators for a given robotic application
- model the kinematics and dynamics any kind of robot
- understand the working principles of several control algorithms for robotic systems
- choose the appropriate approach(es) to control a specific system for a given target application
- implement, tune, and test control algorithms with the Python language

data.name: Tecnologia dei cicli produttivi
data.description:
The course aims to outline the importance of the energy sector in developed countries as well as in developing countries. Energy production and consumption in addition to economic aspects and environmental effects are considered. Furthermore, the technological innovation as a key factor in the exploitation of new energy sources and the improvement in the use of traditional sources is analyzed.
Attendance and active participation at the course and self-study will enable students to:
1.Know the role of energy in the economic system
2.Know the environmental impacts associated with the exploitation of the different  energy sources
3.Compare efficiency in the use of different energy sources and their environmental and economic consequences
4.Analyze and interpret the trends of the international oil prices
5.Relate oil price trends to global geopolitical equilibrium.
6.Assess the importance of technological innovations in the energy sector

data.name: Procedura penale
data.description: The course aims to provide an updated knowledge of italian criminal procedure (with specific regard to the Constitution, the main international sources and the code of criminal procedure in force) and of the conceptual categories uponon which the system is founded. It is expected that students in addition to acquiring knowledge of the institutions of criminal procedure  considered in the framework of constitutional and supranational principles  develop specific competences in the interpretation of procedural law and in the critical analysis of the controversial issues which are debated in literature and in the case-law. It is also expected that students develop their ability to expose and communicate the acquired knowledge in a clear and complete way, using appropriate specialist language and correct legal syntax.

data.name: English for International Communication
data.description:
GENERAL LEARNING OBJECTIVES:

The course aims to develop learners' general and specialized/discipline language and communication skills and competences to a level of proficiency at least equivalent to C1+ (http://www.coe.int/t/dg4/education/elp/elp-reg/Source/Key_reference/Overview_CEFRscales_EN.pdf).

The course also aims to help students become more independent language learners.

The principle objective is that students have a working-knowledge of English and are able to function fully in any future English Language context whether academic or professional.


LEARNING OUTCOMES – the knowledge, skills and competences a learner should have acquired on completion of the course.


Knowledge and Understanding

By the end of the course students should have acquired:

- explicit knowledge of how English works (grammar, pronunciation, lexis, lexico-grammar including collocation and colligation etc) i.e. metalinguistic awareness and knowledge;

- knowledge of the lexis and language conventions of the three main discipline areas, Law, Economics, Political Science;

- awareness of English as a discourse practice, both in academic and professional contexts, through knowledge of the genre analysis approach to texts;

- knowledge of academic and professional socio-linguistic practices, in particular, adapting message to audience/interlocutor;

- awareness of the reader expectation approach to writing, in particular through the concepts of action, agency, separations, theme and stress position;


Applied Knowledge and Understanding,

By the end of the course students should be able to:

- understand texts of a wide range of genres (spoken and written), also of a technical nature, and identify the way these texts are structured;

- identify the communication conventions in the different academic disciplines and professions;

- analyse texts of varying types (Policy Note, Call to Action, Press Release, etc) following a genre analysis approach;

- understand how languages are learned and confidently use tools and resources to enhance their own approach to language learning (metacognitive knowledge);


Skills and Competences

By the end of the course students should be able to:

- communicate effectively and appropriately (i.e. awareness of audience/interlocutor) specific knowledge and expertise, also of a technical nature, in both written and spoken language;

- process and critically evaluate texts of all kinds (spoken or written, academic or professional);

- apply the notions of the reader expectation approach to writing with a particular focus on clarity, coherence and thematic/logical progression to first recognise and ultimately produce clear effective prose in English;

– use the appropriate language skills and competences to perform written and spoken tasks (e.g. summarise, interpret, critique, counter-argue, negotiate, persuade, propose etc.);

- draft texts, also of unfamiliar types, using the genre approach to analysis;

- interact in teams/groups making effective use of interpersonal communication skills, including project management;

- use appropriate communication conventions paying particular attention to register, style and tone;

- adopt effective language learning tools, skills and strategies to enhance learning for self-directed learning;

- discuss language and learning in appropriate terms (metalinguistic skills).
data.degreeProgram: EUROPEAN AND INTERNATIONAL STUDIES - STUDI EUROPEI E INTERNAZIONALI (LM)

data.name: Metodologia della scienza giuridica
data.description:
EDUCATIONAL GOALS AND EXPECTED LEARNING RESULTS

The module aims to provide a critical approach to Methodology of Law.
In this regard, a general theoretical reflection on methods of scientific and social research will be offered . 
In addition, the so-called socratic method will be also analysed as the criteria of topica organization of the juridical material and as a method of overcoming opposition. This method is typical both of the law scientist activities, and of the practical lawyer’s ones. 

Knowledge of the traditional judicial methodologies and their criticisms. In particular, knowledge of:
- the problem of method definition,
- historic or historical methodology,
- systematic methodology,
- formalistic methodology,
- analytical methodology
- dialectical methodology
- socratic methodology
Knowledge of the national and international debate about methodology.

As far as regards the expected abilities, the students will be required:
- To be able to set a judicial reasoning according to sillogistic perspective
- To be able to set a judicial reasoning according to the topica perspective
- To be able to face a simple debate
- To be able to face a judicial debate
- To be able to forecast and overcome the objections moved to their own position.

After learning the basic concepts, students will learn how to use dedicated softwares to discover the brain basis of a psychological disorder and create biomarkers. data.name: Storia della filosofia moderna e contemporanea
data.description:
The course aims to analyze in depth authors, texts and specific themes of the history of modern and contemporary thought, also in relation to the most current problems.
By the end of the course the student will have acquired a thorough knowledge of the topics addressed and the specific skills that will allow him/her to 1) adequately place topics and authors within their contexts, and understand their meaning and value in the overall picture of the history of philosophy, as well as in relation to the contemporary problems; 2) critically analyze and interpret the required texts; 3) discuss the course content and one’s own reasoning using appropriate language and suitable logical-argumentative tools.

data.name: Reti

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
We all take it for granted that our smartphone can access a story on social media, that our messages and photos reach their destination, that video calls with family and friends work at the push of a button. But none of these things could exist without the (complex) telecommunication infrastructure that allows them to exchange data: the Internet.


This course introduces the fundamentals (and many details) of the Internet, and computer networks in general. After a first part dedicated to the theoretical foundations of communication networks (e.g., what is a protocol? What architecture do networks have?), the course explores why (that is, for which applications) we need a global network infrastructure; how we ensure end-to-end communications (both in best effort mode and with error control); how data is routed in distributed networks, and how the use of shared communication channels is managed (especially in wireless networks).


At the end of the course the student

  • will know how the Internet and computer networks work
  • will understand the details of the protocols that underpin computer networks

and thanks also to laboratory activities

  • will be able to configure the a network by acting on the main network-layer and transport-layer protocols.

At the end of the course, the student is expected to know the main stylized facts related to price and return distributions, and to be able to implement by means of Matlab the algorithms commonly employed in finance and quantitative risk management.

data.name: Matematica finanziaria
data.description:
Course Objectives and Expected Learning Outcomes
The aim of the course is to introduce quantitative models and methods used to evaluate financial instruments, yields structure, and fair prices of fixed income securities.
Reference is made to risk management investment models (financial immunization),  followed by fundamental concepts on financial derivatives (if time permits).
At the end of the course the student will be able to carry out basic evaluations of financial instruments, compare the bond market prices, and to deal with choice problems in finance .
The course intends to stimulate the financial awareness and critical analysis skills required in an employee in the financial sector.

data.name: International and European Union Law (Basic)
data.description:
The course aims at providing students with a theoretical and practical understanding of the functioning of both the legal frameworks and the institutions of International and European Union (EU) law. Students will be trained to assess the relevance of legal arguments with reference to a number of case studies.


The general learning objectives of the course are:

- understanding how to apply legal reasoning and legal concepts in international relations;

- understanding the functioning of the sources of the law and their normativity;

- understanding and critically assessing the consequences of the breach of the law in specific situations;

- understanding and critically assessing the role of diversified actors and institutions in the creation and application of International and EU Law.


With specific reference to the International Law Module of the course, students will be able to:

- describe the processes of law creation and application at the international level;

- qualify international disputes in legal terms, taking position and developing sound legal arguments;

- read and understand a judicial decision dealing with international law;

- critically assess the role of international law.


On completing the EU Module of the course, students will:

- be able to describe the process of European integration by means of legal concepts;

- be familiar with the key developments of the process of legal integration in the EU;

- learn core principles, the main sources, the role of the main institutions and organs of the European Union;

- understand the interaction between international law and domestic law with EU law;

- be accustomed to searching and using relevant rules and judgments from the main EU databases.

data.name: Experimental Techniques in Nuclear and Subnuclear Physics
data.description:
The study of elementary particles and interactions of matter as well as cosmology and astrophysics requires an extensive experimental activity whose task is to discover new physics and new particles, as well as to select, among existing theories, those could have a realization in Nature.
The aim of this course is to propose to the student a series of small experiments selected following some important "macro themes" in fundamental particle physics, astrophysics and cosmology.
In this course students will learn to:
- design a simple particle physics experiment, simulating the expected response using the Geant4 toolkit (https://geant4.web.cern.ch/)
- build a simple set-up by using typical particle detectors and tuning a simple electronic chain for data acquisition
- analyze the collected data using basic statistical techniques and libraries for data analysis developed at CERN (https://root.cern/)

data.name: Security and the Environment
data.description:
The course will give an overview of the various challenges brought about by the Anthropocene in the political geographies of the world at different spatial scales. It will highlight the importance of a critical understanding of (in)security issues emerging with the transformation of climate and the disruption on of environmental balance in the contemporary world and it will introduce major political dilemmas. Geography offers an unusually important and relevant vantage point from which to examine and explain matters of environmental (in)security.


The module will firstly define the Anthropocene historically, socially and politically, to then focus on the fast and disruptive changes that constitute a threat to societies and, in some cases, to the very existence of life on earth. The main goal of the course is to provide theoretical and analytical tools to understand the changes that occurred to the geographies of (in)security with the Anthropocene. Attention will also be paid to the environment as a major area of concern and to the diverse frameworks of the climate crisis as a security issue. Moreover, students will be introduced to literature analysing how different ideas of security translate into different kinds of politics.


The expected learning outcomes include:

- Ability to understand the impact of the Anthropocene and link it to historical, political and social factors;

- Understanding of the concept of environmental (in)justice and the capacity to analyse case studies;

- Ability to critically understand the concept of climate/environmental (in)security and discuss its multifaceted nature (from global geopolitics to embodied experiences), especially with regard to present phenomena;

- Understanding of the different factors (e.g. resources, identity issues, environmental politics, territorialities) and scales (e.g. local identities, geopolitical interests, globalization processes) impacting on or influencing environmental, social and political security issues;

- Capacity to develop critical analysis and autonomous judgment, and to conduct independent research (at least via secondary sources) linking case studies to explanatory theories.

data.name: Geotecnica

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
The course is aimed at providing students with the basic knowledge of soil mechanics to define simple mathematical models that describe the hydro-mechanical behavior of soils: seepage, consolidation, shear strength and compressibility. The course gives the fundamentals of soil mechanics which are required in geotechnical design and in advanced courses of geotechnical engineering, such as: Earth-retaining walls and Slope Stability.

At the end of the course, students will be able to: i) identify and classify the soil; ii) model the mechanical behaviour of soils with simple mathematical tools and to interpret laboratory and site testing data; iii) recognize and model the interaction between solid and liquid phases in simple cases of saturated soils below the water table; iv) transfer this knowledge into the design of simple geotechnical structures that will be described in the master's degree programs.

data.name: Disegno Civile + CAD

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
“Traditional technical drawing + CAD” teaches how to understand and communicate the objects and physical spaces through visual representation. The main goal of the course is to provide students with the basic graphic and geometric knowledge useful for documentation, interpretation, and design of architecture and engineering artifacts. The engineer’s education, in fact, can not disregard these two specific areas: the logical and geometrical control of the methods of shapes modelling, and the technical and graphic ability to process and spread information. Therefore, the course aims to lead students towards a conscious use of the conceptual and material tools of drawing, both for the proper preview of the project to be realized and for the suitable description of the built work.
At the end of the course students will be able to: carry out the preliminary analysis of a material object using 2D visual language (freehand drawing); scientifically represent a spatial configuration by the flatness of the graphic support (perspective, orthogonal and axonometric projections based on descriptive geometry); manage the 3D digital model, its levels of details and the corresponding technical charts or figurative outcomes; apply rules, codes and symbols in order to accurately address the contents to the different drawing scales reduction; process digital images and vector graphics with simple operations.

data.name: Genomics Technologies

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description: The course aims at explaining the opportunities that high-throughput technologies give in the analysis of genomes and of transcriptomes, being introduced to the concepts and tools of Precision Medicine. The course will focus on DNA microarrays, Next Generation Sequencing technologies and Next-Next Generation Sequencing technologies, their problems and perspectives. At the end of this course students will be able to: • Distinguish between high-throughput and high-multiplexity technologies. • List different high-throughput technologies. • Relate low-throughput techniques based on nucleic acids hybridization. • Describe a microarray experiment. • List different uses of microarrays: SNP-typing, CGH-arrays, gene expression analysis. • Relate the history of microarray techniques. • Illustrate fabrication methods of spotted, Agilent and Affymetrix, bead-based microarrays. • Discuss differences between Agilent and Affymetrix microarrays. • Discuss experimental design for microarray experiments. • Explain the use of biological replicates and technical replicates. • List and explain different steps in data analysis for microarray experiments. • Explain the need for normalization and the possible strategies for normalization of microarray data. • Illustrate the difference between ratios and fold changes in the identification of differentially expressed genes. • Perform cluster analysis of gene expression data. • Describe what a pathway analysis is and perform it. • Use biological databases and gene ontology in data analysis. • Illustrate the Sanger sequencing method and its direct evolution, the automated DNA sequencing. • Distinguish between Sanger sequencing, Next Generation Sequencing (NGS) and Next-Next Generation Sequencing (NNGS). • Schematise the phases of NGS. • List different applications of NGS and different genome enrichment methods. • Illustrate the workflow of template preparation for NGS. • Describe emulsion PCR methods for library preparation. • Illustrate Quality Control and Library Preparation for NGS. • Illustrate different NGS techniques, their features (read length, run time and maximum throughput) and discuss their advantages and disadvantages: the Roche 454 Pyrosequencing, the SOLiD, the IonProton, the Illumina NGS. • Describe how to multiplex and illustrate paired-end sequencing in Illumina NGS. • Illustrate NNGS techniques: the PacBio, the Helicos, the Oxford Nanopore. • Illustrate NGS applications in Metagenomics. • Illustrate NGS applications in Medical Genomics. • Illustrate Singe Cell Sequencing and Spatial Transcriptomics techniques. Bioinformatics approaches to retrieve biological information from publicly available RNA-seq data. Performing RNA-seq data analyses by applying specific tools through the terminal as well as through R packages in R Studio. Analyzing NGS data to assess quality in order to properly tune accurate reads mapping and from there calculate differentially expressed genes (DEGs), which can be used as input for several activities: clustering analyses, GO and pathways' identification, Gene Set Enrichment analysis (GSEA), to name a few.

data.name: Solid state physics I
data.description:
The course wants to give an overview of the physics of the solid state, presenting the theory of solids and the main experimental observations on which it is based.  Aim of the course is to describe the crystal structures and their symmetries, the elasticity theory, the lattice waves and the electronic structure. The study of more advanced topics is postponed to the subsequent course of “Solid State Physics II”.

At the end of the course the student:

1) Will have acquired an in-depth knowledge of the thermodynamic and transport properties of solids, described in microscopic detail.

2) Will be able to recognise the main crystal structures and he will know the basic elements of the theory of the discrete symmetry groups.

3) Will have become familiar with the modern experimental techniques that allow the observation of the properties of solids.

data.name: Eco-sustainable methods for the prevention and management of invasive alien species
data.description:
Aim. The aim of the course is to provide students with critical evaluation and problem-solving skills to manage the invasion of insect alien species, both in the agricultural and human health contexts, as a preparation for a future career where managers will face the threat of a fast changing world.

 

Learning goals. After completion of the course, the student is able to:

  • recognize the potential threat of invasive alien species,
  • evaluate the risk of an invasive species for a specific area and context,
  • elaborate a strategic plan of action to prevent and contain the invasion,
  • solve a specific problem within a given limited amount of time,
  • work together in a team with diverse backgrounds, towards a common goal,
  • present and defend the proposed solution orally in a professional form.

data.name: Laboratorio di tecnologie delle materie plastiche
data.description:
The course introduces students to the most important manufacturing techniques of plastic materials, giving them competences on the selection of the transformation processes and of the relative technological parameters as a function of the thermophysical properties of the different materials. At the end of the course it is expected that students are able to :
- Reach a detailed knowledge of the different transformation technologies of plastics, and of the correlation between processing parameters and the resulting technological properties.
- Distinguish the different plastic products on the basis of their technological properties and of the production process utilized for their development.
- Know the different equipment necessary for the transformation of plastics, with the setting of the relative process parameters.
- Propose the most suitable technological process for the realization of plastic products, with the selection of the processing parameters. 
- On the basis of the introduced theoretical concepts, carry out experimental activities working in group.
- Present in an exhaustive way the experimental results through oral presentations and a technical report.

data.name: Signal, Image and Video

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: The course provides the basic competences in the field of digital signal processing, with special attention to images and video sequences. Starting from the fundamentals of 1D signal analysis and processing, analog and numerical, in time and frequency domains, we then extend the concepts to the multi-dimensional case of signals in space. Then, we introduce the more important approaches for image filtering and extraction of image descriptors. These concepts are further extended to deal with motion pictures. Finally, the problem of image compression is introduced, focusing on most known techniques for image and video coding, as well as their standard implementations. The approach of the course is rather practical, with the explanation of theoretical concept followed by their translation into algorithmic terms.

data.name: Computer Architectures

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The goal of this course is to provide the basic notions about the organization and architecture of computing machines, either general-purpose computers, or specialized architectures designed to handle specific tasks. Furthermore, the course provides basic knowledge about the assembly language (in particular using as a reference RISC-V and briefly discussing the Intel and ARM architectures), the HW/SW interface, and the low-level mechanisms of a computer. Finally, the course also provides the fundamental knowledge needed to attend advanced courses focused on the design of computer systems from the hardware perspective.

This course does not require any preliminary knowledge. The structure of the course is especially suited for students with a CV oriented towards software and systems, who during their Bachelor Degree have the chance to learn about computer architectures only through this course. On the other hand, the course will also provide the fundamental knowledge needed to attend advanced courses focused on the design of computer systems from the hardware perspective.

data.name: Corso di spagnolo A2 - I periodo (estensivo)
Formal Verification

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
IMPORTANT NOTE: Starting from academic year 2020/21, the course "Formal Methods" is split into two consecutive modules:
Module I:  "Automated Reasoning" [6CFU, of which 4.5CFU theory + 1.5CFU lab]
Module II: "Model Checking" [6CFU, of which 4.5CFU theory + 1.5CFU lab]
which are borrowed respectively as single courses
* Automated Reasoning [6CFU, of which 4.5CFU theory + 1.5CFU lab]
* Model Checking [6CFU, of which 4.5CFU theory + 1.5CFU lab]
from the degree course in Artificial Intelligence Systems.
The first module/course is a prerequisite for the second.

Part of both modules/courses consists on lab sessions, for 3CFU overall (1.5 CFU Automated Reasoning + 1.5 CFU Model Checking)

As such, the first module/course  "Automated Reasoning" will start at the beginning of the semester and end in the middle of the semester, whereas the second module/course "Model Checking" will start in the middle of the semester and terminate at the end of the semester.

Module I:  "Automated Reasoning" [6CFU, of which 4.5CFU theory + 1.5CFU lab]

Automated (logical) reasoning techniques are widely used in many fields, mainly in Artificial Intelligence --as backend "engines" in several automated reasoning, inference and planning tools-- and in the field of formal specification and validation of complex systems --as backend "engines" on top of which automated-verification tools are build.
Module I "Automated Reasoning" introduces the main methodologies and instruments for automated (logical) reasoning.  

Students will experience in laboratory the usage of automated reasoning tools, in particular, e.g., of SAT and SMT solvers. 

At the end of the course, the student:
- will know the main automated reasoning techniques
- will be able to model simple problems and solved them via automated reasoning tools, like e.g. SAT or SMT solvers.

Module II: "Model Checking" [6CFU, of which 4.5CFU theory + 1.5CFU lab]

Formal methods are increasingly used as powerful specification, verification and early debugging methods in the development of industrial SW and HW systems. This course provides an introduction to Formal Techniques and Tools for the specification and verification of Hardware and Software platforms. The main and most-successful fall in the "Model Checking" family, which use automated-reasoning techniques as backend engines. 
Module II "Model Checking" introduces the main specification and formal verification techniques of SW and HW devices. The course will concentrate mainly on formal verification and techniques and, in particular, on Model Checking (MC).

A laboratory will be given in which the students will experience MC techniques by means of the MC NuXmv and SPIN. 

At the end of the course, the student:
- will know the main formal specification and verification techniques, in particular Model Checking
- will be able to formalize simple HW and SW systems and verify their properties by means of the model checker NuXmv.

data.name: Biologia cellulare

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The main objective of this class is to give to provide the students with the concepts essential for understanding the structural and functional organization of the eukaryotic cell with particular emphasis on the animal cell. By providing examples of key cell biological experiments, another goal pursued by the class is to shed light on the relationship between the key concepts addressed and the experimental evidence supporting them. Moreover, the last objective of this class is to clarify the relationship between the proper operation of cellular processes and tissue and organ homeostasis. This is achieved by alluding to pathological conditions resulting from the malfunctions of the cellular processes tackled during the course.  

By the end of the class, successful students will be able to:

-describe the various types of biochemical constituents of the cell

-describe the structural organization of the cell critically addressing the functional relevance of every organelle

-manage the key notions associated to the central dogma of molecular biology and it compartmentalization within eukaryotic cells 

-predict the subcellular localization of a certain protein by knowing key aspects of it primary sequence

-describe structure and function of the different cytoskeletal elements, addressing similarities and differences among them

-understand the regulatory aspects allowing eukaryotic cells to duplicate

-understand the regulatory aspects allowing eukaryotic cells to undergo programmed death

-understand the key techniques utilized in cell biology with particular emphasis on the mammalian tissue culture and microscopy approaches

data.description: The course aims to produce sufficiently stable and definitive knowledge on the foundations of sociological thought, as they developed in Europe between the eighteenth and the twentieth century. data.name: Principles of biomaterials and medical device design
data.description:
The interdisciplinary course is aimed at acquiring knowledge of the main requirements for engineering precision biomaterials, the nature of the interactions between these and biological tissues (work environment) and the design criteria of artificial systems in relation to the functional recovery of the tissue or organ. to be replaced, integrated, or rehabilitated, of the medical device validation process.

In details:

  • Have an understanding of the multi- and inter-disciplinary nature of the biomedical device field;
  • Understanding the concepts of system biocompatibility and its role in precision biomaterials and medical device design;
  • Understanding the biological mechanisms tissue-specific involved in biomaterials and in designing medical devices.
  • Understand of the basic concepts for biomedical devices innovation: from clinical needs to emerging technologies;
  • Understanding of the basic principles and procedures for biomedical products development: from advanced research to product design; personalized medicine, prototype development, regulatory issues and validation;
  • Students will experience practical lab work in a multidisciplinary environment, understanding communication among several disciplines needed for biomedical strategies and products development.

Transversal skills

  • Communicate effectively with professionals/researchers from other disciplines.
  • Access and evaluate appropriate sources of information

data.name: Chimica Organica
data.description:
Obiettivi formativi

Il corso tratta gli aspetti fondamentali della Chimica Organica:struttura e reattività dei principali composti organici. L'obiettivo è di fornire le conoscenzene cessarie per affrontare quegli insegnamenti specifici del corso di laurea di cui la chimica organica è un importante strumento di comprensione.

Risultati di apprendimento attesi

Data la formula di struttura di un composto organico, al termine dell’insegnamento lo studente sarà in grado di:

1) identificare i gruppi funzionali presenti e scrivere un abbozzo di nomenclatura secondo le regole IUPAC,

2) stabilire il numero e tipo di eventuali isomeri del composto e assegnare a ciascuno l’appropriata notazione di configurazione,

3) desumere lo stato di aggregazione del composto in condizioni ambientali, la sua solubilitàin acqua ed il pH di tali soluzioni acquose,

4) descrivere le reazioni cui il composto può dare luogo in termini di solvente e temperatura, catalizzatore o reattivo stechiometrico,reazione di equilibrio o quantitativa, prodotti finali.

data.name: Introduction to Computer Programming (Python)
data.description:
The course aims to make an introduction to basic programming using Python. The

teaching includes practical "hands-on" lessons on programming problems related to

acquiring and manipulating text and images. The aim of the course is for the student to

become familiar with Python and to organize the code in an orderly manner so that he can

acquire a textual corpus and images and perform simple data manipulation procedures.

data.name: Design of precision systems

The course aims to teach the basics of the design and implementation of precision measurement systems, understanding the importance of the correct definition of requirements and specifications, system design, and development of a measurement model and noise sources.

Furthermore, the practical part of the course also requires the learning of computer and programming techniques, also on microcontrollers, for the use of sensors and transducers in the realization of a complex measurement system.

data.name: Distributed estimation for robots and vehicles
data.description:
The instructional goals of the course is to acquire a comprehensive overview of the distributed systems for measurement and automation used today in industrial and service application domains. The course focuses on the most advanced technological solutions adopted in industry as well as on the theoretical aspects that arise when control or estimation are applied in a distributed context. Particular emphasis will be given to robotic perception using Artificial Intelligence techniques to be applied to robotic problems.

During the course, the focus will be on the design and implementation of distributed estimators to be used for intelligent autonomous systems in industrial and service environments, analyzing the resulting problems from both a practical and theoretical point of view. Examples of the application of these techniques on real or realistic systems will be presented during the course.

At the end of the course, the student will be able to:

- Understand the complexity, the issues and the potentialities of distributed systems;

- Compare the various different technological solutions available for a distributed system;

- Evaluate and analyze the practical and theoretical implications of a distributed measurement and/or perception system;

- Analyse and design the distributed solution for a particular system;

- Critically asses the benefits and the limitations of a distributed solution.

data.name: Nanoscience
data.description:
The course introduces the students to the interdisciplinary field of nanoscience, provides a basic understanding of materials properties and physical-chemical processes at the nano-scale, and gives insight into the present and future perspective of the research in this field.
Nanoscience is an interactive course, with basic lessons dealing with the fundamental concepts of nanosciences, and thematic seminars offered by the students.
The lessons are divided into three parts. The first part gives a basic knowledge of the chemical and physical phenomena which govern the behavior of nanostructures or their precursors. The second part introduces the techniques for fabrication and manipulation of structures at the nanometer scale and to the nanostructures which find more application in the field of energy and health. The third part of the course deals with nanostructured materials and systems having envisaged applications as selective membranes and in the field of energy storage. 
The course is experimentally oriented and some lessons will be specifically dedicated to the techniques and processes to synthesize and characterize the nanomaterials.
The thematic seminars will be organized by small groups of students (1o 2 students) together with the teachers. The seminars will deal with a specific topic chosen by each student group and will be presented by the students during the course or at the same time as the exam.

At the end of the course, students should be able to:
understand the basic physical and chemical aspects which determine the properties of the matter at the nanoscale
Know the fundamentals of the most important techniques which allow the synthesis, manipulation, and characterization of nanomaterials, acquire and analyze critically scientific interdisciplinary information from the current literature on nanomaterials and their application.

data.name: Networking I

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: The goal of the course is to provide advanced know-how on modeling and design of tlc networks. The student will learn analytical methodologies for performance analysis of communication networks and will be able to apply those to current and future networks; he/she will learn the behaviour of Internet transport protocols; he/she will be able to understand the architecture and mechanics of next generation networks and to design networks for fixed and mobile operators as well as new protocols and architectures.

data.name: Marketing game
High Performance Computing for Data Science

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The course is intended to provide the fundamentals of High Performance Computing software for High-end Data Science. In particular we present convergent ecosystems of software and data frameworks at a large-scale in relevant scientific disciplines. The course will present both theoretical and practical aspects related to simulation-centric and data-centric paradigms; challenges related to end-to-end workflows joining both paradigms into large-scale experiments will be also presented; case studies from several domains (e.g. medical/health, financial, climate/weather) will be presented and discussed with follow-up hands-on sessions. By the end of the module, students will learn:

  • parallel computer memory architectures and parallel programming models;
  • principles of parallel algorithm design
  • how to develop and benchmark parallel code (using MPI);
  • analytics frameworks and approaches for High-end Data Analysis;
  • how to develop large-scale data analytics applications (using Dask or similar tools);
  • differences between simulation-centric paradigm and data-centric discovery;
  • the complementary role of big data, data science and HPC in tackling real-world problems.

Students are expected to learn how to identify, acquire, manage and analyze data – through the use of the open-source statistical environment R – to address relevant decision-making problems.

data.name: Public Economics

This course aims to provide students with an overall understanding of the economic rationale and main implications of public sector interventions. More specifically, by the end of this course, students will have learned:

data.name: Costruzione di ponti

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
The Course looks at the analysis and the design of bridges, including the analysis of the design methodology, the use of automatic computation, with particular reference to the Finite Element Method. Finally, the course examines the nature of specific static and dynamic problems of various classes of bridges.
At the end of the course, each student will be able to: set the design of a medium/small span bridge, especially taking into account both static and seismic aspects; (Ii) design and verify superstructures made of precompressed concrete and steel-concrete composites subject to fundamental or exceptional actions; Iii) designing and verifying the main structural elements and connections in the same superstructures.

data.name: Filologia italiana II - LM
data.description:
The course aims to provide students with a thorough knowledge of Italian Renaissance literature, to consolidate their skills in textual analysis and strengthen their ability to develop critical hypotheses autonomously.

At the end of the course, students will be able to:

-  contextualise and discuss with confidence authors and works from the early centuries of Italian literature (from the origins to the end of the sixteenth century);

-  paraphrase, analyse and comment upon medieval and Renaissance texts;

-  make appropriate use of the methods and competences required for the study of Renaissance texts;

-   adopt interdisciplinary approaches and interact with a range of scholarly traditions;

-   develop hypotheses with a significant degree of critical autonomy.

data.name: Human-Machine Dialogue

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: Robots that can talk or chat with humans are becoming pervasive in many industry domains and applications. Such agents are called conversational AI systems. In this course the student will learn the basic principles of human computer interaction, conversation linguistics, discourse analysis, computational dialogue models and architectures and their evaluation. In the second part of the course the student will develop a conversational system while  learning the design methodologies, data-driven training and dialogue development tools .

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description: The aim of the course is to provide an introduction to the fundamentals of theoretical mechanics, with particular regard to the problem of determining the equations of motion for the most relevant constrained systems and the related initial conditions, as well as the reduction of the same equations to the normal form, in order to ensure the existence and uniqueness of the complete solutions. At the end of the course the student will be able to model the ideal, dynamical and statical, behaviour of simple mechanical systems (holonomic systems consisting of a finite number of rigid bodies).

data.name: Electrochemistry for energy and environment
data.description:
The aim of the course is to provide the students with fundamental concepts of electrochemistry concerned with the quantitative relations among the chemical, surface, and electrical properties of systems. The students will gain knowledge about the structure of electrolyte solutions as well as the phenomena occurring at the interfaces between metallic electrodes and electrolyte solutions. The lectures are a blend between theoretical aspects (frontal lessons) and laboratory activities. The course is divided into 3 sections (Book I, Book II, Book III), each of which is divided into 4 subsections (Chapters 1-12). The total number of sections corresponds to the 12 weeks course duration, which includes classroom lectures and laboratory activity. Approximately, one classroom lecture and one lab session each week. 


The course will provide the students with hands-on laboratory experience in the field of electrochemistry, specifically within the context of energy and environment-related applications. The expected outcomes are:

- Solidify the students’ theoretical knowledge of electrochemistry;

- apply these concepts in the context of energy and environment-related applications;

- get the students acquainted with different electrochemical techniques

- get the students acquainted with application-relevant materials and preparation methods.

data.name: Automated Reasoning

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
IMPORTANT NOTE: Starting from academic year 2020/21, the course "Formal Methods" is split into two consecutive modules:
Module I:  "Automated Reasoning" [6CFU, of which 4.5CFU theory + 1.5CFU lab]
Module II: "Model Checking" [6CFU, of which 4.5CFU theory + 1.5CFU lab]
which are borrowed respectively as single courses
* Automated Reasoning [6CFU, of which 4.5CFU theory + 1.5CFU lab]
* Model Checking [6CFU, of which 4.5CFU theory + 1.5CFU lab]
from the degree course in Artificial Intelligence Systems.
The first module/course is a prerequisite for the second.

Part of both modules/courses consists on lab sessions, for 3CFU overall (1.5 CFU Automated Reasoning + 1.5 CFU Model Checking)

As such, the first module/course  "Automated Reasoning" will start at the beginning of the semester and end in the middle of the semester, whereas the second module/course "Model Checking" will start in the middle of the semester and terminate at the end of the semester.

Module I:  "Automated Reasoning" [6CFU, of which 4.5CFU theory + 1.5CFU lab]

Automated (logical) reasoning techniques are widely used in many fields, mainly in Artificial Intelligence --as backend "engines" in several automated reasoning, inference and planning tools-- and in the field of formal specification and validation of complex systems --as backend "engines" on top of which automated-verification tools are build.
Module I "Automated Reasoning" introduces the main methodologies and instruments for automated (logical) reasoning.  

Students will experience in laboratory the usage of automated reasoning tools, in particular, e.g., of SAT and SMT solvers. 

At the end of the course, the student:
- will know the main automated reasoning techniques
- will be able to model simple problems and solved them via automated reasoning tools, like e.g. SAT or SMT solvers.

Module II: "Model Checking" [6CFU, of which 4.5CFU theory + 1.5CFU lab]

Formal methods are increasingly used as powerful specification, verification and early debugging methods in the development of industrial SW and HW systems. This course provides an introduction to Formal Techniques and Tools for the specification and verification of Hardware and Software platforms. The main and most-successful fall in the "Model Checking" family, which use automated-reasoning techniques as backend engines. 
Module II "Model Checking" introduces the main specification and formal verification techniques of SW and HW devices. The course will concentrate mainly on formal verification and techniques and, in particular, on Model Checking (MC).

A laboratory will be given in which the students will experience MC techniques by means of the MC NuXmv and SPIN. 

At the end of the course, the student:
- will know the main formal specification and verification techniques, in particular Model Checking
- will be able to formalize simple HW and SW systems and verify their properties by means of the model checker NuXmv.

data.name: Telerilevamento e radar

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
Remote sensing optical and radar systems are one of the most complex information engineering systems, as they  involve many technologies and methodologies (satellites, passive sensors, radar sensors for the acquisition of images, data transmission techniques, advanced signal and image processing techniques, data storage and management techniques).
The course analyses the main elements of remote sensing systems and develops a basic level of competence in processing and automatic recognition of images and signals.
The programme is divided into 5 parts  The first part looks at remote sensing systems in general, and the principles upon which they are based.  The second part focuses on the acquistion phase of remote sensing images; covering satellites, sensors and data transmission systems.  The third part is dedicated to the automatic techniques used for the processing of remotely sensed images, and advanced methodologies for the analysis of multispectral optical images and radar images.  The fourth part of the course examines techniques for automatic recognition of remote sensing images and signals.  The final part of the course presents examples of the application of remote sensing systems and image analysis techniques to real problems.
The student wll also develop practical exercises in laboratory to consolidate the understanding of the theory, and gain experience of the techniques described in lectures.  There will also be some specialist seminars held by experts in the sector from national and international research institutes and from industry.
data.degreeProgram: Ingegneria Informatica, delle Comunicazioni ed Elettronica (L2)

data.name: Bayesian Statistics

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
Purpose of the course

The purpose of the course is to address the study of the foundations of Bayesian statistics starting from the basic principles of the probability calculus. The course is divided into two modules.


  • The first module is devoted to present the parametric Bayesian inferential framework and intends to explore the foundations of the Bayesian paradigm and highlight the similarities and differences with the classical Fisher’s approach. Particular attention will be posed on computational and simulation aspects.
  • The second module focuses mainly on nonparametric Bayesian framework and related methods exploring the implications of Dirichlet and Pitman-Yor process in nonparametric mixture models. Particular attention will also be devoted on computational aspects of nonparametric mixture models.


During the course, the students have the opportunity to familiarize themselves with the principal theorems, logical developments, ideas and issues that underlie the Bayesian techniques, learn to recognize them as natural extensions of the concepts introduced in the previous courses in probability and mathematical statistics and familiarize with their us in practical situations.


The students will be request to have a pro-active participation and a constant involvement in the training program.


Course expected results

After taking this course students should be able to

  • Choose appropriately prior distributions and obtain posterior distributions
  • Simulate values from posterior distributions and make appropriate Bayesian inference.
  • Construct Bayesian prediction intervals and write appropriate conclusions.
  • Construct hierarchical models and adapt mixture models to capture the richness and the variety of the real phenomena.
  • Use a statistical computer packages (mainly R) to implement the data analysis procedures covered in the course.

data.name: Applications of fluid mechanics to energy engineering

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
Applications of fluid mechanics to energy engineering is an optional course within the master in Energy Engineering and is aimed to the students showing particular interest in fluid mechanics.

Some specific topics addressed only marginally in the basic courses of hydraulics and fluid mechanics will be addressed, in order to provide the students with the fundamental knowledge about turbulent flows, physical modelling and CFD (Computational Fluid Dynamics).  Within the tutorials and the homework the students will have the opportunity to compare some commercial codes applied to practical applications relevant to energy engineering.

By the end of the course, students are supposed to be able to:
- Knowledge and understanding: (1) show the equations and explain the main principles relevant to turbulence, CFD, similarity and lubrication; (2) develop an intuitive comprehension.
- Applying knowledge and understanding: (3) give examples of real applications and practical problems to underline how the topics treated in the course are used within engineering activity.
- Making judgements: (4) the ability to make autonomous judgements in the choice and comparison of the suitable tools and for the solution of problems involving the mechanics of fluids.
- Communication skills: (5) communication skills to correctly and properly present the concepts acquired in the course and the results of the homework.
- Learning skills: (6) Ability to autonomously extend the knowledge acquired during the study course by reading and understanding scientific and technical documentation.

data.name: Economia dei mercati e degli intermediari finanziari
data.description:
The course aims to train students to understand the financial contracts issued by intermediaries and / or traded in financial markets. 
The first part of the program will examine the contracts "to confidential information" (deposits, bank loans, factoring, leasing, etc.), the second part of the course instead of listed financial instruments (money market, bonds, equity, foreign exchange and derivatives), the third part of the course will examine the insurance contracts (life insurance) and the last part of the course the logical construction of the portfolios (portfolios and asset management tools). 
At the end of the course, the student will be able to: 
1. know the characteristics of the main contracts for confidential information; 
2. know the risk and return profile of market instruments (money market, bonds, equity, foreign exchange and derivatives) 
3. understand the purpose of insurance contracts and the underlying logic; 
4. understand how portfolio and asset management products can help to reduce financial risks and their economic space of utilization.
