data.name: Ingegneria sismica e progettazione strutturale

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
The course is partitioned into two sections. The section relevant to Seismic Engineering aims at providing a rational basis for the analysis and design of earthquake-resistant structures. The one concerning Structural Design aims at providing basic knowledge to perform a correct structural design of concrete buildings and the design of structural elements not covered in previous courses.

The section relating to Seismic Engineering involves pertinent information from engineering seismology, geotechnical engineering, risk and reliability theory, and architecture in addition to advanced topics related to the dynamics, the analysis, and the design of structures. The focus of the course is on buildings, bridges, industrial facilities, and other types of structures to allow students to acquire a theoretical understanding of the fundamental factors influencing and controlling the response of these structures. Moreover, it develops effective design procedures capable of achieving specified performance goals. The course also looks at existing Italian and international regulations in the field of earthquake-resistant structures, as well as a seismic isolation and control techniques, given their increasing importance.

The section on “structural design” covers the fundamental aspects of the structural design of concrete buildings, the linear and non-linear methods of analysis, the design of stocky elements, the design of foundation elements, the design criteria for concrete slabs, and deep beams.

At the end of the course each student will be able to: (1) set up the design of a reinforced concrete building, especially taking into account both static and seismic aspects; (2) designing and checking reinforced concrete structures subject to fundamental or exceptional loads; (3) designing and checking the main structural elements and connections in the same structures.

data.name: Fog and Cloud Computing

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
In the last few years, the cloud computing revolution heavily impacted the ICT world: cloud infrastructure, both public and private, hosts a significant portion of modern digital services and data. Cloud technologies and methodologies, such as virtualisation, containerisation, micro-service based architectures and service-meshes, are becoming prevalent among large technology providers, cloud operators and software developers. New software applications are, in turn, being developed following the so called cloud-native paradigm in order to exploit the benefits, such as scalability and reliability, offered by the cloud infrastructure and services.

Within this technological revolution, topics such as data locality and management are also attracting increasing interest. For this reason, one area of significant development in this space is that of edge computing resources, leading to the emergence of the fog computing paradigm. Indeed, more and more services are beginning to exploit, or even require, its benefits in terms of reduced latency, lower bandwidth consumption through near data source pre-processing, or simply guarantees around the geo-location of data.

This course provides an introduction to Cloud and Fog computing principles and technologies, following a practical, hands-on approach. More specifically, at the end of the course the student will: (1) learn about cloud and fog computing models, technologies and existing solutions; (2) acquire relevant knowledge on advanced topics related to networking, orchestration and security; (3) use and configure advanced open-source platforms to create and manage cloud computing infrastructures and to effectively and dynamically orchestrate workloads.

data.name: Organizzazione dei servizi sociali e gestione delle risorse umane

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
The scope consists of analysing the characteristics of different organizational models with particular reference to the horizontal and, above all, network models. As far as human resource management is concerned, we will look into the concepts related to the planning and implementation of systems directed to achieve the organizational goals of employee satisfaction and economic viability, by also underlining the specific characteristics of public and non-profit organizations.


At the end of the course the students will able to:


-Illustrate the features of the different organizational models in a comparative perspective, too;


-Apply and integrate the characteristics of the different organizational models to address typical organizational issues;


-Conceive and implement tools favouring the collaboration between publich and non profit organizations within the field of social services;


-Recognize the different human resource management systems and how to improve them, with particular reference to the non-profit sector;


-Identify spaces of participation that peculiar conceptions of 'managerialism' can yield in the management of human resources within public social services.
data.degreeProgram: Metodologia, Organizzazione e Valutazione dei Servizi Sociali (LM)

data.name: Riabilitazione strutturale

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
The course goal is to develop a solid understanding of the issues associated with the safety assessment of existing constructions, with particular focus on seismic evaluation and retrofit of historic masonry structures.
At the end of the course students are expected to be able to: i) identify the main causes of structural vulnerability; ii) assess the level of safety of existing structures, with reference to both static and dynamic actions; iii) design retrofit solutions aimed at improving structural safety and satisfying code requirements.

data.name: Applied Immunology

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description:
The aim of the course is fourfold. First, it provides  students with the understanding of basic immunology including, innate immune responses and adaptive immunity. Second, the course offers the students an overview on the mechanisms of vaccine-induced immune responses, on how vaccines are designed and formulated, and  on the economics of vaccination. Moreover, details on the main vaccines currently in use for the prophylaxis of the main human diseases are provided. Third, the course covers the topics of cancer immunotherapy, and offers an understanding of the main immunotherapeutic strategies current in use to fight cancers. the role of microbiome in cancer development is also covered. Finally, the course allows the students to understand the mechanisms of allergy and autoimmune diseases 
At the end of this course, students will be able to:
a) Describe the difference between the different types of immune responses
b) Understand how vaccine are designed 
c) Understand the mechanisms of action of vaccines
d) Understand the role of the immune system in cancer and how our immune system can be exploited to develop anti-cancer therapies.
e) Describe the mechanisms of allergy and autoimmunity 
f) Describe the current strategies to fight allergy and autoimmunity

data.name: Fundamentals of quality engineering
data.description:
This is a School of Innovation course. It covers the basics of quality management and, specifically, the four main quality management paradigms, the principles of both the ISO 9000 series of standards, and quality awards. 
After completing the course, the student will be able: 
- to understand, summarize and compare the main quality management paradigms; 
- to understand and summarize the ISO 9000 series of standards and the main quality awards.

data.name: Meccanica delle costruzioni con elementi in vetro delle tensostrutture e delle strutture murarie

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
The course aims to merge structural engineering and architectural vision, often believed to be opposite poles that are difficult to reconcile but whose integration is essential for the realization of multifunctional buildings.


The topics addressed during the course will first deal with the comprehensive vision typical of undergraduate courses and then with the pragmatic attitude of the professional world. This last aspect is essential to help students to enter the world of work. It will be accomplished thanks to the partnership with an expert operating in the civil engineering sector, in particular in the building of mega-structures, tensile structures, and retractable construction systems. Such an expert will show the various project phases, from the brainstorming up to the complete realization on site, with the final aim of providing the student with that "mindset" necessary for success in the professional world.

The first part of the course focuses on analyzing the local and global mechanical behavior of masonry and the cracking pattern. It will be shown that the design methods of the masonry structures based on the curve of pressure and the inverted catenary are conceptually similar to those used for the design of tensile structures, discussed in the second part of the course. The two structural systems are respectively not resistant to traction and not resistant to compression, hence the duality of the calculation techniques.

The second part of the course deals with the study of "special" structures realized with unconventional materials and technologies that require a significantly different design approach from that used where classic materials are employed. In particular, this part of the course deals with:

  • the design of glass facades. The theoretical concepts will be applied to the design of the main structural elements used in architecture and engineering (parapets, decks, beams, columns, fins, etc.) both by simplified strategies and by finite element simulations, accordingly to the CNR DT 210 guidelines; 
  • the form-finding and design of tensile structures, based on the concept of lightness (limited weight compared to the surfaces and volumes built) and sustainable architecture aimed at using light, low cost, and low environmental impact materials. The analysis of case studies will support the theoretical aspects.  
  • the details, cutting patterns, cables, and textile materials;
  • the principles underlying parametric design (or computational design). This design approach, considered the design method of the future, allows the designer a unique combination of forms and architectural composition.


At the end of the course, the student must demonstrate an understanding of the topics addressed during the course by applying the theoretical concepts to case studies.

data.name: Antropologia culturale per l'insegnamento
data.description:
GENERAL OBJECTIVES
The main objective of the course - developed through online lectures, discussions in the virtual classroom, group work and possibly the contribution of experts - is to make students acquire the general skills of anthropology related to the world of education. Both the typical methods of the discipline and the tools of the ethnographic approach in school and educational contexts will be illustrated.
Particular attention will be paid to specific sectors of anthropology that may be useful for the teacher's work and through the analysis of specific case studies, tools and interpretations will be provided to relate to cultural diversity.

EXPECTED LEARNING RESULTS
At the end of the course, students will be able to:
1. understand and critically analyze the main issues of cultural anthropology, in particular in its declination in the anthropology of education
2. to master the specific concepts and language of the discipline in relation to the school and educational context;
3. know how to use or tool of ethnographic investigation in relation to the educational and school context.
4. grasp and interpret the characters and transformations of contemporary school and education, also in comparison with European realities, through the ethnographic approach.
5. develop an anthropological gaze, a reflective attitude towards one's own cultural positioning and a relational posture capable of understanding and relating to cultural diversity

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.name: Foundations of Geometry
data.description:
The course aims to

    • Reconsider the basic notions of Euclidean geometry (Books I-IV of Euclid's Elements) from a higher viewpoint, in particular using the modern axiomatic formulation intriduced by Hilbert.
    • Give a rigorous introduction to noneuclidean geometry, with special attention to hyperbolic geometry and to the Poincarè model.
    • Study ruler-and-compass constructions, using the free software Geogebra.

    At the end of the course, in order to take the examination successfully, the student is expected:
    • To know the principal results of the first books of Euclid's Elements, and know how to apply them to solve problems in Euclidean geometry.
    • To be able to identify the parts of the Elements which required the introduction of new and/or different axioms for their justification.
    • To know the modern axiomatic theory of Euclidean Geometry.
    • To know the fundamental notions of hyperbolic geometry and have a good understanding of the Poincarè model.
    • To be able to use Geogebra to make ruler-and-compass constructions.

data.name: Diritto e amministrazione per il servizio sociale

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
The course aims at providing a critical assessment of the main features of the Italian public law.  It will examines the institutional architecture and its functioning. At the same time, the course will also make reference to the main legislative measures in the social assistance field that may be useful for social workers.
It is expected that students will acquire a sufficient knowledge of the legal lexicon and capacity to use it in a proper manner.

data.name: Optimization models and algorithms
data.description:
The following are skills that the student should acquire with the attendance of the course.
• A knowledge of a set of mathematical models and algorithms suitable for some optimization problems in industrial and management framework. 
• The ability to classify different optimization problems and to recognize which types of algorithm and software are the most suitable in order to face a submitted problem. 
• The capability to understand and manage the results of numerical implementation of the algorithms.

data.name: Lineamenti di storia del teatro
data.description:
Aims of the course is the acquisition of the basic notions necessary to get acquainted with the history of theatre, through an analysis of the distinct elements constituting the theatrical event altogether.Students will be able to: 
1)analyse from a critical point of view the theatre stagings of nowadays and of the past within the context of the historical background
2) evaluate the overall cultural impactof theatrical events on society
3) elaborate a comparative view of the theatrical events in differents geographical context

data.name: Pensiero islamico
data.description:
The course will discuss the origins of Islam, focusing on the evolution of Muslim theology, law, and rituals, and include readings of primary sources, together with relevant secondary literature. Major issues in modern Islamic debate will also receive attention.
This course will also examine the origins of the Islamic political history, at the emergence of Mohammad in seventh-century Arabia in VII A.D. Basic concepts such as shari’ah, fiqh, jihad, umma, sunna, shi’a, caliphate, imamate and sultanate will be studied. 
At last, the main modern currents of Islamic thought, together with the critical thought of Islam, will be described and analysed in depth.

data.name: Global Migration and Security
data.description: The course aims at providing students with specific knowledge concerning the phenomenon of global migration and its implications for security from the legal point of view. At the end of the course, the students will know the complexity of this phenomenon, the ethical and social consequences of the decisions taken with regard to its regulation and the difficulties of its governance.

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.name: International Trade and Globalisation
data.description:
The goal of this course is to identify and to map, empirically and theoretically, the main phenomena of the current trade system in the global economy. The course provides insights into the reasons for trade at country and firm level, gains from trade, trade policy tools and international agreements, as well as contexts in which students can engage in debate, discussion, and reflections on the main issues related to trade policies.

By the end of the course students should have acquired:

• an in-depth understanding of the different advantages and costs of trade from various viewpoints of trade theory.

• the use of the necessary basic tools (f. i. some basic trade indices) to analyse, at country and firm level, the contemporary international and European trade relations.

• to apply theoretical perspectives in analysing related policy questions, especially the effects of trade barriers and industry protection.

• to understand the structure and functioning of international trading system and associated institutions (such as the WTO) and regional trade agreements.

data.name: Information system
data.description:
The course aims to provide students with a general understanding of the role of information systems and information and communication technologies (ICT) in modern organizations, in order to prepare managers and staff of modern business to understand the main technological solutions available for organizations operating in the digital economy. The course aims to provide the basis for understanding the business phenomena nowadays more and more connected to the use of ICT, with a special attention to the relationship between ICT, business organization and related costs.

After completing the module students will be able to:
• Understand the main characteristics of modern information systems, their impact and the relationship with the organization
• Understand how technologies can help managers who want to use ICT to improve and make their work and their organization more efficient
• understand the role of technological innovation, both hardware and software, in their organizational choices
• Understand the role and follow the evolution of ICT in the process of improvement and creation of new business opportunities
• Understand the role of ERP systems, data analysis, Business Intelligence and Big Data in modern information systems and apply it in their business domain
• understand the cost items related to Information Systems and related infrastructures in order to evaluate investments in this sector

data.name: Intelligent vehicles and autonomous driving
data.description:
Objectives

To provide the basic knowledge and skills to design and implement an autonomous driving system.

In detail:

1) Understanding of the various levels of automation (SAE levels) and driving support systems (ADAS).

2) Definition of the main perception systems.

3) Definition of the main control algorithm architectures acting on various levels.

4) Providing the appropriate implementation skills.


Expected outcomes

  • Explain the different automation levels.
  • List the ADAS systems and their characteristics.
  • Explain the basic perception system of an autonomous driving system (Lidar, Radar, RGB camera, HD maps).
  • Illustrate the main components of an autonomous driving system's architecture from the low to the high level.
  • Develop a simplified autonomous agent.

data.name: Deep learning Lab

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description: The course aims at studying the fundamentals of machine learning, covering supervised and unsupervised learning methods and deep learning approaches. It includes application examples as well as laboratory exercises. At the end of the course, it is expected that the student will acquire the skills useful to design methods and tools for the analysis of signals and data.

data.name: Macroeconomia
data.description:
The course aims at presenting and analyzing the key macroeconomic problems of growth, fluctuations, unemployment and inflation, the leading contemporary macroeconomic theories and their policy prescriptions. In addition, basic notions and instruments of internationally open economies will be introduced. Finally, the course will examine the main instructional features and principles of governance and economic policy of the European economic and monetary union.


The expected learning results are:

- become familiar with, and develop autonomous and critical interpretation of, main macroeconomic facts and problems and their relevant data; be able to understand and critically interpret the public debate on the macroeconomic policy issues

- know hypotheses, concepts and key results of the main contemporary macroeconomic theories, and their views and implications for economic policy

- be able to understand and apply the basic macroeconomic models

- understand and interpret competently the international dimension of macroeconomic problems and policy issues

- know the political-economic institutions of the European economic and monetary union; understand and critically discuss the main problems of monetary and fiscal policies in the Union

data.name: Environmental Fluid Mechanics/Hydropower Plants

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
At the end of the course, it is expected that the students will be able to:

(Knowledge and understanding)
1.     Recall the basics of pressurized flow and related energy balance
2.	Understand the hydrodynamics and the main hydraulic processes of open-channel flows, including basics of sediment transport
3.	Understand the hydrological cycle.
4.	Understand the hydraulic design/sizing of the main components of a Hydro power Plant (such as: hydraulic equipment for production, control, outlet works).

(Applying Knowledge and understanding)
5.	Compute steady-state profiles of open-channel flows with variable geometry and discharge.
6.	Carry out the main hydrological analyses necessary for the design of hydroelectric systems and simulation of their productivity.
7.	Carry out the hydraulic design of the main components of a HPP

(Making judgments)
8.	Analyze the different compartments of a Reservoir Hydro Power Plant (HPP) and of a Run-of-River HPP.
9.	Estimate the hydrological and environmental alterations induced by the operation of hydroelectric power plants.

data.name: Minority Rights
data.degreeProgram: EUROPEAN AND INTERNATIONAL STUDIES - STUDI EUROPEI E INTERNAZIONALI (LM)

data.name: Organizational Behavior
Epigenetics of Cancer

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description:
Epigenetics of Cancer is the study of the epigenetic mechanisms whose alterations favors tumor initiation and progression. The course will focus on understanding the role of epigenetics in controlling maintenance of cell identity, tissue homeostasis and adaption to environmental changes. In the context of tumorigenesis, the course will provide a framework on the interconnection between alterations of epigenetics, cancer genetics and aberrant environmental signals. Overall, the main objective of the course is to provide to the students a depth knowledge of the alterations of the epigenetic mechanisms that foster tumorigenesis and their possible involvement of designing targeted therapy.
At the end of the course the student will be able to:
- describe different types of epigenetic mechanisms 
- understand the role of epigenetics in controlling gene expression and genome stability
- gain knowledge on the most advanced technologies to profile the epigenome alterations in cancer
- Critically evaluate data regarding cancer epigenomics

data.name: Computer Programming 1

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
Learning Objectives


  • Introduce the student to code programming, programming principles and techniques.
  • Make the student familiar with code programming and provide the basic notions, insights and tools of code programming
  • Learn fundamentals of imperative programming
  • Learn program structures, elements, and operations
  • Learn by doing: learn how to develop programs to face problems of simple/average difficulty
  • Learn the (imperative) language C++
  • Learn introductive notions of object-oriented programming in C++


Expected Learning Outcome


  • At the end of the course the student (1) will know and understand the fundamental notions and concepts about the imperative programming and about the C++ language and (2) will be able to analyze problems of simple/average difficulty and (3) will be able to elaborate code solutions (i.e., develop software programs), by using C++ as imperative programming language to face them.

data.name: Percorso orientativo: Lauree magistrali e mondo del lavoro

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.name: Archeologia e storia dell'arte greca
data.description:
This course is composed of two parts (Greek Archaeology and Art History and Roman Archaeology and Art History) and offers the students a broad overview of art and archaeology in the Greek and Roman worlds.
At the end of the course, students: 1. will have developed an overall knowledge of the main archaeological and artistic aspects of the Greek and Roman worlds; 2. will be able to discuss and analyse monuments and artworks presented to them through pictures and plans; 3. will have thorough awareness of the close relationships between artistic production and the historical and political context; 4. will have familiarised with the technical terminology.

data.name: Diritto commerciale progredito
data.description:
Corporate governance. 
Compliance programs.
The liability of the social members - directors - auditors.
Going concern.
The treatment of the conflicts between partners into the partnerships and corporations."

data.name: International contracts law_
AI for finance

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
Financial institutions are increasingly using Artificial Intelligence and machine learning. The course aims to provide students with financial models on Artificial Intelligence. In particular, the following three models are discussed:
1) Investors' Portfolio selection and its performance optimization
2) Portfolio Credit risk measurements and Credit risk management
3) High frequency trading 
The models are explained using basic concepts of economics and finance. The computation complexities are further explained in details. The final part of the course is dedicated to applications of the models using real financial and economic data.

data.name: Questionnaire Design
data.description:
The course will be held in English. The purpose of the course is to provide students with both practical and theoretical knowledge of questionnaire design and to develop critical skill in evaluating already constructed questionnaires.
The student will learn to:
- understand different research designs in which questionnaires are used
- identify different levels of measurement of the variables
- construct a questionnaire plan (sections, objectives, questions, analysis)
- carefully choose words to use in questions (wording)
- Choose the appropriate type of response format
- construct a cover letter
- Implement the questionnaire using online systems
- Build a coding plan 
- Enter data into a spreadsheet
- construct simple measurement scales and indices
- perform simple statistics on instrument reliability (Cronbach's alpha, factor analysis).
The course is intended as a laboratory in which students will be asked to demonstrate the acquisition of acquired skills through personal or group laboratory activities.
data.degreeProgram: Behavioural and Applied Economics - Economia Comportamentale e Applicata (LM)

data.name: Knowledge and Data Integration

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
This course is concerned with one of the five issues (the % V's) which are core to big data, namely "variety". It creates skills which are core to the role of Data Scientist


The goal of the course is to provide students with tools, methodologies, technologies needed in order to build a KG successfully and with minimal effort

data.name: Etica
data.description: The course aims to provide a concise but exhaustive knowledge of the main issues of ethics, in dialogue with other thought forms (music, in particular). It also aimss to stimulate in students an autonomous and critical reflection on the difficulties of ethical decisions in contemporary society and on the social role of philosophy and culture in general in dealing with ethical problems.

data.name: Metodi di ricerca per il welfare locale

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
The course aims to provide the main methodological and technical references for analysis, design, intervention, in welfare services.
The connection between methodological principles of social work and the methodological principles of social research will be emphasized in the different thematic nodes.
data.degreeProgram: Metodologia, Organizzazione e Valutazione dei Servizi Sociali (LM)

data.name: Quantum field theory I
Informatics and Legal Research (Informatics and the Law)
data.description:
Nowadays technologies dominate everyday life and legal professions are not an exception.

The course focuses on the strong relationship existing between law and technology, even from a practical point of view.

It aims at illustrating mutual influence between law and technology by assuming a critical point of view on their reciprocal developments.

To allow students to gain a complete understanding of legal informatics, the course will be divided into three main parts.


At the end of the course, students will be able to:

-       query database or search engine to retrieve legal information;

-       create a short legal paper on the subject matter of the course;

-       critically approach the introduction of a new technology affecting law and vice-versa;

-       understanding the implications of the technological implementation of law;

-       critically approach the issues related to the protection of the right to privacy and to data protection.
data.degreeProgram: Comparative, European and International Legal Studies (L2)

data.name: Social interaction

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The current course will highlight the social aspects of human-computer interaction and computer- and app-mediated communication. Throughout the course we will analyze the relevance of social psychological theories to predict the success of human computer-interactions and investigate the social effects of computer- and app-mediated communication. Instead of giving a broad overview of these different effects, we will analyze the role of some social psychological theories in human-computer interaction and some specific media effects. At the end of the course students are expected to be able to:

a) apply relevant social aspects in the concept and design of an interface or artifact that is made for human interaction

b) develop an in depth analysis and a critical view on the main social issues and theories that will be discussed during the course

c) communicate in a clear and detailed way ideas, problems, and solutions that are introduced during the course

d) collaborate actively in group discussions and a final group project.

data.name: Managing industrial systems in the context of high product variety
data.description:
The course addresses the context of high product variety in which today industrial systems are functioning. The main goal of the course is to introduce, in a holistic manner, the concepts and tools that can help industrial systems in successful management of high product variety in order to succeed on the market. Main concepts, enablers, tools and techniques addressed by the course are:

  • Group technology
  • Part standardization
  • Product modularization
  • Product platform development
  • Product configurators
  • Form postponement
  • Virtual-build-to-order
  • Single-minute exchange of die (SMED)

All of the techniques/enablers will be looked upon from the point of view of the high product variety context, and how they can help mitigate problems, but also help create opportunities that high product variety brings.

A part of the course will be the practical work with a Configure Price Quote (CPQ) software solution which will be used to develop student projects as one of the outcomes of the course.

During the course students will understand the context of high product variety and the complex consequences this context brings to the industrial systems. Furthermore, students will develop the ability to approach high product variety problematic in their future work in industry from a holistic standpoint.

data.name: Finanza aziendale
data.description: The course covers the foundations of corporate finance, and in particular the methodologies applied to financial decision-making in firms in order to create value to the benefit of shareholders and creditors. Three main areas are covered: (1) a framework for evaluating risk and the market cost of equity and debt financing; (2) capital budgeting and investment valuation; (3) choosing an appropriate financial structure.

data.name: Geotecnica

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
The course aims at providing the basic knowledge usually adopted to approach ordinary geotechnical engineering problems.


By attending in-person lectures and in-class tutorials, the students will:

- Understand what is geotechnical engineering.

- Learn how to describe and classify the ground (generally referred to as "soil").

- Determine the stress state acting in the soil.

- Analyse seepage processes in the soil and understand their effects on the soil mechanical behaviour.

- Learn the tools used to characterise the mechanical behaviour of a soil.

- Analyse the results of the most common in-situ and laboratory tests used to characterise the mechanical behaviour of a soil.

- Identify the key ingredients of soil mechanics commonly adopted in geotechnical design.

data.name: Physics and Chemistry of Materials
Business and Company Law
data.description: The course provides an overview of business law. After some elements of company law from an economic, European and comparative perspective, the course will examine the most relevant topics of company law. Students who have completed the course will be able to understand the essential features of company law in the Member States of the European Union and to provide basic legal advice on company law.
data.degreeProgram: Comparative, European and International Legal Studies (L2)

data.name: Reti

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
We all take it for granted that our smartphone can access a story on social media, that our messages and photos reach their destination, that video calls with family and friends work at the push of a button. But none of these things could exist without the (complex) telecommunication infrastructure that allows them to exchange data: the Internet.


This course introduces the fundamentals (and many details) of the Internet, and computer networks in general. After a first part dedicated to the theoretical foundations of communication networks (e.g., what is a protocol? What architecture do networks have?), the course explores why (that is, for which applications) we need a global network infrastructure; how we ensure end-to-end communications (both in best effort mode and with error control); how data is routed in distributed networks, and how the use of shared communication channels is managed (especially in wireless networks).


At the end of the course the student

  • will know how the Internet and computer networks work
  • will understand the details of the protocols that underpin computer networks

and thanks also to laboratory activities

  • will be able to configure the a network by acting on the main network-layer and transport-layer protocols.

data.name: European security governance between continuity and adaptation
data.description:
The course explores the evolving landscape of security governance in Europe, from the bipolar system of the Cold War to the changing agendas and emerging actors of the post-Cold War period – up to the present. Its main objective is to develop an understanding of the building blocks of European security and their evolution over the years, the scope and modus operandi of the main institutions and organisations dealing with it, and the challenges confronting Europe in the 21st century. 
The course is also designed to encourage the students to analyse complex issues in context and in perspective, and to present them in a comprehensive way. Finally, students will be required to write a short policy paper based on their oral presentations.

data.name: Diritto penale dell'economia
data.description: The first part of the course acts as an introduction, giving a general outline of the subject, with particular emphasis on the technical and legislative particularities of the field, on the issues concerning the "transfer of functions" and on the new area of corporate liability. The second part of the course offers a detailed analysis of the most important cases of bankruptcy and corporate crimes. The aim is to provide students with a solid grounding in the specifics of these areas of criminal legislation. The course also seeks to analyse, through the use of argumentation and logic, the means of application of criminal law by examining and assessing some practical cases.

data.name: Formal Techniques for Cryptographic Protocol Analysis

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description: Aim of the course is to present the main concepts and interpretative tools for studying and understanding critically the role of technologies in contemporary social worlds and relations.

data.name: Sistemi giuridici comparati
Produttività, innovazione e dinamiche d'impresa
data.description: Upon successful completion of this course, students: (i) will know the main definitions of "industry" and its most relevant dynamic characteristics; (ii) will know the main theories on firm growth and its determinants and will be able to discuss firm growth; (iii) will put firm dynamics and firm productivity into perspective within the process of (macro-)economic growth; (iv) will know the main elements of the debate on the micro- and macro-economic effects of Information and Communication Technologies (ICTs); (iv) will know the "Industry Life Cycle" framework; (vi) will interpret the results of the relevant empirical studies in Industrial Dynamics, by applying the concepts described in the previous points.

data.name: Workshop on Financial simulation

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: The course aims at equipping the students with the theoretical and computational methods needed to: (i) mastering tools for statistical/econometric analysis of financial data; (ii) computing numerically fair prices of options; (iii) simulating portfolio loss distributions and computing risk measures. At the end of the course, the student is expected to know the main stylized facts related to price and return distributions, and to be able to implement by means of Matlab the algorithms commonly employed in finance and quantitative risk management.

data.name: Foundations of Analysis
data.description: The goal of the course is the deep study of the field of real numbers with notions to the historical path leading to the modern axiomatization. All important notions and structures of analysis will be (re-)treated, such as: supremum of a set, monotonicity, continuity, differentiation, ordered fields, archimedean fields, complete fields, metric spaces, topological spaces, completeness, compactness, metrizability, cardinality.

data.name: Diritto canonico
data.description:
Learning objectives and expected achievements 
Canon Law, as regulated by the 1983 Code of Canon Law and subsequent legislation, is the right of the Catholic Churchs legal system.
The primary purpose of this course is to highlight the originality and peculiarities of this normative instrument: it is not only the civil communities to adopt normative acts through politics and lawmakers, but also  as the student will learn in this case  religious realities can originate an actual parallel, complete legal system. 
The study of this discipline will allow to appreciate how much Canon Law has influenced and determined the Western legal experience, starting from the very concept of secularism, issued from the verse Give to Caesar what is Caesars, and to God what is Gods.
A number of institutes originated from Canon law and were later modified by secular law; in order to understand, interpret and apply them correctly, it is necessary to develop a deep and critical knowledge of the source from which they originated and which this course aims to provide students with.
Beside an in-depth study of the whole Western legal experience, influenced and in some instances originated from Canon Law, the course also aims to examine the peculiar system relationship between the Catholic Church and Italy, as regulated by the Agreement modifying the Lateran Concordat signed between Italy and the Holy See in 1984. The inclusion of numerous provisions referring to Canon Law for their application makes this law acquire real and actual civil effects: students will thus be able to understand in their complexity the issues belonging to the so called res mixtae (first of all the concordat marriage).
At the end of the course, students will be able: 
-to analyze the constituent and peculiar elements of the law of the Church,
-to appreciate Canon Laws influence on the development of the Western legal experience,
-to understand the normative dimension of the Catholic Churchs system and its institutional structure,
-to analyze different institutes, especially as regards family law (marriage) and the effects (also civil ones) they have by virtue of the 1984 Agreement,
-to know the different normative sources,
-to use the appropriate terminology.

data.name: Gender and Technology in Science Fiction

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description:
This module focuses on how the interaction of gender (in an intersectional perspective) and technology is represented in science fiction literature. In particular, the course aims at exploring the ways in which science fiction has foreseen, represented, supported and/or questioned changes in science and technology and visions of gender, sexuality and ethnicity.

Learning outcomes:

  • to understand science fiction as a genre for representing im/possible futures;
  • to observe how a critical, feminist perspective can question mainstream science fiction, in particular as far as gender and technology are concerned;
  • to reflect on the role of gender in science fiction (i.e. women, lgbtq, non-mainstream authors, characters, topics).

data.name: Laboratorio di test neuropsicologici

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description:
The aim of the course ‘’Neuropsychological assessment lab’’ is to provide the students with fundamental knowledge about the use of the main neuropsychological tests, allowing a correct assessment of cognitive functioning.
By the end of the course, students will be able to: 1) administer specific neuropsychological tests appropriately; 2) follow the guidelines for performance scoring; 3) accurately interpret the results of the neuropsychological assessment.

data.name: Bilancio e principi contabili delle compagnie di assicurazione
Storia delle idee filosofiche e religiose

data.name: Numerical Modeling of Weather and Climate

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description: This course gives an comprehensive introduction into numerical methods used in state-of-the-art global weather and climate prediction models. In a second chapter, a selection of physical parameterizations illustrates how unresolved atmospheric processes are treated in global circulation models. Finally, we study the predictability as a general problem of weather and climate. The usage of ensemble prediction methods as an essential element of the modern weather prediction is outlined. The course combines lectures and simple programming excercises. Later shall help to deepen the understanding and to illustrate the "dry" material of the lectures.

data.name: Lingua inglese I - LM
data.description:
Expertise in translation of tourist texts from Italian to English as a foreign language. Level C1+ both written and oral.
The aim of the 'esercitazioni' is to improve grammar accuracy to a C1+ level, consolidate general and specialized lexis, and learn to write a report focused on tourism.

data.name: Storia della chiesa moderna
data.description:
The Course is devoted to the history of tolerance and intolerance in early modern Europe
The aim of the Course is to give an updated and articulated framework about religious tolerance and intolerance in early modern Europe 
to give an account of the concept of tolerance and his evolution
to give an account of / and reflect on the complexity of religious, social, cultural interactions
to focus on conceptual and methodological issues
to provide methodological elements to contextualize the proposed texts
to develop plural perspectives, also conducting debates/disputationes 
to increase methodological awareness and critical thinking skills
to develop transversal skills: teamworking skills, problem solving skills, presentations skills

At the end of the course students will
Will mature in their understanding and have varied knowledges about the concept and the history of tolerance and intolerance in early modern Europe
Will develop awareness of the concept of tolerance and its complexity
will be able to analyze, contextualize, read critically texts related to the issue of (in)tolerance in early modern Europe   
will be able to debate (disputatio) on (in)tolerance developing convincing arguments
will be able to read, analyze and discuss, and held a well-prepared presentation of a scientific paper/or: sources related to toleration/intolerance

data.name: Signal, Image and Video

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: The course provides the basic competences in the field of digital signal processing, with special attention to images and video sequences. Starting from the fundamentals of 1D signal analysis and processing, analog and numerical, in time and frequency domains, we then extend the concepts to the multi-dimensional case of signals in space. Then, we introduce the more important approaches for image filtering and extraction of image descriptors. These concepts are further extended to deal with motion pictures. Finally, the problem of image compression is introduced, focusing on most known techniques for image and video coding, as well as their standard implementations. The approach of the course is rather practical, with the explanation of theoretical concept followed by their translation into algorithmic terms.

data.name: Crash course - Economics
data.description: At the end of the course students will acquire a basic knowledge of the main concpets and theories used in micro- and macroeconomic analyses. They will also be able to understand and reproduce some graphical analyses of microeconomic models (consumer choices, market demand and supply) and macroeconomic models (production possibilities frontier, aggregate demand and supply).

data.name: Computer vision
data.description: The course aims to provide the student with an in-depth overview on the methods of analysis and management of multimedia data. Starting from the basics of image and video processing, the course will focus on the problems of motion modeling and detection, motion tracking, and object recognition, both by using monocular and multi-view systems.

data.name: Social inequalities: dynamics and policies

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description: By the end of the course, students will have knowledge about specific social policies and their impacts on a variety of outcomes and will understand the principles and theories of life-course analysis. Students will be able to reflect critically on the implications of policies changes and set up the research design for the evaluation of the effects of social policies.

data.name: Sociologia - Corso avanzato

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
What do we mean by social theory? What are the activities that sociologists perform when they “theorize”? What is the relationship of these activities to the broader landscape of sociological research? The course aims to provide at least a basic toolkit to answer to these questions, by highlighting the different meanings of “theory” and the different forms that sociological theorizing takes.
The course gives an overview not only of the different strands of sociological theory, but is designed to expose students to a set of important contributions to sociological theory, with the goal of reconstructing the specific styles of theorizing at work in those authors’ work, and the strategies of theory construction that underline the text.  
The course keeps the traditional division among macro-, micro-, and meso-level theory, and illustrates the contribution of major theorists in these broad areas; at the same time, it presents exemplar cases of sociological theory carried out within those orientations.


Objectives

At the end of the course, the student is expected to:
be familiar with the main streams of theory from the classics of sociology to the present day
be able to identify different styles of theorizing
understand the meaning of central concepts in sociological theory
read critically theoretical work and deconstruct its arguments

data.name: Materials selection for engineering design
data.description: The Course provides the main tools for the selection of materials and relevant processing routes, which better satisfy specific engineering design requirements. The design process is regarded as strictly related to the choice of the best candidate materials, whose specific properties will be therefore considered, together with the relevant processing routes. In this perspective, the Course intends to introduce the students to an alternative, design-led approach to materials science and engineering in the attempt to fill the gap often existing between the optimum design of engineering structures and the selection of suitable materials. At the end of the Course, students will be able to select the best material candidates for designing and manufacturing structures and products, using suitable processing technologies.

data.name: Medicina di laboratorio
data.description: The student will learn the morphological alterations at the cellular and tissutal level that occur in disease. He will understand the distinctive features concurring to the genesis of inflammatory, neoplastic, and degenerative diseases. The molecular basis of these alterations will be emphasized and the tecnhics permitting their recognition will be demonstrated as well as their application for the purposes of research and patient care

data.name: Logical structures in natural language
data.description:
The course addresses topics, problems and methods at the core of current research on natural language semantics, complementing the "Introduction to Human Language" course. At the end of the course, the student is expected to have acquired the following skills:

- Basic understanding of formal logic (propositional and predicate calculus)

- Ability to compute the truth value of a complex formula using truth tables and/or the "tableaux" method. 

- Ability to evaluate the truth value of a formula given a formal model.   

- Ability to translate quantified sentences in natural language (English or Italian) into predicate logic.

- Using lambda calculus to obtain the semantic value of complex expressions from that of their subparts.
 
- Stating problems related to the formal translation of more complex semantic issues such as scope ambiguity o the meaning of plurality, and the distinction between distributive, collective and cumulative predicates in natural language.

- reading a research article in formal semantics and grasping at least its main points.

data.name: Sensors and micro electro-mechanical systems
data.description:
This course offers a general, broad introduction to microsensors and microelectromechanical systems (MEMS), involving devices working across different physical domains. Specifically, the course main topics are: sensing and actuation principles, sensor categories and applications, material properties, fabrication technologies, design and modeling strategies, interface circuit issues, packaging.


After completing the course, the student will be able to:

- understand the physical operation principles of microsensors and actuators; 

- be familiar with state-of-the art processing technologies for microsensors and MEMS;

- describe examples of application of microsensors and actuators implemented in MEMS technology;

- understand the mathematical modeling of selected microsensors and MEMS; 

- perform detailed Finite Element simulations of semiconductor microsensors ;

- evaluate sensor performance and trade-offs between critical design parameters;

- read and understand scientific papers in the relevant field;

- write a scientific report and give an oral presentation in the relevant field.

data.name: Diritto penale
data.description: This course aims to provide students with a thorough understanding of the Italian criminal law system and has the further objective of enabling students to illustrate the main aspects and problem areas of the general principles of the theory of crime and to categorise individual practical cases.

data.name: Tecnica del controllo ambientale

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description: Acquire the basic know-how about the thermal design of the building envelope, the design of the HVAC systems and the integration with renewable sources in order to allow the civil engineer/architect a fruitful interaction with the global design process and/or, to take care of it for simpler buildings.

data.name: Computational physics
data.description:
After completion of the course the student should know the main algorithms commonly used in the numerical solution of physical problems, and have learned the basics of the main simulation techniques for interacting many-particle systems described within non-relativistic quantum physics.
The student should be able to prove she/he has learned the fundamental concepts of the theory, and should be able to:
a) Choose the most suitable algorithm to the solution of a given problem
b) Autonomously write working codes implementing the illustrated algorithms
c) Appropriately use existing software and libraries in support of the self-developed code.

data.name: Crash course - Introduction to international Accounting

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.name: Diritto e genere (gender studies)
data.description:
This course studies gender issues from the point of view of different legal fields, enlighting their common elements and comparing them with the results of other social sciences.
At the end of the course, students will be able to comprehend and properly describe the normative elements, directly or indirectly impacting gender equality. Moreover, they will be able to grasp some innovative sides, in the perspective of the future development.

data.name: Methods for the management and implementation of the innovation process in the company, entrepreneurship and innovative startups
data.description:
The aim of the course is to provide the knowledge and the skills necessary to introduce elements of innovation in companies in the agri-food sector, launching business and / or supply chain initiatives that enhance the typicality and excellence of the territories in which they operate and favouring the transition towards sustainable and quality agri-food production that also includes new market trends (organic, vegan, novel food, etc.).

 

The learning outcomes are aimed at obtaining a figure capable of performing various functions in the organization including:

- the production of new ideas, becoming the creative spirit that develops and seeks new ways and tools for innovation;

- the scouting and exploration of new ideas, acting as a collector of ideas from a wide variety of sources (collection, evaluation and selection);

- the creation of innovation based on the specifics of the objectives or the specifications of the innovation;

- the management of innovation projects, coordinating all the phases and activities of the process including the verification of the achievement of the objectives and the protection of intellectual property;

- the introduction of innovation aimed at the process of continuous improvement and quality management.

 

After attending the course, the student will be able to manage innovation in the entire supply chain, from production to processing, including promotion and marketing, but also to read the evolution of food culture and understand the dynamics of the agri-food markets, considering the evolution of legislation, tastes and consumer behaviour.

data.name: Advanced Topics in Biomathematics
data.description:
The course will be devote to two main areas:
- Mathematical modelling of epidemics.
- Mathematical models in systems biology.
 Competences acquired during the course will be useful in the modeling of many other biological phenomena.

Part 1: mathematical modeling of epidemics
The first part of the course regards the mathematical modeling of epidemics, and to develop mathematical, computational and statistical techniques useful in modeling. The course will include applications to specific examples.
At the end of the course a student is expected to understand the meaning of some of the basic concepts of the mathematical theory of epidemics (basic reproduction number, growth rate, attack rate, mean age at infection, herd immunity .) and their relationships; to be able to build a model for the transmission of an infectious disease, on the basis of the most relevant characteristics of the problem under study; to be able to analyze the main features of a mathematical model of epidemics; to be able to write a code for the simulation and parameter estimation from epidemic data.


Part 2: Mathematical models in systems biology. This part of the course concerns the analysis of models used in systems biology, like the ones to study biochemical reaction and metabolic networks, and their interaction with drug compounds. 
At the end of the course, a student is expected to understand the mathematical basis behind systems biology models; to build and simulate a dynamical model starting from a biological process; to analyze and discuss existing models.

data.name: Storia del pensiero geografico
data.description:
Il corso mira a fornire agli studenti e alle studentesse gli strumenti necessari per muoversi nel sapere geografico comprendendo le peculiarità della disciplina e le differenze rispetto alle altre scienze sociali. Questo obiettivo sarà perseguito attraverso la presentazione dei concetti spaziali che nel tempo hanno fondato il sapere geografico, indagando a fondo la costruzione dei saperi e dell’epistemologia della geografia tra Ottocento e inizio Novecento.

La frequenza del corso consentirà di:

1) sviluppare la comprensione e l'utilizzo dei principali concetti geografici

2) apprendere l'evoluzione dei paradigmi interpretativi e epistemologici della geografia, contestualizzati nel loro contesto storico e spaziale di riferimento;

3) prendere coscienza della natura della geografia come disciplina con vocazione applicativa, atta a rispondere ai bisogni e alle necessità della gestione territoriale.

4) consolidare gli strumenti e le metodologie utili all'analisi dei rapporti tra fonti geostoriche e processi di territorializzazione alle varie scale spaziali

 .

data.name: Statistical methods and data analysis

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description: The aim of the course is to illustrate the basic mathematical tools for the analysis and modeling of experimental data, particularly concerning the main statistical methods. The idea is not simply to describe and discuss the “cooking recipes” for the statistical treatment of data, but also to introduce and analyze in a critical way the statistical models implemented by the computation procedures, stressing their limitations and the actual interpretation of the results.

data.name: Biofisica
data.description:
Biophysics is that branch of knowledge that applies the principles of physics and chemistry and the methods of mathematical analysis and computer modelling to understand how biological systems are made and work.
The course introduces the students to the interdisciplinary approach, with emphasis on physics and physical chemistry, to study the biological functions of cells, tissues, and organisms in terms of the structure and behaviour of biological molecules and molecular assemblies. Topics include molecular mechanisms of transport across biological membranes, the ionic basis of the action potential generation and propagation and the sensory systems organization. The contribution of the physical techniques to provide information about biological molecules (i.e structure, size, shape, dynamics, and modes of interaction), cells (i.e. images of cells, of the subcellular structures, monitoring of cell and intracellular movements) and more complex living systems (i.e. living organisms, human beings.) is highlighted. The pivotal role of biophysics to the progress of human physiology, molecular medicine and diagnostics is also underlined. 

At the conclusion of this course, students will:
a)	Have fundamental knowledge of the properties of biological macromolecules in term of the physical principles which relate their structure and of the mechanisms of their biological function;
b)	Have basic knowledge of some physiological process (such as nerve impulse or visual perception) where physical mechanisms and biological architectures meet to make life able to perform its peculiar mechanisms. 
c)	Be able to deal with the continuous progress of biophysical research and learning from scientific literature.
This course is introductory to medical physics, to study of the interaction of radiation with living matter and to the advanced course Molecular and Cellular Biophysics.

data.name: Crash course - International Business
data.description:
This intensive course aims to form students’ knowledge in the area of International Business. Specifically students will develop capabilities to identify, frame and understand problems related to the management of international operations. Throughout the course issues are discussed in both theoretical and practical terms to stimulate students to relate models and concepts with practical situations.

By the end of the course the students will be able to:
•	discuss implications of globalization and cultural differences 
•	understand the implications of operating across national borders 
•	compare different internationalization processes 
•	describe how firms operate in different markets
•	analyze different international strategies and organizational structures
•	evaluate and criticize different leadership and control models
•	describe the specificity of different functions and units within the international firm
•	understand the basis for the competitive advantage of international firms

Storia medievale III
data.description:
The training objective of the course is to develop precise and in-depth knowledge, skills and competences relating to 

1) the most significant historical facts that marked the early communal period

2) methods of analysing written and iconographic sources from the 11th and 12th centuries

3) recent historiographical interpretations. 

Attendance and participation in the training activities proposed by the course and individual study will ensure that students are able to 

- define and describe the main historical issues relating to the rise of the communes with precision in terms of references, specific vocabulary and chronological references

- Recognise and interpret the different types of written and iconographic historical sources

- Analysing and commenting on a historiographical text

- Analysing a historical map

- Be able to define and use specific medieval terms

data.name: Gestione sostenibile delle imprese
data.description:
The course aims to present how to incorporate sustainable methods into all aspects of an organization and to describe the most important tools for monitoring, managing and improving environmental performance.
Attendance and active participation at the course and self-study will enable students to:
1. Know the role of the management in developing an environmentally and socially responsible enterprise
2. Know and Apply Environmental Communication Tools
3. Organize the activities to carry out an environmental audit
4. Identify and Measure some environmental costs in the firms budget

data.name: Iconografia e iconologia
data.description:
The course aims to


  • introduce students to one of the most fundamental aspects of art-history, namely iconography, as well as to iconology, i.e. the interpretative method deriving from it;
  • make students aware of the profound methodological development which art-history has undergone during the last two centuries;
  • provide students with those tools which are indispensable in order to identify the subject of religious as well as profane works of art;
  • make students aware that today's visual culture is imbued with imagery of the past. Understanding this should help them decoding the messages that contemporary images may hide.

data.name: Distributed systems for measurement and automation

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The instructional goals of the course is to acquire a comprehensive overview of the distributed systems for measurement and automation used today in industrial and service application domains. The course focuses on the most advanced technological solutions adopted in industry as well as on the theoretical aspects that arise when control or estimation are applied in a distributed context. Particular emphasis will be given to robotic perception using Artificial Intelligence techniques to be applied to robotic problems.

During the course, the focus will be on the design and implementation of distributed estimators to be used for intelligent autonomous systems in industrial and service environments, analyzing the resulting problems from both a practical and theoretical point of view. Examples of the application of these techniques on real or realistic systems will be presented during the course.

At the end of the course, the student will be able to:

- Understand the complexity, the issues and the potentialities of distributed systems;

- Compare the various different technological solutions available for a distributed system;

- Evaluate and analyze the practical and theoretical implications of a distributed measurement and/or perception system;

- Analyse and design the distributed solution for a particular system;

- Critically asses the benefits and the limitations of a distributed solution.

data.name: Corso di francese A1 - I periodo (estensivo)
Ingegneria degli acquiferi e dei siti contaminati

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description: The course provides the students with the skills needed for the design of remediation actions and management of contaminated sites, as well as the design of sustainable utilization systems of subsurface water resources in view of the impact of climate change and the growing anthropic pressure. Attention is given to the interaction between groundwater and underground structures and groundwater protection. The first part of the course deals with the design of remediation systems for groundwater and contaminated sites, as well as the design of efficient and sustainable groundwater exploitation systems. The second part of the course deals with the study of the physical and biogeochemical processes controlling the occurrence and the quality of groundwater. Flow and transport modeling is considered here because instrumental to the modern design of water exploitation and remediation systems for contaminated sites. The students will acquire the skills needed for the design of effective remediation systems of contaminated sites, the design of groundwater utilization systems as well as to quantify the interaction between groundwater and underground infrastructures.

data.name: Biologia computazionale

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description:
The aim of the course is to study the fundamental topics of computational biology. This course will provide students with the basis to understand theoretical concepts and apply computational tools to several aspects of biological data analysis.
At the end of the course, students will be able to:
  a) understand and explain the presented computational biology methods and their application
  b) understand and describe the impact of key parameters on the output of these methods
  c) understand the importance and construction of biological data analysis pipelines
  d) select the most appropriate method to solve a given computational biology task
  e) apply computational tools to real data and interpret the results

data.name: Ultrasound Technologies for Medical Applications

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description: This course consists of two parts. In the first part, core topics such as the piezoelectric phenomenon, the physics of ultrasound propagation, modeling, and nonlinear acoustics will be introduced. This will provide the students with the basic knowledge necessary to understand the potentials and the limitations of ultrasound technologies. The second part will then focus on probe design, system architecture of ultrasound scanners, image formation and beam forming, and emerging medical applications (e.g. lung ultrasonography, brain and cancer imaging). The objective of the course is to form students that are not only familiar with the fundamentals and state-of-the-art applications of ultrasound technology, but also able to critically evaluate the technology itself and potentially improve it further.

They will learn fundamental aspects of the theory and how to apply the theory to practical cases with the use of a statistical software.

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
The course aims to introduce the students to the language and concepts of the Political Science, the main democratic institutions, the public policy analysis, and the interactions between the nation states and the European and International political context.
At the end of the course the student:

This course provides basic knowledge of chemistry required to understand chemical phenomena (reactions), structures and properties of main industrial chemical compounds. 
As a result, students should be able to describe a chemical reaction performing both material and energy balances, taking into account the structural informations on molecules acquired during the course.

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

By the end of the course, students will be able to:

- describe serious games and gamification, listing the main charateristics, features in common, and differences between the two;

- report the main theories and elements at the basis of the effectiveness of serious games and gamification;

- differentiate between different modalities of gamification;

- analyze a gamified software, identify the game elements included, and evaluate how those game elements can contribute to motivating users;

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The course aims to provide students with the tools to effectively set up a company's financial decisions in order to create value for the benefit of owners and creditors.

By the end of the course, students will be able to: (1) estimate the price of a company's main financing instruments, shares and bonds; (2) calculate the cash flows of a company's investment projects and correctly apply the selection criteria; (3) estimate the cost of capital and the cost of debt of a company; (4) understand the actual choices made by companies regarding financial structure.

data.name: Optoelectronics and quantum devices for sensing and automation
data.description:
The course provides the basic knowledge of optoelectronics and photonics both classical and quantum including the generation and measurement of light for various applications. At the end of the course the student will be able to:

- know the theoretical concepts at the base of optoelectronics and the interaction of light with matter;

- solve simple physical problems through correct modelling and use of the mathematical tools necessary to reach the quantitative solution.

Attendance and active participation in the training activities proposed by the course (lectures and classroom exercises) and individual study will allow students to:

1) be familiar with the basics of the scientific method applied to the topics of the course;

2) acquire the habit of critical analysis of concepts that enter into scientific and physical theories in particular;

3) participate in lab demonstrations on the topics of the course.

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description:
The course aims to provide the students with the basis for understanding the main cellular characteristics of the different tumor types and the processes involved in neoplastic transformation. At the end of this course, the student will be able to:

b) Describe in details the "Hallmarks of cancer";

c) Explain the fundamental differences between tumor suppressor genes and oncogenes;

data.name: Affective computing

data.description: This course explores computing research that relates to, arises from, or deliberately influences emotion and affect. The aim is to identify the important research issues, and to ascertain potentially fruitful future research directions in relation to the multimodal emotion analysis and to human-computer interaction. At the end of the course the students will know the state of the art in affective computing and will be able to write a research proposal on this theme.

data.name: Effective Managerial Decision Making
data.description:
Throughout their personal and professional lives, managers have to take multitudes of decisions. The general purpose of this course is to familiarise you with problems associated with unaided managerial decision making, as well as with structured decision aiding techniques aiming to overcome these problems. Students will also obtain an understanding of the thinking processes that underlie judgement and decision making, and its systematic errors and biases.

The course will be organised in two parts. (1) The first, smaller, part will focus on the psychology of judgement and decision-making. You will be familiarized with psychological research demonstrating that humans have bounded rationality and are susceptible to systematic errors and biases. We will briefly cover the heuristics and biases approach and prospect theory. (2) The second, more substantial, part concerns decision aiding tools. You will be presented with structured decision aiding techniques that aim to improve the quality of managerial decisions in the realm of business as well as public policy. Their core concept is simplification, breaking a complex problem into a number of simpler problems. For each technique, you will be presented with the steps that it involves and how to apply it to real-life problems. We will discuss SMART, planning networks, decision trees, simulation, and financial analysis. We will also discuss how to be more effective in bargaining and negotiation, which is another central activity in management.

By the end of the course students should have acquired:
-an in-depth understanding of why unaided decision making is often biased. This involves attaining a good grasp of the psychology of judgement and decision making. Students should also be able to cite and critically evaluate empirical evidence.
-an understanding of the various decision-aiding techniques including: the contexts in which each technique should be applied, the steps that they involve, and the benefits/shortcomings of each. Importantly, the students should have also acquired the ability to apply such techniques to solve novel problems.
-an understanding of Raiffa's decision-analytic approach to negotiation, and the ability to apply it to negotiation problems.
-the ability to read journal articles, understand and discuss the main theoretical points and evidence, and critically evaluate them.
