data.name: Diritto privato
data.description:
Knowledge and understanding. Students will be able to:

1. understand what conflicts of interest arise in the fields of personal law, property law, contract law and obligations and how the Italian legal system deals with them;

2. trace the essential outlines of the Italian legal system in solving problems in the above-mentioned fields, with particular reference to the basic choices in the field of property law, and identify the reasons that justify the approach of the Italian private legal system, including its particular socio-economic context and its political choices

3. know the most important principles, notions and rules of which the Italian legal system is composed in the field of private law.

Applied knowledge and understanding. Students will be able to:

4. analyse and critically evaluate the solutions offered by the Italian legal system in the areas of personal law, property law, contract law and obligations;

5. use technical legal terminology when discussing issues relating to the aforementioned topics

6. resolve complex cases of the Italian legal system, also by examining its efficiency and internal justice.

These two topics are fundamental for a Computer Scientist, as they are crucial tools in understanding widely used techniques in Artificial Intelligence, Machine Learning, Statistical Learning, and Data Science.

data.name: Lingua e traduzione francese e letteratura francese
Filosofia della scienza - LM
data.description: The course will be devoted to the main elements of Kant’s theory of science, addressing the main interpretive issues raised in modern times and their implications for contemporary philosophy of science. In particular, the course will present and discuss the Kantian philosophy of mathematics (with reference to issues like the analytic/synthetic distinction, the relation between logic and mathematics, the nature and role of intuition in mathematics) and the Kantian philosophy of physics (with reference to issues like the transcendental foundation of Newtonian physics, the role of schematism, the nature of causation). The conclusions that will be reached will allow to discuss whether and to what extent it is still possible to defend a neo-transcendental approach to the foundations of scientific knowledge.

data.name: Intellectual property rights
data.description: The course aims to introduce students to the study of the intellectual property rights, by critically analysing a selection of topics characterizing this area.

data.name: Psicologia del linguaggio e della comunicazione

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description:
The course offers an introduction to human communication and the mechanisms involved in language comprehension and production. Students will also have the opportunity to construct a product/instrument of communication. Such enterprise will be accomplished in small groups and will then be presented to the class.
Students will acquire basic knowledge about verbal and non-verbal communication mechanisms; will be able to analyze and categorize communicative acts on the bases of their functions and features; will work in group to plan/design an artifact/product of communication; will be able to present and discuss their work in public meeting.

data.name: Economic History
data.description:
The objective of the course is to provide (1) adequate knowledge of the major transformations of the European and world economies from the pre-industrial age to the contemporary era and the underlying factors; (2) the skills necessary to understand, analyze and critically interpret these transformations.

Upon completion of the course, the student will be able to:

- remember the basic concepts useful in the analysis of an economic system;

- describe the main historical manifestations of economic growth/development and crises;

- explain their causes and consequences, grasping the interaction between economic aspects and technological, institutional, cultural and geographical factors;

- communicate effectively in oral and written form, and argue on an economic historical topic.

data.name: Distributed estimation for robots and vehicles
data.description:
The instructional goals of the course is to acquire a comprehensive overview of the distributed systems for measurement and automation used today in industrial and service application domains. The course focuses on the most advanced technological solutions adopted in industry as well as on the theoretical aspects that arise when control or estimation are applied in a distributed context. Particular emphasis will be given to robotic perception using Artificial Intelligence techniques to be applied to robotic problems.

During the course, the focus will be on the design and implementation of distributed estimators to be used for intelligent autonomous systems in industrial and service environments, analyzing the resulting problems from both a practical and theoretical point of view. Examples of the application of these techniques on real or realistic systems will be presented during the course.

At the end of the course, the student will be able to:

- Understand the complexity, the issues and the potentialities of distributed systems;

- Compare the various different technological solutions available for a distributed system;

- Evaluate and analyze the practical and theoretical implications of a distributed measurement and/or perception system;

- Analyse and design the distributed solution for a particular system;

- Critically asses the benefits and the limitations of a distributed solution.

data.name: Business development laboratory
data.description: Being all classes in English, only English syllabus is available

data.name: Filologia romanza I - LM
data.description: This course is designed to provide Students specializing in Spanish language and literature with an opportunity to enhance philological knowledge and to go deeper into an area of interest related to Textual Criticism, Studies in Medievalism, and the formal practices of literary interpretation and translation, gaining expertise in bibliographic searches and literature-related online tools (i.e. corpora and electronic text databases).
data.degreeProgram: Letterature euroamericane, traduzione e critica letteraria (LM)

data.name: Sociologia della religione

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
Like all cultural phenomena, even the religious one tends to be unproblematized and to be summarized in the evidence that materializes before our eyes. In reality, religious phenomena have a founding and structuring role, that is, they are sources of normative action that changes the face of entire societies. The main purpose of the course is precisely to acquire such awareness.
For these reasons the course is divided into two parts.
The first aims to provide the constitutive elements of religiously oriented action.
In this, Weber's analysis of religious action will be treated. In the second part, of monographic orientation, the position and functions of Catholicism in the Italian context will be analyzed.

data.name: Metallic materials engineering
data.description:
The course covers the main manufacturing technologies of metallic materials: forming by plastic deformation and with chip removal and welding, with particular reference to:

• the mechanical aspects;

• the microstructural evolution;

• the tribological interactions between the workpiece and the tools.

After completing the course, the student will be able to perform a preliminary design of the manufacturing systems: rolling, forging, extrusion, drawing, sheet metal forming and forming by chip removal.

The student will also be able to select and manage the manufacturing processes according to the metallurgical quality of the product, with special emphasis to the formation of ductile cracks (use of the criterion for ductile fracture).

The student will be able to select the best engineering surface treatment to optimize the performance of the tools.

The student will be able to design a welding process, with reference the the microstructural quality of the weldments.

The student will be able to carry out a preliminary selection of the technology to make a metal product.

The course covers the main heat treatments and surface hardening processes of metallic materials with particular reference to:

• solid state transformations involved;

• the microstructural evolution;

• the microstructure-properties correlation;

• the proper selection of processing parameters.

The student will learn the basic physical metallurgy aspects necessary to understand solid state phase transformations in metallic materials.

The student be able to make considerations regarding the thermodynamics and kinetics of processes treatment of steels.

The student will acquire useful competences for microstructural analysis and to design the heat and surface treatment process to achieve specific materials properties.

data.name: Chimica
data.description:
AIMS OF TEACHING
The course aims to introduce students to the experimental and theoretical foundations of chemistry and to make them to acquire the necessary technical skills to move in a chemistry lab. 
The most relevant aims of the course are:
a)to relate the chemical knowledge to interpret real phenomena from everyday life
b)to develop adequate chemistry skills and language properties to address and discuss with scientific rigor research fields in which chemistry plays a central role
c)to reach a good understanding, both from a theoretical and practical point of view, of the basic concepts of chemistry, such as the atomic structure, the stoichiometry of the chemical processes, the intra- and intermolecular aspects of chemical bonding, the thermodynamics and kinetics of chemical processes, the properties of ideal and real solutions, the chemical equilibrium in homogeneous and heterogeneous phase, the acid-base equilibria and electrochemistry.
The main aims of the laboratory module are:
a)the familiarization with the basic techniques, equipments and procedures essential for conducting operations in a chemical laboratory; 
b)the practical verification of some fundamental aspects of chemistry covered during the theoretical course

LEARNING OUTCOMES

1)Define the different states and properties of matter, the chemical and physical transformations. Define  isotopes, molecules, ions, anions, cations and allotropes. 
2)Describe the peculiarities of acid-base and redox chemical reactions and know the methods to balance them. Define the limiting reagent and the yield of a reaction and be able to use them in the problem solving approach to stoichiometry
3)Describe the electronic configuration of the atoms also in connection with their periodic properties. Describe the various types of chemical bonds and the geometrical properties of the molecules. Knowing the fundamentals of theories to predict the molecular shape: notation of Lewis; VSEPR; valence bond; molecular orbitals
4)Know how to contextualize the principles of thermodynamics learned in previous Physics Courses to their applications to chemical processes. Understand the nature and characteristics of the state of chemical equilibrium of a system. Knowing the expression of the equilibrium constant. Knowing the numerical methods to calculate the equilibrium concentrations and be able to solve problems related to the chemistry of equilibrium systems. Be aware of ways to express the concentration units of the solutions and know how to use them in laboratory problems. Describe the colligative properties and their  thermodynamic bases.
5)Know the auto-protolysis of water and its role in acid-base processes .Evaluate with approximate and rigorous methods the pH of a solution of strong acids and bases as well as weak acids and bases. Describe the characteristics of the buffer solutions and their preparation. Describe the hydrolysis of salts. Describe the precipitation reactions and the expression of the solubility product. Be able to calculate the solubility of a chemical compound in different external conditions. 
6)Describe the working principles of the galvanic cells. Knowing the use of standard potentials and the general aspects of the Nernst law. Describe the factors that affect the rate of chemical transformations and know the basis of Chemical Kinetics

data.name: Economia dei sistemi agro-alimentari
data.description:
Objective of this course is to provide a framework for understanding and analyzing the role and the evolution of agro-food systems.
Attendance and active participation at three training activities proposed by the course (lectures, small assignments, team group work) and self-study will enable students to:
a) Summarize the structure of the agro-food system in Italy and its recent evolution 
b) Compare the different forms of environmental friendly agriculture based on their sustainability 
c) Interpret the results of simple econometric estimations of demand functions for agro-food products 
d) Compare different approaches to study the agro-food system 
e) Compare the different forms of organization in the agro-food system
f) Analyze the role of quality regulation and certification in the agro-food system.

data.name: Letteratura inglese III
data.description: This module, entitled "Poetics and Ecology: Texts and Contexts of English Romanticism", aims at enhancing students' competence in critically interpreting a poetical text in relation to style, content, and context.

data.name: Diritto commerciale
data.description: Knowledge of the basic concepts of commercial law.

data.name: Materials for energy
data.description:
At the end of the course students will know:

(i) the principles of combustion science and will be able to make mass and energy balances;

(ii) they will know the main types of pollutants and how these depend on the type of flame.

They will also be familiar with the main types of materials (and their developmental issues) used for electricity storage (batteries and supercapacitors), energy transformation (fuel cell), hydrogen storage and CO2 capture, and for the removal of pollutants in combustion processes. Finally they will have the knowledge and skills to design innovative ceramic materials obtained from preceramic polymers and to use them in the field of energy materials.
data.degreeProgram: Materials and production Engineering - Ingegneria dei materiali e della produzione (LM)

data.name: Letteratura tedesca III
Biomaterials and biomedical technologies
data.description:
Natural and synthetic materials have increasingly wider applications for the fabrication of devices and prostheses used to repair or substitute damaged body tissues, organs and functions. Due to the complexity of the phenomena affecting the relationships between the body and prosthetic material, and to the variety and the duration of their functions, prosthetic materials must be carefully selected and designed, following biological, physico-chemical and engineering considerations.

The course is addressed to students wishing to acquire knowledge of the use and characteristics of biomaterials, and will provide information on the design of a biomaterial or a prosthesis.

data.name: Corrosion and degradation control of materials
data.description:
Course purpose

The purpose of this course is to introduce the underlying science of corrosion and the fundamentals of corrosion engineering. This course will examine the general mechanisms of corrosion and relate these specific engineering issues and methods being used to reduce the impact of corrosion. Case studies and typical applications in industries will be discussed. 


Learning outcomes

Expected learning outcomes for the student are to define the key aspects of a corrosion situation, to recommend a course of action for analysis and to decide a plan for remediation.

The course contains background for understanding various corrosion processes, corrosion inhibition strategies and materials selection with practical examples. Based on physical chemical theory, the student shall be able to evaluate if corrosion can occur under specific operating conditions in a given equipment or construction. In cases where corrosion can occur, the

student shall be able to determine the probable corrosion type, estimate the corrosion rate and

identify the critical parameters.

data.name: Cyber Security Risk Assessment

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
Course's Objectives Most CS professionals will actually use, buy, or sell security technology and make security decisions. They don't design protocols, nor crypto algorithms, they decide which security technology they are going to use. The course provides the fundamentals to chose the appropriate security technology based on balancing threat and controls, costs, impact and likelihood of events. In other words the course will teach students to manage risk. The course will introduce students to the key principles of Security Risk Assessment (Risk and Threat Analysis, Risk Assessment, Control Frameworks) both qualitatively and quantitatively. The student will identify threats and the corresponding security controls appropriate for two industrial case studies. Intended Learning Outcomes Regular and active participation in the teaching activities offered by the course (lectures, laboratories and group work) and in independent study and project activities will enable students to:
  • understand the fundamentals of risk management;
  • identify the relevant assets and the corresponding impacts of possible threats for a moderately complex case study;
  • mitigate threats with control according to the risk appetite of a relevant stakeholder;
  • quantitatively estimate, for the particular case of cyber threats, the technical impact of vulnerabilities and the particular impact on their presence in a company's enviroment;
  • quantitatively estimate the overall risk for a large scale network.
In terms of soft skills, active participation in the group-based teaching activities will enable students to learn how to organize group work, apply problem-solving techniques, deliver a presentation, and support their results with compelling arguments. At the end students who successfully passed the course should be able to prepare and defend a cyber risk assessment, identifying the threats and the security controls and the residual risk for an industrial case study of moderate complexity.

data.name: International Economic Law
Logical Structures of Natural Language

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The course addresses topics, problems and methods at the core of current research on natural language semantics, complementing the "Introduction to Human Language" course. At the end of the course, the student is expected to have acquired the following skills:

- Basic understanding of formal logic (propositional and predicate calculus)

- Ability to compute the truth value of a complex formula using truth tables and/or the "tableaux" method. 

- Ability to evaluate the truth value of a formula given a formal model.   

- Ability to translate quantified sentences in natural language (English or Italian) into predicate logic.

- Using lambda calculus to obtain the semantic value of complex expressions from that of their subparts.
 
- Stating problems related to the formal translation of more complex semantic issues such as scope ambiguity o the meaning of plurality, and the distinction between distributive, collective and cumulative predicates in natural language.

- reading a research article in formal semantics and grasping at least its main points.

data.name: Psicologia sociale

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description:
This course intends to provide students with the basic notions of Social Psychology. This discipline studies the social and cognitive processes that determine how individuals understand themselves and the social world, and how individuals influence and interact with each other. At the end of the course students will be able to:
a) know and understand the basic notions of the discipline with a particular reference to the main theories and the research methodology of Social Psychology.
b) develop the capacity for autonomous critical thinking (discern, judge, and possibly question) the social phenomena that will be dealt with during the course.
c) acquire the learning skills needed for a continuous learning process in Psychology and Social Sciences in general (e.g., to undertake advanced studies).
data.degreeProgram: Scienze e Tecniche di Psicologia Cognitiva (L2)

data.name: Armi nucleari e disarmo
data.description: The aim of the course is to discusss some of the "social" aspects of nuclear physics. In particular we intend to deal with the militar aspects, in an hystorical perspective and referring to situations of international confrontation. Therefore it is expected that at the end of the course the student will be aware of the correlations between militar and civil use of nuclear energy, of their developments, and of the consequences on the present political global order, referring in particular to nuclear weapons and proliferaton, disarmament and relative international treaties.

data.name: Corso di tedesco B1a - I periodo (estensivo)
Corso di tedesco A1b - I periodo (estensivo)
The drug discovery process and the role of biomarkers in achieving personalized medicine
Genomics and Drug Discovery

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description:
The course is aimed at providing the basis for the understanding of modern proteomic and genomic applications, including high-throughput biology platforms, to the development of new therapies and novel drugs, from novel target identification to the study of mechanistic and disease-based biomarkers. Examples of applications of genomic or proteomic approaches during the various steps of the development of a target up to clinical trials will be provided. 

On completion of this course the students should become able to:
- illustrate the principles and the characteristics of the most common genomic ad proteomic techniques
- describe their main applications in the biomedical field 
- describe the key steps in the drug discovery process and the main therapeutic modalities
- qualify potential targets based on the strength of their biological rationale
 - explain, by using key examples, how genomic approaches are revolutionizing drug discovery
- illustrate the characteristics and the ideal properties of a biomarker in the context of drug discovery and in the clinical practice
- explain how the use of biomarkers and pharmacogenomic approaches are enabling for personalized medicine

data.name: Agiografia I
data.description: The course aims to offer students an adequate preparation in the field of hagiographic literature, with particular attention to the phenomenon of the rewriting of texts for the purposes of preaching. At the end of the course, students should know the topics covered during the course and a thorough knowledge of the bibliography.

data.name: Architettura tecnica 1 con Laboratorio Progettuale

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
The course aims to provide the basic knowledge and basic tools to understand and deal with the design and construction of the building deepening the technical-construction issues. The synthesis process between the conception of the shape and the constructive feasibility of a building is defined through the discussion of principles to be placed at the basis of the design activity, and through the interpretation of the building itself from a technical perspective. The building is analyzed as a sum of elements with specific roles in relation to load bearing capacity, to the classification of the spaces as well as of environmental comfort conditions. After the course, the student will be able to:

• understand the buildings and recognize the systems and sub-systems of components and their relationships; define and attribute requirements and performance capabilities to the different systems in relation to the needs of the end users (KNOWLEDGE AND UNDERSTANDING);

• develop the design of a simple building with particular reference to the shape and materials of the building components and sub-components; define the correlation between the parts of the building to ensure safety and environmental comfort (APPLYING KNOWLEDGE AND UNDERSTANDING);

• Make informed and reasonable design choices that or contribute to design choices developed in working groups (MAKING JUDGEMENTS);

• Use an appropriate technical language to communicate and prepare accurate project documents; refine the drawing tools and methods in order to effectively represent the design choices at the different scales of representation. (COMMUNICATION SKILLS);

• Refer to additional bibliographic material (e.g. technical handbooks, laws and regulations, websites of manufacturers in the construction sector, etc.) in order to extend the acquired technical knowledge; develop relationship and teamwork skills (LEARNING SKILLS).

data.name: Neuroscienze comportamentali

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description:
The course aims at introducing students to the basics of behavioral neuroscience in light of the results of the latest research in psychophysiology, neuroscience, cognitive psychology and neuropsychology.

At the end of the course students will be able to:
• understand the neurophysiological mechanisms of some important brain processes and how brain structure and functions underlie behavior
• to relate models of cognitive psychology and the empirical evidence of neurophysiological and neuroimaging studies.
data.degreeProgram: Scienze e Tecniche di Psicologia Cognitiva (L2)

data.name: Prototyping interactive systems

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The main objective of the course is to provide theoretical and practical knowledge on prototyping in a design process, with a specific focus on graphical user interfaces. On the completion of the course, the students will be able to: - articulate the rationale for prototyping as a design tool - proficiently use at least one appropriate tool to create prototypes - name, recognize and apply the main principles of interaction design at the micro-level - analyze and criticize a graphical interface in terms of micro-level design principles.


Furthermore, the course aims at fostering soft skills regarding effective communication of results by clear and adequate oral presentation.

data.name: Partial Differential Equations
data.description:
Aim of the course is that of presenting the most relevant types of partial differential equations (elliptic, parabolic, hyperbolic: especially in the linear case), together with the physical models that they describe. Specifically, the functional framework is introduced and it is shown to be suitable for clarifying under which conditions the problems associated with these differential equations are well-posed (existence, uniqueness, stability); [Only for 9-credit course: the students are then introduced to elliptic regularity and maximum principles.]

At the end of the course the student will be able to get oriented among the various types of partial differential equations, to know which are the characteristic qualitative properties of the solutions, to have a deeper knowledge of the mathematical approach to these problems as well as some fluency in the use of modern techniques for the study of these themes.

data.name: Geometry and Topology for Data Analysis
data.description:
The course is aimed at both students of the curriculum of applied mathematics interested in data analysis and students of the curriculum of pure mathematics interested in higher geometry. 

The goal is to offer an introduction to computational algebraic topology and algebraic geometry, with the emphasis on applications ("Topological Data Analysis"). At the end of the course the student is expected to be able to:
- master the fundamental concepts of algebraic topology and algebraic geometry
- understand the possible applications of computational topology and geometry
- individually study a chapter of a higher mathematics text in English
- publicly expose and discuss a topic of higher mathematics in a group

data.name: Advanced Statistical Methods
data.description: The student, at the end of this class, (i) will be able to use classic and modern techniques to study asymptotic behavior of estimators and other relevant quantities in statistical inference as well as to use asymptotic approximations. (ii) will be able to use the techniques based on U-statistics to study the behavior of estimators in non parametric settings (iii) will known the techniques to study convergence of empirical processes with particular regards to concentration measures, uniform law of large numbers and metric entropy.

data.name: International Trade and Globalisation
data.description:
The goal of this course is to identify and to map, empirically and theoretically, the main phenomena of the current trade system in the global economy. The course provides insights into the reasons for trade at country and firm level, gains from trade, trade policy tools and international agreements, as well as contexts in which students can engage in debate, discussion, and reflections on the main issues related to trade policies.

By the end of the course students should have acquired:

• an in-depth understanding of the different advantages and costs of trade from various viewpoints of trade theory.

• the use of the necessary basic tools (f. i. some basic trade indices) to analyse, at country and firm level, the contemporary international and European trade relations.

• to apply theoretical perspectives in analysing related policy questions, especially the effects of trade barriers and industry protection.

• to understand the structure and functioning of international trading system and associated institutions (such as the WTO) and regional trade agreements.

data.name: Agri-food law: introductory notions and the regulation of innovation in agri-food law (EU-FLAG Jean Monnet)
data.description:
The course is organized within Jean Monnet Module EU-Food Law and Globalization (EUFLAG). The aim of the course is threefold: 1. providing students with basic knowledge about the regulation on the production and marketing of agricultural and food products; 2. introducing students to the distinction between public and private regulatory tools and highlighting their pros and cons in the global context; 3. identifying the legal strategies and instruments available to protect innovation in the agri-food sector. The course will emphasize the process of progressive internationalisation of regulatory frameworks and the interdisciplinary nature of legal knowledge.
At the end of the course, students should be able: 1. to identify the main regulatory issues in a given context, taking also into account their international and comparative dimensions; 2. to interact with regulators and legal professionals, in a critical a dialogic way, in order to properly manage such issues; 3.tTo employ both public and private regulatory tools as leverages to advance development and innovation; 4. to identify the strategies to legally protect innovation in the agri-food realm.

data.name: Introduzione alla Data Science per fisici
data.description:
By the end of the course the student will be able to

1. Have a correct understanding of the fundaments of the data-science/machine-learning approach. 

2. Given a dataset and a question,  evaluate whether it is possible to apply a machine-learning approach, and to estimate its predictive value.

3. Extract the most relevant informations from a database (cleaning and dimensionality reduction), and construct machine-learning workflows.

data.name: Sistemi informativi per il turismo
data.description:
The course introduces the fundamental principles of information systems. The course teaches the basic concepts to define and identify information systems modules according to the activities to be supported.  Focusing on web-based information systems, the second part of the course introduces a method to analyse and design an effective web presence strategy.
After completing the course, the student will be able to:
- know and classify information systems and their use in tourism
- know the principles and the protocols of Internet and Web
- apply requirements elicitation and analysis techniques 
- evaluate website quality according to a goal-oriented approach
- model, evaluate and plan web presence strategies
- analyse and manage online reputation.
data.degreeProgram: Management della sostenibilità e del turismo (LM)

data.name: Fisica computazionale
data.description: After completion of the course the student should know the main algorithms commonly used in the numerical solution of physical problems, and have learned the basics of the main simulation techniques for interacting many-particle systems described by classical physics. The student should be able to prove she/he has learned the fundamental concepts of the theory, and should be able to: a) Choose the most suitable algorithm for the solution of a given problem b) Autonomously write working codes implementing the illustrated algorithms

data.name: Geometria e algebra lineare con elementi di statistica

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description: The aim of the course is to provide the basic notions, theoretical and computational, of linear algebra and analytic geometry in the plane and in the space. At the end of the course the student will be able to work with vector spaces, linear systems, matrices, linear functions, eigenvalues and eigenvectors, besides with straight-lines and planes in the space in terms of their parametric and Cartesian representations. - They will know the basic language and concepts of Probability Calculation and will be able to use them to describe and model simple models of random experiments. - They will know the basic concentrates relating to random variables and will be able to illustrate and apply them in the measurement of quantities and in the collection of statistical data. - They will know intuitively, through examples and without a formal presentation, the properties of the sample mean, the law of large numbers, the central theorem of the limit. - They will be able to apply the knowledge acquired to simple problems of both point estimation and interval between statistical inference.

data.name: Organizzazione e risorse umane

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description: The need to regulate in a consistent manner the relationship between people and organization is one of the areas of greatest attention in the enterprises operating in the most competitive sectors, but increasingly also in the nonprofit sector organizations and public institutions (local authorities, social health services, schools, public utilities). The challenge is to create an area of partial convergence between the different interests at stake in order to give rise to an "exchange ratio" favorable both to individuals (especially with regard to their development projects) and to the organization's purpose (in particularly in terms of quality of the services offered to customers and users, management of economy and creation of conditions for competitiveness). The course aims to develop the knowledge necessary to understand the logic that be oriented towards the management and staff development. After completing the course, students will be able to assess the likely effect (especially in terms of performance, motivation and participation) of performance evaluation measures, analysis and skills development, review of pay systems. At the same time, the course will encourage the development of a technical/specialized language, indispensable to interact effectively with other roles and organizational sectors not only in the performance of staff development projects, but also with regard to other specialized support activities (for example, in the performance of selections). The classroom teaching will make use of cases, exercises and simulations to be held in sub-groups during the lessons. An opportunity to explore the modalities of application of theoretical models, through the reference to the concrete experiences, and to develop some basic operating skills in professionalizing value will be provided for the attending students.

data.name: Human Computer Interaction

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The course has the general objective of providing students with the fundamental notions about the interaction between humans and computerized systems. In particular, the course is focused on the principles of the User-Centered-Design methodology, as well as on their application during the design and evaluation of interfaces of various types and for various domains.

Upon successful completion of this module, students should be able to:

- Design and critically assess the user interface of an interactive system as well as the interaction modalities afforded by it
- Use tools, techniques and models for the design and evaluation of the interaction
- Understand the needs and the role of the user and relate them to the design of usable interactive systems
- Know the fundamentals of the human cognitive processes and their implications for the design of interactive interfaces
- Develop prototypes of interfaces of websites and mobile apps, considering usability aspects as well as the peculiarities of the interaction
- Understand the concepts of accessibility, inclusiveness and Universal Design related to the design of interactive systems

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.name: Prova di conoscenza linguistica L.M. - Inglese in ambito economico
data.description:
On completion of the course, students will be able to:
1. understand the main facts and supporting details of a complex text on both concrete and abstract topics relevant to the sphere of economics and management, including current events. 
2. interact with a degree of fluency and spontaneity in a variety of simulated contexts in the field of economics and management without strain. They will be able to speak about some specific  topics related to business management, economics and relevant current events, as well as describe visual information depicting economic and business trends. They will also be able to talk about their own academic career.  
3. compose a short professional business e-mail and/or report on specific issues in an appropriate style. 
4. understand short conventional spoken narratives related to topics/practices common to economics and management.

Mathematical Modeling in Biology

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description:
The aim of the course is twofold: on the one hand, present the students several basic mathematical models in different areas of biology (enzymatic reactions, molecular and physiological networks, ecology, infectious diseases); on the other hand, provide operating competences in the analysis (linearization; equilibria and their stability; bifurcation; regular and singular perturbations) and numerical solution of ordinary differential equations.

The final part of the course will be devoted to the development of a group project on a subject presented during the course.

At the end of the course, students are expected to be able to build mathematical models for biological systems similar to those presented in the course, to perform simple qualitative analysis of systems of ordinary differential equations, to simulate systems of ordinary differential equations and of reaction-diffusion equations using Matlab. Moreover, thanks to the project to e developed, it is expected that all students will have improved in their ability to collaborate in an interdisciplinary setting, and to communicate the results that have been obtained.

data.name: Gestione delle acque e dei sedimenti per lo sviluppo sostenibile

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
The course deals with water, river sediment and development in a broad sense. It takes a multi-scale (international to local) and multi-dimensional approach and focuses on four main themes: global water and sediment issues, river management and development, access to basic water and sanitation services, water- and sediment-related hazards in the developing world. The course is based on integration among different disciplines – as in the frequently addressed case of eco-hydraulics – and between the technical / engineering and the social, cultural and economical context.


The learning goals of the course are:


1. To develop a critical understanding of the multiple linkages between water, sediment and sustainable human development at different spatial and temporal scales.


2: To understand the main challenges in linking water and sediment management with development issues at an international level, with particular focus on data-scarce contexts


3. To learn design criteria and operation and mainteinance requirements of water supply technologies at community scale


4. To learn the main phenomena, orders of magnitudes, and available data bases on global and continental scale availability and use of water and sediment resources

data.name: Cancer Genomics

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description: The course aims to teach to the students the possible events and the associated molecular mechanisms responsible for the tumorigenic process, starting from the neoplastic cellular transformation to the tumor resistance to conventional and novel therapies. In detail, the course describes the cellular mechanisms involved in genome stability, depicts possible events known to alter their regular function and discusses how and when such deregulations acquire oncogenic potential, highlights the inter and intra tumor heterogeneity and the fundamental role played by such a genetic and genomic variability in the efficacy of standard and target therapies.

data.name: Costruire progetti e interventi nel welfare locale

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
The course's objectives are the local welfare policies and their design. The course aims to provide tools for analysing and understanding the design of local welfare policies and the related implementation processes. The course goal is to provide students with learning tools to build evaluation skills in relation to the different paths of implementing local welfare policies. Notably, the course's objectives are related to the in-depth analysis of three areas of interest: i) local welfare, in terms of characteristics, organisation and functioning; ii) the policy areas, like poverty, ageing, disability and migration; iii) definition and set-up of local social protection systems, namely the identification of the potential beneficiaries' social needs and the related responses, and the creation and financing of social programmes.

The course has two main goals: a) the development of analytical and critical abilities concerning the local welfare policies; b) the development of individual and collective design capabilities.

The course aims to teach students the following notions:

-         Critical abilities to analyse the local contexts. These abilities are finalised at understanding the potential needs of social policies and the related organisational, decisional, implementational and administrative setting of professionals who operate in the supply of local welfare policies.

-         Critical abilities to understand a local welfare policy. Notably, the understanding and identification of the policy's goals and tools in relation to the policy needs, as well as the policy strengths and limits concerning the identified social needs.

-         Critical thinking on the importance of values (moral, political, and cultural) in the formulation, analysis and evaluation of welfare policies.

-         Critical ability to conceive a local welfare policy design.

.

data.name: Business and Consumer Transactions
data.description:
The goal of the course is to provide students with an in-depth knowledge of the meaning and relevance of the great divide between business and consumer contracts. Exploring the contents of the two halves of contract law allows students to grasp the most significant developments taking place in this branch of private law. These developments are driven by three factors: new business models and new markets, new technologies, and new meanings of contractual justice. While the first two factors are external to contract law, the third one reflects dynamics taking place within the legal domain. All the three factors affect both domestic and international transactions. The course will discuss the rules applying to business and consumer contracts in each stage of the contractual lifecycle: drafting and negotiation, formation, performance, non-performance, and conflict management. Examples from EU law, national contract law, the UN Convention on the International Sale of Mobile Goods and the Unidroit Principles on International Commercial Contracts will be provided. 
By the end of the course, students will be able to: 
-	Understand the organizing principles for business and consumer contracts
-	Understand the differences between business and consumer contracts
-	Read and interpret the main contract terms for business and consumer contracts
-	Deal with the international dimension of business and consumer contracts
-	Apply their knowledge to new cases involving disputes on business and consumer contracts.

data.name: International and European Union Law (Advanced)
data.description:
The course aims to provide students with a theoretical and practical understanding of the functioning of the legal framework and institutions of international and European Union law with particular reference to the specialised areas of the two subjects. By the end of the course students will have acquired, also through simulations, debates and case studies, a basic knowledge of the main specialised areas of international law and European Union law. They will also have understood, through numerous practical examples, how legal language can guide the actions of institutions and actors in international relations.

More specifically, the general learning objectives of the course are as follows:


- Understand the logic and added value of legal reasoning in the context of international relations and the European Union;

- Understand and critically evaluate the consequences of breaking the law in specific situations relating to international relations and the European context;

- Understand and critically evaluate the role of different actors and institutions in the creation and application of international and European Union law.


After completing the course, students will be able to:


- describe the processes of law creation and application in the international and EU context;

- qualify disputes in different areas of international and European Union law in legal terms by taking a position on them and developing persuasive legal arguments;

- read and understand judgments or other primary sources concerning different specialised areas of international law and European Union law;

- critically evaluate the role of international law and European Union law in general terms and in the specialised areas explored during the course.

data.name: Information system and knowledge management
data.description:
Data, information, and knowledge are increasingly recognized as a crucial asset in modern organizations. The course intends to bring the students a solid general understanding of data, information and knowledge management focusing on concepts, methods and tools that can be used to enable innovation and change management within the organizations. A particular focus will be proposed on service science, an interdisciplinary approach to the study, design, and implementation of services systems. Organizations are complex systems in which specific interdependencies of people and technologies take actions and provide value. 
The course enable the student to deeply analyse from an organisational and managerial perspective Information and Knowledge management systems, Information system and data management, double side platforms, and some emerging technological phenomena such as crowdsourcing and gamification.

data.description: The course aims at providing students with a general overview about workers' rights in times of economic globalisation. At the end of the course students will know the contents of these rights and will be able to understand why the International Labour Organisation (ILO), as a response to the challenges of economic globalisation, decided to focus on some of them, considered as fundamental, and not on others. Finally, students will be aware of the enforcement problems characterizing the fundamental labour standard in the globalized world.

data.name: Statistics
data.description:
Purpose of the course

The purpose of the course is to enable students to correctly synthesize and visualize the information contained in data, familiarize themselves with the main statistical analysis techniques relevant for the applied and behavioral economics, and learn how to use dedicated statistical packages for data analysis and for implementing the inferential procedures studied in the course of the lectures.


Course expected results

After attending the course, the students know how to synthesize and correctly display the informations contained in the data. More precisely, students are able to select the most informative statistics for different types of data sets, to choose suitable estimators and construct classical and bootstrap confidence intervals for the parameters involved in the models in which they are interested in. Students are also able to select suitable statistical tests for different testing settings; they know how to apply different t-tests, chi-square tests, bootstrap-based and non parametric tests and understand the general statistical assumptions required for applying them. Students are also able to detect different types of dependencies between variables; they are familiar with univariate and multivariate linear and logistic regression analysis, understanding the underlying model assumptions and they are able to put these analyses into practice.

data.description:
The course provides students with theoretical and practical information as well as calculation tools for the design of different conventional retaining structures, either under static or seismic loading conditions. In the first part of the course, the problem of earth pressure evaluation is analyzed; the second part of the course is dedicated to the analysis of the failure mechanisms of retaining structures and to the soil-structure interaction.
At the end of the course, the student will be able to: i) recognize among the different types of retaining structures the more adequate for a specific problem; ii) define the geotechnical model required for the design of the structure; iii) calculate the earth pressure accordingly to the geotechnical model; iv) design and verify simple retaining structures.

Formative aims
Main objective of the course is to provide theoretical and hands-on knowledge on general principles of animal development and the underlying cellular, molecular and genetic mechanisms. Advantages and disadvantages of using various vertebrate and invertebrate animal models for the study of these processes will be discussed in the light of applicable techniques and current important topics in the field.
Learning outcomes
At the end of the course, students will be able:
a)	To recall the principles of early vertebrate and invertebrate development.
b)	To understand evolutionarily conserved signaling pathways involved in embryonic development and disease.
c)	To appreciate the importance of cellular interactions during cell morphogenesis and tissue specification.
d)	To apply simple molecular techniques for the study of gene function.
e)	To choose animal models and design experimental strategies for approaching developmental questions.

data.name: Filosofia del diritto
data.description:
The course aims at providing basic knowledge and understanding of the development of European philosophical thinking and at stimulating the students' critical reflection on some crucial topics.

This will be achieved by analysing some particularly significant topics in the context of legal philosophy according to a chronological sequence, beginning with the very first forms of awareness of the nature of law in Western thought and passing through the legal theories related to the rise of the modern state, until the problems associated with the protection of fundamental rights in contemporary age.

In detail, the course will treat:

1. the philosophical languages of classical age as for the problem of the relation between rules and power;

2. the consolidation of the relationship between sovereignty and law in modern age;

3. the question of the proper method of legal knowledge.

By combining the historical-philosophical perspective (which is diachronic-descriptive) and the critical one (which is synchronic-reflective), the course aims at enabling students:

1. to acquire a sufficiently broad framework of notions related to the history of legal philosophy, regardless of previous school education;

2. to recognize the crucial themes of European legal philosophical thought, also in their links with the main political theories;

3. to grasp the specificity of legal reasoning;

4. to develop critical capacity applicable to the various fields of positive law, particularly in judicial reasoning;

5. to apply first-level arguing techniques (deductive and inductive logic, topics, rhetoric).

data.name: Istituzioni di diritto romano per lavoratori/lavoratrici
data.description: This course aims to show the potential and the particular nature of this subject for the training of modern jurists. For this reason - following a historical perspective which looks at the developments in Roman private and procedural law from the foundation of Rome (753 BC) up to the death of Emperor Justinian (565 AD) - the course will examine the creative aspects of the Roman legal system (legislation, interpretation of case-law, the work of lay magistrates)  which form the foundations of the European civil law system.

data.name: Storia economica del turismo
data.description:
The course aims to provide the knowledge and skills necessary to understand and interpret the origins and historical evolution of the tourism phenomenon, grasping its complexity and interrelationship with economic, socio-cultural, technological and political-institutional factors that have accompanied its transformation over time.

At the end of the course the student will be able to:

- describe the main stages in the evolution of the tourism phenomenon, focusing on its characteristics from both the demand and supply sides;

- explain the interconnections between the tourism phenomenon and economic, socio-cultural, technological and political-institutional factors;

- illustrate the implications of the evolution of tourism in terms of sustainability;

- understand and critically analyze a historical-economic essay;

- apply the acquired knowledge to a case study enhancing it from an interdisciplinary perspective;

- work effectively in a group and support an argument in front of an audience.

Quantum mechanics

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
This module course aims to provide students with the basic competencies in quantum mechanics physics. 

At the end of the first module, students are expected to:

1) understand the main difference between the physical phenomenology at the macroscopic level ( governed by the laws of classical physics) and the phenomenology at the microscopic level, where quantum mechanical behavior takes place

2) understand the concept of particle-wave duality, and describe and critically analyze the main experiments which provide evidence of quantum uncertainty, wave-like properties of matter, and energy or magnetic moment quantization. 

3) understand the mathematical and physical significance of the wave-function and the related time-dependent and stationary Schrodinger equation.

4) Solve elementary problems in quantum mechanics (particle in an infinite square well, particle in a finite square potential, ground state of the harmonic oscillator)

5) understand and use the basic mathematical tools involved in physical modeling, including:

- Multi-dimensional calculus: partial derivatives, multi-dimensional integral, differential operators, partial differential equations. 

- Basic linear algebra, including matrix diagonalization, eigenvalues, and eigenvectors, commutation relationships. 

- Notion of Hilbert space and its representation theory

- Notion of Dirac-delta function

data.name: Computational social science

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
The module aims at providing an understanding of the main computational research methods that are specific to online media data and to analyse social processes.  This module offers a unique overview of research methods developed to analyse media and online data with an emphasis to 'big data' sources. The module presents an overview of current cutting-edge methodology in quantitative methods related to online social research. Web surveys, online experiments, opinion mining techniques, social network analysis, computational statistical models will be discussed as means to use of the web to analyse cultural, social and political phenomena. Such techniques have a wide range of applications in social scientific research as well as marketing and consumer research.
At the end of the module, students will be able to:
•	Understanding the main principles at the core of the different computational methods that are applied to social science datasets. 
•	A firm grasp of the coding process using software for automatic text analysis
•	Apply social network analysis to the context of combining network information with other type of data
•	Assess the use of online media data as social and cultural indicators using quantitative data
•	Understanding what is opinion mining and what are its core principles and techniques
•	Use computational models to analyse large survey data through techniques such as model based recursive partitioning, latent class analysis, relational class analysis.
•	Grasp the importance of Data visualization and presentation to relevant stakeholders

data.name: Intercultural communication
data.description:
This course aims at investigating the role of language in intercultural interactions, with a special focus on differences conventions of communication and speech styles. We will explore the inextricable relationship between culture and communication and investigate how knowledge is always positioned and produced from a particular cultural vantage point and with particular purposes in mind.

Students are expected to develop an understanding of the influence of culture on the production and interpretation of messages as well as to be able to identify issues of ethnicity, class, gender and religion within everyday communicative acts.

Bayesian statistics
data.description:
Purpose of the course

The purpose of the course is to address the study of the foundations of Bayesian statistics starting from the basic principles of the probability calculus. The course is divided into two modules.


  • The first module is devoted to present the parametric Bayesian inferential framework and intends to explore the foundations of the Bayesian paradigm and highlight the similarities and differences with the classical Fisher’s approach. Particular attention will be posed on computational and simulation aspects.
  • The second module focuses mainly on nonparametric Bayesian framework and related methods exploring the implications of Dirichlet and Pitman-Yor process in nonparametric mixture models. Particular attention will also be devoted on computational aspects of nonparametric mixture models.


During the course, the students have the opportunity to familiarize themselves with the principal theorems, logical developments, ideas and issues that underlie the Bayesian techniques, learn to recognize them as natural extensions of the concepts introduced in the previous courses in probability and mathematical statistics and familiarize with their us in practical situations.


The students will be request to have a pro-active participation and a constant involvement in the training program.


Course expected results

After taking this course students should be able to

  • Choose appropriately prior distributions and obtain posterior distributions
  • Simulate values from posterior distributions and make appropriate Bayesian inference.
  • Construct Bayesian prediction intervals and write appropriate conclusions.
  • Construct hierarchical models and adapt mixture models to capture the richness and the variety of the real phenomena.
  • Use a statistical computer packages (mainly R) to implement the data analysis procedures covered in the course.

Special emphasis will be placed on both preliminary methods of data analysis (graphical methods and distributional analysis), and on the choice of the most suitable statistical models for psychological disciplines.

Main aims:

data.description:

At the end of the course, students are expected to be able to: i) identify the main causes of structural vulnerability; ii) assess the level of safety of existing structures, with reference to both static and dynamic actions; iii) design retrofit solutions aimed at improving structural safety and satisfying code requirements.

data.name: Neuroscienze cognitive

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description: Cognitive neurosciences constitute a recent, wide and rapidly evolving research field. They aim to shed light on the neurofunctional mechanisms of cognition, determining in which ways the cognitive capacities of humans and other animals emerge from brain structure and function. They offer biologically based perspectives to the study of cognitive processes, which build on the detailed knowledge of theories and methods in cognitive and experimental psychology, as well as general competences in the domain of brain anatomy and function and in the techniques used for brain imaging and stimulation.. The teaching aim is to promote in students the ability to recognize and understand neuroscientific interpretations of behavior, generate arguments based on valid neuroscientific bases, and acquire relevant competences to establish to what extent conclusions are supported by empirical evidence. At the end of the course students should have learned to (1) elaborate and explore further the concepts discussed during the course, supporting their arguments with reference to specific empirical studies; (2) infer the methodology and/or the theoretical paradigms from research articles; (3) deal with the complexity of the discipline avoiding generic statements.

data.name: Soluzioni basate sulla natura per la sostenibilità urbana

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
Upon completion of this course, students will be able to:

1.      Understand contemporary sustainability issues in urban areas, and the role that nature can play for more livable, resilient and healthier cities;

2.      Analyze the supply and demand of ecosystem services provided by urban green and blue spaces, by applying suitable mapping and assessment methods;

3.      Understand the main typologies of nature-based solutions and the key principles for effective and context-specific planning, design and implementation;

4.      Assess the environmental and socio-economic impacts of nature-based solutions through quantitative and qualitative indicators;

5.      Critically review and discuss current thinking and experiences in cities and landscapes in Europe and around the world.
data.degreeProgram: Ingegneria per l'ambiente e il territorio (LM)

data.name: Stochastic Processes
data.description: The course provides some basic elements of the theory of stochastic processes: Gaussian processes,  Markov processes and martingales, having in mind the prototypical example of such processes, i.e., the Brownian Motion.

data.name: Biomedical Applications of Mathematics
data.description: At the end of this course the student will have a better understanding on physiology and pathology of specific portions of the human body, explained by practicing clinical doctors. Thanks to the description of basic and advanced applications of modelling and simulation for biomedical applications, the course will provide a better understanding on the implications of working in this field as mathematicians/engineers and potential activities that will be faced.

data.name: Product design
data.description:
The purpose of the course is to provide the basic elements of industrial design for the production of a manufactured product. Expressive and communicative aspects of an industrial product will be considered and two design paths (industrial and technical design) will be illustrated to create a successful product.

At the end of course the student could be able to:

1. recognize the importance of product design in the success of a product and a company;

2. Know the aspects of product design that are most important for designing and managing an industrial product;

3. to analyze and recognize features related to product design in a product;

4. Use creativity and lateral thinking techniques to address an industrial problem;

5. Have the basics to collaborate with a design team in the design process;

6. identify and select the most suitable materials and technologies in a design in function of the requirements;

7. propose possible solutions in an industrial design, considering the intangible aspects and customer satisfaction;

8. be critical, curious and be prone to considering both technical and perceptive news.

data.name: Altre conoscenze utili per l'inserimento nel mondo del lavoro
data.description:
Critical analysis of the cultural and tourist demand and offer of a destination (organization or business) through the identification, extraction, processing, and interpretation of secondary data in the database, technical report et.
Integration of data, data processing, and information acquired from different sources to draw up reports/documents to support local strategies and policies of cultural and tourism development and tourism and cultural marketing (strategic or territorial)

data.name: Storia greca II
data.description:
The main aim of the module "Death and the Maiden. Ancient Female Teenager Cults and Rituals" is to introduce students to Archaic and Classical Greek History and Religions, in particular cults and rituals practiced by teenagers. Students are expected to get familiar with the main lines of Archaic and Classical Greek History, the most important features of Ancient Greek polytheism, and cults and rituals practiced by female teenagers.

The specific aims are:

a) Knowledge and understanding: students are expected

-to sketch the main lines of Ancient Greek History from the Archaic Age to Philip II
-to get familiar with the most important features of Ancient Greek polytheism (myth and ritual; theogonies; the Ancient Greek pantheon; regional and local cults; the use of epithets; heroes; the sacred; sacrifices; approaches to Ancient Greek religion in the past)
-to get familiar with selected female teenage cults and rituals


b) Skills: students are expected to be able

-to place historical events through the timeline
-to read and to observe critically primary and secondary source material relevant to selected historical problems and valuate different sources of information
-to recognize historical problems and to formulate their own questions about major historical issues
-to gradually develop the ability to approach historical problems with academic rigour

data.name: Sociologia della religione
data.description:
Like all cultural phenomena, even the religious one tends to be unproblematized and to be summarized in the evidence that materializes before our eyes. In reality, religious phenomena have a founding and structuring role, that is, they are sources of normative action that changes the face of entire societies. The main purpose of the course is precisely to acquire such awareness.
For these reasons the course is divided into two parts.
The first aims to provide the constitutive elements of religiously oriented action.
In this, Weber's analysis of religious action will be treated. In the second part, of monographic orientation, the position and functions of Catholicism in the Italian context will be analyzed.

data.name: Corso di inglese B1b - I periodo (estensivo)
Lingua e traduzione francese e letteratura francese II
data.degreeProgram: Letterature euroamericane, traduzione e critica letteraria (LM)

data.name: Storia della banca e della finanza
data.description: The course in History of Banking and Finance aims at providing students with an interpretative framework of the patterns of growth and transformation of financial and credit businesses. Objective of the course is to let students develop knowledge on how banking structures have changed across time, in response to the needs emerging in the different phases of social and economic transformation. The students must therefore be able to grasp, through historical-cultural reasoning, how the current dynamics of the banking firm have emerged. A broad view combining the investigation on the role of credit intermediaries with analysis of the economic transformations in the early modern and contemporary periods, will enable students to understand the role of banks and bankers in all their complexity, in order to evaluate their operating effectiveness. Special attention will be devoted to the origins and subsequent development of cooperative credit, which will be examined both in its strengths and critical aspects, against the backdrop of the different phases of economic transformations in which it operated.

data.name: Progettazione di impianti per il recupero di energia dai rifiuti

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description: The module gives design examples of waste and discarded biomass treatment plants, aimed to energy recovery
data.degreeProgram: Ingegneria per l'ambiente e il territorio (LM)

data.name: Lingua e traduzione inglese I - LM
data.description: The course will focus on the translation of English and Irish literary classics into Italian, with a special focus on the works of Oscar Wilde. Classes will deal with the controversial notion of equivalence, the (re-)translation of classics, as well as issues of drama translation and of the translation of puns. The core text will be The Importance of Being Earnest, but other plays/texts will be considered too. Students are expected to learn to analyse a text in order to translate it and will become acquainted with specific translation procedures.

Urbanistica con Laboratorio Progettuale

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
The course aims to teach the history and the theories of Urban design as well as to experiment methodologies, techniques, analysis and design regarding the city of Trento. Through the analysis and the design experimentation of case studies reagarding the Trento masterplan challenges, the course offers the chance to acquire tools to interpret historical and contemporary, natural and artificial, open spaces and their transformations. By the end of the course students will be able to:

- know and use tools for analyzing the urban context and landscape condition;

- interpret and describe the sense of the places and the ongoing transformations in open spaces of the city (like the physical/morphological context, economic and social landscapes, systems and flows, frameworks);

- learn methodologies and techniques to design and management the landscape in Alpine urban contexts;

- define and design a project for a complex area by verifying the compatibility with general plans and the consistency with the context (nature and history, transformability and constraints, natural and social dynamics);

- define and represent a project idea that highlights the interpretation of context also through the experimentation of traditional or innovative tools (like urban design, urban performances, artistic actions in the city and the landscape, digital devices and new media);

- communicate the project through a variety of tools for a large group of stakeholders (technicians, practitioners, citizens).

data.name: Environmental fluid mechanics

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.name: Genomics and Drug Discovery

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description:
The course is aimed at providing the basis for the understanding of modern proteomic and genomic applications, including high-throughput biology platforms, to the development of new therapies and novel drugs, from novel target identification to the study of mechanistic and disease-based biomarkers. Examples of applications of genomic or proteomic approaches during the various steps of the development of a target up to clinical trials will be provided. 

On completion of this course the students should become able to:
- illustrate the principles and the characteristics of the most common genomic ad proteomic techniques
- describe their main applications in the biomedical field 
- describe the key steps in the drug discovery process and the main therapeutic modalities
- qualify potential targets based on the strength of their biological rationale
 - explain, by using key examples, how genomic approaches are revolutionizing drug discovery
- illustrate the characteristics and the ideal properties of a biomarker in the context of drug discovery and in the clinical practice
- explain how the use of biomarkers and pharmacogenomic approaches are enabling for personalized medicine

data.name: Patologie degenerative del sistema nervoso

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description: The teaching course aims to provide the student with information concerning neurodegenerative pathologies that produce cognitive decline. The aim is to learn to differentiate cognitive and behavioral disorders in the different types of neurodegenerative diseases, from diagnosis to rehabilitation. At the end of the course, the students should be able to distinguish the specific degenerative pathologies on the basis of the neuropsychological picture.

data.name: Introduzione alla Geometria Algebrica
data.description:
The course aims to be an introduction to objects and methods of Algebraic Geometry.

We will study projective varieties and their fundamental properties, such as dimension, degree, smoothness, regular and rational functions, regular and rational morphisms.

A relevant position will be given to examples and classical constructions of projective geometry.

data.name: Management pubblico
data.description:
1. Educational objectives

The main purpose of this course is to introduce students to the knowledge and the general understanding about the operating of public administrations according to the managerial reforms of the public sector.
In the first part we analyze general aspects of public administrations with comparisons with principal european and Anglo-Saxon experiences. Especially: the role, functions of public administrations; processes of managerial reform both at international and national level; the various forms of managing public intervention: direct, public agencies, public and private companies both profit and no-profit.
In the second part we discuss about  managerial functions essential to improve the relationships between public administrations and both companies and citizens: strategic programmation of an local authority; organization of human resources; organization of services and management of relationships with citizens according to principles of citizen satisfaction management.

2. Expected learning outcomes
-	clear understanding of  Public Administration decision making processes
-      factors effectively affecting changing process within  public 
        administrations
-      evolution of relationships between public administrations and 
       citizens
-      public service management system according to citizen 
       satisfaction management

data.name: Tecnologia meccanica
data.description:
The main aim of the course is to give the basic knowledge of manufacturing processes, with particular regard to bulk and sheet forming processes, machining operations and non-conventional processes, joining, surface treatments and 3D printing.

For each process, different aspects related to its mechanics, the suitable process parameters, the process and equipment characteristics, the obtainable products and related materials will be given. Besides the theoretical aspects, some examples will be given with the aim of solving practical manufacturing problems.

data.name: Analisi dei dati e Statistica
data.description: The course is divided essentially two parts. The first aims to introduce students to data analysis and provide them with the essential tools for the study and description of any socio-economic phenomenon through graphical representations and measures of synthesis. The second part of the course aims to provide the basic elements of probability and statistical inference as a mixture of theory, methods and techniques for quantitative analysis of economic and business problems.
