data.name: Contabilità, bilancio e principi contabili

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: Concepts of accounting, the structure of the financial report for the Italian Civil Law. The regulation of the content of the report and the value of the assets.

data.name: Economia
data.description:
At the end of the course, the student will know the main topics of a full-time microeconomics course (consumption theory and demand elasticity, perfect competition and monopoly, oligopoly, game theory, information asymmetry, risk attitudes, public goods and externalities).  He/she will be able to explain the theories learned and to correctly reproduce those theories in the context of a series of relevant examples and cases by using simple graphical and analytical tools.

The course develops different insights into microeconomics, economics of non-profit organizations, public economics and welfare systems. These insights are complementary and represent the next step with respect to the program carried out in Introduction to Economics. They aim to mold some additional concepts and analysis tools so as to reach an advanced understanding of most relevant economics and business issues, as well as a good knowledge of the characteristics and role of nonprofit organizations, public utilities, welfare systems and of public benefit, socio and health services.

data.name: Innovation Management
data.description: The course will supply the students with the tools needed to understand core competencies and learning processes in different organizations. These tools will enable the students to manage product development processes, services development processes and product-service systems. Moreover, the course will propose a critical view of the innovation processes.

data.name: Management delle imprese di servizi e turistiche
data.description:
The training objective of the course is to acquire knowledge and skills for the sustainable management of public and private enterprises and organizations, including those in the tourism sector. The course includes four types of training activities: joint lectures, face-to-face lectures, in-depth thematic seminars, and multidisciplinary laboratory. Each activity makes use of teaching methods such as Computational thinking (for joint lectures and laboratory), Experiential learning (thematic seminars and for the interdisciplinary laboratory), and Multiliteracies and discussion-based teaching (for face-to-face lectures and laboratory).


Attendance and active participation in the proposed activities and self-study will enable students to: identify the relevant aspects of a management problem, organize and integrate the data and information needed to seek a solution; compare methods and tools discussed in the course and choose those best suited to the solution; apply the method deemed most consistent with the sustainable approach; evaluate the applicability of methods for surveying and measuring customer satisfaction evaluate and use methods for customer portfolio management and customer loyalty management.


Active participation in all proposed training activities will enable students to experience experiential learning, in project-based and problem-based work activities; multi-literacy and discussion-based experience through peer review; computational thinking and problem solving approach through student-generated content.
data.degreeProgram: Management della sostenibilità e del turismo (LM)

data.name: ICT Innovation - Product Design and Development

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.name: Bio-Inspired Artificial Intelligence

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
The goal of this course is to study two of the main paradigms of Bio-Inspired Artificial Intelligence, namely: Evolutionary Computation, inspired by evolutionary biology, and Swarm Intelligence, inspired by collective behaviors of social animals. First, the main theories and algorithms will be introduced. Then, it will be shown how these techniques can be applied, for instance, for solving complex optimization problems, training data-driven models, generating new contents (video-games, websites, art), finding bugs in software, automatically synthesizing or fixing computer programs, or finding innovative solutions in robotics, logistics, and engineering. Finally, it will be shown how these techniques can help the understanding of biological systems, in order to close the loop between biology and AI.

At the end of this course, students will be familiar with the most important Evolutionary Computation and Swarm Intelligence techniques, and will be able to apply them to different contexts in industry, research, or even entertainment. They will also know the fundamentals for developing new algorithms and adapt them to new problems.

data.name: Building HVAC Systems

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
By the end of the course, students will be able to:

1. Knowledge and understanding:

a) master the most important concepts about heating and cooling loads of a building and its energy performance;

b) have a clear understanding of the operation of HVAC systems.

2. Applying Knowledge and understanding:

Apply the above concepts to the correct design of HVAC systems.

3. Making judgments:

Evaluate the heating and cooling load of a building, evaluate the performance of an HVAC system and the energy use of a building.

4. Communication skills:

Being able to express engineering concepts also with the aid of technical drawings, schematic diagrams and technical reports.

5. Learning skills

Being able to self-train and stay up to date with the evolution of the technical standards and with the market innovations.

data.name: Sistemi informativi

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: The objective of the course is to provide the skills needed to use ICT for supporting the business processes of different types of organisations.

data.name: Laboratorio di fisica III
data.description: Signal sampling, generation and processing as well as the control of systems make up the key topics of modern electronics. Their applications are widespread in fundamental research in experimental physics as well as in a great number of other scientific and technological contexts. The course (84 hours) addresses these topics both from the theoretical (28 hours) and the experimental (56 lab hours) point of view. The focus is not only on the application of electronics to the practice of experimental physics but also on the physical base of electronics. At the end of the course, students are expected to master the basics of the topics discussed therein and to use them to implement experimental setups. In Covid-19 regime the total number of lab classes might change.

data.name: Composizione architettonica 3 - Laboratorio progettuale

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
The targets of the course are identified in the development of knowledge and the deepening of theoretical and methodological aspects related to contemporary urban architectural design, to the tools and techniques related to formal and aggregative logic, according to which architectural spaces are defined in their elements and related to the characteristics of the city. Students will be asked: to know the principles of composition and applied composition; to apply design theories and methods in an existing architectural-urban context; to interpret critically, the value of a place and the instances related to the transformation; to design and develop an architectural-urban transformation project; to represent and communicate the architectural project clearly and originally; to work in a group.

 


The learning outcomes (knowledge and skills) are:

1. Knowledge and comprehension

The student will acquire through the theoretical lessons and classroom activities knowledge and comprehension of the theoretical and practical issues of discipline architectural and urban design with particular reference to the following aspects:

1.1 the process of defining a project space at different scales, about the urban context, its main constraints, the functional program, the techniques, and the materials.

1.2 knowledge of the main themes that characterize the contemporary architectural design

To achieve these learning outcomes the course will provide students with:

1.3 basic knowledge of principles of architectural composition and composition applied. 

1.4 theoretical and practical analytical techniques for interpretation and transformation of an urban architectural context built

2. Ability to apply knowledge and comprehension

The student will acquire through classroom and laboratory, practical skills for the project of architectural design with particular reference to the following fields of activity: 

2.1 the ability to design a project proposal focusing on a poetic transformation and regeneration;

2.2 elaboration of the project as a response to problems of construction of new architecture;

2.3. solution of practical problems, and the ability to communicate the spatial, formal and technical of the architectural project.

3. 3. Autonomy of judgment, skills and learning abilities 

The student will acquire, through the lessons, exercises and teamwork the ability to:

3.1. act, communicate and evaluate, critically and autonomy of judgement, in architectural and urban transformation/regeneration processes.

data.name: Neural Foundations of Human Behavior
data.description:
• The educational objective of the course is to acquire a knowledge base on the functioning of the central nervous system in mammals with particular reference to primates and humans. Brain function will be addressed at the level of the different systems (macro-scale) that compose it and how each of them is responsible for certain behavioral phenomena such as voluntary movement, affective behavior, memory or communication.
  • The contents will therefore cover the disciplines of neuroanatomy and neurophysiology. Particular emphasis will also be given to methodological aspects and to the possibility of transferring knowledge obtained in non-human models to the human brain.
  • Expected knowledge at the end of the course: to know the anatomy and physiology of brain systems.
  • Expected skills at the end of the course: mapping different behavioral functions onto the central nervous system’s anatomy. Formulate realistic hypotheses on the brain-behavior relationship

data.name: Programmazione 1

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The main goal of the course is learning the foundations of imperative programming. As programming language we will use (a proper subset of) the C++ language, restricted to its imperative part.


Object-oriented programming will not be investigated in this course (since argument of another course on this specific topic).


The students will practice in laboratory sessions all the notions and skills they acquire during the classes.

data.name: Meccanizzazione viticola e viticoltura di precisione
data.description: The main goal of the lectures is to inform the students about the ongoing developments in the mechanization and precision management of vineyards and to provide useful tools for a better understanding of the main physiological processes for grapevine, which are relevant from a viticulture-oenological point of view. The ultimate objective is to train professional figures, able to meet current and future requirements for viticulture.

data.name: Introduction to Robotics

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The course offers a bird-eye view on the most important topics related to modern robotics, highlighting the main problems that need to be faced in order to make the robots operate correctly in the environment. Specifically, the course will cover the following topics: taxonomy of the different types of robots, physical modelling of robots (direct and inverse kinematics and dynamics), simulation of models, sensing and actuation solutions for perception and action.
Using the developed models, the most famous methodologies to control robot motion and interaction, will be presented. These methods will be first studied in theory, and then implemented in simulation (with the Python language) to gain practical experience.
Attention will be also paid to illustrate the most common non idealities and issues that are present when controlling robots. The course will adopt a combination of simulation models and lab experiences to consolidate the knowledge transmitted during the theoretical lessons.
After completing the course, students will be able to:
- select the most suitable sensors and actuators for a given robotic application
- model the kinematics and dynamics any kind of robot
- understand the working principles of several control algorithms for robotic systems
- choose the appropriate approach(es) to control a specific system for a given target application
- implement, tune, and test control algorithms with the Python language

data.name: Sistemi cyber-fisici wireless per radar e comunicazioni mobili

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: The course aims to provide the student with the theoretical skills and methodological knowledge for the analysis and design of modern wireless systems capable of reconfiguring according to the surrounding electromagnetic scenario through software and hardware solutions. In the first part, the course provides the fundamental principles of the radiated propagation of electromagnetic waves and the radiation from elementary sources of electromagnetic field, as well as the description of the basic parameters for the characterization of the antennas. In the second part, the objective is to provide the students with the basic knowledge on the methods and strategies for the analysis and synthesis of suitable radiation diagrams as function of the application context. The course is based on rigorous theoretical contents, but is expressly oriented to wireless applications with a focus on radar and mobile communications systems. During the course, guided exercises will be carried out with the help of SW programs used for the design of radiant systems in the industrial field.
data.degreeProgram: Ingegneria Informatica, delle Comunicazioni ed Elettronica (L2)

data.name: Decision-making processes and digital nudging

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description:
Aims of the course:

  • Understanding digital nudges and their scientific bases (foundations of decision-making theory and decision biases);
  • Detecting digital nudges, critically evaluating and reflecting on their effects;
  • Autonomously designing and developing digital nudges.

data.name: Geometry and Topology for Data Analysis

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
The course is aimed at both students of the curriculum of applied mathematics interested in data analysis and students of the curriculum of pure mathematics interested in higher geometry. 

The goal is to offer an introduction to computational algebraic topology and algebraic geometry, with the emphasis on applications ("Topological Data Analysis"). At the end of the course the student is expected to be able to:
- master the fundamental concepts of algebraic topology and algebraic geometry
- understand the possible applications of computational topology and geometry
- individually study a chapter of a higher mathematics text in English
- publicly expose and discuss a topic of higher mathematics in a group

data.name: Rischi, politiche e diritti

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description: The aim of the module is to introduce the students to the main concepts, theories and methodologies of public policy analysis. Students completing this course will be able to: understand and apply concepts of human rights on national and global levels;  define and discuss the central concepts of freedom, equality and justice; critically analyze social policies from local, national and international perspectives; understand and articulate frameworks for policy analysis and policy practice.

data.name: Istituzioni di sociologia

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description: The course consists of two didactic units: A) The first didactic unit, named "General Part", introduces to the most known sociological perspectives, to the most important scientific interests within sociology and to the fundamental concepts of the discipline by examining their applications to the main areas of social research. B) The second didactic unit, indicated as "Seminar", includes the presentation and discussion of some central themes in the contemporary sociological debate.

data.name: Indipendenza e interdipendenza: Laboratorio teorico e di ricerca su norme culturali,  modelli del sé e cognizione sociale

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description:
The course aims to provide theoretical and applicative knowledge relating to independent and

interdependent cultural norms. Specifically, the course will address cultural differences with respect to socioeconomic

context, and how these differences influence the development of the self, the perception of action

and the context. Students will have the opportunity to refine their scientific communication skills and to grasp

a critical view of the research field through scientific articles’ analyses, class presentations and group

discussions. Furthermore, students will apply the acquired knowledge by implementing a research study.

At the end of the course the students will be able to:

• Get a deepened knowledge of the cultural norms of independence and interdependence;

• Understand advanced level texts on the proposed topics and re-elaborate the knowledge acquired into an

original reflection;

• Hold a critical discussion starting from the acquired knowledge;

• Effectively communicate ideas, problems, solutions and information.
data.degreeProgram: Scienze e Tecniche di Psicologia Cognitiva (L2)

data.name: Introduzione all'economia
data.description: By the end of the course, the student is expected to be familiar with the language of economics and the main methods and models used in this field. In addition, the student should be able to apply these methods and models to analyze situations that occur daily in a modern market economy and to critically consider the potential benefits, failures, and unwanted consequences of economic policies.

data.name: Tecnica delle costruzioni

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
• Understand the fundamentals of structural reliability;
  • Learn to calculate design loads and actions on buildings;
  • Learn the mechanical properties of construction materials;
  • Familiarize with the fundamentals of reinforced concrete design;
  • Learn to design simple reinforced concrete elements at the cross-section level.
data.degreeProgram: Ingegneria per l'ambiente e il territorio (L2)

data.name: Quantitative Methods

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
The course provides competences in the understanding and use of quantitative methods for the analysis of social science phenomena. It will follow a theory guided empirical research approach, introduce the translation of a research question in an empirical research, and the choice of most appropriate data and methods to test theoretically derived hypothesis. Methods will cover multivariate regression analysis, cross-sectional and longitudinal data, measurement issues and comparative research. 

together with the course on survey design, on qualitative methods and statistics for opinion research (2nd term) this course provides the basis for specializing course in the second year.

data.name: Ingegneria degli acquiferi e dei siti contaminati

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description: The course provides the students with the skills needed for the design of remediation actions and management of contaminated sites, as well as the design of sustainable utilization systems of subsurface water resources in view of the impact of climate change and the growing anthropic pressure. Attention is given to the interaction between groundwater and underground structures and groundwater protection. The first part of the course deals with the design of remediation systems for groundwater and contaminated sites, as well as the design of efficient and sustainable groundwater exploitation systems. The second part of the course deals with the study of the physical and biogeochemical processes controlling the occurrence and the quality of groundwater. Flow and transport modeling is considered here because instrumental to the modern design of water exploitation and remediation systems for contaminated sites. The students will acquire the skills needed for the design of effective remediation systems of contaminated sites, the design of groundwater utilization systems as well as to quantify the interaction between groundwater and underground infrastructures.
data.degreeProgram: Ingegneria per l'ambiente e il territorio (LM)

data.name: Fisica generale II
Topografia

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
The primary goal of this course is to convey knowledge and to permit the development of skills about land surveying and mapping.

Basic concepts are provided for the understanding and the evaluation of the various phases of a land survey, namely:
- choice of reference system and measurement technique(s),
- design of a measurement set-up and measurements acquisition,
- treatment of observations,
- critical analysis of the results,
- fusion of informations from different sources,
- representation.

Teaching includes lectures, instrumental exercises and numerical exercises.

The participation in the proposed activities, complemented by appropriate individual study activities, allows the knowledge of:
- concepts, purposes and problems about reference systems and their transformations at the global and local scales,
- conventional and modern, space-based, methods and techniques for measurements acquisition,
- models and methods for the treatment of observations and the estimation of unknown parameters,
- the probabilistic modeling of uncertainties in measurements,
- basic concepts about the representation of the Earth and of its surface, reference surfaces for altimetric and planimetric positioning,
- basic principles about cartography and the practical purposes and uses of mapping products.

At the end of the course the student will be able to:
- perform topographic measurements,
- design a simple topographical survey,
- perform simple topographical calculations,
- critically evaluate the results of a survey,
- use cartographic products.

The effective realization of a survey may require more technical-operational skills than those that can be gained in instrumental exercises, but acquired knowledge and skills should be sufficient for job setting and self-obtain the necessary complementary skills.

data.name: Programming Language Semantics

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: Students will learn how to formalise languages and why that is important, how to reason about different and complex language constructs through advanced methods. Students will come to know all basic typing constructs as well as several advanced ones as found in many modern languages.

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.name: Corso di inglese A2-B1 foundation - I periodo (estensivo)
Geometria differenziale
data.description:
The aim of this course is to introduce objects and methods of differential geometry in the easiest and most natural cases, i.e. for curves and surfaces embedded in euclidean three-dimensional space.
The last lectures will present a general introduction to the theory of differentiable manifolds, to place in a more general context the topics studied in the first part of the course

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.name: Psicologia della memoria e dell'apprendimento
data.description: This course unit aims at providing students with a general overview of the basic mechanisms and most prominent theories of learning and memory, as well as of their relationships with attentive and executive control processes. At the end of the course, students are expected to have achieved a good knowledge of such mechanisms and of the experimental paradigms used to investigate them. They should also be able to link theory, empirical research and practice and discuss properly results of the scientific studies described during the course lessons.

data.name: History of the idea of Europe
data.degreeProgram: EUROPEAN AND INTERNATIONAL STUDIES - STUDI EUROPEI E INTERNAZIONALI (LM)

data.name: Mathematical Modeling in Biology

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description:
The aim of the course is twofold: on the one hand, present the students several basic mathematical models in different areas of biology (enzymatic reactions, molecular and physiological networks, ecology, infectious diseases); on the other hand, provide operating competences in the analysis (linearization; equilibria and their stability; bifurcation; regular and singular perturbations) and numerical solution of ordinary differential equations.

The final part of the course will be devoted to the development of a group project on a subject presented during the course.

At the end of the course, students are expected to be able to build mathematical models for biological systems similar to those presented in the course, to perform simple qualitative analysis of systems of ordinary differential equations, to simulate systems of ordinary differential equations and of reaction-diffusion equations using Matlab. Moreover, thanks to the project to e developed, it is expected that all students will have improved in their ability to collaborate in an interdisciplinary setting, and to communicate the results that have been obtained.

data.name: Advanced Topics in Language/Cognition
data.description:
The course "Advanced Topics in Language and Cognition" addresses
advanced topics between linguistics and science cognitive.

This year, the course will give students an overview of the problem of
innatism in human language: to what extent the human faculty to learn
to speak and understand language is due to brain features innate in
each individual, in a way that that facilitate the acquisition of
language and/or its systematization in specific grammatical
structures.

The topic is extremely controversial and extremely interdisciplinary,
since it involves issues in theoretical linguistics, language
typology, the neurosciences, the theory of evolution along with its
simulation through computational models, general human cognition and
its development. In addition, the various approaches to the problem
are not always fully aware of the arguments of the others.

For this reason the course will be conducted as a active seminar, with
a list of readings. Without any expectation to arrive at a solution of
the problem, we will be able to see the various sides of the debate.

At the end of the course the student should be able to:

- know the main themes of this domain (the Chomskian theory of the
  "Universal Grammar" and its changes through the time; the criticism
  of the computational models to the problem learning; the problem of
  typological universals, the debate on the evolution of language)

- Search independently for specific scientific literature subtopics of
  the main issue.

- Read and present relevant articles and make informed comments on the
  literature presentated by others.

- Be able to formulate hypotheses on specific subproblems (eg
  experiments which could lead to clarify certain aspects of the
  problem)

data.name: Lab. II: Selected Topics in Economics and Management
Calculus 1

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
1. Knowledge and understanding
In-depth knowledge of the basic methods of the calculus for functions of one variable, as specified by the course program. Ability to analyze and understand the main characteristics of differentiable and integrable real value functions. Ability to apply the methods to concrete problems and other scientific or industrial problems.

2. Ability to apply knowledge and understanding
Ability of inductive and deductive reasoning in dealing with problems of the nature of the analysis of functions. Ability to set up a problem and solve it using appropriate analysis tools.

3. Autonomy of judgment
Ability to develop logical arguments, to understand when a proof is rigorous and complete, and to extend and produce minor extensions of the proofs seen in the course. Ability to identify the most appropriate methods for analyzing and interpreting problems.

4. Learning skills
Ability to acquire and manage new information starting from the statements and proofs developed in the lectures.

data.name: Statistics of Stochastic Processes

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description: Knowledge on the problems concerning the statistical analysis of dependent data, especially time series. Develop good competences on of linear ARMA models and Hidden Markov Models, their specification, properties, inferential and computational aspects.

data.name: Algorithms for Bioinformatics

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description:
Goal of the course is to provide the student with notions about the main algorithms used in bioinformatics and skills for their implementation.
At the end of the module the student should be able to:  recall and discuss the algorithms presented, reading the literature about an algorithm in the same class and implement it.

data.name: Memory studies e storia
data.description: Students are expected to acquire adequate theoretical knowledge of the aspects and themes regarding cultural memory, its mechanisms of formation and forms of expression, as well as an awareness of its historical implications. They are also expected to develop a methodological capability to apply the concepts provided by memory studies as an interpretative tool to their own research subjects and topics of interest.

data.name: Cellular and Molecular Neurobiology

data.name: Fondamenti di analisi dei segnali biomedici
data.description: The aim of the course is to provide the fundamental knowledge and tools for the treatment of biomedical data and signals. The student will acquire familiarity with the main statistical techniques for series and biomedical data characterization and for the processing of biomedical signals, in the time and in the frequency domain, with linear and non-linear techniques.

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.name: Quantum Chemistry

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description:
The Second module of the Molecular Physics course focuses on the applications of quantum mechanics to atomic and molecular physics. 

To this end, we shall introduce a number of different approximation methods  and discuss their relevance and then apply them to physical systems of increasing complexity, from atoms to molecule

data.name: Modellazione idrologica

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
The Hydrological Modeling course aims to teach to simulate the hydrological cycle at various spatial scales in order to be able to adequately manage the water resource and to prevent the risk of floods. The importance of these two issues is widely covered by the EU 2000/60 framework directives or "Water directive" and EU 2006/60, "full directive". Based on the hydrological knowledge acquired in the course of Hydrology at the Bachelor of Engineering for the Environment and the Territory, the hydrological processes, analyzed as punctual phenomena are extended to the water catchment areas. Precipitation is analyzed as a measured statistical data, both from ground stations and from remote sensing; the other processes are suitably modeled, as briefly described below. At the end of the course, a student must be able to independently model the flow rates, evaporation and transpiration in a river basin of various sizes, after having delineated it starting from digital terrain data. Of course, the student will have to demonstrate that he has critically understood the concepts that underlie the hydrological modeling presented. The knowledge acquired may be that used in the River Engineering course for the design of defense works. Hydrological modeling also introduces concepts that are used in the course of Aqueducts and Sewers for the calculation of stormwater networks. The course is partly useful for the Hydraulic Protection of the Territory course. More information is available on: 
https://abouthydrology.blogspot.com/2020/01/hydrological-modelling-2020.html
data.degreeProgram: Ingegneria per l'ambiente e il territorio (LM)

data.name: Fondamenti di elaborazione dei segnali

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: The course will provide basic knowledge about one-dimensional and multi-dimensional signals, in analog and digital format. The students will learn how to analyse a signal in its original domain, as well as in the frequency domain, using appropriate transformations. It will also be shown how a signal is modified  by a processing system, in both continuous and discrete domains, and how to design some simple systems to perform basic operations.

data.name: Computational Linguistics

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
The course introduces the basics of computational linguistics. Its goal is to (1) provide students with an overview of the field with focus on the syntax-semantics interface; (2) bring student to be aware on the one hand of several lexicalized formal grammars, on the other hand of computational semantics models and be able to combine some of them to capture the natural

language syntax-semantics interface; (3) evaluate several applications with a special focus to lexical semantics; (4) make students acquainted with writing scientific reports.


All these objectives will help students understand how methods from computer science, mathematics and statistics are applied to the modelling of natural language and start being propositive for new ideas.


At the end of the course students will be able to: (1) illustrate the main challanges addressed in the field, which are its consolidated results and which are the current research questions; (2) master, at introductory level, the basic rules of some formal grammars and of formal and distributional semantics languages and their integration based on the principle of compositionality; (3) compare approaches on computational linguistics tasks, and use some evaluation scripts; (4) apply interdisciplinary approaches to linguistics tasks and write a scientific report on their research in LaTex.

data.name: Analisi matematica 1

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description: Taking into account the observation that "in mathematics you don't understand things, you just get used to them", aim of the course is to make familiar to the students the basic topics of mathematical analysis (functions, limits, derivatives, integrals, series, series of functions, differential equations). At the end of the course the students will be essentially able to orient themselves among the mathematical concepts listed above, and to understand how they can be useful for giving a rigorous form to more specific scientific arguments; they will be also able to solve exercises related to the topics of the course.
data.degreeProgram: Ingegneria per l'ambiente e il territorio (L2)

data.name: Statistica per il controllo della qualità
data.description: This course develops the student's ability to understand, and interpret management data and use statistical instruments thus enabling him/her to operate effectively in the Quality Control world. The student learns the importance of experimenting with strategies and trying new approaches to exploit data and information.

data.name: Complementi matematici della meccanica quantistica
data.description:
The aim of the course is to provide the students with the necessary tools and skills to solve simple problems in quantum mechanics. With its target to physical applications, the course is a fundamental complement to the theoretical course on  Quantum Mechanics which is held in parallel.

The course also aims to provide the students with a "hands on" knowledge of the theory of Hilbert spaces, linear operators in Hilbert spaces and distributions, which are the mathematical foundations of quantum mechanics.

data.name: Visual design

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description:
The course aims at providing students with specific skills for graphic design and the realization of digital products from a graphic-aesthetic point of view.
At the end of the course, students will know the principles of graphic design, with particular reference to the structure of the layout, the hierarchy of contents, color matching, the choice of the correct typeface, and the treatment of vector and bitmap images. He/she will also be able to use the basic functions of the software Illustrator and Photoshop for the elaboration of communication products and Adobe Experience Design for the design and creation of prototypes of websites and mobile apps (UI/UX design). 
The student will have acquired skills to understand the reality in which the product is inserted and to integrate the elements of visual communication to give meaning and value to the product in relation to a specific context. 
The student will have acquired methodological skills to manage design processes.

data.name: Filosofia della storia
Global Economic Policy
data.description: The course aims at analyzing policy issues in a context of open economy. At the end of the course, students are supposed to understand causes, effects and implications of some of the events currently occurring in the global economy.
data.degreeProgram: EUROPEAN AND INTERNATIONAL STUDIES - STUDI EUROPEI E INTERNAZIONALI (LM)

data.name: Stochastic Processes

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description: The course provides some basic elements of the theory of stochastic processes: Gaussian processes,  Markov processes and martingales, having in mind the prototypical example of such processes, i.e., the Brownian Motion.

data.name: Bioenergy

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
The course focuses on Bio-Energy and in particular on the exploitation of biomass and biomass waste for energy recovery. The course encompasses thermochemical energy processes (combustion, gasification, pyrolysis, reforming, hydrothermal conversion), mechanical and chemical processes (e.g. oil extraction and trans-esterification for biodiesel), finally biochemical processes (fermentation and anaerobic digestion for biogas/biomethane).
The course provides chemical engineering tools applied to the analysis of energy conversion processes involving biomass and organic waste.
Finally, the course provides the fundamentals of ASPEN PLUS® - a software package designed for process modeling and simulation that is extensively utilized in the chemical and energy industrial sectors.
The student, at the end of the course: 
• will be able to analyze the various technologies available to valorize energetically the various types of biomass and organic waste;
• will be able to evaluate performances and limits of the same technologies in relation to the substrate to be treated;
• will have clear concepts and design elements to address the design of a bioenergy plant.
data.degreeProgram: Ingegneria per l'ambiente e il territorio (LM)

data.name: Crash course - International Business
data.description:
This intensive course aims to form students’ knowledge in the area of International Business. Specifically students will develop capabilities to identify, frame and understand problems related to the management of international operations. Throughout the course issues are discussed in both theoretical and practical terms to stimulate students to relate models and concepts with practical situations.

By the end of the course the students will be able to:
•	discuss implications of globalization and cultural differences 
•	understand the implications of operating across national borders 
•	compare different internationalization processes 
•	describe how firms operate in different markets
•	analyze different international strategies and organizational structures
•	evaluate and criticize different leadership and control models
•	describe the specificity of different functions and units within the international firm
•	understand the basis for the competitive advantage of international firms

data.name: Lingua e cultura cinese I
data.description: The course aims at providing the students with a basic knowledge of Chinese language and culture. By the end of the course, the students will master a vocabulary of about 300 words, will be able to read and comprehend simple texts, and will acquire elementary conversation skills. Besides, they will acquire a basic knowledge of Chinese history and civilization. At the end of the course, 1. students will have acquired a basic knowledge of the most important aspects of the Chinese civilization and will be able to navigate a different cultural system; 2. they will have acquired a basic knowledge of the historical evolution of China from the ancient times until the XX century; 3. they will have acquired a knowledge of the historical context within which the first contacts between China and Europe took place and the main factors that shaped Western perceptions of China from the XVI century to the early XX century. 4. they will have gained the ability to critically analyse, summarize and re-elaborate the cultural contents of the course.

data.name: Storia dell'arte moderna I
data.description:
The course aims to equip students with a solid knowledge on the history of Italian Art between 1400 and 1470, and to enable students to historically and culturally contextualize artistic phenomena, and to interpret the work of art in its stylistic and iconographic language.
By the end of the course, students will be able also to critically elaborate acquired knowledge in an autonomous and competent way.

data.name: Ultrasound Technologies for Medical Applications

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: This course consists of two parts. In the first part, core topics such as the piezoelectric phenomenon, the physics of ultrasound propagation, modeling, and nonlinear acoustics will be introduced. This will provide the students with the basic knowledge necessary to understand the potentials and the limitations of ultrasound technologies. The second part will then focus on probe design, system architecture of ultrasound scanners, image formation and beam forming, and emerging medical applications (e.g. lung ultrasonography, brain and cancer imaging). The objective of the course is to form students that are not only familiar with the fundamentals and state-of-the-art applications of ultrasound technology, but also able to critically evaluate the technology itself and potentially improve it further.

data.name: Lingua, cultura e letteratura Yiddish
data.degreeProgram: Letterature euroamericane, traduzione e critica letteraria (LM)

data.name: Laboratorio di analisi dei mercati
Embedded systems

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
Embedded computers are found everywhere, from home appliances to automobiles to medical devices. Designing an embedded computing system is a challenging task because the requirements include manufacturing cost, performance, power consumption, user interface, hard deadlines, and rich functionality. 
The objective is to illustrate the embedded system design process, which includes requirements, specification, architecture, components, and system integration phases. The course will be backed up by real-life design examples to illustrate the design process, and also students will be asked to design embedded systems to gain experience.

data.name: Business Development Laboratory

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description: Being all classes in English, only English syllabus is available

data.name: Corso extracurriculare di inglese
data.description:
The aim of this course is to acquire and apply economic and business language skills at a CEFR level B2/a. 
The course is aimed at third year undergraduate students (3rd year) who intend to continue their language learning at ESP level for future work placement at home or abroad, and/or continue their academic career.  
Attendance and active participation will enable the student to:
a) understand an economic text
b) use appropriate lexis
c) discuss university studies
d) describe simple economic visuals.

data.name: Network dynamics
Ethics and Security
data.description: The course aims at developing a critical understanding of contending ethical approaches about security issues that arise from human conduct and from political and military contexts, at both national and supranational level. A specific focus will be devoted to a critical analysis of the conceptual vocabulary used in the most relevant official documents related to specific security issues, also by promoting an interdisciplinary approach to the topics, expounded through the lens of public ethics, political philosophy and European studies. The course is characterized by a balanced mix of theoretical approaches, case studies analysis and interactive sessions, in order to promote a cooperative learning approach.

data.name: Diritto pubblico
data.description:
To provide the basic knowledge of the main categories of public  law, with special emphasis on the sources of law, their role in regulating the relationship among public actors and between the State and the citizens, the role and functioning of public  institutions in the decision-making process. To guide students towards the consultation of the sources of law and the interpretation of legal rules, particularly focusing on the Italian Constitution.
At the end of the course, students will have the basic notions of legal terminology and will be able to comprehend and properly describe the basic elements of the national system of public law. Moreover, they will have the basic tools to directly access legal sources, particularly at the Constitutional level.

data.name: Experimental Physics Laboratory at High School Level I
data.description:
This course aims to provide an introduction to the fundamental concepts of Physics Education Research and to the design of experimental activities for teaching physics.

The course also aims to discuss the basic theory of measurement and error and examine the main features of the Laboratory instruments.


Some experimental activities will be presented from an educational point of view and some case studies will be considered by adopting both traditional laboratory equipment and new technologies applied to the laboratory of physics.

Experimental activities will be performed directly by students working in small groups.


At the end of the course, the student will be able to

1) autonomously design experiments

2) Perform experiments using appropriately the equipment of the physics lab

3) Analyze experimental data using the theory of measurement and error


Ultimately the course aims to prepare students as future teachers of experimental physics courses by introducing them to experimental techniques, teaching methodologies and the design of didactic experiments.

data.name: Counselling e psicoterapia

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.description: The class aims to provide students with theoretical and practical knowledge on psychotherapy and psychological counselling, from the first psychotherapeutic approaches throughout history, to the meaning of modern clinical approaches. There will be insights on the distinction between counselling and psychotherapy, on the difference between the skills of the psychologist and those of the psychotherapist, on the main theoretical orientations (with references to the underlying epistemological thought) and on the consequent implications on the methodological and relational level. Transversal constructs in the therapeutic field and psychological counseling such as therapeutic alliance, intersoggetivity, attachment, and other more specific such as hints of interpretation, dream analysis, transfert and countertransfert phenomena will also be studied. The phenomenology of the first interview will also be addressed in depth as a privileged moment to collect information useful to the clinical intervention plan. These topics will also be developed with reference to the life cycle (childhood, adolescence, adulthood and the elderly), to particular psychopathological conditions (neurotic, psychotic, borderline and "new pathologies"), neurodiversity (autistic spectrum), new forms of psychopathology or related to social phenomena being studied (for exemple social retreat  and other non-pathological but clinically relevant conditions (LGBT people).

data.name: Stabilità dei pendii naturali e delle costruzioni in terra

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
At the end of the course, the students will be able to:

- Understand laboratory and insitu investigation methods to quantify the parameters needed for slope analysis

- Choose the most suitable method for slope stability analysis

- Carry out and differentiate slope stability analyses with different numerical methods

- Evaluate the suitability of different slope stabilization methods.
data.degreeProgram: Ingegneria per l'ambiente e il territorio (LM)

data.name: Letteratura francese I
data.description: This course aims to enable students to understand the historical and formal evolution of the novel during the 19th century. The course focuses on an analysis of Honoré de Balzac’s Père Goriot and Gustave Flaubert's Madame Bovary.

data.name: Storia del teatro e dello spettacolo II
data.description: Aim of the course is 1) acquisition of the necessary skills to fully understand the theatrical events of the past, in order to be able to understand and evaluate them in a comparative geographical and historical context 2) acquire all the critical means necessary to analyse the contemporary stagings in all their elements, from acting to scenery. At the end of the course the student will be able to understand the proposed topics with the help of the didactic material; to put these events into their correct context; to employ the specific language appropriate to the subject

data.name: Mechanics and materials for engineering design
data.description:
One of the most important subjects for any student of materials engineering is the behavior of materials, mechanical components and structures under load. The way in which they react to applied forces, the resulting deflections and the stresses and strains set up in the bodies concerned are all vital considerations when designing a mechanical component such that it will not fail under predicted load during its service lifetime. All the essential elements of a treatment of these topics are contained within this course, starting with the concepts of mechanics of materials (stresses-strains, beam theory, thick cylinders, plasticity, fracture mechanics) and moving on to the examination of strength and stiffness verifications on mechanical components such as cylinders, joints, springs, shafts, bearings and mechanical transmissions.

By the end of this course students should: (1) be able to analyze the stress and strain on mechanical components and understand, identify and quantify failure modes for mechanical parts; (2) know basic machine elements used in machine design and design machine elements to withstand the loads and deformations for a given application, while considering additional specifications; (3) be able to approach a design problem successfully, taking decisions when there is not a unique answer; (4) be familiar with team-working, mathematical computing and CAD software; (5) be able to present analyses in a proper format of a written report such that a technically qualified person can follow and obtain similar findings.

data.name: Scienza politica

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
The course is an introduction to: a) the language, concepts and methods of political science; b) the main theories of democracy and democratization; c) the main institutions and instruments of representative democracy (elections, political parties, political communication, participation, social movements, pressure groups; parliaments, executives, the international system); d) the ways in which Europeanization and globalization processes transform our contemporary democracies. 
The first objective is to equip the students with as precise political science concepts and terms as possible so as to allow them to handle with confidence the theories of political development and democratic functioning. Since democracy is a complex concept, which is embodied in often very diverse political systems, it is important to acquire a minimal definition of democracy, and to be able to recognize non-democracies, in order to then explore the many types and models of contemporary democracies. In order to appreciate the complexity and fragility of democracy, it is thirdly necessary to have a detailed picture of the institutions, procedures, processes and mechanisms which ensure a good democratic performance by acquiring a solid and empirically-founded knowledge which guarantees against subscribing to dangerous and ultimately mistaken simplifications. Lastly the course intends to discuss the tensions that derive to democracy from the processes of globalization and Europeanization, that is from the increased interdependence among contemporary democracies particularly in Europe. 
At the end of the course, students should possess a vocabulary and a conceptual apparatus that allow them to talk about democracy with competence and to use empirically and theoretically founded knowledge to orient themselves in the contemporary political debate.

data.name: Statistica, algoritmi e programmazione

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description: In this course the students learn how to solve simple problems in physics and mechanics at the aid of a computer. The course provides the necessary elements of a theoretical analysis of the algorithms under consideration, as well as their practical implementation under the form of a computer program. The course also contains a module of 3 ECTS concerning an introduction to statistics and probability.
data.degreeProgram: Ingegneria per l'ambiente e il territorio (L2)

data.name: Topics in Mathematical Physics of Quantum Theories
data.description: Development and understanding of some mathematical topics in quantum theories. Possession and development of advanced mathematical instruments, e.g. the theory of operator algebras.

data.name: Statistica per la professione
data.description:
Il corso si propone di offrire agli studenti  gli strumenti statistici per la raccolta, l'elaborazione e l'analisi di dati statistici inerenti la professione di commercialista, di revisione o di responsabile dell'area amministrativa e gestionale di un'azienda
Alla fine del corso lo studente sarà in grado di 
- elaborare informazioni statistiche anche campionarie e di commentare i risultati ottenuti
- commentare in maniera critica reportistica di terzi 
- comprendere articoli e testi che utilizzano metodi statistici

data.name: Advanced topics in Perception and Attention
data.description:
The goal of this advanced course is to introduce the students to the current research topics in the field of attention/perception. The course purports to promote active learning and participation. At the end of the course, the students should be able to:

• analyze critically the scientific literature on attention and perception.

• present the content of a scientific article together with their personal view on it.

data.name: Mathematical Control Theory
data.description: At the end of the course, if proficiently followed, students will be able to formulate, analytically manage, and possibly solve, a control problem as well as an optimal control problem both coming from the applications and from a theoretical point of view. In particular, students will be able to recognize all the essential aspects of the mathematical model (both linear and nonlinear), to know the main questions and the possible answers about it. Moreover, students will know many of the theorems concerning the theory, their proofs, and their applications in order to study examples and counterexamples.

data.name: Experimental Methods
data.description: The goal of the course is a discussion of the main methods that allow to extract information from a measurement, also in presence of unavoidable noise sources. Upon the completion of the course, a student is expected to become acquainted with those methods, which include different advanced mathematical, numerical and experimental tools.

data.name: Sistemi operativi

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The aim of the course is to provide the fundamental concepts that are the basis of modern operating systems, with particular emphasis on concurrency, synchronization, memory and file management. Each concept will be treated from the theoretical point of view. For the most important concepts, the treatment will also cover more practical aspects in order to familiarize with complexity of their implementation.

At the end of the course, the student will be able to discuss the architecture of an operating system, how the main functionalities are designed and implemented. The student will be able to compare and evaluate different design choices and implementations.
data.degreeProgram: Ingegneria Informatica, delle Comunicazioni ed Elettronica (L2)

data.name: Introduction to Italian Law (for erasmus students)
data.description: The course is aimed at foreign students who attend one or more semesters in Trento at the Faculty of Law, as part of exchange programs. The aim of the course is to provide an overview of the essential features of the Italian legal system, describing the fundamental structures of the legal system. In particular, a synthetic analysis of the basic choices that characterize both the constitutional regulation, as well as the private and criminal law one, will be offered. Specific attention will also be paid both to the peculiarities that distinguish the Italian legal experience compared to other national legal traditions, and to the assonances that unite the constitutional, civil and criminal order of Italy with that of other civil law experiences.

data.name: Economia ed organizzazione aziendale
data.description:
The course presents the fundamental concepts related to the organization and functioning of manufacturing companies and the tertiary sector. The engineering students will learn some elements of management and business organization, which form the basis for understanding the functioning of companies. In particular, students will develop the ability to:

a) map the fundamental activities carried out in the company in the different functional areas as well as in the different business processes, and

b) calculate the production costs and use them in current management decisions.

data.name: Laboratorio/seminari multi-stakeholder di rendicontazione sociale e ambientale
data.description:
Training Objectives.

This training activity has three objectives:

-to delve into some specific multi-stakeholder reporting topics, on social, environmental and governance issues according to the students' educational background and interests;

- to make students gain practical knowledge to qualitative and quantitative approaches of analyzing social and environmental reporting systems;

-improve soft skills such as teamwork, research, synthesis and exposition of personal papers.

The training activity forms a link with the other courses in the master's degree track on social entrepreneurship and hybrid enterprises.


Expected Learning Outcomes.

At the end of the course, the student will be able to independently develop an analysis of social/sustainability reporting through different techniques and methodologies, both qualitative and quantitative. More specifically, he/she will be able to:

-distinguish between qualitative and quantitative methods of analysis, appreciate their differences and identify their various potentials and possible limitations;

-conduct content analysis/content analysis using different methodologies (unit based and quality based);

-download, clean, manage and analyze a CSR index (ESG) database,

-experience and improve teamwork skills;

-edit a comprehensive report with appropriate literature sources; and

-express and advocate their positions and ideas in public.

data.name: Genomics Technologies

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description: The course aims at explaining the opportunities that high-throughput technologies give in the analysis of genomes and of transcriptomes, being introduced to the concepts and tools of Precision Medicine. The course will focus on DNA microarrays, Next Generation Sequencing technologies and Next-Next Generation Sequencing technologies, their problems and perspectives. At the end of this course students will be able to: • Distinguish between high-throughput and high-multiplexity technologies. • List different high-throughput technologies. • Relate low-throughput techniques based on nucleic acids hybridization. • Describe a microarray experiment. • List different uses of microarrays: SNP-typing, CGH-arrays, gene expression analysis. • Relate the history of microarray techniques. • Illustrate fabrication methods of spotted, Agilent and Affymetrix, bead-based microarrays. • Discuss differences between Agilent and Affymetrix microarrays. • Discuss experimental design for microarray experiments. • Explain the use of biological replicates and technical replicates. • List and explain different steps in data analysis for microarray experiments. • Explain the need for normalization and the possible strategies for normalization of microarray data. • Illustrate the difference between ratios and fold changes in the identification of differentially expressed genes. • Perform cluster analysis of gene expression data. • Describe what a pathway analysis is and perform it. • Use biological databases and gene ontology in data analysis. • Illustrate the Sanger sequencing method and its direct evolution, the automated DNA sequencing. • Distinguish between Sanger sequencing, Next Generation Sequencing (NGS) and Next-Next Generation Sequencing (NNGS). • Schematise the phases of NGS. • List different applications of NGS and different genome enrichment methods. • Illustrate the workflow of template preparation for NGS. • Describe emulsion PCR methods for library preparation. • Illustrate Quality Control and Library Preparation for NGS. • Illustrate different NGS techniques, their features (read length, run time and maximum throughput) and discuss their advantages and disadvantages: the Roche 454 Pyrosequencing, the SOLiD, the IonProton, the Illumina NGS. • Describe how to multiplex and illustrate paired-end sequencing in Illumina NGS. • Illustrate NNGS techniques: the PacBio, the Helicos, the Oxford Nanopore. • Illustrate NGS applications in Metagenomics. • Illustrate NGS applications in Medical Genomics. • Illustrate Singe Cell Sequencing and Spatial Transcriptomics techniques. Bioinformatics approaches to retrieve biological information from publicly available RNA-seq data. Performing RNA-seq data analyses by applying specific tools through the terminal as well as through R packages in R Studio. Analyzing NGS data to assess quality in order to properly tune accurate reads mapping and from there calculate differentially expressed genes (DEGs), which can be used as input for several activities: clustering analyses, GO and pathways' identification, Gene Set Enrichment analysis (GSEA), to name a few.

Applied Immunology

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description:
The aim of the course is fourfold. First, it provides  students with the understanding of basic immunology including, innate immune responses and adaptive immunity. Second, the course offers the students an overview on the mechanisms of vaccine-induced immune responses, on how vaccines are designed and formulated, and  on the economics of vaccination. Moreover, details on the main vaccines currently in use for the prophylaxis of the main human diseases are provided. Third, the course covers the topics of cancer immunotherapy, and offers an understanding of the main immunotherapeutic strategies current in use to fight cancers. the role of microbiome in cancer development is also covered. Finally, the course allows the students to understand the mechanisms of allergy and autoimmune diseases 
At the end of this course, students will be able to:
a) Describe the difference between the different types of immune responses
b) Understand how vaccine are designed 
c) Understand the mechanisms of action of vaccines
d) Understand the role of the immune system in cancer and how our immune system can be exploited to develop anti-cancer therapies.
e) Describe the mechanisms of allergy and autoimmunity 
f) Describe the current strategies to fight allergy and autoimmunity

Finanza aziendale 2
data.description:
1. Learning objectives and course contents.
The purpose of the course is to provide students with an advanced understanding of the corporate investment and financing decisions. 
The first part focuses on the assessment of investments with leverage and enterprise value, with various approaches (the weighted average cost of capital method, the adjusted present value method and the flow-to-equity discounted cash flow method, multiples approach). The second part introduces the payout policy, in perfect market and in the presence of frictions. The third part analyses the typical sources of capital for corporation, in term of both equity and debt (bonds, leasing), with a medium/ long-term perspective. The fourth part introduces mergers and acquisition. The fifth part concerns finance for SMEs

2. Expected learning outcomes.

1. to describe the methods of evaluation of investment with leverage and to list the steps in computing each (define the input variables and describe how to compute their value; illustrate how the variables are used in the model; define and understand the output of the model);2. to understand and discuss the critical issues of each methods of evaluation (given the specific investment’s risk and leverage assumptions) and to identify the most suitable method of evaluation; to apply the methods of evaluation to examples / real cases;
3. to discuss the effect of dividend payment or share repurchase in a perfect capital market; to discuss the effect of taxes on dividend policy; to describe and discuss the effect of agency costs and information asymmetry on payout policy; 4. to describe the ways in which a private company can raise outside capital; to describe the bond indenture; to compare and discuss callable and convertible bonds with straight debt; 5. to identify the sources of synergies that are commonly cited as justification given for an acquisition; to discuss the premium; to calculate and discuss the maximum exchange ratio;6. to identify why and how SMEs are different from large companies in the financial decisions and to adapt to them the financing approaches.

data.description:
Aim of the course is to provide students with methods and tools for the proper design and realization of different building typologies with high human inner comfort conditions, though respecting/using the surrounding environment. Issues regarding building sustainability, indoor comfort conditions, design of passive solar elements for warming and cooling are presented and discussed, in the frame of emerging Edilizia 4.0 iniziative, in a perspective of circularity and resilience of interventions.

After the course, the student will be able to: know an understand the the main theoretical concepts of indoor comfort and passive energy issues in buildings; design a housing or office building with attention to holistic indoor comfort conditions; define bioclimatic strategies for warming and cooling of the indoor environment; design, calculate and solve issues concerned with passive elements in buildings.

data.name: Political Theory
data.description:
On Leadership

The course aims to provide students with a general knowledge of different leadership styles, teamwork theories and practices, and group thinking methods by investigating case studies. 

The first part of the course will be devoted to examining contemporary theories on leadership. Students will lead seminars, discussions, and make oral presentations on specific case studies during the second part. Thus, by the end of the course, students should deliver an oral presentation on leadership and write a paper (2500/3000 words). They would demonstrate to be able to: 1) identify and analyze the different approaches on leadership; 2) examine, describe, and compare how different approaches work to solve a particular issue. Students are expected to actively discuss other students' presentations.

Adopting a student-centred approach, the course will provide opportunities for student engagement, with a view to successfully achieving its learning objectives.
The course will be structured to ensure meaningful and accessible learning for all students, and the assessment will be consistent with the teaching method.
The course will adopt diversified web-based tools to ensure that every student is able to follow the instructor, participate actively in open debates, ask specific and general questions of interest, test his/her own understanding during the course.

Students interested in attending the course and in taking the exam must enroll on the online Moodle page of the course as soon as possible.

The course aims to provide the student with an overview of the experimental techniques typically employed in the scientific research in condensed matter physics. The course will focus on the study and learning through laboratory sessions of the most common optical spectroscopy techniques, useful for the analysis of the structural and dynamic properties of a wide class of materials.

At the end of the course the student:

1) Will have acquired a thorough understanding of the processes of radiation-matter interaction, at the base of the experimental techniques used.

2) Will be able to independently perform a series of optical spectroscopy experiments, from sample preparation to experimental measurement.

3) Will have deepened the methods of analysis of experimental data and the comparison between the data obtained and some phenomenological models that describe the behavior of the studied samples.

data.name: Computability and computational complexity
data.description:
The course sets the theoretical bases for being able to discuss two fundamental properties of computational problems.
Given a problem, we will be concerned about its computability:
- Is there a method to solve the problem?
- Can we describe this method in an unequivocal way?
- Is there a universal "language" for such task?
When a problem is found out to be solvable, we can wonder how efficiently it can be done.
- What are the meaningful criteria to express how hard a problem is?
- Is there a meaningful way to classify problems with respect to their hardness?
- Does this classification tell us something about the limits of our capability to solve problems?

At the end of the course, the students will be able to:
- Describe problems and problem instances in a formally precise way.
- Describe the solution of simple problems in terms of a universal computational model (the Turing Machine).
- Prove that a specific problem (Turing's halting problem) is not computable.
- Apply the formal notion of reduction in order to extend properties of known problems to new ones.
- Identify quantitative criteria to describe the complexity of an algorithm with respect to instance size.
- Describe the main time and space complexity classes, and their inclusion relationships.
- Define what it means for a problem to be complete for a class.
- Prove that a specific problem (SATISFIABILITY) is complete in the NP class (Cook's Theorem).
-Use reductions for proving completeness of other problems in the class NP.
- Discuss the P vs. NP problem and its main implications on various branches of computer science.
- Identify upperbounds to problems via Turing Machines with oracles.

data.name: Meteorologia per la viticoltura
data.description:
The scope of the course is to introduce the students to the study of vegetation-atmosphere interactions, focusing on the physical processes influencing the life of plants and determining the productivity of agricultural crops. In particular, the theoretical concepts will be applied to vineayard management. During the course, there will be practical sessions where the students will have the opportunity to become familiar with instruments for monitoring main meteorological variables. They will learn how to set up an agrometeorological station and use the collected data to acquire useful information for crop management, in order to increase agriculture precision and sustainability.

At the end of the course, the student will: understand the physical processes regulating mass and energy exchanges between vegetation and the atmosphere; know the sensors for monitoring of main meteorological variables; be able to analyze and interpret meteorological data in order to obtain information to support crop management, in particular for vineyards.

data.name: Solid state physics II
data.description:
Electrons and nuclei determine the nature of matter (atoms, molecules, solids, devices) while electron excitations determine the wide field of electrical, optical and magnetic properties of materials.
The course deals with electronic structure of solids, electron transport phenomena, magnetism and superconductivity. The aim is to give the basics about theoretical models and experiments in topics that are the foundation of the developing applied and fundamental fields of solid state.
At the end of the course, students are expected to be able to discuss the basics of the above contents and gained the capability to go through advanced monographs and novel scientific papers about solid state physics (1Dimensional, 2D, 3D bulks, surfaces), physical-chemistry, nanoscience and material science.

data.name: Cultura e letteratura inglese
data.description: The course, entitled “Victorian Detectives in Literary and Popular Imagination”, aims to provide students with the critical tools that will enable them to study Victorian culture through the lens of detective fiction, a genre that is still thriving in contemporary popular culture. The course will place two novels (The Moonstone by Wilkie Collins and A Study in Scarlet by Arthur Conan Doyle) in the context of important historical, artistic, ideological and epistemic Victorian issues. At the end of the course, students will be expected to be able to recognize and analyze the stylistic and thematic peculiarities of the literary texts and to put them in relation with Victorian culture. At the same time, students will be encouraged to develop critical thinking when considering the afterlives of Victorian detective fiction in contemporary popular culture.

data.description: The course aims at giving the students an overview of the international norms on the use of force, focusing on the problems related to their application. After a brief introductory part on the norms on the use of force in international relations (jus ad bellum), the main object of the course will be the legal regulation of the choice of the means and methods of warfare as well as the norms protecting persons and objects in international and non-international armed conflicts (international humanitarian law - jus in bello).

data.name: Quantitative research methods

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
What accounts for citizens’ interest in politics? Does an economic crisis affect citizens’ attitudes towards democratic systems? What are the factors associated with changes in attitudes towards income redistribution? Do policy programs improve the conditions of targeted groups? Are the levels of development related to cross-country differences in religious service attendance?
This course will provide students with concepts and empirical tools to address these and other questions in the field of social science using quantitative data. The course starts from illustrating general concepts of quantitative research related to research design and the problems that one can encounter in the research process, and then moves to fundamental issues related to statistical inference and the data modeling. These aspects include probability, statistical tests, linear and non-linear regression models, data visualization, and more advanced topics. At the end of the course students will be able to address independently research questions in the field of social science using quantitative data and critically assess academic and non-academic publications including quantitative information. 
Lab sessions will be provided to students in which they will learn the how to put in practice what learned in the course using a statistical software and publicly available data.
