data.name: Quantum mechanics

department.unitName: Department of Cellular, Computational and Integrative Biology - CIBIO

data.description:
This module course aims to provide students with the basic competencies in quantum mechanics physics. 

At the end of the first module, students are expected to:

1) understand the main difference between the physical phenomenology at the macroscopic level ( governed by the laws of classical physics) and the phenomenology at the microscopic level, where quantum mechanical behavior takes place

2) understand the concept of particle-wave duality, and describe and critically analyze the main experiments which provide evidence of quantum uncertainty, wave-like properties of matter, and energy or magnetic moment quantization. 

3) understand the mathematical and physical significance of the wave-function and the related time-dependent and stationary Schrodinger equation.

4) Solve elementary problems in quantum mechanics (particle in an infinite square well, particle in a finite square potential, ground state of the harmonic oscillator)

5) understand and use the basic mathematical tools involved in physical modeling, including:

- Multi-dimensional calculus: partial derivatives, multi-dimensional integral, differential operators, partial differential equations. 

- Basic linear algebra, including matrix diagonalization, eigenvalues, and eigenvectors, commutation relationships. 

- Notion of Hilbert space and its representation theory

- Notion of Dirac-delta function

data.name: Circular economy for materials processing
data.description:
CEMP is a project-based introductory course to the circular economy. The goals and the learning outcomes of the course are to provide overview knowledge on circular economy for materials processing through lecturing (first part of the course) and in-depth knowledge and skills by the project work (second part of the course).

After the course the students would be able to understand:

1. Basic concepts of circular economy, knowledge on materials flow (from mining, processing, manufacturing until end-of-life recycling and re-usage), issues and drivers for changes.

2. Recognize impacts (environmental, economic and social) of the current practice of materials processing from a sustainability aspect.

3. Create new business opportunities to re-enter materials into circular economy.

4. Apply processing technologies to accelerate the implementation in business creation.

In particular, it introduces the most important risk measures, such as Value at Risk and Expected Shortfall for market risk, credit scoring and capital market models for credit risk and operational risk measurement.

data.name: Bio-Inspired Artificial Intelligence

department.unitName: Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science

data.description:
The goal of this course is to study two of the main paradigms of Bio-Inspired Artificial Intelligence, namely: Evolutionary Computation, inspired by evolutionary biology, and Swarm Intelligence, inspired by collective behaviors of social animals. First, the main theories and algorithms will be introduced. Then, it will be shown how these techniques can be applied, for instance, for solving complex optimization problems, training data-driven models, generating new contents (video-games, websites, art), finding bugs in software, automatically synthesizing or fixing computer programs, or finding innovative solutions in robotics, logistics, and engineering. Finally, it will be shown how these techniques can help the understanding of biological systems, in order to close the loop between biology and AI.

At the end of this course, students will be familiar with the most important Evolutionary Computation and Swarm Intelligence techniques, and will be able to apply them to different contexts in industry, research, or even entertainment. They will also know the fundamentals for developing new algorithms and adapt them to new problems.

data.name: Anatomia umana I
data.description: The aim of this course is to enable students to describe the structure of the human body from the macroscopic, microscopic, and ultrastructural point of view as well as the relationship between structure and function. The expected outcome is the ability to describe in a 3D context the morphology of the human with special refence to structures of the locomotor system (bones, muscles, joints), the cardio-vascular system, the spinal nerve system as well as those components of the autonomic nervous system associated with the spinal nerves.

data.name: Web Architectures

department.unitName: Department of Sociology and social research

data.description:
Aim of the course is to give students an understanding of the main issues related to web architectures and with several web technologies. Students will acquire the fundamental concepts, which characterise the web and the use of distributed system for implementing complex web architectures. 
At the end of the course, students will be able to identify and describe the characteristics such technologies. They will be familiar with instruments for building complex and efficient web sites.

data.name: Contemporary History
data.degreeProgram: EUROPEAN AND INTERNATIONAL STUDIES - STUDI EUROPEI E INTERNAZIONALI (LM)

data.name: Patologia, immunologia e genomica
data.description:
General Pathology Module

Main objectives are: 1) the acquisition of conceptual and scientific tools to explain the causes and mechanisms of human diseases and the role of the immune system; 2) the understanding of the molecular mechanisms underlying pathological processes concerning some essential aspects of the functions of cells and tissues and which govern the reaction to tissue damage and their repair. In order to understand the complexity of pathological processes, some manifestations of cell damage and their consequences on the functioning of organs and at the organism level are dealt with in an integrated way. The course deals in detail with all aspects relating to the reactive and reparative processes of cell and tissue damage, namely the acute and chronic inflammatory reaction. Causes, molecular and cellular bases, forms of manifestation, evolution and control mechanisms, pathological consequences are described. The causes of tumors, the molecular mechanisms that regulate the onset, development and formation of metastases, the general consequences of neoplasms are also addressed in general terms.

Expected learning outcomes: acquisition by the student of the knowledge of the scientific terms and of the language used in pathology; ability to integrate knowledge of pathologies at the molecular, cellular and systemic level; knowledge of the main target pathways of therapeutic interventions.

data.name: Principi etici per il design

department.unitName: Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science

data.name: Letteratura spagnola I
Storia delle istituzioni politiche
data.description:
The course aims to bring the student closer to political-constitutional history in the belief that this contributes to make it more aware of being part not only of a family and of a civil and economic society, but also of a historically determined political-institutional system.
Two historical transitions to the constitutional state, namely that of Great Britain and that coinciding with the founding of the United States of America will be presented in the course. It will be taken care to highlight, through a historical-comparative perspective, the unavoidable interconnections between them.
At the end of the course the student will be able to recognize, in relation to the examined historical-political-constitutional events, what kind of form of government (if absolute, constitutional or parliamentary) was established, and the main distinctive features of  the parliamentary institution and of cabinet, of legislative and executive power, etc..

data.name: Ergotecnica edile con Laboratorio progettuale

department.unitName: Department of Civil, Environmental and Mechanical Engineering

data.description:
In order to understand the construction phase activities and site management it's mandatory the awareness about the whole process, starting from feasibility to decommissioning. Scope of the course is establishing theoretical ground (actors, phases, documents,cash flow) and practical ground (planning tools, BIM) about the building process (design process, construction process, facility management, LCA, decommissioning).

Also the course aims to give basic reference for quality management (product and production processes): value analysis, planning tecniques, building and bidding standards.

The teaching follows state of the art methods and knowledge with reference to concept, design, production and evaluation of building elements and systems, with specific attention to the economical, architectural and industry context
